DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies Thursday are as follows:
The Central Daily News:
The United States will push Beijing to explain its missile threat to Taiwan.
The China Times:
The government proposes major changes to personal income tax reporting.
The United Daily News:

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC TIES WITH PARAGUAY REMAIN CLOSE, FM SAYS

TEXT.P: The diplomatic ties between the Republic of China and Paraguay are expected to remain solid after Paraguayan Senator Luis Gonzalez Macchi assumed the presidency on March 28, Foreign Affairs Minister Jason Hu said on Thursday.
Taipei intends to invite Gonzalez, a political heavyweight in Paraguay who is friendly to Taiwan, to visit the island as soon as the political situation in that country settles, Hu noted.

Gonzalez, a key figure in Paraguay's ruling Colorado Party, was originally scheduled to visit Taiwan in February of this year at the invitation of the ROC government. The visit, however, was delayed due to political unrest in Paraguay, Hu said.

The ROC government welcomed Gonzalez's being instated as the leader of Paraguay, which is a diplomatic ally of the Republic of China, Hu said. President Lee Teng-hui, Vice President Lien Chan, Premier Vincent Siew and Minister Hu himself have all sent felicitous telegrams to Gonzalez, he noted.
The ROC Ambassador to Paraguay Liu Tin-tsu went to the Paraguayan Presidential Office on March 28 to congratulate Gonzalez in person.
Gonzalez's predecessor, President Raul Cubas, was impeached after the murder of Vice President Luis Maria Argena on March 23. Cubas handed over the presidency to Gonzalez on March 28.
The change in the country's leadership brought to a halt a weeklong, bloody conflict stemming from the vice president's murder and party infighting.
Huang Kun-hui, secretary general of the ROC Presidential Office, visited Paraguay last year on behalf of President Lee Teng-hui. He extended President Lee's invitation to Gonzalez to visit Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, April 1, or the 15th day of the second month of the Year of the Rabbit according to the lunar calendar. The following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1908: Japan puts into practice a six-year compulsory primary education system.
1924: The Republic of China's Central News Agency is established in Canton by the ruling Kuomintang.
1938: The Emergency National Congress of the Kuomintang in Wuchang elects Chiang Kai-shek as its director-general and decides to organize a People's Political Council and a San-min-chu-i Youth Corps.
1940: The Nationalist government issues a circular to the nation's all levels of governments to call Dr. Sun Yat-sen the "National Father of the Republic of China."
1954: The US Air Force Academy is established in Colorado.
1968: Ma Ssu-tsung, former president of mainland China's "National Music Academy," and his wife arrive in Taipei from the United States. This is their first time to visit Taipei.
1984: Chang Gung Memorial Hospital completes the first human pancreas transplant in Asia.
1984: US soul music singer Marvin Gaye dies on the eve of his 45th birthday after being shot during a violent argument with his father. The singer had threaten to take his own life and had become increasingly unpredictable, largely due to drug addiction.
1989: Namibia gains independence from South Africa.
1991: Martha Graham, US modern dance master, dies at the age of 96.
1995: President Lee Teng-hui starts a four-day visit to the United Arab Emirates and Jordan.
1996: Japan's Mitsubishi Bank and Tokyo Bank merge to become one of the world's largest banks, Tokyo-Mitsubishi Bank.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A wise and good man is easy to serve, but difficult to please. If you go beyond your duty to please him, he will not be pleased. But in his employment of men, he always takes into consideration their capacity. A fool, on the other side, is easy to please, but difficult to serve. If you go beyond your duty to please him, he will be pleased. But in his employment of men, he expects them to be able to do everything."

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC MULLS MORE AID TO MACEDONIA

TEXT.P: The Republic of China is planning a second wave of aid to Macedonia to help the Balkan state cope as refugees continue to pour in from nearby Kosovo, Foreign Affairs Minister Jason Hu said on Thursday.
Taipei sent US$2 million to Macedonia on March 26 to help the country settle Kosovar refugees, Hu said.

The ROC was one of the few countries that sped cash aid to Macedonia for emergency assistance since NATO bombings began last week. Those air strikes have unleashed tides of fleeing refugees into areas bordering Kosovo, Hu noted.
In the second aid package, Hu said, Taiwan may dispatch relief efforts in addition to cash to Macedonia so as to provide extensive assistance to the refugees.
He said it is hoped that personnel from the ROC Red Cross Society or the Tzuchi Compassion Foundation will be seen working in refugee camps in Macedonia soon.

Fielding questions at the Legislative Yuan about Taiwan's aid to Macedonia, Hu said from now until the end of September, Taiwan will accelerate its assistance as well as its presence in Macedonia. The aim is to beef up Taiwan's influence in the Balkan state prior to its presidential election in mid-October.
The ROC efforts in Macedonia is imperative at present, he added, not only because of the refugee issue, but also because the presidential election.

Vasil Tupurkovski, head of Macedonia's reconstruction organization whose Democratic Alternative Party holds the foreign affairs, finance and interior ministries in a coalition government, is a front-runner in the presidential election.
Tupurkovski also spearheaded the campaign to establish formal relations with Taiwan, according to Hu.
Macedonia established formal diplomatic relations with the Republic of China on Jan. 27 of this year, becoming the second European country to do so following the Vatican.

DOC.HEADLINE: IRELAND TO HOST 2003 SPECIAL OLYMPIC GAMES
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 1 (CNA) (By Deborah Kuo) (By Nelson Chung)

TEXT.P: Washington, March 31 (CNA): Special Olympics, Inc. announced Wednesday that Ireland will host the 2003 Special Olympics World Summer Games, the first World Summer Games to be held outside the United States.

Dr. Timothy P. Shriver, president of the Washington-based organization, when making the announcement in Dublin together with Ireland's Prime Minister Bertie Ahern, said the "Holding of the World Summer Games outside of the US is an important step in our movement's effort to globalize and innovate. Ireland is the ideal venue from which to focus the world's attention on the heroics of Special Olympics athletes from around the world."

The World Games Selection Committee noted the tremendous effort made by the Irish bid committee was a major factor in the selection. "The key to a successful World Games experience is true collaboration, which Ireland demonstrated from the start," said Lee Todd, Special Olympics vice president for World Wide Games and Competition.
Dates for the 2003 Games have not been finalized, but they are expected to draw 7,000 athletes from more than 150 countries around the world over nine days in 2003.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA'S IOC DELEGATE VOWS TO KEEP POST

TEXT.P: Despite calls for his resignation, Phil Coles, Australia's IOC representative, is determined to return to the board of the Sydney Organizing Committee of the Olympic Games (SOCOG).

John Coates, president of the Australian Olympic Committee and a friend of the representative, told reporters that he recently spoke with Coles after the latter's return from a meeting in Lausanne, Switzerland where the International Olympic Committee reprimanded him for breaching guidelines.
"My expectation after having spoken to him is that he intends to return to SOCOG ... I don't know if it's realistic or not, but he is entitled to and says he will," Coates said.
Coles' colleagues on the SOCOG board, however, want him to resign after damaging the reputation of the Sydney 2000 Olympic Games due to his involvement in a corruption scandal.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA'S ECONOMY STILL STRONG

TEXT.P: Spurred by strong consumer spending, Australia's economy is showing no signs of slowing down as consumers keep buying to cash in on low interest rates.
Retail sales during February totaled about US$$7.7 billion, slightly less than January's levels. But it was the second strongest sales month on record, economists said.
They said the figure suggested the buoyant consumer sector would underpin another strong economic growth period for the first quarter of 1999.

Along with better than expected building industry figures on Tuesday, and strong demand for imports, most economists believe economic growth in fiscal 1999-2000 will outstrip the government's official forecast of 3.25 percent. In 1998-99, Australia achieved a growth of 4.8 percent in its gross domestic product.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA OFFERS TROOPS FOR UN PEACEKEEPING FORCE IN E. TIMOR

TEXT.P: Australia has offered to provide troops for a UN peacekeeping force in East Timor to prevent violence as the former Portuguese colony undergoes the process of attaining full autonomy or independence.

The offer was made by Foreign Minister Alexander Downer in a speech at the national Press Club in Canberra after resistance leader Xanana Gusmao warned of a possible blood bath in East Timor earlier this week.
Downer told reporters and political analysts that he and a senior UN emissary, Francisco Vendrell, had agreed that a civilian UN presence could be established in East Timor as early as next month.
He said the Australian government hoped peacekeeping troops will not needed, adding, "If that does not eventuate and if the UN makes the call, Australia will respond appropriately."

Downer said a peacekeeping operation would have to have a clear and achievable mandate, adequate probability of success, adequate resources and be of a limited duration and scope with an "exit strategy."

Another consideration is the costs to Australia. These include whether the country's Defense Forces and Federal Police can undertake other tasks such as national defense in addition to ensuring the safety of Australian citizens in East Timor.
Downer noted Australia had on many occasions discussed with the Indonesian government the need to disarm militia groups in East Timor.

Xanana, in a letter to the Australian ambassador to Jakarta on March 27, appealed to Australia to pressure Indonesia and warned that his people's patience was running out as they faced unbearable hardship.
Xanana accused Jakarta of "a systematic policy of terror, threats, and murder of defenseless civilians" in East Timor.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLAND CHINESE SCHOLARS RESIDING IN GERMANY TO VISIT TAIWAN
DOC.DATELINE: Bonn, March 31 (CNA) (By Lilian Lin and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Twelve scholars from mainland China, currently living in Germany, are set to visit Taiwan in mid-April.

The group will comprise professors, research fellows and graduate students at various German universities, as well as journalists and engineers. During their stay in Taiwan, they will visit economic and cultural establishments, and talk with Taiwan academicians.

Their two-week itinerary in Taiwan will include visits to government agencies and organizations, including the Mainland Affairs Council, the Environmental Protection Administration, the Overseas Chinese Affairs Commission, the Council of Labor Affairs and the Central Bank of China.
The group plans to attend a conference in Taipei on China's modernization and the ideas of Dr. Sun Yat-sen, founding father of the Republic of China.

DOC.HEADLINE: DOMESTIC OIL PRICES TO BE RAISED BY 2-TO-3 PERCENT

TEXT.P: Domestic oil prices will be raised by 2 to 3 percent in the near future to reflect rising crude oil prices in the international market, Chinese Petroleum Corp. (CPC) officials said on Thursday.
CPC President Pan Wen-yen said the state-owned company is considering raising retail prices for its products in the coming days to reflect its rising crude oil import costs.
"We have not yet made a final decision on the planned price hike," Pan said, adding that he does not rule out the possibility of making a formal announcement of the upward adjustment next Tuesday.

Pan said the CPC has received notices from Saudi Arabia and Kuwait that they will cut their crude oil supplies to the company. "We have bought crude oil from other countries to make up for reduced supplies from Saudi Arabia and Kuwait. Therefore, there will be no problems with domestic oil supplies.
Nevertheless, Pan said as international crude oil prices are not expected to weaken in the foreseeable future, the CPC must raise its product prices to reflect its increased import costs.
Pan said if the CPC does not adjust its prices now, it may have to raise prices for its oil products by more than 10 percent in the second half of this year.

"We fear that such a large range of price hikes may trigger a dramatic adverse impact on domestic consumer prices. Against this background, we think it will be better to make a modest adjustment right now," he explained.

International crude oil prices have risen significantly since the Organization of Petroleum Export Countries announced in late March that its member states will cut production from April 1 to wipe out a glut on the market.
In anticipation of decreased supplies, crude oil prices have climbed to US$16 a barrel in recent weeks, far higher than the CPC's projected import costs.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC TRUSTS EX-PREMIER WILL NOT HARM ROC INTERESTS ON MAINLAND TRIP

TEXT.P: Former Premier Hao Pei-tsun's upcoming trip to mainland China is a private visit that the government should not prohibit or attempt to monitor, Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairman Su Chi said on Thursday.

Fielding questions at the Legislative Yuan, Su said Hao's mainland visit, scheduled to begin on April 3, does not violate any Republic of China law on visits to mainland China by private citizens or public functionaries.
The council, the top ROC government agency in charge of relations with mainland China, trusts that Hao will "behave himself" and believes that the ROC government need not monitor his visit, Su said.
Su said that he personally has great respect for Hao, who has held a variety of government positions, including that of premier and defense minister.
Under current ROC law, all government officials and employees, including retired ones, are required not to reveal information related to national security or military intelligence, Su noted.
"I believe Mr. Hao will not do anything that would harm or endanger the interests of the government and the people of the Republic of China during his mainland trip," he added.

Hao is expected to arrive in Yencheng, located in the eastern Chinese province of Jiangsu, on Sunday. During the visit he will sweep the tomb of his ancestors in accordance with one of the most important holidays in Chinese culture. A popular figure in his hometown, Hao would be the first retired ROC premier to visit the mainland since the ROC government relocated to Taiwan in 1949.
It has been rumored that Hao will meet with Wang Daohan, mainland China's top negotiator with Taiwan, during his visit.
Democratic Progressive Party Legislator Chuo Jung-tai, during the interpellation session, asked Su to "prevent" Hao from doing anything that would be harmful to Taiwan.
Su responded by saying that the Republic of China is a democratic society and that it is improper for the government to speculate on whether Hao will do anything harmful to ROC interests.
News of Hao's planned trip has provoked heated debate at the Legislative Yuan because of the offices he has held.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING NOT TO SUCCEED IN 'THREE EMPTIES' STRATEGY TOWARD TAIWAN: FM

TEXT.P: Mainland China's "three empties" strategy for completely isolating the Republic of China will not succeed by the end of the century, Minister of Foreign Affairs Jason Hu said on Thursday.
Hu made the remarks when he was fielding questions by Legislator Hsu Tien-tsai at the Legislative Yuan about whether Beijing could successfully isolate Taiwan with its "three empties" strategy.

The strategy calls for Beijing to lure away all the ROC's diplomatic allies by the turn of the century, to block Taiwan from joining any international organizations or taking part in the activities of those organizations and to take away all the bargaining chips Taiwan has used to seek a footing equal to Beijing's.

As to how to deal with Beijing's efforts to squeeze Taiwan, Hu said the first step will be to solidify diplomatic relations with allies by paying greater attention to cooperative projects, engaging in more high-level exchanges and establishing more person-to-person connections with government officials in countries that have relations with the Republic of China.
There have been reports of shaky relations with some allies, Hu said, but he added that no such reports have been received during the past eight months.
Hu stressed that pressure from the mainland will not lessen and that the ministry's diplomatic missions overseas have to mobilize so that Beijing feels pressure in every foothold.

The ministry has in place a system to re-evaluate every three months the stability of relations with ROC allies, Hu said, adding that the system has worked well in the past. The ROC's relations with two-thirds of the 28 nations that maintain diplomatic relations with the Republic of China are firm and solid, he said.

The ministry's annual budget for foreign aid projects currently totals US$200 million, though emergency relief, such as that provided to several Central American countries after they were devastated by Hurricane Mitch last year, does not come out of that budget but from other sources, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC CHIEF MUM ON REPORTS FORMER MAYOR PASSED MESSAGE TO BEIJING

TEXT.P: Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairman Su Chi said Thursday that he knew nothing about, nor was he in a position to comment on, reports that former Taipei Mayor Chen Shui-bian had sent a message through a Singaporean leader to Beijing.

It has been reported that Chen asked former Singaporean Prime Minister Lee Kuan Yew to deliver a message to mainland Chinese authorities regarding the Democratic Progressive Party's (DPP) stance on Taiwan independence.
Reports that Chen had asked Lee to convey a message to Beijing caused concern among members of the Interior Affairs Committee of the Legislature.

As the committee is scheduled to examine the budget for the Cabinet-level MAC under the Executive Yuan on Thursday, Su appeared before the committee to report on matters related to MAC's budget and to answer lawmakers' questions.
Cho Jong-tai, a DPP legislator, called on Su to provide an explanation of the reports about Chen.
In response Su said that as far as he knew, the Presidential Office had denied allegations that Chen had asked Lee to pass along a message.

A local newspaper cited a senior official in the Presidential Office as saying that Chen had visited Singapore four times during his four years as Taipei mayor. The official was quoted as saying that in addition to discussing cross-strait relations during his visits to Singapore, Chen also asked Lee to pass on a message to Beijing that the DPP would not likely declare independence.

Cho called on Su to explicitly deny the allegations on Chen's behalf, but Su said he was in no position to do so, especially since Chen is now a private citizen, not a public official. To speak on matters regarding Chen would be the same as interfering into the affairs of any man off the street, Su said.

When Cho chided Su for his response, asking the chairman to take the matter more seriously, Su said that while he attaches much importance to issues of national security, he considers human rights important as well.

DOC.HEADLINE: VICE FOREIGN MINISTER RETURNS FROM AFRICAN TOUR

TEXT.P: Vice Foreign Affairs Minister Lee Ta-wei returned to Taipei on Thursday after concluding a two-week fact-finding visit to several African countries.

Lee, the major purpose of whose tour was to preside over a working meeting in Swaziland with ROC diplomatic personnel stationed in Africa, described the results of his trip as "satisfactory" because he was also able to meet ranking officials of Swaziland and Malawi, two of the Republic of China's diplomatic partners in southern Africa.
In addition to those two countries, the ROC maintains diplomatic ties with the African nations of Gambia, Senegal, Burkina Faso, San Tome and Chad as well.

Lee also traveled to South Africa, which switched its diplomatic ties from Taipei to Beijing on Jan. 1, 1998, to gain a first-hand understanding of developments in that country since then. The vice foreign minister also visited Malawi, where an ROC-funded hospital is slated to open by the end of this year and a presidential election will take place later this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR UP

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar posted a modest gain against the greenback in Taipei on Thursday, rising NT$0.002 to close at 33.123.
The local currency opened at 33.135 and was traded between 33.125 and 33.145.
The interbank US dollar reached US$235 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: DISSIDENTS REGRET DEATHS IN TIANANMEN MASSACRE

TEXT.P: Exiled mainland Chinese dissidents Wang Dan and Wuer Kaixi on Thursday expressed deep regret at the many students and democracy activists killed in the 1989 Tienanmen Square massacre prompted by the pro-democracy movement of which they were both leaders.
Wang arrived in the central Taiwan city of Taichung a day earlier to pay a visit on Wuer Kaixi, his ally in the June 4 student campaign, who now lives in the city.
The two men had not seen each other for nearly 10 years, ever since they split up to escape arrest following the bloody crackdown in Beijing's Tiananmen Square in 1989.

The two one-time comrades had an all-night chat at Wuer's residence, where they rehashed the June 4 bloodshed, Wang said later, adding that they both became so excited, they were unable to stop expressing their feelings over the painful memories.
He and Wuer also called Ding Zhiling in Beijing, the representative of family members of the victims of the massacre, to apologize for their role as "promoters of a battle," Wang told reporters.
Wang has made similar apologies on several public occasions since arriving in Taiwan on March 27 for a weeklong visit.
After escaping from mainland China, Wuer lived in the United States before marrying a woman from Taiwan and settling in Taichung, where he hosts a nationwide radio show.
Wang was a guest on the show, where he fielded telephone calls from listeners and revealed his innermost feelings about the time he spent in a mainland jail.

Wang was jailed in July, 1989 for his part in the pro-democracy demonstrations in Beijing, and was released in February 1993. He was arrested again in October 1996, and sentenced to 11 more years of imprisonment before being released on medical parole in April 1998.

Asked about his plans for the future, Wang, who is currently studying at Harvard University for a masters degree in history, said he intends to study for a doctorate after finishing his current studies, and then, if permitted by Beijing, will return to mainland China "to do what he should do." Failing that, he said, he plans to persuade another doctoral degree before pursuing a career, possibly in journalism.
Asked whether he would consider living in Taiwan, Wang told his audience in a humorous tone that if he finds a Taiwanese girlfriend, like Wuer did, he may think it over.

Following the radio interview, Wang headed to Tunghai University to deliver a speech titled "The Journey of Wang Dan's Heart." He is scheduled to leave Taiwan on Sunday for his home in the United States.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN IS AGING

TEXT.P: Taiwan's population is graying fast and more than half of its social security payments now go to elderly people, the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) reported on Thursday.
According to DGBAS tallies, Taiwan had 1.81 million of elderly people at the end of last year, accounting for 8.2 percent of its total population.

Elderly people refer to those who are aged over 65. According to the United Nations definition, a country will be defined as a "graying society" when its elderly people make up 7 percent of its total population.

Taiwan became an aging society in 1993 when its elderly people accounted for 7.1 percent of its total population for the first time. The ratio has since risen steadily and reached a new high of 8.2 percent in 1998. The average age of all Taiwan residents reached 31.2 last year, also higher than the UN standard for an aging society.
DGBAS tallies showed that Taiwan had a population of 21.93 million at the end of 1998, up 8.5 percent from 1997. The average life span of Taiwan people was 74.6 years, ranking 21st in the world.
With the number of elderly people increasing, Taiwan's total social security expenditure amounted to NT$744.9 billion last year, accounting for 8.8 percent of its gross national product (GNP).
According to DGBAS tallies, 51 percent or NT$380.1 billion of total social security expenditures were spent on various pension payments and health insurance programs for elderly people.

DOC.HEADLINE: `ANGEL BANK' OPENS IN TAIPEI TO ENCOURAGE VOLUNTARY SERVICE

TEXT.P: An unprecedented manpower resources organization, dubbed the "Angel Bank," opened in Taipei on Thursday to encourage voluntary service to care for the island's elderly citizens.
"The Angel Bank is designed to reward volunteers and promote voluntary service in local society," said Chen Li-hua, a section chief with the Taipei City Government's Bureau of Health.
Chen, who initiated the project, said similar manpower organizations have been operating successfully in many advanced countries for many years.

"We hope the opening of the Angel Bank will encourage more people to volunteer their time to provide care for elderly people who need assistance in their daily lives," Chen said, adding that at present, many local volunteers are only willing to work in hospital out-patient departments.

From now on, Chen said, volunteers can "deposit" the time they have contributed to voluntary service in the Angel Bank. "When a volunteer has contributed 300 hours, he or she will become eligible to receive similar voluntary service from other volunteers, should it ever become necessary," she explained.
The new bank will allow young people to "deposit" their contributions to ensure that they in turn will be cared for when they grow old, Chen said.

To reduce the bank's risk of "bankruptcy," Chen said only volunteers who have contributed the requisite time will be eligible for return services in the initial stages, although she added that "when the Angel Bank grows stronger, we'll consider allowing family members of qualified volunteers to be eligible for feedback services."
According to Chen, the Angel Bank now has some 70 "seed" members, most of whom are women aged between 20 and 50 years old.

The bank's headquarters is located in the Hsinyi District's health office in Taipei, but Chen said the bank plans to open branches in all of the city's 12 administrative districts. "Each branch office will enlist at least 100 volunteers. All adult citizens interested in volunteering to take care of elderly citizens are welcome to join our workforce," Chen added.

DOC.HEADLINE: BILL INTODUCED IN US SENATE ON BEIJING'S WTO ENTRY

TEXT.P: Two US senators have introduced a bill in the Senate which would prohibit the Clinton administration from supporting Beijing's accession to the World Trade Organization (WTO) unless a provision of law is passed that specifically allows such support.

House minority leader Richard Gephardt (D-MO), together with 32 other congressmen, introduced in the House of Representatives a resolution on March 1 that requires prior congressional approval before the United States supports the admission of mainland China into the WTO, and calls for the withdrawal of the United States from the trade regulatory body if Beijing is allowed in before receiving congressional support.

Then on March 25, senators Charles Grassley (R-IA) and Kent Conrad (D-ND) introduced a bill to clarify the requirements for the mainland's WTO accession. Their bill noted that Beijing's entry "shall be treated as an action that would substantially affect the rights or obligations of the United States under the WTO agreement."

The bill stipulates that the US Trade Representative shall consult with the Senate Committee on Finance and the House Ways and Means Committee at least 60 days before the WTO Ministerial Conference or General Council takes a vote for the accession of mainland China into the WTO.

Notwithstanding any other provision of the law, the bill continues, the United States "may not support the admission of the mainland as a member of the WTO unless a provision of law is passed by both Houses of Congress that specifically allows the United States to support such admission."

DOC.HEADLINE: EX-TAIWAN GOVERNOR TO OPEN PRIVATE OFFICE

TEXT.P: Former Taiwan Provincial Governor James Soong will open a private office in Taipei on Friday designed to be a center to serve the public and marshal political support for him.
The office will be managed by Soong's confidant Tang Chi-min, former director of the Social Affairs Department under the Taiwan Provincial Government.
An inauguration ceremony is slated for Friday, during which Soong will personally hang his office nameplate to signify its formal opening.
Meanwhile, Soong, whose four-year term as governor expired last December, continued his "Taiwan walkabout" in Taoyuan County to "hear the voice of the grassroots."

Several opinion polls early this year named him as a favorite candidate for the 2000 presidential election, although his falling out with the ruling Kuomintang's leaders has cast doubt on whether he will be put on the party's ticket for the elections.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSSIE CONTAINER PORT HANDLING RATE FALLS SHORT OF REFORM TARGET

TEXT.P: One year after hard-fought reform, Australia's handling of containerized cargo at five major ports is falling short of the government's target, according to figures released by the Department of Transport on Thursday.

The reform of the waterfront industry was initiated by Workplace Relations Minister Peter Reith, who set the handling of a 20-foot container at 25 20-foot equipment units (TEUs) per hour after Patrick Stevedores, the second largest stevedoring firm in Australia, started the reform process by substantially cutting its workforce in order to raise productivity.
Patrick's 1998 efforts improved productivity by increasing the containerized cargo handled from 18.8 TEUs at the Melbourne Port in Victoria in December 1997 to 21.5 TEUs in the same 1998 period.
Also registering slight improvements were Adelaide Port in South Australia and Fremantle Port in West Australia.

Adelaide registered a rise in its handling of containerized cargo to 23.2 TUEs in December 1998 from 21.4 TEUs during the same period in 1977 while Fremantle handled 20.7 TEUs, up from 18.9 TEUs during the same period.
Handling of containerized cargo at the Brisbane Port remained unchanged at 16.8 TEUs.
Sydney Port turned in the worst performance. Instead of improving its rate of handling, it registered a decline of 15.7 TEUs in December 1998, down from 18.4 TEUs a year ago.

Compared with container ports in Taiwan, South Korea, Hong Kong, Singapore and Japan, Australia's major ports lagged behind in terms of productivity, as the Asian ports averaged between 28 TEUs and 35 TEUs per hour, shipping industry experts said.

Federal Transport Minister John Anderson blamed the Maritime Union of Australia (MUA) for the poor performance in Sydney, saying the figures were a "stark illustration of the damage being caused by the refusal of sections of the MUA to embrace waterfront reform."

Parrick's chief executive, Chris Corrigan, claimed recently that his firm was achieving an average crane rate at or near the benchmark -- "a full 25 percent higher than last year with a greatly reduced number of employees."

But assistant secretary of the Australian Council of Trade Unions, Australia's largest trade organization, Greg Combet said that if the government was claiming "a great victory" on the waterfront when the national crane rate had fallen, "then good luck, Peter Reith."
He said it was "absolute rubbish" to suggest higher crane rates represented a defeat for the union.

DOC.HEADLINE: CORPORATE EARNINGS IN SINGAPORE PLUNGE 90 PERCENT IN 1998

TEXT.P: The total earnings of the 193 companies that filed 1998 full-year results dived nearly 90 percent to S$507.9 million (about US$298 million) in 1998 -- a much more drastic fall than the 48 percent plunge sustained by 106 companies in Singapore's last recession in 1985.
The companies' earnings were down 75 percent to about S$800 million in the first half of last year, compared with S$3.2 billion in the same period in 1997.

But they incurred losses of S$292 million in the second half, at which time Singapore's economy slid into recession. The same companies had enjoyed a combined S$1.3 billion in earnings in the second half of 1997.
Despite last year's economic downturn, however, the proportion of companies that reported positive earnings last year was only marginally lower than in 1995.

A total of 130 companies, or 67 percent the total, managed to stay in the black. Of these, 50 companies or 39 percent, actually turned in higher earnings in 1998 compared with 1997, while another six returned to the black.

In comparison, total corporate earnings during the 1985 recession declined by 48 percent to S$483.1 million from the previous year's S$925.1 million. Some 68 percent of the 106 companies reported positive earnings, with a quarter managing to better their year-on-year profits.

A back-of-the-envelope calculation shows that, on average, earnings per company were about S$2.6 million last year, about half of the S$4.6 average earned by companies in 1985, when the economy contracted during the second half and shrank 1.6 percent for the whole year.

Analysts attribute last year's sharp plunge in total earnings to companies taking the opportunity to clean house by making huge provisions. For example, Singapore's five local banking groups made provisions totaling some S$3.2 billion, while three of the four big property companies -- City Developments, DBS Land, Singapore Land and Keppel Land -- wrote down another S$3.1 billion in total.
While the exact figures for 1985 are hard to come by, some analysts reckon that last year's figures represent a five-fold increase in provisions compared to 1985.
Some market analysts also blame rising costs for the lower earnings-per-company figure.

DOC.HEADLINE: CIVIC ORGANIZATIONS ALLOWED TO USE `TAIWAN' IN NAMES

TEXT.P: Civic organizations will be allowed to use "Taiwan" and "Taiwanese" in their names starting April 1, as old regulations that effectively require the use of "China" and "Chinese" were ruled unconstitutional on Thursday by the Council of Grand Justices of the Judicial Yuan.

The council's ruling came at the request of the Chinese Society of Comparative Law (CSCL), which had argued that the regulations, set by the Ministry of Interior, contravened Article 14 of the Republic of China Constitution.

That article states that all people may freely form civic organizations or groups. MOI regulations, however, mandate that all such societies and groups must be named after the administrative district in which the society or group plans to set up.
This regulation effectively bars groups from using "Taiwan" or "Taiwanese" in their names, as Taiwan is regarded as falling within the Republic of China.
The council ruled that the names used by the groups should be determined exclusively by group members and should not be restricted by MOI regulations.
The MOI should revise the regulations to ensure they are constitutional before attempting to re-apply them, the justices advised.
Meanwhile, the CSCL has formally changed its name to the Taiwan Law Society.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA OFFERS HUMANITARIAN AID TO ETHNIC ALBANIANS IN KOSOVO

TEXT.P: The Australian government will provide immediate assistance of A$2 million (US$1.27 million) to relief agencies dealing with the humanitarian crisis in Kosovo.

In a statement faxed to CNA on Thursday, Foreign Minister Alexander Downer said that around 500,000 ethnic Albanians -- a quarter of Kosovo's population -- have fled their homes, including some 100,000 in the past few days alone.

He said that there have been reports of massacres of Kosovar Albanians and of men being led away from their families, and there have also been reports that Serb paramilitary units have been pillaging and burning Albanian shops in the provincial capital of Pristina.
"I am sure all Australians are as appalled as I am by these events," he said.

He said the money will be given to humanitarian organizations working in the region, including the UN High Commission for Refugees, CARE Australia, the Australian Red Cross, and World Vision Australia.
"This assistance will be targeted at meeting the immediate relief needs of refugees and displaced persons fleeing attacks upon them and their communities," he added.
Australia is a strong supporter of the US-led NATO bombings on Yugoslavia.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER TAIPEI MAYOR MUM ON PRESIDENTIAL BID
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, April 1 (CNA) (By Mike Chang and David Hsu)

TEXT.P: Former Taipei Mayor Chen Shui-bian said during a visit to Japan on Thursday that the time is not ripe for him to talk about whether he will run for the Republic of China's 2000 presidential election.

The stalwart of Taiwan's main opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) said at a Tokyo news conference that while the DPP of course hopes to win the election, he attaches great importance to the party system and to opinions within his party, and must listen to the views of the island's people on his presidential candidacy before deciding on his course of action.

Describing his visit to Japan as "a journey of consensus-seeking on Asia-Pacific security," Chen said he will use the trip to gauge the feasibility of communicating and cooperating with Japan on the security and stability of the Asia-Pacific region.

Chen, who has twice held the post of chairman of the legislature's national defense committee, said both the ROC and Japan are very important to the Asia-Pacific's regional security, and that the two nations "share each other's joys and sorrows."
He stressed that national security is the foundation for a nation's construction, and added that without security, the economic development of a nation will be adversely affected.

Remarking on Japan's problems regarding North Korean missile tests and intrusion of North Korean spy ships over the past year, Chen said he sympathized, because Taiwan faces similar military threats from mainland China.

Chen said that the "new middle route" that he recently began espousing is based on national security, and noted that the government and the people should cease their disagreements and reach consensus on the issue of national security.

Commenting on the Theater Missile Defense (TMD) system, a joint defense concept proposed by the United States for the region, Chen said the concept had originally faced severe opposition in Japan, but noted that North Korea's missile test-firing had finally resulted in a consensus.

Chen urged Beijing to take note of the fact that if not for the North Korean missile threat and mainland China's enforcement of its armed forces, the US and Japan would have no need to even propose the idea of a TMD system.
In the same way, Chen said, it is mainland China's deployment of armed forces and missiles along its coastline that have made Taiwan consider the TMD system.

Chen said he supports President Lee Teng-hui's view regarding the TMD system. Lee has said that if mainland China renounces the use of force against Taiwan, it would not be necessary for Taiwan to join such a system.

The charismatic former mayor said that like other advanced nations, the focus of Taiwan's voters in 2000 will be on financial, economic, industrial and commercial issues, while domestic issues will take precedence over foreign issues.

Turning to Japan's refusal to allow Lee to visit Japan and attend an alumni meeting at his Japanese alma mater for fear of offending Beijing, Chen urged Japan to just say no to Beijing in order not to let down the many people who want Lee to visit Japan.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLAND CHINESE HIJACKERS GIVEN LENIENT SENTENCES BY TAIWAN COURT

TEXT.P: A Taiwan court handed down a relatively lenient one-year prison term to a pilot from mainland China who hijacked his Air China Boeing 737 passenger aircraft to Taiwan last October, sources reported on Thursday.
The Taoyuan District Court found Captain Yuan Bin guilty of violating air safety rather than the much more serious charge of air piracy, which can be a capital offense.

In deciding a just sentence, which was lighter than expected, the judge took into consideration the facts that Yuan did not use force to divert the plane and that the safety of passengers aboard were never threatened.

Meanwhile, Yuan's wife Xu Mei, who accompanied him to Taiwan aboard the same flight, received a six-month sentence for violating national security and illegal entry. The sentence was suspended for two years, and Xu was taken directly to a detention center to await repatriation to the mainland, while her husband was taken to jail to serve his term.
Yuan said he diverted the Boeing 737 with 95 passengers and nine crew because he was upset over pay and working conditions at Air China. He denied having any intention to hijack the plane.
The couple diverted the aircraft to Chiang Kai-shek International Airport on October 28 last year and immediately surrendered to police. No one was injured.
In 12 previous hijackings of mainland airliners to Taiwan, Taipei has meted out prison sentences of at least six years.
Beijing has demanded that Taipei return Yuan and all other mainland hijackers imprisoned on Taiwan, saying they should be tried in mainland courts.

DOC.HEADLINE: SINGAPORE TEENAGER HITS ON SOLUTION TO Y2K BUG

TEXT.P: A teenage Singaporean boy has discovered a way to break the Y2K Bug's grip over the computing industry, in a find heralded by the information technology consultancy group Gardner as a "just-in-time" solution to the millennium bug.
Jack Hon Si Yue, 17, said he stumbled onto a code that would lick the Y2K problem while working out the solution to an algebra problem.
The Y2K problem arises from computer chips' inability to distinguish between the years 2000 and 1900, as early programmers dropped the first two digits to save precious memory space.

Corporations are spending millions to ensure that their business systems run smoothly past midnight, December 31, 1999. Singapore Airlines, for example, has spent about S$50 million (US$29 million) on the problem.
Testing for Y2K compliance involves running tests on every chip, and rewriting every line of computer code that uses a two-digit year.
Hon, who grew up around computers, said an interview from his home that he was working on an algebra problem when he had a flash of intuition.
"I was just idling, tired of revising for my O levels," he said. "My mind was going, '1900 is not 2000. How do you get the computer to recognize that?'"
"Can you substitute one digit for the other? Or add a cipher code?" he wondered. "The solution just came: Write a program that can turn 00 to 2000," he said.

Rather than rewriting all lines of problematic code, simply add another layer of code that clears up the problem, he said. It took him more than 30 minutes to work out the necessary equation, and another three hours to test it.

He woke up his father, science lecturer Hon Yuin Tai, 46, and they worked through the night to refine it. The elder Hon sent the formula a few days later to Sam Brittan, Gardner's worldwide Y2K consultant.
Brittan told The Straits Times in an interview from New York, "We had to rework the formula, but after several weeks, and many many tests later, I'm happy to be able to say it's worked beautifully."
"We made it available to our clients, and we're talking to companies on how to customize the solution for them," he said.
Brittain said the boy's solution has a lot of commercial potential, adding that Gardner has teamed up wth the Hons to market it.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT MULLS BICAMERAL SYSTEM FOR LEGISLATIVE REFORM

TEXT.P: The ruling Kuomintang is mulling a phase-by-phase push for reform of the nation's legislature into a bicameral system, KMT Central Committee Secretary-General John Chang said on Thursday.

Chang made the remarks while meeting the press at the office of the KMT's central committee. He did not elaborate, but said that the time for the KMT to push for the amendment to the Constitution will probably fall between May and July.

He said that on April 6, he will invite speakers and deputy speakers of the National Assembly and the Legislative Yuan to meet on the issue, and added that he hopes the participants will form a consensus and plan a concrete direction for the amendment to the Constitution, as well as arrange the timetable for the political reform engineering.
The conclusions reached by those attending the meeting will be sent to the party's task force for the amendment to the Constitution for finalization, Chang said.

The country's opposition parties have long been asking the government to reform the nation's legislative branch. At present, the Legislative Yuan is responsible for the making of laws, while the National Assembly is responsible for amending the Constitution.
The opposition is hoping that the National Assembly will be abolished and its functions transferred to the Legislative Yuan.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC AMBASSADOR TO HAITI REPORTS ON BILATERAL TIES

TEXT.P: Relations between the Republic of China and Haiti have been friendly over the past four decades, but ties have become strained in recent years as a result of moves by mainland China, ROC Ambassador to Haiti Chiou Jong-nan said on Thursday.
Chiou made the remarks while reporting on the latest developments in bilateral relations between the two countries to a legislative committee on foreign affairs.

Although Haiti has only a limited market and the people there lack purchasing power, Beijing set up a trade office in the country's capital of Port au Prince in January 1997 with the aim of sabotaging ROC-Haiti relations under the cover of trade promotion, he said.

Chiou said that because of the mainland's actions, the ROC Embassy has been under greater pressure recently than in the past. He further noted that there are no overseas Chinese students from the Republic of China in Haiti, the embassy's staff is small and an ROC agricultural mission to Haiti has only 11 members.

He reported that Beijing's trade office has been headed by a career diplomat, who has had extensive contacts with Haitian political and economic figures and who has also arranged for a Shanghai Trade Fair.
Mainland China's representative to the United Nations, Qin Huasun, paid a secret visit to Haiti last October, Chiou said.
He said that Haiti will hold parliamentary elections this year and a presidential election in 2000.

To step up contacts with Haiti's trade and commerce industry, and to promote bilateral trade relations, the Ministry of Economic Affairs sent an official to Miami to handle trade exchanges between the Republic of China and Haiti.

While the country has been hampered by an insufficient infrastructure, an unsteady supply of power and water, an unreliable telephone system and problems with social order, the Haitian government has made some improvements, Chiou said, adding that he hopes Taiwan manufacturers will invest in the country.

DOC.HEADLINE: FPG INSTRUCTED TO HANDLE ITS MERCURY-LACED WASTE PROPERLY

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Cabinet-level Environmental Protection Administration (EPA) on Thursday demanded that the Formosa Plastics Group (FPG) take adequate measures to handle its toxic waste without provoking further international disputes.

Fu Shu-chiang, director of the EPA's Solid Waste Control Bureau, instructed FPG, a local petrochemical giant, to find a suitable destination as soon as possible to dispose of its mercury-laden industrial waste, in light of the fact that the US Environmental Protection Agency has withdrawn a permit for the waste to be shipped to California for disposal following strong opposition from local residents.

Stressing that the EPA will closely monitor how the FPG handles the much-disputed toxic waste, Fu claimed that there is no evidence to back foreign wire service reports that the company is planning to transport the nearly 3,000 tons of toxic substances back to Taiwan.
At a news conference, FPG Manager Lee Chih-tsun also brushed aside the reports, saying that FPG is planning to transport the material to a third destination via the southern Taiwan port of Kaohsiung.

The foreign reports sparkled fierce protests from Ting Shan-lung, head of Kaohsiung County's Environmental Protection Bureau, and Liu Lung-chuan, chief of the local Jenwu Township, with the two men accusing FPG of long-term pollution of the environment in Jenwu, where several FPG plants are located. They demanded FPG relocate its plants elsewhere.
The 3,000 tons of mercury-contaminated industrial waste were produced by one of the Jenwu plants.

The toxic waste was shipped to Cambodia last November, where it was dumped at a landfill in a southern village. However, poor handling of the waste by the local contractor, and the discovery by environmental officials that the waste contained a wide range of toxicity levels, panicked local residents and prompted grave concern from the international community.

Forced to find another destination for the waste, FPG reached an agreement with a US waste disposal company which was going to store the waste at a California landfill, until public outcry from the people living in the vicinity of the proposed site drove the US EPA to revoke its previous approval for the shipment.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN, MAINLAND CHINA AGREE TO JOINTLY DISPLAY TAIWAN GOODS

TEXT.P: Taiwan and mainland China have agreed in principle to jointly sponsor displays of Taiwan-made goods in the mainland.

The agreement was reached by Lin Chen-kuo, chairman of the semi-official China External Trade Development Council (CETRA), and his mainland Chinese counterpart, Yu Xiaosong, chairman of the Beijing-based China Council for the Promotion of International Trade (CCPIT).

Lin said the two sides have reached a preliminary decision to jointly sponsor large-scale trade fairs to exhibit high quality Taiwan-made products in large mainland Chinese cities such as Beijing and Shanghai, on a mutually beneficial basis.

CETRA Secretary-General Ricky Kao said that the plan does not go beyond current Republic of China government policy, and added that CETRA will hold the mainland exhibitions under the name of the Taipei World Trade Center.
It is understood that the first Taiwan fine product exhibition may take place in the mainland as early as next spring, although reciprocal activities by CCPIT in Taiwan will take longer to implement.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN OFFICIAL WARNS BEIJING TO `KEEP HANDS OFF' TAIWAN'S ELECTIONS

TEXT.P: Warning Beijing against meddling in Taiwan's 2000 presidential elections, an official in charge of mainland Chinese affairs said on Thursday that the more Beijing tries to influence the elections, the stronger the backlash it will cause among the island's voters.

Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairman Su Chi told the Legislative Yuan that it is difficult to predict how Beijing will try to sway the outcome of the elections, but he expressed the belief that Beijing should have drawn lessons from its previous experience in trying to influence events in Taiwan, and should realize that any such attempts will be doomed to failure.
Su was referring to Beijing's attempts to intimidate local voters in the runup to the island's first popular presidential elections in 1996 by test-firing live missiles into the Taiwan Strait.
President Lee Teng-hui, whose pragmatic diplomacy is often criticized by Beijing as a disguised attempt to seek Taiwan independence, won an overwhelming victory in those elections.

Hardly an election has taken place in Taiwan in recent years without reports that Beijing has tried to interfere with the outcome by supporting specific favored candidates, although nothing has ever been proven.

Meanwhile, in a defense of the MAC's agenda, Su said that Taiwan has made it's mainland China policy clear to the United States, and will keep a close eye on the forthcoming trip to Washington by Beijing's Premier Zhu Rongji.

He said Taiwan is open to political dialogue with Beijing if Beijing insists, although he pointed out that Beijing should realize that such dialogue will lead nowhere, and could even damage the current ties, unless Beijing renounces violence against Taiwan and treats Taiwan as an independent political entity.

As to the idea of an "interim agreement" with Beijing suggested by Washington's Assistant Secretary for East Asian and Pacific Affairs Stanley Roth recently, Su said this is not an official US opinion, although he added that when it comes to agreements, "one is better than none."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies Friday are as follows:
The Central Daily News:
National social groups can use titles bearing the name of 'Taiwan.'
The China Times:
National social groups can use 'Taiwan' in their designation.
The United Daily News:
Russian submarines, parachute units began preparations for countering NATO airstrikes against Yugoslavia.
The Liberty Times:
Corporate financial statements must record profits/debts of their subsidiaries or affiliates.
The Commons Daily:
Taiwan people residing in the United States will protest mainland Premier Zhu Rongji's US visit.
The China Post:
Formosa Plastics Group waste will return after US rejection.
The China News:
Yugoslavian military captures three US servicemen.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, April 2, or the 16th day of the second month of the Year of the Rabbit according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
742: Charlemagne, King of the Franks and founder of the first empire in Western Europe after the fall of Rome, is born. His court at Aix-le-Chapelle becomes the center of the Carolingian Renaissance.
1513: Ponce de Leon, Spanish explorer who sailed with Columbus on his second voyage, explores Florida while looking for the legendary Fountain of Youth.
1792: The first silver dollar of the new US currency is struck in Philadelphia by the Bank of the United States.
1801: British admiral Horatio Nelson, aboard the HMS Elephant, sinks the pro-French Danish fleet off its home port of Copenhagen.
1872: Samuel Finley Breese Morse, American painter and inventor who refined and patented the telegraph and developed the telegraphic code that bears his name, dies at the age of 81.
1902: The first US movie theater is opened in Los Angeles, California.
1912: The provisional Senate of the Republic of China resolves to move the seat of the government to Peking (Beijing).
1914: Sir Alec Guinness, British actor who won an Oscar for "The Bridge on the River Kwai," is born.
1917: Thomas Woodrow Wilson, the 28th president of the United States and the winner of the 1919 Nobel Peace Prize, summons a special session of Congress to declare war upon Germany. At the Paris Peace conference in 1919, he included the establishment of the League of Nations in the Treaty of Versailles.
1922: Soviet leader Nikolai Lenin appoints Joseph Stalin as general secretary of the Communist Party.
1947: The United Nations Security Council votes to appoint the United States as the trustee for Pacific Islands formerly held by the Japanese.
1953: Karl L. Rankin becomes the American ambassador to the Republic of China.
1971: Garuda Indonesia Airlines makes its maiden flight to Taipei.
1974: Georges Pompidou, president of France, dies at the age of 62.
1979: Prime Minister Menachem Begin becomes the first Israeli leader to make an official visit to Egypt.
1981: President Chiang Ching-kuo is reelected chairman of the Kuomintang by acclamation at the 12th National Congress in Taipei.
1982: Argentine military forces invade the British Falklands Islands.
1983: Chang Da-chien, a noted Chinese painter, dies in Taipei at the age of 85.
1991: Soviet coal miners go on strike across the USSR.
1997: US House of Representatives Speaker Newt Gingrich meets with President Lee Teng-hui during his four-hour visit to the ROC. Gingrich praises Taiwan's political progress and economic achievement.
1997: The Statute Governing Relations with Hong Kong and Macau is promulgated by President Lee Teng-hui and will go partially into effect on July 1, 1997 for Hong Kong, and in 1999 for Macau.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A wise man is dignified, but not proud. A fool is proud, but not dignified."

DOC.HEADLINE: FIRST CROSS-STRAIT HIGH SCHOOL STUDENTS SUMMIT SLATED FOR APRIL 9

TEXT.P: A group of students from Taipei's Chienkuo High School are scheduled to leave for Beijing Saturday as they embark on an expedition no Taiwan student has ever made before.

Thirty-one students from Taiwan's most prestigious all-boys high school will meet with a group of students from Beijing's Huiwen Middle School on April 9 in a cross-strait summit meeting of high school students, said Wu Wu-hsiung, principal of Chienkuo High School. Wu will lead the group of students from the high school in their visit to Beijing.

At the summit the mainland Chinese students will talk about how they are preparing for the 21st century, while the students from Taiwan will talk about the international perspective young people should have as they head into the next century, Wu said.

In addition to the summit, the Chienkuo students will visit prestigious Beijing University, Qinghua University and four Beijing high schools to familiarize themselves with the educational environment on the mainland.

The Chienkuo students will give as gifts a set of textbooks currently used by Taiwan high school students to Huiwen Middle School and Jingshan High School, said Wu. As a traditional Chinese middle school, Huiwen has students at both the junior-high- and senior-high-school level.
During their nine-day stay, the students will stay with 30 host families in Beijing, said Huang Hsiao-tao, director of general affairs at Chienkuo High School and the expedition's project leader.

The Chienkuo students had previously requested permission to make the home stay -- aimed at enabling the students to get a real understanding of the daily lives of ordinary people in Beijing -- but they were rejected by mainland authorities, Huang said.

During their landmark visit the students will collect information on the educational systems, teaching environment and campus culture in mainland China, as well as on cross-strait relations. The information they obtain will be the basis of a booklet that will be distributed to students around Taiwan.

Wen Kuei-lin, director of disciplinary affairs at Chienkuo High School and a member of the visiting delegation, said that although the students' activities have been somewhat restricted by authorities in Beijing, they will still be able to do many of the things they would like to do while in Beijing.

The students are eager to find out how mainland students deal with the pressure of entrance examinations, whether there exists there the same "cram culture" that is pervasive in Taiwan, and what type of extracurricular activities may be found on high-school and college campuses in Beijing, Wen said.

Wang Yung-yi, a Chienkuo student who will take part in the expedition, said that what he most wants to know is what students in Beijing -- who are of roughly the same age and who have the same language and culture as Wang, but who live under a different sociological system -- are thinking about.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWANESE GROUPS TO PROTEST ZHU RONGJI'S US VISIT
DOC.DATELINE: New York, April 1 (CNA) (By David Wang and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Taiwanese groups in greater New York will join similar groups in other parts of the United States to protest in front of the White House over the visit of mainland Chinese Premier Zhu Rongji April 8.

Taiwanese groups in greater New York announced on Wednesday that they have formed an action committee to protest against Zhu's visit. They further stated that the sovereignty of Taiwan belongs to all Taiwan residents and that Taiwan's fate will be decided by its people.

In addition to participating in demonstrations in Washington, D.C., the groups will launch a letter-writing campaign to petition US President Bill Clinton not to use the rights of Taiwan people as bargaining chips or to compromise Taiwan's interests in the United States' dealings with mainland China.

The action committee stressed in their statement that no major powers will dictate the fate and future of Taiwan, and it asked the United States to ensure Taiwan's security and to sell necessary defense weapons to Taiwan in accordance with the Taiwan Relations Act.
Lee Cheng-shan, president of a Taiwanese association in greater New York, said that when Zhu visits New York, Taiwanese groups will also stage demonstrations in front of his hotel.
Zhu will visit the United States next week.

DOC.HEADLINE: JAMES SOONG FORMALLY OPENS PRIVATE OFFICE

TEXT.P: Former Taiwan Provincial Governor James Soong formally opened a private office in Taipei Friday morning with an inauguration ceremony attended by more than 100 supporters from around the island.
Soong, dressed in the trademark white jacket he wore as provincial governor, personally hung up a nameplate to signify the opening of the office.

The 30-ping (180-square-foot) office is located at F1, No. 1, Lane 304, Section 1, Chienkuo S. Road. Tang Chi-ming, former director of the Social Affairs Department under the Taiwan Provincial Government, is head of the office.

Speaking at the inauguration ceremony, Soong said the main purpose of establishing the office is to seek out public opinion and formulate social consensus on various issues in hopes of leading the Republic of China into a promising future.

Asked whether he will be the running mate of current Vice President and presidential aspirant Lien Chan in next year's presidential election, Soong said it would not be his willingness but public opinion that would decide the issue.
Noting that many people are concerned about the current situation in Taiwan, Soong said that rather than worry, it is better to do something.

Soong said he will continue to request advice from senior citizens from all walks of life and to think carefully about various issues. He urged the public to join with him in resisting the pressure currently being applied to Taiwan by mainland China.

Soong stepped down as the first directly elected Taiwan provincial governor last December. Shortly afterward he went to the United States for a lengthy vacation. He returned to Taiwan March 1 and resumed his "walkabout" activities.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA TO DEMAND ACCURATE LABELS ON CHINESE MEDICINES

TEXT.P: Australia is expected to demand importers and exporters to accurately label the ingredients of Chinese medicines in a bid to curb the widespread use of endangered species such as tigers, bears and rhinos and some plant species.
Australia bans trading in endangered species, but a long-standing loophole remains in regard to Chinese medicines, which sometimes contain tiger bone, bear bile or rhino horns.

The Australian Parliament introduced an amendment this week to the Wildlife Protection and Regulation of Imports and Exports Act that would result in stiff penalties for companies trading in products that claim to contain ingredients from endangered species, whether or not the products actually do.
Under the proposed amendment, violators would face a fine of up to US$87,000 or 10 years imprisonment.

DOC.HEADLINE: LIBERAL PARTY SAID LOSING SUPPORT OF ASIAN VOTERS

TEXT.P: A key reason for the devastating defeat of Liberal Party candidates in March 27 elections in New South Wales (NSW) was the party's support for "white supremacists" in Canberra, the new deputy leader of the Liberal Party in NSW said.

Barry O'Farrell, the Liberal Party's newly chosen deputy leader in NSW, said efforts by the Federal Liberals, who advocate "our white supremacists in Canberra" may have lost the support of Asian voters for nearly a generation.
The Liberal Party has lost the Asian vote, just as it did for a generation during the Vietnam War in the 1960s and 1970s, he said.

The Liberal Party and its coalition partner, the National Party, suffered a devastating defeat in the recent elections. The Labor Party ended up with a majority in the state's parliament of about 13 seats and its biggest election victory in 20 years.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRIVATE LOAN GROUPS TO COME UNDER GOVERNMENT REGULATION

TEXT.P: Private loan groups, better known as "huei" in mandarin Chinese, will be legally regulated under the Civil Code, starting next year, so that fraud and related financial irregularities can be effectively curbed, sources from the Legislative Yuan reported Friday.

A revision to the law governing the application of the Book of Obligations of the Civil Code passed its third reading at the legislature Friday, paving the way for the eventual implementation of regulations on huei's.

About 15 percent of Taiwan adults are currently participating in such groups, according to a recent poll. In that same poll 19 percent of respondents said they viewed such groups as a risky means of investment, compared with 57 percent who said the stock market was risky.

In each huei, which is formed for a specific period of time, group members make a monthly contribution into an investment pool. Each month that pool is awarded to one member of the group, by having those members who have not been awarded the pot draw lots.
After receiving the pot, group members continue paying into the fund, adding an interest payment for the "loan" they have received to their regular monthly contributions.
The groups are usually small in size and members may include a person's friends, business associates, neighbors or colleagues in a company or organization.

Until now huei's have been entirely unregulated, and there has been no legal recourse for group members who have been cheated by fellow huei members, who sometimes withdraw from the group after winning the pot. In such cases, the huei's are usually suspended or aborted.

Under new regulations, whenever a huei is suspended or aborted, both the head of the huei -- the person who formed the group -- and all group members who have won the pot during previous drawings must continue to make their regular monthly contributions, but group members who have not won no longer need to pay into the pot.

Each month the money that has been contributed is divided among the group members who did not win the pot before the huei was interrupted, and the monthly contributions continue until the end of the huei's original lifespan.

The regulations require huei heads to provide each member with a list of the names, identification numbers, addresses and telephone numbers of all other huei members. Members are given time to verify the information on the list, which all members must sign before the huei can begin to operate. In addition to containing contact information, the list serves as legal proof of the huei's formation.
People cannot simultaneously participate in a huei as its head and as a regular member under the new regulations, and convicted criminals and the mentally disabled are prohibited from forming huei's.
The regulations are expected to go into effect May 5, 2000, and they will not be retroactive, legislative sources said.
The amendment containing the regulations is the first amendment to the law governing the application of the Book of Obligations of the Civil Code since 1930.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT EXPECTS SUCCESSOR WILL CONTINUE HIS POLICIES

TEXT.P: President Lee Teng-hui said on Friday that he expects his successor will continue his policies that have helped maintain cross-Taiwan Strait stability and have established a solid foundation for the nation's further development.

Lee said his commitment to Taiwan voters over the three years since the presidential election to secure cross-strait peace and stability and usher Taiwan into the next century with a firmer foundation, has borne fruit.

Speaking during an audience at the Presidential Office for a group representing Taiwan alumni in Japan, Lee also said that the welfare and well-being of the country's aboriginal people and senior population are two issues currently high on his list of concerns.
He said he hopes that the next president of the Republic of China, expected to be elected in March 2000, will commit himself to efforts to secure a more just and righteous society in Taiwan.

During the audience, Lee also expressed gratitude to members of the Taiwan Alumni in Japan for their valuable support for him during the 1996 presidential election. Lee, who pursued advanced studies in Japan five decades ago, is himself an alumni of a Japanese university.
The 29-member group from Japan was accompanied by Chiao Jen-ho, chairman of the Cabinet-level Overseas Chinese Affairs Commission.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT LEE MEETS CANADIAN MEMBERS OF PARLIAMENT

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui extended a hearty welcome to a delegation of Canadian members of parliament and their wives on Friday, and exchanged opinions over bilateral relations.
Members of the Canada-Taiwan Parliamentary Friendship Group headed by Canadian MP John Maloney, arrived in Taiwan earlier this week.

Lee pointed out that in light of the close relationship between Taiwan and Canada, and their shared concepts regarding the value of democracy and human rights, there is still ample room for bilateral cooperation.
He expressed his hope that exchanges in various aspects can be enhanced so that bilateral relations can be further promoted.

The Canadian delegation for its part said it was impressed by prosperity evident in Taiwan, and expressed appreciation for the hospitality extended to them by the government and people of the island. The delegates said they cherish the friendship of the people in Taiwan, and promised to work toward improved relations between the ROC and Canada.
Members of the delegation include Mr. and Mrs. John Maloney, Jean Augustine, Mr. and Mrs. Gary Pillitteri, Mr. and Mrs. John Cannis, Raymonde Folco, and Lynn Myers.

They were accompanied at the meeting with Lee by Wu Tze-dan, ROC's vice minister of Foreign Affairs, and David Mulroney, director of the Canadian Trade Office in Taipei. Presidential Advisor Ding Mou-shih, and Lin Bih-jaw, deputy secretary-general to the president, were also present.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR STABLE

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar stayed unchanged at 33.123 against the greenback on the Taipei foreign exchange market on Friday.
The local currency opened at 33.145 and was traded between 33.122 and 33.158.
The interbank US dollar trading reached US$360 million during the session.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLAND CHINESE DISSIDENT SAYS TAIWAN TRIP IS TO LEARN ABOUT ISLAND

TEXT.P: Prominent mainland Chinese dissident Wang Dan said on Friday that he has seen the people and things he wanted to see in Taiwan, and has basically accomplished what he wished to accomplish during his visit here.

He said that unlike Wei Jingsheng, another mainland dissident who visited last December, he did not ask to meet with President Lee Teng-hui, because he wanted to travel around the island to learn the truth about the place through contacts with the people and did not consider a study of the government system to be a major part of his trip.

Wang, who arrived here on March 27 for a weeklong visit, said that he recorded his impressions about Taiwan in his journal every day, and added that he intends to publish the memoirs in order to share them with others.

Wang, one of the student leaders of the ill-fated pro-democracy movement in Beijing a decade ago, said that the Taiwan experience proves that dictatorship is not the true way for the East and that the Chinese are entirely capable of pursuing a democratic course.

Wang said that while he is in no position to speak on the issues of Chinese unification or Taiwan independence, he believes that as long as both sides continue to bridge their gaps through exchanges, political problems will disentangle themselves as soon as the time is ripe.

He also said that the 10 years he has spent in a mainland prison have made him lose some of his youthful feelings. He added that while he feels no remorse for having been sent to prison because of his beliefs, he does have some regrets.

Expressing a love of literature, Wang described his 10 years behind bars as the most prolific for his poetry. He said he wrote down "everything," from his feelings about friendship, to his feelings about his parents, in his poems.

Wang made the remarks during an interview by a local radio station. He also had a long-distance telephone conversation with the father of the late Taiwan singer and producer Chang Yu-sheng, who is currently in Beijing to visit relatives there.
Chang, who died two years ago at the age of 31 after a serious car accident, wrote the music for Wang's poem "The Days When I have no cigarettes to smoke."

Wang said that he met with Chang in Beijing, and found him to be a passionate young man. Wang had given him some of the poems he wrote in prison to be tuned into songs, but the work was left unfinished due to Chang's untimely demise.
Wang said he and the senior Chang agreed that they would meet sometime in Taiwan to talk about the singer they both loved.

Because of the tragic death of Chang, Wang said that he also wanted to meet with the singer A Mei, who recorded the song, but was disappointed to find out that the singer is currently traveling overseas.
Wang later called on Academia Sinica, the highest academic organization in Taiwan.
Academia Sinica President Yuan T. Lee met Wang for the first time, and expressed the hope that as an intellectual, Wang will not only focus on academic learning, but will also care about society.
Wang is currently pursuing a masters degree in history at Harvard University.

DOC.HEADLINE: HANDICAPPED STUDENT WINS TWO SEATS AT TAIWAN'S TOP-RATED UNIV.

TEXT.P: Cerebral palsy sufferer Sun Chia-liang of Taipei has never been willing to surrender to his affliction, and has always strived for a glorious and creative life.
On Friday, the fruits of his labor paid off -- in spades.

The severely handicapped young man on Friday won a place in the department of computer engineering at the Taiwan National University (NTU), the nation's most prestigious higher learning institute. Quite an achievement in itself, but even more impressive in light of the fact that he had already been offered a place in the university's Department of Mathematics a few days earlier.

Sun said that he has yet to decide on which department to enroll in, and added that he will take courses in both fields. Sun was speaking during a tour of the NTU's downtown campus aimed at acquainting him with his new environment and allowing him to talk with his future professors on his future course of study.
Sun, who has spent his entire life in a wheelchair, beat the highest possible score of 700 to post the best performance in the Taipei area high school's joint entrance examination in July, 1996.

With a score of 756.6 after an upward adjustment of 20 percent to take account of his handicap, Sun won a place at the elite Chien Kuo Senior High School that most junior high school boys in Taipei only dream of attending.
In his second senior high-school year, Sun took part in the 1998 national university entrance exam, and achieved a score allowing him to enroll in the Hsinchu-based National Tsinghua University.
However, he did not enroll due to the distance between the campus and his home in Taipei, preferring to wait another year and tilt at a school closer to his home.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SEES HOARDING OF RICE WINE

TEXT.P: News that the price of rice wine in Taiwan could increase more than five-fold in the next five years has led to hoarding of the popular cooking wine, according to statistics compiled by the Taiwan Tobacco and Wine Monopoly (TTWM).

In response to complaints from the public about reduced stocks of rice wine in local markets, the TTWM announced on Friday that it will open its distribution centers around the island to the public every afternoon between Tuesday and Friday, but will ration each customer to a maximum of two bottles at a time.

The TTWM statistics show that sales of rice wine totaled 2.19 million cases in March, higher than the 1.6 million cases sold in the same period of last year. However, the recall rate of empty rice wine bottles was much lower, which shows that hoarding has been taking place.

TTWM officials noted that rice wine has long been a cheap and convenient cooking wine in Taiwan. The wine currently sells at NT$24 (US$0.74) a bottle, and the officials noted that as production is running close to capacity, it is difficult to further boost production to deter hoarding.

The huge increase in prices will be part of the cost of Taiwan's entry into the World Trade Organization (WTO), as the government has to scrap the monopoly system and adopting a system of customs tariffs.

If the Legislative Yuan passes a new tobacco and wine tax law in this legislative session, rice wine will be subject to new taxes, and the price will immediately go up to NT$60 (US$1.85) a bottle, and will soar to NT$135 (US$4.15) in five years.
However, the TTWM officials assured the public that if the price does increase greatly, an alternative cooking wine, priced at about NT$32 a bottle, will be offered.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT SHOULD FORM ANTI-CYBER CRIME UNIT: CIB

TEXT.P: The Taiwan government should set up a unit exclusively to crack down on the computer crime which has become ever-more rampant in recent years, sources from the Criminal Investigation Bureau (CIB) said on Friday.
At present, the sources pointed out, the island's only defense against cyber-crime is a computer crime prevention task force under the CIB.

In light of the ever-increasing expertise and professionalism, and the speed at which such crime is growing, the government should set up an exclusive unit with sufficient professional personnel and budget to provide an effective deterrent, the sources said.

The remarks came following an announcement that Japan on Friday set up a cyber police unit, while in the United States, the Federal Bureau of Investigation has set up its Computer Crime Squad to crack down on national and international cyber crime.
