DOC.HEADLINE: YUEN FOONG EXECUTIVE PLEADS QUILTY OF ATTEMPTED THEFT OF TRADE SECRET

TEXT.P: Taipei-based Yuen Foong Paper Co. said on Friday it respects a decision by its adviser Hsu Kai-lo to plead guilty in a US court to attempted theft of technological secrets from a US firm.

According to a CNA report from New York, Hsu admitted in a Philadelphia court on Wednesday that he and his colleague Chou Hua-ping had attempted to steal technological secrets relating to the anti-cancer drug Taxol belonging to New York-based Bristol-Myers Squibb Co.
Responding to the report, Yuen Foong spokeswoman Su Ying-lin said Yuen Foong respects Hsu's decision. "We think Hsu is entitled to make a choice that is in his best interests," Su said.

According to US criminal procedures, a defendant can reach an agreement with prosecution on giving up his or her rights to be questioned by a jury in the court and then discussing with prosecutors a mutually acceptable verdict.

Noting that it was Hsu, not Yuen Foong Co., who has been charged by US prosecution authorities, Su said Yuen Foong will not make any comments before the Philadephia federal court metes out a verdict on its charges against Hsu on July 13.

Su said the company will continue employing Hsu and Chou Hua-ping, both of whom face US charges of attempted theft of Taxol-related technological secrets, commercial bribes and telecommunications fraud. If convicted, Hsu faces a maximum jail term of 60 years and a fine of up to US$2.5 million, while Chou may receive up to 55 years plus a maximum US$1 million in fines. Chou, who is in Taiwan, would be arrested if she sets foot on US soil.

According to the CNA report, US prosecution has dropped its charges against Hsu of committing commercial bribes and telecommunications fraud after Hsu pleaded guilty of attempted theft of Taxol-related technological secrets. In return, Hsu reportedly agreed to provide all correct information related to the case and to testify in court to Yuen Foong's role in the incident.

In late January, the Philadelphia court approved a US prosecutor's request to drop all criminal charges against Chester Ho, a professor of Taiwan's National Chiao Tung University, in connection with the Yuen Foong case to uphold "judicial justice."
Ho and Hsu were arrested by Philadelphia FBI agents upon their arrival in the United States on June 14, 1997 on charges of attempting to steal Taxol-related technological know-how.
Ho has been living in Boston since he was released on US$1 million bail on June 19, 1997. He is now a visiting scholar at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.

The "Taxol" case began in 1995 when an FBI agent, posing as a technology broker, sought to mediate a deal related to Taxol production expertise for Yuen Foong. Between 1995 and mid-1997, Yuen Foong allegedly contacted the undercover FBI agent 135 times by telephone or letter regarding the proposed deal.
Yuen Foong has consistently denied FBI accusations that it attempted to steal trade secrets from the US pharmaceutical company.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC TECHNOLOGICAL MISSION TO LEAVE FOR MACEDONIA

TEXT.P: A technological mission from the Republic of China will leave for Macedonia on Sunday to help the Balkan nation develop its export industry, agriculture and small- and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs).

Lo Ping-chang, secretary-general of the ROC government-run International Cooperation Development Fund (ICDF), said on Friday that the seven-member mission will be led by Alex Shyy, an ICDF deputy department chief.
Lo said Shyy and several mission members will leave for Macedonia on Sunday to start work first. The remaining members are scheduled to arrive in the former Yugoslav republic late this month.

Lo said the ICDF has decided to post the mission in Macedonia after ROC Foreign Minister Jason Hu visited Macedonia in early March, during hwich time Hu signed a memorandum on bilateral economic cooperation with his Macedonian counterpart.

The mission is expected to help Macedonia map out a comprehensive export promotion program and set up a one-stop investment service system and an investment promotion center, Lo said, adding that ROC experts will also assist Macedonia in SME and agricultural development.

Lo said the mission's top purpose at the moment is to help Macedonia increase job opportunities. Macedonia has been troubled by its huge unemployed population, caused partly by its loss of the former Yugoslav federal market.
The mission will also help Taiwan companies intending to invest in Macedonia find suitable joint-venture partners or investment opportunities.
According to the memorandum signed by Hu, Taiwan agreed to offer loans to Macedonian SME operators and farmers in launching new investment projects or expanding their current operations.
Lo said the ICDF has approved a loan application by Macedonians to open a bakery in the Macedonian capital of Skopje. A formal loan agreement will be signed in the near future.
In the future, Lo said the ICDF may also dispatch experts in other fields to Macedonia to assist in its overall economic development.
The ICDF technical mission will stay in Macedonia until June 2002. After the agreement expires, the two countries will make an overall review and decide whether to continue such cooperation, Lo said.

DOC.HEADLINE: SHARE PRICES AND FUTURES RISE

TEXT.P: Taiwan's share prices skyrocketed to their highest level this year on Friday due to strong buying by cooperative investors and encouraged by the firm trading on Wall Street.
The Taiwan Stock Exchange weighted price index, the market's key barometer, surged 213.83 points to close at 7,232.51.
A total of 4.86 billion shares changed hands on market turnover of NT$151.35 billion (US$4.57 billion).
Gainers outnumbered losers 402 to 62 with 35 stocks unchanged.

All eight major stock categories saw gains, with financial issues posting the largest growth at 5.4 percent. Construction issues surged 4.1 percent, followed by cement shares at 3.9 percent, textile shares by 3.6 percent, foodstuff stocks by 2.9 percent, plastic and chemical issues, 2.0 percent, paper and pulp shares by 1.7 percent, and electrical engineering issues, 1.5 percent
The over-the-counter market registered a 1.55-point rise, closing at 163.67, with a turnover of NT$5.64 billion.
Taipei's stock index futures trading was also in a bullish sentiment during Friday's session.
The Taiwan Stock Exchange Capitalization Weighted Stock Index Futures (TAIEX Index Futures) for April surged 256 points to finish at 7,366, with 5,807 contract transactions.

The TAIEX Index Futures for May won 239 points to close at 7,360, while those for June climbed 250 points to 7,370, those for September lost one point to 7,150 and those for December moved up 235 points to 7,301. Contract transactions for these futures totaled 407, 71, 10 and eight, respectively.

DOC.HEADLINE: LOS ALAMOS LAB'S SECURITY IS TIGHT

TEXT.P: Security at the Los Alamos National Laboratory, America's largest nuclear weapons facility, sometimes seems straight from a Hollywood thriller, according to a report in the Los Angeles Times on Thursday.
The report says that the suspected efforts by mainland China and others to obtain data has put US researchers under the microscope.

The report mentions security details such as secure phones and special conference rooms rigged to jam electronic eavesdropping. Heavily guarded walk-in vaults hold top-secret documents. Fingerprints are scanned outside restricted zones. In some areas, visitors are followed into rest rooms.

"Secret Restricted Data" is marked on the 48 linked servers that comprise Blue Mountain, the world's most powerful computer. Hidden portals and sensors check people and cars for smuggled nuclear material. The lab proudly calls its prison-like plutonium storage site "the most heavily guarded four acres in the US.

But for all the high-tech hardware used to protect the seven million classified documents from spies, Los Alamos increasingly is under attack by critics in Congress and elsewhere who fear security is left behind when some scientists meet their peers overseas, especially in mainland China.

"The toughest problem is dealing with what's in someone's mind, not with protecting classified documents in a file in the lab," said John C. Brown, director of Los Alamos. "I don't know how you can have one hundred percent guarantees."

That's the challenge the FBI, CIA and other US agencies face as they investigate whether Los Alamos computer scientist Wen Ho Lee passed along nuclear weapon design data in the 1980's to help mainland China build smaller, more powerful nuclear warheads suspiciously similar to the W-88 warheads that are aboard US Trident submarines. If true, the leak would be a major blow to US security.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA DECIDES TO SEND MORE AID TO MACEDONIA

TEXT.P: Following an economic aid package of US$2 million last week, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) announced on Friday that it will organize delegations to send another aid package to Macedonia to help the country settle ethnic Albanian refugees.

Liu Hsiang-pu, and Andrew L. Y. Hsia, the respective heads of the European Affairs Department and the International Organizations Department, said at a news conference following a meeting that MOFA, in conjunction with 17 civic charity groups, will send assistance and staff to Macedonia at a proper time.
Lawmakers Lee Hsien-jen, Wang Hsueh-feng, and Chen Shei-saint also took part in the meeting.

Citing information dispatched by the ROC embassy in Skopje, Liu said that around 40,000 ethnic Albanian refugees have fled Kosovo, a province in neighboring Yugoslavia, due to a genocide campaign being conducted against them, to Macedonia. "What they need most at present is clothing and food," he noted.

Hsia said MOFA encouraged the private sector to do their best to cooperate with the government in the move, and added that the ministry will call a meeting next week to decide the appropriate time to send the relief material to the Balkan state.
Several groups, Hsia said, have revealed the amount of their donations. "Although they are not large amounts, the money represents the love and concern from the people of Taiwan," he noted.

Hsia added that MOFA, following the proposal of the three legislators, will also study the feasibility of helping the private sector set up an institutionalized body to coordinate efforts in relief or emergency cases.

DOC.HEADLINE: SEF OFFICIAL TO VISIT MAINLAND IN LATE APRIL

TEXT.P: The Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) informed its mainland Chinese counterpart on Friday that it will send a vice secretary-general in late April to continue talks in preparation for the visit by Wang Daohan, mainland China's top envoy, to Taiwan.

In a letter to the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS), SEF said it will dispatch Jan Jyh-horng to the mainland late this month to continue bilateral talks to clear the way for ARATS Chairman Wang's visit to Taiwan.

SEF said that its legal service personnel will accompany Jan to the mainland, in the hope of resuming bilateral talks on technical issues such as the repatriation of mainland Chinese hijackers and illegal immigrants. SEF expressed the desire of being able to conclude negotiations with ARATS on technical issues in order to buttress the significance of Wang's autumn visit to Taiwan.

Jan's planned mainland visit comes after his ARATS counterpart -- Li Yafei -- visited Taiwan in mid March. Jan and Li reached agreement during their March meeting that Wang would visit the island this autumn to reciprocate a landmark visit by SEF Chairman Koo Chen-fu to the mainland last October.
SEF and ARATS are quasi-official organizations authorized by Taipei and Beijing, respectively, to deal with bilateral exchanges in the absence of formal contacts.

Systematic SEF-ARATS talks were unilaterally suspended by Beijing in 1995 after President Lee Teng-hui paid an unofficial visit to the United States earlier that year. Beijing viewed Lee's US trip as a covert move to promote Taiwan independence.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN WILL WORK TO EASE US TRADE FRICTIONS

TEXT.P: Wang Chih-kang, minister of economic affairs said on Friday that Taiwan will continue negotiations with Washington to ease trade friction amid reports that Washington faults Taiwan's trade practices.

Given the United States is one of Taiwan's biggest trade partners, Wang said that Taipei will try to iron out trade disputes with Washington via dialogue in hopes that Washington will not list the island as one of those countries closely monitored by Washington for possible sanctions under the Special 301 provisions of the 1989 US Omnibus Trade Acts.

In its annual report, the office of US Trade Representative (USTR) faults Taiwan for what it called Taiwan's incomprehensible protection of intellectual property, discrimination against US firms in government procurement procedures, and Taiwan's import policy.
Citing several legal wrangles involving US patent rights in Taiwan, the report blamed Taiwan's judiciary system for failing to do justice to US firms when their intellectual rights were violated.

The report, which covers 51 US trade partners, also blamed Taiwan's government procurement process which they said unfairly shut out US firms by imposing unnecessarily strict requirements on would-be bidders.
The USTR is expected to release on April 30 a list of countries that require close monitoring and could be subject to trade sanctions if they fail to address US concerns.

Vowing to beef up trade dialogue with Washington, Wang said he was confident that Taiwan, which has been on and off the list many times but has avoided sanctions for several years, will not receive a status worse than "special monitored country" as it did last year.

DOC.HEADLINE: Y2K JOKE FOOLS EXPERTS

TEXT.P: Singapore, April 2 (CNA): The April Fools' Day joke in Thursday's The Straits Times, about a teenager who had discovered how to solve the Y2K problem, was so convincing that it drew calls from journalists and computer specialists.

A journalist from Channel News Asia telephoned to ask for the youth's contact number, saying she had read that the teenager in question was "camera-shy", but perhaps he could be "persuaded to go on air".
When told the story was a joke, she laughed and said she had thought another Straits Times report, about university graduates "speaking for their supper", had been the hoax.
The article said the student, Jack Hon Si Yue, 17, had stumbled on the code that would solve the Y2K problem while working out the solution to an algebra problem.
The Y2K problem arises from computer chips' inability to distinguish between the years 2000 and 1900.
A few computer specialists called to verify the story, and when told it was the paper's April Fools' Day joke, one complained that it was misleading to firms desperate for Y2K solutions.

Senior correspondent Chua Mui Hoong, who wrote the story, said, "I wanted a story that was incredible but plausible - straining credibility, yet sounded convincing. The idea of a story on the Y2K problem came in a flash at 10 p.m. and I wrote it up."
Alert readers would have spotted the clues written in to give the game away.

The main ones: Jack's name, Si Yue, means "April" in Chinese, while the name of the company, Polo Flari, is an anagram for April Fool. Also, there is no IT consulting company called Gardner, but there is one called Gartner.
Meanwhile, another reader telephoned to say that her aunt, a computer novice who had signed up for computer classes, had also come up with a solution.
Alas, her message on the answering machine was deleted, along with her contact number, so The Straits Times has not found out if there is really a solution out there to the dreaded bug.
Or could the phone call also have been an April Fools' Day joke? (sherman wu)

DOC.HEADLINE: PROVISIONS RELATED TO CIVIL CODE REWRITTEN

TEXT.P: The provisions concerning obligations under the Civil Code underwent an overhaul on Friday with 234 articles out of 604, or 38 percent of the total, being added to, altered or deleted.
The revised Book Two of Civil Code passed the third reading at the legislature on Friday clearing the last hurdle before enactment.
The rewritten provisions feature more comprehensive protection of privacy, chastity, credibility and the rights of kinship, said an official at the Ministry of Justice which initiated the overhaul.
A new section concerning travel contracts was tacked on to the Book Two to regulate the obligation and rights between tourists and travel agencies, added the official.

DOC.HEADLINE: SFC HEAD TO GO ABROAD TO LURE FOREIGN INVESTMENT

TEXT.P: Securities and Futures Commission (SFC) Chairman Lin Tzong-yeong is slated to attend several seminars abroad in the months ahead in a move to lure foreign capital into the local bourse.

Lin will travel first to Tokyo on May 9, where he will take part in a symposium, jointly sponsored by the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development and the Asian Development Bank, to introduce the current situation of the Taiwan stock market, according to the SFC.

From May 21-28, Lin will participate in an international seminar concerning management of stock markets in Lisbon, Portugal's capital, before flying to London in early June. There he will introduce the development of the Taiwan economy to court British investment.
Lin then will travel to New York to attend seminars for similar purposes, the SFC said.
In addition, SFC Secretary-General Wu Tang-chie said Pension 2000, a US-based consulting firm, will hold an investment seminar in Taipei April 15-16 to assess the local bourse.

The Taipei seminar is expected to attract representatives of more than 40 US-based large fund management companies interested in investing in the Taiwan stock market, according to Wu, who added that the SFC is delighted to see such activities being held here.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Saturday, April 3, or the 17th day of the second month of the Year of the Rabbit according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1859: The Hsiahai Chenghwang Temple, one of the oldest temples in Taiwan, is formally inaugurated in Taipei.
1862: Sir James Clark Ross, the British polar explorer who located the magnetic north pole, dies at the age of 62. On an Antarctic expedition from 1839 to 1843, he also discovered Victorialand and the Ross Sea.
1881: Alcide de Gasperi, the Italian statesman who became prime minister in 1945 and led Italy into successful post-war reconstruction, is born.
1897: German composer Johannes Brahms dies in Vienna at the age of 64. His works, blending classical tradition with the new romantic impulse, include concertos, four symphonies, chamber music, and choral compositions.
1898: Henry Luce, the American publisher who founded Time, Life, and Fortune magazines, is born.
1903: Chou Jung, author of "The Revolutionary Army," dies in jail in Shanghai at the age of 21.
1924: Doris Day, the American actress and singer who delighted audiences with musicals such as "Young at Heart," "The Pajama Game," and "Calamity Jane," is born.
1924: Marlon Brando, the American actor who won Oscars for "On the Waterfront" and "The Godfather," is born.
1930: Helmut Kohl, the German chancellor who stayed in power for a record 16 years until his defeat by Gerhard Schroeder in 1998, is born.
1936: Bruno Haupmann, a German-born carpenter, goes to the electric chair in the US for the kidnap and murder of the 20-month-old baby son of aviation hero Charles Lindbergh and his wife Anne.
1946: Directed by the Soviet Union, the so-called "Inner Mongolian Autonomy Movement Committee," is established in Chengteh, Jehol Province.
1948: US President Harry Truman signs the Marshall Plan, allocating US$6 billion in aid to 16 European countries to help rebuilding after World War II.
1962: President and Mme. Philbert Tsiranana of the Republic of Madagascar arrive in Taipei for a six-day state visit.
1964: The Dalai Lama establishes a Tibetan office in New York.
1971: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs of the Republic of China issues a statement severing diplomatic relations with the Republic of Cameroon.
1975: The ROC Control Yuan passes a resolution impeaching Hsu Chi-wei, commissioner of the Department of Education under the Taiwan Provincial Government.
1992: Two weeks after a non-communist parliament is elected, Albanian President Ramiz Alia resigns.
1996: A plane carrying US Commerce Secretary Ron Brown crashes in stormy weather on a hillside outside Dubrovnik, Croatia, killing all 33 aboard.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A man of strong, resolute, simple character approaches closely the true moral character."

DOC.HEADLINE: US SHOULD SEEK COMMITMENT FROM ZHU RONGJI: ANALYST

TEXT.P: The Clinton administration should seek a commitment from Premier Zhu Rongji during his upcoming visit to the United States that mainland China will renounce the use of force against Taiwan, an American China expert said on Friday.

Stephen J. Yates, senior policy analyst for the Asian Studies Center at The Heritage Foundation, said the Clinton administration should also convince Beijing of the need to support Taiwan's bid to join the World Trade Organization (WTO).

"This gesture would build confidence in the cross-strait relationship. Because the WTO does not require sovereignty for membership, this would not violate China's opposition to Taiwan's membership in state-based international organizations," said the analyst.

In meeting with Zhu, Yates added, President Bill Clinton should also "praise Taiwan's example of successful democratization that has produced greater stability through increased political and economic freedom."
He said Zhu's priority during his visit to Washington next week will be promoting Beijing's membership in the WTO.
However, according to Yates, instead of trying to make deals on subjects like the WTO, the Clinton administration should seek Beijing's cooperation in matters of importance to US security.

For example, the administration should make clear its resolve to develop an effective missile defense system, emphasizing that deployment of such a system to protect innocent civilians against missile attack "cannot legitimately be considered a threat to China's security."

In addition to seeking a commitment from Zhu that the PRC will renounce the use of force against Taiwan, the administration should also seek mainland China's commitment to use its diplomatic leverage to encourage positive changes in North Korea's military, diplomatic, or domestic behavior, Yates said.

President Bill Clinton should insist that mainland China demonstrate market-opening reforms before agreeing to support its entry into the WTO, and should hold mainland China to the letter and spirit of its international human rights commitments, he added.

He stressed that the United States has great interest in deterring aggression and promoting freedom throughout Asia. But to advance these goals, the Clinton administration needs to see results. Actions speak louder than words, and "fresh promises from China are no substitute for real reform." Unfortunately, he went on, Clinton's China policy emphasizes cooperation over results.
Yates concluded that the forthcoming summit offers Clinton an opportunity to adjust course by insisting that mainland China's reforms come before its reward -- membership in the WTO.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIAN MINISTER TO VISIT TAIWAN DESPITE BEIJING PROTEST

TEXT.P: Australian Industry Minister Nick Minchin is to make an unofficial visit Taipei on Monday, where he will open a technology exhibition, despite a protest from the mainland Chinese embassy in Canberra.
Minchin will open the Australian Technology Week, or Oz-Tech '99, during his two-day visit to Taiwan, The Australian newspaper reported on Saturday.

In calendar 1998, two-way trade between Australia and Taiwan totaled about A$7.8 (US$5.4) billion, with Australia enjoying a large trade surplus. Australian exports to Taiwan also rose about 5 percent in 1998 from the 1997 level.

Oz-Tech '99 is an important exhibition which will allow Australia to promote sales of its technology to Taiwan in hope of boosting exports, analysts said, adding that there is room for expansion in two-way trade between Taiwan and Australia.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR DOWN ON TAIPEI FOREX MARKET

The local currency opened at 33.121, the highest level of the day, and was traded between 33.121 and 33.128.

DOC.HEADLINE: Y2K HAZARD MAY BEGIN AS EARLY AS APRIL 9, DGBAS WARNS

TEXT.P: The year 2000 computer problem may attack computers much earlier than the originally estimated date of Jan. 1, 2000, the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) warned on Saturday.

The Millennium Bug, also known as Y2K, may attack as early as April 9, when internal computer clocks and chipsets show the numeral 9999. According to the dating system used in some old computer systems, April 9 is displayed as the 99th day of 1999, according to DGBAS officials.

However, 9999, the highest four-digit number, is also often used to represent certain special codes, such as a calculation error, which may lead some older computer systems to crash or display faulty data, the officials added.

The DGBAS lists 12 other dates that computer systems may also run into problems with, such as Sept. 9, 1999, when calendars will also display 9999 in many computer programming data; Dec. 31, 1999, the last day of the year; and Jan. 1, 2000, the first day of the new year.
Others include Jan. 3, 2000, the first day of work for most businesses in the new year; Jan. 10, 2000, when a seven-digit date (1/10/2000) will crop up for the first time in the new year.

The remaining dates that are also potentially risky include Jan. 31, 2000, the last day of the first month of 2000; Feb. 29, 2000, the extra day in a leap year; March 31, 2000, the last day of the first quarter of 2000; Oct. 10, 2000, when an eight-digit date (10/10/2000) will show up for the first time in the year; Dec. 31, 2000, the last day of the year; Jan. 1, 2001, the first day of the 21st century; and Dec. 31, 2001, the date when the operations of the past 365 days will be checked, the DGBAS officials said.

DGBAS Director-General Wei Duan gave an assurance that all government and public sectors, including power, water supply, telecommunications, transportation, finance, taxation, customs system and law-enforcement administration sectors, should be Y2K-compliant before June 30.
He added that people affected by government inefficiency as a result of poor preparedness for the Y2K crisis will be able apply for compensation from the government.
Businesses and operations in the private sector will also be held accountable if they cause trouble or inflict losses on the public because of failure to tackle the Y2K problem in advance, he noted.
Wei estimated that the biggest impact of Y2K in Taiwan will be seen in the banking, stock exchange, telecommunications, and medical service sectors.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA URGES VISITORS TO CIS TO OBTAIN PROPER TRAVEL DOCUMENTS

TEXT.P: Travelers to the former Soviet republics of the Commonwealth of Independent States (CIS) should have their travel documents ready before leaving Taiwan, an official from the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) warned on Saturday.
Clark Chen, director of MOFA's Department of West Asian Affairs, issued the warning amid reports that a Taiwan student was detained by Russian immigration authorities at Moscow airport on March 16.
Chen said the student, who had obtained permission to study at Moscow University, abruptly changed his mind and decided to study instead at Kiev University in Ukraine when he arrived in Moscow.
However, when he tried to leave for Ukraine without a visa, he was detained to await deportation, until Taipei's representative office in Moscow stepped in and helped him get a Ukraine visa.
Chen said that Russian Foreign Ministry officials have warned Taiwan visitors that they will be deported on the same plane on which they arrive if they come to Russia without proper documents.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER TAIPEI MAYOR MEETS THE PRESS IN TOKYO

TEXT.P: Cross-Taiwan Strait and Asia-Pacific security is of mutual concern to both Japan and Taiwan, former Taipei Mayor Chen Shui-bian told reporters on Friday night.
Chen, who arrived in Japan on Wednesday for a three-day private visit, said that he met with some Japanese VIPs during his visit, but he declined to reveal their names.
He noted that the Japanese Diet, or parliament, is currently screening a domestic bill in accordance with the guidelines set out for US-Japan defensive cooperation.

Commenting on Japan's ambiguous stance regarding "matters surrounding Japanese territory," which are included in the guidelines, Chen said that after meeting with Japanese officials, he understands the necessity for Japan to adopt this attitude.

Beijing has protested to Japan over the possibility that the guidelines will include Taiwan in the proposed defensive system, known as Theater Missile Defense (TMD), describing any inclusion of the island in such a defense system as "interference in Chinese sovereignty."

The stalwart of the Republic of China's major opposition Democratic Progressive Party stressed the necessity for both sides of the Taiwan Strait to establish a mechanism for dialogue on military mutual trust.

He also indicated that Taiwan's inclusion in the TMD system would not contradict the establishment of the dialogue mechanism, because the establishment of such a mechanism would pacify Beijing as to Taiwan's intentions.

Chen said that through his visit, he has come to understand that many Japanese people think that what Japan has provided mainland China in the past has been based on the "sunshine policy," for example, providing mainland China with large amounts of economic assistance.
However, they now think Japan should also have a "north wind policy" with regard to mainland China, such as the TMD system and the long established US-Japan Safety Treaty, he said.

Chen disputed media reports that President Lee Teng-hui thinks that Chen is the best successor for the presidency of the ROC in 2000, saying that it is not possible for a leader of a political party to support a possible candidate of another political party, especially since he has not yet even decided whether or not to run in the election.

Chen praised Lee for his contributions to the reform of the ROC's democratic politics. Turning to Japan's refusal to allow Lee to visit Japan and attend an alumni meeting at his Japanese alma mater for fear of offending Beijing, he urged Japan to "just say no" to Beijing in order not to let down the many people who want Lee to visit Japan.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT ANTICIPATES FEW ROC POLICY CHANGES AFTER HIS RETIREMENT

TEXT.P: Touting the Republic of China as a state which enjoys a well-established democracy, President Lee Teng-hui said on Saturday that he does not expect to see many changes in national policy after his retirement in 2000.

Lee told visiting US Senator Craig Thomas, chairman of the Asian and Pacific Subcommittee of the Foreign Relations Committee, and Representative Greg Walden, that Taiwan is a country ruled by law rather than by the personal whims of its leaders. He added that he is not worried about his policies being changed by his successors.

Now that the ROC's political reforms are taking root, Lee said, the government is pushing for reforms in education, the judiciary, administration, and in the spirit of the people, all of which will in return consolidate the country's democratic development.

When his guests, who visited Beijing before coming to Taiwan, told him that Taiwan's participation in the US-led Theater Missile Defense system is of great concern to Beijing, Lee pointed out that Taiwan is more concerned about its safety and security than about Beijing's worries.
He reiterated that peace, stability and narrowing differences through dialogue and exchanges are the supreme goals pursued by Taiwan is its ties with mainland China.
Lee expressed thanks to US Congress for its support of the ROC, and called on US lawmakers to endorse the island's bid for membership in the World Trade Organization and World Health Organization.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN ORNITHOLOGISTS TRACK BLACK-FACED SPOONBILL MIGRATION ROUTE

TEXT.P: The mystery surrounding the migration route of the rare black-faced spoonbill was solved on Saturday when the Taipei-based Chinese Wild Bird Federation (CWBF) unveiled the results of its attempts to track the birds using satellites.
The federation and the Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture (COA) held a joint news conference to release a report which details the north-bound flight path of a selected black-faced spoonbill.

According to the report, the bird, known by its nickname "Turtle," flew directly to mainland China's southeastern coastal provinces of Fujian and Zhejiang after leaving a coastal area near Taiwan's southwestern town of Chiku on March 14. After a brief stopover there, it continued its journey to Jiangsu and finally reached its breeding ground near the North Korean city of Haeju, a city some 121 km northwest of Seoul.
"This is the world's first comprehensive satellite tracking report on the black-faced spoonbill's migratory route," said Chen Hsi-chou, a COA department chief.
Under a plan to study one of the world's rarest bird species, the CWBF has installed transmitters on four selected birds, and all four are transmitting signals.

CWBF President Kuo Cheng-yu said another of the birds, nicknamed Discoverer, has been wandering around the northern coastal region of Hsinchu since leaving Tainan in the island's south on March 19. "The bird appears to be getting ready to migrate northward," Kuo noted.

Kuo said there are only some 613 black-faced spoonbills left in the world, and added: "More than half of these surviving birds, or about 363, tend to fly to Taiwan in autumn or winter to avoid the frigid cold in their northern breeding grounds."
As a result, Kuo said, Taiwan has emerged as one of the world's most important black-faced spoonbill study centers.

"The tracking of their migratory route is the first step in exploring the species' habitat and its reproduction situation," Kuo said, adding that such knowledge is expected to help work out effective ways to protect the species.

The black-faced spoonbill migratory route study project is jointly initiated and carried out by the Bird Life International and several Asian countries, including the Republic of China, Japan and Hong Kong.
Kuo said the CWBF will continue working on the research project to gain a better understanding of the rare species' living and reproduction patterns as well as other related issues.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER URGES WASHINGTON TO STICK TO COMMITMENT TO SELL TAIWAN ARMS

TEXT.P: Premier Vincent Siew urged Washington to stick with its commitment under the Taiwan Relations Act to provide Taiwan with the arms necessary for it to defend itself.

Noting that hundreds of missiles have been deployed by Beijing along its coast across the Taiwan Strait, Siew told visiting US Sen. Craig Thomas and Rep. Greg Walden that Washington should not compromise a promise made to Taiwan in 1982 that it would not consult Beijing on possible arms sales to Taiwan.
Siew also said Washington should not give in to demands by Beijing that Taiwan be excluded from the US-proposed Theater Missile Defense (TMD) system.
Washington should take the security of the entire Asia-Pacific region into consideration and provide Taiwan the option of joining the missile defense program, he said.

As to Taiwan's bid for membership in the World Trade Organization (WTO), Siew noted that Taiwan has completed all necessary bilateral negotiations. Siew said he hoped Taiwan's application would be judged on its own merits and that the island's entry would not be postponed until mainland China is admitted into the body.
He thanked Sen. Thomas for sponsoring a resolution that calls for US support for Taiwan's participation in international organizations.
Thomas and Walden, who arrived in Taipei after a visit to Beijing and Hong Kong, were accompanied by Vice Foreign Minister David Lee at Saturday's meeting with Siew.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SHARE PRICES, FUTURES LOSE GROUND

TEXT.P: After two days of gains, profit-taking pushed the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) lower Saturday, with the weighted price index, the market's key barometer, declining 50.31 points to close at 7,182.2.
Trade on Saturday totaled 4.4 billion shares worth NT$136.91 billion (US$4.13 billion), down from the previous session's NT$151.35 billion.
Decliners outnumbered gainers 217 to 216, with 63 stocks unchanged.
The eight major stock categories closed mixed.
Construction stocks rose 0.7 percent, followed by textile stocks, which were up 0.4 percent, and foodstuff stocks, which rose 0.3 percent.

Financial stocks suffered the largest loss Saturday, falling 1.6 percent. They were followed by electrical stocks, which were down 0.7 percent; pulp and paper stocks, 0.5 percent; and cement stocks, 0.2 percent.
Plastic and chemical stocks remained unchanged.
The over-the-counter market also lost steam with the market's index dropping 0.64 points to close at 165.62 on a turnover of NT$5.62 billion.
TAIEX Capitalization Weighted Stock Index Futures (TAIEX Index Futures) were lower as well.

TAIEX Index Futures for April sank 61 points to close at 7,305 with 4,636 contract transactions; May futures moved down 41 points to close at 7,319 with 288 contract transactions; and June futures were down 51 points to close at 7,306 with 25 contract transactions.
TAIEX Index Futures for September slid 37 points to close at 7,305 with 19 contract transactions, while December futures were down 17 points to close at 7,383 with four contract transactions.

Reference levels provided by the Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange for TAIEX Index Futures trading on Saturday were 7,366 points for April; 7,360 points for May; 7,357 points for June; 7,342 points for September; and 7,400 points for December.
The local bourse will be closed on Monday for a public holiday.

DOC.HEADLINE: KAOHSIUNG CITY DETERMINED TO INTRODUCE LOTTERIES THIS YEAR

TEXT.P: Kaohsiung will reintroduce public lotteries later this year, despite the absence of consensus between the central government and local governments around the island on the issue, a city government official said on Saturday.

Wei Yao-chien, deputy secretary-general of the government of the southern port city, said the lottery, in the form of scratch-cards, will be introduced in Kaohsiung in August this year at the earliest, and the proceeds used to finance public welfare projects.

Wei was among a group of officials from the municipalities of Taipei and Kaohsiung, Taiwan Province, and 21 other cities and counties around the island who were invited by the Ministry of Finance (MOF) to a meeting on Saturday to discuss principally how revenues generated from the officially sanctioned lotteries should be distributed.

The official from the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP)-governed city said that according to the revised statutes governing lotteries and related financial programs, the central government, or more directly, the MOF, does not have the right to introduce, or authorize the introduction of, public lotteries.

Wei blasted as "rubbish" a statement by a top Cabinet official that the MOF will reintroduce lotteries so that the national coffers can be augmented in order to fund the proposed national pension program.
He urged the central government not to use the national pension as an excuse for stealing the right of local governments to introduce lotteries.

The MOF drew up regulations on official lotteries in 1995, but has yet to put them into practice. At that time, it was estimated that lottery profits could be as high as NT$20 billion (US$606 million) per year.

The MOF said recently that it has reached an agreement with city and county governments over relevant rules and distribution of funds generated from lotteries. Technically, it said, the first public lotteries will begin next year, with three different lottery schemes being organized by the Bank of Taiwan, the Taipei Bank and the Kaohsiung Bank, respectively.

MOF statistics also showed that funds expected to be generated from the officially sanctioned lotteries will be roughly 1 percent of Taiwan's GDP, or NT$85 billion. Seventy-five percent of this will be used for prizes, while another 10 percent used to cover administration and marketing costs, the MOF said.

All lotteries in Taiwan were banned in 1988 in an effort to discourage gambling and speculation, but two years later, the relevant statutes were revised so as to permit the introduction of lotteries by Taipei and Kaohsiung cities, as well as by the Taiwan provincial government.

In 1990, Taipei City launched a single-lottery scheme but suspended it after just three months. The short-lived lottery resulted in revenue of about NT$900 million for the city government, and provided jobs for the physically challenged.

DOC.HEADLINE: LIST OF NON-Y2K-COMPLIANT MEDICAL EQUIPMENT TO BE PUBLISHED IN JUNE

TEXT.P: A list of medical equipment that is not Y2K compliant will be published in June, and any equipment on that list that is not fixed by November cannot be used after that point, the Department of Health (DOH) said Saturday.

In a survey of computer-controlled medical equipment used around the island, more than 70 machines -- about one-fourth of the approximately 290 included in the survey -- are incapable of recognizing the year 2000, and this could result in incorrect diagnoses and cause harm to patients, said the DOH.

Many of the computers in use today recognize years by only their last two digits. As a result these machines may mistake 2000 for 1900. This could cause systems to operate incorrectly or to crash completely.

DOC.HEADLINE: FUNDS FOR DOPING TESTS IN 2000 OLYMPICS BY BE INSUFFICIENT

TEXT.P: It is doubtful that the 2000 Olympic Games in Sydney will include drug tests to detect the use of banned artificial hormones unless the International Olympic Committee (IOC) provides the funding necessary for the tests to be perfected, according to a British medical researcher.

Professor Peter Sonksen, head of an IOC-funded research team that has produced a long-awaited test for detecting the use of synthetic growth hormones by Olympic athletes, said current tests can be applied only to white males, according to The Sydney Morning Herald.
The IOC and the European Union have previously provided funding to the research team, which is aiming to devise a test to detect synthetic human growth hormone (hGH) abuse in athletes.
Synthetic hGH is a so-called smart drug that is undetectable by traditional drug tests, as the hormone is indistinguishable from naturally occurring human growth hormones.
About two years ago mainland Chinese swimmers were found to be carrying illegal drugs at Sydney Airport while they were on their way to Perth to participate in the Pacific Swimming Championship.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIAN POLICE PLANS TO OPEN ANT-DRUG OFFICE IN BEIJING

TEXT.P: In an attempt to stem drug smuggling, the Australian Federal Police plans to open an office in Beijing to help bolster's Australia's international drugs surveillance.

In a dispatch from Bangkok, The Australian newspaper reported that Australian Justice Minister Amanda Vanstone will try to clinch an agreement with her mainland Chinese counterpart when she visits Beijing this weekend.

Australian police and customs officials regard an office in Beijing as vital to their narcotics surveillance efforts because in the past five years, mainland China has become a major transshipment point for heroin originating in the Golden Triangle.

Last October, Australia smashed the biggest narcotics smuggling ring in history by seizing about 400 kg of pure Burmese heroin near the town of Port Macquarie in New South Wales. The heroin was routed through mainland China's Yunnan Province by a Chinese syndicate.

Interpol says Australia has become one of the largest markets for Burmese heroin, while US authorities estimate that Burma, the world's largest source of illegal narcotics, produced about 170 tons of heroin last year alone.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING URGED TO BE PRAGMATIC ON 'DESIGNATION'

TEXT.P: A senior ROC official on Saturday urged Beijing to adopt a pragmatic attitude toward engagements between Taiwan and Macau after the Portuguese colony reverts to mainland China's rule late this year.
Lin Chong-pin, vice chairman of the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC), made the appeal at the opening session of a two-day seminar on Taiwan-Macau relations.

Lin said the Republic of China is hopeful that its current commercial exchanges and airlinks with Macau as well as its representative office there will remain unchanged after the colony's handover on Dec. 20.

"We also hope mainland leaders will not make too much fuss over 'label' or designation issues," Lin said, adding that mainland authorities should deal with Taiwan-Macau engagements in a pragmatic manner and based on a reciprocal, "win-win" principle.
The existing ROC representative office in Macau is named "the Taipei Trade and Tourism Office, Macau." Beijing authorities reportedly want the word "office" to be changed after Macau's handover.
Lin said he hopes mainland China will not insist on a change to the ROC representative office's designation. "It is meaningless to make a fuss over such a superficial issue," he remarked.
This is the first time that Taipei has expressed its stance on issues related to the designation of its representative office in Macau.
Lin said in preparation for Macau's handover, the ROC government has legislated a statue governing exchanges with post-handover Macau.
The mainland affairs expert-turned-technocrat said the MAC's Macau Affairs Bureau will start operations on the same day of Macau's handover to Beijing.

Lin went on to say that Taiwan and Macau have maintained mutually beneficial relations based on the principle of reciprocity. Two-way trade reached US$360 million in 1998, with Taiwan enjoying a trade surplus of US$270 million.

Meanwhile, Lin said, Taiwan people made 820,000 visits to Macau last year, making Taiwan Macau's second largest source of tourists, second only to mainland China. The number of Taiwan-Macau flights now accounts for 55.77 percent of Macau's total air traffic volume. Moreover, more than 5,000 Macau residents have studied at various Taiwan universities or colleges over the past few years. The number of Macau residents who regularly work in Taiwan ranges between 15,000 to 20,000.

"All these figures point to the ever closer relationship between Taiwan and Macau," Lin noted, adding that the ROC looks forward to seeing continued growth in Taiwan-Macau exchanges even after Beijing reclaims the colony.

More than 60 scholars and experts from Taiwan and Macau are participating in the seminar being held at Taipei Fortuna Hotel. A total of 25 papers on Taiwan-Macau-Hong-Kong-Beijing relations as well as various problems facing Macau will be discussed during the two-day seminar.

DOC.HEADLINE: GENERATION-X WOMEN SAY LEE, LIEN UNCONCERNED OVER WOMEN'S ISSUES

TEXT.P: Most women in the so-called X generation do not support President Lee Teng-hui and Vice President Lien Chan, but that does not mean that Lien would have difficulty winning the 2000 presidential election, the results of a poll conducted by the opposition New Party showed.

The poll of women aged above 20 found that 70 percent of women voters aged between 20 and 29 do not think President Lee Teng-hui is concerned about the issues that most affect women in Taiwan, and 46 have the same opinion about Vice President Lien Chan.

Even among many women 30 and older, the president and vice president are seen as being unconcerned with women's issues, as 46.4 percent said Lee is either "very unconcerned" or "unconcerned" about women's problems, while only 22.1 percent said he is concerned. Lien fared little better, as 43.5 percent of women 30 and older said he does not care about women's problems, while 25 percent said he does.

Although Lien -- the ruling Kuomintang's most likely presidential candidate -- is far less popular among generation-X women than among women above that age group, it is not at all certain that he would have trouble winning the election, said Chen Sheng, a New Party deputy at the National Assembly who oversaw the poll.
Far fewer generation-X women vote than do women above that age group, which means the female generation-X vote will not be a significant factor in the next election, Chen said.
If Lien wins the support of women 30 and older, he could easily beat rival candidates from the opposition Democratic Progressive Party or those who run as independents, Chen said.

The same poll found that 62.7 percent of respondents said they choose candidates based on their personalities and character rather than on their political party affiliation, and only 3.8 of respondents said a candidate's party membership is a decisive factor when deciding who to vote for.
Chen said this finding may be of interest to those thinking of running in next year's election as independents.
Although has yet formally announced his candidacy, former Taiwan Provincial Governor James Soong is thought to be considering running as an independent.

As for the appeal of a man and woman running on the same ticket, 22.6 percent of respondents said such a ticket stands a chance of winning, while 33.6 percent said the ticket would not stand a chance.
The poll, conducted via telephone between April 1 and 2, was based on surveys of 1,018 women voters aged above 20 and has a margin of error of 3.1 percent.
