DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER SIEW RECEIVES HONDURAN DEFENSE MINISTER

TEXT.P: Premier Vincent Siew received Honduran Defense Minister Edgardo Dumas Rodriguez on Saturday.
Premier Siew said during his talks with Dumas that the Republic of China and Honduras have maintained long-standing diplomatic relations and have banded together in intensive cooperation.
He also thanked Honduras for its continual support for the ROC's participation in international activities and its entry into international organizations.
Siew extended the ROC's concern over reconstruction efforts in the Central American nation after it was ravaged by Hurricane Mitch last year.
Dumas said the hurricane had caused a severe damage to Honduras' infrastructure. He thanked the Republic of China and the international community for extending a helping hand.
He said Honduras has a strong willingness to maintain sound bilateral ties with the Republic of China.

Honduras' first civilian defense minister said he visited the Republic of China more than 10 years ago. He said he is deeply impressed by the significant progress made by the Republic of China in various fields since his last visit.
He hopes the two nations will continue to strengthen cooperation.

DOC.HEADLINE: EXTENDING TENURE OF PRESIDENCY CANNOT BE DONE RECKLESSLY: KMT

TEXT.P: In response to talk about revising the constitution to extend by one year the tenure of the current president of the Republic of China, the general-secretary of the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) said the issue cannot be handled recklessly.
John Chang noted that issue is sensitive and that the KMT has been addressing it in an "extremely cautious" manner.
The extension would come as part of a plan to combine presidental, legislative and National Assembly elections.

The KMT is now preparing to make some revisions to the ROC constitution, said Chang, although he added that before such revisions are made there should be a consensus not only within the KMT but among all major political parties.

Chang said the amendments being considered by the ruling party include ones to extend the term of office of legislators and ones that would change the rights and responsibilities of the National Assembly.
Many scholars in Taiwan have said that after legislators' terms are extended, amendments should focus on the combination of separately held elections for various levels of government.

Scholars have said elections for president, the legislature and the National Assembly should be held at the same time, while local-level elections -- such as those for mayor of Taiwan's special municipalities, county magistrates and speakers of city and county councils -- should be held at the same time as well.
Such combination would be an improvement over the current situation, in which elections of some sort are held nearly ever year and which exacts a toll on society, scholars have said.

But if such combination were to take place, the current president's term would need to be extended by one year, Chang said cautiously. To date, Chang admitted, promoting election combination has been difficult.
Although the KMT holds a majority in the National Assembly, it does not have enough seats to pass constitutional amendments without support from opposition parties, Chang said.
Chang noted that he will meet the speaker of National Assembly and the president of the Legislative Yuan next Tuesday, to determine the future direction of this issue.
The KMT will do its best to understand public opinion regarding constitutional changes before promoting the project, stressed Chang.

DOC.HEADLINE: POLL FINDS LOCAL PARENTS SPEND LITTLE TIME WITH CHILDREN

TEXT.P: About 50 percent of local parents with children aged between six and 12 spend less than three hours with their kids a day, according to the results of a poll released on Saturday.

The survey was conducted by the Cabinet-level Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) in March 1998. According to DGBAS tallies, 2.61 million local couples have children aged between six and 12. The DGBAS surveyed 6,000 samples, randomly selected from couples residing in 23 cities and counties around the island.

According to the survey, only 49.13 percent of the respondents said they spent at least three hours with their children per day, while 10 percent said they spent less than one hour with their kids a day.

The survey further found that local fathers generally spent less time with their children than mothers. Only 31.61 percent of fathers interviewed said they spent more than three hours a day with their kids, compared to 66.19 percent recorded with local mothers. Meanwhile, 57.84 percent of working mothers surveyed said they spent over three hours with their children a day.

Another disappointing finding was that 80.91 percent of parents interviewed said most of the time they spent with their children was used to watch television. Only 10-to-20 percent said they would join with their chidden in athletic or video games or other recreational activities; 26.76 percent said they usually accompanied their children in doing homework, taking a walk or shopping.

Survey results also showed that only 30 percent of local parents would give their children aged between six and 12 corporeal punishment, while 80.81 percent said they usually would only give their children pep talks or advice when they do something wrong.

According to the survey, parents with only elementary education are more likely to resort to corporeal punishment, while those with college or even higher-level education seldom use violent means to punish their children.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Sunday, April 4, or the 18th day of the second month of the Year of the Rabbit according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1581: Sir Francis Drake, who in 1580 became the first Englishman to circumnavigate the globe, is knighted in London by Queen Elizabeth I. The English naval hero later became vice admiral of the fleet that destroyed the Spanish Armada in 1588.
1617: John Napier, the Scottish mathematician who invented logarithms and introduced the use of the decimal point in writing numbers, dies at the age of 67.
1841: William Henry Harrison, the ninth president of the United States, dies of pneumonia at the age of 68 after only one month in office.
1900: Prince Edward, heir to the throne of England, narrowly escapes death when a teenage anarchist fires two shots at the prince who is on a train in Brussels station.
1905: Earthquake rocks Lahore, then part of British India, killing some 19,000 people.
1919: Soviet republic is declared in Bavaria.
1932: The Republic of China observes its first Children's Day. Children have the day off from school.
1942: Japanese forces sink three British warships in the Bay of Bengal.
1949: The foreign ministers of Belgium, Britain, Canada, France, Holland, Luxembourg, Norway, Denmark, Iceland, Italy, Portugal and the United States sign the North Atlantic Treaty in Washington to protect Western nations from Soviet aggression.
1950: The Chinese Refugees Relief Association is inaugurated.
1967: Australian Prime Minister Harold E. Holt arrives in Taipei for a three-day visit.
1968: Dr. Martin Luther King, the Amerian civil rights leader who won the 1964 Nobel Peace Prize, is assassinated at a motel in Memphis, Tennessee. His eloquence and commitment to nonviolent tactics formed the foundation of the civil rights movement of the 1950's and 1960's.
1975: A US Air Force transport plane carrying Vietnamese orphans crashes on take-off in Saigon, killing 199 people aboard.
1979: Zulfikar Ali Bhutto, Pakistan's former president who was deposed by Gen. Zia ul-Haq in 1977, is hanged in Rawalpindi for the alleged murder of a political opponent.
1980: ROC President Chiang Ching-kuo presides over a ceremony marking the inauguration of the Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall.
1983: The United States grants political asylum to Hu Na, a noted tennis player from mainland China.
1990: Communist China's legislature approves the Basic Law, the constitution that will govern Hong Kong after it reverts to Chinese sovereignty in 1997.
1990: Britain publishes a bill to grant citizenship to up to 225,000 Hong Kong residents in the runup to the colony's handover to mainland China in 1997.
1994: A communist Chinese court sentences Si Yang, a reporter of Hong Kong's Ming Pao newspaper, to 12 years in prison for "stealing and probing national secrets."
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A gentleman must be sympathetic, obliging and affectionate: sympathetic and obliging to his friends and affectionate to the members of his family."

DOC.HEADLINE: CHEN SHUI-BIAN TO VISIT NEW YORK
DOC.DATELINE: New York, April 3 (CNA) (By David Wang and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Chen Shui-bian, a stalwart of Taiwan's leading opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) is scheduled to arrive here on April 22 for a two-day visit, sources said on Saturday.
According to the Taiwanese Office, an organization composed of immigrants from Taiwan, a group has been established to prepare for Chen's visit.

Chen will give a speech at a dinner party in the afternoon of April 22. The next day, he will take part in a fund-raising banquet held by his supporters in New York, with the money collected to be used to fund the New York Chen Shui-bian support club.
Chen, who just completed a visit to Japan, is widely viewed as the DPP's most likely candidate in Taiwan's next presidential election slated for 2000.

DOC.HEADLINE: LIEN CELEBRATES CHILDREN'S DAY WITH LOCAL AND ABORIGINE CHILDREN

TEXT.P: Republic of China Vice President Lien Chan wished children a happy Children's Day on Sunday while attending an activity to celebrate their day at a downtown Taipei elementary school.
The activity, with its theme of celebrating World Children's Day and concern for aborigines, was co-sponsored by the Youth Development Foundation and Aboriginal Affairs Commission.
Lien, in his capacity as chairman of the Youth Development Foundation, said he was impressed with the passion exhibited by the aborigine children in asking for his autograph.

Lien called the activity a good chance for urban children to mingle with their aborigine counterparts, noting that more than 300 aborigine children were present in addition to the students from Tachao Elementary School.

Lien urged his young audience to pay equal attention to academic studies and physical training, urging them to take part in extra curricular activities. He said that they could shine in every field if they pursue their dreams vigorously.
Lien also took the chance to promote the Youth Development Foundation, saying that he hopes the children will take part in the foundation's activities after they grow up.
Lien presented each of the aborigine guests a pair of sneakers, while giving an alarm clock to every student from Tachao Elementary School.
Aborigine children also presented Lien with locally grown plums, mushrooms and mangoes.

DOC.HEADLINE: WANG DAN URGES MAINLAND CHINA TO STOP THREATENING TAIWAN

TEXT.P: At the conclusion of a weeklong visit to Taiwan, prominent mainland Chinese dissident Wang Dan on Sunday urged Beijing to abandon threatening Taiwan with military aggression.

Wang Dan, at a farewell media conference, said that the problems between Taiwan and the mainland, instead of being solved by Taiwan's ruling Kuomintang or mainland's communist regime, should be left to the people to work out.

He stressed that Beijing should take the lead in constructing a harmonious political atmosphere between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait to pave the way for two-way communication. "Beijing should follow the global trend of adopting peaceful methods, not force, to solve problems," he said.

Wang said that visits to Taipei and Taichung made him realize how energetic and urbanized Taiwan society was. The fact that the people here are very concerned about future development on the mainland also impressed him.

Wang regretted that the short length of the trip did not permit time to observe and understand the transition that had occurred in Taiwan's upper society, including how the ruling and opposition parties perform. He hoped he would be granted another opportunity to visit Taiwan so as to understand more.
Wang said that democracy movements had prospered on Taiwan due largely to the efforts made by the island's intellectuals in transforming Taiwan from a dictatorial regime into a democracy.
Taiwan's democracy experiment of forwarding pragmatic suggestions for political reform to the government is a good example for intellectuals on the mainland to follow, said Wang Dan.

According to Wang, the people here are enthusiastic about politics, yet the people in a mature democracy, such as the United States, do not devote themselves so much to politics. He therefore considered Taiwan as still undergoing a political transition and predicted that more political transformations will take place in the future.
Wang Dan urged the winner of Taiwan's 2000 presidential election to handle the problems between Taiwan and the mainland peacefully and reasonably. (by Amanda Chang)

DOC.HEADLINE: TREMOR ROCKS TAIWAN

TEXT.P: An earthquake measuring 5.7 on the Richter scale rocked northeastern Taiwan on Sunday. There were no immediate reports of causalities or property losses.

The Central Weather Bureau said the quake took place at 12:59 p.m. and lasted for 40 seconds. The epicenter was located at 24.8 km northeast of Ilan county. Bureau officials said the tremor was felt in many parts of eastern, northern and central Taiwan, including Taipei, with the level of intensity ranging from one to three on the Richter scale.

DOC.HEADLINE: HAU PAYS TRIBUTE TO ROC FOUNDER IN MAINLAND CHINA

TEXT.P: Former ROC Premier Hau Pei-tsun on Sunday paid respect to the Founder of the Republic of China, Dr. Sun Yat-sen, at his tomb in Nanjing, the capital of mainland China's Jiangsu province.
Praising Sun as a patriot and a great statesman, Hau said Sun, who founded the ROC 88 years ago, is admired by the people both in Taiwan and mainland China.

The former premier also visited a local museum set up to commemorate the Nanjing Massacre in 1937. More than 300,000 civilians were killed by occupying Japanese troops in the tragedy, a major incident marking the start of the Eight-Year War of Resistance Against Japan.

Hau is slated to travel to Yancheng, his hometown in central Jiangsu, in Sunday afternoon. On Monday, he will visit his ancestral temple and sweep the tombs of family members, to observe the Ching Ming, or Tomb Sweeping Festival for Chinese people.

Accompanied by his wife, two sons, including Legislator Hau Lung-pin, and a granddaughter, Hau arrived in Nanjing via Hong Kong in Saturday afternoon for a 10-day visit. He was greeted by Du Guoling, head of Jiangsu province's Taiwan Affairs Office, at the airport.
It was Hau's first trip back to mainland China since he left 61 years ago after taking part in the war against the Japanese aggression.

An aide of Hau Lung-pin, who is traveling with the Hau family, said that Hau's plan to meet Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS) Chairman Wang Daohen, mainland China's top negotiator with Taiwan, on April 9 in Shanghai remains unchanged.
ARATS is a semi-official organization authorized by Beijing to deal with bilateral exchanges with Taiwan in the absence of formal contacts.

Wang is scheduled to visit Taiwan this autumn in a gesture to reciprocate a historical visit by his Taiwan counterpart, Koo Chen-fu, chairman of the Straits Exchange Foundation, to mainland China last October.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT TO INVEST IN PRATAS ISLANDS

TEXT.P: Taiwan's ruling Kuomintang (KMT) is planning to invest more than NT$100 million in the Pratas Islands as a way of helping the government claim its sovereignty over the islands, the China Time Express reported on Sunday.

The evening paper quoted Liu Tai-ying, director of KMT's Business Management Committee (BMC) as reported that KMT's China Development Corp. plans to build resort hotels and construct other infrastructure on the islands to attract tourists from Taiwan.

The KMT has worked out the plan to invest in Paratas after a survey by experts of the Spratly Islands recently. Taiwan has long stationed troops on the Pratas Islands, and a local airlines has maintained regular flights between Taiwan and Pratas.

The Spratly Islands in the South China Sea are also claimed in part or wholly by mainland China, the Philippines, Vietnam, Malaysia and Brunei. Partas, about 500 kilometers southwest of Kaohsiung, is also claimed by mainland China.
The Ministry of National Defense and the Kaohsiung City Government which governs the islands have supported the plan.
Apart from existing infrastructure, facilities for desalination and garbage disposal system are still needed to support tourism, said Liu.

Liu expressed the hope that also other parts of the disputed Spratlys Islands will be jointly developed by claimant countries as a method to ease tensions in the area, said the Express. (by Amanda Chang)

DOC.HEADLINE: ECONOMICS MINISTER HEADS FOR MEETING IN INDONESIA

TEXT.P: Republic of China Economic Affairs Minister Wang Chih-kang will leave for Jakarta on Monday to attend an annual ministerial-level energy meeting between ROC and Indonesia.

A delegation composed of officials from the Energy Commission, the Industrial Development and Investment Center under the Ministry of Economic Affairs, as well as the state-run Taiwan Power Company (Taipower) and Chinese Petroleum Corp. will also take part in the ROC-Indonesia energy meeting, which will open on Monday and run through Thursday.
Taipower and its Indonesian counterpart are expected to sign a memorandum on technical cooperation during the four-day conference.

The annual ROC-Indonesia energy meeting has alternated between Taipei and Jakarta since 1990. Officials of the two countries will discuss and exchange opinions on bilateral cooperation during the annual gathering.
As the political situation remains uncertain in Indonesia, ROC officials will ask the Indonesian government take measures to better protect Taiwan business interests there.

Indonesia, which maintains close economic ties with Taiwan, is an important energy supplier to the country. Taiwan imported more than 100 million metric tons of both crude oil and coal from Indonesia last year.
Two-way trade totaled US$3.15 billion in 1998, with Taiwan suffering a deficit of US$1.5 billion, a result of the island's large energy imports from Indonesia.
Last year Taiwan businesses poured in US$162 billion in investment in to Indonesia, making the country one of Taiwan's major overseas investment targets.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies Monday are as follows:
The Central Daily News:
Former Democratic fund-raiser Johnny Chung told US federal investigators that the chief of mainland China's military intelligence secretly directed funds from Beijing to help President Bill Clinton's re-election bid in 1996.
The China Times:
The civil service examination system will undergo significant changes.
The United Daily News:
The United States will send attack helicopters to the Balkans.
The Liberty Times:
The ruling Kuomintang-owned business groups will invest in the Pratas Island.
The Commons Daily:
DPP Chairman Lin Yi-hsiung said he is pleased to see the ruling and opposition parties have similar policy toward rival mainland China.
The China Post: Witness says key PRC official directed funds to help US President Bill Clinton's 1996 re-election bid. @The China News:
Taiwan roads were jammed.

DOC.HEADLINE: SEMINAR ON TAIWAN INVESTMENT IN VIETNAM SHOWS RISKS REMAIN

TEXT.P: As Taiwan businessmen scramble to invest in Vietnam amid the nation's all-out, post-war economic development efforts, Taiwan businessmen wishing to invest there still face risks, Taiwan businessmen said Sunday at an investment seminar aimed at encouraging Taiwan investment in Vietnam.
The seminar was held by the Kaohsiung office of the China External Trade Development Council (CETRA).

The Republic of China is Vietnam's largest foreign investor, as Taiwan businessmen have invested a total of US$3 billion there. Bilateral economic and trade relations have been growing steadily as well.

But some Taiwan businessmen said Vietnam's infrastructure -- including its electrical, transportation and communications systems -- is insufficient. They also said that regulations governing investment and trade are inadequate and that some localities are governed by the rule-of-man instead of the rule-of-law.

With an area of 331,000 square kilometers, Vietnam lies in the eastern portion of the Indochina peninsula. Hanoi, Hai Phong, Ho Chi Minh City and Towrane are its main industrial and commercial centers.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC MINISTER LEAVES FOR INDONESIA FOR ENERGY MEETING

TEXT.P: Economics Minister Wang Chih-kang left for Jakarta on Monday to attend an annual ministerial-level energy meeting between the Republic of China and Indonesia.
Wang said prior to his departure that the ROC must maintain friendly relations with Indonesia as the Southeast Asian country is a major source of its energy supplies.

At present, Indonesia accounts for 30 percent of Taiwan's total coal imports and 60 percent of its petroleum gas imports. In 1998, Taiwan also imported 100 million metric tons of crude oil from that country.
Wang said he will take advantage of the annual meeting to explore possible cooperative projects with Indonesia in energy and other related economic fields.

A delegation of economics officials and senior executives from state-owned enterprises, including Taiwan Power Co. (Taipower) and Chinese Petroleum Corp., will also take part in the four-day meeting that began on Monday and will run through Thursday.

Wang said Taipower will sign a technological cooperative agreement with its Indonesian counterpart during the the annual conference. "The deal is not only aimed at helping Indonesia upgrade its energy technology but is also expected to stabilize our energy supplies," he noted.

The minister went on to say that Taiwan entrepreneurs have poured more than US$13.5 billion for various investment projects in Indonesia in the past few years, making Taiwan Indonesia's sixth largest foreign investor.
As Indonesia's political and economic situation changed dramatically in the past couple of years, Wang said he is concerned about Taiwan investors' operations there.

"I'll meet with senior executives and rank-and-file members of the Taiwanese chamber of commerce in Indonesia to collect first-hand information about the problems or difficulties facing our investors there," Wang said.

In addition to conveying Taiwan business people's opinion or their plight to the Indonesian government, Wang said he will also ask relevant Indonesian authorities to take effective measures to protect Taiwan investors' personal safety and their legitimate rights and interests.

Despite the absence of formal diplomatic ties, substantive ROC-Indonesian relations have been close. Two-way trade amounted to US$3.15 billion in 1998, with Taiwan suffering a deficit of US$1.5 billion, a result of the island's large energy imports from Indonesia.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Monday, April 5, or the 19th day of the second month of the Year of the Rabbit according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1793: President George Washington approves plans for new public buildings and roads in the American capital city.
1827: Joseph Lister, British surgeon and discoverer of antiseptic agents is born. He demonstrated in 1865 that carbolic acid was an effective antiseptic.
1896: The first modern Olympic Games begin in Athens.
1900: Spencer Tracy, American actor who won an Oscar two years running for "Captain Courageous" (1937) and "Boys Town" (1938), is born.
1915: Jack Johnson, the first black world heavyweight boxing champion, losses his title to the "Great White Hope" Jess Willard.
1949: The Chinese national government begins talks with Chinese communists.
1950: The Executive Yuan grants Taiwan authority to carry out self-government by popular elections in counties and cities within two months.
1951: Julius and Ethel Rosenberg are sentenced to death in the United States for giving away atomic secret to the Soviet Union.
1954: More than 14,000 Chinese communist POW's in Korea, who refused to return to the Chinese mainland, take their oath to join the ROC armed forces.
1955: British Prime Minister Sir Winston Churchill announces his resignation. He is succeeded by Foreign Secretary Sir Anthony Eden.
1964: Douglas MacArthur, American general who served as US chief of staff and commanded the Allied forces in the South Pacific during World War II, dies at the age of 84. He commanded UN forces in Korea until a conflict in strategies led to his dismissal by President Harry S. Truman.
1970: Count Carl von Spreti, West German ambassador to Guatemala, is found murdered six days after being kidnapping by guerrillas.
1975: President Chiang Kai-shek passes away in Taiwan at the age of 89.
1976: Howard Robard Hughes, American film producer, aviator, and multimillionaire, dies at the age of 71. He founded Hughes Aircraft Corporation, broke the airplane speed record in 1935 and flew around the world in record time in 1938.
1982: The British task force sets sail to oust Argentinian forces from the Falkland Islands.
1988: Arabic-speaking gunmen seize a Kuwait Airways Boeing 747 flying from Bangkok to Kuwait. The 111 hostages aboard were freed on April 20 when the hijackers surrendered in Algiers.
1989: A political pact between the independent trade union federation Solidarity and the government of Wojciech Jaruzelski ends communist rule in Poland.
1990: The Republic of China reestablishes diplomatic relations with the Kingdom of Lesotho. Peking (Beijing) severs ties with Lesotho two days later.
1994: Israel begins to withdraw from the Gaza Strip.
1998: Japan's 3,911 meter-long Akashi Kaikyo Bridge, the world's longest suspension bridge linking the main islands of Honshu and Shikoku, is opened to traffic.
Confucius's lesson of the day: "A good honest man, after educating the people for seven years, will be able to lead them to war."

DOC.HEADLINE: NEARLY US$1 BILLION PUMPED INTO LOCAL STOCK MARKET IN FIRST QUARTER

TEXT.P: Nearly US$1 billion in foreign funds were pumped into the domestic stock market in the first quarter of the year, the Central Bank of China (CBC) said on Monday.

CBC officials noted that foreign investors have turned their focus from Europe and the United States to financial markets in Asia, including Taiwan, Hong Kong and South Korea, since the beginning of the year.
The officials said the inflow has not only contributed to a brisk stock market, but has also helped stabilize the New Taiwan dollar.

Looking ahead to the second quarter, the officials noted that foreign money is still expected to flow into Taiwan's stock market in April and that this will help ensure that Taiwan's currency remains stable.
Officials said they hoped foreign money was not being invested in the domestic market merely to manipulate it and to undermine financial stability.
The CBC's Foreign Exchange Department said that it welcomes long-term investment in local stocks and that it provides incentives for such investment.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSSIE MPS GOING TO TIBET TO OBSERVE HUMAN RIGHTS SITUATION

TEXT.P: An 11-member parliamentary mission from Australia will make a weeklong trip to Lhasa and Shigatse in Tibet to gauge firsthand the region's human rights situation.

In a dispatch from Beijing, The Australian on Monday reported that the 11 members of parliament, led by Victorian Liberal Party MP Peter Nugent under the aegis of the Australia-China Parliamentary Friendship Group, arrived in the capital of mainland China on Sunday and that they will soon go to Tibet. Nugent heads the parliament's subcommittee on human rights.
The Australian MPs will meet with government leaders in Lhasa and will visit an Australian-funded water purification project in Shigatse.
The visit comes amid reports of a security crackdown in Tibet, coinciding with the 40th anniversary earlier this month of a failed uprising against mainland Chinese rule.
The daily reported that there are plainclothes police officers all over Lhasa, cameras on the roofs of buildings in an old part of the city and a very, very tense atmosphere.

Australia Tibet Council President Alex Butler said that mainland Chinese authorities have introduced new regulations that forbid overseas visitors to Lhasa from leaving their hotels unless they are accompanied by official guides.

The daily reported that, like all international delegations to Tibet, the Australian delegation is expected to have very little access to ordinary Tibetans and to have their movements severely curtailed by their hosts.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLAND DISSIDENT BARRED FROM RETURNING HOME
DOC.DATELINE: Hong Kong, April 5 (CNA) (By Stanley Cheung and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Mainland Chinese pro-democracy dissident Wang Xizhe was prevented from returning to Beijing from his exile in the United States and instead had to take a flight to Bangkok, Thailand to wait for a second chance to return home.

An official of the Information Center of Human Rights and Democratic Movement in China said that Wang, who boarded an Asiana Airline flight from New York Saturday evening, had planned to arrive in Beijing via Seoul, South Korea, on Monday.

The official said the Asiana office in Seoul had refused to let Wang board the flight for Beijing Monday morning. He quoted sources as saying that Beijing had warned the airline that if Wang was allowed to board the plane, it would have to bear all consequences.
Wang expressed his displeasure to the Asiana Airline for depriving him of the right to return home, the official said.
The official added that four dissidents who had planned to meet Wang at Beijing airport were taken away by police.

Wang, a former factory worker, was sentenced to 14 years in prison for what the Beijing authorities called "counter-revolutionary" activities, but was released two years early in 1993. He has since been jailed periodically for parole violations.

Wang, who fled to the United States in Oct. 1996, had planned to return home to go to his father's tomb, who died in February of this year, for Tomb-Sweeping Day, the traditional day for the Chinese to pay respects to their ancestors and clean the environment around their tombs.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIAN ENGINEERS SEE STRUCTURAL PROBLEM WITH BOEING 737S

TEXT.P: Australian engineers have identified a structural problem with Boeing 737 jets, saying it can seriously compromise safety, and both Ansett Australia and Qantas Airways are inspecting their aircraft to ensure that they are safe.

The Australian on Monday quoted engineers from the Civil Aviation Safety Authority (CASA) as warning of the landing gear defect -- which can damage control cables, structural components and hydraulic lines -- to Australian operators, the manufacturer and the US Federal Aviation Administration.
CASA has also issued an urgent air worthiness directive calling for major inspections of Australian aircraft.
CASA said the Boeing 737 is one of the world's most popular airliners with almost 3,000 in service worldwide and more than 60 operating in Australia, the daily reported.

It said the defect came to light after the crew of an Ansett 737-300, traveling from Launceston in Tasmania to Melbourne in Victoria last March, heard a loud thump when they extended the landing gear.

The plane landed without incident, and a brief inspection failed to reveal the cause of the thump. Nonetheless, Ansett, the second largest airline operator in Australia, removed the aircraft from service. A more detailed inspection revealed that a component in the right landing gear, called the actuator beam arm, had fractured.
Qantas is also investigating its fleet of Boeing 737s, according to the Bureau of Air Safety Investigation, which subsequently found the fractures were due to a combination of stress and corrosion.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI MAYOR MA VISITS SINGLE VETERANS

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou used a visit to 150 elderly single veterans in Taipei on Monday to say the government should strengthen its care of elderly men.
Braving drizzle on the Chinese traditional Tomb-Sweeping Day, Mayor Ma arrived at the veterans' residence at Fang Lan mountain village.

Ma was warmly greeted by the veterans upon his arrival. After listening to their stories of living conditions and visiting their facilities, Ma said the government must improve the veterans' living environment and facilities.

Ma said the government should formulate a plan to solve how to care for elderly single veterans and all other elderly men who need care as soon as possible, because at present, an average of seven to eight people care for one aged man in the Taiwan area. After 30 years that average is expected to drop to three people doing the same job due to an explosion in the aged population. Ma emphasized the government should attach great importance to the issue.
In addition to Ma's visit to Fang Lan mountain village, several charity groups were present donating daily necessities and food, warming the veterans' hearts.

DOC.HEADLINE: EVEN AMID BAD TIMES, GAMBLING CONTINUES IN SINGAPORE

TEXT.P: The economy has plunged into recession, bonuses have evaporated, salaries have shrunk and more than 29,000 jobs have been lost, but this has not dampened Singaporeans' passion for gambling.
They parted with more than S$5.5 billion (US$3.2 billion) last year on legalized gambling alone.
But the economic crisis has left its mark. Instead of the hefty jumps in takings seen in the last few years, growth last year was negligible.

Gambling houses took in S$4.2 billion in 1995, S$5 billion in 1996 and S$5.5 billion in 1997, but last year's takings were about the same as in 1997, judging by the amount of tax on the takings collected by the government. In 1997 the government collected S$1.26 billion from gambling-related revenue and the same amount last year.
Singapore's favorite game of chance is 4-D, with last year's takings topping S$3 billion. Horse racing came second, at more than S$1 billion.
Although the economy is not expected to do much better this year, takings for gambling could swell.
The government expects people to wager an extra S$250 million this year on legalized football betting, which began last week.
That could push spending on gambling this year close to the S$6 billion mark, provided the deadly viral outbreak in Malaysia and Singapore does not disrupt the horse-racing calendar.
While local legal gambling appears to be holding its own amid the current recession, it is less clear how the industry's "gray" market is faring.
This market includes the gambling dollars that flow offshore to casinos in Genting Highlands, Australia and other places, and cruise ships anchored off Singapore.

With police action against illegal 4-D syndicates squeezing "black" money and the recession-induced slide in travel shrinking the amount of "gray" money being generated, greater growth could be seen in legal local gambling.

DOC.HEADLINE: LATE PRESIDENT CHIANG'S DEATH ANNIVERSARY MARKED

TEXT.P: President Lee Teng-hui, heading senior government officials, paid a visit to the late President Chiang Kai-shek's mausoleum in Tzuhu, Taoyuan county on Monday to mark the 24th anniversary of Chiang's passing.

President Lee laid a wreath before Chiang's mausoleum and made three bows to express his tribute to the late national leader. He then observed a minute of silence and afterwards led all participating officials in circling the mausoleum in remembrance of the late president.
Generalissimo Chiang died on April 5, 1975. April 5 is also the traditional Chinese Tomb-Sweeping Day.

Later in the day, President Lee and other senior government officials also paid a visit to the late President Chiang Ching-kuo's mausoleum in Touliao, also in Taoyuan county, some 40 kilometers south of Taipei.

The officials included Vice President Lien Chan, Premier Vincent Siew, National Assembly Speaker Su Nan-cheng, Legislative Yuan President Wang Chin-ping, Control Yuan President Fredrick Chien and Chief of the General Staff Tang Yao-ming.
Braving chilly wind and drizzling rain, many people made long lines in front of the Tzuhu and Touliao mausoleums for paying tribute to the two late presidents.

The pro-unification New Party mobilized more than 500 members and supporters to visit the two Chiangs' mausoleums. The New Party group was led by Legislator Lee Ching-hua, convener of the New Party All-Out Development Commission.

Some New Party supporters clashed with police because they were barred from entering the Tzuhu mausoleum when senior government officials were paying homage to Generalissimo Chiang. The clash ended soon and no injuries were reported.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN RELATIONS ACT HELPS MAINTAIN STABILITY IN W. PACIFIC (I)

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Relations Act (TRA), a unique law of the United States enacted 20 years ago, is being seen by officials and scholars of the United States and Taiwan as useful and important in maintaining peace and stability in the Western Pacific.

Stanley Roth, assistant secretary of state for East Asian and Pacific affairs, told the U.S. Senate Foreign Relations Committee in late March that the United States' accomplishments of the TRA was "very great," and that the United States will continue to honor its commitment to the security of Taiwan as stated in the act.

The TRA, which was passed by U.S. Congress in March, 1979 and signed into law by former President Jimmy Carter on April 10, 1979, states that it is aimed at helping "maintain peace, security, and stability in the Western Pacific" and promoting the foreign policy of the United States by authorizing the continuation of commercial, cultural, and other relations with Taiwan.

The enactment of the TRA was prompted by the Carter administration's decision to switch diplomatic recognition from Taipei to Beijing on Jan. 1, 1979. It authorized the establishment in 1979 of the American Institute in Taiwan (AIT), a non-governmental organization, to take care of US interests in the absence of diplomatic relations with Taipei.

It says in Section 2 that it is the policy of the United States to declare that peace and stability in the Western Pacific area are "in the political, security, and economic interests of the United States, and are matters of international concern."

It adds that it is the policy of the United States to make clear that the US decision to establish diplomatic relations with Beijing "rests upon the expectation that the future of Taiwan will be determined by peaceful means."

"It is the policy of the United States to consider any effort to determine the future of Taiwan by other than peaceful means, inclusing by boycotts or embargoes, a threat to the peace and security of the Western Pacific area, and of grave concern to the United States," the TRA says, adding that it is the policy of the United States to provide Taiwan with arms of a defensive character "to enable it to maintain a sufficient self-defense capability."

The act also states that it is the policy of the United States to maintain its capacity "to resist any resort to force or other forms of coercion that would jeopardize the security, or the social or economic system, of the people on Taiwan."

Roth said in the Congressional hearing that the United States continues to insist that the differences between mainland China and Taiwan be resolved peacefully, and that the US position on this point was clearly shown in March, 1996, when President Bill Clinton sent two carrier battle groups to the waters near Taiwan in response to mainland China's provocative missile-firing tests in the Taiwan Strait.
In a seminar cosponsored by AIT and the Woodrow Wilson Center in Washington on March 24, Roth also said, "I have no hesitation in declaring the TRA a resounding success."

Over the past 20 years, the TRA has not only helped to preserve the substance of US relationship with Taiwan but also contributed to the conditions which have enabled the United States, mainland China, and Taiwan "to achieve a great deal more," he added. (more)

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN RELATIONS ACT HELPS MAINTAIN STABILITY IN W. PACIFIC (II)

TEXT.P: Roth said the fact that Washington-Taipei relations are unofficial has not harmed Taiwan's interests.

The TRA stipulates that "the absence of diplomatic relations or recognition shall not affect the application of the laws of the United States with respect to Taiwan, and the laws of the United States shall apply with respect to Taiwan in the manner that the laws of the United States applied with respect to Taiwan prior to Jan. 1, 1979."
The act also states that the US Congress approves the continuation in force of all treaties and other international agreements, including multilateral conventions, entered into by the two countries.

The properties of Taiwan in the United States are also protected under the act, which stipulates that "Recognition of the People's Republic of China shall not affect in any way the ownership of or other rights or interests in properties, tangible and intangible, and other things of value, owned or held on or prior to Dec. 31, 1978, or thereafter acquired or earned by the governing authorities on Taiwan."

Roth said that Taiwan's political transformation into democracy over the past two decades has been profound, and that the shelter of the TRA, made real by each successive US administration's commitment to its provisions, helped make this transformation possible.
He further said that, although the United States will continue to provide Taiwan with defensive weapons, "sustained peace does not rely on military strength but on dialogue and consultations."

Assistant Secretary of Defense for International Security Affairs Franklin Kramer said in the same Congressional hearing that "We take our obligations to assist Taiwan in maintaining a self-defense capability very seriously."
"We do so not only because it is mandated by US law in the TRA, but also because it is in our own national interest," he added.
Roth and Kramer made the remarks in the Congressional hearing on the 20th anniversary of the enactment of the TRA, which falls on April 10.

In addition to the Congressional hearing, the House of Representatives adopted on March 23 by an overwhelming 429-1 vote a concurrent resolution, calling on the US government to reaffirm its commitment to the TRA and specifically to the guarantees that the United States will provide adequate defensive weapons to Taiwan.

The resolution also says that the United States should seek from mainland Chinese leaders a public renunciation of any use of force, and of the threat to use force, against Taiwan. The Senate Foreign Relations Committee passed on the same day a similar resolution.The resolutions also said that it should be US policy, in accordance with the TRA, to publicly support Taiwan's admission to such world bodies as the World Trade Organization and the World Health Organization.

Rep. Benjamin Gilman (R-N.Y.), chairman of the House International Relations Committee, said the TRA has been instrumental in maintaining peace, security, and stability in the Taiwan Strait since its enactment 20 year ago.

Fredrick Chien, president of the Control Yuan, also said in a recent interview with the CNA that the TRA has contributed greatly to the maintenance of stability in Taiwan and the Western Pacific area. (more)

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN RELATIONS ACT HELPS MAINTAIN STABILITY IN W. PACIFIC (III)

TEXT.P: Chien was vice foreign minister when Washington broke diplomatic relations with Taipei. He later served as representative in Washington of Taiwan's Coordination Council for North American Affairs (CCNAA), which was the counterpart of AIT.
He said the TRA has remained unchanged in both content and importance. "Some people believe the TRA should be amended, but we believe it is better not to change it," he said.

Chien, who had served as foreign minister and later president of the National Assembly before his present post, said the relationship between the United States and Taiwan is different from US relationships with any other country, "because our relationship is regulated by the TRA, a US law."

It is important now to make all US lawmakers familiar with the unique character of the US-Taiwan relationship, because 85 percent of the members of 1979 US Congress have been replaced by new faces, Chien said.

Chen Chien-jen, director general of the Government Information Office, said recently in an interview with the CNA that the TRA has enhanced the security and prosperity of Taiwan and the peace and stability of the Asia-Pacific region.

Chen, who was a young diplomat privy to the development of the legislation at the time in Washington, said that the TRA "displays the justice-pursuing spirit of US foreign policy," and that it is unprecedented in the history of international relations and international law.

He stressed that the TRA has played a very important role in the past two decades, and that it has laid a solid foundation for the development of friendly relations between the United States and Taiwan.

James Lilley, former US ambassador to mainland China, said in Washington in early March that, for the past 20 years, the TRA has been successful in strengthening security relationships between the United States and Taiwan.
Lilley, who has also served as director of AIT in Taipei, also said Taiwan still enjoys bipartisan support in US Congress despite generational changes over the past two decades.

To help make US lawmakers more familiar with the unique character of the relationship between the two countries, Taiwan's representative office in Washington is organizing celebrations to highlight the 20th anniversary of the enactment of the TRA. One of them is a cocktail reception to be co-hosted by Stephen Chen, Taiwan's representative in Washington, and several Congressional heavyweights on April 13.

A large-scale seminar on topics concerning the TRA will be jointly held in Washington on the next day by two prestigious think tanks-- the American Enterprise Institute and the Heritage Foundation. Sen. Jesse Helms (R-N.C.), chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee; former AIT chairman David Dean; Sen. Murkowski (R-Alaska), and Lester L. Wolff, a retired lawmaker who played a key role in the drafting of the act, are expected to take part in the seminar. Chien, Chen, and several Taiwan scholars are also expected to attend the seminar.

DOC.HEADLINE: BETEL NUT CHEWING COULD BE POISONOUS

TEXT.P: Despite the fact that betel nut chewing is popular in Taiwan, few of those who put "Taiwan's gum" in their mouths realize the substance is poisonous, the Veterans General Hospital said on Monday.
Doctors at the hospital reported that they have observed at least 10 poisoning cases over the past decade, with one patient dying before reaching a hospital.
The doctors reported their findings in the latest medical publication of the hospital.

They documented a case of a 42-year-old man, who despite not regularly chewing betel nuts, developed dizziness, sweating, heart palpitations, and vomiting after eating a "betel nut king." His conditions only improved after treatment.
A betel nut king, has the same appearance as an ordinary betel nut but with twice as much alkaline. Every betel nut tree produces up to four betel nut kings.

Another 21-year-old man, who developed numbness in his limbs, bulging eyes and lips, was told by physicians that he was not suffering an allergic reaction to drugs or being inflicted by an illness. Instead, they determined that his condition was the result of betel nut chewing.
The Veterans General Hospital doctors said that there are various kinds of alkaline substances in betel nuts. In its production process, other substances are added, including many carcinogens.
As most cases of betel nut poisoning are not serious, they are generally neglected or left unreported, they said.

The doctors added that the amount of poison in betel nuts needed to adversely affect a chewer varies from one to another. But they cautioned betel nut users to remember that a small amount could result in poisoning.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER FUND-RAISER CLAIMS BEIJING SOUGHT TO INFLUENCE 1996 ELECTION

TEXT.P: The chief of mainland China's military intelligence secretly directed funds from Beijing to help re-elect President Clinton in 1996, former Democratic fund-raiser Johnny Chung has told federal investigators.
The Los Angeles Times on Sunday carried an investigative report that indicated Chung's testimony links top Beijing officials to secretly directed funds for Clinton's re-election campaign.

Chung said he met three times with the intelligence official, Gen. Ji Shengde, who ordered US$300,000 deposited into a bank account for subsidized campaign donations intended for Clinton, according to sources familiar with Chung's sealed statements to federal prosecutors.
During their initial meeting on Aug. 11, 1996, in Hong Kong, Ji conveyed to Chung the Beijing regime's specific interest in supporting Clinton:

"We like your president," Ji said, according to sources familiar with Chung's grand jury testimony. Chung testified that he was introduced to the intelligence chief by the daughter of a retired senior military officer.

Chung's testimony has provided investigators the first direct link between a senior mainland Chinese official and illicit foreign contributions that were funneled into Clinton's 1996 re-election effort. It is the strongest evidence to emerge in two years of federal investigations that the highest levels of the Beijing regime sought to influence the US election.
But key aspects of Chung's testimony have not been corroborated by financial records in the United States and Hong Kong, according to law enforcement and other sources.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER ROC PREMIER SAYS HE HAS NO PLANS TO SETTLE ON MAINLAND

TEXT.P: Former ROC Premier Hau Pei-tsun said on Monday that he has no plans to settle in mainland China, according to reports from the mainland.
Hau is currently on a 10-day visit to his ancestral home in the eastern mainland province of Jiangsu in the company of his wife, two grown-up sons and a granddaughter.
This is Hau's first mainland trip since he moved to Taiwan in 1949 after the Chinese communists took control of the mainland.
Hau was quoted by local newspapers as saying in his hometown of Ynecheng that he has never considered returning to the mainland for settlement.

"I don't think it is necessary to resettle on the mainland," Hau said, adding that he may make occasional visits to the mainland in the future simply for reminding the younger generations not to forget their roots.
Hau, an anti-Communist stalwart, said he believes as long as all Chinese people do not forget their roots, it will be helpful to the solidarity and unity of the Chinese race.
Hau, a former military chief who retired from the ROC government as premier in 1993, said he is concerned about economic and educational development on both sides of the Taiwan Strait.
"I think universal education is key to mainland China's bid to modernize its economy and upgrade the quality of life of its people," said the 79-year-old former ROC premier.

Hau and his family paid a visit to his parents' grave on Monday morning. An emotional Hau reportedly broke into tears when he knelt down and kowtowed to his parents' tombstone. Hau last visited his hometown 61 years ago as a graduate of an army academy before taking part in the Eight-Year War of Resistance against Japan.
Hau also paid a visit to the grave of ROC national founding father Dr. Sun Yat-sen in Nanjing on Sunday. "As a follower of Dr. Sun, I should come here," he explained.

During his low-profile, nostalgic mainland trip, Hau will visit Fenghua in Zhejiang province, hometown of the two late ROC presidents -- Chiang Kai-shek and Chiang Ching-kuo. Hau served as chief of the General Staff and defense minister during the terms of the two Chiangs.

Hau is also scheduled to meet with mainland China's top negotiator with Taiwan, Wang Daohan, in Shanghai on April 9. Hau said prior to his departure that he hopes to exchange views with Wang on feasible ways to promote civilian exchanges across the Taiwan Strait to help maintain regional peace and stability.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC ARMY BEREAVED FAMILY SCHOOL ALUMNI CONGRATULATE MME CHIANG
DOC.DATELINE: New York, April 4 (CNA) (By David Wang and David Hsu)

TEXT.P: Eighteen alumni of the Republic of China's Nationalist Revolutionary Army bereaved family school gathered in New York on Sunday to congratulate Mme Chiang Kai-shek on her recent 102nd birthday.

Led by Hsiang Hou-lu, president of the North American chapter of the alumni association, the delegation went to Mme Chiang's residence in Manhattan, New York City, to belatedly celebrate her March 29 birthday.
The alumni sang a hymn and recited the 23th Psalm to Mme Chiang. They then donated a congratulatory calligraphy to her.

Addressing the gathering, Hsiang thanked the late President Chiang Kai-shek and Mme Chiang for their founding of the bereaved family school and favors they have bestowed on alumni of the school over the years. The 18 alumni representatives also presented a mirror with the logo of the bereaved family school and congratulatory words on it.
Mme Chiang happily received the "old boys" , who are 60-70 years old. After the alumni wished her a happy birthday through song, Mme Chiang shared birthday cake and shook hands with each of them.
Alumni representatives of the bereaved family school meet annually on Mme Chiang's birthday.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT LEE'S MONTHLY SALARY 1.5 TIMES CLINTON'S

TEXT.P: ROC President Lee Teng-hui's monthly salary reached an average of NT$834,636 (US$25,292) last year, about 20 times that of an average salaried man here, according to a survey by the Hong Kong-based Chinese weekly Yazhou Zhoukan.
The survey showed that Lee's monthly salary was 1.5 times that of US President Bill Clinton, but only about 65 percent of the top Singapore leader's.

Based on the findings of the Yazhou Zhoukan survey, the ROC's Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) said although salary levels in most Asian countries declined last year because of regional financial turmoil, salaries of top leaders of Hong Kong, Japan, Singapore and Taiwan were still higher than that of their American counterpart.

According to a report carried in the latest issue of the CEPD-sponsored International Economic Situation Weekly, the US head of state's monthly salary was equivalent to NT$550,011 in 1998, based on an exchange rate of US$1 vs. NT$33.
In terms of the same exchange rate, the top Hong Kong leader's 1998 monthly pay was about NT$1.15 million, compared to Japan's NT$1.04 million and Singapore's NT$1.28 million.

Quoting the Yazhou Zhoukan survey, the CEPD weekly further said South Korea far lagged behind its Asian competitors in its general pay levels. The South Korean head of state made about NT$207,801 a month last year, only one-sixth of monthly salaries of his Singaporean, Hong Kong and Japanese counterparts.
The South Korean president's monthly salary was only higher than mainland Chinese leader's, which stood at NT$3,399 last year, according to the report.

An interesting finding was that Taiwan's white-collar employees in various professional fields generally made less money than their American counterparts, but its president's salary was much higher than the US president's.
The Yazhou Zhoukan survey also found that a medical doctor could make an average of NT$185,000 a month in Taiwan last year, while the monthly earning of a Taiwan lawyer was about NT$203,000.
The average monthly pay for a Taiwan bank executive was NT$112,000, but Taiwan's top banker -- governor of the Central Bank of China could only earn about NT$169,000 a month.

A local technician could make an average of NT$142,000 a month, while the monthly salary for a national university professor was only about NT$94,000, according to the survey. And the average monthly pay for local journalists stood at NT$68,000.

Survey results further showed that the industrial and commercial sector was the most lucrative profession in Taiwan. In 1998, the average monthly salary for the chief executive officer reached NT$402,000 and that for a professional manager also amounted to NT$223,000.
The average monthly pay for a computer software programmer was US$66,000 and those in the secretarial jobs could make an average of NT$44,000 a month.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN BUSINESSES RESERVED ABOUT INVESTING IN AFRICA

TEXT.P: Despite the fact that Africa is a diplomatic stronghold of the Republic of China, Taiwan businesses appear reluctant to invest there.
Taiwan maintains formal diplomatic ties with 27 nations around the world, many of which are African countries.

Although it is a government wish that the local business community would cooperate with it in breaking into that part of the world, Taiwan investments remain limited in that continent compared to the amount poured into other continents.

"Africa, a virgin land rife with investment and business opportunities, only waits for ambitious and courageous pioneers," said Michael K.M. Wei, deputy director-general of the Board of Foreign Trade (BOFT).
"Africa is a promising market for many sectors. Its natural resources, such as timber, coal, cotton and cocoa beans, are cheap and of good quality," the BOFT official noted.

Two-way trade between Taiwan and Africa totaled US$3.41 billion in 1998, down 20.6 percent from 1997, ROC government statistics show. Taiwan exported US$1.45 billion-worth of products and services to Africa last year, down 4.9 percent from the year-earlier level, while imports from African countries hit around US$1.96 billion, a fall of 20.6 percent from a year ago.

South Africa is Taiwan's leading trading partner in Africa, followed by Egypt, according to the same tallies. Taiwan exports to South Africa and Egypt reached US$600 million and US$213 million in 1998, accounting for 44.7 percent and 15.7 percent, respectively, of the country's total outbound shipments to that continent.

The island's five other major export markets in Africa are Nigeria, Liberia, Mauritius, Morocco, and Tunisia. The seven countries together absorbed 83.2 percent of Taiwan's overall exports to the continent, while on the other hand, South Africa is also Taiwan's leading source of imports in Africa, the statistics indicate.

South Africa exported US$700 million-worth of goods and services to Taiwan last year, accounting for 38.41 percent of the island's total inbound shipments from Africa. Angora ranked second, exporting more than US$300 million-worth of goods, or 16.58 percent of the total, followed by Congo, Nigeria, Cameroon, and Ivory Coast.
Imports from these six African countries to Taiwan made up nearly 90 percent of Africa's total shipments to the island.
In the meantime, South Africa is also the African country which has attracted the largest number -- 624 -- of Taiwan businesses to set up footholds there.

The ROC provided considerable economic aid to South Africa, once a strong ROC diplomatic ally in Africa, during the period of the US-led trade sanctions against it, prompting many Taiwan businesses to invest there.
Although Pretoria switched its diplomatic recognition from Taipei to Beijing in 1997, two-way substantive ties between Taiwan and South Africa remain close.

There are currently about 280 Taiwan businesses operating in South Africa, most of which are in the garment and shoe-making industries, while the rest are involved in the retail business, import-export trade, and tourism sectors.

But with the rapid deterioration in South Africa's public order and security in recent years, Wei said many Taiwan companies with operations in that country have expressed the wish to relocate their factories to other countries in the region.

During a working meeting sponsored by the Ministry of Foreign Affairs with its personnel stationed in Africa last month, several South Africa-based Taiwan businessmen voiced their desire to relocate their plants, Wei pointed out, adding that the ROC government will work out special measures to help them shift their investments.

The Ministry of Economic Affairs, meanwhile, is organizing a fact-finding delegation to visit Senegal, Burkina Faso, Gambia and Liberia in late May in the hope of seeking trade and investment opportunities for Taiwan firms, Wei added.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER DPP CHAIRMAN HSU TO MEET NEW ERA FACTION HEAD CHANG

TEXT.P: Former Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) chairman and presidential hopeful Hsu Hsin-liang will pay a visit on Tuesday to Chang Chun-hung, convener of the party's New Era faction, against the backdrop that several factions within the DPP are hoping that Hsu will remain in the party.

The possibility that Hsu might quit the DPP and run as an independent has become a dilemma for the opposition party. The office of the New Era faction is seeking the help of more than 20 DPP Legislators to stop Hsu from quitting the party.

In addition, the DPP Central Committee called on party members to persuade Hsu not to quit. The DPP's party congress is scheduled to convene on May 8 leading to speculation that if Hsu is to quit, he will announce it prior to the congress.

Huang Hsin-chien, former DPP chairman, predicted that Hsu would not quit. However, Hsu stressed recently that he must consider whether the DPP has fostered new values, a new way of thinking, as well as defining a new historical mission.
Hsu was disappointed with the DPP's failure to transform itself, and has since contemplated his future relations with the party.
The DPP's existing party platform contains a "four-year clause" which states that a member may only run once for a major public office within a four-year period.

Accordingly, since former Taipei mayor Chen Shui-bian, the DPP's heavy-weight personality, ran for Taipei mayor last year, he should not be able to seek the presidency next year, according to that clause. However, since he is the only one within the party likely to win the presidency, DPP officials are inclined to abolish the so-called four-year clause.
Party headquarters plan a vote on the four-year clause at the May congress, despite dissent.

Complicating matters is the fact that members of the procedures sub-committee, its spokesman and its preparatory sub-committee as well as emergency sub-committee conveners are all Chen supporters. The only exception is the New Era faction's convener Chang, who has remained neutral.

Former DPP chairman Yao Chia-wen has proposed revising the "four-year one option clause" with a "four-year two options clause" in regard to election bids for president, vice president, party chairman and mayor of Taipei or Kaohsiung--Taiwan's two largest cities.
Hsu's office staff said on Monday that Yao's proposal would not have much influence on Hsu's decision.

Some DPP's Legislators affiliated with the New Tide faction suggested holding a policy seminar prior to the opening of the DPP party congress, to allow Chen and Hsu an opportunity to debate party policy, how to implement it and how they see the future.
Former DPP chairman Huang wondered the feasibility of the debate because the party has not yet nominated a presidential candidate.

The Five-member Sub-committee of the Formosan Faction is scheduled to meet on Saturday to discuss activities for the 20th anniversary of the Kaohsiung Formosa Magazine Incident. It is not known whether the sensitive issue of Hsu's quitting will be discussed at the gathering.
Members of the sub-committee include: former DPP chairmen Shih Ming-teh, Hsu Hsin-liang, Chang Chun-hung (acting chairman for a short period), Yao Chia-wen, and the incumbent chairman Lin Yi-hsiung.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAKE-UP MEASURES NEEDED TO OFFSET REVENUE DEFICIT

TEXT.P: President Lee Teng-hui has recently asked the government to take make-up measures to offset declining government revenues while introducing tax reduction program, Cabinet source said on Monday.
The economic recession and reduction in certain types of taxation has led to a decline in government revenue for 1999, and a serious deficit has appeared, according to Lee.

In order to avoid any further widening of the deficit, Lee said that any administrative departments mulling downward tax adjustments to provide stimulus to certain industries should provide substitute measures that can cover the resultant revenue insufficiency.
All levels of government that are involved in revising regulations which will reduce government revenue should also ponder make-up plans, he said.

According to the Executive Yuan, many administrative departments have set up tax-reduction schemes to boost stalled development in certain industries. The reduction of business tax for the banking industry and the cutting of the share transaction tax are the most prominent examples.
These considerable reductions have lowered tax revenue to less than 60 percent, putting a heavy burden on the government's finances.
Extra annual expenditure of up to NT$30 billion from this year to subsidize the new national pension scheme has further added to the need for revenue make-up plans.

The establishment of a bond foundation would be a feasible and proper way of helping the government to raise revenue, said Lee, adding that experts should be hired to assist the government in asset management.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC OFFICIALS STAND BY PRATAS INVESTMENT PLAN

TEXT.P: Ministry of the Interior officials on Monday adopted a positive stance on a plan by the ruling Kuomintang to invest in the Pratas islands, a group of islets in the South China Sea.

The officials said investing in the Pratas, also known as the Tungsha islands, can reassert ROC sovereignty over the territory, as well as providing a boost to tourism, although several issues, such as water supplies and desalination, would pose thorny problems, they said.

Meanwhile, a spokesman for the Ministry of National Defense (MND) said during a regular news briefing that his ministry will stay abreast of any government moves to develop resources in the South China Sea region.
However, he declined to confirm recent reports that the proposed investment project has gained MND approval, saying only that the ministry is studying the issue.
Tungsha Island, the largest of the archipelago, is a horseshoe-shaped coral atoll measuring about 100 square kilometers, with about 168 hectares lying above sea level.
ROC military facilities cover the island, which lies about 450 km southwest of Kaohsiung, southern Taiwan. There is also a runway to allow the island to be resupplied by air.
Other establishments on the windswept island include a weather station, power generator, hostels for fishermen, and a reservoir with a capacity of 100,000 gallons of fresh water.
Mainland China also claims the Pratas islands.

According to reports, Liu Tai-ying, director of the KMT's Business Management Committee and chairman of the KMT-owned China Development Corp. (CDC), has won the support of ROC President and KMT Chairman Lee Teng-hui for a proposal for the CDC to invest more than NT$100 million (US$3.02 million) in developing the islands into a tourist resort.

In his plan, Liu also recommends that Taipei should invite Washington, Tokyo and Beijing to join in efforts to develop the disputed area, saying that resource sharing is the best way to settle thorny sovereignty disputes in a region believed to be rich in oil and gas.

In addition to Taiwan and mainland China, Brunei, Malaysia, the Philippines and Vietnam all claim sovereignty over territory in the South China Sea. The most bitter dispute centers on the Spratly Islands, located to the south of the Pratas.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SEEKING CLOSER TIES WITH POLAND, CZECH AND HUNGARY
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 5 (CNA) (By L.R. Yen and Wendy Chung)

TEXT.P: After its success in forging diplomatic relations with Macedonia, the ROC is seeking to enhance its substansive relations with Poland, the Czech Republic and Hungary.

The successful development of Taiwan's small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) will be the principal medium through which it hopes to promote closer ties, a Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) official said recently, adding that there is a need to allay a commonly held belief that the ROC has "bought" its diplomatic ties with its poorer African and Latin American allies.

The government should not only help foster a better understanding of the country's diplomatic situation, but also develop genuine "mutually beneficial" relationships with its potential allies, he said.
After the breakdown of communism in Europe, former socialist countries faced urgent problems with economic development and unemployment.
Poland, the Czech Republic and Hungary wish to emulate the ROC's experience in the development of SMEs, credited with bringing about Taiwan's "economic miracle," in their own economic development.

Instead of making frequent claims of "promoting substantial relations," MOFA will extend the ROC's diplomatic relations through "experience sharing" to benefit prospective allies with practical results, according to MOFA officials.

MOFA and the Chung Hua Institute for Economic Research held a joint SME seminar for economic, trade and finance officials from the three central European countries in February, and received a positive response, while MOFA announced recently that beginning in July, ROC economic and trade offices will begin a series of activities to promote trade and relations with eastern Europe.

The Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) and MOFA is also slated to hold a business exhibition targeted at Poland, the Czech Republic, Hungary and Latvia, while the China External Trade Development Council (CETRA) will form a large-scale economic and trade delegation to visit these countries in July.
Taiwan offered Poland a US$20 million SME management loan in January, which the Polish government will use for its SME policy development.
Polish Vice Economics Minister Bernard Blaszczyk expressed gratitude towards Taiwan's SME investments in Poland, and also thanked Taiwan for its care and help in training Poland's developing SMEs.
The MOFA officials pointed out that if Taiwan can build more friendships with the rest of Europe through central and eastern Europe, this would greatly benefit the country's international relations.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLAND CHINA DISSIDENT WANG XIZHE ARRIVES IN THAILAND
DOC.DATELINE: Bangkok, April 5 (CNA) (By Kuo Fang-chih and Amanda Chang)

TEXT.P: Mainland Chinese dissident Wang Xizhe arrived in Bangkok on Monday after being expelled from South Korea while trying to return to mainland China, sources reported.

Wang walked out of Bangkok airport displaying a poster reading "right of return to homeland cannot be deprived." He told the media that he had already braced himself for possible detention by the Beijing authorities as he has spent 15 years in political detention in the mainland.
Wang was planning to return to his homeland to visit the tomb of his farther who died in February, but his plan was frustrated by the Seoul authorities, who threw him out of the country.

He told a CNA reporter he regretted not being able to pay his last respects to his father, but said he will try again to apply for travel documents to legally enter the mainland. Currently he holds US-issued refugee travel documents.
He did not say how long he intends to stay in Thailand, but added that he did not expect to be expelled, as he had been granted legal entry by the Thai authorities.
Wang, a former factory worker, launched his career as an activist when he wrote several big character anti-government wall posters in 1974.

In 1981, he was sentenced to 14 years in prison for what the Beijing authorities called "counter-revolutionary" activities. He served 12 years and was released in 1993. He has since been jailed periodically for parole violations.
Wang fled the mainland in 1996 after Beijing arrested and sentenced another activist, Liu Xiaobo. Wang first surfaced in Hong Kong and later went to the San Francisco area.

DOC.HEADLINE: DGOP TO INVEST IN CROSS-STRAIT EXPRESS DELIVERY SERVICE

TEXT.P: The Directorate General of Posts (DGOP) has received official approval for a project to establish a company which will operate a cross-Taiwan Strait express delivery service, the United Daily News reported on Monday.

The newspaper said the DGOP under the Ministry of Transportation and Communications, along with China Airlines and another six private businesses including EVA Airways, TransAsia Airways and Hsinchu Cargo Transport, have agreed to jointly set up China Express Corp., aimed at exploiting the cross-strait market.
The DGOP will take a 45 percent stake of the cooperation venture, for an investment of NT$200 million (US$6.06 billion), and will name a chairman to run the business.

China Express is expected to begin operations at the end of this year to provide air express services between Taiwan and mainland China via a third country or area, the report added, noting that the company is planning to open offices in Taipei, Hsinchu, Taichung, Tainan, and Kaohsiung.

DOC.HEADLINE: ARATS CHIEF CONFIRMS TAIPEI VISIT IN SEPTEMBER OR OCTOBER

TEXT.P: Mainland China's top negotiator with Taiwan confirmed on Monday that he will visit the island in September or October this year.

Wang Daohan, chairman of the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS), made the remark at a meeting in Shanghai with delegates of a visiting right-wing group from Taiwan, said delegate leader Chen Chih-chi in a telephone interview with CNA.

Wang said that he has set his Taiwan trip for the coming autumn as a visit before that time would cause "unnecessary speculation" at a time when Taiwan's political parties will be busy preparing to select their candidates for the 2000 presidential election.
Wang's trip will be a reciprocal visit to a trip to mainland China by his Taiwan counterpart, Koo Chen-fu of the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) last October.
SEF and ARATS are semi-official organizations authorized by Taipei and Beijing, respectively, to handle cross-strait exchanges in the absence of formal contacts between the two sides.
The 20-man delegation from the New Tung Meng Hui was visiting the mainland to attend a series of seminars on cross-strait ties.

DOC.HEADLINE: CPC ANNOUNCES TO RAISE DOMESTIC OIL PRICES EFFECTIVE APRIL 7

TEXT.P: China Petroleum Corp. (CPC) announced Tuesday its intention to raise domestic oil prices an average of 2.69 percent, effective April 7.
Domestic gasoline and diesel will be raised NT$0.3 per liter, while bunker oil will be raised NT$137 per kiloliter.
CPC said it decided to raise domestic oil prices after oil producing nations reached an agreement recently to decrease output.
This will be the first time CPC has raised oil prices since March 7, 1998 when it adopted a flexible system for the adjustment of domestic oil prices.
Since the beginning of this year, CPC has lowered domestic oil prices seven times for an accumulated decrease of 14.63 percent.

Although the government on Feb.1 allowed the private sector to import liquefied natural gas, aviation oil and bunker oil, the sector has not yet imported the oil. Therefore, CPC will also raise prices of the three types of oil simultaneously.
