DOC.HEADLINE: ROC MARCH CONSUMER GOODS PRICE INDEX DECREASES 0.46 PERCENT

TEXT.P: The Republic of China's consumer goods price index in March recorded an annual growth of -0.46 percent, while its wholesale goods price index registered an annual growth of -5.83 percent, according to statistics released Tuesday by the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS).

According to DGBAS statistics, the ROC's consumer goods price index in March was 101.38, a decrease of 0.46 percent compared with March of last year, and a drop of 1.9 percent compared with last month.

The ROC's wholesale goods price index in March was 95.45, down 5.83 percent compared with the same month of last year. It was the sixth consecutive month the nation's wholesale goods price index decreased.
DGBAS said the March decline of prices was a short-term phenomenon and not an indication of deflation.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Tuesday, April 6, or the 20th day of the second month of the Year of the Rabbit according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1789: George Washington is unanimously elected the first president of the United States.
1814: French Emperor Napoleon Bonaparte is forced to abdicate unconditionally.
1830: The Church of the Latterday Saints, whose followers are known as Mormons, is founded in Fayette, New York State, by Joseph Smith.
1868: Japanese Emperor Meiji establishes the Charter Oath which changed the form of government. He also promises an assembly.
1890: Anthony Fokker, Dutch-born American aircraft designer and manufacturer who revolutionized aerial warfare by synchronizing a front-mounted machine gun, is born.
1909: On his third attempt, American naval officer and Arctic explorer Robert Peary reaches the North Pole as the head of an expedition.
1913: The provisional Senate of the Republic of China is dissolved.
1917: President Woodrow Wilson signs a resolution entering the United States into World War I on the side of Great Britain and France.
1933: The Ministry of Finance of the Republic of China orders the implementation of a yuan currency system instead of the tael currency system.
1935: Emperor Henry Pu Yi of the Manchukuo, a puppet regime installed by the Japanese, visits Japan.
1938: The ROC armed forces score a major victory over Japan in the battle of Taierchuang, killing more than 30,000 Japanese troops.
1941: German bombers raid Belgrade, killing some 2,500 people. Hundreds of buildings were burndown during the attack, including the National Library with countless medieval manuscripts.
1945: US naval forces score a major victory against the Japanese at Kyushu.
1953: Scrap bombs explode on a hillside in Nanshihchiao, Taipei County, killing and injuring more than 300 people.
1965: The United States launches Early Bird I, the first commercial communications satellite, from Cape Kennedy, Florida.
1968: Pierre Trudeau becomes prime minister of Canada.
1971: Igor Stravisky, Russian-born composer who was one of the 20th Century's leading musical figures, dies in New York at the age of 89.
1975: Yen Chia-kan, vice president of the Republic of China since 1966, takes the oath of office as the nation's second constitutional president.
1993: Two mainland Chinese youths, Liu Bao-zai and Huang Shu-kang, hijack a Southern Airlines' Boeing 757 passenger plane to Taiwan.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "To allow people to go to battle without first instructing them, is to betray them."

DOC.HEADLINE: US CONGRESSMAN WANTS INTERVIEWS IN MAINLAND
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 6 (CNA) (By Ben Wu) (By Nelson Chung)

TEXT.P: Washington, April 5 (CNA): US Rep. Dan Burton (R-IN) wrote President Bill Clinton Monday that investigators from both the Congress and Justice Department should be allowed to interview principal witnesses in mainland China in order to find out whether mainland Chinese officials attempted to influence the 1996 US presidential elections.

In the letter the congressman urged President Clinton to insist that the People's Republic of China provide US investigators "with bank records.....that would demonstrate the origin of the millions of dollars that flowed from China" into the Democratic Party and the Clinton-Gore campaign in 1996.
Burton is the chairman of the House Government Reform and Oversight Committee which is charged with investigating where foreign donations to the 1996 presidential elections originated.

The Los Angeles Times reported from Washington on Saturday that Taiwan-born businessman Johnny Chung, a former Democratic Party fund-raiser, told Justice Department investigators that the PRC's military intelligence chief ordered US$300,000 be directed to him for use as political contributions to the Clinton campaign.

DOC.HEADLINE: AMERICANS SHOULD BETTER UNDERSTAND TRA: US DAILY
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 6 (CNA) (By Ben Wu) (By Nelson Chung) (By Nelson Chung)

TEXT.P: Washington, April 5 (CNA): As tensions between the United States and mainland China mount and the issues become more complex, Americans' familiarity with the history of two decades of the Taiwan Relations Act "someday might make a difference between a major war or a milestone for peace in the heart of Asia," wrote the Houston Chronicle Monday.

In an editorial titled "History Lessons," the Texas newspaper noted that relations between the US and the PRC have for decades been buffeted by tempests and typhoons of varying degrees. As Chinese Premier Zhu Rongji visits this week, the storm warnings are flying high again.

But regardless of the political weather at the moment, one of the principal realities is the United States' long-standing relationship with the democratic Republic of China on Taiwan. "It is somewhat ironic that Zhu's visit comes the same week that the 20th anniversary of the Taiwan Relations Act is observed," said the editorial.

The Act, like so much in US-Sino relations, is an oddity. So odd, in fact, that people on both sides of the Taiwan Strait would prefer it be done away with -- but for starkly different reasons. Even in Washington, the Act is a source of deep contention, added the newspaper.

Given the importance of the TRA, the editorial continued, "the 20th anniversary of its passage is a very appropriate time to say that Americans would benefit from a better knowledge and understanding of the law upon which, it is no exaggeration to say, the future of the world might turn."

The law stems from President Jimmy Carter's 1978 normalization of relations with Communist China, conceding that the People's Republic is "the sole legal government of China." The move made US relations with the huge Chinese mainland somewhat less complicated, but the relations with the more democratic Republic of China on Taiwan more difficult, according to Houston Chronicle.

The TRA enables unofficial commercial, cultural and other dealings with Taiwan and offers protection from the United States that the democratic island -- which has been a model for economic success and, more recently, rapid democratization -- has needed to survive, wrote the newspaper.

Tensions have grown, and the issues have become more complicated over the years. For example, the TRA codifies a role for the Congress in conducting foreign policy that to some degree overrules the executive branch's prerogatives, said the editorial.

On the other hand, it added, the TRA's provisions assert the US position that the island's future is to be determined by peaceful means only while acknowledging that United States' aid given to Taiwan has been crucial to that government's continued existence.

The newspaper concluded that as tensions mount and the issues grow more complex, Americans' familiarity with the nuances and history of two decades of the Taiwan Relations Act someday might make a difference between a major war or a milestone for peace in the heart of Asia.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHEN SHUI-BIAN TO VISIT SOUTH KOREA, MONGOLIA

TEXT.P: Former Taipei Mayor Chen Shui-bian will leave Wednesday for a five-day visit to South Korea and Mongolia as part of an international tour in which he will exchange opinions with officials there in the run-up to next year's presidential election.

Considered by many to be the opposition Democratic Progressive Party's most likely presidential candidate, Chen has also been traveling around Taiwan, and his travels are said to be in preparation for a presidential bid.
Chen, who recently returned from Japan, said the issue of security in the Asia-Pacific region would be the focus of his trip to South Korea, as it was in Japan.

While in Seoul, Chen will call on members of parliament and political party officials, though he has refused to name whom he will meet. In addition, he will atttend a seminar at Kyongnam Universty, from which he has received an honorary doctorate.

After South Korea, Chen will then travel to Ulan Bator, Mongolia, to meet with former Ulan Bator Mayor and current Mongolian Premier Janlaviin Narantsatsralt. Taipei and Ulan Bator signed a sister-city agreement when Chen and Narantsatsralt were mayors.
Chen noted that strong neighboring countries have not prevented Mongolia from becoming independent, sovereign, dignified and secure. Taiwan could learn a lesson from Mongolia, he said.
This is Chen's first visit to Mongolia. He had hoped to visit Ulan Bator to sign the sister-city agreement, but Chen instead sent his deputy, Pai Hsiu-hsiung, because of pressure from mainland China.
Chen has announced that he will visit the United States later this month.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR DOWN

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar dropped against the greenback on the Taipei foreign exchange market Tuesday due to strong buying of the US dollar and to the continuing weakness of the Japanese Yen.
The NT dollar fell NT$0.011 to the greenback, closing at 33.135.
The local currency opened at the day's high of 33.122, and fell as low as 33.15. In the short term, dealers said, the currency will continue to trade within a narrow band.
Interbank US dollar trading reached US$171 million during the session.

DOC.HEADLINE: ZHU RONGJI'S US VISIT SEEN BECOMING A DIFFICULT BALANCING ACT

TEXT.P: The visit of Premier Zhu Rongji, which starts on Tuesday, is seen as a difficult balancing act because many Americans still regard mainland China as the "Evil Empire."

The Australian Financial Review on Tuesday, said, in a article by its Hong Kong-based corespondent Rowan Callick, that Zhu's key goal is to put US ties with mainland China back on track following recent friction over the alleged theft of US nuclear secrets by China and the mainland Chinese media depicting President Bill Clinton as Hitler for his role in the NATO bombings of Yugoslavia.

Though known as a reformist, Zhu is unlikely to clinch mainland China's entry into the World Trade Organization (WTO) because it requires Beijing to quicken the pace of economic reforms and market opening measures. Currently the mainland is experiencing anxiety over rising unemployment and social dislocation which is slowing the pace of economic reforms there.

The daily reported Clinton and Zhu will probably issue a statement noting their closeness on WTO issues. The visit now appears unlikely to clinch any formal agreement because mainland China's entry requires other countries, including Australia, to sign off on WTO membership.

While Zhu is facing US hawks and a hostile Congress, Clinton will be unable to help as he himself is under siege for the failure of NATO's bombing campaign to relieve the plight of suffering ethnic Albanians in Kosovo.
Clinton is regarded as being too accommodating to mainland China and he is still facing murky tales of mainland Chinese officials contributing money to his re-election campaign.

Australia wants firm relations ties between mainland China and the US because a further falling out between the two would place Australia in an awkward position. However, Australia does not want to see the US concede the mainland's entry into the WTO, the daily reported. (By Peter Chen) EDITEM ZCZC CEP011 04-06-99 ISLAMIC LEADER ACCUSES SUHARTO OF FOMENTING VIOLENCE

Canberra, April 6 (CNA) An influential Islamic leader and Indonesian presidential candidate, has for the first time accused former President Suharto of deliberately provoking the recent violence and bloodshed as a way of delaying or disrupting the national election on June 7.

In an interview with the Australian Financial Review, Dr. Amien Rais, former leader of the Muhammadiyah group in Indonesia, said he suspects Suharto of destabilizing parts of Indonesia as a way of influencing the June election.

Amien, who stepped aside from the group, which has a membership of 28 million, in order to take part in the June presidential election, is the first Indonesian leader to implicate Suharto on the record.

He claimed that Suharto and the ruling Golkar Party are using large sums of money to neutralize political opponents and to bribe voters. Rais said that parts of the Army seemed to be working with Suharto and he called for the resignation of the commander of the armed forces and the former Suharto adjutant -- General Wiranto.

"Most probably Suharto is involved in destabilizing the political situation and trying to delay the election. I believe he is involved in the unrest on Ambon, but I cannot prove it," Amien told the daily.
"Part of the army is working with him, but not the whole army," he added.
More than 200 people have died in clashes between Muslims and Christians on the island of Ambon in recent months.
Across the archipelago, violence and mass unrest have broken out with increased frequency since Suharto resigned on May 2 of last year amid economic crisis, he said.
"Suharto is defending himself, defending the economic imperial of his children," Amien said.
President B. J. Habibie has guaranteed the physical safety of Suharto and has refused to convene an independent inquiry into alleged corruption by the former president.

Amien has said publicly that one of Suharto's daughters phoned him last November with an offer of multiple pay-offs of 11 billion rupiah in an apparent effort to blunt his campaign against Suharto and his family.
Amien told the Review that Suharto could face a trial under a reformist government.

"He still has a lot of networks, a lot of allies and friends in the armed forces and the bureaucracy; a lot of people believe their fate depends on him and if he collapses, if he goes on trial, there will be a lot more political and economic fallout.

"We have to hit him, again and again, harder and more often, until we deliver the coup de grace, and then we can begin to build a democratic Indonesia," Amien said, adding "The status quo forces will do anything to delay or disrupt the election. They are afraid of the election."

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA RELUCTANT TO ACCEPT ETHNIC ALBANIAN REFUGEES

TEXT.P: Australia was reluctant to accept a portion of ethnic Albanian refugees who successfully fled to Macedonia out of fear of a repetition of the influx of mainland Chinese students and refugees into the country after the Tiananmen Square massacre in 1989.

Immigration Minister Philip Ruddock on Monday told reporters that Australia would not give any temporary stay to ethnic Albanian refugees because it would repeat the experience of allowing more than mainland 55,000 Chinese students and refugees into Australia after the June 4 massacre.
His answer was in response to an urgent call from the opposition Labor Party that the government should be more flexible in accepting ethnic Albanian refugees.

Albanian Australian communities here also made a similar request to the government, saying Australia should increase its immigration intake for ethnic Albanian refugees because they are desperate and need help.
The United States, and some European countries, including Italy, have agreed to accept tens of thousands of ethnic Albanian refugees fleeing massacre by Serbian troops.
Ruddock said the government would only extend visas for some 2,000 ethnic Albanians who were already in Australia before the start of the NATO bombings of Yugoslavia last week.

Former Labor Party Prime Minister Bob Hawke was sympathetic with the mainland Chinese refugees and granted them a temporary stay in Australia. But four years later, most of the mainland Chinese refugees used their refugee status to gain permanent residency.
Ruddock said the government was worried about a recurrence of that situation, adding, it would cause a financial strain for Canberra.

Among the 55,000 mainland Chinese refugees given a temporary stay in Australia, most of them succeeded in gaining permanent residency status and later a number of them applied for family members to come. The influx cost Australian taxpayers an enormous amount because the new arrivals were entitled to social welfare upon their arrival in Australia.
The influx of mainland Chinese refugees and their parents effected the government budget, immigration analysts said.

In order to prevent a similar situation from recurring, the Coalition government under Prime Minister John Howard last year introduced a very tough immigration policy aimed at discouraging family reunions by imposing a two-year waiting period.
During the waiting period, parents of Australian citizens are not entitled to any social welfare.

Since 1997-98 Australia has set its immigration limit at around 68,000 migrants plus 4,500 humanitarian refugees, down sharply from the 100,000 intake in 1996-97 during the Labor Party government under former Prime Minister Paul Keating.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCK PRICES DOWN 0.3 PERCENT

TEXT.P: Taiwan share prices closed 0.3 percent lower on Tuesday as investors were reluctant to trade before companies release their annual earnings reports due at the end of April.
The benchmark Taiwan Stock Exchange Weighted Price Index fell 18.21 points to close at 7,163.99.
Trade on Tuesday totaled 2.74 billion shares worth NT$79.55 billion (US$2.4 billion), down from the previous session's NT$151.35 billion.
Among the eight major stock categories, construction shares posted the largest gain, climbing 1.9 percent, followed by paper and pulp shares, which gained 0.5 percent.
Cement issues increased 0.3 percent, and electronic stocks went up 0.1 percent.
The financial sector registered the largest loss of day, dropping 1 percent, followed by textile shares, which fell 0.7 percent.
Plastic and chemical shares posted a 0.3 percent decline, and foodstuff issues went down 0.1 percent.
The over-the-counter market registered a slight drop of 0.53 points to close at 165.09 points, with a turnover of NT$3.49 billion.
Meanwhile, the TAIEX Capitalization Weighted Stock Index Futures (TAIEX Index Futures) for April posted a slight gain of 9 points, closing at 7,314 points, with 2,770 contract transactions.

TAIEX Index Futures for May dropped 8 points to close at 7,311 points, while those for June went down 5 points to close at 7,301 points. Contract transactions for the two months totaled 212 and 12, respectively.
September futures declined 25 points to close at 7,310, with 3 contract transactions, and December futures dropped 29 points to close at 7,310, with 3 contract transactions.

Reference levels provided by the Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange for TAIEX Index Futures trading on Tuesday were 7,305 points for April; 7,319 points for May; 7,306 points for June; 7,330 points for September; and 7,339 points for December.

DOC.HEADLINE: DOC ANNOUNCES THREE TAIWAN WIRE MAKERS GUILTY OF DUMPING
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, April 5 (CNA) (By Herman Pan and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Three Taiwan stainless steel wire producers are among companies from six countries that were accused Monday of dumping stainless steel round wires on the US market at below market prices, sources from the Department of Commerce (DOC) reported Monday.

After completing an investigation into dumping charges filed by 10 US steel producers, the DOC ruled that companies from six countries -- including Taiwan's Rodex Fasteners Corp., Tien Tai Electrode Co. and Kuang Tai Metal Industrial Co. -- dumped the wires on the US market.
Steel producers from South Korea, Japan, India, Canada and Spain were also named in the ruling.

The DOC's verdict has been referred to the US International Trade Commission (ITC) for adjudication. The ITC is scheduled to hold a final public hearing on the case Wednesday, and it will decide in 45 days whether the foreign steel producers have hurt the interests of the 10 US companies.

If the ITC upholds the verdict, then starting May 24 Tien Tai Electrode and Kuang Tai Metal will be subject to a punitive tariff rate of 4.75 percent, while Rodex Fasteners will face a punitive tariff rate of 3.94 percent, according to the DOC sources.
Stainless steel round wires from certain steel producers in South Korea, Japan, India, Canada and Spain would face tariff rates ranging from 3.07 percent to 24.4 percent.

According to DOC tallies, Taiwan is the third largest exporter of stainless steel round wires to the United States, behind only Canada and South Korea. Taiwan exported 2.25 million kilograms of stainless steel round wires worth about US$3.97 million to the United States in 1996.

DOC.HEADLINE: CROSS-STRAIT MARRAIGE ENDS IN BRIDE'S BURNING TO DEATH

TEXT.P: A 27-year-old mainland Chinese woman married to a Taiwan man was found burned to death in her home in Minhsiung village in southern Chiayi County.
The body of Mo Yen-yin was found by police in the couple's bedroom.
The woman's husband, 37-year-old Tsai Kun-jung, said his wife died of self-immolation and that he himself nearly burned to death in the fire.

But neighbors reported hearing loud squabbles between Mo and Tsai, and police said there were signs that there had been a fight in the house. Authorities are continuing their investigation into the cause of the fire.

The fire was reported to the village fire brigade in the wee hours of Thursday morning. When firefighters arrived, Tsai was found sitting in the parlor on the ground floor of the house. His chest had been burned, and the fire had already been extinguished.

Tsai told firefighters that his wife had set fire to their second-floor bedroom with herself in the room. When firefighters rushed to the bedroom they found Mo's body lying in front of the bedroom door.
According to an initial police investigation, gasoline could be smelled in the bedroom. In addition, some furniture in the room had been destroyed by the fire.
Gasoline may have been spilled onto Mo's body before she caught fire, police said.

Tsai told police that he and his wife had been having problems recently. She tried to burn him with gasoline, he said, adding that he managed to escape with a slight chest burn. Tsai said he ran downstairs after being attacked by Mo and that he did not know what happened in the bedroom afterward.
Police said there were signs of fighting in both the parlor and bedroom.
Tsai and Mo, who had been married for several years and had no children, moved to the village last year.
Neighbors said Tsai had become unemployed recently, and they claimed that in recent days he had often become drunk and that there had been frequent arguments between Tsai and Mo.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING MAY FURTHER ACCELERATE FINANCE MARKET LIBERALIZATION
DOC.DATELINE: Hong Kong, April 6 (CNA) (By Stanley Cheung and David Hsu)

TEXT.P: Besides allowing four foreign-funded insurance companies to set up branches or participate in joint ventures in mainland China, Beijing is also thinking of permitting foreign companies to buy the bad debts of mainland Chinese banks, a pro-Beijing newspaper reported Tuesday.
The move would be an attempt to prevent Asia's financial turmoil from affecting mainland China's financial market, and it would further open the market, according to the Wen Hui Bao daily.
It was reported that mainland China will proceed this year with an all-out settlement of state-owned banks' bad debts. China Construction Bank is said to be the first bank targeted for settlement.
The daily quoted a high-ranking China Construction Bank official as saying that as the bank settles its bad debts, it will surely be necessary to allow foreign companies to buy the debts.
Mainland China presently attracts foreign funds mainly through direct investment in mainland China and through the purchase of mainland Chinese stocks and bonds listed on markets overseas.

DOC.HEADLINE: POLICE ESCORT HOME FIFTH CRIMINAL TO BE REPATRIATED IN PAST MONTH

TEXT.P: Vietnam recently handed over to Taiwan a Republic of China national convicted of fraud in Taiwan, and the man's return marks the fifth time in the past month foreign countries have agreed to repatriate suspected or convicted criminals sought by Taiwan, an official with Taiwan's Criminal Investigation Bureau (CIB) said Tuesday.

ROC police escorted 44-year-old Wu Ching-tsun back to Taiwan aboard an EVA Airways flight Tuesday afternoon after he was handed over by Vietnamese police. Wu fled to Vietnam after being sentenced to five months in prison by Taiwan's Supreme Court in 1995. He was arrested recently by police in Vietnam.

Wu is the fifth suspected or convicted criminal to be repatriated to Taiwan in the past month, and his extradition comes after high-ranking police officials in Taiwan visited five Southeast Asian countries last month to promote joint crackdowns on criminal activity.
National Police Administration Director-General Ting Yuan-chin and CIB Commissioner Cheng Ching-sung visited Thailand, Malaysia, Singapore, Vietnam and the Philippines in March.

The officials noted that since 1996, police have conducted around a dozen crackdowns on gangsters in Taiwan every year, but as the masterminds of most criminal operations have fled the country, the public has questioned the effectiveness of these crackdowns.
Police said the crackdowns would continue and that bringing back gangsters who have fled Taiwan will be the focus of their next one.

To achieve this goal, the bureau will ask for more money and will station ROC police officials in other countries to track and collect information on suspected Taiwan criminals who live abroad, bureau officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA TO ANNOUNCE AID PACKAGE FOR ALBANIAN REFUGEES IN MACEDONIA

TEXT.P: The ROC Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said on Tuesday that it will soon announce an aid package to relieve the suffering of the thousands of Albanian refugees who have flooded into Macedonia from neighboring Yugoslavia.

MOFA spokesman Roy Wu said at a news conference that MOFA, in conjunction with 17 local charity groups, has worked out a package to help Macedonia settle some of the Albanian refugees who have fled there to avoid ethnic cleansing in Kosovo, a province of neighboring Yugoslavia.

The ROC government is very concerned about the Albanian refugees' safety and needs in Macedonia, and it will make public its detailed aid package within this week in order to help Macedonia quickly tackle the refugee crisis, Wu said.

According to Wu, the ROC embassy in Macedonia has suggested that Taiwan charity groups go first to refugee camps in Tetovo and Gostivar, in western Macedonia, where around 50,000 refugees have gathered.

In addition to sending materials such as clothing and food, the spokesman said last week that several local charity organizations may travel to Macedonia to directly take part in aid operations there.

DOC.HEADLINE: SATELLITE PHONES NOW ON SALE IN SINGAPORE

TEXT.P: Satellite phones, which allow people to call into and out of the most remote places in the world, are now on sale in Singapore.
Satellite-based global-telephone network provider Iridium has tied up with SingTel Mobile to provide the service.
It involves the use of the world's first hand-held satellite phones, which cost US$4,000 each.
Calls are charged at between US$2 and US$6 a minute, depending on where the calls are made and whether they are domestic or international calls.
Iridium uses 66 low-orbit satellites to transmit the calls, unlike normal cellular phone networks, which rely on ground stations.
Both Motorola and Kyocerea, a Japanese manufacturer, make the handsets, and the Motorola ones became available here less than two weeks ago.
Iridium launched the service in November last year.
There are fewer than 10,000 subscribers around the world and SingTel's product manager for international mobile service, Ng Tai Tee, said that about 10 Singaporeans have already bought the phone.
She said she expected this number to rise to several hundred next year.
Current users are businessmen and executives working in inaccessible regions of Indonesia and Papua New Guinea, she said.
Those who do not want to buy the handset can rent it from SingTel Mobile at S$50 (about US$29) a day. Calls are not included in the rental fee.
Besides SingTel Mobile, Iridium has agreements with about 300 other cellular operators around the world.
The only other portable satellite phone now on the market is the Inmarsat mini-M, which was launched in 1997 and comes in the form of a laptop-sized phone set and antenna.
It costs US$3,000 and the usage charge is US$3 a minute. There are about 500 customers using the phone in Singapore.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PRESIDENT MEETS FORMER US CONGRESSMAN

TEXT.P: President Lee Teng-hui said on Tuesday that the Republic of China has always been concerned over crises in the international community, and has always been willing to contribute to efforts to help ease these crises.

In an meeting with former US Congressman Stephen Solarz at the Presidential Office, Lee said the ROC is one of the few countries in the world to have sped cash and other aid to Macedonia to help the refugees who have streamed into the country in the wake of the Kosovo conflict in neighboring Yugoslavia.

The prevention and handling of international crises, most of which stem from human infractions, are directly related to international stability and the security of all nations around the world, Lee said.
If a crisis is prevented before it erupts or handled before it becomes full-blown, tension and confrontation can be reduced, and even war can eventually be avoided, he added.

Lee welcomed the visit to Taiwan by Solarz, who is currently a board member of the New York-based International Crisis Group (ICG), a private non-profit organization formed to strengthen the international community's ability to prevent international crises.
Solarz, a big supporter of the ROC who sees the country as a very strong democracy, has visited Taiwan many times in his previous capacity as a Democratic member of the House of Representatives.

During his audience with President Lee, Solarz thanked him for his consistent support for efforts to prevent and handle international crises. He also offered his congratulations to Lee, who was celebrating his golden wedding anniversary.

The ICG, first conceived in 1993 by veterans of crisis operations in Bosnia-Herzegovina, Cambodia, Northern Iraq and Somalia, was formally established in November 1995 in New York, comprising some 50 international statesmen, former parliamentarians, business executives, and civic and humanitarian leaders.
The ROC is one of the donors to the ICG, whose annual budget comes from a wide range of sources, including donations from individuals, foundations, governments and corporations.

Among the ICG's board members are Malcolm Fraser and Michel Rocard, former Prime Ministers of Australia and France, respectively, Solarz, Ed Turner, president of the global news network CNN, and American financier George Soros.

DOC.HEADLINE: EVERGREEN DOES NOT INTEND TO BUY JAPAN AIRLINE SHARES

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Evergreen business group denied on Tuesday that it is planning to purchase 4 percent of Japan Airlines (JA) stocks, worth NT$8.5 billion (US$256.8 million).
A spokesman for Evergreen Marine Corp. (EMC), affiliated to the group, made the announcement after foreign wire service reports said that EMC was putting in a tender for JA shares.

The spokesman said that the JA stockholder who is selling his 4 percent share in the company had invited Evergreen to make him an offer, but was turned down as the company would prefer to concentrate on its own airline business.

He further declared none of the group's affiliates, including EMC and EVA Airways, will become involved in JA's operation, explaining that EVA is now busy releasing its own shares on the stock market, which means the company must concentrate on its own business.
EMC holds a 25.58 percent share of EVA. The EMC official's remarks echoed those of EVA spokesman Nie Kuo-yui, who spelled out that EVA has at present no plans to invest in other airlines.

EVA is one of the few Asian air companies which made a profit last year. According to the company, its 1998 revenue reached NT$42.93 billion (US$1.29 billion), with an after-tax profit of NT$75.4 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA TO ACCEPT 4,000 KOSOVO REFUGEES

TEXT.P: The Australian government has bowed to opposition pressure by agreeing to accept 4,000 of the ethnic Albanian refugees who have fled to Macedonia from neighboring Yugoslavia.

At a press conference on Tuesday, Prime Minister John Howard said: "We do have a responsibility to help the refugees on a humanitarian basis. We will give them a temporary stay in Australia." But he also said the government will see to it that they return to their homeland after the crisis is over.
He said Australia will donate another US$2.6 million to buy food and medicine for ethnic Albanian refugees of the crisis in Kosovo, following an earlier donation of US$1.3 million.

Meanwhile, at a separate news conference on Tuesday, Foreign Minister Alexander Downer said the Australian government remained worried about the safety of two missing aid workers believed to have been detained on the border of Yugoslavia and Croatia.
Earlier, the Australian government had been reluctant to accept any ethnic Albanian refugees for fear of upsetting the current immigration policy.
Some political analysts welcomed the acceptance of the 4,000 refugees, but said the number is too small because Australia can afford to receive more.

DOC.HEADLINE: CAA DENIES REPORTS THAT LOCAL CARRIER TO FLY JAPAN ROUTES

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Civil Aeronautics Administration (CAA) on Tuesday denied media reports that a third local carrier has been approved to fly between Taiwan and Japan.

Denying press reports that Far East Air Transport (FAT) Corp. has been given the green light to fly routes between Taiwan and Miyazaki and Kumamoto in southern Japan, CAA Director-General Chang You-heng said he was unaware of such a development.

Chang stressed that the issue is not for FAT to decide alone, but is also a foreign affairs issue which would require the two countries to modify a current accord in order to allow another airline to ply the route.
The CAA head was reluctant to speculate on when the two countries might hold such negotiations, saying only that the time is not yet ripe for such talks.
Currently, China Airlines and EVA Airways, Taiwan's two largest carriers, and Japan's All Nippon Airlines and Japan Asia Airways, operate flight services between Taiwan and Japan.

DOC.HEADLINE: ITR COOPERATES WITH WORLD'S LEADING AEROSPACE SUBSYSTEM MAKER

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Institute of Technology Research (ITR) and Allied Signal Aerospace (ASA) of the United States on Tuesday signed an agreement on strategic cooperation in the development of modern technology in aeronautic systems.
In the early stage of the cooperative venture, the two sides will concentrate on jointly engaging in the repair and maintenance of aeronautic electronic systems, according to the agreement.

ASA is the world's largest subsystem manufacturer in the space and aviation industry. With self-developed products such as engines for small- and medium-sized aircraft and aeronautic electronic systems, the US-based company enjoys annual revenue of some US$6 billion.

ASA presently has 35,000 employees, and the company is also the world's largest aviation and space system services provider, said an official for the ROC's Committee for Aviation and Space Industry Development, which played a key role in brokering the agreement.

ASA maintains close cooperative relations with Taiwan, and has helped Taiwan in the development of various military aircraft, such as assistance in the manufacture of the TFE1042 engine for Taiwan's indigenous defense fighter (IDF).
ASA has also helped the ROC military resolve technological problems in the repair and maintenance of various radar systems, the official said.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER M'LAND VICE CULTURE MINISTER IN CRITICAL CONDITION
DOC.DATELINE: Taichung, central Taiwan, April 6 (CNA) (By Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Former mainland Chinese vice culture minister Wang Chifu was reported in critical condition, following a heart attack and severe fall, sources from a Taichung hospital said on Tuesday.

Wang, who was among the members of a mainland Chinese cultural delegation invited to visit Taiwan, suffered a heart attack and fell down a flight of stairs while visiting the Provincial Taiwan Museum of Fine Arts earlier in the day, according to other members of the delegation.
Wang, 71, was immediately rushed to the nearby Chung Shan General Hospital for treatment.

According to doctors at the hospital, Wang suffered four skull fractures in addition to brain hemorrhage. His index of vital signs was a weak 2 points (15 points is standard for a healthy man under normal conditions) as of late Tuesday afternoon.
The doctors were unable to perform surgery on Wang because of his weakened state, and gave him little chance of survival.
Wang, who is currently chairman of the China Foundation for Minority Cultures and Arts, is visiting Taiwan at the invitation of the office of Democratic Progressive Party Legislator Hsu Jung-shu.
Wang's hospitalization marks the first major accident ever suffered by a mainland Chinese delegate in Taiwan since the Republic of China opened private visits across the Taiwan Strait in 1987.

DOC.HEADLINE: ARATS HEAD STATEMENT `A STEP FORWARD': MAC HEAD

TEXT.P: "China's division," a concept suggested by Wang Daohan, Beijing's point man in dealing with Taiwan, to replace Taiwan's idea of "a divided China," is a step forward from Beijing's usual claim that there is only one China, a Taiwan official said on Tuesday.

Mainland Affairs Council Chairman Su Chi said it remains to be seen whether Wang's view really reflects a new approach by Beijing toward Taiwan, cautioning that Taipei will not be drawn into a war of semantics with Beijing.
Wang reportedly made the statement during a meeting with visiting members of a Taiwan pro-reunification group, New Tung-meng Hui, in Shanghai on Monday.
In a bizarre turn of phrase, Wang was quoted as telling members of the group that the political situation between Taiwan and mainland China is more "China's division" than "a divided China."

However, Wang was also reported to have told the same group one year ago that Beijing's "one China" policy did not refer to the People's Republic of China, but this was later vehemently denied by Beijing Vice Premier Qian Qichen, which casts doubt on the veracity of Wang's latest utterance.

Wang's words raised a chorus of criticism from Taiwan's legislature, with lawmakers from a wide political spectrum pointing out that his alleged statement is nothing but a play on words and contains no new points.

DOC.HEADLINE: UNDERSEA HOT SPRINGS MAY HELP TAIWAN DETECT EARTHQUAKES: EXPERT

TEXT.P: High-temperature undersea hot springs recently discovered to the northeast of Taiwan may help detect the activities of tectonic plates and eventually contribute to earthquake prediction, an oceanographic geologist said on Tuesday.

Prof. Chen Chen-tung of National Sun Yat-sen University and his research team conducted an undersea probe of the sea bed near Gueishan (Turtle Hill) Island, off the northeastern Taiwan city of Ilan last month, and discovered Taiwan's first undersea hot spring.

The springs, which are unrecorded in any local historical or geological archives, are eruptions of billowing steam mixed with sulfur fumes, with temperatures as high as 102 degrees Celsius, Chen said.

After diving to the hot springs, collecting sulfur samples from the eruptions, and erecting four thermometers in the area, Chen said he now has scientific proof that the group of undersea hot springs actually exist.
He added that he believes similar high-temperature undersea hot springs also exist in other nearby areas and in eastern parts of the Tiaoyutai Islands, which lie further north.
Chen said his research was inspired by recent reports that Japanese scientists have discovered undersea hot springs near the island of Okinawa.

He said he felt that similar undersea hot springs should be found in the Taiwan area, which is located on the same belt of the Pacific Rim, or "ring of fire," where oceanic tectonic plates are exceptionally active.
Chen and his research team will again visit the undersea hot springs on April 23 to collect data from the undersea thermometers in order to further evaluate the hot springs' research value.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO CLOSELY MONITOR MAINLAND CHINA PREMIER'S US TRIP

TEXT.P: Calling on Washington not to damage Taiwan's interests in its engagement with Beijing, Republic of China Premier Vincent Siew said on Tuesday that his government will closely monitor a visit to the United States by Beijing Premier Zhu Rongji.

In response to lawmakers' questions at the Legislative Yuan, Siew said that Taipei has made clear to Washington that the United States should not develop its ties with mainland China to the detriment of its relationship with Taiwan.
Zhu left Beijing for Washington on Tuesday for an official visit, becoming the first mainland Chinese premier to have visited Washington in 15 years.

DOC.HEADLINE: DOH HOLDS CARNIVAL TO MARK WORLD HEALTH DAY

TEXT.P: The Department of Health (DOH) will stage a fair at the Taipei Railway Station on Wednesday to raise public awareness about the elderly, against a backdrop of concern over the island's rapidly aging population.

The fair, which will feature health consultations, an introduction to health through Chinese medicine, food and nutrition, and acupressure, and balance, cholesterol and blood-sugar testing, is part of the DOH's efforts to mark World Health Day, which falls on Wednesday, and the International Year of the Senior Citizen.

According to a statement issued by the DOH, Taiwan's population is graying rapidly, and people aged 65 and over will increase from 9 percent of the population in 1999 to 14 percent in 2121, while those aged over 100 will increase from 740 to a massive 14,000.

That means the average number of persons sharing the cost of caring for one elderly person will decrease from eight to 2.5, the statement said, adding that in light of the fact that 57 percent of the elderly currently die from diabetes, high blood pressure, malignant tumor or heart failure, the larger proportion of elderly people in the population will place a heavier burden on future generations.
To brace for this grim prospect, the DOH statement said, it is working on a comprehensive plan to provide care for the nation's elderly.

DOC.HEADLINE: PHILIPPINE GOVERNMENT UNFAZED BY ROC PRATAS HOTEL PROPOSAL

TEXT.P: The Philippines does not feel threatened by a Republic of China plan to build a hotel on a disputed island in the South China Sea, Executive Secretary Ronaldo Zamora said on Tuesday.

Zamora said the Philippine government sees nothing wrong with the plan which, he noted, will involve a Taiwan-controlled island in the Pratas, or Tungsha islands, an area claimed by mainland China and the ROC.

Zamora said the Philippines wants to maintain close relations at all times with the ROC and the other four claimants -- mainland China, Vietnam, Brunei, and Malaysia -- to various territory in the South China Sea.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies Wednesday are as follows:
The Central Daily News:
The ruling Kuomintang reached internal consensus on constitutional amendment topics.
The China Times:
The KMT plans a one-year-and-nine-month extension of the tenure of the next president.
The United Daily News:
This year's constitutional amendments will not include proposed extension of tenures for president, lawmakers and National Assembly deputies.
The Liberty Times:
The government may let poorly managed banks close doors if they suffer a run of deposits.
The China Post:
Slim chance of breakthrough is seen as mainland Chinese Premier Zhu Rongji begins US visit.
The China News:
Mainland Premier Zhu Rongji starts his big visit.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN HIGH-SPEED RAILWAY TO BE OPENED TO TRAFFIC IN 2003

TEXT.P: Taiwan's high-speed railway is slated to be completed and opened to traffic in 2003, Transportation and Communications Minister Lin Fong-cheng said on Wednesday.
Lin made the remark when meeting with members of the Legislative Yuan's Taiwan Union group on issues related to transportation and communications.
Lin said the high-speed railway, which is being built by Taiwan High Speed Railway Corp. (THSRC), is scheduled to be completed in June and opened to traffic on July 1, 2003.
Under a build-operate-transfer construction agreement, THSRC will operate the railway for 30 years before control is transferred to the government.
It is estimated that THSRC will bring in a daily turnover of NT$100 million once the railway is formally opened to traffic.

According to the contract between THSRC and the Ministry of Transportation and Communications, the government will help raise NT$240 billion for the railway's construction while THSRC will raise NT$40 billion by itself.

DOC.HEADLINE: ZHU'S US VISIT COULD AID WTO ENTRY OF TAIWAN AND MAINLAND: LIEN

TEXT.P: Vice President Lien Chan on Wednesday called for the international community to help push forward Taiwan's bid to join the World Trade Organization (WTO), saying Taiwan's application should be considered solely on the basis of its economic development and foreign trade regime.

Lien said mainland Chinese Premier Zhu Rongji's visit to the United States is likely to accelerate both mainland China and Taiwan's admission into the WTO, as joining the world trade body will likely top Zhu's talks with US officials.

Given that the United States and other Western countries have become increasingly impatient with what they perceive as Beijing's procrastination in its efforts to join the WTO, why shouldn't those countries help Taiwan enter the WTO before Beijing does? Lien asked.
Lien made the remarks during a speech delivered to a general meeting of the Chinese National Association of Industry and Commerce.

Taiwan, which is one of the world's economic powerhouses and at the WTO's doorstep, should continue to upgrade industrial and business research and development, raise educational levels and obtain more advanced technologies to further increase the country's overall competitiveness, Lien said.

Taking stock of Taiwan's economic development, Lien said some sectors -- including the capital, stock and foreign exchange markets -- need to be overhauled and streamlined if the country really intends to secure sustainable development. There has been too much liberalization and too little discipline in those sectors, he said.

Meanwhile, Foreign Affairs Minister Jason Hu said Taipei does not expect that Zhu's US visit will produce any "accident" detrimental to Taiwan, though it will closely monitor Zhu's activities in the United States.

Beginning Wednesday afternoon Vice Foreign Affairs Minister David Lee will preside over a supra-ministerial meeting at the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) to keep abreast of all Zhu's activities during his US visit, according to Hu.
Officials from MOFA, the ministries of economic affairs and national defense, the Mainland Affairs Council and the Government Information Office will take part in the meeting, Lee said.

On Wednesday the group will mainly examine the impact mainland China's WTO admission would have on Taiwan, as the latest reports have indicated that Beijing and Washington have made progress in discussions on this issue, Lee noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, April 7, or the 21st day of the second month of the Year of the Rabbit according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1348: Charles IV, king of Bohemia, founds Prague University, the first in central Europe.
1506: Saint Francis Xavier, Spanish Jesuit missionary, is born. A co-founder of the Jesuit order in 1534 with Ignatius of Loyola, he established missionaries in Japan, Ceylon, and the East Indies.
1906: Hundreds of Italians living in the vicinity of Mount Vesuvius are killed in a cataclysmic volcanic eruption.
1943: Chemist Albert Hoffman synthesizes the drug lysergic acid diethylamide (LSD) in his laboratory in Switzerland.
1945: The Yamato, Japan's largest battleship, is sunk by US aircraft carrier warplanes.
1947: Henry Ford, American car manufacturer, dies at the age of 84. He developed a gasoline-powered automobile in 1893, founded the Ford Motor Company in 1903, and mass-produced the Model T from 1908 to 1927.
1948: The World Health Organization (WHO) is founded in Geneva.
1953: Dag Hammarskjold, Swedish diplomat and political leader who won the 1961 Nobel Peace Prize posthumously, succeeds Trygve Lie as secretary-general of the United Nations.
1954: Jakie Chan, Hong Kong movie star who is noted for his action films, is born.
1969: Traffic courts are set up in Taipei City and other places in Taiwan and begin to handling traffic violation cases.
1971: US President Richard Nixon promises to withdraw 100,000 troops from Vietnam by Christmas.
1976: The Communist Party of China's Political Bureau decides at a meeting to appoint Hua Kuo-feng (Hua Guofeng) as premier and to depose Teng Hsiao-ping (Deng Xiaoping) as deputy premier after riots in Peking (Beijing).
1979: The International Olympic Committee (IOC) decides the ROC can retain its membership while admitting communist China as a new member.
1981: Voters in the Philippines approve a new constitution, giving President Ferdinand Marcos sweeping powers.
1989: Cheng Nan-jong, the person in charge of the "Era of Freedom" magazine, immolates himself after refusing arrest for involvement in an insurrection case.
1989: The Chinese Taipei Olympic Committee announces that ROC athletic teams and organizations will participate in international sports events held on the mainland under the name "Chinese Taipei."
1990: Communist China launches a US-made telecommunications satellite into orbit.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "When there is justice and order in the government of the country, to think only of pay is dishonorable. When there is no justice and order in the government of the country, to think only of pay is also dishonorable."

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP PRESIDENTIAL HOPEFUL LEAVES FOR S. KOREA, MONGOLIA VISITS

TEXT.P: Chen Shui-bian, a presidential hopeful of Taiwan's main opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), left for a five-day visit to South Korea and Mongolia on Wednesday as part of what he called an "Asian-Pacific security communication trip."
The two-leg visit followed Chen's journey to Japan last week. For similar "security" purposes, the former Taipei mayor is also scheduled to visit the United States late this month.

Local observers said Chen's frequent overseas trips are not only designed to promote regional security cooperation to maintain peace and stability in the Taiwan Strait and the entire Asia-Pacific region but also to increase his international exposure for his presidential bid.
Chen said prior to his departure for Seoul that he believes Taiwan has something to learn from both South Korea and Mongolia.

"Despite longtime military threat from North Korea, South Korea has managed to thrive over past decades and even survive the recent Asian financial turmoil under the leadership of President Kim Dae-jung," Chen said, adding that South Korea's foreign exchange reserves have increased from US$9 billion to US$50 billion at the end of February this year. "I believe that South Korea's handling of the regional financial crisis could provide some inspiration to Taiwan."
As for Mongolia, Chen said it is worth understanding how Mongolia, surrounded by two gigantic neighbors -- Russia and mainland China -- could gain its independence and keep its sovereignty intact.

The charismatic DPP heavyweight said he had strived to promote city-to-city diplomacy during his stint as Taipei mayor. "I'm convinced that despite Beijing's strenuous efforts to isolate Taiwan in the international community, there is still ample room for Taiwan to expand its external relations."

In Ulaanbaatar, the Mongolian capital, Chen will meet with Mongolian Prime Minister Tsahiagiyn Elbegdorj, with whom he made acquaintance back in June 1997 when Elbegdorj, then-mayor of Ulaanbaatar, led a delegation to Taiwan to sign a sister-city agreement with Taipei.
Dozens of pro-independence people staged a demonstration at Chiang Kai-shek International Airport to protest what they called Chen's disregard for his pro-independence stance.
The demonstrators waved banners and posters reading: "In memory of pro-independence martyr Cheng Nan-jung and condemn Chen Shui-bian for his putting aside his pro-independence position."

An unidentified protester dashed toward Chen and clapped his own hands. "My move symbolized a slap on Chen on behalf of Taiwan people to punish his disregard for his previous vow to promote Taiwan independence," the demonstrator claimed.

Meanwhile, a CNA report from Washington said Chen will arrive in Washington, D.C. around April 20 for a two-to-three-day visit. Chen last visited the US capital some 13 months ago when he was still on his Taipei mayoral post.

According to the report, Chen will hold a news conference at the US National Press Club focusing on the triangular Taipei-Washington-Beijing relations and the general prospects of Taiwan's next presidential election slated for March 2000.
During his visit, Chen will meet with Richard Bush, the top US liaison officer with Taiwan in the absence of official ties, as well as American experts in mainland China- and Taiwan-related affairs.

Some US China hands said they hope Chen will give more detailed explanations of his concepts and stances concerning international affairs, particularly those related relations with the United States and exchanges across the Taiwan Strait.
