DOC.HEADLINE: CISCO SYSTEM MAKES TAIWAN ITS LIFELONG PARTNER

TEXT.P: Cisco System, the world's largest manufacturer of computer networking equipment, regards Taiwan as its lifelong business partner, and the company will continue to bolster cooperation with both Taiwan's government and private sector, a Cisco executive said here on Wednesday.
John Chambers, chairman and CEO of Cisco System, said computer networks are heading toward a state where digitized images, and audio and video transmissions are all integrated into one system.
In addition, the Asia-Pacific region is becoming one of the most important markets in the world for makers of Internet-related equipment, Chambers said.
Cisco is planning to channel US$40 million into the Asia-Pacific region in the next year and a half. In particular the company seeks to bolster cooperation with Taiwan, he said.

Among its cooperative projects, Chambers said, Cisco is working to jointly establish with Taiwan's Institute for Information Industry (III) in July a cable modem laboratory, to further develop Taiwan's Internet hardware technologies. Cisco previously helped III to establish a laboratory in Taiwan to develop asymmetric digital subscriber line (ADSL) technology.

ADSL modems provide instant high-speed data communication connections for Internet access, video conferencing, remote access and multimedia applications. The modems operate across existing copper telephone lines.

Commenting on Cisco's future business strategy, Chambers said Cisco is striving to perfect its One-Shop system to provide a complete solution and follow-up services in light of the current explosion in Web commercial activity. Cisco seeks to achieve this goal through its Cisco Connection On-line (CCO), which now dominates one-third of e-commerce around the world, he added.
Cisco has successfully merged more than 20 companies worldwide since 1993 under a "win-win" policy, Chambers noted.

Chambers is currently in Taipei to attend the III-sponsored "New Era Leadership Summit." Among the leaders in Taiwan's computer and high-tech realm that Chambers will meet with during his stay are Stan Shih, chairman and founder of Acer Computer and Morris Chang, chairman and CEO of Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC TO HELP MACEDONIA OUT OF REFUGEE CRISIS

TEXT.P: The Republic of China will do all it can to help Macedonia deal with its refugee disaster, and is also very keen to contribute to efforts to settle the conflict in eastern Europe, Foreign Minister Jason Hu said on Wednesday.

Hu told reporters that Macedonia, the ROC's most recent ally, is now stuck in a worse situation than it could have imagined, referring to the swarm of ethnic Albanian refugees from the neighboring Yugoslavian province of Kosovo which is threatening Macedonia's development.
Foreign wire services have quoted Macedonian Prime Minister Ljubco Georgievski as saying that the country is in danger of economic and political collapse unless the tide of refugees is stemmed.
In order to save Macedonia from its predicament, Hu noted, the United States has so far offered Skopje a US$100 million aid package, while Germany has also donated some US$6 million.
Asked how much Taipei will spend on its own Macedonian aid project, Hu said the government will do its best, but stressed that money is not the only way in which Taiwan can help its friend.
The Ministry of Foreign Affairs is to hold a meeting on Thursday of local private charity organizations to discuss Taiwan's humanitarian aid to Macedonia.

Meanwhile, Vice Foreign Minister David Lee revealed that a number of doctors and nurses have expressing their willingness to travel to Macedonia to provide their services. Macedonia has around 120,000 refugees at the moment, out of the approximately one million people who have been made homeless by the Serbian ethnic cleansing program of Yugoslav leader Slobodan Milosevic.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLAND CHINA RELUCTANT TO FIGHT HIGH SEAS PIRACY

TEXT.P: Mainland China has come under growing pressure due to its reluctance to fight worsening piracy in the South China Sea and other waters, according to The Australian newspaper.

According to a report in the paper, the London-based International Maritime Bureau -- an international watchdog -- says that at least two and possibly four crews on vessels leaving mainland Chinese ports have been murdered in recent months.
The IMB estimates that at least 39 sailors have been missing since last December from two confirmed incidents in which heavily laden vessels disappeared soon after leaving Hong Kong waters.

It said mainland China has now become a safe haven for gangs of pirates running highly organized and heavily armed operations using speedboats to target vessels in the South China Sea and surrounding areas.

Some of the worst piracy is masterminded by a single gang made up of Indonesians, Malaysians and mainland Chinese, according to the IMB. They overpower the targeted ships and then take control of them and set sail for a friendly mainland Chinese port.

At least one sugar vessel a month goes missing in South China, one trade source told the daily. "China might be in the midst of a smuggling crackdown, but it doesn't appear to be making any difference," he said.

Despite the rising piracy incidents, and urgent demands for action from the international trading community, mainland China appears reluctant to vigorously crack down on the pirates, the daily reported, although Beijing has denied being soft on piracy.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA QUESTIONS NATO'S AIR WAR AGAINST YUGOSLAVIA

TEXT.P: Australia has privately questioned the United States about NATO's strategy of bombing Yugoslavia despite its public support for the air war in the interests of alliance unity.

In a front-page story on Wednesday, The Australian Financial Review reported that Foreign Minister Alexander Downer is understood to have voiced Australia's concerns to US Ambassador to Australia Genta Hawkins Holmes at a lunch in Canberra last Thursday when Downer held a reception for Vietnamese Prime Minister Pham Van Khai.

The daily reported that Downer has personally assured Holmes that Australia as an ally to the United States would refrain from public criticism of what it viewed as an ill-conceived attempt to force Yugoslav President Slodoban Milosevic to end the persecution of ethnic Albanians in Kosovo.
Downer's remarks were echoed by Prime Minister John Howard, opposition leader Kim Beazley and the chief of the Australian Defense Force, Adm. Chris Barrie, according to the paper.

They all agreed that the NATO bombings were not moderating Milosevic's behavior, but only intensifying the humanitarian crisis as refugees poured out of Kosovo to escape the vicious Serbian campaign of ethnic cleansing.

The Australian officials questioned the assumption on which the NATO action had been based and the failure of the United States and its NATO allies to develop a "plan B" to end the crisis, the daily reported.
Their views appeared similar to the reported views of US military chiefs in the weeks before the air campaign was launched, the daily reported.

DOC.HEADLINE: US-MAINLAND CHINA RELATIONS SHOULD NOT COME AT ROC'S EXPENSE: MAC

TEXT.P: The development of relations between the United States and Canada with mainland China should not be at the expense of the Republic of China, a high-ranking Taiwan official said on Wednesday.

Speaking on the second day of a visit to the United States and Canada by mainland China's Premier Zhu Rongji, MAC Chairman Su Chi noted that any discussion involving Taiwan should consult with Taipei, and should not impair the interests of the ROC.

Su noted that development of relations between Washington and Beijing, and Ottawa and Beijing, are matters pertaining to each of the countries involved, and nothing to do with Taipei. However, he stressed that Taipei will monitor the situation closely, to see whether such development is likely to have any impact on the interests of Taiwan.

The development of relationships based on mutual interests and benefit is the common wish of Taipei, Washington and Ottawa, and all three agree that such benign interaction should occur bilaterally, Su added.

DOC.HEADLINE: INDONESIAN PRESIDENT MEETS ROC MINISTER

TEXT.P: Indonesian President Bacharuddin Jusuf Habibie has assured visiting ROC Economics Minister Wang Chih-kang that his administration will take all necessary measures to protect Taiwan investors in Indonesia, reports from Jakarta said on Tuesday.
According to the reports, Habibie has also told Wang that the Indonesian situation will soon resume its former "business as usual" status.

During their talks, Habibie and Wang exchanged views on the general regional situation and development, existing bilateral cooperative projects, and effective ways to further promote mutual investment.

Habibie said the Indonesian government attaches great importance to its trade and economic relations with the Republic of China. The Indonesian leader also expressed his hope that substantive relations between the two countries will further grow and expand in the years ahead.
Wang left for Indonesia on Monday to attend an annual ROC-Indonesian energy conference, which opened in Jakarta on Tuesday.

The ROC delegation, headed by Wang, is composed of Ministry of Economic Affairs officials in charge of energy, mineral, international cooperation and investment affairs as well as senior executives from major state-run enterprises, including Taiwan Power Co. (Taipower) and Chinese Petroleum Corp. (CPC).
Kuntoro Mangkusubroto, Indonesia's mineral and energy minister, led the Indonesian delegation to the conference aimed at promoting bilateral energy and technological cooperation.
At the conference, Indonesian officials introduced their country's upperstream and downstream petroleum industry development projects and the ambitious Natuna natural gas development program.
Indonesian officials said they hope the CPC will evaluate the feasibility of investing in Indonesia's natural gas development project.

Indonesia is a major source of Taiwan's energy supplies. It now accounts 30 percent of Taiwan's total coal imports and 60 percent of its total petroleum gas imports. In 1998, Taiwan also imported 100 million metric tons of crude oil from the Southeast Asian country.

Despite the absence of formal diplomatic ties, substantive ROC-Indonesian relations have been close. Taiwan is Indonesia's sixth largest foreign capital supplier, with an accumulated direct investment of US$13.5 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCK PRICES, FUTURES DROP

TEXT.P: Taiwan stock prices closed 0.4 percent lower on Wednesday as investors were reluctant to trade due to a lack of buying incentives.
The benchmark Taiwan Stock Exchange Weighted Price Index fell 28.10 points to 7,135.89 by the close of trade.
a total of 2.24 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$70.76 billion (US$2.14 billion), down from the previous session's NT$79.55 billion.
Among the eight major stock categories, only the electronic sector remained static, while the rest all registered losses, with textile shares dropping the most at 1.8 percent.

Plastic and chemical shares went down 1.6 percent, followed by paper and pulp stocks, which fell 1.5 percent. Cement issues declined 1.2 percent, construction shares dropped 1.1 percent, foodstuff stocks fell 0.5 percent, and the financial sector dropped 0.1 percent.
The over-the-counter market posted a slight drop of 1.06 points to close at 164.03 points, for a turnover of NT$3.64 billion.
Meanwhile, the TAIEX Capitalization Weighted Stock Index Futures (TAIEX Index Futures) for April declined 40 points to close at 7,274 points, with 3,160 contract transactions.
TAIEX Index Futures for May fell 21 points to close at 7,290, with 255 contract transactions, while those for June dropped 25 points to close at 7,285, with 26 contract transactions.

September futures posted a slight decline of 6 points, closing at 7,319, and December futures went down 10 points to close at 7,319 points. Contract transactions for the two months totaled 3 and 2, respectively.

Reference levels provided by the Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange for TAIEX Index Futures trading on Wednesday were 7,314 points for April, 7,311 points for May, 7,310 points for June, 7,325 points for September, and 7,329 points for December.

DOC.HEADLINE: LA TIMES: A TOUGH LIST FOR ZHU

TEXT.P: On the sliding scale of Washington-Beijing relations, Premier Zhu Rongji began an eight-day visit to America Tuesday at a sour point.

In addition to Beijing's demands that NATO halt its bombing campaign against Yugoslavia, there is considerable tension over trade issues, human rights, and allegations of espionage and illegal campaign contributions.
The Los Angeles Times on Tuesday carried an editorial, "A Tough List for Zhu," that indicated it is to the premier's credit that he is making the trip at all in these turbulent times.

The editorial pointed out that even though Zhu has a reputation as a polished, energetic leader in mainland China, he will find the going tough on the fundamentals of the bilateral relationship between mainland China and the United States.

But the paper said that, despite the obvious difficulties and challenges he faces, Zhu is wise in coming. A cancellation would have been a mistake, as the relationship between the two countries requires constant work and understanding.

On foreign affairs, mainland China stands squarely opposed to the NATO air assaults on the Yugoslavian forces uprooting the culture and people of Kosovo. Of course mainland China has done plenty of its own cultural uprooting when calls for autonomy have been raised in Tibet, the paper pointed out.

But of far greater concern to the Beijing regime is Taiwan, which Beijing still insists is a province of mainland China. The parallel with the province of Kosovo must be uncomfortably obvious. The crisis in Yugoslavia is bound to color the talks between Clinton and Zhu.
So might reports alleging US$300,000 was funneled by Beijing's military intelligence chief to Clinton's 1996 presidential campaign.
"When the relationship is bad, we need more visits of this kind," said a key official of the mainland Chinese Embassy in Washington.

The paper said Zhu seeks to clinch during his trip an agreement on mainland China's accession to the World Trade Organization. Officials from both countries have been working for weeks to try to reach an agreement, though one has not yet been nailed.

DOC.HEADLINE: OPPOSITION PARTY URGES CROSS-TAIWAN STRAIT EXCHANGES

TEXT.P: On the eve of the convening of the conference of the National Unification Council (NUC), Taiwan's opposition New Party on Wednesday urged both sides of the Taiwan Strait to engage in positive exchanges.

Speaking at a press conference at the Legislative Yuan, Lee Ching-hua, organizer of the pro-unification party's national committee on elections and development, explained his party's view on cross-strait relations.

Lee urged President Lee Teng-hui to expound openly that the "new Taiwan people" are also Chinese people, and said his party hopes that Beijing will announce that its "one China" formula is not the People's Republic of China, in order to give the two sides more room to seek unification.
President Lee first voiced the "new Taiwan people" concept last December during Taiwan's three-in-one election.

The spokesman for the tiny opposition party said that although the "new Taiwan people" concept is conducive to the solidarity of the people of Taiwan, it will lead to suspicion and mistrust on the other side of the strait, and should therefore be made clear that it also refers to people of Chinese descent living in Taiwan.

In regard to the concept of a "China division" raised by Wang Daohan, mainland China's top negotiator with Taiwan, Lee said his party supports the concept of "a separately ruled China" proposed by the government of the ROC, and that Wang's labored semantics are of no help to the strengthening of cross-strait relations.

He also urged Beijing to listen to the voice of the Taiwan people and to respect the will of the Taiwan people in the process of seeking China's unification. "One China" should not refer to the People's Republic of China under communism, he stressed.

With regard to the controversial issue of the Theater Missile Defense (TMD) system, Lee said his party's stance is that Taiwan and mainland China should begin with the abandonment of mutual military threats.

These moves, together with the setting up of "hotline" to avoid conflicts, and the exchange of visits of military delegations, will be helpful in the establishment of a foundation for the strengthening of mutual trust, Lee said.

He also said that as long as Taiwan does not follow a path toward independence, and as long as mainland China renounces the use of force against Taiwan, it will not be necessary for Taiwan to join the TMD system.

DOC.HEADLINE: RESCUED TAIWAN FISHERMEN DETAINED IN PHILIPPINES

TEXT.P: A 40 ton Taiwan fishing vessel sank on Monday in Philippine waters off Luzon Island, and three survivors have been detained, the Philippine National Police reported on Wednesday.
Of the seven crew members of the vessel, identified as the Hung Shin We Xll, three survived for several hours in the open sea, while four others were still missing as of press time.
The survivors were identified as Li Shuin-twon, 36 the vessel's skipper; Tan Ding-shung, 27; and Chua Chui-sing, 38.
Based on the ship's manifest presented by Li to the police, the missing crewmen are Chai Cha-chin, Shon Shuen-yu, Tai Hai-sung and Chein Yu-chai.
The survivors said their boat sank when one of its two engines caught fire and exploded while they were fishing near Scarborough Shoal off the coast of Zambalez Province.

After abandoning their vessel, the three fishermen kept themselves afloat for hours by clinging to floating debris until they were found and brought to shore, where they were placed in detention by police authorities who believe they may have been poaching in Philippine waters.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR EDGES UP

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar posted a modest gain against the greenback on the Taipei market Thursday, rising NT$0.005 to close at 33.13.
The market was dominated by a wait-and-see sentiment although the local currency was appreciating thanks to the increasingly strong Japanese yen, dealers said.
The NT dollar opened at 33.132, and was traded between 33.129 and 33.138.
The interbank US dollar trading reached US$155 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: DEMOCRACY AND PEACE TO BE KEYNOTES IN PRESIDENT'S SPEECH TO NUC

TEXT.P: President Lee Teng-hui is to deliver a speech at the National Unification Council (NUC) on Thursday which will center on democracy and peace, a high-ranking government and ruling Kuomintang official said on Wednesday.
Lee's speech will also stress that security is the most fundamental issue for Taiwan, and that benign interaction across the Taiwan Strait needs further constructive dialogue, the official added.

Lee's speech at the sixth meeting of the NUC will also reiterate his hearty welcome to Wang Daohan's visit this autumn, the unnamed official revealed. Wang is chairman of the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS), mainland China's quasi-official body authorized to handle contacts with Taiwan.

Touching on the KMT's mainland policy, the official said the party feels it is not necessary to revise its policy, as under Lee's direction, it has complied with the needs of Taiwan's situation and the trend of Taiwan public opinion.

He pointed out that this is best reflected by former Taipei mayor and presidential hopeful Chen Shui-bian's adjustment of his former objection to the KMT's mainland policy and Guidelines for National Unification to his current much touted "new middle road" stance.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP LAWMAKERS TO LAUNCH HUNGER STRIKE TO PROMOTE REFERENDUM LAW

TEXT.P: A lawmaker from Taiwan's opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) will launch a hunger strike on Saturday in order to push for legislation of a public referendum law.

DPP Legislator Trong Tsai, who initiated the campaign, said on Thursday that more than 180 people, 43 of whom are incumbent legislators, have expressed their support for the action, dubbed the "410 fast."
Tsai said he, along with other seven legislative colleagues, have determined to embark on a long-term fight for the law.

At a press conference on Wednesday, Tsai explained that April 10, the beginning of the hunger strike, marks the 20th anniversary of the enactment by the United States of the Taiwan Relations Act, which states the "expectation that the future of Taiwan will be determined by peaceful means."
The DPP legislator claimed that the most "peaceful means" is to enact legislation making public referendums possible.

Echoing Tsai's remarks, fellow DPP Legislator Chang Chuan-tien stressed that the right to hold referendums is a basic human right, as well as being an example of the democracy which Taiwan is been pursuing. He urged the ruling Kuomintang to help promote the legislation of the public referendum law.

A draft law has already passed its first-reading in the legislature, but because the ruling KMT holds more than a half of the legislative seats, the party, especially its leader, President Lee Teng-hui, plays an influential role on the passing of legislation, according to Tsai.

Tsai said the KMT opposes the proposed law that would provide the right to Taiwan's voters to call a referendum on issues concerning public interests because it believes that the people of Taiwan are too immature to make political decisions.

Coinciding with the start of the hunger strike, the Taiwan Professors' Association will stage a demonstration in downtown Taipei to back the call for the right of public referendum. Members of the organization revealed they will join Tsai in his hunger strike after the protest march.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC DELEGATION TO PROVIDE HUMANITARIAN ASSISTANCE IN MACEDONIA

TEXT.P: A Republic of China delegation comprised of representatives from government and private charity groups will visit Macedonia next week to provide medical and other humanitarian assistance to the Balkan country.

The delegation will be headed by Vice Foreign Affairs Minister David Lee. With flight schedules erratic because of NATO's strikes on Yugoslavia, the delegation may have to charter a plane from Taipei or a European nation to Macedonia for the three-day visit.

The visit comes as NATO forces continue to pound Yugoslavia for its killing of ethnic Albanians in the province of Kosovo. Hundreds of thousands of people have been driven out of Kosovo and have fled to neighboring Macedonia and Montenegro to escape the campaign of ethnic cleansing by Serbian President Slobodan Milosevic.

Lee said that "the ROC is sympathetic to the plight of the refugees who have been driven out of Kosovo," and added that by providing humanitarian assistance, the ROC hopes that others will see the island as not only an economic miracle, but also a caring nation.
In addition to aid such as drinking water and pharmaceuticals provided by the charity groups, the government will also provide money, the second cash donation following US$2 million provided earlier.
Although Foreign Affairs Minister Jason Hu and Lee would not reveal the exact amount of the new assistance, it is understood that it will be more than US$2 million.

Lee noted that the situation in the Balkans is the greatest human tragedy there since World War II, noting that there are 120,000 refugees in Macedonia alone and that the total number in the whole region exceeds 1 million.

In light of the fact that some Western nations, including the United States and Germany, have said they will accept some of the refugees, Lee was asked if Taiwan will do likewise, but he said that there is no such plan at present.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PEOPLE OUTPACE JAPANESE, SOUTH KOREANS IN NUTRITIONAL TERMS

TEXT.P: Nutritional intake among the people of Taiwan has continued to increase over the past few years, with per capita daily intake reaching an average of 3,129 calories, according to government statistics released on Wednesday.

The Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) said Taiwan people have outpaced their Japanese and South Korean counterparts in daily intake of calories, protein, minerals and vitamins.

According to a DGBAS study, local daily intake of protein and vitamin C has exceeded Department of Health (DOH)-recommended levels, while calorie, iron and calcium intake falls within standard levels.

"The study indicates that local people's nutritional intake is adequate," a DGBAS official said, adding that local people should control their diet and avoid overeating in order to maintain good health.
DGBAS tallies show that per capita daily nutrient intake increased significantly last year compared with the levels recorded 10 years ago.

During the 10-year period, local people's fat intake recorded the sharpest increase at 35.1 percent, followed by calcium intake, up 29.4 percent; iron intake, up 16.7 percent; protein intake, up 13.5 percent; phosphorous intake, up 11.2 percent; and vitamin C intake, up 10.6 percent.
The study also found that local people's intake of carbohydrates, such as rice, sugar and noodles, has declined during the past decade, pointing to diversification in the country's diet.

The report went on to say that Taiwan people's average fat intake is twice that of their Japanese counterparts; calorie intake is 53.2 percent higher; carbohydrate intake is 33.2 percent higher; and protein intake is 23.2 percent higher.

Compared with the United States, Taiwan people topped Americans only in vitamin C intake while lagging behind in all other nutrients. Local people's vitamin C intake was 25.8 percent higher than average daily intake in the United States.

Health officials said local people's daily protein intake, at 101 grams, exceeds the DOH-suggested level by 31 grams, while phosphorous and vitamin C intake exceeds the standard levels by 582 mg and 96 mg, respectively.

DOC.HEADLINE: EAT MORE VEGETABLES AND CUT FAT INTAKE TO AVERT CANCER: EXPERTS

TEXT.P: Eating more rice and vegetables while cutting down on meat and fat intake will help reduce the risk of cancer, local health experts said on Wednesday.
Peng-Wang Chia-kang, vice chairman of the non-profit Formosa Cancer Foundation (FCF), said a wise diet or a well-balanced diet can help avert cancer.
Peng-Wang, an academinician of Academia Sinica, Taiwan's highest research institute, said the World Health Organization once studied more than 10 million cancer cases around the world.
According to the research, Peng-Wang said, 30-to-40 percent of cancer patients studied might not have developed cancer if they had controlled their diet.
"Elaborate laboratory tests also show that eating more vegetables can help lower the risk of cancer," Peng-Wang noted.

Meanwhile, FCF Chief Executive Lai Chi-ming said rising incidence of breast cancer, colorectal cancer, prostate cancer, lung cancer and pancreatic cancer here is closely related to a significant increase in local people's fat intake over the past two decades.

Lai said an adult man needs only 70 grams of fat intake a day, compared to 40 grams needed by an adult woman. At present, Lai said, local people's daily fat intake reaches 34 percent of thier total daily calorie intake, far exceeding the required levels.
Lai suggested that local people eat chicken, duck, fish and beans instead of pork, beef and mutton. He also urged local people to eat more steamed foods while cutting down on intake of fried foods.
With financial support from Nan Shan Life Insurance Co., the Formosa Cancer Foundation has published a diet manual with an aim to help local people control their diet to reduce the risk of cancer.
The foundation will also sponsor a series of publicity progams to teach local people how to eat wisely and ensure their continued good health.

DOC.HEADLINE: OCAC HEAD URGES INCREASED INTERNATIONAL PUBLICITY

TEXT.P: Overseas Chinese Affairs Commission (OCAC) Minister Chiao Jen-ho urged the government on Wednesday to step up its international publicity drive to buttress global awareness of the Republic of China.

Reporting to the Foreign Affairs and Overseas Chinese Affairs committees at the Legislative Yuan, Chiao called on the government to effectively strengthen international publicity to allow the world to heed the fact of the ROC's existence. In the face of Beijing's increased diplomatic blockade and threats against Taiwan, the government should adopt a more active strategy regarding international relations, he added.

As a result of the increasing influence of Chinese people abroad, the OCAC chief said Beijing has replaced its reserved approach of the past with a strategy of active rapprochement to win the hearts and minds of ethnic Chinese living abroad as part of its efforts to achieve its goal of "one country, two systems" for governing Taiwan.

Early this year, Beijing held a nationwide conference on overseas Chinese affairs -- the largest in 20 years -- which was attended by more than 240 ranking government officials, according to Chiao. Mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin declared at the meeting that Beijing's overseas Chinese affairs policy will be a significant element in its efforts to build an advanced socialist society, he added.

Since Beijing launched its economic reforms in the 1980s, the number of mainland Chinese officials involved in overseas Chinese affairs has greatly increased to a current level of more than 20,000, and over 1,000 trade, sports and cultural groups travel abroad every year to promote mainland China's image, a far greater number than Taiwan ever musters, Chiao went on to say.
Lamenting the inadequate budget earmarked by the government for this purpose, the OCAC head pointed out that its budget is tiny compared with the level distributed by Beijing.

For instance, the OCAC received a government budget of just NT$7.4 million (about US$224,000) this fiscal year to help with the operations of overseas Chinese presses, an amount which he described as a "drop in the ocean."

In contrast, Chiao said, Beijing is set to renew a wave of united front efforts later this year to mark the 50th founding of the Chinese Communist Party and the 20th anniversary of its establishment of ties with Washington, as well as the imminent return of Macao to mainland Chinese rule by the end of this year.

In addition to a round-the-clock program already being aired by the state-run China Central Television Station to the entire world, he said Beijing will also produce a 24-hour English program for the whole of Asia, and will broadcast more programs via satellite to the United States, Canada, and Latin America.

At the same time, Chiao continued, Beijing also allocates at least US$5 million every year to help fund 200 Chinese-language newspapers and more than 4 million copies of magazines in the United States. He added that by providing such a wide range of services, mainland China is gradually gaining momentum in overseas Chinese communities around the world.

Analyzing the changing situation of Taiwan and mainland China among overseas Chinese people, Chiao said Taiwan no longer enjoys the "monopoly" and the "advantages" which it had from the 1960s to the 1980s. At present, Taiwan and the mainland are at a "competing" stage, he noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC FOREX RESERVES TOP US$93 BILLION, HITTING NEW HIGH IN 44 MONTHS

TEXT.P: The Republic of China's foreign exchange reserves in March totaled US$93.005 billion, the highest level since August 1995, according to statistics released Wednesday by the Central Bank of China (CBC).
The number keeps the ROC in third place in the list of global foreign exchange reserves.

CBC's statistics show that the ROC's foreign exchange reserves at the end of March increased US$389 million compared with the previous month, and grew US$9.39 billion compared with the same month of last year.

The nation's foreign exchange reserves first topped US$100 billion in May 1995, at that time, the most in the world. Its foreign exchange reserves the following month expanded to US$100.41 billion, the nation's historic high.

The ROC's foreign exchange reserves after July 1995 decreased gradually due to changes in the domestic financial situation, the tension of relations across the Taiwan Strait and the Asian financial turmoil. However, the figures always exceeded the US$80 billion-level.
Thanks to the New Taiwan stronger dollar against the US dollar, the nation's foreign exchange reserves rallied month by month. By December of last year, the figure had risen to US$90.34 billion.

The ROC's foreign exchange reserves in the first quarter of this year increased US$2.66 billion. Dealers attributed the rise mainly to routine monthly interest earned on foreign exchange reserves and the continuous buying of foreign currencies in Taipei's foreign exchange market.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC CHIEF: NO RESTRICTIONS ON TOPICS FOR KOO-WANG TALKS

TEXT.P: Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairman Su Chi said on Wednesday that a range of difficult political topics, including the "division of China," can be taken up at the forthcoming talks between the top negotiators from mainland China and Taiwan.
Su pointed out that the recent remarks by Wang Daohan, chairman of Beijing's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait, concerning the "division of China" has become "more practical."

Therefore, he noted that Taipei will not reject political topics from being on the agenda during the talks this fall in Taiwan between Wang and his Taiwan counterpart, Straits Exchange Foundation Chairman Koo Chen-fu.
Su refined the current cross-Taiwan Strait state as "a divided China" -- "there is one China, with two equal political entities."

He said Taiwan is not afraid of engaging in talks concerning the "division of China," "equal status," "diplomacy," and "Theater Missile Defense," because the results of all talks must be then scrutinized by the legislature.

But Su said that reaching satisfactory conclusions to difficult topics in two or three years is not easy. Therefore, Taipei hopes Koo and Wang will start their talks with less difficult issues, so as to gradually improve bilateral relations.

He reiterated that Taipei will not restrict the topics to be raised by Koo and Wang, but will oppose Beijing restricting the cross-strait talks to limited political issues favoring Beijing. (By Victor Lai)

DOC.HEADLINE: FPG'S MERCURY-LACED WASTE MUST LEAVE WITHIN 45 DAYS

TEXT.P: A ship that brought back the mercury-laced waste of the Formosa Plastics Group (FPG) from Cambodia five days ago anchored in waters off Kaohsiung Harbor Wednesday afternoon.

FPG has formally applied to the Kaohsiung Harbor authority to approve entry of the cargo ship, "Eagle Prosperity". The port authority has set three conditions for entry -- that FPG posts a bond of NT$50 million (US$1.5 million), releases comprehensive pollution prevention plan and obtains the approval of the Environmental Protection Administration.
EPA officials said they will allow the ship to enter the harbor but that the 3,000 tons of mercury-laced waste in 30 containers will be housed temporarily in a warehouse wharf.
Kaohsiung authorities in a meeting Wednesday afternoon decided that the hazardous waste will have to leave the harbor within 45 days.

The mercury-tainted mercury was shipped from a FPG plant in Kaohsiung, southern Taiwan late last year to the southern coastal town of Sihanoukville, Cambodia, causing panic and chao among local residents.
FPG apologized to Cambodia for causing unrest among its residents and promised to ship the waste out of the country.

DOC.HEADLINE: 240 MAINLANDERS EMBARKED AT KEELUNG TO BE EXPATRIATED

TEXT.P: A total of 240 illegal immigrants from mainland China were boarded on navy warships in Keelung Harbor, northern Taiwan on Wednesday, in preparation for deportation back to mainland China via Matsu, Taiwan's frontline island near mainland's Fujian Province.

The 240 mainlanders, 120 men and 120 women, were boarded on three warships. The ships left Wednesday afternoon for Matsu where they will be turned over to mainland authorities by the Red Cross Society.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC TO RESTRUCTURE ECONOMY IN FACE OF NEW CHALLENGES: LIEN

TEXT.P: Republic of China Vice President Lien Chan said Wednesday the country's economy is facing the stern challenges of restructuring and called on the people to adjust their methods and thinking in order to strengthen the nation's financial security.
Lien made the remarks during a speech delivered at the Chinese National Association of Industry and Commerce general meeting Wednesday.

Despite Taiwan's economy having been in the doldrums since last year due to the Asian financial crisis, but was able to achieve a 4.8 percent growth in 1998, thanks to the joint efforts of the industrial and business sectors, Lien pointed out.

Since the 1980's, the ROC has been strengthening its economic competitiveness and promoting liberalization and globalization by privatizing state-owned enterprises, developing an Asia-Pacific Regional Operations Center (APROC) and opening up the manufacturing and industrial services to foreign investment.

Taiwan has also achieved satisfying results in upgrading its industries, Lien said, but cautioned , it doesn't mean there are no problems in our economic disposition. He called the Asian financial storm of 1997 a litmus test for Taiwan's economic system.

Taiwan was less hit by the economic depression due to the stability of commodity prices, a trade surplus and large foreign reserves, said Lien. He cautioned that in facing new challenges, the nation should strive for better discipline and secure sustainable development.

As an island, Taiwan lacks natural resources, thus it cannot afford to destroy the environment, Lien pointed out, adding that the country needs to strike a balance between economic development and sustainable development.
Lien also addressed industrial and business sector concerns, such as the improvement of public security, increased administrative efficiency, and an overhaul of the financial sector.

Lien believed that long-term positive economic developments depend on strengthening the fundamentals, which means a continuation of industrial and business research, rising the educational level and obtaining more advanced technologies to further increase Taiwan's national competitiveness.

Lien concluded that Taiwan's economy is facing structural changes. "We need to strengthen the economy fundamentals, restructure business enterprises and improve our production conditions," he said. He urged the industrial and business sectors to continue their hard work to help the ROC's overall economic development.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP AFFIRMS TRA'S CONTRIBUTION TO TAIWAN SECURITY

TEXT.P: The opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) on Wednesday issued a statement affirming the contribution of the Taiwan Relations Act (TRA) to the safeguard of Taiwan's security.

On the eve of the 20th anniversary of the TRA's enactment by the US Congress, the DPP said that the TRA has been "an important pillar" to the maintenance of the security of the Taiwan Strait and the peace of East Asia during the past 20 years.

The statement noted that the DPP has no intention of provoking conflicts between mainland China and Taiwan over the "Taiwan independence" issue, because the party understands the United States' deep concern, as stipulated in the TRA, over the stability of the Western Pacific.

The DPP indicated it supports the US asking Beijing to give up military attempts to take over Taiwan, and called for effective international cooperation to control mainland China's weapon proliferation.

The party expressed its appreciation for the US Congress' support for Taiwan, and hopes that the US will follow the provisos in the TRA to support Taiwan's entry into the International Monetary Fund, the World Health Organization and the World Bank.
The DPP advocates Taiwan's joining the World Trade Organization (WTO), because only under the WTO guaranteed framework, can Taiwan gradually open its trade with mainland China.

DOC.HEADLINE: BAUER BLASTS CLINTON POLICIES TOWARD MAINLAND
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 7 (CNA) (By Victor Lai) (By Nelson Chung)

TEXT.P: Washington, April 6 (CNA): The visit of Chinese Premier Zhu Rongji to the United States this week "exposes the absolute weakness and wrong-headedness of the Clinton-Gore administration's foreign policy," said Republican presidential contender Gary Bauer Tuesday.

"Rather than considering the many valid reasons why China should not be rewarded a coveted World Trade Organization (WTO) membership, President Clinton and his top officials have been pulling out all stops to seal a deal. Once again, we are confronted by the sad spectacle of photo-op diplomacy," Bauer noted in a statement.

"Our foreign policy is being driven by trade considerations. Rather than basing diplomatic decisions on national security and support for human rights, we are chasing dollars," added the leading critic of the Clinton administration's zealous desire to have Beijing join the WTO.

By all objective measures, Bauer stressed, "China should be facing condemnation rather than rewards. The plain fact is that China has emerged as the world's gravest threat to American values and security. It is incredible that our leaders refuse to acknowledge this simple reality."

He continued that in the last two months, "it has become clear that China stole some of our most important and sensitive nuclear secrets; that they continue to threaten the United States and its allies over important security matters in Asia; and that the Chinese government continues to ruthlessly clamp down on basic human rights. Yet this administration rushes to help the Chinese gain a coveted seat on the WTO."

Bauer concluded that "It is time to relink human rights and American values to America's foreign policy with China. We should put the brakes on Chinese membership in WTO. We should deny China most favored nation trading status. It is time common sense returned to American foreign policy."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN FUGITIVE REPORTEDLY APPEARS IN XIAMEN

TEXT.P: A convicted Taiwanese former politician who allegedly jumped bail was spotted Wednesday in Xiamen, Fujian Province.

The China Times reported on Wednesday that Nien Chung-jen, the former deputy speaker of the Changhua County Council, has failed twice to report to prosecutors in Taitung County despite being summoned to begin a thirty-five-month sentence.
A gangster-turned politician, Nien was convicted of one count of hiring illegal mainlanders as bodyguards, and two counts of racketeering.

He has also been convicted of killing a backhoe driver in an racketeering attempt against his employer, a sand and gravel site owner. That case is still under review by the Taiwan High Court after Nien appealed a 20-year imprisonment sentence handed down by the Taitung District Court.

Nien was the first gangster-turned politician detained in the government's crusade against the underworld in 1997. In December of that year, he was transferred from Green Island Jail where most of the island's gang lords are detained to a hospital in Hualien County for medical treatment, and then released on bond of NT$2 million.
Court documents show that he had a body weight of only 39 kg when he was released due to kidney disease.
Nien has failed since the beginning of this year to turn up at court hearings to review his release on bail for health reasons.
An official from the Criminal Investigation Bureau told CNA that police are looking into the allegations that Nien has fled to mainland China.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC FOREIGN MINISTER SPEAKS OF TRA IMPORTANCE

TEXT.P: Republic of China Foreign Minister Jason Hu said on Wednesday that the United States should continue to honor its commitment to Taiwan, and to provide Taiwan with sufficient deterrent power.
Hu made the remarks at a public hearing on the "20th anniversary of the Taiwan Relations Act and US-China relations," hosted by the Democratic Progressive Party's caucus in the Legislative Yuan.

He said that only if the US continues to fulfill its commitment, to provide Taiwan with necessary defensive weapons, and to indicate its resolve to safeguard the security of the Taiwan Strait, can the 20-year TRA continue to display its power.
The foreign minister expressed satisfaction over US fulfillment of its promise to protect the security of the Western Pacific and to maintain substantive relations between Washington and Taipei.
But he said Taiwan's economic power has also played an important role in the island's current development, and he attributed Taiwan's achievements to self-dependence.

At the hearing, Legislator Parris Chang of the DPP described the TRA as virtually an "umbrella of protection" for Taiwan. But he complained that US arms sales to Taiwan have been affected by the US-PRC joint statement of August 17, 1982.
Other speakers on the occasion included Mainland Affairs Council Chairman Su Chi and Pao Tsung-ho, director of the Department of Politics under National Taiwan University.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEE URGES GOODWILL TO PROMOTE NORMAL CROSS-STRAIT RELATIONS

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui said on Wednesday that both sides of the Taiwan Strait should focus on developing their economies and democracies to maximum the benefit of the people.
Lee made the remarks when he met with overseas scholars prior to an international conference on mainland China's reforms.
Lee said that the ROC has always worked toward negotiation, instead of confrontation, and the use of communication to assuage hostilities between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.

Noting that Wang Daohan, mainland China's top negotiation with Taiwan, will visit Taiwan in the autumn, Lee expressed his sincere welcome, saying that a little more goodwill, and a little less hostility, a little more mutual trust, and a little less suspicion, will contribute to normal cross-strait relations.
Lee said that Wang and his Taiwan counterpart, Koo Chen-fu, last October agreed that they would step up dialogue and engage in an institutional channel of communication.

The president also said that democracy will play an ever increasing important role in the development of cross-strait relations, adding that when mainland China deepens its reforms, it will help its democratization. And when the mainland China becomes more democratic, it will help cross-strait relations.
Lee said that he calls any nation democratic if it respects human rights, the rule of law, and pays attention to the value and dignity of men.
Lee noted that reforms implemented by the mainland have resulted in structural changes, and that they have substantially improved the lives of mainland people in coastal areas and major cities.
As the mainland economy becomes market oriented and privatized, it effectively undermines the Beijing power base as well as deepens the craving for democracy among its people, Lee said.

The president said that during the five decades of separated rule between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, the ROC has pushed through political reforms and economic development. Such a valuable "Taiwan experience," has won recognition among the international community and has become the model for developing countries.

Lee said the "Taiwan experience" has also played a substantial role in reforming the mainland, reaffirming that close exchanges between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait bring about positive effects.
The two-day conference, dubbed "the PRC's Reforms at Twenty: Retrospects and Prospects" will open at the Grand Hotel Friday.

DOC.HEADLINE: DEFENSE MINISTER PROPOSES CHANGES IN MILITARY SERVICE

TEXT.P: The government is mulling a cut in the number of conscripts from three-fourths of the whole military strength to one-half, said the Minister of National Defense Tang Fei on Wednesday.
The other half will be filled by volunteer recruits, said Tang, in a brief to the Legislative Yuan on the military conscription overhaul.
Other change aimed at increasing the professionalism of the armed forces, is shortening the period of mandatory military service from two years to one year, said Tang.
Owing to the government's limited financial sources, and the concerns about national security , Tang ruled out the possibility to replace draftees completely with recruits, said Tang.

The MOND set a target of 400,000 as the number of armed force personnel necessary for the island's defense. That number, however, is beyond the government's means if some of them were not conscripted, explained Tang.
A thoroughly assessment will be completed within two years, and the half-half formula for draftee and recruits will be appropriate whatever the strength of armed forces is, said Tang.

Tang pledged to trim the 60 percent portion of the national defense budget devoted to armed forces personnel, admitting the number is high compared to 30 percent in the United States and 50 percent in Japan. Tang blamed the figure on deep cuts in the defense budget.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies Thursday are as follows:

DOC.HEADLINE: IDB, RAYTHEON TO JOINTLY TACKLE Y2K PROBLEMS

TEXT.P: Raytheon Co. of the United States will join Taiwan's Industrial Development Bureau (IDB) in its efforts to tackle the year 2000 computer problems in the country's industrial sector, IDB sources reported on Thursday.
IDB forged an agreement Wednesday with Raytheon, formally contracting the renowned US missile manufacturer to help out in preparing Taiwan to deal with the Millennium Bug, also known as Y2K.

Under the agreement, Raytheon will provide IDB with Y2K technology and relevant inspection software packages. In return, IDB will seek offset industrial cooperation contracts for Raytheon from other related Taiwan companies, said IDB Director General Wang Ya-kang.
Wang predicted that 80 percent of the companies in Taiwan's manufacturing sector will pass the Y2K test on Friday, April 9, or the 99th day of 1999.

There is fear worldwide that Y2K may attack as early as April 9 of this year, when internal computer clocks and chip sets show the numeral 9999. According to the dating system used in some old computer systems, April 9 is displayed as the 99th day of 1999.

However, 9999, the highest four-digit number, is also often used to represent certain special codes, such as a calculation error, which may lead some older computer systems to crash or display faulty data.
Wang expected that 90 percent of the companies in Taiwan's manufacturing sector will be Y2K compliant by the end of 1999.

Under the agreement, personnel from the IDB Y2K Service Group, the Institute for Information Industry, and the Industrial Technology Research Institute will regularly attend future training workshops sponsored by Raytheon in regard to Y2K handling measures and technologies, Wang added.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN PHILANTHROPIC GROUP TO LEAVE FOR MACEDONIA

TEXT.P: A Republic of China delegation comprised of government officials and representatives from private philanthropic organizations is scheduled to leave for Macedonia next Monday to provide medical and other humanitarian assistance to the Balkan country.

Vice Foreign Affairs Minister David Lee will lead the ROC delegation, which will also include doctors and nurses, as well as officials from the Department of Health and the Red Cross Society of the ROC.

Other members of the delegation will be representatives from private charity groups that include the Buddhist Compassion Relief Tzu Chi Foundation, the Buddhist Fo Kuang Shan Foundation, World Vision of Taiwan, the ROC Chapter of the International Lions' Club, Kiwanis International, ROC District, the Mingtao Cultural Center, the Taiwan Luchu Association and the Taiwan Pharmaceutical Association.

In consideration of fact that flight schedules are erratic because of NATO air strikes on Yugoslavia, MOFA has chartered a China Airlines direct flight from Taipei to Skopje, to carry the ROC delegation to Macedonia, according to MOFA officials.

Lee and other officials are scheduled to stay in Macedonia for three days while members of the medical and philanthropic groups will stay for at least two weeks to join relief efforts, the officials said.
The ROC will also send a second round of cash aid to Macedonia to help settle Albanian refugees, who so far total more than 120,000, officials from the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said.
MOFA officials, however, would not reveal the exact amount of the new cash aid to Macedonia, the ROC's most recent ally. It is understood that the amount will be more than US$2 million.
Taipei sent US$2 million to Macedonia on March 26 to help the country settle Albanian refugees from Kosovo.

Stressing that money is not the only way Taiwan can help its friend, MOFA officials said Taiwan's 17 philanthropic organizations are joining the government in the relief cause. The philanthropic groups will provide medical and other material assistance to Macedonia with Taiwan personnel flying there to personally render service.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, April 8, or the 22nd day of the second month of the Year of the Rabbit according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
217 AD: Caracalla, or Marcus Aurelius Antonius, the Roman emperor who was obsessed with and sought to imitate Alexander the Great, is assassinated after a bloody reign.
1838: The Great Western, a new 236-foot steamship which is the first to cross the Atlantic regularly, leaves Bristol on her maiden voyage to Boston.
1861: Elisha Graves Otis, the American inventor of the passenger elevator which was first installed in 1857, dies at the age of 50.
1902: The Ching court and Russia reach agreement on the evacuation of Manchuria. After the Boxer Uprising in 1900, Russia took the opportunity to occupy Manchuria. When the troops of the other foreign powers withdrew from Chinese territory, Russia refused to leave Manchuria.
1907: France and Britain sign convention confirming the independence of Siam (now Thailand).
1913: Brazil officially recognizes the Republic of China, which was founded in Jan. 1, 1912, becoming the first country in the world to do so.
1925: The Australian government and the British Colonial Office offer low-interest loans to encourage 500,000 Britons to emigrate to Australia.
1946: The League of Nations holds its final session in Geneva. It was later replaced by the United Nations.
1950: Pakistan and India sign pact in New Delhi on the treatment of minorities.
1965: The Republic of China severs diplomatic relations with the Republic of Dahomey.
1966: Leonid Brezhnev is elected general secretary of the Soviet Communist Party. He later became president of the USSR in 1977.
1973: Pablo Picasso, the Spanish artist who was one of the most prolific and influential artists of the 20th century, dies in his chateau at Mougins at the age of 92. He excelled in painting, sculpture, etching, stage design, and ceramics.
1977: Israeli Prime Minister Yitzak Rabin admits violating Israel's currency laws. He later resigned.
1979: Lee Pao-chen, a noted Chinese musician, dies in Taipei at the age of 73.
1986: Clint Eastwood, the screen tough guy famed for his portrayal of "Dirty Harry," is elected mayor of Carmel, a Californian resort town.
1989: More than 60 Soviet submariners die after a nuclear-powered "Mike" class submarine refuses assistance from nearby Western merchant ships after catching fire off the coast of Norway.
1990: ROC Economics Minister Chen Li-an and Singaporean Minister of Trade and Industries Lee Hsien Loong preside over the first ministerial-level conference on economic cooperation between the two countries.
1994: Japanese Prime Minister Morihiro Hosokawa resigns over a loan scandal.
1995: At a meeting of the National Unification Council, ROC President Lee Teng-hui offers a six-point proposal for Taiwan-mainland China relations.
Confucius lesson of the day: "A gentleman who only thinks of the comforts of life, cannot be a true gentleman."

DOC.HEADLINE: DECREASED EXPORTS, INVESTMENTS CAUSED ROC ECONOMIC RECESSION IN 1998

TEXT.P: A decrease in exports and investment in domestic inventories were the two major factors that caused the nation's economic growth rate last year to be significantly lower than originally targeted, the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) said Thursday.
The Republic of China's economy in 1998 only grew 4.8 percent, much lower than the expected 6.7 percent level, and the lowest level since 1983.
CEPD said due to the lingering effects of the Asian financial turmoil many of the nation's targeted macroeconomic goals were not achieved last year.

However, the CEPD said, compared with other nations in East Asia, the ROC's macroeconomic performance in 1998 was relatively stable. The three characteristics of the nation's macroeconomic performance in 1998 were:
-- the economy maintained moderate growth;
-- the misery index increased slightly; and
-- financial markets fluctuated.

The nation's 4.8 percent economic growth rate in 1998 ranked the 15th in the world. Due to the New Taiwan dollar's weakness against the US dollar, the nation's 1998 gross national product (GNP) declined to US$262.3 billion if calculated in US dollars. The per capita GNP also dropped to US$12,040, retreating to 1994 and 1995 levels respectively.

The CEPD indicated that the ROC's exports in 1998 decreased significantly, leading to a shrinkage of the nation's trade surplus with a contribution to the overall economy 1.2 percentage points smaller than estimated.

Last year, consumption by the ROC government and private sector kept the nation growing. The two sectors' spending contributed 0.5 percentage points more to the economy than was expected, however, investments by the government and private sector did not attain targeted goals.

Investments in domestic inventories in 1998 declined significantly, mainly due to a large decline in demand for all commodities. The nation's total government and private sector investments in 1998 lagged 0.7 percentage points behind their targeted contribution rate to the economy.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC WELCOMES CLINTON'S REAFFIRMATION OF US COMMITMENT TO TAIWAN
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, April 7 (CNA) (By Nelson Chung and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The Republic of China welcomes and appreciates US President Bill Clinton's reaffirmation of his administration support for the ROC's cause, the Taipei representative office in the United States said on Wednesday.

The de facto ROC embassy in Washington, D.C. issued the statement after Clinton delivered an important foreign policy speech, in which he said the United States will continue to maintain strong, unofficial relations with democratic Taiwan.

Clinton also reaffirmed the consistent US stance that the two sides of the Taiwan Strait should resolve their disputes with strictly peaceful means. Clinton delivered the speech at a presentation organized by the US Institute for Peace.
In response, the ROC representative office said pursuing peaceful solution to cross-strait disputes has long been Taipei's basic policy toward its relations with mainland China.

"Clinton's speech indicates that our stance on the solution to cross-strait differences complies with America's," the statement said, adding that the ROC will continue promoting constructive dialogue and contact with mainland China to forge mutual understanding and trust.

The statement went on to say that the ROC deems it a "timely move" Clinton's reaffirmation of the US policy toward Taiwan as mainland Chinese Premier Zhu Rongji arrived in Washington, D.C. for an official visit.

In his speech, Clinton touched on Taiwan-related topics many times, signifying his concern about the situation in the Taiwan Strait as well as the US determination to maintain peace and stability in the region.
