DOC.HEADLINE: RENOWNED HORSE PAINTER PASSES AWAY AT 90

TEXT.P: A veteran artist known for his paintings of horses, Yeh Tzuei-pai died of pneumonia Tuesday at the age of 90, though memories of his paintings and of the artist himself will live on in fans in both Taiwan and abroad.

Yeh, a general who followed Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek in battles against the Japanese and against Chinese communists before turning to painting, will be remembered for Chinese brush paintings of horses full of life and beauty.

His most famous work -- "Sky Horse" -- is symbolic of Yeh's paintings and so illustrious that one of his fans in Japan is building a "Sky Horse Museum of Fine Art" exclusively to display Yeh's paintings.

Kazushige Fujino, a rich Japanese businessman who several years ago came to Taiwan trying to purchase some artistic masterpieces to beef up his personal collection, was moved by Yeh's horses and consequently developed a long-lasting friendship with Yeh.

Fujino was so touched by Yeh's "Sky Horse" that he wrote an essay titled "The Dandelion" to describe his feelings as he observed the flying horse. He said in the article that he found where his heart belonged simply by looking at the horse.

He financially sponsored an exhibition of Yeh's works in Tokyo's Ginza, and is now having built a fine art museum exclusively to display Yeh's horses. The museum is expected to open to the public on May 25 this year.

Yeh, who will be saluted by the Republic of China government in a military-sponsored funeral service, insisted that he be cremated and that his ashes be scattered into the Pacific Ocean, according to his family members.
During his 50-year artistic career, Yeh was twice conferred with citations by presidents of the Republic of China and received numerous awards for his artistic achievements.

DOC.HEADLINE: CLINTON AGAIN DEFENDS ENGAGEMENT POLICY
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 8 (CNA) (By Deborah Kuo) (By Nelson Chung)

TEXT.P: Washington, April 7 (CNA): The United States has maintained strong unofficial ties to a democratic Taiwan while upholding its "one China" policy, and has encouraged both sides to resolve their differences peacefully and to have increased contact, US President Bill Clinton said Wednesday.
But he added that the US has also "made clear that neither can count on our acceptance if it violates these principles".

In a foreign policy address on US-China relations, Clinton once again defended his policy of engagement with the People's Republic of China, claiming that bringing former adversaries Russia and mainland China into the international system as open, prosperous and stable nations is one of the major challenges for America in the next century.
The president said he wanted to speak about the US' relationship with the PRC because it is being tested and hotly debated as mainland Chinese Premier Zhu Rongji arrives in Washington.

A growing number of people, who say that the PRC is the next great threat to US security and well-being, "are concerned rightly by Chinese missiles aimed at Taiwan and at others," admitted Clinton, adding, "We know that in the past decade, China has increased its deployment of missiles near Taiwan. When China tested some of those missiles in 1996, tensions grew in the Taiwan Strait."

But Clinton noted, "We demonstrated then with the deployment of our carriers that America will act to prevent a miscalculation there. Our interests lie in peace and stability in Taiwan and in China, in the Strait and in the region, and in a peaceful resolution of the differences. We will do what is necessary to maintain our interests."

The United States has known since the early 1980s that the PRC has nuclear-armed missiles capable of reaching the US. "Our defense posture has and will continue to take account of that reality," added Clinton.

The president, however, pointed out that because of US engagement, mainland China has "at best marginally increased its deployed nuclear threat in the last 15 years." By signing the Comprehensive Test Ban Treaty, mailand China has accepted constraints on its ability to modernize its arsenal at a time when the nuclear balance remains overwhelmingly in favor of the United States.

Clinton also said the United States is determined to prevent the diversion of technology and sensitive information to the PRC, and the restrictions placed on US exports to mainland China are tougher than those applied to any other major exporting country in the world.

But he believed that mainland China's biggest challenge in the coming years will be "to maintain stability and growth at home by meeting, not stifling, the growing demands of its people for openness and accountability. It is easy for us to say; for them it is a daunting task."

In fact, the president continued, almost every goal to which Beijing leaders are dedicated, from maintaining stability to rooting out corruption, and to reuniting peacefully with Taiwan, would actually be advanced if they embraced greater openness and accountability.

Yet citing the lessons from Japan's long recession and Russia's current economic troubles, Clinton said "as we focus on the potential challenge that a strong China could present to the United States in the future, let us not forget the risk of a weak China beset by internal conflicts, social dislocation and criminal activity, becoming a vast zone of instability in Asia."

The president noted that "we can only deal with the challenge if we continue a policy of principled, purposeful engagement with China's leaders and China's people.....Our long-term strategy must be to encourage the right kind of development in China, to help China grow at home into a strong, prosperous and open society coming together, not falling apart; to integrate China into the institutions that promote global norms on proliferation, trade, the environment and human rights."

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR UP

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar rose NT$0.012 against the greenback on the Taipei market Thursday, closing at 33.118.
The local currency opened at 33.128 and was traded between 33.112 and 33.136.
The interbank US dollar trading reached US$334.5 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIAN UNEMPLOYMENT RATE FALLING
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 8 (CNA) (By Elizabeth Hsu) (By Peter Chen)

TEXT.P: Canberra, April 8 (CNA): Australia's unemployment rate is expected to drop below 7 percent in the second half of this year as the country's economy continues to perform strongly, employing more people, according to a new survey by one of the four leading banks here.

The quarterly survey by the National Australia Bank shows that the retail, construction, business service and communication sectors are shrugging off fears about a global slowdown and as a result trading conditions and confidence remain high.

The survey shows improved trading, profitability and employment conditions throughout the economy during the first three months of this year. The bank will revise upward a government forecast of Australia's GDP (gross domestic product) growth to more than 4 percent in fiscal 1998-99 from the previous estimate of 3.25 percent.
Australia's GDP grew 4.8 percent in fiscal 1997-98, the highest among developed countries.
The bank also predicts that employment will rise which will result in the unemployment rate falling below 7 percent in the second half of this year. The unemployment rate currently is 7.4 percent.
Federal Treasurer Peter Costello said his government's goal is to bring the unemployment rate down to 5 percent in the longer term. He did not specify when that goal would be attained.

DOC.HEADLINE: POLL FINDS LOCAL PEOPLE HAVE LITTLE KNOWLEDGE ABOUT Y2K

TEXT.P: The majority of Taiwan people do not know the Y2K hazard, according to the results of a public opinion poll released on Thursday.

The telephone poll of 1,216 adults, conducted on April 4-5 by a market research company at the request of Legislator Lin Chih-chia, found that 84.7 percent of the respondents said they have no idea what Y2K means.

According to the poll, 38.3 percent said they think Y2K is a cosmetic brand name; 15 percent said they deem Y2K a household article; and only 18.3 percent said they know Y2K refers to the year 2000 computer problem.
Survey results further show that 67.7 percent of those interviewed said they do not have confidence in the government's ability to tackle the Y2K- or Millennium Bug-related issues.

Meanwhile, the poll found that 80.3 percent of the respondents have not installed computers in their own home, and as high as 92.5 percent said they do not know the Millennium Bug may attack as early as Friday or April 9, when internal computer clocks and chipsets show the numeral 9999. According to the dating system used in some old computer systems, April 9 is displayed as 99th day of 1999.
Analyzing the survey results, Legislator Lin said the government is to blame for local people's little knowledge about the possible Y2K threat to their personal and property safety.

Lin said the government should step up publicity efforts to help ordinary members of the public understand the critical Y2K hazard. He suggested that the Cabinet call an interministerial meeting, to be chaired by Vice Premier Liu Chao-hsuan, to discuss measures to ensure "zero defects" in Y2K control at various government departments and industrial sectors.

Lin also urged local people to check their bank passbooks on Thursday to avoid any possible financial losses in case the Millennium Bug really attacks on Friday. "If possible, local people should also avoid taking a flight tomorrow," he suggested.

DOC.HEADLINE: 1 DEAD, 38 INJURED IN TAIPEI BUS ACCIDENT

TEXT.P: One person was killed and 38 injured on Thursday morning when one city bus plowed into another, knocking the second bus into several cars and motorcycles, and then hitting several others itself.

The accident occurred at around 8:30 a.m. when a bus driven by 32-year-old Chiu Wen-chih hit another bus at the intersection of Hsinhseng South Road and Hoping East Road. Chiu, who was driving a Capital Transport Co. bus, was supposed to have turned left from Hsinhseng South Road onto Hsinyi Road. But he failed to make the turn and instead proceeded to the next intersection.

Chiu did not slow as he neared the intersection, even though traffic in his direction was stopped for a red light. Chiu's bus, a No. 226 Capital bus, rear ended a No. 311 Chunghsin bus. Propelled by the powerful collision, the two buses crashed into five automobiles, three taxis, three motorcycles and one bike. In all 38 people were slightly or seriously injured in the accident.
Twenty-seven-year-old motorcycle driver Kuo Jui-wen was hit by one of the buses and trapped underneath its wheels. She died after being rushed to the hospital.
Police are now investigating the cause of the accident. In particular they will seek to understand why Chiu did not follow his normal route and turn from Hsinhseng South Road onto Hsinyi Road.
Chiu underwent Thursday a series of tests at National Taiwan University Hospital (NTUH) to ascertain his mental state. Police said passengers reported that Chiu appeared to be in a trance.
Capital Transport President Lee Chien-wen said his company would not seek to escape punishment and would provide compensation if it is found to have been at fault.
Lee said initial police investigations indicated that the brakes on Chiu's bus had failed, and police are trying to determine whether the failure occurred before or after the accident.
Lee noted that Chiu had worked for Capital for two years and had a clean record. Before working for Capital, Chiu had been a tour bus driver, Lee said.
Meanwhile, Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou paid a visit to the victims of the accident, who were being treated at NTUH and Jen Ai Hospital.
Ma also extended his heartfelt condolences to Kuo's family, saying that he was sorry the accident resulted in the loss of life. He said he is determined to punish those responsible for the tragedy.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT LEE RECEIVES TRADE DELEGATION FROM NEBRASKA

TEXT.P: President Lee Teng-hui said Thursday the Republic of China has completed preparations for entry into the World Trade Organization and that it is waiting for the arrival of the right time.
President Lee made the remark when receiving an 11-member economic and trade delegation from the US state of Nebraska led by Gov. Mike Johanns.

Johanns said he last visited the Republic of China seven years ago. In his current visit, he said he can see that the Republic of China has made great strides in the development of its political and economic systems.

President Lee said that in addition to striving for political and economic reform, a renaissance of Chinese culture would be conducive to democratic politics and a free economic system. He also indicated that the ROC's successful development experience can be a model for the future development of mainland China.

In regard to bilateral economic and trade cooperation, President Lee said Taiwan province and Nebraska state established sisterly ties in 1983, and the volume of two-way agricultural trade between them has been significant. There is more room for the two sides to enlarge this type of trade in the future, he added.
President Lee said agriculture is not a sunset industry and that it should be combined with high technology to promote its development.

Accompanied by Vice Foreign Minister David Lee, the Nebraskan delegation went to the Presidential Office in the morning to call on President Lee. Also present were Ding Mou-shih, senior adviser to the president, and Lin Pi-chao, deputy secretary-general to the president.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOTC MINISTER TO FLY TO SHOW CONFIDENCE IN Y2K CONTROL

TEXT.P: Transportation and Communications Minister Lin Feng-cheng will travel by air to the southern port city of Kaohsiung on Friday to show his confidence in the domestic civil aviation agency's ability to handle the Y2K challenge.
Lin made the decision during a meeting of the Legislative Yuan's Transportation and Communications Affairs Committee.
During the meeting, some lawmakers expressed concern about the Civil Aeronautics Administration's (CAA's) preparedness for the impending Y2K crisis.

Opposition Legislator Tsai Huang-lang suggested that Lin take the first scheduled flight from Taipei to Kaohsiung on April 9 to enhance the public's confidence in the CAA's ability to tackle the year 2000 computer problems satisfactorily.

April 9, when some internal computer clocks and chipsets will show the numeral 9999, is likely to be the first day when the Y2K, also known as the Millennium Bug, may attack. According to the dating system used in some old computer systems, April 9 will be displayed as the 99th day of 1999.
The problem with this is that the numeral 9999 is also used as a computer error code, which means computers may crash or behave erratically when they read the number.
In response, Lin said he would accept Tsai's proposal if the legislative committee made a formal decision on the proposed travel plan.
The committee then adopted a resolution inviting Lin and CAA Director-General Chang Yo-heng to take a flight to Kaohsiung on Friday in the company of committee members.
Lin, Chang and several legislators will take a UNI Airlines flight from Taipei to Kaohsiung at 6:55 a.m. on Friday, and return to Taipei after having breakfast at Kaohsiung airport.
"The round-trip flight is mainly aimed at demonstrating to the public that our civil aviation facilities will be able to pass the Y2K challenges," Lin said.

In the face of the possible computer failures on Friday, Lin said, the CAA has formed a special task force to handle any emergencies. "The CAA Y2K special task force will begin operations on Thursday evening and will not be disbanded until 8 a.m. April 10, by which time we will have been able to prove that our civil aviation control system can survive the Y2K test," the minister noted.

Lin further said if the aviation control system is affected by the Millennium Bug, the CAA has two measures to cope with the situation. One is to resume the operating system used 28 years ago, while the other is to resort to manual operations.

Meanwhile, Lin said all other operations and services under the jurisdiction of the Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC), including freeway toll collection, mobile phone communications and postal savings deposits and money transfer services, have also already been adjusted to cope with possible Y2K challenges.
"I believe there will not be any problems with any MOTC-administered services on Friday. We will be able to pass the Y2K-related tests," Lin said confidently.

DOC.HEADLINE: US POLICY ANALYST SAYS US MUST STAND UP FOR TMD SYSTEM IN ASIA

TEXT.P: Mainland China's increased deployment of missiles near Taiwan requires that the United States sell Taiwan Theater Missile Defense systems, and such sales are consistent with the goal of the 1979 Taiwan Relations Act as well as the US goal that future Taiwan-mainland China relations be determined by peaceful means, according to a senior American policy analyst.

Richard D. Fisher, Jr., director of the Asian Studies Center at the Heritage Foundation, wrote Wednesday in a background analysis that mainland China's growing missile forces and its campaign to block the development and deployment of US missile defenses pose a serious challenge to US-mainland China relations and to stability in Asia.

The prevention of a future crisis with mainland China requires that America be firm and resolute in responding to future mainland Chinese threats. "Missile defenses in Asia can help to persuade China that missile competition with the United States cannot succeed, and that China must instead refrain from threatening the US and its Asian neighbors," said the analyst.

Fisher noted that revelations that mainland China stole US nuclear warhead secrets highlight two strategic challenges to the United States. First, new, small nuclear warheads -- developed with the help of US information on warhead designs -- will allow mainland China to put multiple warheads on new intercontinental ballistic missiles or equip short-range missiles with nuclear warheads.

In Asia, mainland China already has increased to over 100 the number of missiles targeted at Taiwan, and future theater ballistic and cruise missiles could threaten US forces and allies in Asia, said Fisher.

Second, mainland China's vigorous campaign to block missile defense cooperation between the United States and Japan and future US sales of missile defense equipment to Taiwan "seeks to preserve a growing advantage in missile forces while putting great pressure on US allies in Asia in the hope that this will weaken their alliances with the United States," he said.

Fisher said if the United States and its allies did not cooperate in missile defenses, this would "undermine allied confidence in US defense commitments and force Asian states to consider building their own missiles to deter China."
The People's Liberation Army hopes that by developing a range of nuclear and non-nuclear missiles, it can deter American support for Taiwan and project military power in Asia, added the analyst.

For mainland China, missiles are a weapon system that it can produce; it has much difficulty in producing modern combat aircraft and warships. Missiles also address a military weakness of the United States and its allies: the lack of effective missile defense systems, said Fisher.

He continued that by having more accurate missiles mainland China will be able to seek greater political leverage in Asia, and mainland China will likely use the threat of its new missile forces to coerce political concessions, especially from Taiwan.

Fisher wrote that mainland China also hopes to create the impression that American defensive missiles, not mainland China's offensive missiles, threaten peace in Asia. But it can be expected that mainland China will increase its missile forces in response to US missile defense plans. The Clinton administration is not responding adequately to mainland China's threats and is not sufficiently affirming the need for US missile defenses, he said.

"China's attack against US missile defense plans must be seen as an attempt to limit the future scope of US alliances in Asia. This is unacceptable for the United States, as its alliances are a vital element of its national security in Asia," said Fisher.

To prevent the US-mainland China relationship from lapsing into a Cold War-like confrontation, Fisher stressed that America must demonstrate resolve and leadership in responding to the challenge of mainland China's growing missile forces and its anti-missile defense campaign.

The United States should state that mainland China's missiles threaten peace in Asia; deploy national missile defenses; use Theater Missile Defense systems to strengthen US alliances in Asia; sell Theater Missile Defense systems to Taiwan; and suspend commercial space cooperation with mainland China pending missile control negotiations, concluded Fisher.

DOC.HEADLINE: NOBEL LAUREATES CALL FOR CLOSER TAIWAN-AUSTRALIAN COOPERATION

TEXT.P: A symposium on Australia-Taiwan research collaboration opened in Taipei to discuss effective measures to promote scientific and technological cooperation between the two countries.
Speaking at the opening session, Australian Nobel laureate Peter Doherty said Australia has made remarkable progress in agricultural, mining and biotechnological fields in recent years.

"As both Taiwan and Australia are Asia-Pacific countries, they should strengthen cooperation in scientific and technological research for mutual benefits," said the winner of the 1996 Nobel Prize in medicine.

Yuan T. Lee, president of Academia Sinica, Taiwan's highest research body, echoed Doherty's view, saying that the Republic of China and Australia can complemented each other in scientific and technological development.
Noting that Australia has outstanding achievements in the development of basic sciences, Lee said Taiwan has accumulated huge amount of capital and production capabilities over past decades.

Against this backgound, Lee said there is ample room for Taiwan and Australia to cooperate in scientific and technological research and development. Lee was a co-winner of the 1986 Nobel Prize in chemistry.
Earlier in the day, Doherty met with ROC President Lee Teng-hui for wide-ranging talks. Yuan T. Lee was also present at the Lee-Doherty meeting.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN RELATIONS ACT IS 20 YEARS OLD (I)

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Relations Act (TRA), a US law that governs unofficial ties between the United States and the Republic of China on Taiwan, will be 20 years old on April 10.

US President Jimmy Carter announced on Dec. 15, 1978 that the United States had decided to establish diplomatic relations with the People's Republic of China on Jan. 1, 1979 and cut its formal ties with the Republic of China. A special law was needed to regulate America's relations with Taiwan in the absence of formal ties.

In late January 1979, President Carter sent a hastily drafted bill, known as the Omnibus Bill, to the US Congress for deliberation and enactment. The bill clarified the application of American laws to the people of Taiwan so as to allow for an unofficial relationship between the peoples of the two countries.

Many members of Congress were unhappy with Carter because of his decision to recognize Beijing without fully consulting them. They also thought Carter had not given enough consideration to the security of Taiwan and its people. Therefore, they decided to revise the draft bill by adding new provisions that offered more security guarantees to Taiwan. The revised bill, later known as the TRA, was signed into law by Carter on April 10, 1979.

In addition to maintaining cultural and commercial ties between the United States and the Republic of China, the law also allows the United States to sell defensive weapons and equipment to Taiwan to ensure its security.

After Washington recognized mainland China, the Sino(ROC)-US Mutual Defense Treaty signed in 1954 was suspended, resulting in the withdrawal of American forces stationed in Taiwan. The TRA then became a timely replacement to the mutual defense treaty.

Under the TRA, the United States is obliged to assist Taiwan when it faces a military threat. During the 1996 Taiwan Strait crisis, caused by the firing of missiles into the seas around Taiwan by mainland Chinese forces during military exercises, the US government sent two aircraft carrier battle groups to waters near Taiwan to prevent Beijing from further aggression. The situation eased because of the US move.
Due to the United States' determination to fulfill its commitment, peace and stability in the Taiwan Strait have been maintained during the past 20 years. (more)

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN RELATIONS ACT IS 20 YEARS OLD (II)

TEXT.P: With the implementation of the TRA, commercial and cultural relations between the two countries have developed steadily despite the lack of formal ties. ROC-US trade in 1978 was a mere US$7.3 billion. The two-way trade volume between the two countries reached US$49.07 billion in 1998, an increase of more than six fold over 20 years. The Republic of China has become an important trading partner of the United States.

In 1978, the ROC government approved 10 investment projects in Taiwan from the United States with a combined capital of US$69.8 million. Last year, 208 projects with a total investment of US$887.2 million were approved, a 12-fold increase in 20 years. Meanwhile, the ROC's investments in the United States jumped from US$3.3 million in 1978 to US$598.7 million last year.

Culturally, the United States has continued to be the ideal place for Taiwan students to pursue advanced studies. In 1978, 4,350 Taiwan students went to the United States for advanced studies. By 1998 that figure had jumped to 13,190.

Arms sales constitute the core of the TRA, which stipulates that the United States shall sell sufficient defensive weapons and equipment to Taiwan to meet its security needs. As a result, the Republic of China has been able to buy tanks, missiles, warships, jet fighters and other military hardware from the United States. The ROC's total purchases since the act's enactment are estimated at some US$40 billion.
Jaw Ling Joanne Chang, a research fellow at Academia Sinica's Institute of European and American Studies, said during a recent CNA interview that the TRA has served the following purposes:
--It has prevented crises and deterred Beijing aggression toward Taiwan;
--It has created a viable environment for Taiwan to develop its economy and democratic political system;
--It has enabled the people of Taiwan to pursue a free, democratic and prosperous life, setting a good example for mainland China to follow; and
--It has given Taiwan confidence to increase contacts with mainland China and hold dialogue with Beijing on matters of mutual concern, such as the reunification of China. (more)

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN RELATIONS ACT IS 20 YEARS OLD (III)

TEXT.P: The TRA is not perfect. Despite the useful role the TRA has played in the past 20 years, there are still areas in the law that could be improved to make it more effective, Chang said.

For example, the provision that says the United States shall sell defense articles and services to Taiwan in such quantities as are "necessary" to enable Taiwan to maintain a "sufficient" self-defense capacity does not indicate whose standards of necessity or sufficiency should be applied--Taiwan's or Washington's, she said.

Besides, the US president and the US Congress should also jointly determine the nature and quantity of arms to be sold to Taiwan, according to the TRA. In fact, it is usually the executive branch of the US government that has the final say over arms sales. She suggested that the US president and Congress keep in close contact in making decisions on arms sales to Taiwan.

Meanwhile, Foreign Minister Jason Hu praised the US Congress for its role in both the enactment and the implementation of the TRA, which has functioned well in the past 20 years in promoting unofficial relations between the two countries. In this regard, he said in a recent interview with CNA, Taiwan should maintain good communication with the US Congress to ensure its interests remain effectively protected.

During the past couple of years, there have been suggestions that some provisions of the TRA should be revised in light of a changing cross-strait situation. Revisions may be helpful, but Taiwan should keep a close watch that they do not produce negative effects, he said.

Twenty years have passed since the TRA was enacted. The Republic of China has through the years become more democratic and more prosperous, he said. To further strengthen bilateral relations, Washington should change its policy by promoting government-to-government dialogue with Taipei and allowing visits by higher ranking officials to each other's country in the 21st century, Minister Hu urged.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SCORES US$1.09 BILLION TRADE SURPLUS IN MARCH

TEXT.P: Taiwan scored a US$1.09 billion trade surplus in March -- its third consecutive surplus and an increase of US$700 million compared with the same period last year, according to government statistics released Thursday.

A summary of imports and exports that cleared Taiwan customs in March showed that exports totaled US$10.41 billion, while imports totaled US$9.32 billion. Both levels were the highest seen since last April, though March exports were 1.6 percent lower than in March 1998, while imports were 8.5 percent lower. The figures were released by the Ministry of Finance (MOF).

For the first three months of this year, Taiwan's exports totaled US$27.8 billion and its imports, US$25.13 billion. Year-to-March exports are 3.5 percent higher than during the same 1998 period, while year-to-March imports are 6.8 percent lower.
Taiwan has amassed a year-to-March trade surplus of US$2.67 billion, compared with a deficit of US$100 million in the same 1998 period.

Hsu Kuo-chung, director of MOF's Department of Statistics, said three consecutive monthly trade surpluses will help improve Taiwan's international current account. Taiwan's quarterly trade conditions have improved from negative to positive growth, indicating that Taiwan's foreign trade will likely return to normal and become stable, Hsu added.

In addition, the director noted that the Wharton Econometric Forecasting Association has predicted 3.4-percent global trade growth for 1999, up from 3-percent growth last year. This will also benefit Taiwan's exports.

The construction of Taiwan's high-speed railway and the Y2K crisis will surely attract more investments in capital goods, which in turn is expected to accelerate the pace of the resurgence of the domestic economy, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: PHILIPPINE GOVERNMENT ENDORSES JOINT NAVAL EXERCISE PROPOSAL

TEXT.P: The Philippine government Thursday endorsed the proposed holding of joint naval exercises with Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) members in the South China Sea as part of confidence-building measures to ease tensions in the area.
Presidential spokesman Jerry Barican said joint naval exercises could be done with prior consultation with other ASEAN countries.
Barican added that the exercises could even be expanded to other common maritime borders.
Senate Foreign Relations Committee Chairman Blas Ople proposed that war games be held jointly by ASEAN members to show their resolve to resist any act of aggression in the area.

But while Malacanang supports the holding of conventional military exercises, Barican said Malacanang would continue negotiating for other confidence-building measures, such as the holding of maritime search and rescue exercises.

DOC.HEADLINE: MASSIVE NUGGET MAY HAVE BEEN SMUGGLED OUT OF AUSTRALIA

TEXT.P: A massive gold nugget found in western Australia and set for auction in New York by Sotheby's in June may have been smuggled out of Australia, the Department of Arts said.

The nugget, dubbed the King of the West, weighs about 25 kilograms and is worth about A$478,860 (US$305,000), according to an estimate by Sotheby's, which expects the gold nugget could fetch more than double that amount at the auction.

A department spokesman said an export license from the department is required for any nugget worth more than A$250,000 (US$160,000). "Without a permit, the nuggets would be a prohibited export," he added.
He said the nugget, one of the biggest found in Australia, is set for auction by Sotheby's on June 2 in New York.
Sotheby's has agreed to withdraw the monster from sale if it is proved to have been illegally smuggled out of Australia, the spokesman said.
Sotheby's expects the nugget can fetch more than A$1 million (US$637,000) at the auction.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC TO STEP UP EXPORT DRIVE TO SOUTH KOREAN MARKET

TEXT.P: Taiwan will step up an export drive aimed at the South Korean market in the second half of this year as that country's economy is recovering well, according to the semi-official China External Trade Development Council (CETRA) on Thursday.
In line with that policy, CETRA has decided to station a representative in Seoul in the near future to strengthen the collection of economic and trade information in South Korea.
Statistics show that South Korea is Taiwan's 13th-largest export destination and the island's third-largest import source.
Last year, Taiwan registered a deficit of US$4.18 billion in its trade with South Korea, and narrowing the trade imbalance has become an important economic task for Taiwan.
To enhance Taiwan's economic and trade relations with South Korea, CETRA will station a Korean-speaking representative in Seoul to gather related information.

CETRA Secretary-General Ricky Kao said that this representative will coordinate with the Seoul-based Economic Division of the Republic of China's Ministry of Economic Affairs to provide services to Taiwan exporters.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SOFTWARE FIRM BROKE MELISSA VIRUS IN 70 MINUTES
DOC.DATELINE: Singapore, April 8 (CNA) (By Sherman Wu and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: The Taipei-based Trend Micro Inc. was the world's first computer software firm to devise a program to counter a cunning virus called Melissa, just 20 minutes after the virus was discovered, a company executive said here on Thursday.

Trend Micro Southeast Asian Affairs Manager L.C. Lu, who flew into Singapore to attend an Internet technology fair, said that the company's research center in California's Silicon Valley spent just 70 minutes -- 20 minutes to devise the anti-Melissa software, and 50 minutes to upload the program -- to enable users worldwide to counter the Melissa virus after it appeared in E-mail systems on March 26.

Lu attributed Trend Micro's fast response to the widespread use of the Internet, saying it would have been impossible for Trend Micro to transmit its anti-Melissa program to users so quickly without it. "The use of the Internet has effectively broken the barriers of time and space," he noted.

Those users whose computers' have been infected by the Melissa virus should use anti-virus software to clean their entire systems, especially their personal documents, in order to counter the spread of the virus, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: REFORMS FUNDAMENTALLY AFFECT MAINLAND CHINA: US CHINA HAND

TEXT.P: Mainland China has been fundamentally affected by reforms that have taken place there over the past two decades, a US China hand said in Taipei on Thursday.

Harry Harding, dean of the Elliott School of International Affairs at George Washington University, made the remarks during a keynote speech at an international conference to review the reforms over the past two decades in the mainland.

Harding, who was among several people who briefed US President Bill Clinton before his visit to the mainland last year, noted that the reforms have seen the rise of nationalism in the mainland which he said has made the issue of China's unification more urgent.

The scholar noted that the reforms have led to the virtual extinction of ideology, as the mainland no longer stresses the liberation of Taiwan -- an ideology which has preoccupied Beijing's leaders in the past.

Noting that the rise of nationalism has provided unity and direction for the country, he also said that territory issues, unification, and the development of a comprehensive national power have become mainland China's prime objectives.

But Beijing's leaders have become more "impatient" with unification as they cannot understand why Taiwan will not accept terms of unification which are more generous than in the past as the socioeconomic gap between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait narrows.

On the effect on relations between the United States and mainland China, he said that increasingly, the issue between the mainland and the United States is not ideology but the relative power of two major nations, one of which is a status quo power and the other a rising force.
Harding said that the reforms over the past two decades have had a far-reaching effect on mainland China's foreign policy and its relations with other countries.

He said that as mainland China gradually becomes an emerging power, it becomes more resistant to pressure from other countries, a situation which also affects cross-strait relations and relations between mainland China and the United States.

Harding said that the mainland and the United States should also define the role each plays in Asia. He said crucial issues will be whether the United States will be willing to accept the mainland as the emerging power in the region, and whether the mainland will be willing to accept the role of the United States as holder of the balance of power in the region.

He also said that although the reforms have opened mainland China to an unprecedented degree, making it a major world trading partner with major investment from the United States, Japan, the European Union and Taiwan, the trade barriers it has erected against its trading partners have become a source of tension.

He noted that the large trade imbalance Beijing enjoys has become unacceptable for the United States, while in the case of Taiwan, the concern has been more that the large amount of investment from Taiwan has made the island more dependent on the mainland, which the mainland could use as leverage against Taiwan.

He also said that human rights have seen improvement in mainland China, but have also become a source of irritation with many other nations, noting that the improvements are not "complete, even or continuous," citing the practice of forced abortion and the situation in Tibet as examples.

He pointed out that while this has not affected mainland China's foreign policy, it has affected its foreign relations with other neighboring countries, and noted that the United States has put the issue high on its mainland agenda.

For Taiwan too, the issue is becoming increasingly important, he said, noting that Taiwan will ask how can it even consider unification until the issues of democratization and the honoring of human rights have moved further along.

He also said that Beijing has engaged in a more cooperative foreign policy but this has not lessened the tension with other nations, noting that although Beijing participates in many international institutions, compliance with international norms is still incomplete.

Looking ahead to the next century, Harding said that reforms in mainland China have been a mixed blessing for the United States and Taiwan alike, pointing out that they have not resolved some problems but have created several new ones which the rest of the world has had to prepare for.

He also attributed the contractions of the reform process to the fact that Beijing's leaders do not see reforms as good things, but as a necessary evil required to develop a "comprehensive national power."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SHARE PRICES UP 1.9 PERCENT

TEXT.P: Taiwan share prices closed 1.9 percent higher on Thursday as the market was boosted by Wall Street's record high of 10,085.31 points in Wednesday's session.
The benchmark Taiwan Stock Exchange weighted price index rose 137.52 points to 7,273.41, and the turnover reached NT$131.51 billion (US$3.97 billion).
Trading in technology shares accounted for 57 percent of Thursday's total turnover, and a total of 3.58 billion shares changed hands.
Advancers led decliners 322 to 99, with 73 stocks unchanged.
Among the eight major categories, electronic engineering shares posted the largest gain at 3.3 percent, while construction issues registered the only decline, dipping 0.8 percent.

Textile stocks, which were the second most actively traded issues, ended up 1.7 percent, followed by plastic and chemical shares, which climbed 1.3 percent; financial stocks, 0.9 percent; foodstuff issues, 0.5 percent; and paper-making issues, 0.4 percent. Cement shares remained unchanged.
Meanwhile, trading on the over-the-counter market opened higher and closed higher in Thursday's session. The index closed at 166.71 with a turnover of NT$5.61 billion.
TAIEX Capitalization Weighted Stock Index futures for April climbed 106 points to close at 7,380 with 4,669 contract transactions.

TAIEX Index Futures for May rose 111 points to 7,401 with 459 contract transactions; those for June moved up 116 points to 7,406 with 37 contract transactions; and those for September rose 165 points to 7,450 with 1 contract transaction. There were no contract transactions for December futures in Thursday's trade.

Reference levels for TAIEX Index Futures trading on Thursday were listed as 7,274 points for April; 7,290 points for May; 7,290 points for June; 7,285 points for September; and 7,289 points for December.

DOC.HEADLINE: CABINET APPROVES LOWERING OF DUTY ON IMPORTED SEMICONDUCTORS

TEXT.P: A plan to reduce tariffs on imported semiconductors filed jointly by the Ministry of Finance (MOF) and the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) was approved by the Cabinet on Thursday.
According to the plan, tariffs on 25 items relating to imported semiconductors will be lowered by 50 percent for one year, effective after the MOF receives written approval from the Cabinet.
The MOF and MOEA jointly filed the plan in the hope of being allowed to join the World Semiconductor Council (WSC) and the World Government Association (WGA) as soon as possible.

The WSC and the WGA invited the Republic of China to attend their meetings last year, and the WSC has cited an ROC abolition of import duty on semiconductors as an important factor for the ROC Semiconductor Industry Association's entry into the organization.

However, in order to join the WSC, the MOF decided to advance the plan's implementation and cut the rate to zero effective Jan.1, 1999, and to incorporate the revised plan into a draft amendment to the regulations on import tariffs.

DOC.HEADLINE: NORMALIZATION OF CROSS-STRAIT RELATIONS URGED

TEXT.P: Taiwan and mainland China should promote the normalization of their relations and work together for the long-term welfare of all Chinese people, President Lee Teng-hui said here Thursday.

Addressing the 14th plenary meeting of the National Unification Council (NUC), Lee said that the two sides of the Taiwan Strait should try to normalize their relations through constructive dialogue "with democracy and peace as the main pivots."

"We welcome a visit to Taiwan by Mr. Wang Daohan... to continue the constructive dialogue launched last year, and to facilitate a meeting between the top leaders of the two sides," Lee said. Wang, chairman of the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS), is mainland China's chief negotiator with Taiwan. His Taiwan counterpart is Koo Cheng-fu, chairman of the Strait Exchange Foundation (SEF). Koo visited the Chinese mainland last year.

"The two sides of the Taiwan Strait should resume the institutionalized cross-strait consultations as quickly as possible ... and gradually establish mechanisms for cross-strait peace and stability," Lee said, adding that the two sides should "expand and enhance the scope of cross-strait exchanges and cooperation to build mutual trust and seek mutual benefits."

To reach the goal of national unification, the two sides should narrow the gap between them, Lee said. "Only when mainland China quickly accomplishes its social diversification and political democratization, can the two sides gradually establish consensus regarding future developments on the basis of democracy and freedom."

"We call upon the Beijing authorities to open their minds, cease their internal suppression of different voices, protect human rights, and create room for everyone to fully express his or her free will," he said.

The NUC, established in 1990, functions as an advisory board and provides the President with research findings and ideas. The council has 61 members and researchers. The 13th plenary meeting of the council was held in July, 1998.

President Lee, who heads the NUC, said "Our unswerving objectives are peace, mutual benefit and joint prosperity for both sides of the Taiwan Strait." The government's mainland policy has not been changed, he added.

Lee also said that the development of cross-strait relations "should begin from the recognition of historical fact and the political reality of separate rule by two distinct but equal political entities." "While promoting cross-strait relations, we must not waver in our stance of giving top priority to national existence, as well as placing the people's safety and welfare foremost."

"If Beijing authorities reduce their hostilities toward us and concurrently diminish the uncertainties in mainland China's development, then there may be a greater shift in this government's policies," Lee said.
Taiwan is forced to continue the policy of "avoid haste, be patient; walk steadily to go far," because Beijing's hostilities towards Taiwan continue to deepen, he pointed out.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT LEE'S CLOSING REMARKS TO NUC'S 14TH PLENUM (I)

TEXT.P: The following is the full text of the speech delivered by President Lee Teng-hui at the closing ceremony of the 14th Plenum of the National Unification Council (NUC) on Thursday:
Vice-Chairmen of the Council; Members of the Council; Members of the Research Council:

After rigorous deliberations, the 14th Plenum of the National Unification Council will be closing shortly. I would like thank you again for attending the meeting today and for offering your valuable recommendations on matters concerning international affairs, mainland affairs and cross-strait relations, which will be forwarded to the relevant government agencies for their reference. I am certain that your recommendations will be helpful to the formulation of our policies and programs toward the mainland.

It is of timely significance that the plenary meeting of the NUC is being held now. Looking at the current trend of world, it continues to develop in the general directions of peace, cooperation and prosperity. Interminable regional conflicts notwithstanding, as the tides of globalization, information and democratization continue to spread throughout the world, the depth of mutual interdependence among countries and among regions deepens every day, while the expectations of countries for political democracy, economic prosperity and world peace grow more ardent. As for Asia Pacific, this region was ravaged severely by a financial storm during the last two years. The most difficult period may be over, but the turbulence has yet to subside. All the countries in this region now fully understand the urgency of economic and financial stability and re-acknowledge the importance of regional mechanisms for dialogue.

After the end of the Cold War, all the countries in the world have strengthened dialogue and cooperation to reduce tensions and maintain safety. However, to this day the security of Taiwan Strait and the South Seas, important air and sea passageways in the West Pacific, cannot yet be ensured. The major reasons are the refusal of Peking authorities to renounce the use of force against Taiwan, the rapid expansion in their military budget year after year, the acceleration of their deployment of missiles and other offensive weapons, and their unilateral suspension of institutionalized cross-strait consultations. These actions delay the establishment of normal relations between the two sides and present a threat to the security and stability of the Asia Pacific region.

In recent years, significant internal and external changes have occurred in Mainland China. The social and economic developments since its reform and opening up have gradually affected the political sphere. Its people not only have demanded economic liberalization, but also have begun to seek political democratization. Concurrent with developing the economy, however, the Chinese communists have suppressed democracy and human rights inside the mainland to preserve their one party dictatorship rule. On the other hand, in their external relations, they have pursued outward expansion and aspired for regional hegemony. All of the above make Mainland China an important variable in the security of the Asia Pacific region. Whether the Peking authorities can respond to their domestic demands for democracy and human rights and participate in international frameworks and mechanisms of peace and cooperation will significantly affect the well being of all Chinese people and peace of the world. (TO BE CONTINUED)

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT LEE'S CLOSING REMARKS TO NUC'S 14TH PLENUM (II)

TEXT.P: In contrast, successfully completing its "Three-in-One" elections last year, the Republic of China again has proven that democracy in the ROC has become mature and has taken root. These elections have fully manifested our democratic values, rational demands and peaceful process. Such rational and mature political environment has enabled the government and people to remain calm, think objectively, and effectuate policy measures in facing the new challenges of the new century, as well as in promoting new developments for a new era. In particular, by firmly rooting our foundation in democracy and human rights, we have received world affirmation and recognition for promoting pragmatic diplomacy and strengthening international cooperation. The ROC thereby has become a new force for world peace and development.

Concerning the development of cross-strait relations, the ROC has always acknowledged historical reality and given primary consideration to safeguarding the people*s welfare. Since 1987 when the ROC government lifted the ban on family visits to the mainland, our unswerving objectives are peace, mutual benefit and joint prosperity for both sides of the Taiwan Strait. My abolishing the Temporary Provisions Effective During the Period of Communist Rebellion in 1991, is a concrete demonstration of our sincerity to abandon the use of force in resolving cross-strait issues. In addition, we have pragmatically faced the reality of the existence of Peking authorities, and further have begun cross-strait exchanges based on the principles of parity and reciprocity. Further developments and implementation of these policies include the first Koo-Wang talks, many rounds of institutionalized consultations between the two sides, and my "six positions" regarding the establishment of normal bilateral relations, which I first announced four years ago today at your Plenary Meeting. These six positions are: to pursue unification of China based on the reality that the two sides are governed separately by two distinct political entities; to strengthen cross-strait exchanges based on Chinese culture; to enhance trade and economic relations to develop a mutually beneficial and complementary relationship; to ensure that both sides join international organizations on an equal footing and that the leaders of both sides meet in a natural setting; to adhere to the principle of resolving all disputes by peaceful means; and to jointly safeguard prosperity and promote democracy in Hong Kong and Macau.

Regrettably, the Peking authorities have never responded reasonably to our goodwill and sincerity. They even have gone so far as to unilaterally distort reality and create tensions in the Taiwan Strait. Nevertheless, under the patient and persistent efforts of the ROC, Mr. Koo Chen-Fu led a delegation to the mainland last October. This visit is a constructive step forward for peace in the Taiwan Strait and security in the Asia Pacific region and lets the Peking authorities have some rudimentary understanding of the essence and accomplishment of our democracy.

After today, our first task in the promotion of cross-strait relations is to increase our understanding of Mainland China. We must not only look at a particular event, published statistics, or the superficial impressions of tourists to the mainland. Rather, we must fully grasp the total situation there. Without question, the ability of Mainland China to attain wealth and peace deserves applause. However, we should not be overly optimistic and create expectations based on wishful thinking. Nor, should we be excessively pessimistic and make mistakes in judgement. What we must do is to present a clear comparison based on objective facts. Presently, there exists a high degree of uncertainty in Mainland China. If such uncertainties cannot be eliminated quickly, then the basic reforms cannot be completed. For example, some uncertainties are created from systemic ambiguities and others are produced by the delays in democratization. Still, additional uncertainties result from the rule of man rather than the rule of law. These uncertainties leave open a big question mark on the future development of Mainland China. (TO BE CONTINUED) ZCZC CEP033 04-08-99 PRESIDENT LEE'S CLOSING REMARKS TO NUC'S 14TH PLENUM (III)

In recent years, all the countries around the world take into consideration the above uncertainties in formulating their policies toward Mainland China. The ROC is separated from the mainland by only a body of water and there are frequent exchanges between the two sides. Therefore, it is even more impossible for the ROC to ignore these profoundly ingrained changes. If Peking authorities reduce their hostilities toward us and concurrently diminish the uncertainties in Mainland China*s development, then there may be a greater shift in this government*s policies. Nonetheless, while our good intentions are currently on the rise, Peking*s hostilities continue to deepen. We have been unable to achieve our win-win scenario and are forced to continue our policy of "avoid haste, be patient; walk steadily to go far."
Therefore, we must insist on the following:
1. The development of cross strait relations should begin from recognition of the historical fact and political reality of separate rule by two distinct but equal political entities.
2. While promoting cross-strait relations, we must not waver in our stance of giving top priority to national existence, as well as placing the people*s safety and welfare foremost.

As we look ahead to the 21st century, creating peace based on democracy and stimulating progress through cooperation have already become unstoppable global trends. Looking to the future, the two sides of the strait should work together to create a new horizon. That is, with democracy and peace as the main pivots, they should promote the normalization of bilateral relations through constructive dialogue, and jointly seek the long-term welfare of all Chinese people on both sides of the strait. Toward this, I would like to raise the following points:

1. We welcome a visit to Taiwan by Mr. Wang Daohan, Chairman of the Association for Relations Across the Strait, to continue the constructive dialogue launched last year, and to facilitate a meeting between the top leaders of the two sides.

2. The two sides of the Strait should resume the institutionalized cross-strait consultations as quickly as possible to address the myriad functional problems that have arisen from cross-strait exchanges and gradually establish mechanisms for cross-strait peace and stability.
3. Expand and enhance the scope of cross-strait exchanges and cooperation to build mutual trust and seek mutual benefits.

4. Narrow the development gap between the two sides to bring about unification. Only when Mainland China quickly accomplishes its social diversification and political democratization, can the two sides gradually establish consensus regarding future developments on the basis of democracy and freedom. We call upon the Peking authorities to open their minds, cease their internal suppression of different voices, protect human rights, and create room for everyone to fully express his or her free will.

Ladies and gentlemen: in this global community where interaction among members grow closer every day, the peace and stability of the Taiwan Strait and the development of cross-strait relations have already become major regional issues and widely receive the attention of the world. We must acknowledge this significant trend. Therefore, how to create future prospects for the two sides of the strait using ingenious intelligence, flexible policies, and constructive actions is something that all the people should jointly work for and contemplate. I hope the Peking authorities will also uphold good intentions and pragmatically face the tide of global development to work together with us to create a vast development horizon for all Chinese on both sides of the strait in the 21st century.
Thank you all.

DOC.HEADLINE: FAMILY OF STRICKEN BEIJING EX-OFFICIAL ALLOWED TO ENTER TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) notified its mainland Chinese counterpart on Thursday that relatives of an injured visiting former Beijing official can enter Taiwan to visit him in hospital, where he remains in critical condition.

In a letter to the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS), the SEF said that six friends and family members of Wang Jifu, former mainland Chinese vice culture minister, have been given permission to travel to Taiwan on humanitarian grounds.
According to ARATS, Wang's wife, son, daughter, a doctor, his secretary and an official with mainland China's Ministry of Culture will come to Taiwan.

Wang, 71, remains in an intensive care unit at the Chung Shan General Hospital in Taichung, Central Taiwan, for treatment of brain hemorrhage and multiple skull fractures sustained as a result of a fall down a flight of stairs at the Provincial Taiwan Museum of Fine Arts during a visit there on Tuesday.
Wang, who is currently chairman of the China Foundation for Minority Cultures and Arts, was on a tour of Taiwan at the invitation of Democratic Progressive Party Legislator Hsu Jung-shu.
The SEF and ARATS are semi-official organizations set up by Taiwan and mainland China, respectively, to handle cross-strait contacts in the absence of official ties,

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA CRITICIZED OVER PLAN TO HOUSE ALBANIAN REFUGEES IN BASES

TEXT.P: Australia's plan to house most of the 4,000 ethnic Albanian refugees in regional military bases has come under strong criticism from critics who demanded that the Howard administration treat them more humanely because of the trauma they have suffered as targets of an ehtnic cleansing campaign by Serbian troops in Kosovo.
Opposition leader Kim Beazley of the Labor Party said he did not agree with the government plan to send the Albanian refugees to remote areas of Australia.
"I don't want them to go into an experience of Australia that is ungenerous, that is distant, that is only going to add to the traumas they' ve already experienced," he told reporters on Wednesday.
Greg Sheridan, foreign editor of the Australian, on Thursday said in an article that the 4000 refugees are new "mates" who deserve a fair go while staying in Australia.

"Having decided to accept 4000 Kosovo Albanian refugees, it is crucial now that the Howard government treat them decently and avoid the mentality of punishment and control that has characterized so much of our recent refugee policy," he said.
The Australian governments have been criticized for mistreating the Cambodian boat people, who languished for years in the isolated Port Hedland detention facility in Western Australia.

Even before the government decision on how to airlift these Albanian refugees, Prime Minister John Howard said on Wednesday that his government would introduce a special legislation on April 19 when Parliament resumes session in which it will prevent all the Albanian refugees from applying for social security benefits or permanent residence.
Howard wanted to prevent the recurrence of the asylum given to more than 55,000 Chinese students and refugees during the Tienanmen Square massacre in Beijing in 1989.
Most of the Chinese refugees were first granted an extended stay of four years and then given permanent residence later.

Michelle Grattan, an editor of the Sydney Morning Herald, said the circumstances are not exactly parallel, but the lesson is. In 1993, the Chinese were given permanent residence. There were no other choice.
"The same will have to be -- and should be -- done eventually for the Kosovo people if they cannot go home," she said.
But Howard said the government planned to allow them a three-month temporary stay in Australia and the stay can be extended if the Albanian refugees could not go home.

Immigration Minister Philip Ruddock said ethnic Albanian refugees will be allowed to stay in private homes if they have sponsors. But the government is preparing to house most of them in military facilities where they would be supplied with food, medical support and other care in addition to shelters.

DOC.HEADLINE: CONTROL YUAN HEAD TO VISIT US

TEXT.P: Control Yuan President Fredrick Chien is slated to depart for the United States on Tuesday for an 11-day visit at the invitation of the American Enterprise Institute and the Heritage Foundation.

Chien is scheduled to give a keynote speech on the 20th anniversary of the enactment of the Taiwan Relations Act (TRA) at the Hilton Hotel in Washington D C on Wednesday, and will also meet with leaders of local think tanks, according to sources, who denied that Chien will meet with US government officials.
The TRA has served as the US policy framework for its dealings with Taiwan over the past 20 years since Taipei and Washington suspended diplomatic ties in 1979.

DOC.HEADLINE: PHILIPPINE AUTHORITIES HUNT FOR DRUG LORDS

TEXT.P: The Philippines National Bureau of Investigation (NBI) has expressed optimism that three drug lords, two of whom are Republic of China nationals, will be captured.
NBI Regional Director Franklin Javier said his office has sufficient evidence to pin down three suspects identified as Jimmy Huang, Jorge Gan, and Ernesto Pinera.
Both Huang and Gan are suspected to be members of the 14K triad gang.

Agents of the NBI, Coast Guard and the Economic Intelligence and Investigation Bureau seized six drums of chloroform and 11 drums of hydrochloric acid, believed to have been smuggled from mainland China, together with laboratory equipment, during a raid on an amphetamine factory earlier this month.
The raid was an offshoot of another raid which resulted in the seizure of 229 kg of amphetamine, and the arrest of another two men.
Another suspect is still at large and is now the subject of an intense manhunt.
Police authorities have been alarmed over intelligence reports that ROC nationals posing as fishermen have been entering the Philippines illegally.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC TO CONTINUE PURSUING PRAGMATIC DIPLOMACY: FOREIGN MINISTER

TEXT.P: Republic of China Foreign Minister Jason Hu said on Thursday that Taipei will continue to pursue pragmatic diplomacy, and expressed the hope that Beijing will not deem this an attempt at "national division."

Hu made the remarks in a report titled "The current external relations of the country -- cross-century pragmatic diplomacy" which he delivered at a general meeting of the National Unification Council.
He pointed out that Taipei cannot accept Beijing's concept of the ROC's pragmatic diplomacy along with the development of cross-Taiwan Strait relations as being a "zero sum" relationship.
Instead, the foreign minister said, Taipei's pragmatic diplomacy and its mainland policy "absolutely can be complementary to each other."
Hu stated that Taiwan and mainland China are equal political entities under separate rule, and that both sides are entitled to international space for their survival until reunification.
This being the case, he said, Taipei will not alter its policy of pursuing pragmatic diplomacy, despite the all-out containment efforts and oppression from Beijing.

Hu criticized Beijing for trying to lure away the ROC's diplomatic allies, describing it as an obvious attempt to force Taiwan to start political talks with Beijing, and to reunify with the mainland under Beijing's "one country, two systems" formula.

The foreign minister pointed out that pursuing pragmatic diplomacy is the consensus of the people of Taiwan, and he said he hoped that Beijing will understand that its relentless oppression of this pragmatic diplomacy is the source of Taiwan's antipathy toward Beijing.

He cited as proof of this a public opinion survey conducted by the Mainland Affairs Council in October last year, in which about 70 percent of those polled said they were against stopping pragmatic diplomacy in exchange for goodwill from Beijing.

In the report, Hu acknowledged that mainland China has been making efforts to improve its economic and political power, to play an active role in international affairs, and to increase its military buildup.

He said that these developments have not only affected Taiwan's security and the stability of the Asia-Pacific region, but have also prompted the United States to formulate new security guidelines with Japan and to consider introducing the Theater Missile Defense system to the region.

Hu said that while pursuing its pragmatic diplomacy, the ROC has no intention of challenging or creating rivalry with Beijing, and will not interfere in foreign countries' development of relations with Beijing, so long as Taiwan's interests are not sacrificed.
Facing the new century, the foreign minister said the country's pragmatic diplomacy will continue to put forward and strengthen its existing traditional political and diplomatic engagements.

He went on to say that positive efforts will also be given to the following six areas: 1. economic, trade and investment diplomacy; 2. Internet diplomacy; 3. congressional and party diplomacy; 4. academic and democracy diplomacy; 5. humanitarian diplomacy; and 6. cultural and sporting diplomacy.

DOC.HEADLINE: END TO CROSS-STRAIT HOSTILITY TAIWAN'S MAIN CONCERN: VICE PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: Republic of China Vice President Lien Chan reaffirmed on Thursday that the termination of cross-strait hostility and the promotion of security in the Taiwan Strait are the primary concerns of his government.

Lien said that any development that runs counter to these concepts is bound to cause international concern, and noted that a stable and peaceful development between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait is crucial to regional stability and peace.
Lien made the remarks at the National Unification Council (NUC) conference which took place on Thursday.
He noted that a majority of the people of Taiwan support the ideas espoused by President Lee Teng-hui at the closing ceremony of the last NUC conference in July last year.
The president said at that time that although there will be a united China in the future, the China of the present is divided and under separate rule.

He also said that the democratization of the mainland and cross-strait development will dictate the process of peaceful reunification. In addition, he said that the two sides of the Taiwan Strait should expand exchanges, and concentrate on cooperation rather than confrontation.

Meanwhile, speaking on the same occasion as Lien, Premier Vincent Siew said that the government has made appropriate arrangements for a visit to Taiwan this autumn by Wang Daohan, the mainland's top negotiator with Taiwan.
Siew said that Taiwan welcomes Wang's visit, and hopes that it will correct the lack of communication across the Taiwan Strait over the years and open up a mechanism for systematic dialogue.
But the premier also expressed the hope that Beijing will not set preconditions for such dialogue.

Siew said that the dialogue channel between the Straits Exchange Foundation and its mainland counterpart, the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait, has been operating for years, and is the only channel authorized by their respective governments for cross-strait contact.
He stressed that this dialogue channel should be kept viable and not neglected or cast aside.

He expressed the hope that both before and after Wang's visit, the two intermediary bodies will continue to consult on issues concerning the rights of the people on both sides of the Taiwan Strait, especially the establishment of cross-strait exchanges, and the protection of the personal security and investments of Taiwan businessmen in the mainland.

He said that more consultation between the two sides will be better than less consultation, and that it is better to solve tangible issues pragmatically rather than becoming mired in thorny political issues.

He also said that Taiwan would like to increase agricultural and technological exchanges, and to join forces with the mainland to combat crime so as to promote mutual trust and create an environment conducive to reciprocal exchanges.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC CABINET APPROVES MEMORANDUM ON COOPERATION WITH MACEDONIA

TEXT.P: A memorandum on economic development cooperation between the Republic of China and Macedonia was approved on Thursday during a regular Cabinet meeting.

The memorandum was signed by ROC Foreign Minister Jason Hu and his Macedonian counterpart Aleksandar Dimitrov when Hu visited Macedonia last month following the forging of diplomatic ties between the two countries on Jan. 26.
The Main points of the memorandum include:
-- An ROC-sponsored financial aid project to help the development of Macedonia's civilian enterprises;
-- Prompt action to sign a free trade agreement, investment protection agreement, and other related agreements.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLAND CHINESE OFFICIAL EXECUTED FOR MURDERING ROC NATIONAL

TEXT.P: A former mainland Chinese public security official was executed in January in Jilin Province, northeastern mainland China, for murdering a businessman from Taiwan and others, according to a mainland Chinese newspaper report on Wednesday.
The Anhui Legal Daily reported that Chuang Weihua, a former public security official from the province's Helung City, was executed in Helung along with an accomplice, identified as Bu Huxiong.
The daily said Chuang met Bu and another accomplice, Fan Dezhung, in jail while serving a seven-year sentence in 1981. Fan is still at large, the newspaper said.
After his release, Chuang managed to find a job with the public security office in Helung City in 1993, and worked as a deputy director of the office, doubling as the manager of a subsidiary office.
He then hired his former fellow inmates Bu and Fan as assistants, the daily said.

On March 23, 1994, Chuang and his two accomplices lured Taiwan businessman Wu Ching-yu and his four mainland Chinese business associates to Helung by falsely offering to sell them a batch of Japan-made motorcycles at an attractive price.
Chuang and his two associates drugged the five men, bludgeoned three of them to death, and dumped their bodies in an underground vault.
The next day, they escorted the other two to a bank to withdraw 90,000 yuan from the account owned by Wu's company. They were both later killed.
Wu's sister in Taiwan wrote a letter to Taipei's Straits Exchange Foundation in June of 1994, asking for help to locate her brother, whereupon the Beijing authorities began to investigate the case.
However, the case remained open until April, 1996, by which time Chuang had been promoted to deputy captain of Helung City police squad.
Chuang eventually confessed to the five murders and disclosed the involvement of the two other accomplices in December of 1996.

DOC.HEADLINE: MEETING BETWEEN ROC, MAINLAND LEADERS URGED

TEXT.P: A meeting between Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui and his Beijing counterpart Jiang Zemin was urged on Thursday by Hsu Li-nung, a vice chairman of the National Unification Council (NUC).

Saying that such a meeting would usher in a new era in bilateral ties, Hsu, who is also the leader of the tiny opposition New Party, predicted at a NUC conference that Lee and Jiang would win the Nobel Peace Prize for such a historic encounter.

Praising the formation of a single European market and the introduction of a single European currency, the pro-Chinese unification Hsu said it is regrettable that the Chinese on each side of the Taiwan Strait are still steeped in their feud of the past, and still engaged in their cut-throat struggle against each other, both diplomatically and militarily.
As a result, Taiwan currently has to earmark NT$360 billion (US$10.9 billion) for its national defense budget, Hsu lamented.

He urged Taipei and Beijing to stick to the "one China" principle, give up their arms race, and divert the huge resources used for military build-up to social welfare, economic, educational, and cultural development.

Meanwhile, the pro-independence opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) reiterated its opposition to the goal of reunification with mainland China as set out in the Guidelines for National Unification.

In a written statement, the DPP also echoed a call by President Lee Teng-hui that both Beijing and those concerned about Taiwan's future should come to realize that there are two separate sovereignties on the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies Friday are as follows:
The Central Daily News:
President Lee Teng-hui said democracy and peace should be axes of cross-Taiwan Strait relations.
The China Times:
Taiwan opens doors for 150 additional agricultural products from mainland China.
The United Daily News:

The Liberty Times:

The Commons Daily:
President Lee broached four new proposals in hopes of achieving breakthroughs in cross-strait relations.
The China Post:

The China News:
Beijing-Washington WTO differences remain unresolved as mainland Chinese Premier Zhu Rongji arrives in Washington.

DOC.HEADLINE: SHIP WITH FPG'S MERCURY-LACED WASTE ENTERS KAOHSIUNG HARBOR

TEXT.P: A ship carrying back mercury-laced waste belonging to Formosa Plastics Group (FPG) and formerly stored in Cambodia entered Kaohsiung Harbor in southern Taiwan on Friday.
The ship, Eagle Prosperity, carried the solidified waste in 357 containers and arrived in waters off Kaohsiung Harbor Wednesday to await approval to enter the harbor.

After FPG presented a plan to transfer the waste to another country and posted a bond of NT$50 million (US$1.5 million) to the Kaohsiung Port Authority, the authorities agreed to allow the ship to dock and the containers to be temporarily stored in a warehouse.
But the mercury-laced waste can be stored there for only 60 days, which means FPG must send the waste to another country within that period.

As reports indicated that environmental groups planned to protest against the mercury-tainted waste's entering the harbor, the agents responsible for the unloading of the containers said they would speed up efforts to unload the cargo. Police were also on hand to maintain order. But no protesters showed up, and the operation went smoothly without incident.
The mercury-tainted waste was first shipped from a FPG plant in Kaohsiung late last year to the southern coastal town of Sihanoukville, Cambodia, causing panic and chaos among local residents.
FPG apologized to Cambodia for causing unrest and promised to ship the waste out of the country.

DOC.HEADLINE: DOMESTIC AIR, LAND TRAFFIC UNAFFECTED BY Y2K BUG

TEXT.P: Transportation and Communications Minister Ling Fong-cheng flew safely from the southern Taiwan city of Kaohsiung to Taipei Friday morning to prove the Y2K crisis is not affecting the nation's air transportation system.

Lin, accompanied by eight members of the Legislative Yuan's Transportation and Communications Committee, took a UNI Airlines flight departing at 6:55 a.m. to Kaohsiung and arrived safely there at 7:45. He returned to Taipei before noon aboard a Far East Air Transport Corp. airliner.

Lin took the flight to fulfill a promise he made Thursday to accompany members of the legislature's Transportation and Communications Committee to prove the nation's transportation and communications installations can weather the millennium bug.

Lin said the information center under the Ministry of Transportation and Communications has completed tests on air traffic control systems and he is confident that the center will surely pass the tests.
Meanwhile, the Taipei Rapid Transit System operated smoothly Friday, thanks to test and preparations conducted beforehand by the traffic authority of the Taipei City government.
Friday is the 99th day of 1999. Some experts have forecast that the first effects of the computer glitch known as Y2K would been seen on Friday.

DOC.HEADLINE: MINISTER URGES CROSS-STRAIT JUDICIAL, CRIME-FIGHTING TIE-UP

TEXT.P: Justice Minister Yeh Chin-feng on Friday called for expanded and more intensive cooperation in crime-fighting judicial regimes across the Taiwan Strait.

Only when the mainland and Taiwan actually cooperate in crime-fighting judicial procedures can both sides of the strait mutually benefit, Yeh said during a seminar, sponsored by the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF), on cross-strait jurisprudence exchanges.

Yeh, who once served in the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC), the top government agency in charge of Taiwan's mainland China policies, said she knows the differences between the legal systems and practices of Taiwan and the mainland, and the plight of people involved in legal or judicial controversies across the Taiwan Strait.

She admitted that there are some channels of communication across the strait, but because the channels are either indirect or erratic, they have not been conducive to joint crime-fighting efforts by the two sides.
Officials from the Judicial Yuan and the Ministry of Justice, and representative of public notaries and arbitration and legal groups took part in the seminar.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN MINISTER REJECTS ZHU'S ANALOGY

TEXT.P: Republic of China Foreign Affairs Minister Jason Hu on Friday rebutted mainland Chinese Premier Zhu Rongji's analogy between the cross-Taiwan Strait relations and the American Civil War.

In his first joint press conference with US President Bill Clinton at the White House since arriving in Washington, D.C., Thursday for an official visit, Zhu said Beijing has repeatedly stated that mainland China strives for a peaceful reunification of the motherland, but that it has never renounced the use of force against Taiwan in this regard.
Zhu also noted the historical example of US President Abraham Lincoln, who went to war in the 1860s to keep southern US states from seceding.
