Responding to Zhu's remarks, President Clinton said, "the facts of the relationship between Taiwan and China over the last 50 years are somewhat different than the facts leading up to the American Civil War, as I am sure that you would all agree."
Foreign Minister Hu said Zhu's drawing an analogy between cross-strait relations and the American Civil War is illogical and "embarrassingly awkward."

Hu said the American Civil War was launched basically over the rights, freedom and democracy of black people in America. If Beijing triggers a war in the Taiwan Strait, it would hurt the freedom and democracy hard sought after by the Chinese in both Taiwan and mainland China, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN GUARDS AGAINST INVASION OF HONG KONG BIRD FLU

TEXT.P: The Council of Agriculture (COA) on Friday called for heightened vigilance against a new strain of the fatal "bird flu" that has struck two children in Hong Kong, saying there must be across-the-board alertness among Taiwan poultry farms to prevent infections.
COA officials urged chicken and other poultry farms to make sure their birds do not come into contact with migratory birds that may turn out to be the source of the "bird flu" infections.
In addition to keeping the birds at the farms isolated from migratory birds, the farms should also prevent their feed from being exposed to unknown migratory birds, COA officials said.
Meanwhile, COA informed the seven wetland habitats for wild and migratory birds around the island to watch closely for the arrival of any affected or ill birds.
Hong Kong health authorities have launched a probe into the new strain of influenza A virus (H9N2), which struck two little girls, aged 1 and 4, on Wednesday. Both girls have fully recovered.
It is still unknown how they contracted the virus, which is found only in birds, chickens and other poultry.
The H9N2 virus also reportedly affected five people in southern mainland China last year, Hong Kong sources said.
An outbreak of the fatal H5N2 "bird flu" in late 1977 killed six people in Hong Kong and led to the slaughter of 1.5 million chickens to prevent the flu from spreading.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, April 9, or the 23rd day of the second month of the Year of the Rabbit according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1241: Batu Khan, grandson of Genghis Khan, leads his Mongol horsemen to victory over the Teutonic Knights at Liegniz, Silesia.
1626: Sir Francis Bacon, English philosopher, essayist, courtier, jurist, and statesman, dies at the age of 65. His writings include "The Advancement of Learning," and the "Novum Organum," in which he proposed a theory of scientific knowledge based on observation and experiment that came to be known as the inductive method.
1667: The world's first art exhibition opens in Paris, and lasts for 15 days.
1682: La Salle, the title of Robert Cavelier, French explorer in North America who claimed Louisiana for France in 1682, reaches the Gulf of Mexico after traveling down the Mississippi River.
1865: Confederation Gen. Robert E. Lee surrenders to Union Gen. Ulysses S. Grant at the Appomattox Court House in Virginia, ending the US Civil War.
1926: Tuan Chi-jui resigns as provisional chief executive of the Republic of China.
1928: Islam is no longer recognized as the state religion in Turkey.
1940: German troops invade Norway and Denmark.
1942: American and Filipino forces on Bataan surrender to the Japanese after a four-month siege.
1957: Egypt announces the opening of the Suez Canal after the withdrawal of invading troops from Great Britain and France from Port Said.
1961: The Republic of Vietnam holds its first presidential elections with Ngo Dinh Diem elected as president.
1963: British Prime Minister Winston Churchill is proclaimed an honorary US citizen at the White House.
1965: The Republic of China and the United States conclude in Taipei an accord to establish a Sino-American fund for economic and social development in Taiwan.
1970: Singer-songwriter Paul McCartney issues a High Court writ winding up the business partnership of the squabbling Beatles.
1988: Communist China's National Peoples Congress names Li Peng as premier.
1990: The Democratic Forum of Hungary sweeps to power in elections, after 40 years of communism.
1991: Georgia declares its independence from the Soviet Union.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "When there is justice and order in the government of the country a man may be bold and lofty in the expression of his opinions as well as in his actions. When, however, there is no justice and order in the government of the country, a man may be bold and lofty in his actions, but should be reserved in the expression of his opinion."

DOC.HEADLINE: CLINTON-ZHU JOINT STATEMENT ON BEIJING'S WTO BID

TEXT.P: United States President Bill Clinton and mainland Chinese Premier Zhu Rongji issued a joint statement on Beijing's admission to the World Trade Organization (WTO) on Thursday following a summit meeting at the White House.

In the statement, both Clinton and Zhu committed to instruct their trade ministers to resume bilateral negotiations in order to satisfactorily resolve the important remaining issues as soon as possible in support of the common goal of admission of the People's Republic of China to the WTO on strong commercial terms in 1999.
The full text of the statement is as follows:

On the occasion of the official visit of the Premier of the Government of the People's Republic of China Premier Zhu Rongji to the United States, President of the United States William Jefferson Clinton and Premier Zhu Rongji jointly affirm that China's admission to the World Trade Organization (WTO) is in the interest of the United States, the People's Republic of China and the global trading system.

To that end, they welcome the significant progress made by the United States and the People's Republic of China toward a strong agreement based on a balance of rights and obligations. Noting that agreement has not been reached on some important issues, they commit to work to resolve these remaining issues through further bilateral negotiations in order to conclude a strong agreement as the basis for the accession of the People's Republic of China to the WTO.

President Clinton and Premier Zhu recognize the complexity of WTO accession negotiations. In this regard, they note that agreement has been reached on market access for agricultural and industrial goods, as well as for a wide range of services sectors, as set out in Attachment 1, but that certain matters remain to be resolved in banking, including consumer auto finance, as well as securities and audio visual services.

They further welcome the conclusion of the Sino-US Agricultural Cooperation Agreement, especially the resolution of bilateral issues concerning imports by the People's Republic of China of US citrus, meat products, and Pacific Northwest wheat, as set out in Attachment 2.

President Clinton and Premier Zhu note agreement has been reached on a variety of important rules to be applicable in the WTO, including ones concerning trading rights, technology transfer and offsets, state enterprises, and subsidies, as set out in Attachment 3. However, they recognize that certain differences remain to be resolved on a mechanism to ensure implementation, the duration of provisions governing dumping and product safeguards, and rules governing textiles trade.

President Clinton and Premier Zhu welcome this significant progress and instruct their trade ministers to resume bilateral negotiations in order to satisfactorily resolve the important remaining issues as soon as possible in support of the common goal of admission of the People's Republic of China to the WTO on strong commercial terms in 1999.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S WTO BID SHOULD BE UNAFFECTED BY MAINLAND CHINA: PREMIER

TEXT.P: Premier Vincent Siew said on Friday that Taiwan's entry into the World Trade Organization (WTO) should be treated separately from, and be unaffected by mainland China's entry bid.

Siew made the remarks as he fielded questions in the Legislative Yuan one day after US President Bill Clinton and mainland Chinese Premier Zhu Rongji issued a joint statement on the mainland's bid for membership in the world trade regulatory body.
Meanwhile, Minister of Economic Affairs Wang Chih-kang said on the same day that the chances of Taiwan being allowed to join the WTO are better this year than last, although some "variables" remain.
Wang noted that mainland China has made several concessions in its talks with the United States on its WTO membership, which he said should help its entry bid.

Wang said he believes that mainland China will open more of its market, quicken the pace of its economic reforms, and widen its economic liberalization, all of which he said will benefit the mainland, Asia and Taiwan businessmen with operations in the mainland.
Against this background, Wang said, he will be happy to see the mainland gain entry to the WTO.

On the possible impact on Taiwan of the mainland's WTO entry, Wang noted that there are big differences between Taiwan and the mainland in terms of size and population, pointing out that Taiwan has a population of 22 million, while the mainland represents a market of 1 billion people. Although Taiwan cannot compare with the mainland in terms of market size, it can certainly focus on providing a higher quality market, he added.

Meanwhile, Vice Economic Affairs Minister Lin Yi-fu noted that Taiwan's imports from the United States were 25 percent higher than the mainland's imports from the same source last year, and added that this should be the main concern of the United States and its businessmen.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA WATCHING US-MAINLAND CHINA TRADE TALKS

TEXT.P: Australia is keeping a close watch on trade talks between US President Bill Clinton and mainland Chinese Premier Zhu Rongji in Washington, D.C., on Friday because the meeting could have an impact on Australian access to the mainland Chinese market.

Australian analysts said the Australian exporters could benefit from any concessions negotiated by the United States during talks this week, although Australia has a number of specific interests not likely to be addressed in the negotiations.

The Australian Financial Review has reported over recent months that a number of World Trade Organization (WTO) members have expressed concerns that mainland China's WTO entry is increasingly being seen as a bilateral deal between the United States and mainland China.

This view was summed up by European Commission Vice President Sir Leon Brittan, who warned last month that it should not be forgotten that WTO accession negotiations are a multilateral process and that no bilateral agreement "can be imposed on other members of the WTO as a basis for a final accession deal."

The daily reported there is a considerable overlap between Australian and US interests in the mainland Chinese market, though there are also a number of sectors where Australian priorities diverge from those of the United States.
The daily cited examples covering those sectors in which the United States is not a major player in the mainland Chinese market, including wool, sugar and malting barley.
Other priorities include ensuring equal treatment of agricultural products used for similar purposes such as canola.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA CRACKS DOWN ON SMUGGLING OF GINSENG

TEXT.P: The Australian government is cracking down on the smuggling of ginseng into the country as the appetite for the herb is spurring the creation of a multimillion dollar industry, customs officials said.

Australian Customs officers at Sydney Airport recently seized 207 kilograms of American ginseng worth almost US$100,000 after it arrived as cargo from the United States via Hong Kong, making the haul the largest ever in this country.
Customs officers said about 70 illegal American ginseng imports are seized each month at Sydney Airport, and airports around the country report similar seizure rates.
International Post last year intercepted 67 illegal ginseng imports to Australia, up from 55 in 1997. This reflects growing demand for the herb, according to The Sydney Morning Herald.
Ginseng is regarded as a herb capable of enhancing stamina and endurance.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA VOWS TO OPPOSE JAPAN'S PUSH FOR WHALING

TEXT.P: Australia has vowed to strongly oppose a call by Japan to reopen commercial operations for whaling in the Southern Ocean sanctuary, saying the Japanese demand will only accelerate the extinction of the endangered whale species.
The remarks were made by Environment Minister Robert Hill, who said he was not surprised at Japan's latest move to reintroduce commercial whaling, adding Australia would oppose the move vigorously.

Hill said the Australian government will push for a ban on whaling in the South Pacific at a meeting scheduled in Grenada on May 24. Australia will move toward a final position of a global sanctuary for all whales.

Commercial whaling was closed five years ago but whaling countries such as Japan and Norway remain adamant to pushing for the reopening of commercial operations. Only Taiwan ceased commercial whaling a few years ago in cooperation with Australia and for the good of the endangered species.

DOC.HEADLINE: LUNG CANCER CANADA'S NUMBER 1 CANCER KILLER

TEXT.P: The Canadian Cancer Society said Thursday that the general incidence of cancer and cancer deaths are down, although breast, prostate and lung cancer are still exacting a high toll.

Nearly 130,000 new cases of cancer are expected in Canada this year, and more than 63,000 people will die of cancer. By far, the biggest killer is lung cancer and, not surprisingly, most of the cases are caused by smoking, according to the society.
It noted that almost a third of all cancer deaths in men and a quarter in women are due to lung cancer alone.

"The lung cancer death toll on Canadians is devastating," said Dr. Barbara Whylie of the Canadian Cancer Society. "It is all the more tragic as most lung cancer deaths could have been prevented, as the vast majority are caused by smoking."
In 1999 about 12,000 Canadian men will be diagnosed with lung cancer and 10,600 will die of the disease. For women, approximately 8,500 will be diagnosed with lung cancer and 6,800 will die.
The society predicted a dramatic increase in cancer rates in the next decade as the Canadian population, now around 30 million, ages and grows in size.

DOC.HEADLINE: CROSS-STRAIT DISPUTE NOTHING LIKE AMERICAN CIVIL WAR: PREMIER

TEXT.P: Republic of China Premier Vincent Siew said on Friday that cross-strait relations cannot be likened in any way to the confrontation in the American Civil War, since Taiwan and mainland China are governed by two separate sovereign powers.

Siew was replying to a question from Legislator Lee Wen-chung of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party, who took offense at remarks made in the United States by mainland Chinese Premier Zhu Rongji about Taiwan, describing them as "provocative."

At a joint press conference with US President Bill Clinton, Zhu cited the example of Abraham Lincoln, who went to war in the 1860s to keep the southern states from seceding from the union, as a defense for Beijing's refusal to renounce the use of force against Taiwan.

Siew said that every country has its own unique history, and pointed out that the American Civil War was triggered by separatists in a united country, a situation which has never occurred in the Taiwan Strait region.

There has been no united China since 1949 when the ROC government was forced to relocate to Taiwan from the mainland after its own civil war. Since then, two distinct political entities have ruled the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, and neither has jurisdiction over the other, he stressed.
Accordingly, the method used by Lincoln to settle the separatist problem in the 1860s can in no way be adapted to settle the cross-strait dispute, Siew said.

Asked whether Taipei will invite Zhu to visit the island in the wake of his "provocative" remarks, Siew said he believes the two sides should build a systematized channel for dialogue before talking about high-level visits or exchanges.

Siew noted that the ROC has been striving for a "win-win" resolution to the Taipei-Beijing confrontation, and would welcome leadership visits at the proper time. He also pointed out that President Lee Teng-hui himself has expressed his willingness to visit the mainland under the proper circumstances.

DOC.HEADLINE: CROSS-STRAIT ISSUES SHOULD BE RESOLVED PEACEFULLY: CLINTON

TEXT.P: Mainland Chinese Premier Zhu Rongji on Thursday likened the current cross-strait situation to the attempted secession of the Confederate States of American from the United States in the 1860s, saying that mainland China should learn from former US President Abraham Lincoln, who used force to quell the Confederacy's push for independence.

US President Bill Clinton, who appeared with Zhu at a joint press conference in Washington, quickly replied that the situation across the Taiwan Strait is different from the one that led to the American Civil War, adding that the United States' position is that the cross-strait issue should be resolved peacefully.
Following are Zhu's responses to questions on Taiwan, put to him by a Hong Kong reporter:

Q: Seven hours before you landed in Andrews Air Force Base yesterday, President Clinton made a foreign policy speech in which he mentioned the sending of carriers to the waters in the Taiwan Straits in March 1996. And he said that that move had helped maintain the security in the Taiwan Straits. So, in your view, how do you see the effect of the military capabilities of the United States on the situation across the Taiwan Straits? And do you think there should be a timetable for the reunification of the mainland and Taiwan? And do you wish to pay a visit to Taiwan?

Zhu: The policy of China on the reunification of the mainland and Taiwan -- of China -- is a very clear-cut one, and President Jiang Zemin has already expounded on China's policy in this regard, so I don't see the need for me to reiterate here.

Since the return of Hong Kong to the motherland, the policy of "one country, two systems" -- Hong Kong people administering Hong Kong; Hong Kong enjoying a high degree of autonomy -- have been fully implemented, which is a fact there for the people in the entire world to see.

And our policy for the reunification of China with Taiwan is more generous than our policy towards Hong Kong; and that is to say Taiwan will be allowed to maintain its army. And we are also prepared to let the head of Taiwan to come to the Central Government to serve as the deputy head. But as for whether he or she is able to be the head, then I'm not sure. But I'm afraid he would not get enough votes; nobody would vote for him.

On the question of the reunification, the Chinese government has repeatedly stated that we strive for a peaceful reunification of the motherland, but we have never undertaken to renounce the use of force in this regard, because if we were to make such a pledge, make such an understanding, then I'm afraid Taiwan would be in a perpetual state of separation from the motherland.

Just now, in the Oval Office of President Clinton, I saw the portrait of President Abraham Lincoln. Abraham Lincoln, in order to maintain the unity of the United States and oppose the independence of the Southern part, he had resorted to the use of force and fought a war for that, for maintaining the unity of the United States. So I think President Abraham Lincoln is a model.

As for whether I am going to visit Taiwan, since none of them have issued an invitation to me, so how can I go there? And in what capacity should I go there? I hope you will also help me to think of this.
At this point President Clinton intervened: "I think I have to just say one thing, if I might, since I got zapped by Abraham Lincoln.
"First of all, the United States has a 'one China' policy. And I have reaffirmed that at every opportunity. I do so again today.
"Secondly, we believe that this matter should be resolved peacefully.

"The facts of the relationship between Taiwan and China over the last 50 years are somewhat different than the facts leading up to the American Civil War, as I am sure that you would all agree. It does seem to me that China and Taiwan, apart from the blood ties of being Chinese, even the native Taiwanese, that they have a lot -- you have a lot to offer each other, including economic power, but beyond that as well.
"And so I hope that we will see a resolution of this. And I think if the premier is as humorous and clever in Taiwan as he is here, I think it'd be a good thing for him to go."
To that, Zhu added: "Would I be beaten black and blue there?"

DOC.HEADLINE: GERMAN-CHINESE SOCIETY WILL MOVE TO BERLIN IN SEPTEMBER

TEXT.P: The German-Chinese Society, founded in Bonn in 1957 for the promotion of understanding between the people of Germany and the people of the Republic of China on Taiwan, will move its office to Berlin in September.

Over the past 42 years, the German-Chinese Society has dedicated much effort to promoting the image of the Republic of China and its people to German society. When the society was founded by Ernst Majonica, a German parliamentarian between 1950 and 1972, Taiwan was rarely known by Germans. Majonica and some other members of the German Parliament at that time believed that the German people should at least know about Taiwan even though the Republic of China was not recognized by the German government.

The society has been a forerunner to establish German political contacts for Taiwan. Among its more than 200 members, there are quite a few parliamentarians belonging to different political parties, business executives and journalists who are keen to know about developments in Taiwan. These people have built a solid base of friendship for Taiwan in Germany's political circle.

Under the initiation of the society, more than 60 German parliamentarians formed the Bonn-Taipei Parliamentarian Group (Parlamentarischen Freundeskreise Bonn-Taipei) in 1989. A counterpart group was formed by members of the Legislative Yuan of the Republic of China. The parliamentarian groups have served as an important channel for direct contacts.

With a new seat in Berlin, the society will continue its functions in Bonn, while seeking a new orientation in the new capital. In the meantime, the society's monthly publication "Freies Asien" will keep the many members staying in the Rhine area informed about developments in Taiwan and the society's programs.

DOC.HEADLINE: SINGAPORE TO BECOME A LEADING INFORMATION ECONOMY

TEXT.P: Singapore will be the world's second-most dominant information economy by the year 2000, surpassing Sweden and Finland, which are currently ahead.
Singapore will be right behind the United States, which will continue to be the world's most powerful information economy then -- as it is now.

This prediction comes from a new study called the Information Society Index (ISI), conducted by researcher International Data Corp. (IDC) and World Times Inc., which specializes in analyzing critical global issues through The World Paper publication.

"The US will continue to remain the world's dominant information economy, but smaller nations such as Singapore are progressing more quickly than traditional countries such as the United Kingdom, France and Japan," the study said.
"The ISI study shows how effective policy translates into progress and how information technology suppliers can find new opportunities for growth."
The study tracked data from 55 countries that collectively account for 97 percent of the world's gross domestic product (GDP) and 99 percent of IT expenditures.
The research includes forecasts through the year 2002 for 23 variables spanning four infrastructure categories -- information, the Internet, computer and society.

In 1998, the top five information economies were, in descending order, the United States, Sweden, Finland, Singapore and Norway. By 2002, the top five will be the United States, Singapore, Sweden, Australia and Japan; Finland will drop to eighth place.
Meanwhile, Hong Kong will move up from 12th in 1998 to 10th in 2002; Taiwan from 21st to 16th; and mainland China from 53rd to 50th place.

Among the countries expected to slide in their positions by 2002, South Korea is expected to fall from 20th to 21st, Malaysia from 34th to 38th, Thailand from 45th to 48th, the Philippines from 46th to 49th, India from 52nd to 54th and Indonesia from 54th to 55th place.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR UP

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar rose NT$0.023 against the greenback in Taipei Friday, closing at 33.095.
The local currency opened at 33.117 and was traded between 33.091 and 33.121.
The interbank US dollar trading reached US$430.5 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO REMAIN OPEN FOR MAINLAND CHINA FARM GOODS: MOEA

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Minister of Economic Affairs Wang Chih-kang revealed on Friday that the island will open even further to mainland Chinese agricultural goods, following an announcement a day earlier that imports are to be expanded.

Wang said that the opening is part of government efforts to obtain membership of the World Trade Organization. He explained that Taipei has granted import approval to more than 5,000 items, or 90 percent of mainland China's industrial products.
In January, Taiwan first opened to the import of 87 items of mainland Chinese farm products, the first of four market-opening stages, Wang said.
Thursday's move represented the second stage of the plan, Wang said, adding that the third and fourth stages will be implemented in the near future.

The Board of Foreign Trade (BOFT) under the Ministry of Economic Affairs announced on Thursday that an additional 150 mainland items, covering corn, wheat, barley, glutinous rice, and fishery products such as shrimps and clams, have been approved for import.
The announcement added that this raises the number of mainland agricultural items allowed to be shipped to Taiwan to 621, or 30 percent of the agricultural items produced there.
Meanwhile, the Council of Agriculture expressed optimism over the opening, stressing that all the mainland farm goods on the import list can help the island's agricultural development.

DOC.HEADLINE: EXCHANGE OF VISITS BY CROSS-STRAIT LEADERS CAN BE DISCUSSED: MAC

TEXT.P: Cross-Taiwan Strait visits by the leaders of the two sides can be discussed during the visit to Taiwan by mainland China's top negotiator with Taiwan Wang Daohan, a senior official of the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) said on Friday.

Hsu Ke-sheng, vice chairman of the Cabinet-level MAC, noted that Wang, chairman of the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS), might discuss the matter with his local counterpart Koo Chen-fu, chairman of the Taipei-based Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF).

Hsu pointed out that in President Lee Teng-hui's speech delivered on Thursday at the 14th Plenum of the National Unification Council, he said he welcomes Wang's visit, and that he hopes the constructive dialogue conducted last year can be continued, which in turn might lead to an exchange of visits by cross-strait leaders.
Meanwhile, ARATS Vice Chairman Tang Shubei denied a Japanese newspaper report that he said Beijing will object to any overseas visits by the ROC president after his retirement.
Tang is also deputy director of both the Central Office for Taiwan Affairs under the Chinese Communist Party, and the Taiwan Affairs Office under the State Council.
Hsu, however, refused to accept Tang's explanation, and said that if the report was indeed unfounded, then Tang should seek clarification from the newspaper as to why it ran the story.

He stressed that Taipei's mainland policy is based on a pragmatic method of promoting benign cross-strait relations, and expressed his hope that the Beijing authorities will exert more effort to the improvement of cross-strait relations, and less to "impractical" issues.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC MILITARY, DA-YEH UNIVERSITY TO COOPERATE ON STUDY PROGRAMS

TEXT.P: Officers in the Republic of China Armed Forces will have the opportunity from next week to pursue academic study in addition to carrying out their military duties, following the signing of an agreement between the military and a local university.

Yang Te-chih, commander-in-chief of the General Headquarters of Combined Services Force, and Liu Shuei-shen, president of Da-Yeh University, jointly signed an agreement to co-sponsor "life study" classes for certain armed forces personnel.
They also jointly presided over a ceremony to signal the official start of the classes, which will begin in earnest from Monday.

The credit-based "life study" classes will allow military officers and non-commissioned officers to study the most up-to-date information technology with the aim of promoting the combat capability and educational background of the nation's defenders.

In the initial stage of the program, Da-Yeh University will allow military officers to obtain credits toward masters degrees in industrial relations, information management, and international business administration.

In addition to providing related specialist courses, Da-Yeh University will also hold special forums for busy high-ranking officers, and organize various activities for high-ranking officers' group to achieve a goal of "all-out study in the military."

DOC.HEADLINE: MERIT OF TRA PROVEN OVER 20 YEARS, SAYS AIT CHAIRMAN

TEXT.P: In accordance with the spirit of the Taiwan Relations Act (TRA), any hostile action against Taiwan will be considered a threat to the peace and security of East Asia, and a matter of grave concern to the United States, top US liaison officer with Taiwan Richard Bush said on Friday.

The TRA requires the US executive branch to maintain Taiwan's capability to resist hostile action, so that if there were a threat to Taiwan, the US president and Congress should consult on how to deal with it, said Bush, chairman of the board and managing director of the American Institute in Taiwan (AIT).

In an interview with the Free China Journal on the significance of the TRA legislation and the course of US-ROC relations over the past 20 years, Bush said the TRA, a domestic US law, has played a key role in US-ROC relations over the past 20 years in four principal ways.
First, the TRA provides a legal basis for the unofficial relationship between Taiwan and the United States.

Second, the TRA provides on the American side an institutional framework for conducting that relationship, specifically, the AIT, with its headquarters in Washington, D.C., and offices in Taipei and Kaohsiung, Bush said.

Third, the TRA sets forth some statements of policy in a lot of different areas, not the least of which is human rights. The most important is probably in the security area, where the TRA reaffirms the US expectation that the Taiwan Strait issue will be resolved in a peaceful manner.

Fourth, the TRA reflects a political commitment on the part of the Congress, the American public and the US executive branch concerning our friendship and close ties with the people on Taiwan. That political commitment is an important reinforcement for the law itself, Bush added.

Meanwhile, he said, the TRA has been very successful over the last 20 years as one element of a larger policy that helped create an environment in East Asia in which the United States was able to maintain substantive relations with Taiwan.
Three other positive things occurred, he went on:
-- Twenty years of unprecedented peace and prosperity have been enjoyed;
-- The people on Taiwan chose to take risks to open up the political system and move toward the full democracy that they now enjoy; and
-- People on Taiwan have been willing to take risks to open up ties with mainland China and facilitate the economic and human interdependence that has occurred over the last 12 years.
On relations among Taiwan, mainland China and the United States, Bush reiterated that the United States insists that the Taiwan Strait issue be resolved peacefully.

The United States also believes that dialogue between the two sides is the best way to reduce tension, improve the atmosphere, identify areas of cooperation and, hopefully, move toward resolution of this issue, he noted.

Furthermore, he said, the United States believes that whatever the results of cross-strait dialogue, they should be the work of the two sides themselves. "The United States is not going to insert itself as a mediator. We think that it is better for the two sides themselves to do it," he added.
"We're going to be even-handed in that respect. We are not going to take one side's view over the other's, nor pressure one side over the other, Bush said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCKS, FUTURES DECLINE SLIGHTLY

TEXT.P: Taiwan stock prices closed 0.1 percent lower on Friday as investors gathered profits from the previous day's strong gains, but the bourse still rallied for the ninth consecutive week.
The benchmark Taiwan Stock Exchange Weighted Price Index fell 7.71 points to 7,265.70 by the close of trade, following a 1.9 percent rise in the previous session.
A total of 3.86 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$142.06 billion (US$4.29 billion), up from the previous session's NT$131.51 billion.
Losers outnumbered gainers 261 to 162, with 71 issues unchanged.
Among the eight major stock categories, the paper and pulp sector posted the largest gains, rising 0.7 percent, while financial shares dropped the most at 0.8 percent.
Cement issues climbed 0.5 percent, followed by electronic shares, which rose 0.4 percent. The foodstuff sector remained static.
Plastic and chemical shares slipped 0.3 percent, textile stocks went down 0.5 percent, and construction issues posted a 0.1 percent decline.
The over-the-counter market posted a slight drop of 1.40 points to close at 165.31 points, for a turnover of NT$5.12 billion.
Meanwhile, the TAIEX Capitalization Weighted Stock Index Futures (TAIEX Index Futures) for April declined 50 points to close at 7,330 points, with 4,024 contract transactions.
TAIEX Index Futures for May fell 41 points to close at 7,360, with 544 contract transactions, while those for June dropped 30 points to close at 7,382, with 27 contract transactions.
September futures slipped 31 points to close at 7,360, and December futures went down 48 points to close at 7,400 points. Contract transactions for the two months totaled 3 and 11, respectively.

Reference levels provided by the Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange for TAIEX Index Futures trading on Friday were 7,380 points for April, 7,410 points for May, 7,412 points for June, 7,391 points for September, and 7,448 points for December.

DOC.HEADLINE: LESS THAN 10 PERCENT OF TERMINALLY ILL PATIENTS GET HOSPICE CARE

TEXT.P: Although more and more people are coming to accept the concept of hospice care for the terminally ill, it is estimated that less than 10 percent of such patients get the care they need because of the limited number of hospital beds.
The situation was revealed on Friday at a hospice care seminar sponsored by the Sun Yun-suan Academic Foundation and the Catholic Sanipax Socio-Medical Service & Education Foundation.
Speaking at the seminar, Department of Health Director-General Chan Chi-shean expressed the opinion that better hospice care and more beds should be the future goals of the medical care industry.

Lo Chi-chin, a researcher at Academia Sinica, the highest research institute in Taiwan, noted that research here and overseas has shown that medical expenses to care for the terminally ill rise dramatically in the one or two months prior to a patient's death, which he said highlights the cost-efficiency of hospice care.

Hospice care is not about "giving up" on patients, but about providing active medical care that focuses on the easing of the pain and suffering of patients in the twilight of their lives, the participants heard.

Professor Tai Tung-yuan of National Taiwan University noted that although cancer tops the list of the 10 most common causes of death in Taiwan, the demands for hospice care are so great that less than 10 percent of sufferers receive such care.
The DOH estimates that there are 16 hospitals islandwide with a total of just 216 hospice beds.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC HOPING FOR A MULTI-WIN SITUATION FOR TAIPEI, BEIJING AND WASHINGTON
DOC.DATELINE: San Francisco, April 9 (CNA) (By Neil Lu and Eva Chen)

TEXT.P: Any discussion between the United States and mainland China which involves Taiwan should be discussed by Washington and Taipei in advance, a senior Republic of China official said on Friday.

Lin Chong-pin, vice chairman of the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC), made the remarks upon his arrival in San Francisco to attend a seminar which opens on Saturday at the University of California at Berkeley.

He was addressing matters concerning mainland Chinese Premier Zhu Rongji's current nine-day state visit to the United States, a visit which is being closely monitored by Taipei to see whether it will have any impact on the interests of Taiwan.
Lin pointed out that Taipei basically hopes that a "multi-win" situation will be achieved, allowing Taiwan to maintain good relations with both mainland China and the United States.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies Saturday are as follows:
The Central Daily News:
US President Bill Clinton rejected mainland Chinese Premier Zhu Rongji's misleading analogy.
The China Times:
Clinton rebutted Zhu's 'Civil War' analogy.
The United Daily News:
The United States, mainland China failed to clinch WTO membership deal.
The Liberty Times:
Clinton rebutted Zhu's wrong analogy.
The Commons Daily:
Foreign Minister Jason Hu dismissed Zhu's likening Taiwan to American South.
The China Post:
Clinton, Zhu spar over civil war.
The China News:
Zhu: force an option.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Saturday, April 10, or the 24th day of the second month of the Year of the Rabbit according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1810: Pirate chieftainess "Dragon Lady" Cheng Yi-sao surrenders herself and the 1,800 junks under her command to the Ching court.
1829: William Booth, the British religious leader who founded the Salvation Army with his wife Catherine Mumford Booth and who served as its first general, is born.
1847: Hungarian-born American journalist Joseph Pulitzer is born. The newspaper publisher owned newspapers in St. Louis and New York City and established and endowed the Pulitzer Prizes for achievements in journalism and literature.
1858: Chinese governor-general Ye Ming-chen of Canton and a prisoner of Britain, dies in Calcutta during an Anglo-French expedition against Peking in 1858.
1898: France obtains concessions from the Ching court.
1921: Dr. Sun Yat-sen is elected president of the Republic of China.
1932: German general and politician Paul von Hindenburg is re-elected president of the Weimar Republic with 19 million votes to Adolf Hitler's 13 million. He appoints Hitler chancellor in 1933.
1945: US forces liberate a Nazi concentration camp at Buchenwald, Germany.
1946: Japan holds general elections with women joining in for the first time.
1953: The Executive Yuan approves the resignation of Taiwan Governor Wu Kuo-chen and names Yu Hung-chun as the new governor of Taiwan.
1958: Dr. Hu Shih assumes office as president of Academia Sinica.
1960: The US Senate passes the Civil Rights Bill.
1963: Thresher, a US atomic submarine, sinks in the northern Atlantic, killing all 290 aboard.
1971: Ethnic Chinese hold a mass rally in Washington, D.C., to show their support for the protection of a disputed territory known to the Chinese as the Tiaoyutai Islands.
1972: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs of the Republic of China announces the establishment of diplomatic relations with the Kingdom of Tonga.
1972: The United States and the Soviet Union sign a treaty banning biological warfare.
1979: US President Jimmy Carter signs legislation permitting continued commercial and cultural relations between the US government and the Republic of China following their break in diplomatic ties.
1980: Mainland China and the Soviet Union end a friendship pact they signed in 1950.
1984: One million people attend a rally in Rio de Janeiro demanding free presidential elections after 20 years of dictatorship.
1985: Enver Hoxha, the 76-year-old man who safeguarded Stalinist-Leninist ideals in Albania since 1945, is on the brink of death after suffering a stroke.
1986: The United States conducts a nuclear test in the Nevada desert.
1995: The top United Nations weapons inspector reports that Iraq seems to be developing biological weapons.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A man who possess moral worth will always have something to say worth listening to; but a man who has something to say is not necessarily a man of moral worth."

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC DONATES UNIFORMS AND SHOES TO PANAMA POLICE
DOC.DATELINE: Panama City, April 9 (CNA) (By Edward Chen & Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: The Republic of China donated US$3 million-worth of uniforms and shoes to Panama's police force on Friday.

In a brief ceremony at the police headquarters on Friday morning, ROC Ambassador Lan Chih-min presented the first half of the donation -- 26,000 uniforms and 13,000 pairs of shoes -- to Panama police head Jose Sosa.
Lan said at the ceremony that he hoped the gift from Taiwan will further cement the friendship between the two countries.
The second half of the donation will be presented later this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRO-TAIWAN CHINESE DEMONSTRATE IN FRONT OF WHITE HOUSE
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, April 9 (CNA) (By Herman Pan & Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: Hundreds of pro-Taiwan Chinese protesters demonstrated in front of the White House on Thursday when Beijing's Premier Zhu Rongji arrived for a meeting with President Bill Clinton.

Wearing caps bearing the national flag of the Republic of China, they gathered in Lafayette Square in front of the White House, and unfurled Chinese and English banners reading "Opposing one country, two systems," "Denouncing militarily threat against Taiwan," "Long live the ROC."
The demonstrators shouted anti-Beijing slogans and sang songs to show their solidarity with the Republic of China.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC REITERATES SUPPORT FOR NEW PARAGUAY LEADERSHIP
DOC.DATELINE: Asuncion, April 9 (CNA) (By Ramon Huang and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Republic of China Ambassador to Paraguay Liu Tin-tzu has reiterated the ROC's comprehensive support for the new Asuncion government led by President Luis Angel Gonzalez Macchi.

Liu declared the support during a recent meeting with Paraguay's Foreign Minister, in which he also introduced cooperation programs between the two nations and offered Taiwan's experience and know-how to help Paraguay develop its farm products and expand exports.

Liu said loans that the ROC government has promised to provide or has offered Paraguay as part of its assistance with the economic development of the Latin American country will not be withdrawn because of the leadership change in Paraguay. He stressed the ROC is Paraguay's ally and partner in the pursuit of national development.

Gonzalez, a key figure in Paraguay's ruling Colorado Party, took power in late March after his predecessor Raul Cubas resigned in the wake of the assassination of his vice president which triggered six days of bitter rioting.
Gonzalez was originally scheduled to visit Taiwan in February at the invitation of the ROC government. The visit, however, was delayed because of the political unrest.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOLD PROSPECTOR'S GLITTERING DREAM BECOMING A NIGHTMARE

TEXT.P: The dream of an Australian gold prospector to become an instant millionaire is rapidly turning into a nightmare, with the government seeking to confiscate a 25 kg gold nugget he allegedly smuggled out of Australia.

The nugget, one of the world's largest, is worth about A$477,000 (US$303,800) by weight value, but it might fetch more than AT$1 million (US$637,000) at an auction scheduled to take place in New York on June 2.

Australia's Department of Arts is investigating how the nugget reached the United States without a permit from the Australian government. It has confirmed that the unnamed prospector did not secure a legal export permit to sell the nugget.

A spokeswoman of the department told the Sydney Morning Herald on Friday that under the federal law on movable cultural heritage, the nugget will be forfeited if is proved to have been exported illegally.
The auction house, Sotheby's, has agreed to cancel the auction if the nugget is proved to have been brought to the United States illegally.
The nugget is believed to have been discovered near Kalgoorlie in Western Australia.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA DEMANDS RETURN OF WORKERS DETAINED IN YUGOSLAVIA

TEXT.P: The Australian government has demanded that Yugoslavia return two detained aid workers of CARE Australia, the country's biggest aid and charity organization.

The demand was made by Foreign Minister Alexander Downer after Australia on Friday announced that the first batch of about 300 ethnic Albanian refugees from the Yugoslavian province of Kosovo will be airlifted to a military barracks near Sydney late next week.
Downer said the release of Steve Pratt and Peter Wallace is more important than the release of three US soldiers captured by Serb forces because they were "not participants in the political affairs."
Prime Minister John Howard said his government would do all it could to ensure the release of the two CARE workers.
The two workers went missing on March 31 while trying to cross the Yugoslavian border into Croatia.

CARE Australia workers are currently in the refugee camp of Stentovec, a tent city a few kilometers from the Kosovo-Macedonia border, taking care of between 8,000 and 10,000 ethnic Albanians who escaped the ethnic cleansing campaign being waged by Serb troops.

DOC.HEADLINE: NJIT RATED `MOST-WIRED' PUBLIC UNIVERSITY IN US

TEXT.P: For the second consecutive year, Yahoo! Internet Life magazine has ranked New Jersey Institute of Technology (NJIT) the "most wired" public university in the United States in its annual ranking of America's most wired colleges.
The magazine also ranked NJIT the second most wired technological university in the United States, second to the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.
NJIT is a public research university enrolling nearly 8,200 students in 76 degree programs.

US News and World Report's 1,000 Annual Guide to America's Best Colleges ranked NJIT among the nation's top universities, and Money magazine's Best College Buys 1998 rated NJIT as the sixth-best value among US science and technology schools and among the top 100 overall.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SHOULD HAVE TMD PROTECTION: US ANALYST

TEXT.P: Although the United States does not promote Taiwan independence, Washington should provide Taiwan with theater missile defense (TMD) protection against the growing missile threat from mainland China, according to Peter W. Rodman, director of national security programs at the Nixon Center.

Rodman noted in the latest issue of "National Review," a conservative monthly magazine, that mainland China is already expanding its offensive missile arsenal -- reportedly tripling its missile deployed against Taiwan.

The senior editor of "National Review" said that mainland China's growing offensive missile capability is a major change in the region's balance of power, necessitating an American response. If the technology exists to defend against these missiles and the United States flinches from providing it to allies and friends on the front line, "it will be a severe blow to the confidence of those who have relied on us for 50 years. Our alliance relations might not survive it," he said.
"And if we were to flinch because of Chinese pressure, the geopolitical implications would be even more profound," he added.

He said Taiwan is a particularly sensitive case, "warranting prudence in how we go about our long-standing policy of helping the island protect itself against the use of force by Beijing." Currently, Taiwan is allowed to purchase an upgraded Patriot missile system, but no more.

This constraint is artificial. A range of options is available, from sea-based systems (which could remain in US hands but be deployed near Taiwan in a crisis) to outright transfer of an advanced system, Rodman claimed.

The analyst stressed that "we are not in the business of promoting Taiwan's independence. But under the Taiwan Relations Act, we have reserved the right to provide `arms of a defensive character.' And what could be more defensive than missile defenses?"

Meanwhile, he continued, Beijing's diplomatic effort is reminiscent of the Soviet bluster against NATO's Euro-missile deployment in 1983; it should be resisted just as firmly. Whether concerning Taiwan or some other US friend, Beijing seems to be saying: "How dare you take steps to defend yourselves against the weapons with which we now choose to intimidate you"
"This is not a position that China should seriously expect the United States to accept," Rodman concluded.

DOC.HEADLINE: FREEDOM, DEMOCRACY KEY TO CEMENTING TIES WITH US: ROC ENVOY
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, April 9 (CNA) (By Jay Chen and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The Republic of China should continue promoting freedom, democracy, human rights, rule of law and equitable distribution of wealth if it wants to cement its ties with the United States, the top ROC envoy stationed here said on Friday.

Stephen Chen, ROC representative to the United States, made the remarks in an interview with CNA in connection with the 20th anniversary of the Taiwan Relations Act (TRA), the US law governing exchanges with Taiwan in the absence of formal diplomatic ties.

Chen pointed out that substantive ROC-US relations are now in good shape and stable. In the long run, he said, the ROC should avoid provoking tension in the Taiwan Strait in order not to add to America's headaches and problems in the Asian region.

"As long as the ROC does not take any action that may induce regional tension, there will not be any problems in ROC-US relations," Chen said, adding that if Taiwan does take certain "provocative actions," it would be a bad omen for Taipei-Washington ties.
Chen went on to say that the 1996 Taiwan Strait crisis tested US determination to maintain peace in the strait. "The crisis highlighted what actions the United States would take when necessary."

Mainland China conducted a series of live-fire war games and missile tests in the Taiwan Strait "on Taiwan's doorstep" in the run-up to the island's first-ever direct presidential election in March 1996, prompting the United States to send two aircraft carrier battle groups to nearby waters to demonstrate its determination to safeguard peace and stability in the region.

Chen said hot debate in the United States following the 1996 crisis led more or less to a conclusion that as long as Taiwan does not deliberately take any provocative action, its security deserves serious US concern.

The de facto ROC ambassador to the United States said the Clinton administration has repeatedly reminded mainland China that cross-strait issues should be resolved strictly by peaceful means while also urging Taiwan not to "provoke" Beijing.
"Americans have unequivocally expressed their stance on the Taiwan Strait issue," Chen noted.

He agreed with some reports that the United States feels an urgent need to make its stance "crystal clear" to both sides of the Taiwan Strait as Taiwan is stepping up preparations for its next presidential election scheduled for March 2000.

"I think this is why US President Bill Clinton, in a major policy speech delivered on April 7, again called on both sides of the Taiwan Strait not to misunderstand the basic US stance on cross-strait issues," Chen said.

As a diplomat, Chen said he should not make public comments on Taiwan's domestic political developments. Nevertheless, he said he firmly believes that freedom, democracy, human rights, rule of law and economic well-being are key elements to shore up substantive ROC-US relations.
"I'm convinced that maintaining domestic political stability and continuing promoting the above-mentioned values are the right direction for our future national development," Chen stressed.

The veteran career diplomat pointed out that most Americans remain unfamiliar with Taiwan issues. "I hope ROC nationals can be more active in introducing Taiwan to American people when they visit the United States," he said, adding that when Americans feel as familiar with Taiwan as they do with Britain or Japan, ROC-US relations will be far more solid and "worry-free."

Chen further said he expects that a sub-Cabinet-level ROC-US economic meeting will continue to be held this year. The sub-Cabinet-level dialogue was held for the first time in 1995 in accordance with a 1994 US review of its policy toward Taiwan.

According to an understanding reached at that time, a decision was to be made after the third such meeting as to whether it would be continued. The two sides had already held three sub-Cabinet-level meetings as of 1998.

DOC.HEADLINE: TOO MANY AMENDMENTS SPOIL CONSTITUTION: SCHOLAR

TEXT.P: Too many amendments to the ROC constitution will spoil it, warned a scholar in a seminar on Saturday.

Cheng Chen-ming, a professor of journalism at Chinese Culture University, said at a seminar on constitutional revision that the constitution should be supplemented by precedents and practices that require time to set up.
If gaps remain, they do not necessarily need to be bridged by amendments, said Cheng, adding that legal interpretations might work instead.

By amending the constitution too frequently, the government denies it the chance to take root, he said, even if amendments affect only a small portion of the document. Moreover, frequent amendments will result in controversy, especially if no consensus is reached on amendments before they are approved, he said.
The Republic of China has amended its constitution four times since 1991, and the ruling Kuomintang is pushing for yet another revision to be made this year.

Teng Chung-chien, a professor of diplomacy at National Chengchi University, urged all political parties to stop tinkering with the constitution. Instead, they should charter a long-term path for the constitution and solicit public support, Teng said.
Meanwhile, Legislator Lin Cho-shui, a member of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party, made a pitch for the party's advocacy of plebiscites at the seminar.
Lin said the addition of plebiscites is essential to ensure constitutional amendments made by the National Assembly conform with public opinion.
He claimed there exists a proposal to change the National Assembly into a gathering of political party representatives. This makes the addition of plebiscites all the more necessary, he said.
Lin's view met with opposition from Ho Cheng-sheng, deputy secretary-general of the New Party.
Arguing that plebiscites are a political instrument for the DPP to claim Taiwan independence, Ho said it will lead to suspicion and controversy.
Instead, Ho said, the New Party calls for the resumption of referendum and recall -- authorized under the constitution but currently frozen.
Referendum and recall function in much the same way as plebiscites, while they do not pose the constitutional problems that plebiscites do, Ho said.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP LEGISLATORS LAUNCH HUNGER STRIKE TO PROMOTE REFERENDUM LAW

TEXT.P: Over 100 activists, including dozens of lawmakers, participated Saturday in a hunger strike dubbed "410 Fast" at the front doors of the Legislative Yuan to demonstrate a consolidated and determined will to push for the legislation of a public referendum law.
The activity was led by Legislator Trong Tsai from the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP). Trong said that the strike will continue indefinitely until there is progress on the legislation.

As the strike began, Tsai read a statement in which he urged the legislature to write a bill authorizing the holding of referendums into law as soon possible. Taiwan's political development requires such a law, he said.
The hunger strike is intended to call public attention to the issue, the statement said.

Some of the participants elected to go on a limited hunger strike, lasting from one to seven days, while 22 others -- among them Tsai and fellow DPP legislators Sheng Fu-hsiung and Chen Chau-nan -- have vowed to strike indefinitely.

More than 100 people including Taiwan Independence Party Chairman Hsu Shih-kai, former Taipei County Magistrate You Ching and Green Party representative Kuo Cheng-yien are participating in limited hunger strikes.
Saturday's activity also included a speech by Professor Lee Hung-hsi of National Taiwan University and performances by choral groups.
A draft referendum bill has already passed its first reading in the legislature, but it has been stalled because no agreement has been reached on the bill by the ruling and opposition parties.

Wang Jin-pyng, president of the Legislative Yuan, said Saturday that he is not optimistic that the referendum bill will be put on the legislature's agenda for Tuesday. He said he is also doubtful that the bill will be passed into law.
Wang has expressed concern over the "410 Fast" event, calling for attention to be paid to the strikers' health and for discussions aimed at finding a solution to the referendum issue.

According to the Republic of China constitution, citizens of the country have the rights of election, recall, initiative and referendum. In practice, however, only the right of election has been frequently exercised, while legislation governing the rights of initiative and referendum has yet to be passed.

Some lawmakers have opposed legislation authorizing the holding of referendums, saying it could become a tool of pro-independence forces. Others have objected to the legislation on different grounds, saying Taiwan voters already have the means to make influential political decisions.

DOC.HEADLINE: ONE IN THREE IN TAIWAN HAVE TURNED TO WRONG DOCTOR

TEXT.P: When it comes to choosing a specialist, the opinion of a person's family doctor has less influence on the decision than the person's own feelings and the opinions of relatives, according to a new survey released on Saturday.

The survey, conducted by Shutien Infirmary, a hospital in Taipei, and Shih Hsing University found that 46 percent of respondents choose a specialist based on their own feelings, while 23 percent said they make their decisions after consulting with relatives.

As a result, 36 percent of the public have turned to the wrong doctor for help at least once, according to the survey, which also found that 32 percent of respondents did not receive appropriate medical care when the wrong doctor was chosen. Twenty-three percent said their ailments worsened as a result of choosing the wrong doctor, while 25 percent said the decision wasted their money.
Respondents said the biggest problems with choosing the wrong doctors were incorrect diagnoses and prescriptions.

Dr. Hsu Jong-shuo, a family practitioner at Shutien Infirmary, said at a press conference called to unveil the survey results that family practitioners can help address this problem by providing patients with primary medical care and referring them to the right specialists.

DOC.HEADLINE: ENVIRONMENTAL MISERY INDEX RISES FURTHER: POLL

TEXT.P: Taiwan's environmental misery index rose to a four-year high of 77.47 points this year, indicating that the local living environment has worsened further, according to the results of a public opinion survey released on Saturday.
The telephone poll of 1,139 adults residing throughout the island was conducted by the Environmental Quality Protection Foundation (EQPF) from April 2 through April 5.
The foundation questioned the randomly selected local residents about their views on some 20 most common domestic environmental problems.

Among the 18 indicators used by the foundation to gauge the environmental misery index, 15 indicators, including air pollution, water pollution, garbage disposal, noise pollution, disposal of deserted cars and motorcycles, foul smell, and ecological problems, all showed signs of worsening. Only three factors -- wildlife protection, household waste water treatment and urban vegetation -- showed signs of improvement.

According to the latest survey, the overall misery index reached 77.47 points this year, up 2.1 points from the 1998 level. It was also the second highest level since the foundation began to conduct the annual survey five years ago. The first-ever such survey conducted in 1995 recorded the highest misery index of 78.72 points. In the foundation's measurement system, the higher the points, the worse the environmental misery.

Survey results showed that river pollution, widespread plastic containers, vehicle emissions and water pollution were the most disgusting environmental problems. Waste water and emissions from factories, mudflow and stray dogs were also cited by many respondents as the most serious environmental woes.

EQPF Secretary-General Liu Ming-lung attributed the rise in this year's environmental misery index to a combination of factors, including the Formosa Plastic Group's mercury-laced waste issue, typhoon damage, mudflow and flooding disasters reported over the past year, as well as slow progress in environment-related infrastructure construction.
"The government inefficiency in controlling pollution and improving environmental quality has made more local people feel uncomfortable and frustrated with their living environment," Liu noted.

The same survey found that only 36.8 percent of the respondents said they are satisfied with the performance of the Cabinet-level Environmental Protection Administration (EPA), down from last year's 39.5 percent.

Compared with previous polls, the number of people who are dissatisfied with the EPA's administration has increased steadily. The number of respondents who said they believe that many of EPA's administrative measures are adopted in favor of business interests has also surged continually, according to survey results.

On the future development, 36 percent said they expect Taiwan's general environment to deteriorate further over the next five years; only 18 percent said they believe the local environment will improve; 33.3 percent said they think the environment will remain almost the same.

Meanwhile, the latest survey found that 82 percent of those interviewed said they support the proposal to set up an environmental police corps under the EPA's jurisdiction; only 8.1 percent voiced opposition to such an idea.
Sixty-one percent threw support behind the proposal to upgrade the EPA to the status of a ministry, while 8 percent said they oppose such a change.

According to the poll, 70 percent gave a thumbs-up to the proposal to increase government budget for environmental protection programs; 11.2 percent were opposed to it; and 18.7 percent said they have no opinion about the issue.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING CONSISTENTLY HOSTILE TOWARD TRA: US SCHOLAR

TEXT.P: Beijing has been consistently hostile toward the Taiwan Relations Act (TRA) since the enactment of the law on April 10, 1979, Professor June Teufel Dreyer of the University of Miami said on Saturday.
Dreyer made the remark during the second day of an international academic seminar titled "International Conference on United States-Taiwan Relations: 20 Years after the TRA."

The two-day seminar was held by the Republic of China's Academia Sinica with some 170 scholars and experts from home and abroad attending. Twelve papers were presented and discussed during the seminar.

Beijing has contended that the TRA, especially its provisions for arms sales to Taiwan, runs counter to the sprit of both the Shanghai Communique of February 1972 and the normalization agreement of December 1978.
This view is consistent with recently declassified US materials concerning conversations between then US Secretary of State Henry Kissinger and mainland Chinese leader Deng Xiaoping.

Kissinger told Deng the act could be reviewed after a period of time. In essence, this review occurred in the form of a third communique in August 1982, in which the United States promised to gradually reduce the quantity and quality of its arms sales to Taiwan.
The 1982 communique, though never formally repudiated by the American side, has frequently been ignored or circumvented.

Beijing has argued that since the TRA is a domestic decision of the United States, it can have no relevance to mainland China. In addition to regular and vigorous protests against US actions consonant with the TRA, mainland China has:
-- used US desire for certain international arrangements and for commercial advantage as leverage to gain concessions from Washington;
-- argued that international agreements outweigh domestic legislation; and
-- sought to obtain a fourth communique or other official statements that more clearly undermine or vitiate the intent of the TRA.

Dreyer said that since the enactment of the TRA, every American administration has affirmed its intention to abide by it. But, as with all legislation, much depends on the interpretation of its clauses, she said.

She went on to say that what constitutes a defensive weapon and when there is a military imbalance in the Taiwan Strait are matters on which persons with different ideological proclivities have disagreed, often heatedly.

The general trend has been for US presidents to take small steps to placate Beijing and erode the intent of the TRA, hoping to avoid a deterioration of relations with mainland China while not going so far as to inflame domestic opposition, said the professor.

To date, though, these steps have tended to solidify domestic opposition, as was most recently exemplified by the strong congressional reaction to President Bill Clinton's public iteration of the Three Noes during his visit to mainland China last summer, Dreyer said.

DOC.HEADLINE: LITERARY LUMINARY SU HSUE-LING CELEBRATES 104TH BIRTHDAY

TEXT.P: Saturday marked the 104th birthday of one of Taiwan's most noted writers, Su Hsue-ling, and a birthday celebration for Su in the southern city of Tainan coincided with the publication of her collected diaries.

The celebration took place in the intensive care ward of National Cheng Kung University Hospital, which Su has called home for a number of months. President Lee Teng-hui and Vice President Lien Chan both sent Su birthday cards and presents.
A number of Su's students and several political and educational celebrities, including Cheng Kung University President Wung Cheng-yih and Tainan Mayor Chang Chan-ao, congratulated her in person.

During a ceremony marking the publication of Su's diaries, Wung praised her as a remarkable modern woman who lived in a traditional era in Chinese history. She is also the only living writer to have been writing at the time of 1919's May Fourth Movement, which marked the start of a Chinese intellectual revolution.

Su began writing around the age of 15. Most of her earliest diaries have been lost, but a Cheng Jung University task force successfully collected and had printed her diaries from 1948 to 1997. In all the books contain more than 4 million words.

DOC.HEADLINE: ENVIRONMENTAL WATCH CENTER TO BECOME OPERATIONAL ON APRIL 17

TEXT.P: A private environmental watch center will be inaugurated on April 17 to push for improvement in Taiwan's general living environment.
The new watch center will be operated by the Environmental Quality Protection Foundation (EQPF).

"We have decided to set up the watch center mainly because our government has failed to take effective measures to curb environmental pollution and improve environmental quality," EQPF Secretary-General Liu Ming-lung said.
Liu said although the Cabinet-level Environmental Protection Administration (EPA) has been set up for 10 years, the local environmental misery index has continued rising.
According to the results of a recent EQPF survey, Taiwan's environmental misery index surged to a four-year high of 77.47 points this year, up 2.1 points from the 1998 level.
"The rising index indicated that the local living environment has worsened further," Liu said.

In view of the government's inefficiency in protecting local living environment, Liu said the foundation has decided to pool resources in the private sector to push for faster progress in local environmental protection.
Liu further said the center will file its first environmental lawsuit on April 22 which has been designated Earth Day worldwide.

DOC.HEADLINE: OVER 1,000 TAIWAN PEOPLE JOIN IN REFERENDUM DEMONSTRATION

TEXT.P: More than 1,000 Taiwan people on Saturday took to the streets in downtown Taipei to push for the passage of legislation governing the holding of referendums.
Holding banners with messages such as "Save Taiwan Through Referendum" the crowd marched from Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall to the Legislative Yuan via the Office of the President.

While passing the Office of the President, some activists threw letters marked "Referendum to Bomb the Office of the President" and folded into paper airplanes at the office. This resulted in a warning from police, but the demonstration ended up peacefully after the group joined a hunger strike event at the Legislative Yuan.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO REFERENDUM ON VISITING FORCES AGREEMENT NEEDED: MANILA

TEXT.P: The Philippine government said Saturday a referendum is not required to ratify the Visiting Forces Agreement (VFA) between the Philippines and the United States, since the accord involves only temporary visits by American troops to the country.

National Security Adviser Alexsander Aguirre said the need for a referendum as specified under the constitution pertains only to international agreements involving the permanent basing of foreign troops and facilities in the Philippines, which clearly, does not encompass the VFA.
"The referendum is not needed because the VFA does not involve permanent military bases," Aguirre said.

Aguirre reacted to reports that some lawmakers had insisted that the government should follow a constitutional provision stating the conduct of military exercises here needs approval of the people through a national referendum.

The VFA, an implementing mechanism of the 1951 RP-US Mutual Defense Treaty (MDT), will serve as the legal framework for the treatment of American soldiers and military officials, who will visit the country for limited periods to participate in joint military exercises with Filipino troops. He said that under this provision, only the Senate's approval of the accord is needed to ratify the VFA.
Under the constitution, a two-thirds vote by the 23-member Senate is needed to ratify the VFA.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI CITY BUS SERVICE QUALITY GETS LOW CREDIT: POLL

TEXT.P: Most residents in the Greater Taipei Area do not give high marks to city bus service quality, according to the results of a public opinion survey released on Saturday.

The telephone poll was conducted by TVBS cable TV company on April 8-9, shortly after a No. 226 city bus caused the worst traffic accident in Taipei's history on Thursday. The 15-car pileup resulted in one death and 38 injuries.
TVBS interviewed 2,336 randomly selected residents in the Greater Taipei Area (comprising Taipei city and county), and collected 817 valid replies.

Survey results showed that 47.7 percent of the respondents said they are satisfied with the quality of city bus services in the Greater Taipei Area, while 46.9 percent said they are unhappy with city bus services.

Despite Thursday's city bus-triggered serious traffic accident, 80 percent of those interviewed still said they feel it is safe to take a city bus ride, only 16 percent said they feel riding on a city bus is unsafe.

According to the survey, 55.5 percent of the respondents are most dissatisfied with city bus drivers' service quality; 45.2 percent cited slow replacement of old city buses as the most unsatisfactory factor. Other drawbacks included poor air conditioning and dirty ambiance in the city bus.

Asked about city bus drivers' bad habits, 43.3 percent said they are most dissatisfied with the drivers' smoking and betel nut chewing; followed by speeding, abrupt braking and failing to stop at the right place.
City bus remained the most popular mass transportation tool for Taipei residents; followed by taxi, mass rapid transit system and train, according to the poll.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Sunday, April 11, or the 25th day of the second month of the Year of the Rabbit according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1512: French troops defeat Spanish and Papal forces at Ravenna in one of the bloodiest battles of the 16th century.
1713: France cedes Newfoundland and Gibraltar to Britain.
1755: James Parkinson, the British physician who defined Parkinson's disease, a progressive disease of the nervous system also called paralysis agitans or shaking palsy, is born.
1893: Dean Acheson, the US politician and secretary of state who helped to formulate the Truman Doctrine and the Marshall Plan, and promoted the setting up of North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO), is born.
1899: Spain transfers the Philippines to the control of the United States.
1919: The International Labor Organization (ILO) is founded in Geneva in affiliation with the League of Nations to improve living standards and working conditions.
1935: Dust storms wreak havoc in the so-called "Dust Bowl" states of Kansas, Colorado, Wyoming, Oklahoma, Texas, and New Mexico in the United States.
1950: The Bank of Taiwan issues its first lottery.
1951: US President Harry Truman relieves Gen. Douglas MacArthur, the World War II hero who accepted the Japanese surrender in Tokyo Bay in 1945, of all his commands, including that of UN forces commander in Korea.
1957: Singapore is granted self-government by the United Kingdom.
1961: Alleged Nazi war criminal Adolf Eichmann enters a Jerusalem court to hear 15 charges against him, 12 of which carry the death penalty.
1969: Taiwan's Executive Yuan approves the "Guidelines for the Population Policy of the Republic of China."
1970: The government of Prime Minister Lon Nol announces abolishment of the monarchy and proclaims Cambodia a republic.
1974: Golda Meir resigns as Israeli prime minister.
1978: The Taiwan Province Black Foot Disease Control Center is inaugurated in Peimen Village, Tainan County.
1981: Chen Ta, a noted singer of Taiwanese folk songs, dies at the age of 76.
1984: Konstantin Chernenko is appointed president of the Soviet Union.
1994: US President Bill Clinton orders trade sanctions against Taiwan in accordance with the "Pelly Act."
1995: Chen Yun, one of communist China's leading veteran hardliners, dies in Beijing at the age of 90.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A moral character always has courage; but a man of courage is not necessarily a moral character."

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC AID DELEGATION HEADS FOR MACEDONIA
DOC.DATELINE: Bonn, April 10 (CNA) (By Lillian Lin and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: A 90-member Republic of China mission will depart for Macedonia on Tuesday to help the Balkan state as ethnic-Albanian refugees continue to enter from neighboring Kosovo, a province of Yugoslavia.

The delegation, led by Vice Foreign Minister Taiwei Lee and composed of medical care personnel, business leaders and more than 20 reporters, will donate a field hospital and assistance materials to the Macedonian government.

Tens of thousands of ethnic Albanian refugees have flooded into Macedonia since NATO launched a bombing campaign in Belgrade as a result of Yugoslavia's massacre of ethnic Albanian population in Kosovo.
Meanwhile, the local press reported that an ROC trade delegation had left for Skopje on Saturday to help the southeastern European country with its economic development.
The official mission will be stationed in Macedonia for a period of three years, during which the ROC government will dispatch various technical missions to that country, according to the reports.
Apart from the Vatican, Macedonia is the ROC's sole diplomatic partner in Europe. Taipei and Skopje forged formal diplomatic ties on Jan. 27.

DOC.HEADLINE: HEADS OF MEDIUM-SIZED ENTERPRISES PREFER SOONG AS PRESIDENT: POLL

TEXT.P: Nearly 60 percent of the heads of small- and medium-sized enterprises support former Taiwan provincial governor James Soong running in the 2000 presidential race, according to a poll Sunday.

The poll, conducted by Legislator Lai Shih-pao of the opposition New Party, was made at a time when potential candidates of the ruling Kuomintang and the opposition Democratic Progressive Party are gearing up for their presidential campaigns.

The heads of the small- and medium-sized enterprises were asked who they would support for president among Vice President Lien Chan, Soong, former Taipei City Mayor Chen Shui-bian and former chairman of Democratic Progressive Party Hsu Hsin-liang.
The poll showed that 58.2 percent would support Soong, followed by Chen with 20.8 percent. Lien received 19.1 percent, and Hsu 2.9 percent.
More than half those polled said that they believed Soong will eventually break with the KMT and run independently, while 27.5 percent said Soong would not do so.
The poll also found a Soong-Lien ticket (27.8 percent) had slightly more support than a Lien-Soong ticket (27.3 percent) when the leaders were asked to name their favorite presidential tandem.
Some 42 percent of those polled also said that John Chang, secretary general of the ruling Kuomintang, is most likely to be chosen as a KMT vice presidential nominee.

Of DPP supporters, 37.6 percent of those polled said they didn't know which tandem would be the best ticket. But 32.4 percent said they support a Chen-Hsu ticket, with 16 percent supporting a Hsu-Chen ticket.
Some 53 percent of those polled said that candidates in the 2000 presidential race should first and foremost have vision, followed by resoluteness, and then caliber.
More than 60 percent of those polled said that they do not believe the 2000 presidential race will be a fair and fraud-free race.

Lai, in interpreting the poll, said that the results disprove the myth that candidates who break with their parties are out, noting the 2,000 volunteers who recently signed up Soong's private office show the popularity of the former Taiwan provincial governor.
The poll was conducted March 23- April 9, with responding questionnaires totaling 418 out of 1,250 issued.

DOC.HEADLINE: GREATER CHINA HAS MOST OF WORLD'S FOREIGN RESERVES

TEXT.P: The combined foreign exchange reserves of Taiwan, Hong Kong and mainland China in March reached US$328,805 billion, ranking the greater-China area at the top of the world's foreign exchange reserves, statistics from the Central Bank of China showed on Sunday.
Japan, whose foreign exchange reserves totaled US$222.5 billion in March, trailed in second place by a considerable amount, according to the data.
