The data showed that the mainland increased its reserves from last December's US$144.9 billion to US$146 billion, while Taiwan's reserves soared to US$93 billion, the highest in 44 months. Hong Kong's foreign reserves were US$89.8 billion.
Taiwan's foreign reserves in March increased a significant US$9,389 billion, compared to reserves of the same month last year.
The total amount of gold reserves kept in the Central Bank of China amounted to 1,357 million ounces, roughly equaling US$3,799 billion.
Officials from the bank said that the foreign exchange reserves increase indicates the stability of the local stock market and New Taiwan dollar exchange rate. (by Amanda Chang)

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT LEADER RAPS ZHU'S REMARKS ON USING FORCE AGAINST TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Kuomintang Secretary-General John Chang on Saturday criticized mainland Chinese Premier Zhu Rongji's recent remarks claiming that Beijing would not rule out the use of force against Taiwan.
Zhu indicated at a White House press conference last Thursday that for the sake of keeping a territory intact, mainland China may have to learn from President Abraham Lincoln's Civil War.
His remarks were interpreted as mainland China's intention of using force to attain reunification.
Chang, a former Republic of China foreign minister well versed in Sino-American affairs, described Zhu's remarks as distorting the historical event.
He said that the Civil War was waged to solve the slavery and racial problems, with its background totally different from the current cross-Taiwan Strait situation.
Chang noted that Zhu's making such a comparison was "quite improper," adding that if Zhu's idea is widely shared by the Beijing leadership, "it is really a troublesome and worrisome matter."

Despite the stiff attitude toward Taiwan, the KMT leader said that Taipei will continue to follow its existing strategy and to push forward democratic and economic reforms, so as to provide a lesson for mainland China.

DOC.HEADLINE: 80 PERCENT OF PREGNANT TEENAGERS SEEK ABORTION

TEXT.P: Only about one out of every five pregnant teenager in Taiwan will give birth, with the remainder seeking an abortion, a doctor reported on Sunday.
Chiang Chien-tai, president of the Taipei Municipal Hospital for Women & Children, made the remark while attending a meeting of obstetrics and gynecologists.

Chiang said that on average, among 1,000 Taiwan teenagers aged 14-19, 12-14 babies will be born in a year. Among every five teenaged pregnancies, only about one will result in a birth, with the other four aborted.

She noted current regulations stipulate that minors who seek abortions must have the consent of their legal guardians. But as most of the country's unwed teenagers do not tell their families about their pregnancy, they end up seeking an unlawful abortion.
She said that the situation showed the gulf between current regulations and the actual situation.

Hsu Yu-Chyong, an obstetrics and gynecologist, said on the same occasion that she had encountered one girl who had undergone four abortions in 18 months. Hsu lamented the fact the teenagers are too ignorant about sex.

Chiang said that health authorities should step up the sex education campaign among teenagers, educating them about the use of condoms to avoid pregnancy before marriage, as well as to prevent venereal diseases.
Chiang suggested that law be amended to lower the age of adulthood from the existing 20 to 18.

Hsu echoed her words, asking if an 18-year-old is able to take a test to get a driver's license, why the same age girl cannot control the rights to her body? She said that current regulations requiring teenagers to have the consent of their legal guardians to seek an abortion is meaningless and only contributes to the number of illegal abortions.

DOC.HEADLINE: ZHU'S US VISIT NOT EXPECTED TO PRODUCE BREAKTHROUGH: SEMINAR

TEXT.P: Mainland Chinese Prime Minister Zhu Rongji's current US visit is not expected to produce a major breakthrough in bilateral ties, academics attending a Sunday seminar said. Speaking at a seminar on the impact of Zhu's US trip, some scholars and experts even opined that Zhu's visit will deteriorate two-way Beijing-Washington ties. Although Zhu has taken a low profile during his current US tour, Liang Chung-min, an associate professor at Fu Jen Catholic University, said the US side has not made any compromises as a result. Such an outcome has merely buttressed the differences and conflicts of interest between mainland China and other western countries, further deteriorating the Beijing-Washington relationship, he contended.

Pang Hsi-tang, professor at Tamkang University's Mainland China Affairs Study Institute, predicted that two-way Beijing-Washington ties will not turn for the better in the short term, as sharp differences remain on issues related to Taiwan, Tibet, political contributions to the US Democratic Party, technology theft and the US-proposed Theater Missile Defense System for its allies in east Asia.

Pang, however, said he believes that the United States' willingness to support mainland China's entrance into the World Trade Organization will help Taiwan accelerate its pace to join the Geneva-based world trade regulatory body as well. But Taiwan will face a series of complicated issues on cross-strait economic activities, including the opening of trade, transportation and mail service links between the two sides and the allowance of mainland Chinese capital and agricultural and farm product exports to enter Taiwan, he pointed out.

In addition, Pang said Zhu has demonstrated a more hardline stance on issues regarding Taiwan than mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin, underscoring his threat to use the military to achieve unification with Taiwan. Zhu's demonstration of his reluctance to forswear the use of force against Taiwan showed that the Taiwan issue has become a pressing matter to Beijing, he added.

Echoing Pang's view, Chinese Culture University Professor Kuo Chan-li said Zhu's remarks on Thursday in Washington that Beijing will learn from US President Abraham Lincoln's use of force to keep the country together as it deals with Taiwan indicated that the Chinese communist regime is running out of patience with Taipei.

Such a mood will fuel worries among the people of Taiwan, he noted, warning that the use of military intimidation to resolve the Taiwan issue will only create hatred between the younger generations on the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.

Wu Yu-heng, professor with Fu Hsing Kang University, said Zhu made a big mistake while commenting on the Taiwan issue, but added that the eloquent mainland Chinese leader's US trip has undoubtedly helped Beijing to lure US Chinese communities.

DOC.HEADLINE: JAPAN FINDS MOST ILLEGAL IMMIGRANTS FROM MAINLAND CHINA

TEXT.P: The Japanese police caught 379 illegal immigrants in 25 groups between Jan. 1 and April 6, of whom 324 or 85 percent were from mainland China.
Japanese news media quoted police authorities as saying that most of the illegal immigrants came in modified container ships or other kind of cargo ships with the help of "smuggling organizations."

The Japanese police have found that the number of illegal immigrants coming to Japan in South Korean ships is increasing. A great majority of them have entered Japan successfully, as can be seen from the increasing number of criminal cases involving aliens from mainland China, the reports said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S ECONOMY REVIVES: VICE PRESIDENT

TEXT.P: Taiwan has successfully survived the regional economic turmoil as evidenced by an outstanding 4.83 percent economic growth, the second highest in Asia, Vice President Lien Chan claimed on Saturday in Kaohsiung.
The first quarter growth of Taiwan exports also proved the the country's economic climate has been revitalized, Lien added.
The Vice President made the remark in response to questions raised by reporters during the inauguration ceremony of Taiwan's first theme shopping mall in the southern Taiwan port city.
This shopping mall, named "The Treasure Island shopping mall", was jointly developed by the state-run Taiwan Sugar and a private firm at a cost of NT$1.6 billion.
Lien said when he served as Premier, he instructed the government to develop resorts and shopping malls as he considered they would meet the nation's demand for more leisure facilities.
Lien believed the shopping mall would stimulate southern Taiwan's economic development. (by Amanda Chang)

DOC.HEADLINE: ARMY TO HOLD DRILL IN MID-MAY

TEXT.P: The Republic of China army will hold a drill in mid-May on the offshore island of Penghu, a spokesman for the Department of National Defense said on Sunday.

The spokesman said the series of drills, code named "Chengkung", will he held to test the combat capability of the newly formed "integrated brigades". Chengkung will include a display of combat equipment, an inspection of all units, and a live ammunition drill.
More than 100 military personnel from tank combat units in the Penghu Defense Command will take part in the live ammunition drill.

The Chengkung drill was not included in the annual exercise schedule unveiled by the Ministry of National Defense earlier this year because it is a routine training drill, not a large-scale exercise, the spokesman said.
The spokesman said that the drill will happen in May because that is the most suitable time for Penghu adding, there is no need for unnecessary speculation.

Military sources said that journalists, government officials and local dignitaries will be invited to visit the drills. A ranking military official with the rank of chief of the general staff or above, will preside.
President Lee Teng-hui or Vice President Lien Chan are likely to visit the drills to inspect the army.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP KEEPS QUIET OVER PLEBISCITE HUNGER STRIKE

TEXT.P: The Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) is taking a tone-downed posture toward a hunger strike calling for a constitutional amendment to allow a plebiscite to decide Taiwan's future and other major issues.
The indefinite strike was staged in front of the Legislative Yuan (Parliament) on Saturday by some DPP legislators and some pro-independence activists.

Although some DPP lawmakers were among the organizers of the strike, the DPP leadership has avoided direct involvement, as the party considers it poor timing to employ such a radical measure before a presidential election.

Former Taipei Mayor Chen Shui-bian, a prospective DPP contender for next spring's presidential election, has previously stated that a plebiscite is not necessarily to be written into the constitution or to be enacted as a law.

DPP National Assemblyman Chiu Yi-ying admitted that in the eyes of most people in Taiwan, a plebiscite is undoubtedly aimed at Taiwan independence, and, therefore, it will deal a blow to Chen Shui-bian's "new middle road policy."

Since hunger strike began, the DPP leadership, headed by Chairman Lin Yi-hsiung, has visited the strikers to extend the party's concern, but has refrained from voicing strong support for their actions.
A spokesman for the ruling Kuomintang, Huang Hui-chen, on Saturday reiterated the party's consistent opposition to a constitutional amendment for a plebiscite.

He stressed that there is no need for a plebiscite to decide Taiwan's future as the Republic of China enjoys an independent sovereignty and the Ministry of the Interior is working on a bill for initiative and referendum.

DOC.HEADLINE: 1998 CREDIT CARD SPENDING HIT RECORD HIGH

TEXT.P: Taiwan's spending via credit cards set a record high of NT$491.9 billion (about US$15 billion) in 1998, up 31.1 percent, or NT$116.6 billion, from 1997, according to the Central Bank of China (CBC). Statistics compiled by the CBC showed that NT$441.5 billion, or 89.9 percent, of the total spending was charged in Taiwan, while the remaining 10.1 percent was charged overseas.

In addition, NT$5.18 trillion (about US$157 billion) worth of transactions were made in 1998 via automatic teller machines islandwide, setting a historical high and reflecting a noticeable increase of NT$385.2 billion from 1997.

DOC.HEADLINE: CANCER CAN BE DETECTED IN BLOOD

TEXT.P: Many earlier types of cancer can be discovered with a small sample of blood, Academia Sinica member Tsao An-pang announced on Sunday.
Using 20cc of blood, Tsao is able to detect many types of cancer cells in areas including the prostate, large intestine, kidney and pancreas through a special test which yields results in two days.

Tsao, a professor at Johns Hopkins University in Baltimore, Maryland, explained in a medical conference that due to the special antibodies or nucleic acids in a cancer cell, he can detect different types of cancer through a dyeing process and with the help of a color fluorescent microscope.
The new testing method is safer and more reliable than traditional methods, Professor Tsao said adding, it has passed more than six hundred individual experiments in the United States.

Professor Tsao announced he will transfer the technology back to Taiwan and set up a laboratory in six months. The National Taiwan University Hospital and Taipei's Veterans General Hospital have been in touch with him on this matter, he added.

The discovery that malignant tumors can be discovered and treated in the early stage is a good news for Taiwan, as the country annually has 30,000 new cancer cases and with 20,000 of those patients eventually dying.

DOC.HEADLINE: UN ASKS AUSTRALIA NOT TO AIRLIFT REFUGEES

TEXT.P: Canberra, April 11 (CNA): The Australian government has put on hold its biggest ever airlifting operation for ethnic Albanian refugees from Macedonia at the request of the United Nations.

UN High Commissioner for Refugees Ms Sadako Ogata on Saturday asked Australia, the United States and Canada to halt their plans to evacuate tens of thousands of Albanian refugees until it was further assessed that aid funds could be better spent in Europe.

Albanian Prime Minister Pandeli Majko indicated that his country could take most of the refugees if other countries offered financial aid. UN officials are expected to urge Australia, the US, Canada and other countries to support Albania's efforts to accommodate the refugees.
"We have put a pause on the arrangements we were going to implement, pending further advice from the United Nations," said a spokesman for Immigration Minister Philip Ruddock.

He said the Australian government remained ready to help and staff from the Immigration Department would go to Macedonia to complete the preparations for the evacuation if the plan returns to the original one.

"We would expect Australia would be in a position to move people within 48 hours of the lifting of such a pause," he added. Australia estimates the airlifting operations of Albanian refugees would cost the Howard government about A$40 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: BOAT PEOPLE LAND IN AUSTRALIA UNDETECTED

TEXT.P: Immigration officials told reporters police had detained 43 boat people -- 39 men and four women -- and were looking for more from the same boat.
Earlier at least two groups of boat people also sneaked into coastal Australia in Queensland, but most of them were caught and sent to Port Hedland in Western Australia for questioning.

Police said the latest group of boat people, including three mainland Chinese, landed in the small hours on Saturday and many of them changed into fresh clothes, including suits and ties, which they carried in zip-up plastic bags, leaving their old clothes strewn across the sand dunes.
Some of the arrested refugees even carried local telephone numbers and detailed Australian maps, according to Federal Member of Parliament Gary Nehl.
The Australian government said the illegal migrants would be sent to Port Hedland for questioning before being deported to their port of origin.

Despite a tightening of air and coastal surveillance, the boat people were able to land in Australia undetected until they were onshore and spotted by Australian residents, who reported the cases to police.

DOC.HEADLINE: CLINTON-ZHU JOINT STATEMENT

TEXT.P: The United States and mainland China issued a joint statement by President Bill Clinton and Premier Zhu Rongji on Saturday, after a vigorous late Friday night bargain over the languages and context of the statement.

As weird and unusual as it seems, this is the second time the White House had issued such a statement in as many days. The new version has been significantly abridged from what the White House had issued on Thursday.

Zhu said in a banquet here on Friday that the US unilaterally publicized a list of commitments by mainland China over the market access and protocol issues of World Trade Organization (WTO). He showed his displeasure to the Clinton administration by saying that "they said we have agreed to them, but we don't."

After a last minute tough bargain over the joint statement before Zhu's departure to Denver Saturday morning, US and mainland Chinese negotiators agreed to eliminate any mention of the detailed market access and protocol appendixes of the statement.

The key language of the statement has also been changed from both sides support the "common goal of admission of the People's Republic of China to the WTO on strong commercial terms in 1999" to "the United States strongly supports the accession of the People's Republic of China to the WTO in 1999."
The full text of the statement is as follows:

On the occasion of the signing of the Agreement on US-China Agricultural Cooperation, President Bill Clinton and Premier Zhu Rongji reaffirmed that the United States and the People's Republic of China have advanced substantially their common goal of China's accession to the World Trade Organization (WTO).

This Agreement and the significant consensus achieved on a broad range of market access and Protocol issues have further advanced that goal. President Clinton and Premier Zhu welcome this significant progress.
The United States strongly supports the accession of the People's Republic of China to the WTO in 1999.

Therefore, President Clinton and Premier Zhu instruct their trade ministers to continue bilateral negotiations in order to satisfactorily resolve the important remaining issues and reach agreement on strong commercial terms as soon as possible.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies Monday are as follows:

DOC.HEADLINE: MA USES CAMPAIGN SUBSIDY TO FORM 2 FOUNDATIONS

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou has used his campaign subsidy for mayoral election to form two foundations.

Ma noted that he garnered 766,377 votes during mayoral elections last December. Under election and recall laws, the Taipei City Election Commission reimbursed him NT$30 (US$0.90) for each vote he won, or a total of more than NT$22 million (US$664,650).
To make the best use of the money, Ma said, he has decided to form two foundations. One is a cultural and education foundation, while the other is a charity foundation.

Ma said the New Taiwanese Cultural and Education Foundation seeks to assemble people from all walks of life to pool their wisdom to promote the study and discussion of public issues in a supra-race and supra-party manner.
The popular Taipei mayor said that neither he nor his family will hold any position in either of the foundations.

He stressed that the foundations' budgets are meager and that they will rely heavily on donations in the future. All donations will be certified by accountants, and the financial operations of the two foundations will be completely transparent, he said.
The "New Taiwanese" part of the foundation's name was first broached by President Lee Teng-hui during the mayoral race, Ma noted.

The concept received an enthusiastic response from the public, showing the public's aspiration for racial harmony and social progress. He said that the foundation seeks to shake off old ideas and internal rivalry and focus on solidifying the society.

The New Taiwanese foundation will ask Sun Yun-suan, senior adviser to the president, to serve as its honorary chairman, while Shen Chun-shan, former president of National Tsing Hua University, will be asked to serve as chairman.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC CHARITY GROUP TO LEAVE FOR MACEDONIA ON MONDAY NIGHT

TEXT.P: A Republic of China charity group, jointly organized by the government and private institutes, is slated to leave Taipei for Macedonia Monday night to provide the refugee swarmed Balkan nation with humanitarian assistance.
The group, led by Vice Foreign Minister David Lee, will take a chartered plane and is expected to arrive in Macedonia on Tuesday.

Peter Cheng, the first de facto ambassador of the Republic of China to Macedonia, will also go with the group to assume his new post. Cheng most recently served as deputy representative of the Republic of China to the United States.

The ROC Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) has announced over the last few days plans to provide Macedonia with US$2 million to help the nation solve the financial dilemma that has resulted from an influx of Albanian-Yugoslav refugees.
MOFA officials revealed that the ROC government will provide Macedonia with additional monetary assistance, though they would not specify the amount.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT OF RUSSIAN STATE OF KALMYKIA TO VISIT TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The president of the state of Kalmykia, one of the 21 autonomous republics of the Russian Federation, is scheduled to arrive in Taiwan next Sunday for a four-day official visit, sources from the Mongolian and Tibetan Affairs Commission (MTAC) reported Monday.
Taiwan has maintained frequent contacts with Kalmykia in recent years, and MTAC Chairman Kao Kung-lien visited the Russian state last year, according to Liu Hsueh-chao, chief secretary of MTAC.
Kalmykian officials joined overseas Mongol groups to visit Taiwan last October to attend celebrations marking the Republic of China's National Day on Oct. 10, said Liu.

Under an academic agreement that Taiwan and Kalmykia forged in 1991, Kalmykia has sent students of Mongol origin to Taiwan to learn mandarin Chinese. Each year MTAC offers a scholarship to a Mongol student from Kalmykia wishing to study mandarin Chinese in Taiwan.

Kalmykia borders the Caspian Sea and lies within the Caspian Sea lowlands. Within its borders is the area where the Volga River feeds into the sea. It has a population of about 330,000, half of whom are Mongols, which are present-day descendants of the Mongols who ruled Russia between 1237 and the late 1400s.

The country's economy is based mainly on agriculture with livestock breeding accounting for 77 percent of overall production. Kalmykia is famous for its Karakul soft wool, hard sought after by clothing manufacturers worldwide.

Kalmykia, whose fur, hide, butter, cheese and meat processing industries are also well-developed, welcomes Taiwan businesses to invest in the Russian republic, particularly in wool processing, oil drilling and harbor development, Liu noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: SHINTARO ISHIHARA HAS NO PLAN TO VISIT TAIWAN AT PRESENT
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, April 12 (CNA) (By Mike Chang and David Hsu)

TEXT.P: Personnel from the campaign headquarters of Tokyo Mayor-elect Shintaro Ishihara said that they have not heard of any plans by Ishihara to visit Taiwan.
They made the remark in response to a CNA reporter who asked whether Ishihara plans to visit.
Some Taiwan newspapers have reported that Ishihara expressed an intention to visit Taiwan if he were to win the election.

Officials of Taipei Economic and Cultural Representative Office in Japan said they also have not heard about the matter. But they said that if Ishihara is willing to take the trip, the representative office would offers its assistance.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER MAINLAND VICE CULTURE MINISTER DIES IN TAICHUNG

TEXT.P: Former mainland Chinese Vice Minister of Culture Wang Jifu died in a hospital in Taichung on Monday from injuries suffered in a severe fall during a tour of a private museum in central Taiwan six days ago.

Wang, who arrived in Taiwan on March 31 at the head of a mainland Chinese cultural delegation, had been in a coma since he was rushed to Chungshan Medical College Hospital in Taichung after falling down a flight of stairs on April 6.

Doctors at the hospital said Wang's condition worsened early Monday morning, with his heartbeat and blood pressure dropping abruptly. After 30 minutes of emergency treatment, Wang was pronounced dead.

Wang, 71, suffered four skull fractures in addition to brain hemorrhage during the fatal fall. His index of vital signs was a weak 2 points when he was sent to Chung Shan Hospital, according to doctors. Fifteen points is standard for a healthy man under normal conditions.
Wang's death marks the first major accident ever suffered by a mainland Chinese visitor in Taiwan since the Republic of China opened doors to private visits across the Taiwan Strait in 1987.
Out of humanitarian considerations, the ROC government already allowed three of Wang's family members and several relevant mainland people to travel to Taiwan on April 9 to help care for Wang.
Wang's wife and their son and daughter were in the hospital when he died at around 3:40 a.m.
His family said Wang's body will be cremated in Taichung on Tuesday and that his ashes will be taken back to mainland China later this month.

Wang was invited by a local private cultural organization to visit Taiwan in his capacity as chairman of the China Foundation for Minority Cultures and Arts. He had been scheduled to leave here for home on April 8.
Su Chi, chairman of the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC), which charts Taiwan's policy toward the mainland, expressed deep regret over Wang's death.

Su said he has ordered relevant MAC officials and the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) to assist Wang's family in handling aftermath. SEF is a quasi-official body authorized by the ROC government to handle exchanges with mainland China in the absence of official ties.
Su urged mainland visitors to pay greater attention to their own safety during their stay in Taiwan.

The senior mainland policy planner further said the MAC will demand all mainland private groups intending to visit Taiwan to buy travel insurance policies for their members. Sources said Wang didn't buy any travel insurance policy in Taiwan as his tour was handled by a mainland travel agency.

DOC.HEADLINE: ZHU CRITICIZES CLINTON OVER FAILED TRADE BID

TEXT.P: Showing obvious pique about a summit gone awry, mainland Chinese Premier Zhu Rongji sharply criticized President Bill Clinton for refusing to approve a proposed deal aimed at bringing mainland China into a global trading organization, according to a report in Saturday's Los Angeles Times.

At a private breakfast with 15 members of Congress, Zhu briefly abandoned his easygoing manner to complain through a translator that Clinton "did not have enough courage" to sign an accord backing mainland China's application to the World Trade Organization (WTO) because of likely opposition in Congress, according to several people who attended.

Zhu, who listened intently to the Americans in English but responded in Chinese, did not correct his interpreter's translation of his forceful remark, as he did at other points during the hour-long meeting at Blair House. Aides said Zhu understands English better than he speaks it.

Several participants said they were surprised at Zhu's barbed words and were disappointed when he appeared to brush aside their own complaints about mainland China's human rights abuses, alleged spying and missile proliferation, as well as other disputes that have badly strained recent ties with Beijing, according to the report.

DOC.HEADLINE: DESPITE ECONOMIC DOWNTURN, ASIANS ARE SAVING MORE

TEXT.P: As incomes declined across the region last year with the deepening economic crisis, Asians actually began saving more money, according to The Straits Times.
Some see this as a uniquely Asian phenomenon in contrast to situations elsewhere, where there would be a higher temptation to draw down savings to maintain living standards, it said.

With the exception of Indonesia, where the situation was complicated with political and ethnic tensions, national savings rates in other declining economies -- Malaysia, Thailand, the Philippines and South Korea -- all went up last year, even as the worst of the region's downturn swept through their economies and incomes declined.

Asia's famous reputation for thrift is confirmed by data from official and International Monetary Fund sources that indicate that the gross national savings -- money saved by individuals, companies and the government -- of many Asian countries is anywhere from 30 percent to 50 percent of those countries' respective gross domestic products for last year, the report said.

DOC.HEADLINE: VIAGRA TO ENTER SINGAPORE MARKET SOON

TEXT.P: Men who need the anti-impotence drug Viagra in Singapore will be able to get it through their doctors, starting April 19.
Pfizer, the company that developed the drug, said the first shipment is scheduled to leave Sydney, Australia, for Singapore on Friday.
Regulations here restrict doctors to prescribing no more than 12 pills for each patient in a month. Each pill is expected to cost about S$17.
There are no official numbers of the men who need the medicine. But doctors here say their patients have already "booked" Viagra prescriptions.

DOC.HEADLINE: ECONOMICS MINISTER DEFENDS INTRODUCTION OF MAINLAND HIGH-TECH TALENT

TEXT.P: Economic Affairs Minister Wang Chih-kang on Monday defended the Ministry of Economic Affairs'(MOEA) plan to introduce mainland Chinese scientific and technological talent into Taiwan, saying that the policy will not result in contentiousness in Taiwan's high-tech industry.

Answering questions at the Legislative Yuan about a recent MOEA plan to introduce mainland Chinese high-tech personnel, Wang said the screening of prospective mainland candidates would be "extremely severe and vigilant."

Only a small number of candidates will be approved, and approvals will be made on a case-by-case basis, he said, adding that this will ensure that the mainland hirings are added to high-tech areas where more talent are needed.

Democratic Progressive Party Legislator Su Huan-chih of Tainan County said lax government control over inflows of high-tech personnelfrom the mainland -- for example, allowing mainland Chinese with only a junior-college- or college-level education to enter Taiwan -- would deal a blow to the local job market, which is already faced with an alarming unemployment rate.

Su, who does not see the proposed influx of mainland high-tech talent as an answer to Taiwan's bid to upgrade its high-tech industry, urged the MOEA to be extraordinarily careful when adopting the plan.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Monday, April 12, or the 26th day of the second month of the Year of the Rabbit according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1606: The Union Jack becomes England's official flag.
1860: Vajirananavarorasa, prince and patriarch of Buddhism in Siam, is born. He institutionalized Thai Buddhism.
1861: US Civil War breaks out as Confederate forces under Gen. Pierre Beauregarde take Fort Sumter in Charlestown harbor, South Carolina.
1927: The Kuomintang starts a "purification" movement by expelling communist members.
1945: US President Franklin D. Roosevelt dies in Office at the age of 63. Vice President Harry S. Truman is sworn in as his successor.
1949: The Farm Rental Reduction Program goes into effect in Taiwan.
1953: The Legislative Yuan passes a bill submitted by President Chiang Kai-shek, extending the term of office for legislators another year, i.e., to May 7, 1954.
1958: The first national meeting for commending "Good Men and Good Deeds" is held at the Chung Shan Hall in Taipei.
1961: The Russians put the first man into space when Cosmonaut Yauri Gargarin is launched in the Vostok I space vehicle for a single orbit of the earth.
1963: Indonesian forces launch the first armed attack against Malaysia in a policy of confrontation.
1965: Twisters attack six US mid-west states, killing 239 people.
1966: US bombers carry out their first raids over North Vietnam.
1973: Deng Xiaoping, who was purged during the Cultural Revolution, resumes his position as the vice premier of communist China.
1973: Vietnamese President Nguyen Van Thieu and his wife arrive in Taipei for a visit.
1979: Taiwan's first geothermal power plant formally starts operation.
1980: President William Tolbert of Liberia is assassinated in a military coup.
1981: Columbia, the world's first re-usable space shuttle, is launched at Cape Canaveral.
1983: China Airlines inaugurates its regular flight service to Amsterdam as the first step toward establishing a world commercial air service.
1989: Honduran President Jose Azcona Hoyo and his wife arrive in Taipei for a visit.
1991: The United States and Vietnam agree to set up an office in Hanoi to help locate US soldiers missing in action during the Vietnam War.
1994: The Mainland Affairs Council decides to suspend all cultural and educational exchanges with the mainland until Beijing provides reasonable and satisfactory explanations for the Qiandao Lake tragedy on Mar. 31 in which 24 Taiwan tourists are killed.
1996: The Petronas Towers in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia, are declared the world's tallest buildings.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "There are wise men who are not moral characters; but a fool is never a moral character."

DOC.HEADLINE: HUNGER STRIKE FOR PLEBISCITE PROVISION WILL CONTINUE, SAYS LEADER

TEXT.P: A hunger strike in support of the establishment of provisions for holding plebiscites entered its third day Monday, and the strike's organizer said it would continue despite recent actions by the ruling Kuomintang that appear conciliatory.

Trong R. Chai, a Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) legislator who is leading the strike, said on Monday that the strike would not end simply because the KMT has agreed to add discussions about the establishment of provisions to the legislature's agenda.
Chang Chun-hsiung, the DPP's party whip at the Legislative Yuan, said the party will not negotiate with the KMT when it is insincere.
Chang said the DPP would agree to negotiations only if they are conducive to the final passage for a bill adding plebiscite provisions to the Constitution.

The DPP will continue to say no to the KMT if the ruling party aims only to alter the legislature's agenda to include discussions on the matter and then kill the enactment proposal, Chang said, adding that he supports the continuation of the hunger strike, which is currently being staged in front of the Legislative Yuan.
According to the DPP sources monitoring the health of the strikers, most strikers are weak but still in fair health, and no one has had to be hospitalized so far.

Meanwhile, KMT Secretary-General John Chang called for the strikers "not to overdo it" after they have made their stance known. He said hunger strikes are too extreme and threaten to undermine social stability.

The secretary-general said the Republic of China is a politically open society, where different opinions can be voiced from various channels, and efforts to change the government's policies can be achieved through amendments to the Constitution and rules of law. It is unnecessary for people to take such extreme measures as engaging in hunger strikes, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCKS, FUTURES DECLINE

TEXT.P: Taiwan stock prices closed 0.3 percent lower on Monday as most funds flowed into the electronic sector, causing a decline in other issues.
The benchmark Taiwan Stock Exchange Weighted Price Index fell 23.30 points to 7,242.40 by the close of trade, following a 0.1 percent dip in the previous session.
A total of 3.15 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$127.83 billion (US$3.86 billion), down from the previous session's NT$142.06 billion.
Decliners led advancers 349 to 110, with 34 issues unchanged.
Among the eight major stock categories, the electronic sector posted the only gain of the day, rising 1.5 percent, while textile shares dropped the most at 3.1 percent.
Cement issues slipped 2.9 percent, followed by plastic and chemical shares, which dipped 1.9 percent. Foodstuff stocks went down 1.7 percent.
The paper and pulp sector edged down 1.4 percent, the construction sector 1.2 percent, and financial shares fell 1.1 percent.
The over-the-counter market posted a slight decline of 0.93 point, closing at 164.38 points, with a turnover of NT$4.04 billion.
The TAIEX Capitalization Weighted Stock Index Futures (TAIEX Index Futures) dropped 55 points to close at 7,275, with 3,600 contract transactions.
TAIEX Index Futures for May fell 50 points to close at 7,310, with 721 contract transactions, while those for June slipped 60 points, closing at 7,310, with 54 contract transactions.
September futures decreased 110 points to close at 7,250, and December futures declined 51 points to close at 7,312 points. Contract transactions for the two months totaled 4 and 2, respectively.

Reference levels provided by the Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange for TAIEX Index Futures trading on Monday were 7,330 points for April, 7,360 points for May, 7,370 points for June, 7,260 points for September, and 7,363 points for December.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENTIAL OFFICE TO OPEN FOR PUBLIC ON APRIL 18

TEXT.P: The Presidential Office will be opened to the public April 18 with sixty-two artistic renderings of rabbits on display, sources said Monday.
Huang Kun-huei, secretary general to the president, at a tea party on Monday thanked the creators of the art work for their contribution to the beautification of the Presidential Office.
This year is the Chinese Lunar Year of the Rabbit. Therefore, in addition to a routine exhibition of building art, the 62 life-like rabbits will also be displayed.
This will be the second time this year the Presidential Office has been opened to the public.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAJOR MILITARY EXERCISE SCHEDULED FOR LATE JUNE

TEXT.P: A major military exercise will be held in late June, military sources said on Monday.

Military sources made the remarks after Minister of National Defense Tang Fei, announced in the legislature early in the day that the Hankuang Exercise will be held as scheduled but will not be a large-scale exercise.

Tang, fielding questions from the National Defense Committee of the Legislative Yuan, said that in view of the changing pattern of warfare, the military will reduce the number of large-scale exercises in order not to disrupt the lives of the public and to stop the waste of manpower and material.
Military sources said Army General headquarters is now coordinating the Hankuang Exercise.

The sources said the Hankuang Exercise will focus on war games and small-scale live-fire drills for the theater command posts, adding that the scale, mobilized military personnel and ranking officials participating will be smaller than in past years.
The reason behind the scaled-down exercise is to avoid disrupting the lives of civilians and to ease political and military tensions across the Taiwan Strait.

The military sources ignored a question on whether the timing of late June was chosen in consideration of the autumn visit to Taiwan of mainland's top negotiator Wang Daohan, saying only that the exercise will be held to verify the training of the armed forces.
They said the climate as well as the training progress of military personnel are most suitable for holding the exercise in June, adding that there was no special political consideration.

DOC.HEADLINE: 16 ILLEGAL MAINLAND IMMIGRANTS ARRESTED

TEXT.P: Sixteen illegal mainland Chinese immigrants were seized off the northern Taiwan coast near Yehliu on Monday, maritime police said.
Also arrested were Tung Mu-tsun, skipper of the Suao-based fishing boat Chinshunchi No. 12 and other crew members aboard the ship.
Police said they were tipped off last week that the Chinshunchi planned to take advantage of rough seas in the Taiwan Strait in recent days to smuggle mainland people into Taiwan.
The Keelung maritime police squad then formed a special task force to keep close monitoring of suspicious offshore fishing boat activities.
During a routine patrol around midnight, maritime police found that the Chinshunchi was operating in waters three nautical miles off Yehliu.

Police then boarded the fishing boat for a spot check and discovered 16 stowaways from mainland China's Fujian province. After extensive questioning of Chinshunchi crewmen and mainland stowaways, police found that the failed human smuggling was jointly organized by criminal rings on both sides of the Taiwan Strait.

Police said mainland people intending to sneak into Taiwan were required to pay 13,000-to-20,000 renmingbi (mainland currency) to the mainland human smuggling ring which would then purchased legal "service permits" from mainland China's security offices at a price of 500 renminbi apiece.

When the number of prospective mainland applicants reaches a certain level, the mainland ring would inform its Taiwan partner when and where it would transport the would-be mainland immigrants. Its Taiwan partner would then send a speed boat to carry mainland stowaways from a midpoint in the Taiwan Strait to Taiwan. According to police, the Taiwan smuggling ring could make 5,000-to-6,000 renminbi by smuggling a mainland resident into Taiwan.

Police said this was the first time that they have discovered such corporate-style human smuggling operations. Moreover, all the 16 mainland stowaways were wearing Western-style suits and leather shoes.

The 16 mainlanders have been sent to an illegal mainland immigrants detention center in northern Taiwan and will be repatriated later, while Chinshunchi crewmen have been detained on charges of violating Taiwan's anti-smuggling law.

DOC.HEADLINE: CPC CONSIDERING OVERSEAS NAPHTHA CRACKER PLANT

TEXT.P: The state-owned Chinese Petroleum Corp. (CPC) is studying the feasibility of cooperating with Japanese and Philippine companies to set up a naphtha cracker plant in Bataan, Philippines.

CPC officials noted that the CPC, PNOC Petrochemical Development Corp. (PPDC) of the Philippines, and the Itochu Corp. of Japan, signed a memorandum of understanding (MOU) in 1998 to develop, construct and operate a US$600 million naphtha cracker plant in the Philippines.

CPC officials said that the company is now studying the conditions of the proposed plant, including the middle and down-stream petrochemical plants, land acquisition, environmental protection, transportation, and other related matters.

If the plant is built, PPDC will be in charge of the development of the 530-hectare industrial park in Bataan, CPC will provide the technology for the naphtha cracker and Itochu will handle marketing.
The proposed naphtha cracker will annually produce up to 60,000 metric tons of polymer grade ethylene and about 310,000 metric tons of polymer grade propylene.
The officials said the second naphtha cracker plant in Kaohsiung, southern Taiwan, is now moribund and would not rule out moving the plant's equipment overseas.

DOC.HEADLINE: THAI EDITORIAL TOUGH ON LI PENG VISIT
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 12 (CNA) (By Lilian Wu) (By Kuo Fang-chih)

TEXT.P: Bangkok, April 12 (CNA): On the eve of the arrival of mainland Chinese parliamentary leader Li Peng for a six-day official visit, a Thai media has urged Li to explain the threat the mainland poses to Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) over the Spratly Islands.

The Bangkok Post, a wide-circulation English daily in Thailand, said in an editorial that it is entirely right that communist China be called to account for a number of serious violations of international decency.

"ASEAN continues to try to convince Beijing to renounce force in the Spratly Islands. Five of our neighbors and friends have claims to that confusing archipelago and (mainland) China's threat does not help any solution," it said.
The editorial adds that "The Chinese action in Tibet can charitably be described as merciless."

Reminding its readers that a 10-year effort to cover up the Tiananmen massacre continues and that hundreds of Chinese are in jail simply for attempting to criticize that blood bath, the English newspaper told Thai readers that Li, who will enjoy the Songkran festival in Ching Mai April 13-15, is the author of that shameful butchery.
"Mr. Li's visit to Thailand properly will draw some protests over the Tiananmen slaughter." it says, stressing that Thai citizens have the right to such free speech.
The Bangkok Post also urged Thai Prime Minister Chuan Leekpei, in his forthcoming trip to the Chinese mainland in late April, to encourage a promise of a more security for Thai people.

DOC.HEADLINE: US DOLLAR DIPS TO 45-DAY LOW

TEXT.P: The US dollar slid against the New Taiwan dollar to a 45-day low of NT$33.01 on Monday, shedding NT$0.085.
A total of US$602.5 million changed hands.
Dragged down by the slumping Dow Jones Industrial Average, the greenback opened at NT$33.093, and fluctuated between NT$32.941 and NT$33.093.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIAN ECONOMIC GROWTH PREDICTED TO SLOW
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 12 (CNA) (By Maubo Chang) (By Peter Chen)

TEXT.P: Canberra, April 12 (CNA): Australia's strong economic growth is expected to lose steam later this year as a result of an "investment recession" triggered by the flagging mining industry and a slowdown in spending on curing the millennium bug and the Sydney 2000 Olympic Games, according to a leading research body.
Access Economics warned that economic growth could fall to only 2.5 percent in fiscal 1999-2000, down sharply from its forecast of 4.3 percent for the current year, which ends on June 30.
The Australian Financial Review on Monday quoted JP Morgan-New York as predicting that Australia will be the 24th fastest growing nation during 2000, down from last year's fourth position.

The forecast from Access Economics says the Australian economy will lose steam by the end of this year and early 2000 as a result of a global economic slowdown, a business investment recession and a housing sector that will no longer significantly boosts national demand.

"Consumer spending will keep roaring for at least another six months, boosted by the cocktail of real wages, low interest rates, cheap Asian imports and surging share markets and house prices. And come late 2000, there is the promised land of one of the largest ever personal income tax cuts in Australia," the report says.

"But ... Australia is staring down the barrel of an investment recession. The long boom in mining investment is ending and that will be reinforced next year by an easing of investment spending on the millennium bug and the Olympics," it adds.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI PREPARES FOR NEW ROUND OF WTO TALKS

TEXT.P: Taipei is preparing to participate in the World Trade Organization's (WTO) new round of talks in the autumn, according to officials of the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA).
MOEA officials pointed out Monday that issues concerning agriculture, services, government purchases, investments, trade and environment protection, will be included in the new round of talks.
As to the framework under which the talks will be conducted, there is still difference between the American and European camps, MOEA officials noted.

The Office of the US Trade Representative announced that the WTO's 3rd Ministerial Meeting is scheduled to convene on Nov. 30 in Seattle, Washington, which will be followed by a new round of WTO talks after the Uruguay Round.

Chen Ruey-long, director-general of the Board of Foreign Trade (BOFT) under the MOEA, deemed that although not a member of the WTO, Taipei expects to be allowed in the new round of talks. As of Monday, various departments of the government, including MOEA, and the Council of Agriculture under the Executive Yuan, are actively preparing for the talks, Chen added.

Chen said the European Union favors a multi-lateral framework of negotiation, along with Hong Kong, Israel, Japan, Hungary, Argentina, South Korea, Chile, Iceland, and Australia. Additionally, the EU reached a consensus with Japan recently that the negotiations will be concluded within three years.
However, the US and Canada asserted that the new round of talks should be addressed according to categories, pointed out Chen.
Most WTO members supported suggestions that each accord reached under the WTO, should be handled as the top priorities of the next round of talks.

In light of the fact that the new round of talks will be critical to Taipei's entry into the WTO and a further opening of markets, government authorities attached extreme importance to the autumn meeting.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA SEEN BENEFITING FROM US-PRC PACT
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 12 (CNA) (By Eva Chen) (By Peter Chen)

TEXT.P: Canberra, April 12 (CNA): Australia is expected to reap major gains from the market-opening package signed by mainland Chinese Premier Zhu Rongji and U.S. President Bill Clinton on Sunday, trade officials said.

The Australian Review said the package represents a breakthrough for the mainland's 13-year efforts to join the World trade Organization (WTO) and is a major victory for Chinese reformers, including Zhu.
The daily reported experts in the US, Australia and Belgium predict mainland China will join the WTO in late 1999.

Under the package, mainland China promised to lower trade barriers to farm, manufactured goods, and offer improved access for service industry providers, including the telecommunications, insurance, banking, legal and accounting sectors.

Beijing will reduce its average tariff on agricultural products, beef, citrus and grapes, and increase its quotas on a range of bulk commodities of interest to Australian exporters, including wheat, rice and cotton.
Mainland China also promised to reduce import tariffs on cheese, wine, automobile parts and computers.
All import tariffs reductions will be substantial, the daily reported. However, access to wool, sugar and canola remains excluded in mainland China's market opening package.
Australia's Trade Minister Tim Fischer is scheduled to visit mainland China next month to negotiate with his Chinese counterpart market openings for those products.

DOC.HEADLINE: OUTBOUND TRAVELERS REGISTER 1ST DECLINE IN 12 YEARS

TEXT.P: The number of ROC nationals making overseas trips registered the first decline in 12 years in 1998, according to statistics released by the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) on Monday.
The Cabinet-level agency said ROC nationals made a total of 5.91 million overseas visits in 1998, down 4.1 percent from 1997. It was the first negative growth since 1987, the agency said.
ROC travelers to all major tourist destinations dropped last year except Europe. The number of ROC visitors to Europe increased 4.5 percent in 1998 as compared with the year-earlier level.

DGBAS officials attributed the rare travel decline to a combination of factors, including a general domestic economic slowdown, the depreciation of the New Taiwan dollar against major foreign currencies, and the implementation of a bi-weekly five-day work week system which results in a reduction in long holidays.
DGBAS tallies showed that sightseeing remained the main purpose of local people's overseas trips, accounting for 80 percent of total overseas visits.

Meanwhile, Asia remained the top travel destination, accounting for 4.47 million overseas visits or 75.6 percent of the total. Nevertheless, the ratio of Asia-bound visits to overall overseas trips fell 14.8 percent from 1991's 90.4 percent.
With Taiwan's per capita national income and the number of flights to Europe and North and South America increasing steadily, ROC visitors to those areas have also risen substantially.
In 1998, Taiwan people made 705,000 visits to North and South America, marking a 1.5-fold growth from the 1991 level.
Europe has emerged as a new favorite travel destination for ROC nationals who made a total of 196,000 visits to European countries in 1998, representing an 8.8-fold increase in seven years' time.

Thanks to geographic proximity, Hong Kong and Macau have replaced Japan as the top overseas travel destinations since 1988. In 1998, Hong Kong and Macau took a 39.3 percent share of total ROC overseas travelers; Japan came in second, with 11.4 percent; the United States ranked third, with 9.8 percent.

The number of Taiwan visitors to South Korea has decreased substantially since the two countries severed diplomatic ties in 1992. In 1998, Taiwan visitors to South Korea accounted for a mere 1.5 percent of total ROC overseas holidaymakers, down from 8.5 percent recorded in 1991.

DOC.HEADLINE: TRADE-PROMOTION DELEGATION TO VISIT EASTERN EUROPE AND MACEDONIA

TEXT.P: A trade-promotion delegation, organized by the China External Trade Development Council (CETRA), will leave to explore the markets in eastern Europe in May, said CETRA officials on Monday.

The delegation, comprised of representatives from 65 firms, will be lead by CETRA Secretary General Ricky Y. S. Kao beginning on May 15. The team will conduct fact finding missions in Romania, the Czech Republic, Poland, Hungary, and Russia.
Representatives from seven of the 65 firms will continue on to Taiwan's new European ally, Macedonia, to explore trade opportunities there, said CETRA officials.
The trip is part of Taiwan's efforts to beef up trade ties with the former communist states in Europe and reverse the island's trade deficit with those countries.
While calling on the chambers of commerce of various states the delegation will seek opportunities to promote Taiwan exports, said CETRA officials.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO SET UP FIELD HOSPITAL FOR REFUGEES IN MACEDONIA

TEXT.P: Republic of China Vice Foreign Minister David Lee said on Monday that a humanitarian delegation from Taiwan will establish a field hospital and distribute relief materials for refugees in Macedonia.
The delegation, headed by Lee himself, was scheduled to leave Chiang Kai-shek International Airport at midnight on Monday aboard a China Airlines charter flight.

The delegation consists of 91 members, including government officials, representatives from charity groups, 26 medical personnel from the Lu Chu Medical Group, six legislators, 18 reporters and 10 physicians and engineers from the Defense Ministry.
Peter Cheng, the ROC ambassador to Macedonia, was also scheduled to go with the delegation to assume his duties in Skopje.

The relief materials, worth US$2 million and weighing about 12 tons, include medicines, medical appliances, sleeping bags, blankets, and clothing. In addition, the ROC has also ordered ambulances, trucks and jeeps from neighboring countries.

Lee told reporters that about 150,000 refugees have already fled into Macedonia from neighboring Kosovo Province in Yugoslavia, posing a heavy burden, which is why the ROC government decided to organize its "humanitarian mission."
The ROC established diplomatic relations with Macedonia last January.
According to Lee, the ROC delegation will set up a field hospital at a refugee camp, with the 26 Taiwan medical personnel providing first-aid services to the refugees for two weeks or more.
Lee said the Defense Ministry personnel are medical and engineering personnel engaged in a peaceful and humanitarian mission, and are not combat personnel.
The rest of the delegation is scheduled to leave Macedonia on April 15.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT LEE MEETS WITH MAGAZINE SYMPOSIUM SPEAKERS

TEXT.P: Taiwan's people enjoy complete speech and media freedom, which combined with the island's information development, make an important international magazine market, said President Lee on Monday.
Lee made the remarks while meeting with a group of foreign delegate to the 1999 Taipei International Magazine Symposium.

The symposium is the first international magazine symposium hosted by Taiwan's magazine industry in 50 years, and this year's subject is the changes and new opportunities for the magazine market in the 21st century.

Lee said Taiwan hosted this year's meeting in order to understand the international magazine market and to profit from the experience of renowned magazine editors and managers in the run-up to the 21st century's age of information.

Lee pointed out that Taiwan is a free and democratic country, which has contributed to the well-rounded development of its media and offers a diversified choice of magazines. The local magazine market is very competitive, but in a market-oriented industry, the future of magazines will be decided by market force, Lee said.

The ROC government has plans to develop Taiwan into an Asian-Pacific media center since it possess a vast Mandarin-language market, Lee said, adding that the plan's foundation lies in the country's flourishing media environment and its information technology.

Present at the meeting included American Magazine Association chairman Donald D. Kummerfeld; Roger Black, chairman of the Roger Black group; Asian Weekly president Jack Maisano; Dieter Filip, president of market analysis for Germany's Burda magazine group; and Reader's Digest Chinese-version editor-in-chief Feng Chiang.

Accompanying Lee at the meeting were Taipei Magazine Association chairman Chien Chih-hsin, the cabinet-level Government Information Office Deputy Director General, Chang Ping-nan, Presidential Senior Adviser Ding Mou-shih and Presidential Deputy Secretary-General Lin Bih-jaw.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC CALLS FOR CROSS-BORDER COOPERATION TO PROTECT GREEN TURTLES

TEXT.P: An international seminar on conservation of green turtles opened in Taipei on Monday to discuss cross-border cooperative projects to protect the endangered species.
Oceanographers and experts in marine ecology from the United States, Japan, the Philippines, mainland China, Hong Kong, Malaysia and the host Republic of China took part in the meeting.

Professor Chen I-chun of National Taiwan Ocean University said at the opening session that the green turtles which traditionally arrive on Wangan Island in Taiwan's offshore Penghu County to breed travel over a very wide area.

"Satellite tracking shows that green turtles usually migrate to the continental shelf off mainland China's eastern coast after laying their eggs on Wangan Island," Chen said, adding that the green turtles' migratory routes spans from Japan in the north to the South China Sea in the south.

Giving a brief introduction to the habits and life-cycle of the green turtle, He noted that of the thousands of hatchlings which emerge each year from buried nests on Wangan Island, only a tiny percentage reach maturity and return to lay their own eggs and repeat the cycle. Apart from coming ashore to breed, the turtles spend their entire lives at sea.
As they must surface to breathe, and can only swim at speeds of one or two kilometers per hour, Chen said the animals are easy prey for unscrupulous fishermen.
Noting that green turtles are a common natural asset of all East Asian countries, Chen said cross-border cooperation among the countries in the region is needed to conserve the rare species.

To this end, the ROC has designated Wangan Island as a green turtle refuge and breeding ground for nesting green turtles. Wangan Island is one of the world's few green turtle habitats that remains largely untouched by human intrusion.

The Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture has also commissioned National Taiwan Ocean University to conduct a long-term study on the green turtle, and the university has been tracking the turtles' using satellite technology since 1994.

DOC.HEADLINE: ALCOHOLISM LINKED TO BULIMIA

TEXT.P: Canberra, April 12 (CNA): Australian researchers have discovered a link between women suffering from bulimia and alcoholism.
Dr. Petra Staigar of the Deakin University in Western Australia, found that about 40 percent of women with drinking problems also suffer bulimic symptoms.
Staigar and her colleague discovered the link following a study in 1997 involving 265 women aged between 16 and 40 from Melbourne and Brisbane.
She said most respondents had not recognized a link between their alcohol dependency and bulimia.
"Some of these women had bulimia for 15 years and were drinking 15 standard drinks a day," she said.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA WILL BENEFIT FROM US-MAINLAND TRADE AGREEMENT

TEXT.P: Canberra, April 12 (CNA): Deputy Prime Minister Tim Fischer on Monday welcomed a trade breakthrough between the United States and mainland China, predicting Australian exporters will benefit.

In a news release faxed to the CNA on Monday, Fischer, who also serves as trade minister, said, "This is good news both for Australian exporters and the world trading regime. "The deal moves mainland China a step closer to joining the World Trade Organization, which if it proceeds, will see the concessions reached in bilateral negotiations being made available to other countries worldwide, including Australia," he said.

"Australia has consistently been very supportive of the mainland's entry into the WTO on commercially meaningful terms. China's membership would unlock large additional trade opportunities for Australia," he said.

He stressed however that a final outcome on mainland China's accession to the WTO "will depend on full agreement being reached with all of China's WTO partners." "These new Chinese offers are of great potential value to Australian exporters and point the way to acceptable outcomes for the unresolved trade issues of importance to Australia, which include access for sugar and wool," Fischer said.

"I will pursue these outstanding issues when I visit China next month," he added. Fischer said the trade deal would improve market access for Australian agricultural products in the Chinese market. These include wheat, rice and cotton.

"China has also offered to reduce its agricultural tariffs dramatically, with most to phase down over 5 years to maximum levels of around 10 percent to 20 percent," he said. "For example, beef and pork tariffs would be reduced to 12 percent, tariffs on apples, pears, grapes, peaches and plums would be reduced to 10 percent, tariffs on citrus to 12 percent, certain cheeses to 12 percent and wine to 20 percent. These arrangements will provide much improved and predictable access to the Chinese market for many key agricultural products," Fischer said.

He said two-thirds of mainland China's industrial tariff cuts would be fully implemented by 2003 with most of the remainder by 2005, down to maximum levels of around 10 percent for most industrial products, including automobile parts.

In addition, he said mainland China has offered to participate in the WTO Information Technology Agreement, which requires the elimination of tariffs on a range of computer and other high-tech products.

"These outcomes will benefit Australian companies involved in insurance, professional services such as legal services and accountancy, engineering, education services, telecommunications and distribution services," Fischer said.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING TO STEP UP ANTI-CORRUPTION EFFORTS: REPORT

TEXT.P: The Sun, a daily newspaper of Hong Kong, reported Monday that Beijing is to target officials in the higher echelons of government organizations for anti-corruption investigation in the next two years.

The report quoted informed sources in Beijing as saying that the decision was made when mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin, Premier Zu Rongji, and Wei Jianxing, secretary of the Central Commission for Discipline Inspection of the Communist Party of China (CPC), met on April 3 with officials from the Ministry of Supervision of the State Council, the Commission for Discipline Inspection of the CPC Central Military Commission, and the Central Commission for Discipline Inspection of the CPC.

Jiang said that the anti-corruption efforts are being offset primarily by resistance from the political, judicial, law, and disciplinary sectors. The problems caused by "leading officials" of these sectors must be solved in "the anti-corruption struggle," he was quoted as saying.

"Leading officials" at the provincial and ministerial levels, and in the law enforcement, procuratorial, judicial, and other related sectors of the government will soon become the targets of investigation in the anti-corruption drive. The officials of mainland China's financial and investment organizations in Hong Kong and other parts of the world will also be targeted, the report said.

In the meeting, Zhu acknowledged that the problem of government corruption is rather serious and said that the central government will spend more money in fighting financial and economic crimes, according to the report.
Beijing has long been criticized by the general public for being able to catch small fry only in the on-going anti-graft campaign, it added.

DOC.HEADLINE: ILLEGAL MIGRANTS BELIEVED PART OF SMUGGLING TRADE

TEXT.P: Canberra, April 12 (CNA): The latest group of illegal migrants landing in New South Wales is possibly part of a people-smuggling racket from mainland China, Immigration Minister Philip Ruddock said on Monday.

Australian police have so far arrested 54 illegal migrants, up from 43 detained last week when the government was alerted on the arrival of boat people, including three Chinese, at the Coffs Harbor in New South Wales.
Police believe more than 60 illegal migrants could have landed.
Ruddock told reporters that it's possible the illegal immigrants were part of a people-smuggling racket from mainland China.

Earlier this year, mainland Chinese authorities allowed a group of Australian police and academics to meet officials from the mainland's southeast coastal provinces to discuss what is assessed to be the largest illegal immigration racket in the world.
Coincidentally, these provinces are also headquarters for much of mainland China's illicit drug trade, according to the Sydney Morning Herald.
In an editorial on Monday, the daily says much of the illicit immigration racket, together with heroin smuggling, appears to originate in mainland China.

The latest group of illegal migrants landed in Australia undetected just like the earlier group of mainland Chinese boat people, who landed in Queensland recently without being detected by the Australian coast guard.
Ruddock believed the arrival of illegal immigrants will be slowed by the government's proposed reforms to limit the access of asylum seekers to judicial review.
He said Australia must have a system that ensures that unlawful arrivals are not able to frustrate and delay their removal, particularly by using endless court actions to do so.
The editorial says Australia should encourage mainland Chinese authorities to clamp down on illegal rackets, identify and punish all operators to help stop the entry of illegal migrants to Australia.
Australian immigration officials said the 54 illegal migrants would be questioned whether they paid an international smuggling syndicate to escape Asia's economic doldrums.
Immigration experts said the illegal migrants also routinely come from Vietnam, Indonesia, and some Eastern European countries. Their main purpose is to seek the good life in Australia, they said.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSSIE POLICE FIND CAPSICUM SPRAY REDUCES VIOLENCE

TEXT.P: Canberra, April 12 (CNA): The use of capsicum spray by Australian police disabling potentially dangerous people has helped reduce violent confrontations with no evident health risks to either police or suspects, according to a 30-month internal review.

A review of incidents in which police used the hand-held aerosol found that when sprayed, 96.7 percent of suspects either gave up or were immediately disabled. However, in at least half the cases, police suffered minor side effects from secondary exposure. After police used capsicum spray on 192 suspects and 35 animals between April 1996 and October 1998, they found none of those sprayed suffered severe allergic reactions.
About 50 percent of those sprayed recovered fully in 30 minutes or less, 79 percent within 45 minutes, with police adding that none suffered any medical complications.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN INVESTIGATING ALLEGED DUMPING BY US DRAM MAKERS

TEXT.P: Taiwan on Monday decided to investigate whether dynamic random access memory (DRAM) chip makers in the United States have dumped their products on the island's market.
The Tariff Committee under the Finance Ministry made the decision after receiving complaints from the Taiwan Semiconductors Industry Association (TSIA) on March 12.

The TSIA said that Taiwan's DRAM market, which accounts for about 14 percent share of the world's DRAM consumption, is open to foreign competition, and pointed out that over 80 percent of locally used DRAMs are imported.
However, it said that local DRAM prices fell 10-fold last year, resulting in some makers going out of business, and others canceling expansion plans.
The association laid the blame on DRAM makers in the United States who have dumped their products on the local market at prices 46 percent below fair market levels.
According to local regulations, the Trade Investigation Committee will primarily determine, within 45 days of being given notice by the Finance Ministry, whether US DRAMs have harmed local products.

If the Trade Investigation Committee comes to a positive conclusion, the Tariff Committee will then conduct a formal investigation into the dumping charges, and if the conclusion is positive, will suggest punitive tariffs on US products. This suggestion will require approval by the Cabinet before it can formally go into effect.

DOC.HEADLINE: LOCAL ENGINEERING AGENCY ALLEGEDLY EXPLOITING WORKERS

TEXT.P: A local engineering company was accused on Monday by an opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) legislator of exploiting its casual workers, a charge denied by company officials.

At a press conference, Legislator Chien Hsi-kai and workers' representatives alleged that the RSEA Engineering Corporation forced casual workers to quit, either by refusing to renew their contracts or by cutting their salaries by 55 percent in exchange for contract renewals.

According to Chien, after more than one thousand contracts were suspended, 80 percent of which were with aboriginal residents, the company then made up the labor shortfall with foreign laborers, at a greatly reduced basic salary. "RSEA benefits foreign laborers at the expense of local workers" Chien alleged.

Workers' Representative Lin Shi-chien alleged that RSEA stopped renewing contracts for workers with the excuse that it was streamlining its operations, and said that the company should compensate the workers with severance pay.

However, RSEA Chief Secretary Chen Ming-chuang, who also attended the press conference, said the former state-run company was still streamlining its operations as part of the privatization process, and added that only around 600 aboriginal residents were under contract with the company. He also denied they had been dismissed, and rejected the demand for severance pay.

According to officials from the Council of Labor Affairs, the annulment of contracts with local workers and replacement with foreign labors violates the Employment Services Act, which guarantees equal job opportunities.
CLA officials said that according to existing labor laws, foreign laborers rather than local workers should be first to go during economic recession.

The officials said further classification was necessary to decide whether the workers fall under the Labor Standards Law's definition of "casual workers," and added that the council also plans to check if RSEA has acted unlawfully by employing foreign laborers.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT REITERATES OPPOSITION TO PLEBISCITE PROPOSAL

TEXT.P: The ruling Kuomintang on Monday reiterated its opposition to a proposal to enact a plebiscite law to pave the way for deciding the country's future through plebiscite.

Hung Yu-ching, executive director of the KMT's Policy Coordination Committee, issued a two-page statement on Monday evening to call for enactment of an initiative and referendum law, rather than the proposed plebiscite law.

As Article 17 of the nation's Constitution stipulates that "The people shall have the right of election, recall, initiative and referendum," he said that there is no need to consider the controversial plebiscite law.

Some Democratic Progressive Party legislators and pro-independence activists have been staging a hunger strike in front of the Legislative Yuan since Saturday to call for enactment of a plebiscite law or for the writing of a plebiscite clause into the Constitution.
If such a law were to be enacted without any restrictions, the island's future, and other major policies, would be decided by plebiscite.

The KMT statement said that, unlike the plebiscite proposal, enacting an initiative and referendum law would be in line with the Constitution, and would not cause unnecessary tension and suspicion from mainland China and the international community.

Meanwhile, a recent survey by the KMT-run Sun Yat-sen Institute for Policy Research and Development indicated that only 30 percent of the citizens of Taiwan support the holding of an unconditional plebiscite.

Fifty-five percent voiced their support for a plebiscite on condition that the issue of the country's formal name, and the issue of self-determination be excluded from the subjects covered by plebiscite.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN EXPORTS TO SOUTH KOREA INCREASE IN FIRST QUARTER

TEXT.P: Taiwan's exports to the rest of Asia increased considerably in the first quarter of 1999, most notably to South Korea, which saw an increase of 51.7 percent, according to statistics released on Monday by the Cabinet-level Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS).
Meanwhile, exports to Japan rose by 14.6 percent, and by 5.7 percent to the five member countries of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations, the statistics show.

The DGBAS said the regional economic turmoil has shown signs of easing since the beginning of this year and this is reflected in recent rallies in bourses and foreign exchange markets across Asia, as well as stronger domestic demand.

In the first quarter of this year, South Korea imported 8.3 percent more than it did in the same period of last year, the DGBAS said, adding that imports in Taiwan, Japan and Singapore also rose significantly, although growth rates remained negative.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC WILL NOT ENGAGE IN ARMS RACE: PREMIER

TEXT.P: Republic of China Premier Vincent Siew said on Monday that if mainland China continues to pose a military threat to Taiwan, the island will consider taking part in a regional security system.

Siew made the remarks during a meeting with a group of Beijing-based German reporters, who came to Taiwan to gain an understanding of Taipei's policy toward the mainland in connection with their coverage of a trip to Beijing by German Chancellor Gerhard Schroeder which is scheduled for next month.

Asked about Taiwan's plans regarding the US-proposed Theater Missile Defense (TMD) system, the premier said that if Taiwan were to participate in the TMD, it would base its decision on the maintenance of regional stability and peace, rather than on the idea of an arms race.
Siew told the German reporters that Taiwan and the mainland share a common cultural and linguistic background, but have developed differing ideologies.

Turning to the economic field, he expressed the hope that after the entry of Taiwan and the mainland into the World Trade Organization, the two sides will contribute to the development of the world economy.
On the development of cross-Taiwan Strait relations, Siew said that Taiwan's door is always open to constructive dialogue in order to promote mutual understanding and to improve mutual trust.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI AND PERTH STRIKE `FRIEND CITY' TIES VIA TV LINK-UP

TEXT.P: Taipei and the Australian city of Perth struck "friend city" ties via a TV link-up on Monday, the first time Taipei has used a TV link-up to conclude such ties.

In a ceremony staged concurrently in Perth and Taipei, Perth Mayor Peter Nattrass said that establishing "Friend City" ties is a necessary step before concluding "Sister City" ties, according to Perth City Council policy.
Thus far, Perth has six sister cities around the world, and two friend cites -- Nanjing in mainland China and Taipei.

Located on the west coast of Australia, Perth is the capital of the state of Western Australia. It is a tourism hub and a mining industry center, with half of its 1.1 million population made up of Asian people.

Meanwhile, Taipei City Mayor Ma Ying-jeou admired Perth's achievements in education, culture, and the economy. He said he hoped the new relationship will facilitate exchanges between the two cities in these areas.
If it eventually gets twinned with Taipei, Perth will be Taipei's 44th sister city.

DOC.HEADLINE: BRAZIL AIRPLANE MAKER MULLING COOPERATION WITH TAIWAN FIRM

TEXT.P: Executives from Brazilian airplane maker Embraer arrived in Taiwan on Monday for a meeting with officials of Taiwan's Aerospace Industrial Development Corp. (AIDC) on possible cooperation in building medium-haul passenger planes.
Three senior managers from Embraer's manufacture, design and cooperation departments will visit their AIDC counterparts and tour the plants of several local airplane component manufacturers.

The decision by the largest airplane manufacturer in Central and South American to weigh the possibility of a joint venture with AIDC comes after extensive lobbying by the Miami Office of Taiwan's China External Trade Development Council (CETRA).
Embraer has suggested producing 400 of its 70-seat ERJ-170s, and 200 of its 90-seat ERJ-190s in Taiwan over a period of 20 years.
With a price tab of US$20 million apiece, such a venture would translate into US$12 billion-worth of output.
Under Embraer's risk-sharing plan, AIDC and its Taiwan partners would take part in the production and design of wings, tails and fuselage, as well as marketing and after-sales service.

According to an assessment by CETRA, cooperation with Embraer would help AIDC carve out a share of the high-potential market for medium-haul aircraft, which would be relatively easy to break in for a newcomer such as AIDC.
Estimating the worldwide need for medium-haul aircraft at 1,650 in the future two decades, Embraer forecast that a venture with AIDC would grab a 30 percent market share.
