DOC.HEADLINE: EVERGREEN MARINE CORP. TO OPEN ANOTHER TURKEY-US BUSINESS
DOC.DATELINE: Ankara, April 12 (CNA) (By Kuo Chuan-hsin and David Hsu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Evergreen Marine Corp. (EMC) will open an additional shipping lane from Turkey to the United States in June, EMC's business agent in Turkey said on Monday.
Gulf Agency Denizcilik A.S., EMC's business agent in Turkey, will be responsible for the operation of the shipping business. It is expected to handle 25,000 containers per year.

Ismet Imdadoglu, deputy chief executive officer of Gulf Agency Denizcilik A.S., told CNA in a telephone interview that in order to achieve the 25,000-container goal, the corporation formed a new branch corporation in Gemlik, a port city in western Turkey.

Founded in 1992, Gulf Agency Denizcilik A.S. handled 20,000 containers last year. After the formation of the new base in Gemlik, the corporation is confident that it can achieve its goal of 25,000 containers.
Based in the southeastern Turkish city of Iskenderun, Gulf Agency Denizcilik A.S. became a business agent for Evergreen Marine Corp. in 1994.
In addition to the container shipping business, Gulf Agency Denizcilik A.S. also ships oil to the Far East, the US and Europe via a separate business.

DOC.HEADLINE: MORE FOREIGN BUYERS AT TAIPEI CYCLE SHOW

TEXT.P: More than 3,400 foreign buyers visited the just concluded Taipei International Cycle Show, the China External Trade Development Council (CETRA) said on Tuesday.

CETRA officials said the number of visitors increased 23 percent, with most buyers coming from Japan, followed by the United States, Hong Kong, Germany and Australia. Japanese buyers increased by 52 percent from last year.

Officials said that the increase in buyers was attributed to the show being the first major international cycle show this year and that foreign buyers are currently interested in Asian cycles. They noted that more than 90 percent of the visitors were managerial-level officials who were authorized to place orders.
The April 8-12 cycle show exhibited products from 584 manufacturers, among them 94 manufacturers were from 25 foreign countries and regions.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Tuesday, April 13, or the 27th day of the second month of the Year of the Rabbit according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1589: Britain launches an expedition of 150 ships and 18,000 men to Portugal.
1732: Frederick North, English prime minister who introduced the Tea Act that led to the "Boston Tea Party," is born. His policies finally led to Britain's loss of America.
1743: Thomas Jefferson, the third president of the United States, is born. He drafted the Declaration of Independence in 1776. His presidency was marked by the purchase of the Louisiana Territory from France in 1803, and the Tripolitan War from 1801 to 1805.
1862: France and Annam (now Vietnam) sign the Treaty of Shanghai, annexing the province of Cochinchina to France.
1898: Prompted by the success of the Meiji Reformation in Japan, Kang Yu-wei initiates a reform movement and submits a report to Emperor Kuang Hsu of the Ching dynasty, requesting government reformation.
1904: In the Russo-Japanese War, a mine sinks the flagship of the Russian fleet at Port Arthur (Lushun) in northeastern China, killing 600.
1919: British troops under the command of Brigadier-General Dyer open fire on some 380 followers of Mohandas K. Gandhi in an incident known as the Amritsar massacre.
1939: Italian dictator Benito Mussolini's forces invade Albania.
1941: Japan and the Soviet Union sign the Soviet-Japanese Neutrality Pact in Moscow.
1945: Allied bombers launch massive bombing raids over Japan, destroying a large part of Tokyo.
1960: The construction of the atomic reactor at National Tsinghua University in Hsinchu, the first of its kinds in Southeast Asia, is completed.
1964: Sidney Poitier wins an Oscar for his performance in Ralph Nelson's "The Lilies of the Field," and becomes the first black actor to receive the award.
1966: Iraq's President Abdul Salam Arif is killed in a helicopter crash.
1978: Communist China and Portugal formally sign a "joint statement" that clears the way for the return of Macao to Beijing on Dec. 20, 1999.
1990: The Soviet Union admits that its secret police was responsible for the 1940 systematic murder of 1,500 Polish army officers at Katyn, Poland.
1988: Hainan Island becomes the 23rd province and the fourth "special economic region" of mainland China under communist rule.
1995: Ukraine agrees to close the Chernobyl nuclear reactor by 2000.
1995: Lang Chin-shan, known as "China's father of photography," dies at the age of 104.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Where there is affection, exertion is made easy; where there is disinterest, instruction will be neglected."

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC APPRECIATES US CONGRESSIONAL SUPPORT

TEXT.P: The Republic of China appreciates and welcomes the US Senate's passage of two pro-Taiwan resolutions, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said on Tuesday.

Chen Ming-cheng, deputy director of the MOFA's Information and Cultural Affairs Department, made the statement after the US Senate on Monday unanimously approved a resolution supporting Taiwan's proper and meaningful participation in the World Health Organization (WHO).

The US Senate also adopted a concurrent resolution urging the Clinton administration to reaffirm its secuirty commitment to Taiwan and to push mainland China to renounce the use of force against Taiwan in connection with the 20th anniversary of the Taiwan Relations Act (TRA), the US law governing exchanges with Taiwan in the absence of official ties.
The WHO-related Resolution No. 26 is binding to the US executive branch while the concurrent resolution is non-binding, which only expresses the Senate's sense.

The Resolution No. 26 also demands the US secretary of state present a report to the Senate Foreign Relations Committee before April 20 detailing how the Clinton administration will help Taiwan participate in WHO activities when the organization holds its annual conference in Geneva in May.

The resolution further requires the secretary of state to brief the Senate Foreign Relations Committee on possible US measures to help Taiwan join major international organizations in accordance with a 1994 US Taiwan policy review.
Commenting on the two resolutions, Chen said the ROC is grateful to the US Senate for its generous support for Taiwan's cause.

Chen echoed the US Senate's call on mainland China to renouce the use of force against Taiwan, saying that the Senate's call complies with the ROC's fundamental national policy of resolving all disputes and problems across the Taiwan Strait by strictly peaceful means.

Chen went on to say that the US White House and Congress have on many occasions urged Beijing authorities to renounce the use of force against Taiwan, while the ROC government has also repeatedly called for peaceful solution to cross-strait issues.
"We earnestly hope that mainland authorities will make positive response to all these appeals," Chen added.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA SEEKING RUSSIAN HELP FOR CARE WORKER

TEXT.P: Canberra, April 13 (CNA): Australia's Foreign Minister Alexander Downer has accused Serbia of making rediculous spying charges against aid workers while the head of the relief agency CARE Australia is in Moscow seeking their release.

Downer on Monday summoned the Yugoslav ambassador to Australia, telling him Canberra was angry with the "preposterous " accusations against Steve Pratt, head of the CARE Australia in Belgrade, spied for NATO.
"The accusations against Mr. Pratt are simply preposterous," Downer told Yugoslav ambassador Dragan Dragojlovic at an urgent meeting in Downer's Canberra office.
Downer insisted Pratt was not a spy and reiterated his demand for his immediate release and fellow worker Peter Wallace, both of them now being detained in an unknow place in Yugoslavia.
After meeting with Downer, Dragojlovic indicated that Pratt and Wallace might not be released until NATO bombings on Yugoslavia stopped.
"I'm sure as soon as NATO stops the bombing it will be much easier to solve this problem," the Yugoslav envoy said.
Pratt was seen on the Yugoslav television confessing that he was spying for NATO. He was expressionless when making the deadpan statement.
"When I came to Yugoslavia, I performed some intelligence tasks in this country, using a cover of CARE Australia," Pratt said on the Yugoslav TV.
But Pratt's wife -- Samira, who is now in Budapest, said, "For God's sake, he's not (a spy) -- he's an aid worker."

Former Australian Prime Minister Malcolm Fraser, now the head of the CARE Australia, the largest relief agency in Australia, has flown to Moscow to seek help from Russian leaders to secure the release of the two aid workers.

Australian Ambassador to Yugoslavia Chris Lamb was due to start talks with officials of the Yugoslav Foreign Ministry in Belgrade, trying to secure the release of both Pratt and Wallace. But it is feared the meetings will be protracted.
Aid workers from Australia and other countries are becoming worried that the spying charge against Pratt could have an impact on their operations.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSSIE PM ORDERS COASTAL SURVEILLANCE PROBE
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 13 (CNA) (By Peter Chen) (By Peter Chen)

TEXT.P: Canberra, April 13 (CNA): Alarmed by an increasing influx of refugees, Australia's Prime Minister John Howard has established a special task force to investigate a new wave of illegal immigration following the detention of another group of 59 boat people in Western Australia on Monday.

The latest group of illegal migrants was the third from Asia, mainly from mainland China, within a period of less than two months. The first group of about 50 people landed near Cairns in Queensland undetected in March and the second group of 54 refugees landed at the Coffs Harbor in New South Wales last week.
The task force will include experts from intelligence, defense, customs and immigration agencies.
The latest group of 59 boat people, who landed at Broome in Western Australia, came from mainland China, according to a preliminary investigation by the Immigration Department.
Their arrival forced Immigration Minister Philip Ruddock to concede that Australia was a target of Chinese "snake heads" who smuggle illegal immigrants internationally.
Meanwhile, the Australian Customs Service intercepted and sank an Indonesian fishing boat off the West Australian coast on Monday after placing 10 suspected illegal immigrants aboard under guard.
Ruddock said people-smuggling rackets by air and sea were "big business."

West Australian Premier Richard Court has ordered a "beefed up" defense presence to help check the possibility of a new wave of illegal migrants from Asia, including mainland China, and other countries.

All boat people will be flown to a Port Hedland detention center in Western Australia where they will be questioned concerning their purpose of coming to Australia before being deported to countries of origin.

DOC.HEADLINE: SIGNING NON-AGGRESSION PACT IS IMPRACTICAL AT PRESENT STAGE: PREMIER

TEXT.P: Whether a non-aggression pact is to be signed across the Taiwan Strait will hinge on whether relations between the two sides become more peaceful and stable, said Premier Vincent Siew on Tuesday.

In light of the fact that Beijing is still unwilling to relinquish the option of using force to reclaim Taiwan, Siew noted, signing a cross-strait non-aggression pact now would be not only impractical but risky.
The premier made the remark when he answered questions at the legislature.

Siew pointed out that Taipei has long desired to develop a peaceful and stable relationship with mainland China. That is why a termination of the Period of National Mobilization for Suppression of the Communist Rebellion was announced by President Lee Teng-hui in 1991, he said, adding that the announcement signified the ROC government's determination not to use force to achieve national reunification.

In response to a legislator's question concerning the establishment of a cross-strait military mechanism based on mutual trust, Siew cited a recent speech by President Lee in which he called for the grounds for mutual trust to be laid. But the Beijing authorities have not responded to the call.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR EDGES UP

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar posted a modest gain against the greenback on the Taipei market Tuesday, climbing NT$0.001 to close at the highest NT$33 in the past 45 days.
The local currency opened at the day's low of 33.005, and had a high of 32.961.
The interbank US dollar trading reached US$505 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: NATO CAN STILL NEGOTIATE WITH MILOSEVIC

TEXT.P: NATO can still negotiate a peace agreement with Yugoslav president Slobodan Milosevic even though he has been branded a war criminal, Canada's Prime Minister Jean Chretien said Monday.
"We want all the criminals that have caused the genocide in Serbia and the neighboring nations to face trials by the international community," Chretien said at the House of Commons.

"In the meantime, the government in Belgrade is the one that is run by Milosevic and that is the government that exists at this moment in that country. If they want to sign a peace agreement, even if it is Milosevic, we should take it and if he's a war criminal he should face the consequences of his actions in an international court," he added.

Chretien said there are no plans at this point to send ground troops into Kosovo to aid displaced ethnic Albanian refugees, despite words to the contrary last week by his defense minister, Art Eggleton.
"There is absolutely no discussion at this time at the ministerial level of sending troops into Kosovo," said Chretien.
"This is not something that is on the table and it's not being considered by the government," he stressed.

NATO began air strikes against Milosevic's nationalist Serb government on March 24, sparking a mass ethnic cleansing of the disputed province of Kosovo. Canada has sent a dozen F-18 fighters to join the allied bombing efforts.

A Globe and Mail/CTV/ANgus Reid poll of 1,000 Canadians from April 8 to 10 shows that six out of ten would support the use of NATO ground troops if that is the only effective way to stop the massacre in Kosovo. Thirty-eight percent of those surveyed opposed sending ground forces under any circumstances.

DOC.HEADLINE: ENTRY INTO WTO DOES NOT NECESSARILY SIGNIFY A WIDE OPEN DOOR: MAC

TEXT.P: Taiwan will not necessarily open its markets widely to mainland China and other member states of the World Trade Organization (WTO) after its entry into the world trade regulatory body, said a ranking government official Tuesday.

Hsu Ke-sheng, vice chairman of the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) under the Executive Yuan, made the remark in view of the expectation that both Taipei and Beijing are likely to become full members of the WTO by the end of this year.

Hsu added that it will not be necessary for Taiwan to lift its ban on the "three links" -- direct mail, transport and trade links across the Taiwan Strait -- after both sides are admitted into the WTO.
After Taiwan's entry, stressed Hsu, Taipei's current "no haste, be patient" policy in terms of Taiwan investment in the mainland would not likely be affected.

It is premature to discuss at present whether Taipei would employ the "exclusion provision" in dealing with mainland China under the WTO framework, the MAC vice chairman said. He added that it will depend on whether the implementation of the provision would have any adverse impact on Taiwan's industries.
According to WTO regulations, a member is allowed to exclude another member from open market access under special conditions.
Generally speaking, Hsu said, no member would invoke the measure, because it would result in exclusions by other members.

DOC.HEADLINE: SALVADORAN VICE PRESIDENT-ELECT ARRIVES IN TAIPEI FOR SIX-DAY VISIT

TEXT.P: The Republic of El Salvador's vice president-elect, Lic Carlos Quintanilla Schmidt, and his wife arrived in Taiwan Monday evening for a six-day visit.
The dignitaries from the Republic of China's Central American ally were greeted by Vice Foreign Minister Francisco H.L. Ou and his wife at Chiang Kai-shek International Airport upon their arrival.
Vice President-elect Schmidt and President-elect Francisco Flores won Salvadoran presidential elections on March 7 and will be inaugurated on June 1. Their term will last until May 31, 2004.
Schmidt received a master's degree in banking development at American University in Washington, D.C., and is a well-known lawyer in his country. He and his wife have two sons.

Schmidt is slated to visit President Lee Teng-hui on Friday. He will meet with Premier Vincent Siew on Wednesday, and Vice President Lien Chan will throw a dinner banquet in his honor Wednesday evening.

Visits to the Taipei World Trade Center, the National Palace Museum and the Tantzu Export Processing Zone in Taichung, southern Taiwan, are also on his itinerary. Schmidt and his wife are scheduled to leave Sunday evening.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER HOPES TO RAISE BUDGET FOR NATIONAL DEFENSE

TEXT.P: Premier Vincent Siew said on Tuesday that he hoped the budget for national defense in the future could be raised to the standard of advanced nations.
Siew, fielding questions at the Legislative Yuan, said the budget for national defense for the next fiscal year, which will begin July 1, 1999, is too low.

He noted that the budget for national defense has accounted for more than 6 percent of the country's gross national product (GNP) in past years. In recent years, however, the level has fallen, he said, adding that next year's defense spending accounts for 2.75 percent of Taiwan's GNP, compared with 3 percent to 3.5 percent in advanced countries.
For the sake of national security, Siew asked that the budget for national defense be raised to a par with advanced nations.
Meanwhile, a spokesman from the Ministry of National Defense said that the army will complete its conversion training by 2001.

Kung Feng-ting said that all armed forces are expected to familiarize themselves with the second-generation weaponry purchased in recent years, adding that the weaponry will come into service in 2001.

In view of the military threat from potential enemies and the likely patterns of future warfare, the army will focus on streamlining the command and control mechanisms of joint operations, as well as on achieving information dominance and stepping up the training and upgrading the combat readiness of the army, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA ASKED TO EXTEND VISAS FOR RIOT VICTIMS

TEXT.P: Canberra, April 13 (CNA): Representatives from Australian academics, migrants from Taiwan, mainland China, Hong Kong, Chinese, Hong Kong and Indonesia have requested the Howard government to extend visas for about 20 Chinese Indonesian women victimized during riots in Jakarta last year.
The group on Monday went to see Immigration Minister Philip Ruddock to make a direct request with a petition statement signed by different Chinese associations in Canberra and Sydney.

In addition, Australian scholars from different universities, including the Australian National University, Melbourne University and Adelaide University, and human rights workers also signed the petition.

They called on the Australian government to give "a priority processing and facilitation of the special protection visa to the Chinese Indonesia rape victims on grounds of hardship so that they can remain in Australia for recovery".
Ruddock on Monday spent about one hour with the representatives in his office in Canberra. He was sympathetic and explained the government policy in regard to the handling of such cases.
The 20 Chinese Indonesian women, who were raped and tortured during the riots in Jakarta and other cities in Indonesia in May 1998, were given a three-month visa in late 1998.
None of the victims disclosed their experience to the media out of fear for their lives and those of relatives still living in Indonesia.

Januar Achmad, who is an Indonesian health official of Chinese origin, now making a doctoral study at the Australian National University, told CNA many migrants from Taiwan, mainland China, Hong Kong and other Asian countries were very sympathetic with the plight of Chinese Indonesian women and jointly signed a petition, which was presented to Ruddock personally so that he could consider extending the three-month visas.
Several associations in Sydney have raised considerable funds to be used for the victims during their stay in Australia.
"A return to Indonesia in the near future would be extremely dangerous for the women concerned," Januar said.
"Australia should not compound this feeling of insecurity by expelling the Chinese Indonesian (women) who have fled to Australia," he added.

He said Chinese Indonesians were targeted by Indonesian gangs for systematic looting, murder, burning of homes and businesses and rape last May. They could face more sufferings during elections for parliamentarians and the Indonesian president in June and August respectively, he added.
In a statement, Sydney Jones of the Asia Division of the Human Rights Watch, said: "I believe ethnic Chinese in Indonesia have a valid fear of persecution in Indonesia."

He said ethnic Chinese are targeted to some extent during any period of social or political unrest in Indonesia. "This has been the case since the Dutch colonial administration. But I have never seen anti-Chinese sentiment as it is today, nor would I have written an affidavit supporting political asylum simply on the grounds of ethnicity," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: US-TAIWAN-PRC RELATIONS COMPLICATED: EXPERT

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Relations Act stipulates that the United States cannot allow Taiwan to be invaded by mainland China, nor can it allow Taiwan's future to be decided solely by Beijing, stressed an American expert on China Monday.

John F. Copper, a professor of international studies at Rhodes College in Tennessee, said that two opposing views of mainland China have caused a cleavage between the executive and legislative branches of the US government, and this divide is the most pressing question facing US foreign policy makers.

One view is that the United States should regard the People's Republic of China as a challenge and a threat to American interests abroad and, consequently, as a present-day or future enemy. The opposing view holds that the United States should regard mainland China as both a friend and the key to the United States' fulfilling its foreign policy objectives and maintaining a peaceful world.

The United States faces a dilemma over Taiwan, Copper said. The United States supports democracy around the world, and this is a central tenet of American foreign policy. The United States was to a considerable degree responsible for Taiwan's becoming a democracy, he said. As a result of Taiwan's democratization, its people and government feel they are entitled to decide the country's future, and most observers agree, Copper said.

But this contradicts America's "one China" policy and better Washington-Beijing relations. This dilemma accounts for the difficult triangle between Washington and the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, added the professor.

The Tiananmen massacre in 1989 and the Taiwan Strait missile crisis in 1996 have dramatically changed the US-Taiwan-PRC relationship, with Taiwan's democratization exacerbating both crises, said Copper. But Washington still views mainland China as important because it is a big power that cannot be contained.

Looking to the future, Copper said, the United States cannot allow Taiwan to be invaded and its future determined by Beijing without the agreement of the Taiwan people. Taiwan has followed the model of American democracy, and it cannot be abandoned if America wants to remain a world leader or a nation with credibility in East Asia, he said.

Although the Taiwan Relations Act is open to interpretation, it does seem to oblige the United States to protect Taiwan from attacks against it by force. Even if it does not, he added, Congress would likely interpret the act this way in the event Taiwan is threatened.

On the other hand, Copper said, Washington can agree to Taiwan's forging links with mainland China, even permanent political ones. The United States would also be willing to guarantee that Taiwan does not come under the control of Japan or any other nation.

Moreover, it can -- and will -- "warn advocates of Taiwan independence and perhaps even prevent them from coming to power by declaring that its security guarantees do not apply if the present or any future government declares Taiwan independent," he said.

All of this seems to suggest that the three players in the "China triangle" espouse positions that are not negotiable. Yet all three can also make concessions and can probably overcome at least some of their differences, Copper pointed out.

"Talks should emphasize areas of agreement. In addition, the three players need to be patient and seek results over a fairly long period of time rather than quickly. The alternative to success is not one to ponder easily," he said.

Professor Copper was invited by the World Affairs Council in Dallas, Southern Methodist University and the World Affairs Council in San Antonio to speak about US relations with both sides of the Taiwan Strait.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC UNDECIDED ON ANTI-DUMPING TARIFFS FOR US DRAM MAKERS

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Finance (MOF) has not yet decided whether to levy anti-dumping tariffs on imported US dynamic random access memory (DRAM) chips, MOF Vice Minister Yen Ching-chang said Tuesday.

The Tariff Committee under the MOF has decided to investigate whether DRAM makers in the United States have dumped their products in Taiwan after receiving complaints from the Taiwan Semiconductor Industry Association (TSIA) on March 12.

Under the ministry's procedures, the MOF will send official documents on the case to the Trade Investigation Committee under the Ministry of Economic Affairs. The committee will then start a 45-day initial investigation into what damage may have been incurred by Taiwan's domestic DRAM industry.

A working group of the Trade Investigation Committee is slated to hold its first meeting on April 16. In the initial investigation the group will conduct interviews and hold public hearing to collect data.
The group will submit a report to the Trade Investigation Committee, which will rule on whether US DRAM chips have hurt Taiwan's semiconductor industry.

If the committee rules no damage has been done, the matter will be dropped. If the committee rules that Taiwan DRAM makers have been hurt, it will send its report to the MOF for a two-stage investigation. The first stage of that investigation will last 75 days and the second, 60 days.
During that investigation the MOF would decide whether to impose tentative anti-dumping tariffs.

If the MOF finds that US DRAM chips have been dumped in the island's market, it would send official documents to the Trade Investigation Committee under the Ministry of Economic Affairs and let the committee proceed with a final investigation into what damage had been incurred by Taiwan's semiconductor industry.

The committee would then make a final determination as to whether US DRAM chips had indeed caused harm to Taiwan's manufacturers. If it decides harm had been caused, the MOF would make within 10 days a determination of whether to levy anti-dumping tariffs. Cabinet approval would be required, though, before the tariffs could go into effect.

DOC.HEADLINE: TWO RANKING ROC OFFICIALS LEAVE FOR US VISIT

TEXT.P: Two ranking Republic of China officials set off Tuesday for Washington to attend activities marking the 20th anniversary of the enactment of the United States' Taiwan Relations Act (TRA).

Control Yuan President Fredrick Chien, as well as Chen Chien-jen, director-general of the Government Information Office, are scheduled to arrive in Washington Wednesday. There they will attend a series of TRA-related conferences and meetings jointly sponsored by the Heritage Foundation and the American Enterprise Institution, Chen said prior to his departure.

During Wednesday's activities the two ROC officials will deliver a report on the TRA's influence and function in the maintenance of stability in the Taiwan Strait area, Chen said. Both men will also deliver speeches on the state of cross-strait relations.

Chien, who has formerly served as ROC foreign minister and as representative to the United States, will also visit with officials from various think tanks and with friends in the United States, some of whom are understood to be congressmen or members of the US government.

Chen will appear on several radio programs during his US visit, he said. He will head to Chicago Friday to deliver a speech at the University of Chicago on such issues as ROC-US relations, the TRA and cross-strait ties. He will return home April 20, while Chien will return April 23.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S FIRST TEST-TUBE BABY TURNS 14

TEXT.P: Taiwan's first and also Asia's oldest test-tube baby will turn 14 on Friday.

The youngster, identified only by his surname of Chang, is now a second-grade student at a Taipei junior high school. Like many other local teenagers, Chang feels great academic pressure and complains about a shortage of time for athletic and recreational activities.
Slim of stature and 162 cm tall, Chang is a gentle, polite and quiet student. He is also diligent, and ranked top of his class last semester.
Interviewed recently, he said that his greatest dream is to become a medical doctor, so that he can "help many other people."
Chang said he discovered he was a test-tube baby when he was seven years old.

"I came to learn of my origin through conversations between my mother and her friends," Chang recalled, adding that he once looked up the term "test-tube baby" in an encyclopedia in order to find out what it means. However, he admitted that he still does not fully know its meaning.
Chang said he has never told any of his classmates that he was born through assisted reproductive technology (ART). "I see no need to talk about that with my classmates," he added.

Chang, whose favorite subjects are English and physical education, and who counts basketball, swimming and cycling as his preferred sports, said that in any case, he does not feel there is any difference between him and his peers.

Chang's mother said that at the time, she had no idea she was to become the mother of Taiwan's first test-tube baby, and added that one year after giving birth to her test-tube baby through Cesarean section, she became pregnant again -- though this time fertilization occurred naturally.

The doctor who successfully used ART to help Chang Shu-hui produce Taiwan's first test-tube baby was Chang Sheng-ping, who is now chief of the reproductive endocrinology division at Veterans General Hospital in suburban Taipei.
Dr. Chang recalled that he was studying reproductive technology in the United States when the first ART baby was delivered in Britain in 1978.
Under his efforts, the Veterans General Hospital formed an ART task force in 1984, which managed to create the island's first ART baby after 41 failed attempts.

Over the past 14 years, Dr. Chang has helped many women suffering from endometriosis and tubal occlusion to deliver babies with various assisted reproductive techniques. A total of 1,300 test-tube babies have been born with Dr. Chang's assistance over the past decade.
Other local hospitals began to experiment with ART five or six years after Veterans General Hospital successfully created its first test-tube baby.

According an estimate by Dr. Soong Yung-kuei, chief of the department of obstetrics and gynecology at Chang Gung Memorial Hospital, more than 10,000 test-tube babies have been born in Taiwan over the past 14 years.

Soong, who concurrently serves as president of the ROC Infertility and Reproductive Endocrinology Society, said with the maturity of ART techniques in Taiwan, about 800 to 1,000 "test-tube" babies are born here annually.

Soong said although progress in ART expertise has helped resolve nearly all infertility problems here, new worries and problems have arisen. "Such worries include the birth of ART children with genetic disorder or diseases, and ethical problems," he noted.

Against this background, Soong said he is working on an ART white paper which will detail evolution of reproductive medicine and its potential risks and problems. The white paper is scheudled to be unveiled at the turn of the century.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCKS, FUTURES RISE

TEXT.P: Taiwan share prices closed 1.3 percent higher Tuesday on strong institutional buying by foreign investors and a firmer local currency.

Market sentiments were bolstered after the index passed the 7,273-point annual moving average. The benchmark Taiwan Stock Exchange Weighted Price Index ballooned 95.45 points to close at 7,337.85 points.
Trade Tuesday saw a volume of 2.89 billion shares worth NT$122.03 billion (US$3.70 billion), compared with NT$127.83 billion in the previous session.
Advancers led decliners 323 to 110, with 67 stocks unchanged.

Among the eight major stock categories, plastic and chemical shares and paper and pulp shares posted the best performance, with both rising 2.5 percent. They were followed by textile stocks, which climbed 2.3 percent.
Electronic shares gained 1.8 percent, construction issues went up 0.9 percent and cement stocks and financial stocks both rose 0.7 percent. The foodstuff sector remained static.
The over-the-counter market saw an increase of 3.04 points, closing at 167.42, with a turnover of NT$5.83 billion.
The TAIEX Capitalization Weighted Stock Index Futures (TAIEX Index Futures) for April advanced 104 points to close at 7,379, with 3,215 contract transactions.
TAIEX Index Futures for May gained 91 points to close at 7,410, with 745 contract transactions, while those for June climbed 90 points to close at 7,400, with 41 contract transactions.
September futures rose 130 points, closing at 7,410, with 7 contract transactions. No transaction records were registered for December.

Reference levels provided by the Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange for TAIEX Index Futures trading on Tuesday were 7,275 points for April; 7,310 points for both May and June; and 7,281 points for both September and December.

DOC.HEADLINE: MILITARY DRILLS, WAR GAMES SCHEDULED FOR MAY AND JUNE: MND

TEXT.P: The Republic of China Armed Forces are scheduled to hold a combat drill in mid-May and a tri-forces military exercise in late June to test its combat preparedness and maintain its fighting edge, a spokesman for the Ministry of National Defense (MND) said on Tuesday.
The drill, code named "Chengkung," will be held on the offshore island of Penghu in mid-May to examine the combat capability of the newly created "integrated tank brigade," said the spokesman.
Only about 550 army personnel will take part in the "Chengkung" drill, which will feature 12 M60A3 tanks, tank support troops, and various light artillery, including 105 mm cannons.
The drill, which is scheduled to last for about 20 minutes, will only be a small-scale test drill, rather than a full display of weaponry, the spokesman said.

He noted that Penghu was chosen as the location of the drill because of the island group's strategic importance, and the fact that the region is judged by the MND as one of the most likely landing sites in the event of an invasion by mainland Chinese troops.

The spokesman also stressed that in order to preserve the area's unique environment, blank cartridges rather than live ammunition will be used, while the drill will not involve protected areas where coral reefs, manmade reefs and seashell beaches are located.
In regard to the tri-forces war game slated for late June, the spokesman said the "Hankuang No. 15" exercise, an annual event, will focus on small-scale live-fire drills for theater command posts.

The exercise, aimed at testing the defensive capabilities of Taiwan and Penghu, will also be joined by a newly-created integrated brigade from Kinmen, an ROC-held frontline post located near mainland China's coastal province of Fujian, the spokesman said.

Unlike previous "Hankuang" exercises, this year's event will be small-scale, partly because of the changing patterns of warfare, partly to avoid disrupting the lives of civilians living in the area, and partly to ease political and military tension across the Taiwan Strait, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNET FAIR PRESENTS NEW NET CONTENT

TEXT.P: An internet fair opened on Tuesday at the Taipei Convention Center to introduce new Internet content and applications to the island's web surfers.

The four-day fair, titled "Net '99 Internet Content and Life Expo," is being sponsored by Chinese Open System Association (COSA) with the aim of widening net users' applications from mere e-mailing or information-collecting to a broad range of functions such as long-distance conferencing, electronic business, and net banking.
COSA chairman Chang Shan-chen said Internet applications are becoming more and more popular, and the relationship between people and the Internet is getting closer and closer.

However, the most common problem of Internet transmission -- congestion caused by insufficient bandwidth -- is preventing users from working efficiently, which is why the fair is promoting the newest broadband Internet system as a solution to the problem, Chang said.

The new system uses the cables used for cable television, which can carry much more information than the telephone wires used at present, and make the speed of transmission 100 times faster. For this reason, Chang said, several companies in the industry are promoting broadband transmission via TV cable.

Although the broadband system is not widely used, either in Taiwan or the rest of the world, the high number of local cable TV subscribers will enable Taiwan to adapt to this new system without needing to purchase additional facilities required for broadband transmission, Chang noted.
Apart from the variety of Internet applications, COSA also hopes attention can be drawn to the issues of privacy on the net, net crime, net piracy, and regulations to govern the Internet.

In related news, the results of a survey conducted by the Ministry of Transportation and Communications released on Tuesday show that most of Taiwan's Internet users are not content with the limited services and content of government web sites.

The survey indicated that half of Taiwan's 4 million web surfers have visited government web sites, and many of the survey respondents suggested that the broadband system be adopted to improve the problem of transmission congestion and insufficient content.

DOC.HEADLINE: GIO CHIEF CALLS FOR PROFESSIONALISM IN MAGAZINE INDUSTRY

TEXT.P: Taiwan's magazine publishers should stress professionalism, globalization and digitalization in order to cope with the industry's general international trends, a senior official said on Tuesday.

Chen Chien-jen, director-general of the Government Information Office (GIO), made the call in his speech delivered at the opening session of a three-day international conference on the magazine industry, jointly sponsored by the GIO and the Magazine Business Association of Taipei.
Chen said local magazine publishers must adjust their concepts concerning editing, design and management in the face of ever-increasing competition in the industry.
In addition to competition from Internet and other media, Chen said, local magazine publishers also face competition from their foreign counterparts.
The US-based National Geographic magazine, Japan's Kadokawa bookstore and the largest German magazine group Burda have all made inroads into Taiwan's magazine market, Chen said.
Despite increasing competition, Chen said he remains optimistic about Taiwan's magazine industry. For one thing, Chen said Taiwan's magazine readership has continued to grow steadily.

Quoting a recent public survey, Chen said 60 out of every 100 local people aged between 15 and 65 have read magazines every month. Another survey found that local magazines raked up more than NT$5.58 billion (US$169.1 million) in advertisement bills last year, second only to newspapers and television.
"The above figures indicate that there is still ample room for the local magazine industry to grow," Chen noted.

He encouraged local magazine publishers to take advantage of the current meeting to exchange views with foreign media executives and expand their visions in order to upgrade the quality of their magazines.
"The government is determined to join forces with local magazine publishers to develop Taiwan into a Chinese-language magazine marketing center in Asia," Chen added.

The ongoing meeting is the first of its kind since the country's Publishing Law was phased out early this year. The conference is also the largest in scale ever hosted by Taiwan's magazine industry in 50 years.
Eleven noted magazine managers and editors from Japan, the United States, Germany and France have been invited to speak on magazine marketing, designing, advertising, editing and Internet services.
The foreign guest speakers include Donald D. Kummerfeld, chairman of the American Magazine Association; Roger Black, chairman of the Roger Black Group; and Asian Weekly President Jack Maisano.
A total of 342 local magazine publishers, editors and managers are taking part in the discussion.

Speaking on the same occasion, C. S. Chien, president of the Magazine Business Association of Taipei, said he is optimistic about the prospects of the island's magazine industry as Chinese readers make up a quarter of the 6 billion world population.
Attracted by the vast potential Chinese readership, many foreign magazine groups have launched Chinese magazines in Taiwan and mainland China in recent years, Chien said.
There are more than 5,800 magazines in Taiwan currently, and over 450 of them are available on the market, forming the highest density in the world, Chien added.
In connection with the meeting, an exhibition of more than 700 periodicals, including 300 domestic and 400 foreign ones, is being held in Taipei.

DOC.HEADLINE: OUTPATIENT VISITS AVERAGED 15 PER PERSON IN 1998: BNHI

TEXT.P: Statistics released by the Bureau of National Health Insurance (BNHI) on Tuesday reveal that each person in Taiwan made an average of 15 visits to hospital outpatient departments in 1998.

The statistics also show that twelve people out of every hundred were hospitalized last year, far outnumbering American and European statistics, and pushing up National Health Insurance (NHI) expenditure every year.

The tallies show that 79.9 percent of the high treatment patients were ordinary patients, 8.9 percent were senior citizens over the age of 65, 7 percent were infants under the age of four, and seriously ill/injured patients accounted for just 4.2 percent.

The BNHI said that many cases of abuse of the national health insurance system were discovered in 1998, including the exchanging of NHI cards for "other bonuses" at medical institutions, and medical institutions claiming reimbursement for non-existent hospitalizations and treatments.

To ensure the financial integrity and sustainable development of the NHI system, the BNHI said it will improve the medical reimbursement system, strengthen the analysis and examination of medical records, and provide evaluation and guidance for questionable medical institutions and patients.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO PUNITIVE TARIFFS FOR SPAIN, ITALY, SOUTH AFRICA: MOF

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Finance (MOF) has decided not to levy punitive anti-dumping taxes on Spain, Italy or South Africa for steel bearings imported from those countries, MOF officials said on Tuesday.

The MOF said after investigating allegations of dumping at the request of one Taiwan firm that although the quantity and price of the bearings from the three countries did represent dumping, the action did not cause serious damage to local industries, so no punitive action would be taken.

The MOF is also investigating allegations by Taiwan Steel and Iron Industries Association that Brazil, Russia and Ukraine have dumped steel plate, while the Taiwan Semiconductor Industry Association has urged the MOF to levy anti-dumping taxes on US semiconductor firms accused of dumping their products on the domestic market.

DOC.HEADLINE: US POLITICAL ANALYSTS DISPUTE BEIJING PREMIER'S ANALOGY
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, April 12 (CNA) (By Jay Chen & Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: Former US ambassador to Beijing James Lilley described as "absurd and skin-deep" the analogy made by Beijing's Premier Zhu Rongji between the mainland China-Taiwan conflict and the American Civil War.
Lilley said Zhu's argument that Beijing will follow US President Abraham Lincoln's suit and will go to great lengths, even to war, to keep the nation united, will not sell to the American public.
Beijing's idea of using force to keep Taiwan from splitting is "terrible," he said.
While there were 600,000 soldiers killed in the American Civil War between 1861 and 1865, a similar war nowadays could claim the lives of more than 50 million, said Lilley.
The heavy fatalities a civil war would entail today underlines what a terrible idea it is of Beijing to resort to force to head off Taiwan's schism, said Lilley.
He expressed regret that President Bill Clinton failed to mention this when Zhu made the remarks in his presence at a joint press conference at the White House last Thursday.
Ralph Clough, a Chinese affairs expert at the Johns Hopkins University, also blasted Zhu's remarks as inappropriate.

While Beijing claims that it is taking its cue from Lincoln by threatening force against Taiwan, Clough said that some people in Taiwan are trying to justify their campaign for Taiwan independence by likening themselves to activists during the American revolution.
Clough expressed reservation about both claims, saying that the vast differences in the historical backgrounds would nullify any attempt to draw support from history.
In particular, he said, the American Civil War was triggered by the moral dispute over the abolishment of slavery, while there is no similar element in the conflict between Beijing and Taipei.

Admitting that the analogies of Zhu and the Taiwan separatists might lead the American people to think seriously about territorial integrity and people's right to self-determination, Clough said they will not change the situation dramatically, despite the conflicting influence they could exercise on US public opinion.

DOC.HEADLINE: SENIOR JOURNALIST PAN HUAN-KUN DIES

TEXT.P: Taiwan's National Press Council (NPC) announced on Tuesday that a funeral will be held on May 9 for Pan Huan-kun, formerly one of the island's most influential and foremost journalists.
Pan died on Sunday of pneumonia at the age of 83 at the Veterans General Hospital, Taipei. He had been bedridden since 1997 with diabetes, high blood pressure and Parkinson's disease.
His weakened state had lowered his immunity from infection, making him easy prey for the pneumonia that killed him, his daughter said.
During his long career, Pan had served as NPC chairman, president of the Central News Agency and president of the Central Daily News.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRIME MINISTER REITERATES POSSIBILITY OF JOINING TMD

TEXT.P: Premier Vincent Siew on Tuesday reiterated that Taiwan will not rule out the possibility of joining the Theater Missile Defense (TMD) system proposed by the United States.

"But this cannot be decided unilaterally by ourselves, nor will our decision on this issue be affected by the opposition of mainland China," Siew said while fielding questions at the Legislative Yuan.
He pointed out that Taiwan is studying the issues, and will need to take into account various factors, including defense needs, the financial burden, and the risk involved.
He said that mainland China's military buildup, which poses a great threat to the security of Taiwan, is the main reason for Taiwan to consider joining the TMD.
Therefore, Beijing's military development, and whether or not it will exercise restraint, are two of the most important factors that will govern Taiwan's eventual decision.
Before reaching such a decision, Siew added, the nation's military will also give priority to establishing an effective and independent air defense capability.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC HUMANITARIAN MISSION STUCK IN ABU DHABI EN ROUTE TO MACEDONIA

TEXT.P: A Republic of China humanitarian aid mission en route to Macedonia had been stuck at the airport of the capital of the United Arab Emirates for more than 20 hours as of Tuesday owing to bad weather conditions.

After intensive negotiations with NATO headquarters and the United Nations, which are now in charge of Macedonia's air traffic, the Taiwan mission was finally given permission to leave for Macedonia early on Wednesday.

The mission, comprised of representatives and medical personnel from Taiwan's 17 philanthropic organizations, six legislators, 10 military doctors and engineering corpsmen, and 18 reporters, is scheduled to arrive in the Macedonian capital of Skopje at around 5 p.m. on Wednesday.
The mission is bringing with it some US$2 million-worth of relief goods, including sleeping-bags, blankets, sweaters, medicine and medical equipment.

To beef up the relief to Macedonia, centered mainly on efforts to assist Skopje in handling the flood of refugees from the neighboring Yugoslavian province of Kosovo, which currently numbers around 120,000 so far, Taiwan has also purchased ambulances, jeeps and trucks from other countries in the region.

Vasil Tupurkovski, the head of Macedonia's reconstruction organization whose Democratic Alternative Party holds the foreign affairs, finance and interior ministries in a coalition government, will receive the ROC relief aid on behalf of Macedonia at a brief ceremony at the airport, said Vice Foreign Minister David Lee, who is leading the group.

Later on Wednesday, the group will formally meet with Tupurkovski, who spearheaded the campaign to establish formal relations with Taiwan and is a front-runner in Macedonia's presidential election slated for later this year, Lee said.
The 26-strong medical personnel team traveling with the aid group is planning to establish a field hospital, probably in the Radusa camp, for at least two weeks and possibly longer.

The field hospital, to be equipped with an operating theater, two sets of dentistry equipment, and 20 sets of surgical equipment, together with some US$300,000-worth of medicine, is expected to provide treatment for 400 to 500 people daily, according to Liu Chi-chun, a medical doctor and chairman of the Taiwan Luchu Association, which routinely provides free medical care to residents living in rural or mountainous areas of Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: STILL ROOM FOR NT DOLLAR APPRECIATION: ECONOMICS OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: An economics official said on Tuesday that appreciation of the new Taiwan dollar is expected in the near future, contributed by expanded foreign trade surpluses in the first quarter and an increasing inflow of overseas funds.

However, K.C. Lee, vice chairman of the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD), said he would prefer a gradual growth of the local unit's value against the greenback so that local exporters will not sustain an intolerable impact.
The NT dollar broke through the 33 barrier on Tuesday, reaching its highest level in the past 45 days.

In the first three months of this year, Taiwan's exports posted a 3.5 percent growth compared with the year-earlier level, bringing its trade surplus to a level in excess of US$2.67 billion, according to Lee.

Meanwhile, prompted by optimistic sentiment in international stock markets, the government's financial reforms, and surging exports, trading in the local stock market has seen 14.3 percent growth since the end of last year, according to statistics of the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS).
As of the end of March, the total value of listed stocks amounted to NT$9.3 trillion (US$281.82 billion), up 11 percent from the level at the beginning of this year.

The average daily turnover expanded to NT$95.6 billion (US$2.9 billion) in March from January's NT$67.1 billion, while that of the first 13 days of April reached NT$116.3 billion, the statistics show.

DOC.HEADLINE: HIGH-PROFILE VIETNAMESE GROUP VISITS TO PROMOTE BUSINESS TIE-UP

TEXT.P: A visiting high-profile Vietnamese business delegation called on Tuesday at the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) for talks on efforts to cement closer business and trade ties between Vietnam and Taiwan.

The delegation, headed by former Deputy Prime Minister Doan Duy Thanh, met with Vice Economic Affairs Minister Lin Yi-fu and expressed the group's principal desire that Taiwan businesses will expand investment in Vietnam to help it develop its agricultural production and processing industries.

In addition to Doan, who is currently chairman of Vietnam's Chamber of Commerce and Industry, other members of the delegation include Dao Duc Chinh, secretary-general of Vietnam's Taiwan Affairs Working Committee, Ha Tri Thuc, governor of Vietnam's Ninh Binh Province, and other officials in charge of business and industrial development.

Two-way trade between Taiwan and Vietnam has increased by leaps and bounds over the last several years -- from US$118 million in 1990 to US$1.688 billion in 1997, with Taiwan usually enjoying a trade surplus with the Southeast Asian country, according to MOEA tallies.

Taiwan now ranks as the second-largest source of Vietnam's foreign capital of Vietnam, but most of the capital equipment and raw materials used in Taiwan investments in Vietnam are imported from Taiwan, said MOEA officials.

DOC.HEADLINE: US CONGRESS URGED TO STICK TO SPIRIT OF TRA
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, April 13 (CNA) (By Jay Chen & Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: Two political analysts in the United States called on the US Congress to stick to the spirit woven throughout the Taiwan Relations Act (TRA) to ensure Taiwan's continued existence in peace and prosperity.

In a letter carried in Tuesday's edition of the Washington Times, Christopher DeMuth, president of the American Enterprise Institute for Public Policy Research, and Edwin J. Feulner Jr., president of the Heritage Foundation, said that the political transition of the last two decades would not have taken place in Taiwan without the safety brought to the island by the guarantee provided by the TRA.

In a letter to mark the 20th anniversary of the TRA which was enacted on April 10, 1979, Demuth and Feulner said that US support for Taiwan in the last two decades has driven the island to change dramatically. Notably, the liberty has spread from the market to the ballot box, and has made the island the best and proudest example of free market and democracy in Asia.

The recent actions of President Bill Clinton's administration, however, have cast doubt on Washington's commitment to Taiwan under the TRA, especially the promise made by Clinton to Beijing in 1998 of no support for Taiwan independence, or "one China, one Taiwan," or Taiwan's membership in organizations that require statehood.

Claiming that Clinton's "three noes" deviates from Washington's long-standing policy toward Taiwan, the letter urged Congress to rein in the government by reaffirming Congress' commitment to the island just as it did in 1979 by altering significantly the draft law of the TRA submitted by the administration of then-President Jimmy Carter.

Noting that the 21 million people in Taiwan buy almost twice the amount of American goods purchased by the 1.2 billion people of mainland China, the two authors called the island a real but unappreciated and unrewarding partner of Washington in Asia.
The two analysts urged Washington to substitute its "three noes" with a resounding "yes" toward Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies Wednesday are as follows:
The Central Daily News:
The US Senate adopted two resolutions supporting Taiwan's cause.
The China Times:
The Cabinet approved a draft bill on sweeping amendments to the Civil Code to legalize a separate property system for married couples.
The United Daily News:
Internet phone services will be liberalized in 2001.
The Liberty Times:
The US Senate passed a resolution supporting Taiwan's participation in the World Health Organization.
The Commons Daily:
The US Senate passed two pro-Taiwan resolutions.
The China Post:
The ROC government will act on US dumping as DRAM prices plummet.
The China News:
Beijing is on high alert as key date approaches; mainland officials wary on anniversary of reform leader's death.

DOC.HEADLINE: KAOHSIUNG HARBOR WORLD'S THIRD LARGEST CONTAINERPORT
DOC.DATELINE: Kaohsiung, southern Taiwan, April 14 (CNA) (By Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Kaohsiung Harbor handled 6.27 million 20-foot equivalent units (TEUs) of containers in 1998, making it the world's third-busiest containerport, up from fourth place in 1997, a top government statistics agency reported on Wednesday.
Kaohsiung Harbor currently trails only Hong Kong and Singapore in terms of container handling capacity, said officials from the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS).

Both the harbor's container- and cargo-handling capacities have increased by leaps and bounds since the Republic of China government launched plans in 1997 to make Kaohsiung an offshore transshipment center for Taiwan, DGBAS officials said.

At Kaohsiung Harbor last year, 88 million metric tons of export and import cargo were loaded and unloaded, and the harbor accounted for 57 percent of all the cargo loaded and unloaded in Taiwan's harbors in 1998. Taichung Harbor in central Taiwan was next with 38 million metric tons, followed by Keelung Harbor in northern Taiwan with 23 million metric tons, according to DGBAS tallies.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC REPRESENTATIVE OFFICE IN US THANKS CONGRESS FOR SUPPORTING ROC
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, April 13 (CNA) (By Nelson Chung and David Hsu)

TEXT.P: The Republic of China representative office in the United States on Tuesday extended its thanks to the US Congress for its unanimous passage on Monday of two resolutions in support of Taiwan.

The first resolution passed by the Senate on Monday, Resolution No. 26, supports Taiwan's entry into the World Health Organization (WHO). The US House of Representatives on Oct. 10, 1998, adopted a similar resolution by a 418-0 vote.
The Senate also passed on Monday Joint Resolution No. 17 to commemorate the 20th anniversary of the enactment of the Taiwan Relations Act (TRA).

In the joint resolution, US lawmakers affirmed the TRA's maintenance of various relations between the Republic of China and the United States and reiterated US commitments to Taiwan under the TRA, especially an agreement to provide Taiwan with defensive weapons.

The joint resolution also asks US president Bill Clinton to urge Beijing to renounce the use of force or military threats against Taiwan, and to support Taiwan's joining the World Trade Organization (WTO).
The House of Representatives passed a similar resolution on March 23 by a 429-1 vote.

Amid the commemoration of the 20th anniversary of the enactment of the TRA, the US Senate and House of Representatives unanimously adopted resolutions praising the Republic of China for its development and reiterating US commitments to Taiwan under the TRA.

The Taipei Economic and Cultural Representative Office in the United States thanked the US Congress for the passage of these friendly resolutions toward the Republic of China and said it hopes that bilateral relations will be further strengthened.
