DOC.HEADLINE: US CONGRESSMAN SAYS DPP LESS UNCOMPROMISING ON TAIWAN INDEPENDENCE
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, April 13 (CNA) (By Jay Chen and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) no longer seems uncompromising in its stance on seeking independence for the island, said US Rep. Doug Bereuter (R-Neb.) on Tuesday.

Bereuter, chairman of the House Asia and Pacific Subcommittee, said he thinks this development is a good sign for Taiwan and that he hopes the DPP made the change in its position after making a deliberate assessment of Taiwan's interests and of the common wishes of the Taiwan people.

Speaking during a cocktail party marking the 20th anniversary of the enactment of the Taiwan Relations Act (TRA), Bereuter said he found in his last visit to Taipei in January that the DPP seemed to have departed from its staunchly pro-independence position.

He attributed the policy shift to the DPP's poor showing in elections last December. He said he hopes that the change was not because of Beijing's military and political threats but because of a deliberate consideration of Taiwan's interests and of the wishes of its people.

Bereuter, who strongly supports US President Bill Clinton's policy of engagement with Beijing, has twice visited Taiwan. He was in Taiwan between the end of March and early April in 1998, just one year after Beijing launched live-ammunition missile tests off Taiwan, and at a point when there was no indication that the two sides of the Taiwan Strait would resume dialogue.
He said he will meet with former Taipei Mayor Chen Shui-bian, the DPP's most likely presidential candidate in elections slated for 2000, when Chen visits Washington, D.C., in late April.

As for Beijing's increased missile deployment in strategic locations against Taiwan, Bereuter said he sees no sign that Beijing has taken steps to reduce the number of missiles deployed, even though both the US Congress and the Clinton administration have asked Beijing to do so.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN RANKS FOURTH WORLDWIDE IN OBTAINING US PATENTS IN 1998

TEXT.P: Taiwan obtained 3,805 patent rights from the US federal government in 1998, making it the fourth-largest US patent recipient country in the world behind only Japan, Germany and France, sources from the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) reported on Wednesday.

The 3,805 US patents secured by Taiwan companies and individuals in 1998 was an increase of 46 percent over the year-earlier level, according to officials from MOEA's Intellectual Property Office (IPO).
Taiwan ranked sixth in obtaining US patents in 1997 and in previous years, IPO officials said.

Last year, the government-subsidized Industrial Technology and Research Institute and Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. each received 218 US patents for new products or technologies, while United Microelectronics Corp. obtained 174 US patents.
Meanwhile, the IPO received 16,417 applications from Taiwan companies and individuals for patent rights in Taiwan last year.
Officially approved and valid patents totaled 708 per 100,000 people in Taiwan in 1998, up from 686 per 100,000 people in 1997, the officials noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, April 14, or the 28th day of the second month of the Year of the Rabbit according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1527: Philip II, king of Spain (1556-1598), of Naples and Sicily (1554-1598) and of Portugal (1580-1598) as Philip I, is born. He sent his armada to conquer England in 1588 and met with total defeat and the loss of his fleet.
1629: Christiaan Huygens, the Dutch physicist and astronomer, is born. He discovered Saturn's rings in 1655, pioneered the use of the pendulum in clocks in 1657, and formulated Huygens' principle.
1865: US President Abraham Lincoln is failing fast after being shot in the back of the head at point-blank range by actor John Wilkes Booth, a Confederate fanatic, at the Ford Theater in Washington, D.C. He died the next day and was succeeded by Andrew Johnson.
1903: The typhus vaccine is discovered by Dr. Harry Plotz in New York.
1931: Spain's King Alfonso XIII flees his native country for Rome after a landslide win for Republican parties in the municipal elections. Alcala Zamora becomes president of the provisional government.
1941: Condemning the Soviet-Japanese Neutrality Pact, Foreign Minister Wang Chung-hui of the Republic of China declares that Outer Mongolia and the northeastern provinces are Chinese territory and that the Soviet-Japanese statement is not binding on China.
1949: The Taiwan provincial administration announces a decision to carry out the "37.5 Percent Farm Rental Reduction" and the "Land-to-the-Tiller" policies.
1956: USS Saratoga, a US Navy aircraft carrier which joined the fleet in 1927 as the largest warship in the world, is formally decommissioned.
1956: The first videotape is demonstrated in Chicago.
1962: French Prime Minister Michel Debre resigns and is succeeded by Georges Pompidou.
1972: The first satellite observation station in the Republic of China is inaugurated at National Cheng Kung University.
1975: Sikkim abolishes the monarchy and seeks full Indian statehood.
1977: The ROC Ministry of Foreign Affairs announces severance of diplomatic relations with the Hashemite Kingdom of Jordan.
1982: Armed bandit Lee Shih-khe robs the Land Bank of Taiwan's Kuting Branch in Taipei City of more than NT$5 million, a major criminal case by that time.
1986: Simone de Beauvoir, the French feminist writer and philosopher, dies in a Paris hospital at the age of 78.
1988: Soviet Union ends its intervention in Afghanistan and allows its troops to withdraw.
1989: After nationalist demonstrations, the Communist Party chief and prime minister of Soviet Georgia are replaced in a purge of the Republic's leadership.
1993: On International Women's Day, a Chinese newspaper asks 100 women what they would most like to be. Sixty say they want to be men.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "To be poor without complaining is not easy; but it is easy to be rich without being proud."

DOC.HEADLINE: CANADA OPTIMISTIC MAINLAND CHINA WILL ENTER WTO THIS YEAR

TEXT.P: Canada, which has always supported rule-based trade, showed its optimism Tuesday that mainland China will gain membership in the World Trade Organization (WTO) this year.
Mainland China's entry into the world trade body could pry open "a huge market for Canadian business," said Canadian International Trade Minister Sergio Marchi.
Marchi made the remarks as mainland Chinese Premier Zhu Rongji was about to visit Canada. Zhu will stop in St. John's, Newfoundland, Wednesday, before traveling to Ottawa Thursday.

Canada has played a key role in helping mainland China during its 13-year bid for membership in the WTO, Marchi said. "We don't pretend to be as big as the United States, but our relationship (with China) is quite strong, and in engaging the Chinese, we can have an impact."

He predicted mainland China's accession to the WTO could come by the time WTO ministers meet in Seattle at the end of November. "I think it would make ... a lot of sense to issue a new round with the membership of China included -- that would be my hope and I think it's a realistic one."

Mainland China was Canada's fourth-largest trading partner last year, with two-way trade reaching almost C$10 billion. Canada exported C$2.1 billion in goods to mainland China in 1998, while imports were valued at C$7.7 billion.

About 350 Canadian companies now do business in mainland China, most of them small and medium-size enterprises. Canada's direct investment in mainland China rose from C$15 million in 1991 to C$377 million in 1997, most of which is concentrated in the manufacturing sector.
Canada's main objective in mainland China has been to encourage the latter to maintain an open-door policy and to become fully integrated in global and regional political and economic institutions.

DOC.HEADLINE: EXPORT STIMULUS PACKAGE PAYS OFF: BOFT

TEXT.P: The government's export stimulus package has paid off, evident in the 3.5 percent increase in Taiwan's exports in the first quarter of 1999, a ranking trade official said on Tuesday.

Taiwan exports to Japan and South Korea registered the largest growth of 14.6 percent and 51.7 percent in the first three months of the year, a sharp contrast to the decrease of 22.2 percent and 37.2 percent, respectively, in outbound shipments to the two countries for the whole of 1998, according to Board of Foreign Trade (BOFT) Director-General Chen Ruey-long.

Since the BOFT adopted the measures last year, the package has been most effective in boosting exports to Japan and South Korea, which can be seen in the fact that Taiwan's first-quarter growth rates in outbound shipments to these two Asian countries were larger than the two countries' import increase rates posted for the same three-month period, Chen said.
The BOFT head also predicted that Taiwan will register a larger export growth rate in the second quarter, as some Southeast Asian economies have now bottomed out of the region's financial crisis.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSSIE ARCHITECT'S PLAN TO BUILD WORLD'S TALLEST TOWER COLLAPSES

TEXT.P: Plans to build the world's tallest tower in Melbourne have collapsed because of a payment dispute between a well-known Australian architect and the Victorian government.

The dispute has shattered architect Bruno Grollo's dreams of building the US$1.6 billion, 113-story tower. Grollo has refused to pay nearly US$24 million to the Victorian government for using the Docklands land near Melbourne Harbor.

The Docklands Authority on Tuesday unilaterally announced its termination of the contract with the Grollo family, saying the termination was the result of Grollo's refusal to meet a financial condition of the contract for the proposed tower.

Many have attacked the scale of the project, including Kim Dovey, an associate professor of architecture and urban design at Melbourne University. Dovey has described it as an embarrassment to Melbourne and an enclave for the rich.
But the building has the support of many high-profile Victorians, and about 650 people had already paid about US$3,200 each for the 450 apartments in the 560-meter-high tower.
The Grollo family was advised by its bankers not to pay the money without receiving a freehold title to the Batman's Hill site.

It is believed that the authority would not transfer the freehold title, instead offering to a lease-hold title and a staged release of the freehold upon construction. This offer was unacceptable to Grollo's lenders -- mainly banks.

DOC.HEADLINE: FREQUENT PRESCRIPTION OF ANTIBIOTICS RESULTS IN RESISTANT SUPER-BUGS

TEXT.P: Squashing bugs is getting harder, as many are developing resistance to antibiotics as a result of doctors prescribing them too freely, often in response to demands from patients, according to The Straits Times.
Researchers have found that a common bug that causes respiratory tract infections has evolved into a killer in Singapore after developing resistance to a variety of drugs over the last decade.
The number of cases of drug-resistant "streptococcus pneumoniae" has shot up from 2 percent in 1991 to 43 percent in 1997, according to the most recent study on the subject.
The killer bug detected by researchers is a common bacteria that causes respiratory tract infections, sinus problems and ear infections.

"It used to be very sensitive to penicillin, but over the years, we have been seeing resistance to it," said Dr. Ling Moi Lin, a microbiologist at Singapore General Hospital. "It is also showing resistance to alternative drugs," she added.
In some cases, especially those involving the elderly and very young, the now drug-resistant bug can kill, she said.

About half of all patients over 60 die when the bacteria is found in normally sterile places, like the blood and brain, while in children less than a year old, four in 10 who have the bug die from it.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA PLAYS LEADING ROLE AT APEC 'Y2K WEEK'

TEXT.P: Australia will play a leading role in activities next week aimed at preparing the economies of the Asia-Pacific region for the so-called Millennium Bug (Y2K), Deputy Prime Minister Tim Fischer said on Wednesday.

Speaking at a Pacific Economic Cooperation Council meeting in Canberra, Fischer said the Asian-Pacific Economic Cooperation forum (APEC) had nominated the week beginning April 19 as "Y2K Week." He said 21 APEC members would conduct a range of activities to accelerate their readiness to deal with the Y2K problem.

"Y2K has the potential to cause widespread economic and social disruption if we don't prepare ourselves properly. This is especially true in APEC because of its strong regional economic linkages," he said.

"In our own case, almost 70 percent of Australia's trade by value is with the other APEC economies and their level of preparedness for Y2K, therefore, is of great consequence to us. No economy can isolate itself from the problems which another economy might experience. Sales, payments and the provision of services could all be affected," he said.

He said special activities within Australia during Y2K Week would include a meeting of the Year 2000 National Steering Committee of federal and state governments and industry representatives, and a seminar for public service managers on current and emerging legal issues.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER TAIWAN GOVERNOR'S DAUGHTER INJURED IN TRAFFIC ACCIDENT

TEXT.P: The daughter of former Taiwan Governor James Soong was hospitalized on Wednesday morning following a traffic accident in which she sustained a deep wound to her left thigh.
The accident occurred at about 9 a.m. when a motorcycle on which Soong Chen-mai was riding pillion was hit by a city bus as she was on her way to an off-campus class.

Soong and the driver, classmate Ho Chia-hsin, were both injured, and were rushed to Taipei Municipal Ho Ping Hospital by ambulance, where Soong received surgery which was carried out uneventfully, doctors said.
Ho's injuries were less serious, and she was released from the hospital.
Soong's father and mother rushed to the hospital upon being notified of the accident to see their daughter, a freshman at Fu Jen Catholic University.
Soong's mother said she was thankful that her daughter did not suffer any brain or spinal injuries, and added that her ability to walk will not be affected.
Police are investigating the circumstances surrounding the accident.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR UP

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar climbed NT$0.048 against the greenback in Taipei Wednesday, closing at 32.952.
The local currency opened at the day's low of 32.994, and experienced a high of 32.925.
The interbank US dollar trading reached US$579 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: DELEGATES FROM MORE THAN 20 NATIONS TAKE PART IN PECC MEETINGS

TEXT.P: The Pacific Economic Cooperation Council (PECC) on Wednesday started three days of coordination group and steering committee meetings with delegates from Taiwan, mainland China, Hong Kong and 20 other member countries attending in Canberra.

During the opening ceremony, Australian Deputy Prime Minister Tim Fischer praised the contribution of PECC to the Asian-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum's work in areas such as competition policy, trade services and the identification of impediments to trade and investment in the region.

He said that APEC needs to keep pressing on with its core activities of trade liberalization, trade facilitation and economic and technical cooperation and that PECC has a role to play in all three areas.
The ROC delegation, which includes Professor Wu Rong-i, head of the Taiwan Economic Research Institute, is led by Jeffrey Koo, chair of the Chinese Taipei Committee of the PECC.

Other participating delegates come from such countries as Brunei Darussalam, Canada, Chile, mainland China, Colombia, France, Hong Kong, Indonesia, Japan, South Korea, Malaysia, Mexico, New Zealand, Peru, the Philippines, Russia, Singapore, Thailand, the United States and Vietnam. Australian officials are taking part also.
Fischer emphasized the importance of information technology in the transformation of international trade as the 21st century draws near.
"If there is one area where APEC must ensure that it remains ahead of the game, it is the subject of today's meeting -- the information economy," he said.

"The globalizing forces of information technology are transforming international trade. But managing these changes and fully exploiting the opportunities which new technologies offer requires concerted action," he said.

He cited the widespread and rapid increase in the use of the Internet as an example of the information economy, which affects not only the 23 member countries of PECC and 21 economies of APEC but also other many countries in the world as well.
"In 1995, there were a mere 2 million users, today that figure is 300 million," he said.
Fischer said APEC remains "the cornerstone of our regional trade policy. Notwithstanding the Asian economic crisis, 50 percent of our exports still go to East Asia."

"In times of economic difficulty, APEC's role in promoting trade becomes all the more important. APEC can build momentum for a new round of trade negotiations in the World Trade Organization -- negotiations which are crucial for the health of the global economy as it enters the new millennium," he added.
In his opening remarks, PECC Chairman Robert Romulo from the Philippines said the meetings in Canberra would address a number of issues, including trade, economic cooperation and financial systems.
But he said all global commercial activities will undergo a dramatic change as a result of the wider and rapid use of information technology, including the Internet.

"The technological leaps we have made in the past 20 years have provided us with economic opportunities that were unheard of just a generation before. The Internet in particular provides us with the potential to finally break down the barriers of time and space on economic transaction," he said.

"It is a simple and powerful vision of the future of business. Producers and retailers -- regardless of their size -- gain access to the global market fairly easily, labor cost savings are considerable, inventory is more easily managed, and the potential for profit guarantees that market competition will be intense," he said.

Both Fischer and Romulo stressed the need to regulate the use of information technology, particularly the Internet, so that the risk of fraud and other irregularities in global commercial activities can be reduced.

Between April 14 and 16, all participants will take part in a wide range of discussions on trade policy, food and agriculture, transportation, tourism, telecommunications, information technology, small and medium enterprises, human resources development and financial and capital markets.

DOC.HEADLINE: HIGH-PROFILE FOREIGN FUND MANAGERS VISIT TAIWAN

TEXT.P: A visiting high-profile retirement fund management sector delegation arrived in Taiwan from the United States on Wednesday for the second leg of an Asian trip aimed at studying and inspecting the investment environment and Asia's economic trend.

The 100-member delegation was led by Philip A. Schaefer, chairman of Pensions 2000 Corp., an investment consultant company that is to hold a large-scale conference, dubbed "Forward to Asia," in Taiwan.
Schaefer said upon his arrival that the delegation's visit to the island was motivated by Taiwan's democratization and political stability, while foreign investment here receives tax privileges.

Among the delegates are executives and fund managers of several US government-run and private pension fund trusts, all of which are listed in the top 100 US pension fund trusts, and all of which manage a total of more than US$1 trillion-worth of funds.

The experts, some of whom specialize in high-tech investment and some of whom are expert in foreign currency trading, will take part in the two-day conference to gain in-depth knowledge of Taiwan's economic and financial fundamentals and performance.

The conference will open in Taipei on Thursday, when President Lee Teng-hui will give an address on the country's financial and economic development. Premier Vincent Siew and other high-ranking economic and financial officials, as well as business tycoons, will also attend.
Asked about the conference, Finance Minister Paul Chu said that it is expected to help Taiwan's globalization in both the economic and financial fields.

Unlike individual investors, Chu noted, most of the delegates are institutional investors dealing with pension funds, who are most concerned about the economic, financial, and stock-trading fundamentals of a country, key considerations for long-term investors.

These long-term foreign investments, especially those launched by pension fund trusts, are the key power in the maintenance of stock market stability, stressed Perng Fai-nan, governor the Central Bank of China (CBC), at a legislative meeting on Wednesday.
Accordingly, Perng said, the CBC hopes to introduce foreign funds for long-term investment, which is always the central bank's consistent policy, he added.
The conference has already taken place in Seoul, and will be held in Hong Kong following the Taipei meeting.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCKS RISE TO HIGHEST LEVEL THIS YEAR

TEXT.P: Taiwan share prices rose 0.8 percent and hit the highest level this year on Wednesday, fueled by continuous strong buying by foreign investors in the financial sector.
The benchmark Taiwan Stock Exchange Weighted Price Index rose 60.80 points to close at 7,398.65 points.
Trade on Wednesday saw a total of 3.58 billion shares change hands on a turnover of NT$143.60 billion (US$4.35 billion), up from the previous session's NT$122.03 billion.

Among the eight major stock categories, the financial sector posted the largest gain of the day, rising 2.6 percent, due to the possible merger of Taiwan's largest business conglomerate Lin-Yuan group with the Taichung Commercial Bank.

Cement issues climbed 1.7 percent, followed by paper and pulp stocks, which gained 1.1 percent. Textile stocks went up 1 percent, and foodstuff shares advanced 0.4 percent. The construction sector remained static.
Plastic and chemical shares posted a 0.4 percent decline, and electronic stocks showed a slight drop of 0.1 percent.
The over-the-counter market saw an increase of 2.84 points, closing at the year's high of 170.26 points with a turnover of NT$8.43 billion.
Meanwhile, the TAIEX Capitalization Weighted Price Index Futures (TAIEX Index Futures) for April fell 12 points to close at 7,365 points, with 3,501 contract transactions.
TAIEX Index Futures for May dropped 1 point to close at 7,400, with 223 contract transactions, while those for June gained 20 points to close at 7,420, with 67 contract transactions.
September futures advanced 57 points, closing at 7,450 points, and December futures went up 67 points to close at 7,450. Contract transactions for the two months totaled 10 and 9, respectively.

Reference levels provided by the Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange for TAIEX Index Futures trading on Wednesday were 7,377 points for April, 7,401 points for May, 7,400 points for June, 7,393 points for September, and 7,383 points for December.

DOC.HEADLINE: EX-LEADERS FROM ASIA, EUROPE TO BE INVITED TO PECC CONFERENCE

TEXT.P: Organizers of the 1999 Pacific Economic Cooperation Council (PECC) will invite former leaders from Taiwan, mainland China and other countries to attend a conference in Manila this October, said the council's chairman.

In an interview with CNA at the opening of a meeting of PECC's coordinating group and standing committee in Canberra, Roberto Romulo, who was formerly foreign secretary of the Philippines, said PECC would broaden its scope not only by inviting former leaders of both sides of the Taiwan Strait to attend an upcoming meeting but also by inviting some 200 European scholars, business leaders and former government leaders to take part.
Present and former government leaders from outside Europe will be invited as well.

Aside from President Joseph Estrada of the Philippines and President Kim Dae Jung of South Korea, others on the invitation list are former Philippine President Fidel Ramos, former Australian Prime Minister Bob Hawke, former Singaporean Prime Minister Lee Kuan Yew and former Prime Minister Anand Panyarachun of Thailand.

Invitations to former leaders of Taiwan and mainland China will be discussed with Jeffrey Koo, the leader of Taiwan's delegation, and Koo's mainland Chinese counterpart at PECC's present meeting in Canberra, Romulo said.
In addition, about 200 European business leaders, former government officials and scholars will also be invited to attend the Manila meeting in October so that PECC can broaden its scope.

"The purpose of inviting Europeans is to exchange views, because there is no longer an Asian financial crisis. But it's a global crisis. Certainly in this area, we have to talk with them in order to find a global solution to the global problem," he said.

Moreover, PECC members this year will have their first ever meeting with the secretary-general of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations to discuss how "we can pursue issues of mutually complementary," Romulo said.

Since its inception in 1980, PECC has been a unique partnership of senior individuals from business, government and academic spheres, who work in a non-official capacity on practical policy issues to increase trade, investment and economic development in the Asia-Pacific region, he said.
Despite issuing invitations to European leaders to attend the upcoming meeting in Manila, Romulo said PECC would not increase its membership to include members from Europe.

DOC.HEADLINE: COMMON ASIAN CURRENCY WORTH STUDYING: CBC

TEXT.P: The launch of a common Asian currency is a good idea worthy of further study, Central Bank of China (CBC) Governor Perng Fai-nan said on Wednesday.
Perng's remark was made in response to a lawmaker's question at the Legislative Yuan, which was holding its third plenary session of the Financial Committee.

In view of the success of the euro, the single currency launched by the European Union, the promotion of a common currency in Asia should have a bright prospect, said Chen Sheng-hung of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) during the interpellation.
Chen expressed his hope that the CBC will take action to promote the idea.
The CBC governor said that the launch of an "Asian dollar" would be better promoted by a giant economy, so that the move would be more forceful and effective.

There are three prerequisites for the promotion of a single Asian currency, Perng said. They are: Participating members should all be democratic free nations; all members should adopt a market-oriented economic system; and all members should have a low financial deficit and low inflation.
He stressed that the CBC will do its best to promote the idea, and propose it in international venues, in the hope that a common understanding can be established among the economies of Asia.

DOC.HEADLINE: PROPER HANDLING OF TOXIC WASTE URGED

TEXT.P: Taiwan should devise a proper way to handle its industrial waste given the island's dense population, a Control Yuan member said on Wednesday.

Ma Yi-kung, who is also an active environmental protection advocate, made the call after concluding a weeklong fact-finding visit to the city of Westmoreland in southern California, where Taiwan's Formosa Plastics Group (FPG) had planned to dispose of some 2,700 tons of mercury-tainted waste.
The industrial waste, originally buried at a landfill in Cambodia, was shipped out by FPG late last month after local residents discovered the substance was toxic.

FPG, Taiwan's largest petrochemical firm, later applied to transport the waste to Westmoreland, but strong public opposition forced the US Environmental Protection Agency to revoke FPG's disposal permit.
The mercury-tainted waste is currently being stored at Taiwan's southern Kaohsiung Port.

Ma blasted FPG for inadequate handling of the waste, pointing out that even though Westmoreland is a desolate desert area usually used by the US Navy for bombing exercises, it was still unwilling to take the substance.

Ma, who brought back a pile of documents from the United States, said the US Environmental Protection Agency decided to revoke its permit for FPG's application citing concern that the toxic waste may pollute nearby environments while being transported to Westmoreland from either a port of entry on the East or West coast.
FPG's mercury-contaminated waste, though already solidified, will change into a damaging chemical substance when exposed to a windy or rainy climate, Ma added.
Ma urged relevant authorities to properly address the issue of Taiwan's toxic waste, as at least another 22,000 tons of industrial waste is being poorly handled in southern Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN OLYMPIC COMMITTEE CHAIRMAN OFF TO SEOUL

TEXT.P: Huang Ta-chou, chairman of the Chinese-Taipei Olympic Committee, left Taipei for Seoul on Wednesday to promote sport exchanges between Taiwan and South Korea.
After a two-day stay in South Korea, Huang will fly to Japan to meet with Japanese sports leaders and visit facilities.

As Huang is also president of the Chinese Professional Baseball League, he will study the development of professional baseball in South Korea and Japan. He will discuss the possibility of professional teams from the three countries competing in exhibition series.
Huang's delegation includes representatives from several Taiwan professional baseball teams.

In Japan, they will call on the Japan Professional Baseball Commission, the Central League and the Pacific League, and visit Chiba Stadium, Yokohama Stadium, the Tokyo "Big Egg" Stadium, Seibu Stadium and Jingu Stadium.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO NEED TO CUT BANK RESERVE RATIOS: CBC

TEXT.P: Central Bank of China (CBC) Governor Perng Huai-nan said on Wednesday that the CBC is not prepared to cut bank reserve ratios at present as the money supply in the market is sufficient.

Perng made the remark at a Legislative Yuan joint committee meeting of finance and budget in response to legislators' questions on speculation that the CBC is planning to reduce bank reserve requirements in order to boost the money supply in the stock market.
This would help certain Kuomintang-owned companies to recoup some of their stock market losses of last year. These companies reportedly lost a total of as much as NT$10 billion.

Perng categorically denied the rumor, saying that the CBC will only consider cutting the bank reserve ratios when foreign exchange rates and prices are stable but banks' money supply is insufficent. He assured the legislators that no rushed or partial decision on the matter will be made.

Compared to the global trend of adjusting bank reserve ratios downward, Taiwan's weighted average bank reserve ratios of 6.41 percent put Taiwan at the top of the global list in this regard. Luckily, Taiwan's substantial bank reserve ratios of 4.48 percent mean the island's banks can remain competitive, said Perng.

Concerning legislator's charges that the CBC made use of the reduction of bank reserve ratios to profit banks, especially those whose fundamentals are weak, at the expense of bank customers, Perng denied the accusation, stressing that the CBC acts in the best interests of the nation, and that the only reason to adjust the ratios would be to strengthen the competitiveness of the country's banks.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PREMIER MEETS WITH SALVADORAN VICE PRESIDENT-ELECT

TEXT.P: Republic of China Premier Vincent Siew met on Wednesday with Vice President-elect Lic Carlos Quintanilla Schmidt, and told him that hard work and a well-formed system are the foundations of the ROC's successful development.

Schmidt, who is visiting Taiwan at the behest of Salvadoran President-elect Francisco Flores, said the main purpose of his trip is to learn from the ROC's successful development and to expand and enhance cooperation between the two countries.
Siew responded that Taiwan would be glad to share its experience with its Central American ally and is keen to promote further ties and cooperative plans.

Taiwan went through a period of poverty and great hardship after its retrocession to the ROC government from Japanese rule in 1945, but the government's land reforms and a series of four-year development plans revitalized the economy, Siew said.

Taiwan's economic development has been hailed all over the world as the "Taiwan experience," Siew went on, adding that Taiwan has also managed to maintain its agricultural development as it has transformed into an industrial power.
Small and medium-sized enterprises have been the backbone of the ROC's economic development, and have played a pivotal role in its economic growth, the premier pointed out.
Siew also praised the success of Schmidt's Nationalist Republican Alliance in the Salvadoran presidential elections.

DOC.HEADLINE: HEALTH OF 24 MEN ON PLEBISCITE HUNGER STRIKE STABLE

TEXT.P: The health of 24 people on a hunger strike in support of holding a plebiscite was stable on Wednesday, the fifth day of the strike.

Cho Jung-tai, a Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) legislator and one of the strike's leaders, said all 24 strikers possess a strong volition and that the strike will continue until the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) agrees to discuss a plebiscite with opposition camps.
He also protested allegations that some of the strikers "secretly have eaten," stressing that the character and determination of the strikers should be respected.

Medical and nursing personnel from Chang Hua Christian Hospital said with the exception of a few strikers showing signs of hypertension and low blood sugar, no one is suffering serious health complications.

Wednesday saw Lee Po-jung, who unsuccessfully ran for a legislative spot, challenge Trong R. Tsai, a DPP legislator and strike leader , to join him in self-immolation, saying "if you want to put on a show, let everyone join the act."
The situation was resolved by police.

DOC.HEADLINE: DEMOCRACY IS TAIWAN'S BEST SHIELD AGAINST BEIJING THREAT: JANE'S
DOC.DATELINE: London, April 13 (CNA) (By Mark Ou and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Democracy is Taiwan's best shield against the threat from mainalnd China, the authoritative Jane's Defense Review monthly said in its April issue.

A fast-looming issue now is Taiwan's presidential election in March 2000, which could have a significant impact on security issues across the Taiwan Strait, said the article written by Mark Daly, the magazine's editor-in-chief.
"One danger is that sheer political and economic frustration in Taiwan could be reflected in next year's election results," he continued.

Mainland China and Taiwan have co-existed for almost 50 years, in part because of the latter's very careful handling of the independence issue, and because of the US role in providing arms and defensive support to Taiwan, Daly said.
At stake is the deeply sensitive issue of independence from mainland China, an issue which Taiwan's ruling Kuomintang (KMT) has skillfully finessed.

The declared KMT policy is peaceful reunification with the mainland -- a political objective so distant as to be invisible -- which nevertheless has provided the basis for mostly peaceful co-existence. That delicate status quo has been under particular pressure over the last decade, he continued.

The missile crisis of 1996 caused Taiwan a US$23 billion flight of capital, which has left a deep wound. Yet Taiwan switched from a one-party state to democracy without any economic or political breakdown, the article said.
There are signs that the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) may be softening its independence line, and that its "trigger-happy" image is unfounded.

"I feel that judging from what opposition leaders have been saying, they are becoming more sensible, a little more rational. I don't see a great danger of Taiwan doing something unilateral towards China," the article quoted Dr. Hung-mao Tien, president of the Institute for Policy Research, an independent think-tank, as saying.

A US Department of Defense report tabled to Congress last February as part of the Fiscal Year 1999 Appropriation Bill, says: "By 2005 Taipei will posses a qualitative edge over Beijing in terms of significant weapons and equipment," citing the ROC air force's 300-plus fourth-generation fighters as an example.

For the most part Taiwan is satisfied with its air defenses, but the Patriot PAC-2S offers only limited tactical missile defense, which leads back to the thorny Theater Missile Defense (TMD) debate, the article continued.
While there is a growing feeling in Taiwan that the invasion threat is increasingly unlikely, mainland China's ambitions to build a blue-water navy could pose a strategic threat to Taiwan, it noted.

Taiwan's greatest naval weakness lies in its inability to acquire submarines. The state-owned Chung-Shan Institute of Science and Technology has benefited to some extent from technology transfers from the United States, but its independent capabilities are considerable, it continued.

Beijing has said in recent years that "Chinese should not kill Chinese." Some in Taiwan say that is mere propaganda -- China was blighted by wars and rebellions for half of this century -- but there are strong reasons on both sides for making sure that this does not recur, the article said.

DOC.HEADLINE: DESERTED BABIES REEL IN SPRING CHILL (I)

TEXT.P: Spring is often described as the season of romance, a time to foster love and life. But with local society becoming increasingly open regarding sex, spring has also become a peak season for deserted babies.
No exact figures on Taiwan's deserted newborns or toddlers are currently available, but behind each abandoned child lies a story of misfortune and social plight.

The issue of deserted babies has long existed in Taiwan. In the past, abandoned children were seen as products of a poor, backward society. Ironically, even though Taiwan has by now evolved from an agricultural backwater to an affluent economic powerhouse, the issue remains alive and has even got worse.
A few days ago, Liao Hui-ying, a social worker at the private Chungyi children's home, took charge of a newborn who had been discarded in the arcade of a skyscraper in Taipei.
Hugging the tiny baby, Liao said that all the children in the Chungyi residence need a hug, as well as other people's care and concern.

"I always feel joyful every time I take an abandoned child back to Chungyi. All the children here were nameless, unwelcome lives when they were born. They would not have an identity or a temporary home if they were not sent here," Liao said.

A score of young children crawl on the wooden floor. Those who bear a middle name of "Yu" were abandoned at birth. In a corner of the room stands a small bed in which several babies are sleeping serenely. Their angelic faces make people forget the misfortune which led to their presence here.

The Chungyi children's home specializes in providing shelter for deserted babies, runaways and abused children. It was set up by Liu Teh-chen, a great-granddaughter of Liu Ming-chuan, the first governor of Taiwan during the imperial Ching dynasty.
Initially, Liu used her family assets to support the children's home. But in recent years, the Chungyi residence has relied mainly on private donations to maintain its operations.

Raising abandoned babies is usually costlier than rearing older children because baby formula and diapers are so expensive. However, present Chungyi President Kao Ming-chu stressed that no matter how severe its financial straits, the organization has consistently given top priority to the care of deserted babies.

Without a comprehensive checking and reporting system, it is difficult to calculate the number of babies which are abandoned in Taiwan. According to unofficial tallies by another local children's welfare group -- the Child Welfare Legal Foundation (CWLF) -- a total of 313 abandoned babies were discovered in 1992 alone. The number declined to 75 last year.

Although the figures show a downward trend, welfare organizations are skeptical of the statistics. A CWLF executive pointed out that as many cases go unreported, and because some of the babies are illegally adopted, it is no easy task to compile an exact figure of the island's abandoned infants.
A CWLF analysis of 57 deserted babies discovered in six cities and counties around the island last year indicated that 37 percent of them were dumped in the spring and 27 percent in the winter.
In terms of age, more than half of the babies were discarded less than one month after birth, and nearly 80 percent of them were aged under six months.
Yang Tsuai-chin, a member of the Taipei Women's Police Corps, said several of the abandoned infants she handled in recent months still had their umbilical cords attached when they were found.

Yang said abandoned babies are most commonly discovered at hospitals, parks, on sidewalks and overpasses. Other likely places include restaurants, lavatories, school campuses, staircases, phone booths, and even garbage dumps.

Some of these helpless children are taken directly to police stations, while many others are left by their mothers in hospitals. In most cases, the mothers use aliases and other false data when checking into the hospital, making it heard to trace them when they flee after giving birth. (To be continued)

DOC.HEADLINE: DESERTED BABIES (II)

TEXT.P: According to government regulations concerning the handling of deserted babies, such kids cannot be transferred privately. Any members of the general public who discover an abandoned baby must hand the child over to the police, who must inform the bureau of social affairs of the local government.

The deserted baby will then be sent to a hospital for a physical checkup. "Due to a lack of proper care or medical treatment, many abandoned children are usually very weak when they are found," Yang said, adding that while some babies may look healthy, they are often later found to have been infected.

Following the physical checkup and any necessary medical treatment, the child is sent temporarily to either a public or a private children's welfare institute. In the following six-month period, police and other relevant public agencies attempt to find the parents.

If no one comes forward to claim the child during the grace period, the welfare organization must file an application with the district court to become the child's legal guardians. The organizations can also look for a suitable individual or family to adopt the child.

In the past, people have tended to think that handicapped children are most likely to be discarded. However, a CWLF study of 455 abandoned infants showed that nearly 85 percent of them were normal and healthy.
Kao said several other social factors also need to be considered.

"Many children living in Chungyi are very curious about their origins," Kao said. "They hope to know who their parents are. Some of them have told me that if the opportunity presents itself, they would ask what kinds of difficulties or hardships prompted their parents to abandon them."
Noting that every child is entitled to know his or her origin and past, Kao said she believes that people who are aware of their own family background will have greater confidence in their own lives.
"However, as it is usually very difficult to find out their birth parents, their origins have often become forever riddles," Kao said.
Lee Chao-jung, chief of the CWLF's research and development division, said complicated social problems are to blame for the deserted baby issue.

"The CWLF once discovered a criminal ring which either stole infants or abducted young children and then sold them as abandoned children," Lee said, adding that the institute also had found that some people disguised themselves as philanthropists to take charge of deserted children, but later sent the children to work in factories and pocketed the wages earned by the helpless child laborers.

Meanwhile, Lee said, the number of newborns discarded by legal and illegal foreign workers here has also been increasing steadily, adding to the pressure on local children's welfare organizations which lack the funds and trained manpower to take care of the rapidly increasing number of deserted babies.
Lee went on to say that the problem of deserted babies has also highlighted the adverse impact of the increasingly lax attitude toward sex among local teens.

"As a result of dramatic changes in social values, local adolescents now pursue passion rather than true love, and pre-marital sex has become all too common among them, leading to increases in the number of unmarried mothers and deserted babies," Lee noted.

Lin Chia-teh, a CWLF social worker in charge of adoption affairs, said that about 50 percent of adopted children handled by the CWLF were born to unmarried mothers. Other factors that prompt parents to have their children legally adopted by other families include marriage breakups and family financial problems.
"The reasons behind a parental decision to have children adopted by other families may also shed light on the plight facing those who discard their newborns or young children," Lin said.
In the first few years following his joining the CWLF team, Lin said he thought people who discard their children are cold-blooded monsters.

"But after years of work, I can now look at the issue from a more compassionate and sympathetic perspective," Lin said, adding that the birth parents of many abandoned or adopted children are plagued by hardships unimaginable to others.

Lin further said that the high percentage of deserted babies born to unmarried mothers implies another increasingly serious social problem that deserves concern -- the plight of unmarried teenage mothers. (This story is credited to the China Times reporter Ms. Lin Chao-chen.)

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN RELIEF GROUP ARRIVES IN MACEDONIA
DOC.DATELINE: Skopje, Macedonia April 14 (CNA) (By Yen Lingju & Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: A relief group financed by the Republic of China government and private groups arrived in Skopje on Wednesday morning.

They flew in aboard a chartered flight from Abu Dhabi, the capital of the United Arab Emirates and were warmly greeted by Vasil Tupurkovski, chairman of the ruling Democratic Alternative Party, and officials from the Foreign Ministry.
Tupurkovski hugged David Lee, ROC vice minister of foreign affairs and head of the relief group. A banner reading in English "Love from Taiwan, ROC" was hung at the airport.

The 91-person relief group, comprised of medical crew, ROC legislators, officials of relief agencies, and Taiwan journalists, brought 20 tons of aid, including NT$10 million (US$303,000) worth of medicine and medical equipment.
They will set up an eight-tent field hospital at the Radusa refugee camp between Skopje and the Kosovo border for at least two weeks.
The chartered plane went on to Italy after unloading its passengers and goods because the Skopje airport only allows aircraft a stay of two hours.
The plane will return to Skopje on Friday to deliver a second shipment of ROC aid and take back to Taiwan non-relief workers among the ROC delegation.

DOC.HEADLINE: RECEPTION HELD ON CAPITOL HILL TO MARK TRA'S 20TH ANNIVERSARY
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, April 13 (CNA) (By Jay Chen and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: A cocktail reception was held on Capitol Hill on Tuesday to mark the 20th anniversary of the Taiwan Relations Act (TRA), the US law enacted on April 10, 1979 to regulate exchanges with Taiwan in the absence of official ties.

Many US lawmakers from both the Senate and the House of Representatives, including Sen. Strom Thurmond (R-S.C.), president pro tempore (temporary president) of the Senate, attended the reception at the Mansfield Room.

During the reception, Benjamin A. Gilman (R-N.Y.), chairman of the House International Relations Committee, and Sen. Frank H. Murkowski (R-Alaska), presented three meaningful souvenirs to Stephen Chen, ROC representative to the United States.
The souvenirs were framed Senate and House resolutions reaffirming their commitment to upholding the TRA and supporting Taiwan's participation in the World Health Organization (WHO).

Speaking on the occasion, Senate majority leader Trent Lott (R-Miss.) said Taiwan has set a model for democratization and economic development and that Congress supports sustained close US-Taiwan relations.
Rep. Gilman said the TRA has played an important role in preserving and promoting ROC-US relations over the past two decades and is also crucial to maintain peace and stability in the Taiwan Strait.
Gilman went on to say that US Congress hopes the TRA will continue contributing to peaceful resolution of the Taiwan Strait issue.

It is regretful that mainland China still refuses to renounce the use of force against Taiwan, Gilman said, adding that the United States is delighted to see Taiwan evolve into a mature democracy and hopes Taiwan will continue serving as a model for mainland China and other East Asian countries to promote the development of democracy, human rights and rule of law.

ROC Representative Chen said Taiwan is a faithful US ally in the pursuit of their common ideals of democracy and market economy. This partnership will be further expanded in economic, political, cultural and security fields in the years ahead, the de facto ROC ambassador added.
American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) Chairman Richard Bush said the TRA has provided a legal framework for US-Taiwan relations over the past 20 years.
The TRA has also underscored the US determination to safeguard peace in the Taiwan Strait and security of the people of Taiwan, Bush said.
The top US liaison officer with Taiwan further said that the TRA reflects the US executive branch and Congress' commitment to Taiwan people's well-being.

The TRA, coupled with Taiwan's vitality, ingenuity and strong confidence in its future, has enabled Taiwan to become a prosperous democracy and a good member of the international community, Bush added.

American lawmakers present at the reception also included William V. Roth, Jr. (R-Del.), chairman of the Senate Finance Committee; Orrin G. Hatch (R-Utah), chairman of the Senate Judiciary Committee; and Rep. Doug Bereuter (R-Neb.), chairman of the House Asia and Pacific Subcommittee.

Lester L. Wolff, a retired congressman who played a key role in the TRA's legislation, former AIT Taipei Office Director James Lilley, and scores of congressional staff members also attended the reception.

Many of them will take part in a seminar on the TRA to be held in Washington, D.C. on Wednesday. Two senior ROC officials -- Control Yuan President Fredrick Chien and government spokesman Chen Chien-jen -- will deliver speeches at the seminar.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SEMI-CONDUCTOR MAKERS SEEKING COOPERATION IN JAPAN

TEXT.P: A mission consisting of 12 Taiwan major semi-conductor producers will hold seminars in Tokyo and Osaka in the coming days to seek cooperation with their Japanese counterparts.

An official with the Taipei-based China External Trade Development Council (CETRA) said that the seminars are designed to provide opportunities for Taiwan and Japanese manufacturers to cooperate in production and sale strategies.
Last year, a similar seminar held in Tokyo, attracted some 350 representatives from 200 Japanese semi-conductor makers.
This year, the Tokyo seminar will be held at the Tokyo International Convention Center on April 15-16, and in Osaka on April 19-20.

According to Wu Min-chiu, leader of the Taiwan mission, Taiwan's IC production last year totaled US$9.7 billion, down 3.5 percent from the preceding year. He estimated this year's output will reach US$11.9 billion.

Wu said that cooperation with Taiwan manufacturers would offer Japanese IC manufacturers several advantages including geographical convenience, high productivity, high competitiveness, and an internationally-recognized quality.
The 12 Taiwan companies participating in the seminars account for 45 percent of Taiwan's total IC production.

The semi-official CETRA set up an International Sourcing Center (ISC) in 1997 to help foreign manufacturers cooperate with Taiwan makers. So far, more than 200 foreign companies have entered into projects with Taiwan producers through ISC arrangements.

DOC.HEADLINE: SALVADORAN VP-ELECT VISITS OVERSEAS CHINESE AFFAIRS COMMISSION

TEXT.P: Visiting Salvadoran Vice President-elect Lic Carlos Quintanilla Schmidt and his wife visited the Overseas Chinese Affairs Commission, sources reported on Wednesday.
Schmidt visited the commission to learn how it handles issues related to over 30 million overseas Chinese scattered around the world.

Vice Minister of the Commission Chu Chien-yi met with the dignitaries on behalf of Minister Chiao Jen-ho and congratulated Schmidt on his election victory. Chu said that the commission's main task is to keep close contact with overseas Chinese and actively promote Chinese culture.

Chu added that Taiwan recognizes double nationalities, thus any overseas Chinese that identifies with the Republic of China is entitled to apply for a Taiwan passport and is eligible to vote in Taiwan elections.
The commission now runs 19 cultural centers world-wide to sponsor activities, training and lectures of all kinds, and more will be set up in Brazil, the United Kingdom and Canada.
The commission also is in charge of training teachers for overseas Chinese. Most of the commission's budget is spent on education, said Chu.
Salvadoran vice president-elect Lic Carlos Quintanilla Schmidt and his four-person entourage arrived in Taiwan on Tuesday for a six-day official visit. (by Amanda Chang)

DOC.HEADLINE: PHILIPPINE PRESIDENT `SAD' OVER ANWAR RULING

TEXT.P: Philippine President Joseph Estrada said on Wednesday that the ruling by a Malaysian high court judge finding former Deputy Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim guilty of corruption was "unfortunate" but stressed that it is Malaysia's internal problem.

Estrada, a personal friend of Anwar, said: "In my personal view, this is unfortunate, I feel sad about it. I personally know the character of Anwar. This is a sad event, but I cannot give any comment about it because this is Malaysia's internal problem."
According to reports, Anwar was found guilty of four counts of corruption and sentenced to six years in jail. His lawyers are appealing the ruling.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NAVY TO RESUME BUILDING 8TH PERRY-CLASS FRIGATE

TEXT.P: Taiwan's navy will soon resume the construction of its eighth Perry-class frigate, said the China Shipbuilding Corp. (CSBC), the shipyard commissioned to build the missile-guided frigate.

The navy began the "Kuang Hua No. 1 Project" in 1989, contracting the state-run CSBC to build eight frigates modeled on the US Perry-class frigate. So far the navy has taken delivery of seven such frigates.
Construction of the eighth frigate, which was originally scheduled to be completed in October of this year, was suspended to an insufficient budget.
The CSBC said that it recently reached an agreement with the Navy on the issue and the construction of the eighth and last Perry-class frigate will begin in the second half of this year.

With a displacement of 4,200 tons, each Perry-class frigate is equipped with advanced radar, artillery, torpedoes, surface-to-surface and surface-to-air missiles as well as anti-submarine helicopters. Each frigate costs NT$7 billion (US$2.12 billion).
The military-run Chungshan Institute of Science and Technology will handle the installation and integration of all weaponry systems aboard the frigate.
As part of its efforts to modernize its naval fleet and upgrade defense capabilities, Taiwan has gradually retired aging destroyers and replaced them with a second-generation of vessels.

In addition to the Perry-class frigates, six Lafayette-class frigates have been purchased from France and six Knox-class frigates leased from the United States to form the backbone of Taiwan's naval fleet.
Meanwhile, the CSBC denied reports that two coastal patrol ships "Tamchiang" and Hsinchiang" it built for the Navy had failed fire control system tests.
The shipyard said that the two 500-ton ships have passed all tests and the Navy will soon take delivery.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP PRESIDENTIAL HOPEFUL CHEN SHUI-BIAN TO VISIT D.C.
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, April 13 (CNA) (By Jay Chen and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Former Taipei Mayor Chen Shui-bian will arrive in Washington, D.C. on April 18 for a three-day visit.
Chen will visit the US capital in his capacity as a member of the Central Standing Committee of Taiwan's opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP).

The DPP's representative office in the United States said on Tuesday that Chen will meet with US lawmakers, noted American think tanks fellows, media executives and Chinese community leaders during his stay here.

Chen, who is believed to seek DPP's nomination to run in next year's presidential election, is scheduled to host a news conference at the US National Press Club on April 20 and will deliver a speech at a gathering to be organized by a Taiwanese association on April 21.
Rep. Doug Bereuter (R-Neb.), chairman of the House Asia and Pacific Subcommittee, said he will exchange views with Chen on some security issues during Chen's visit.

Chen, the most popular politician in Taiwan's opposition camp, is also expected to meet with US officials under the arrangement of the American Institute in Taiwan, a semi-official body authorized to handle relations with Taiwan in the absence of official ties.
Chen last visited Washington, D.C. in March 1998 during his stint as Taipei mayor.
Chen's upcoming visit is part of his global "journey of learning" aimed at expanding his vision to boost his presidential bid. The journey already took him to Japan, South Korea and Mongolia.
Chen will also visit New York and other American cities during his upcoming journey.

DOC.HEADLINE: 70 PERCENT OF TAIWAN'S FOREIGN RESERVES ARE IN GREENBACK

TEXT.P: Taiwan's foreign currency reserves at the end of March totaled US$93 billion, with 70 percent in US dollars, according to data released by the Central Bank of China (CBC) on Wednesday.
The data indicated that about 20 percent of the reserves, worth US$18.6 billion, are in the euro, and 10 percent, worth US$9.3 billion, are in Japanese yen.
Meanwhile, CBC Governor Perng Fai-nan said on Wednesday that foreign capital in Taiwan now amounts to US$12.8 billion, but that is still a figure the CBC is able to control.
If the figure increases, he said, the CBC and the Finance Ministry will meet to discuss how to cope with the new situation.
Perng noted that Taiwan's commodity prices are expected to remain stable this year, with the year's consumer price index up a slight 1.6 percent.
Perng said that the mainland China's renminbi has not yet been devaluated, mainly because of economic and political factors.
However, he stated that he has never said that the renminbi would not be devalued this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT LEE ADVOCATES CLINTON'S WIN STRATEGY

TEXT.P: Taipei-Washington ties and Washington-Beijing ties can develop in a parallel manner, said President Lee Teng-hui on Wednesday.

In a written message sent to an international conference on the 20th anniversary of the Taiwan Relations Act in Washington, Lee urged Beijing not to consider engaging in a "zero-sum game" with Taiwan in which one country's gain means the another's loss.
Rather, Lee said that he supports US President Bill Clinton's 1997 remarks that "all three relationships can prosper" in a "win-win-win" situation.
Lee praised the enactment of the 1979 Taiwan Relations Act (TRA) for ensuring friendly relations continued between the US and the ROC after the severance of diplomatic ties.
Furthermore, Lee said the TRA contributed greatly to the peace and stability in the Taiwan Strait and to the advancement and elevation of US-ROC relations.

He expressed appreciation to the Heritage Foundation and the American Enterprise Institute for co-sponsoring the "Conference on Taiwan Relations Act 20th Anniversary" in Washington on Wednesday, and hoped the conference would map out a future direction for the TRA.

The two conservative think tanks' conference brings together political leaders and scholars from the United States and the Republic of China to discuss the performance of the TRA in the past and how it can be better implemented in the future.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC WILLING TO PARTICIPATE IN INTERNATIONAL AFFAIRS: VP

TEXT.P: Republic of China (ROC) Vice President Lien Chan on Wednesday called on the country's diplomatic allies to support the ROC's bid for more participation in the international arena.
He made the remarks at a dinner hosted by him in honor of visiting Salvadoran Vice President-elect Carlos Quintanilla Schmidt and his wife.

Lien said that the ROC's achievements in the economic and political areas have been recognized internationally, and he hoped its allies will support the ROC's bid for a bigger role in international affairs.
Lien expressed the appreciation of the ROC government and its people for El Salvador's support in the international community.
He said that the ROC is willing to become El Salvador's partner in its national development by sharing the experience of Taiwan's development.

In El Salvador's presidential election early last month, Francisco Flores and Carlos Quintanilla Schmidt gained 51.98 percent of the votes to become the new president and vice president. They will be sworn in on June 1.

Lien said in his dinner remarks that he personally maintains close connections with El Salvador because he served as ROC ambassador to that country between 1975-76. Since then he has made return visits in 1994 as premier and in 1998 as vice president.

Other ranking ROC officials invited to the dinner included Senior Presidential Advisor Ding Mou-shih, National Assembly Speaker Su Nan-cheng, Vice Premier Liu Chao-shiuan, and Foreign Minister Jason Hu.

DOC.HEADLINE: MACEDONIAN PREMIER TO VISIT TAIWAN IN MAY

TEXT.P: Macedonian Premier Ljubco Georgievski told David Lee, the Republic of China's vice minister of foreign affairs Wednesday, that his Balkan country is out of danger now and he expects to visit Taiwan in May.

In a meeting with Lee and six ROC legislators who arrived here Wednesday morning with a planeload of Taiwan relief goods, Georgievski said the worst of the crisis caused by the huge influx of Kosovo refugee into Macedonia is over. He predicted the Kosovo crisis will be peacefully resolved soon.

Saying foreign investment can reinvigorate his government's faltering economy he encouraged Taiwan businessmen to send capital into the Balkan state, adding that he can ensure it will be safe and risk-free.
Georgievski told the Taiwan press corps accompanying Lee that his government appreciates the aid extended to Macedonia by the ROC.

The ROC sent a chartered plane loaded with 20 tons of aid to Macedonia, including NT$10 million (US$303,000 million) worth of medicine and NT$8 million (US$242,424) worth of medical equipment. It was presented to Vasil Tupurkovski, chairman of the ruling Democratic Alternative Party, in a brief ceremony at the Skopje airport earlier on Wednesday.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies Thursday are as follows:
The Central Daily News:
US, Canadian pension funds executives arrived in Taipei for a fact-finding visit aimed at familiarizing them with the local capital market.
The China Times:
Taipei and Kaohsiung mayors criticized the Cabinet over tax revenues.

The National Health Insurance Program will cover only three persons per family; premium will not be adjusted.
The Liberty Times:
Taipei and Kaohsiung mayors fumed over the central government's decision to cut subsidies.
The Commons Daily:
The legislature will set up a special panel to check financial institutions' files and documents.
The China Post:
Pension funds raise Taiwan's stock index.
The China News:
Former Malaysian Deputy Prime Minister Anwar gets six years in prison.

DOC.HEADLINE: TRA INSTRUMENTAL TO CEMENTING ROC-US TIES: CLINTON
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, April 14 (CNA) (By Jay Chen and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: US President Bill Clinton said on Wednesday that the Taiwan Relations Act (TRA) is instrumental in strengthening relations between the Republic of China and the United States as well as in preserving peace and stability in Asia.
Clinton made the statement in a written congratulatory message to a conference marking the 20th anniversary of the TRA, the US law governing relations with Taiwan in the absence of official ties.
Clinton's message was read by Christopher C. DeMuth, president of the American Enterprise Institute, which co-sponsored the forum with the Heritage Foundation.

Clinton said in his message that America's continued success and stability depend in part on its ability to foster intercultural dialogue and understanding and forge productive international relationships.

Based on this spirit of cooperation and community, Clinton said, the United States and Taiwan continue to enjoy strong bonds of friendship that have promoted the two countries' well-being, broadened their people's cultural horizons, and offered promising opportunities for economic growth.
Clinton went on to say that the TRA has been instrumental in strengthening those bridges of friendship and in preserving peace and stability in Asia.

"As we celebrate this landmark legislation, I applaud your long-standing dedication to strengthening Taiwan-American cooperation and to exploring our common goals for the future," Clinton said, adding that the trust and fellowship fostered through concerted efforts of both sides offer a vital opportunity for realizing a future of continued prosperity and lasting peace.
The full text of Clinton's message reads:
"Warm greetings to all those gathered in our nation's capital to mark the 20th anniversary of the Taiwan Relations Act.

"In this era of sweeping global change, it is more important than ever for our citizens to recognize the ties that link us with other peoples of the world. America's continued success and stability depend in part on our ability to foster intercultural dialogue and understanding and forge productive international relationships.

"In that spirit of cooperation and community, the United States and Taiwan continue to enjoy strong bonds of friendship that have promoted our well-being, broadened our people's cultural horizons, and offered promising opportunities for economic growth. The Taiwan Relations Act has been instrumental in strengthening those bridges of friendship and in preserving peace and stability in Asia. As we celebrate this landmark legislation, I applaud your long-standing dedication to strengthening Taiwan-American cooperation and to exploring our common goals for the future. The trust and fellowship fostered by your efforts offer a vital opportunity for realizing a future of continued prosperity and lasting peace.
"Best wishes for a memorable observance."
