DOC.HEADLINE: MILITARY HARDWARE NOT SOLUTION TO CROSS-STRAIT DIFFERENCES: SHIRK
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, April 15 (CNA) (By Jay Chen and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: US Deputy Assistant Secretary of State for East Asia Susan Shirk on Wednesday urged both sides of the Taiwan Strait not to over-emphasize a military build-up, but should foster dialogue to solve their differences.

Although the United States is considering providing a missile defense to Taiwan based on standards of other defensive weapon sales, the Clinton administration calls for both sides of the Taiwan Strait to address differences through dialogue, Shirk said during a luncheon here marking the 20th anniversary of the enactment of the Taiwan Relations Act (TRA).
"Neither the People's Republic of China nor Taiwan would be served by an over emphasis on military hardware while neglecting the art of statesmanship," she noted.

"From the PRC's perspective, it should think twice about whether developing or upgrading any one type of weapon system will contribute to the PRC's security, or conversely, whether it might actually detract from that security by fostering tension, anxiety, political instability or an arms build up in the region," she said.

"At the heart of this calculation is the reality that the PRC cannot expect to pursue its defense policy in a vacuum. Its decisions on military modernization will generate responses from other actors," she said.

"Or, as Secretary Albright said recently in Beijing: Nothing would better serve China's interest than using its developing dialogue with Taiwan to build mutual confidence and reduce the perceived need for missiles or a missile defense," Shirk added.

From Taiwan's perspective, she said, the TRA's continuing guarantee that Taiwan will not lack a defensive capability enhances Taiwan's confidence and counterbalances anxieties over the PRC's military capability.
"There has been a lot of attention focused on a potential US theater missile defense for Taiwan. This is premature," she noted.
"A high-altitude TMD is still in development and is therefore not going to be provided to anyone in the immediate future," she added.

"Down the road, as with our consideration of sales of other defensive capabilities, our decisions on the provision of any sort of missile defense will be based on an assessment of Taiwan's legitimate defense needs."

"As we consider these needs, we will certainly take into account the security situation in the Strait, including PRC deployments, the pace and scope of dialogue between the PRC and Taiwan, and the overall regional security picture," she said.

"In this age of highly sophisticated weaponry, I think we are all sometimes prone to equate security with military capability," she said, adding that a durable peace will rest less on arms than success in addressing differences through dialogue on a mutually acceptable basis.
"Thus, whereas missiles and missile defense systems ultimately cannot in themselves secure peace and prosperity, dialogue and creative compromise can do so," she added.

She emphasized one aspect of the Clinton administration's policy that is firm and unchanging, saying that the administration continues to insist that cross-strait differences be resolved peacefully, as demonstrated in March 1996, when President Clinton ordered US carriers to the waters near Taiwan.
"Our belief is that dialogue between the PRC and Taiwan fosters an atmosphere in which tensions are reduced, misperceptions can be clarified, and common ground can be explored," Shirk said.

The exchange of visits under the SEF/ARATS framework, currently rich in symbolism but nascent in substance, has the potential to contribute to a peaceful resolution of difficult substantive differences, she continued.
She said the US administration has great confidence in the creativity of the people on Taiwan and the people on the mainland to give the dialogue real meanings.

"Imaginative thinking within this dialogue might result in new understandings or confidence building measures on any number of difficult topics. But only the participants on both sides of the strait can craft the specific solutions that balance their interests while addressing their most pressing concerns," she said.
Shirk's speech during the luncheon was also her testimony on the "TRA at 20" before the House International Relations Committee, Subcommittee on Asia and the Pacific, in the afternoon.

DOC.HEADLINE: US MUST INCREASE MILITARY COOPERATION WITH TAIPEI: HELMS
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, April 14 (CNA) (By Jay Chen and David Hsu)

TEXT.P: The United States must take steps to increase its military cooperation with Taipei and provide the country with a means of self-defense, Jesse Helms, chairman of Senate Foreign Relations Committee, said on Wednesday.

The United States also must make clear to Beijing in no uncertain terms that the United States considers peace in the Taiwan Strait, and the preservation of Taiwan's democratic, free market system to be a vital national security interest of the United States, Helms said.
Helms made the remarks at the "Conference on the 20th Anniversary of the Taiwan Relations Act" co-sponsored by the Heritage Foundation and the American Enterprise Institute.

The Taiwan Relations Act (TRA) declares that "the President and the Congress shall determine the nature and quantity of such defense articles and services based solely upon their judgment of the needs of Taiwan," Helms said, adding that, in other words, Beijing's point of view does not count.

In 1982, President Ronald Reagan signed the "August Communique" with Beijing in which he agreed to limit and gradually reduce US arms sales to Taiwan. Ever since the communique, Beijing has been browbeating the United States to cut arms sales to Taiwan.
Today, sensing the Clinton administration's boundless desire to appease them, the Chinese communists are ramping up the pressure as never before, Helms said.
Just last summer, President Bill Clinton caved in to Beijing's "three noes" demand. Helms said he is fearful that US arms sales to Taiwan be sacrificed next.

"I have introduced the Taiwan Security Enhancement Act to ensure people in Taiwan will have the equipment to maintain self-defense capabilities, by prohibiting any and all politically motivated reductions in arms sales to Taiwan pursuant to 1982 communique, and by authorizing the sale of a broad array of defense weaponry to Taiwan," Helms said.

Helms (Rep. NC) said the TRA calls for the United States to maintain a capacity to resist any resort to force or coercion that jeopardizes Taiwan. But this is difficult if the United States does not train, plan or communicate with Taiwan's military, he said.

The Senate heavyweight said the Taiwan Security Enhancement Act will change this by increasing Taiwan participation at US defense colleges, enhancing military exchanges, establishing direct communication between the two nation's militaries and authorizing the US executive branch to approve the sale of defense weapons to Taiwan.

The 77-year-old senator said, "For years we have been told by Red China's apologists that our insistence on democracy and human rights in China is a form of cultural imperialism. 'Asian values,' we are told, are different from 'Western values.' Chinese people, we are lectured, don't care about democracy and freedom -- 'Asian values' place order above freedom."

He said, however, the Republic of China on Taiwan has laid waste to that "Asian values" nonsense in the process of transferring from a society under martial law to a vibrant, multi-party democracy, with a spirited opposition, a free press and a flourishing civil society.

Helms presented the Taiwan Security Enhancement Act on March 24. The act has not yet been given a screening agenda. It is believed that a final edition of the act will have to be significantly amended because many articles in Helms' version violate the current US position on arms sales to Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, April 15, or the 29th day of the second month of the Year of the Rabbit according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1912: The British luxury liner the Titanic sinks after hitting an iceberg during her maiden voyage to New York. More than 1,500 people are feared drowned in the icy waters of the North Atlantic.
1923: Insulin is made available for general use by diabetics, when Canadian physiologist Sir Frederick Grant Banting shares a 1923 Nobel Prize for the discovery of insulin.
1927: Chiang Kai-shek, Commander-in-chief of the National Revolutionary Forces, organizes the national government in Nanking.
1942: Japanese artillery blasts US position on Corregidor in the Philippines.
1952: US President Harry S. Truman signs the Treaty of Peace between the United States and Japan.
1955: The first McDonald's hamburger store opens in San Bernardino, California.
1958: The first meeting of African independent nations is held in Accra, Ghana.
1959: US Secretary of State John Dulles resigns due to illness. The American diplomat and politician pursued a policy of opposition to the USSR largely through military and economic aid to American allies.
1966: A team of American virologists develop a vaccine for German measles, known medically as rubella.
1971: President Joseph Desire Mobutu of Congo and his wife arrive in Taipei for a visit.
1971: London and Beijing agree to the reopening of a telephone link between London and Shanghai which had been closed for 22 years.
1976: India and communist China resume diplomatic relations.
1980: Jean-Paul Sartre, the French writer and philosopher who declined the 1957 Nobel Prize for literature, dies in Paris at the age of 74. A leading existentialist, he wrote literary works such as the autobiographical novel "Nausea" and the play "No Exit," as well as philosophical volumes that include "Being and Nothingness."
1988: President Kim Il Sung receives 43,000 gifts as he celebrates his 76th birthday in style. The North Korean dictator died in 1994.
1989: Hu Yaobang, former general-secretary of China's Communist Party, dies of heart attack in Beijing at the age of 73. A democracy movement is launched by Beijing University students following his death.
1990: Greta Garbo, the Swedish-born American actress known for her reclusiveness and her performances in such films as "Queen Christina" in 1933 and "Camille" in 1937, dies in New York at the age of 84.
1994: The Uruguay Round of talks on General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT) concludes with ministers from more than 100 of the world's trading nations signing the GATT pact, the biggest market-opening treaty in history, and with the announcement of the setting up of the World Trade Organization (WTO).
1996: The US and Japan announce the closure of six more US military facilities on Okinawa.
1997: During the Haj, as 2 million Muslims gather for sacred rituals, a fire sweeps across an encampment outside Mecca, killing at least 300 pilgrims and injuring several thousand others.
1997: The first locally-developed Ching Kuo (IDF) tactical combat aircraft wing, a second generation of warplanes of the ROC Air Force, is founded at the Chingchuankang air force base in Taichung.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A wise and good man looks upwards in his aspirations; a fool looks downwards."

DOC.HEADLINE: US SHOULD INCLUDE TAIWAN IN TMD: EXPERTS

TEXT.P: Washington, April 14 (CNA): The United States should provide Taiwan with theater missile defense systems or equipment to maintain a capacity to defend against a military threat from mainland China, according to US China experts.

Meanwhile, Deputy Assistant Secretary of Defense Kurt Campbell told a conference on the 20th anniversary of the Taiwan Relations Act (TRA) that the United States is encouraged by cross-Strait dialogue and that it is in the US national interest to maintain peace and stability across the Taiwan Strait.

The Clinton administration is committed to providing Taiwan with necessary defensive arms in accordance with the TRA, said Campbell, adding that although it is not known how much patience Beijing has to seek a peaceful resolution, time is on Taiwan's side.

Paul Wolfowitz, dean of the Paul H. Nitze School of Advanced International Studies, at Johns Hopkins University, noted that Taiwan is the most important human rights issue in US-China relations and, therefore, it's important to provide Taiwan with defensive weapons, including a theater missile defense, in the face of a growing missile threat from mainland China.
Wolfowitz said Taiwan is not an obstacle to better US-China relations, it is an opportunity for the United States to preserve human rights for the people of Taiwan.
Richard Fisher, director of the Asian Studies Center at the Heritage Foundation, agreed that the US should continue to sell Taiwan defensive arms in order to prevent war in the Taiwan Strait.

Taiwan requires defensive weapons because the People's Liberation Army is modernizing its military and missile forces, attempting to exercise political pressures on Taiwan and force the island to accept its terms for peaceful reunification, said the policy analyst.

Fisher added that the US should provide Taiwan with submarines, which are defensive in character, and other technical superiority to maintain a cross-strait balance of air power, as well as a theater missile defense system to defend against Chinese missiles.

While expanding military exchange programs with mainland China, the United States should also try to balance the situation by changing its currently very restrictive military exchanges with Taiwan, added Fisher.
US Navy Adm. Eric McVadon said the United States should redouble its effort to persuade Beijing that use of missiles against Taiwan will harm China the most.

McVadon also suggested that leaders on both sides exchange visits for better mutual understanding, and that Beijing set a realistic timetable for mainland reforms, instead of a timetable for reunification, because the whole world is hoping to see a change towards democratization. (by Nelson Chung)

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA URGES INDIA, PAKISTAN TO REFRAIN FROM ARMS RACE
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 15 (CNA) (By Ben Wu) (By Peter Chen)

TEXT.P: Canberra, April 15 (CNA): Australia has called on both India and Pakistan to refrain from further heightening tensions in South Asia.
In a statement, Foreign Minister Alexander Downer said Australia deeply "regretted Pakistan's test of a Ghauri medium range ballistic missile" on Wednesday.
Pakistan conducted its test immediately after India made similar testing. Australia also condemned the Indian test.

Downer said the Pakistani test "raises the disturbing prospect of a missile arms race in South Asia and of nuclear weapon use by India and Pakistan, further heightening tensions in this unstable region of the world."
"I urge both countries to refrain from entering into a destabilizing missile arms race," he said.
Canberra earlier asked its envoy in Islamabad to urge Pakistan not to respond to India's testing by conducting a test of its own.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA CONCERNED OVER SENTENCING OF ANWAR
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 15 (CNA) (By Ben Wu) (By Peter Chen) (By Peter Chen)

TEXT.P: Canberra, April 15 (CNA): Australia has expressed its concern over the six-year imprisonment sentence given to Malaysia's former deputy prime minister Anwar Ibrahim in Kuala Lumpur on Wednesday.

In a statement, Foreign Minister Alexander Downer said: "I understand that Anwar Ibrahim's defense team will lodge an appeal in the next few days against the verdict and will also seek Anwar's release on bail pending an appeal."

"I understand that the appeal is likely to reflect criticism already made by Anwar Ibrahim's defense team -- namely concerning the conduct of the trial and concerns about possible judicial bias in favor of the prosecution," he said.

But Downer declined to make further comments, fearing that it could anger the Malaysian government under Prime Minister Mahathir, who severed ties with former Prime Minister Paul Keating after Keating called Mahathir "recalcitrant" for refusing to attend the APEC leaders' meeting in Seattle in 1993.
Prime Minister John Howard and Downer have since held talks with Mahathir and recovered considerable ties with that country.

"The Australian government made clear its hope and expectation that the trial would be conducted in accordance with the principles of natural justice, due process and the rule of law. We would hope that these principles applied in the appeals process," Downer said.

DOC.HEADLINE: THAILAND BANS IMPORTS TO FIGHT VIRUS

TEXT.P: Thailand has temporarily barred a variety of animal imports from Malaysia, Australia and New Zealand to prevent the outbreak of a deadly brain disease, the Ministry of Public Health announced here Thursday.

The Thai government has imposed a temporary ban on imports of pigs, horses, cats, and pork from Malaysia after the three types of animals were found to be carriers of a new strain of the deadly virus, Dr. Vichai Chokvivat, an expert of the ministry's Department of Communicable Disease Control, said.
Since a Hendra strain was found in Australia, the Thai government has exercise more caution by also temporarily banning cattle imports from Australia and New Zealand.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEWFOUNDLANDERS GIVE ZHU COLD WELCOME

TEXT.P: Mainland China's Premier Zhu Rongji arrived in St. John's, Newfoundland, to a cool reception Wednesday, the first stop of his six-day visit to Canada.

Conspicuous among those absent from the reception line was the mayor of the capital city, Andy Wells. To protest China's human rights record, Wells forwent a tradition of presenting Zhu with the keys to the city.
"This Chinese leader should be informed that if you wish to trade and do business with Canada, we expect you to start substantially improving your human-rights record," said Wells.

The mayor stressed, "We are a democratic society. We don't like a government that oppresses, tortures, murders, incarcerates, locks up citizens, and commits all sorts of heinous crime against their (own) people."
Human-rights groups in St. John's also protested Zhu's visit. But the Canada-Tibet Committee's plan to fly the Tibetan flag over City Hall while Zhu visits was abruptly scrapped.

James Pilgrim, a spokesperson for the committee, said the group was trying to draw attention to China's worsening human-rights record. The flag plan was first endorsed by Wells, who later changed his mind.
The mayor explained that he was warned by contacts in the business community that if the flag was not lowered, Zhu would cancel his trip to Canada.
Still, Wells said, "It's just one small protest to remind the Canadian government that not all Canadians support shameless pandering to China for business contracts."
Canada's Trade Minister Sergio Marchi said Canada will play a key role in helping China with its bid for the World Trade Organization membership. Marchi will meet with Zhu Thursday in Ottawa.
China was Canada's fourth largest trading partner last year, according to the Foreign Affairs Department, with two-way trade reaching almost C$10 billion.
Canadian activists want their Prime Minister Jean Chretien to raise human rights matters with the Chinese leader.

Earlier this week the Canadian chapter of Amnesty International made a plea. Its executive secretary Roger Clark said, "At a time when the UN Commission on Human Rights is discussing human rights around the world, it really behooves the Canadian leadership to make strong public statements to the visiting premier."

DOC.HEADLINE: ZHU URGED TO FREE PANCHEN LAMA

TEXT.P: Canadian Prime Minister Jean Chretien should press Chinese Premier Zhu Rongji for information about the safety and whereabouts of the nine-year-old Gendhun Choekyi Nyima, the 11th Panchen Lama of Tibet, also known as the world's youngest political prisoner.
Chretien is to host a dinner in honor of Zhu Thursday and meet with him again on Friday in Ottawa.

The Panchen Lama will celebrate his tenth birthday on April 25, 1999 and will begin his fourth year of incommunicado detention on May 17. Although Chinese authorities have admitted holding the boy, no international observer has been able to see him and there is no evidence that he is still alive.
The child was detained with his family in 1995, only days after the Dalai Lama announced his recognition in a centuries old tradition.
"No amount of international pressure seems to be enough for the Chinese to free this innocent child," said Thubten Samdup, president of the Canada Tibet Committee.

"The Chinese believe our government will sacrifice its values in order to access their market and Tibet's vast mineral resources. It's time we showed them otherwise by taking a principled position on this issue," Samdup added.
An international postcard campaign is underway demanding that authorities free the Panchen Lama. Tibetan protesters will attempt to deliver the cards to Zhu when he visits Toronto late Friday.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TYCOONS WELCOME VISIT BY PENSIONS 2000 FUND MANAGERS

TEXT.P: A visit to Taiwan by delegates of Pensions 2000 Corp. of the United States was favorably received Thursday by business and capital executives in Taiwan.
Morris Chang, chairman and CEO of Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co., described the arrival in Taiwan of the 100-strong US retirement fund executives and managers as "remarkably significant."

Chang, who himself has pursued advanced studies and worked in the United States for years, said most American fund managers seek to make only long-term stock market investments, adding that such a mentality is needed in Taiwan.

"Their visit here, mainly to inspect the Taiwan stock market and assess its investment potential, will eventually help enrich the capital gains of the local bourse, and will help rectify undesirable practices in the market as well," he said.

Benny Hu, president of China Development Industrial Bank Inc., said Pensions 2000, which includes some of the United States' top-100 government-run and privately run pension fund trusts, has been financially influential in many countries.

Hu, who has experience cooperating with such pension fund trusts, said that once a fund decides to invest in a certain market, it usually stays in the market for a long time and has a positive impact on the market's growth.

Hu is currently attending a two-day Pensions 2000 conference -- dubbed "Access to Asia" -- in Taipei that began Thursday and ends Friday. He spoke at the event Thursday on relations between Taiwan's capital market and high-tech development.

With a high caliber workforce, a healthy capital market, strong entrepreneurial capabilities, tax privileges and commendable technological creativity, Taiwan is capable of becoming a gateway to high-tech investment in Asia, he said.

Eric Tong-sheng Wu, chairman of Taiwan Security Co. and a deputy of the National Assembly, said the holding of the Pensions 2000 Conference in Taipei will help improve the image of the Taiwan stock market among institutional fund operators and managers from abroad.

Wu said that in the past, the presence of foreign capital in Taiwan and Hong Kong varied greatly. If Pensions 2000 Corp., which currently manages about US$1 trillion in funds, were to consider investing only 1 percent of its funds in the Taiwan stock market, the local bourse would get a real shot in the arm, he added.

During their stay in Taiwan, the Pensions 2000 delegates -- most of them executives and fund managers of public and private fund trusts in the United States who are either specialized in high-tech investment or experts in foreign currency trading -- are expected to gain an in-depth knowledge of Taiwan's economic fundamentals and of the performance of the island's financial sector, including the stock market.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI HOPES TO JOIN WTO BY END OF 1999: CEPD

TEXT.P: Taipei hopes to join the World Trade Organization (WTO) by the end of this year, in spite of the fact that there are still lots of issues that need to be resolved, said a ranking economic official Thursday.

Chiang Pin-kung, chairman of the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) under the Executive Yuan, also said Taipei's "no haste, be patient" policy regarding Taiwan investment in the Chinese mainland is not likely to change after Taipei's entry into the world trade body.
Taipei hopes it can enter the WTO at the same time, on the same day or even in the same session as Beijing, Chiang said.
Chiang made the remarks when he answered questions during interpellations at the Legislative Yuan.
To date, none of the WTO member states that requested talks with Taipei has demanded a change to its "no haste, be patient" policy, he said.
The United States also would like to see the two sides of the Taiwan Strait join the WTO on the same day, said Chiang.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR UP

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar surged NT$0.052 against the greenback on the Taipei market Thursday, closing at 32.9.
The local currency opened at the day's low of 32.935, had a high of 32.838.
The interbank US dollar trading reached US$888.5 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO EXPAND FOREIGN INVESTMENT PRIVILEGES: LEE

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui on Thursday said that Taiwan will provide incentives for foreign investments, without any undue restrictions, in hopes of developing the island into a regional financial center in Asia.

Lee revealed the plan in a written address to the opening of the "Access to Asia" conference in Taipei, attended by a delegation organized by consultancy Pensions 2000 and comprising nearly 100 managers and executives of foreign investment funds. The delegation has come to Taiwan to learn about its stock market and financial sector.

Lee said that the delegation, through its fact-finding visit, may come to recognize that Taiwan presents "a unique perspective toward a better understanding of investing successfully in the Pacific Rim."

He pointed out that the Republic of China, like many other developed economies, is well prepared to enter the next millennium. It is willing to continue to strengthen Taiwan's financial role in the region and to serve as a proactive player in helping Asia's economy to fully recover.

To reach that goal, Lee said, many measures aimed at economic and financial reform have been enacted, including ones to further develop technology-based industries, to improve Taiwan's system of higher education, to strengthen environmental protection and to gain entry into the World Trade Organization.

Lee said he welcomes investment in Taiwan by members of the visiting Pensions 2000 delegation, saying their investments would create a long-term tie between the Republic of China and the United States.

The delegation, headed by Pensions 2000 Corp. Chairman Philip Schaefer, arrived in Taiwan Wednesday for a two-day conference and to study the island's financial and economic sectors. The funds the delegates represent manage some US$1 trillion in assets.

As pension funds seek to provide safe and stable returns for members, pension fund managers are generally more conservative than those who manage other types of investment funds, local stock brokers said. If the visiting US fund managers were to invest in Taiwan's stock market, it would help to improve the market's stability, they said.

DOC.HEADLINE: AIT LAUDS TAIWAN'S CRACKDOWN ON COUNTERFEITING

TEXT.P: The Taipei Office of the American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) on Thursday lauded Taiwan for its efforts to eradicate commercial piracy.

The de facto US embassy in Taiwan's recognition came after local law enforcement officers cracked two companies in the central Taiwan county of Taichung, which allegedly had counterfeited American and Japanese brand-named golf equipment.
Under the command of the Taichung Prosecutor's Office, Ministry of Justice Investigation Bureau agents cracked the two golf equipment counterfeiting companies on Wednesday.
Law enforcement officers confiscated a large amount of phony golf clubs and parts, worth an estimated NT$200 million (US$6.06 million) in market value.

The heads of the two companies, identified as Liu Tai-chi and Chang Chu-ping, were charged with violating the country's trademark law. After extensive questioning, the duo were released on NT$100,000 and NT$80,000 bails, respectively, late Wednesday night.
Concerned about the anti-counterfeiting operations, the AIT sent staff members to the Taichung Prosecutor's Office Wednesday evening to collect first-hand information about the case.

In addition to expressing appreciation of Taiwan's efforts to eradicate commercial piracy, the AIT officials also urged local law enforcement authorities to continue their anti-counterfeiting crusade in order to protect legitimate rights and interests of genuine manufacturers.

The newly seized counterfeit goods, including both finished and semi-finished golf equipment, carried such American labels as Callaway, S-Yard, Honma, Fila and Spalding, as well as Japanese brand Mizuno.

Genuine golf equipment of these brands can fetch hundreds of thousands of New Taiwan dollars per set or even a million NT dollars, but a counterfeit set was sold for NT$20,000 to NT$40,000. AIT officials said such practice has seriously affected American companies' rights and interests.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER TAIPEI MAYOR SEES 24 MEN ON PLEBISCITE HUNGER STRIKE

TEXT.P: Former Taipei Mayor Chen Shui-bian on Thursday morning went to see the 24 men participating in a hunger strike in front of the legislature in support of legislation governing the holding of plebiscites.
Chen said he supported the actions of the men, whose health was said to be stable on Thursday, the sixth day of the strike.
Chen said that plebiscites are a worldwide trend that cannot be stopped. He urged President Lee Teng-hui to listen to the true voices of the Taiwan people.

The major opposition Democratic Progressive Party stalwart paid tribute to the 24 men participating in the strike and praised them for striving to bring about the establishment of plebiscite provisions in the constitution.
He also urged more people to be concerned about the men's actions and to give them moral support.

DOC.HEADLINE: SEF OFFICIAL DENIED ENTRY TO MAINLAND CHINA

TEXT.P: The Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) on Thursday expressed regret over the failure by its mainland Chinese counterpart to help arrange for one of its senior officials to visit mainland China.

SEF Deputy Secretary-General Wu Hsin-hsing said another SEF deputy secretary-general, Chang Liang-jen, was originally scheduled to leave for mainland China on April 15 to take part in a golf tournament to be sponsored by Fuzhou- and Gueilin-based Taiwan businessmen.

SEF faxed a message to the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS) on April 6, asking it to help arrange for Chang's visit, Wu said. "However, Chang's scheduled departure date has now already passed, but we still have not received any response from ARATS. We regret this and are concerned about the incident," Wu said.

As part of its efforts to substantiate the four-point consensus reached between the two intermediary bodies during a high-profile meeting of SEF Chairman Koo Chen-fu and ARATS President Wang Daohan last October, Wu said, SEF has never hesitated to help arrange for ARATS staff members and mainland officials in charge of Taiwan affairs at various levels to visit Taiwan.

Wu urged ARATS to faithfully abide by the four-point consensus reached at the Koo-Wang meeting, which requires SEF and ARATS to work together to boost bilateral exchanges and constructive interaction based on the principle of reciprocity.
As for possible reasons behind Beijing's rejection of Chang's application to visit, Wu said mainland China often regards SEF-ARATS interaction from a political perspective.

Wu said ARATS has also not yet responded to SEF's proposal that Jan Jyh-horng, also an SEF deputy secretary-general, lead a delegation of officials to Beijing to discuss details concerning a planned visit to Taiwan by ARATS President Wang this autumn.
SEF and ARATS are quasi-official intermediary bodies authorized by their respective governments to handle cross-strait exchanges in the absence of official ties.

DOC.HEADLINE: PENSIONS 2000 LOOKS TO INCREASE INVESTMENT IN TAIWAN BOURSE

TEXT.P: Pensions 2000, which manages a combined total of US$8 trillion worth of pension funds, is looking forward to increasing investment in Taiwan's stock market, said Pensions 2000 Corp. Chairman Philip Schaefer on Thursday.

Addressing a two-day Pensions 2000 conference, dubbed "Access to Asia," which opened Thursday in Taipei, Schaefer said that as various Pensions 2000 fund trusts are managed and operated by different experts, it is hard for him to speculate exactly how much Pensions 2000 will invest in the Taiwan bourse in the near future.

He is positive, however, that Pensions 2000 will increase its investment in Taiwan's bourse after it gains a better understanding of the island's economic fundamentals and stock market development, Schaefer said.

With its outstanding economic performance, high education standards and political stability, Taiwan is an area that Pensions 2000 could not afford to ignore when it organized its "Access to Asia" investment-seeking roadshow, Schaefer noted.

He said Pensions 2000, which includes both private pension funds and funds run by city and state governments, is looking for long-term investment opportunities, not speculative ones. Funds in the group have invested across the United State, Europe and the Asia-Pacific region.

An "Access to Asia" seminar has already taken place in Seoul, and another will be held in Hong Kong following the Taipei gathering. Through the seminars Pensions 2000 members hope to further their understanding of regional markets, and the information obtained during the seminars will be used by the group for reference when making decisions on fresh investments, he said.

Schaefer said the seminar will help those trusts and funds that have already invested in Taiwan to further understand Taiwan's economic fabric, and it will help those who are unfamiliar with Taiwan's investment climate to obtain first-hand information.
President Lee Teng-hui offered congratulations via a written message on the opening of the seminar, touted as the biggest seminar on foreign capital ever held in Taiwan.

Ranking Republic of China officials, including Economic Affairs Minister Wang Chih-kang and Schive Chi, vice chairman of the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development, were invited to deliver speeches during the opening session of the seminar.
About 100 senior executive and managers of US, Canada and European funds, who represent more than US$1 trillion, are attending the seminar.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI CONTINUES ITS EFFORTS TO PROMOTE CROSS-STRAIT RELATIONS: MOEA

TEXT.P: Taipei hopes to join the World Trade Organization (WTO) at an early date and will continue its efforts to promote cross-strait relations in the meantime, said the head of the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) Thursday.

Minister Wang Chih-kang said in a written speech delivered at the "Access to Asia" conference now being held in Taipei that improving the domestic economy and promoting international cooperation will be the basis of Taiwan's economic and trade policy.

The conference, sponsored by Pensions 2000, is being attended by 115 representatives and managers of US and Canadian pension funds. They arrived from Seoul to take part in the second leg of a series of seminars designed to familiarize them with the capital markets and economies of South Korea, Taiwan and Hong Kong.

In view of the fact that a stable cross-strait relationship is crucial to foreign investment in Taiwan, Taipei will certainly follow a policy that will ensure stable economic and trade development between the two sides, Wang noted.
The economics minister indicated that Taipei hopes to enter the WTO before the organization holds its next round of trade talks next year.

Taiwan has concluded bilateral negotiations with the 26 WTO members that requested such negotiations. To date, only Canada and Hong Kong have not signed a formal agreement with Taiwan, observed Wang, adding that he hopes the agreements can be completed by May.

Improving Taiwan's domestic economy is one of the main ways in which the MOEA hopes to attract foreign investment to Taiwan, and the ministry is working to improve Taiwan's investment environment and strengthen the management capacity of Taiwan enterprises, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: MACEDONIAN LIQUOR VENDORS SEEK TRADE OPPORTUNITIES IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: A Macedonian trade delegation called on the Ministry of Economic Affairs on Thursday to seek trade opportunities for the Balkan nation's Almako liquor.
Received by Vice Economics Minister Lin Yi-fu, Ivan Cvetkovski, chairman of Macedonia's main Almako liquor factory, expressed the factory's willingness to export Almako liquor to Taiwan.
Members of the delegation also hope that Taiwan businessmen will set up banks and buy buildings to be used as trade centers in Macedonia.

Lin said Almako liquor is the best in Macedonia, although bottles for the liquor are made outside the country. Because of the liquor's quality and its high production costs, it is the most expensive liquor in Macedonia, he said.

Costs could be lowered -- and the liquor made more competitive on the Taiwan market -- if it were brought into Taiwan in barrels and bottled locally. Talks on the matter are underway between the Taiwan Tobacco and Wine Monopoly Bureau and the Almako liquor factory's Cvetkovski.
As for the prospect of Taiwan businessmen buying buildings in Macedonia for use as trade centers, Lin said the matter must be further evaluated.

Lin said Macedonia's banking sector is underdeveloped and that while the idea of Taiwan banks entering into joint ventures with Macedonian banks is worth consideration, it may be more convenient for Taiwan banks to set up branches there.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S SEMICONDUCTOR GODFATHER CALLS FOR INNOVATION

TEXT.P: Taiwan's semiconductor godfather said Thursday that Taiwan must encourage innovation and ingenuity to maintain its mrket niches and sustain its economic growth.
Morris Chang, chairman of Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Corp. (TSMC), made the call in a speech delivered at National Taiwan University.
Chang said vision, values and strategy are the three pillars of business management.
Chang said a company must have visions to inpire innovation and stimulate corporate growth.
Noting that innovation is the smartest business strategy, Chang said local companies must invest more in research and development (R&D) to sustain development.
As small- and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) form the backbone of Taiwan's industry, most Taiwan companies pay little attention to cultivate their own corporate culture.

Chang said in most cases, only large-sized enterprises can afford to support R&D projects to nurture new inventions. As Taiwan lacks large-sized and globalized companies, it lags behind in technological development.
Chang said SMEs are usually conservative and prefer to copy successful technology and management strategy invented by advanced countries.
"We must drop this kind of mentality. Otherwise, we can never become a true leader in any high-tech fields," Chang stressed.

He went on to say that visions can be changed once every four to five years, but values should never be changed. "As for strategy, it is key to business success. And the wisest strategy is innovation."

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC GOVERNMENT SPOKESMAN COMMENTS ON TRA
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, April 14 (CNA) (By Jay Chen and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Although the implementation of the Taiwan Relations Act has been successful over the past two decades, the relations it seeks to govern can never replace diplomatic relations, a Republic of China spokesman said Wednesday.

Chen Chien-jen, director-general of the Government Information Office, made the remarks when he attended a conference marking the 20th anniversary of the TRA, which defines the framework of relations between the Republic of China and the United States in the absence of diplomatic ties.

Chen, speaking at a conference co-sponsored by the Heritage Foundation and the American Enterprise Institute in Washington, D.C., said the ambiguity in the TRA, which was enacted in 1979, has provided flexibility. Nevertheless, the act also has inherent drawbacks, he said.

Chen said that the TRA states that the United States will not accept a forcible invasion of Taiwan by mainland China, but it does not explicitly state how the United States would respond if Beijing uses force.

Chen, speaking of the deficiencies of the TRA, noted that the US government, bowing under pressure from mainland China, has restricted arms sales to Taiwan and stated that it will not support Taiwan's entry into international organizations in which statehood is a requirement.
He said the US moves go against the spirit of the TRA and have to do with the ambiguity in the language of the TRA.

Chen said that no matter how good the language of the TRA is, the relations it seek to govern can never replace diplomatic relations. The United States' six-point statement in 1982 and its 1994 Taiwan policy review were necessary but insufficient, he said.

The United States has not agreed to hold prior consultations with mainland China on arms sales to the Republic of China. The United States will not play any mediation role between Taipei and Beijing. The United States has not agreed to revise the Taiwan Relations Act. The United States has not altered its position regarding sovereignty over Taiwan, and the United States will not exert pressure on Taiwan to negotiate with mainland China.
Chen also said that when the Taiwan Relations Act was first enacted, nobody thought Taiwan would become fully democratic in such a short period of time.

Some believe that Taiwan's democratization is a step toward independence and have claimed Taiwan is a troublemaker, he said. He stressed that Taiwan's move toward democracy has been in the interest of the United States and its values.
Chen said that he is basically positive in regard to the results of the TRA, saying that the US law has been unique, pragmatic, flexible, elastic and continuous.
Meanwhile, debate over the enactment of a plebiscite law in Taiwan has also spread to the conference, with Chen and Parris Chang, who is also taking part in the conference, at adds with each other.

Chen said that the Legislative Yuan is currently discussing what is the best way to implement referendum rights, adding that he does not think that plebiscites would be in the best interests of the people in Taiwan.
He said plebiscites are not the only option, and that in deciding whether to implement them, the sensitivity of relations between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait need to be considered.

DOC.HEADLINE: ARMY UNITS BEGIN ON-SITE TRAINING FOR MID-MAY MANEUVERS ON PENGHU

TEXT.P: Several army units involved in the "Cheng Kung Operation," to be held on Penghu in mid-May, began on-site practice on Thursday, said the Republic of China Defense Ministry.
A spokesman for the Defense Ministry said that infantry and light cannon units conducted separate training exercises on Shanshui Beach in the morning.
The units training activities were conducted separately, he said, adding that a rehearsal for the operation will be held on May 6.
The medium-scale operation, code named Cheng Kung Operation or "Operation Success," will feature an exhibition of military equipment, a parade and counterattack operations on the beach.

DOC.HEADLINE: PHILIPPINE PRESIDENT DENIES RUMORS OF CABINET RESHUFFLE

TEXT.P: Philippine President Joseph Estrada reiterated on Thursday his confidence in every member of his Cabinet, as he called for a stop to speculation about Cabinet changes.
The president belied reports that Secretary Andrew Gonzalez of the Department of Education, Culture and Sports, and Commissioner Rufus Rodriguez of the Bureau of Immigration are on the way out.
"I hope there will be no more speculation about the Cabinet. They are performing well, each and every one of them," Estrada said.

DOC.HEADLINE: PHILIPPINE REBELS TO RELEASE MILITARY OFFICERS: REPORT

TEXT.P: Philippine President Joseph Estrada said on Thursday he has been assured by Senator Loren Legarda that two military officers held hostage by communist rebels will be release on Friday in Mindanao.

Legarda is a member of an independent third-party group led by Davao Archbishop Fernando Capalla which negotiated with the Netherlands-based National Democratic Front (NDF) for the release of the officers.
According to reports, the NDF has committed to push through with the scheduled release of the two officers, despite the government's firm stand of release without preconditions.
The NDF had earlier asked the government to free 51 people who were among those apprehended by the military during a previous encounter with communist rebels.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIAN OLYMPIC ORGANIZERS LOOKING TO CUT COSTS

TEXT.P: Organizers of the Sydney 2000 Olympic Games are turning to sponsors to secure a fifth of their permanent staff for free in a bid to contain costs ahead of a likely sponsorship shortfall.

The Sydney Organizing Committee for the Olympic Games (SOCOG) is launching a campaign to second up to 500 staff from Australian businesses after failing to raise funds of US$139 million to meet the shortfall in the Olympic budget.

SOCOG chief executive Sandy Hollway confirmed that the campaign could help cut the costs in billing for the Olympic Games in September 2000 because sponsors are now reluctant to donate after the International Olympic Committee was hit by a bribery scandal.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC DELEGATE ELECTED PECC DIRECTOR-GENERAL

TEXT.P: A senior member of the Chinese Taipei Committee of the Pacific Economic Cooperation Council (PECC) was unanimously elected director-general of PECC at a standing committee meeting in Canberra.
Dr. Mignon Man-jung Chan, now director of research and analysis at the APEC Secretariat in Singapore, was unanimously chosen by the standing committee members of PECC to hold the three-year position.

In an interview with CNA, PECC Chairman Roberto Romulo said: "We are delighted about the appointment of Dr. Mignon Chan. The Standing Committee selected her for this position on the basis of her experience and outstanding qualifications. We feel that she represents the new breed that will help move the PECC agenda forward."

DOC.HEADLINE: SERBIAN AUSTRALIANS HARASSED

TEXT.P: Hundreds of Serbian Australians in Brisbane and Melbourne have been harassed, and threatened, as Canberra seeks help from UN Secretary-General Kofi Annan to help secure the release of two Australian aid workers charged in Yugoslavia with spying for NATO.

Father Rode Radan of St. Lazarus' Serbian Orthodox Church said there were unconfirmed reports of an explosion at a Serbian church in Brisbane, and graffiti and smashed windows at an Orthodox church in Melbourne.

Foreign Minister Alexander Downer on Wednesday night wrote a letter to Annan asking his assistance in helping to secure the release of Steve Pratt and Peter Wallace, the two CARE Australia workers who were charged earlier this week with spying for NATO in Yugoslavia.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCK INDEX SOARS TO 1999 ACME

TEXT.P: Taiwan share prices climbed to their highest point this year on Thursday, closing at 7,498.17, up 99.52 points, or 1.9 percent, from Wednesday.
Dealers said the rally was boosted by strong foreign buying and by Wall Street's posting another record high on Wednesday.
A visit by a delegation of more than 100 US pension fund managers seeking investment opportunities provided additional stimulus to the local stock market.
Thursday's volume was 3.89 billion shares worth of NT$139.89 billion (US$4.24 billion). Gainers outnumbered decliners 266 to 164, with 68 stocks unchanged.
Among the eight major categories, all but construction shares -- which remained unchanged -- closed higher, with textile issues rising the most at 3.5 percent.

Foodstuff stocks, which were the second-most actively traded issues, ended up 3.4 percent, followed by financial shares, which rose 2.4 percent; cement issues, 2.3 percent; plastic and chemical shares, 2.2 percent; textile stocks, 0.4 percent and electronic shares, 0.1 percent.
Meanwhile, trading on the over-the-counter market opened higher and closed higher in Thursday's session. The index closed at 170.96 with a turnover of NT$9.36 billion.

TAIEX Capitalization Weighted Stock Index futures for April were buoyed by the stock market's strong performance and by foreign investors' interest in Taiwan's stock market. April futures closed 115 points higher to finish at 7,480, with 3,417 contract transactions.

TAIEX Index Futures for May rose 119 points to 7,519 with 1,724 contract transactions. Those for June were up 90 to 7,510 with 57 contract transactions; those for September moved up 74 to 7,499 with 11 contract transactions; and those for December climbed 15 to 7,485 with 9 contract transactions.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC LEGISLATORS ANGRY ABOUT REMARKS BY MAINLAND CHINA PREMIER

TEXT.P: Unfriendly remarks about Taiwan by mainland Chinese Premier Zhu Rongji have brought rebukes from several legislators in Taipei, who suggested the cancellation of a visit this autumn by the mainland's top negotiator with Taiwan.
Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairman Su Chi faced the wrath of the lawmakers on a Thursday meeting, where he also faced argument over the government's mainland China policy.

The legislators were angry with Zhu's refusal to renounce the use of force against Taiwan, and irritated by Zhu's using the example of the American civil war as an analogy during his visit to the United States earlier this month.

There is no sign of any goodwill toward Taipei on the part of Beijing, said Hou Huei-hsien, as he asked Su how Taiwan can extend a warm welcome in the face of mainland China's cold shoulder. Instead, he said, Taiwan should refuse a planned visit by Wang Daohan, chairman of the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait, the intermediary body founded by Beijing to handle cross-strait exchanges in the absence of official ties.

Su said although he agreed with Hou's observation, the government regards exchanges between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait as an important factor which can help the promotion of better cross-strait relations. Therefore, Wang will be welcomed, and it is hoped that his visit will give him a better understanding of Taiwan, Su said.

He stressed that the MAC will not manage cross-strait affairs in an emotional manner, and noted that the council has mapped out a blueprint for the resolution of cross-strait disputes, and is trying to turn it into a reality.

DOC.HEADLINE: HONG KONG EXPECTED TO EASE VISA RESTRICTIONS ON TAIWAN VISITORS

TEXT.P: The Hong Kong government is mulling a further easing of restrictions on visa requirements for Taiwan visitors, in a bid to lure more tourists, local media reported on Thursday.

Citing sources from the Hong Kong Tourism Association, the reports said the authorities are considering granting three-day visa-free treatment to Taiwan visitors as part of their efforts to attract a greater number of tourists from the island.
However, the report added that the measure is just a preliminary plan, which will take a long time to implement.
Hong Kong has always been a major overseas destination for Taiwan travelers, who made more than 1.8 million visits to Hong Kong last year, trailing only behind visitors from mainland China.
Currently, Taiwan travelers who hold valid travel permits to proceed to mainland China are allowed to stay for one week in transit in the former British colony.

DOC.HEADLINE: MACEDONIAN FOREIGN MINISTRY NAMES FIRST ENVOY TO TAIPEI

TEXT.P: The Macedonian Foreign Ministry on Thursday appointed Vera Modanu, director of the Asian Affairs Department, as first envoy to the Republic of China.
Modanu, who studied Chinese literature and history at the University of Beijing between 1973-1978, speaks fluent Mandarin.
Meeting with the Taiwan media, she said she was happy with the appointment, adding that she will assume her duties in Taipei next week.

Modanu has been working with the Asian Affairs Department since the independence of Macedonia in 1991. Before that, she worked for the Yugoslavian government and a state-run trade company for about 10 years.
The ROC and Macedonia established diplomatic relations in January this year. The first ROC envoy to Macedonia, Peter Cheng, arrived in Skopje to assume his post this week.

DOC.HEADLINE: MANILA ASKED TO REDUCE NUMBER OF AT-LARGE WORKERS IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) on Thursday asked the Philippine representative office here take measures to reduce the number of runaway Filipino workers in Taiwan.

In a meeting with the Taipei-based Manila Economic and Cultural Office (MECO, CLA demanded MECO's Filipino workers Center achieve the goal within three months, or it will slash the current level of quota on labor imports from the Philippines.

Lin Tsong-ming, director-general of CLA's Employment and Vocational Training Administration, said MECO must take effective measures to help improve the situation, as Filipino laborers employed in Taiwan have registered a higher percentage of running away from their workplace.

Lin revealed that the government is planning to import foreign workers from other countries in the short term, adding that the planned move will keep pressure on the Philippines, one of Taiwan's major sources of foreign laborers, to pay heed to the problem.

As of the end of February, a combined 5.41 percent of the overall legal Filipino laborers working in Taiwan have been at large, exceeding the rates of 4.66 percent and 4.65 percent posted respectively by Malaysian and Thai workers, according to Lin. Indonesian workers registered the lowest percentage of 3.37 percent.
Currently there are 270,000 foreign laborers working in Taiwan, with a vast majority of them coming from Thailand, the Philippines, Malaysia and Indonesia in that order.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN IS WILLING TO HELP EL SALVADOR DEVELOP AGRICULTURE

TEXT.P: Salvadoran Vice President-elect Carlos Quintanilla Schmidt met with Chairman Peng Tso-kwei of the Council of Agriculture on Thursday, and expressed the hope that Taiwan will help his country develop agriculture.
Peng said that the ROC is very much willing to extend assistance in agricultural development, adding that Taiwan is also promoting fishery cooperation with El Salvador.
During the talks with Peng, Carlos Quintanilla Schmidt expressed appreciation for the outstanding contribution made by the ROC agricultural technical mission in El Salvador.
He said that during the campaign for last March's election for president and vice president, he promised to step up agricultural development and improve the living standard of the farming villages.
The vice president-elect, who will be sworn in on June 1, said he hopes El Salvador will learn from Taiwan in agricultural development.

Peng indicated the Taipei government's willingness to continue providing agricultural experience for El Salvador, and went on to say that his council is seeking to engage in fishery cooperation with El Salvador.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN BUSINESSMAN TO DEVELOP INDUSTRIAL PARK IN HONG KONG

TEXT.P: A Taiwan company has bought more than a hundred hectare of land in Hong Kong with the purpose to build an industrial park at the cost of NT$20 billion (5 billion Hong Kong dollar), said Tien Chang-lin, chairman of the Commission on Innovation and Technology (CIT) on Wednesday.
Tien would not identify the Taiwan firm, saying only that it is a world-class business group, with close business ties with mainland China.

Tien said the business group has several factories in the Pearl River Delta, Kwangdung Province, with more than 100,000 employees. It also has investment in Hong Kong and owns a Hong Kong-listed company.

It is learned that the Taiwan-based group took over a plot of land in New Territories from a cash-strapped Japanese firm about six months ago. The business group intended to develop manufacturing industry with high-returns on this land and is trying to seek local developing companies as its partners to help it penetrate into local market.
Tien said the firm eyes Hong Kong as a ideal place for industries with high added value owing to the cheap labor cost at adjoining Pearl River Delta.
The Taiwan business group has presented a developing plan to the CIT for approval, said Tien.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies Friday are as follows:
The Central Daily News:
The United States urged Beijing to stop missile deployment against Taiwan.
The China Times:
The seven government-run banks' overdue loan ratios set new highs in the first quarter of the year.
The United Daily News:
Top mainland Chinese envoy Wang Daohan will meet ROC President Lee Teng-hui when he visits Taiwan.
The Liberty Times:
Premier Vincent Siew agreed to reconsider the proposed fund reduction issues after Taipei and Kaohsiung mayors angrily protested the Cabinet's tentative decision to cut the shares of total government tax revenues to the two special municipalities.
The Commons Daily:
Taipei and Kaohsiung mayors blasted the Cabinet's decision to slash the shares of tax revenues to the two cities.
The China Post:
Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou and Kaohsiung Mayor Frank Hsieh unite in protest over fund reductions.
The China News:
Ma, Hsieh blast budget cuts.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC NEEDS DEFENSE IN THE FACE OF GROWING BEIJING MILITARY THREAT
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, April 15 (CNA) (By Jay Chen and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: The Republic of China on Taiwan will have to bolster its defenses if Beijing continues to intimidate the island with missile threats, ROC government spokesman Chen Chien-jen said here on Thursday.

Speaking at the "Morning Newsmaker" press conference at the National Press Club in Washington, D.C., Chen said he fully agrees with the view that it is premature to talk about whether the United States would provide Taiwan with a Theater Missile Defense (TMD) system, but he said Taiwan may be forced to beef up its defense capabilities in the face of growing military threats, particularly missile threats, from mainland China.

Chen said the TMD system, which is still in development, is only one of several weapons systems that Taiwan may consider acquiring, adding that any such acquisition would, of course, be up to the government of the United States to decide.

What matters most to the ROC government is how to guard Taiwan's security and how to protect its people from mainland Chinese threats, Chen noted, adding that Taiwan will seek defensive capabilities that can adequately protect the island's existence and secure sustainable development.

If mainland China persists in threatening Taiwan, then Taiwan will consider the US-proposed TMD system, as well as other defensive systems. This position is reasonable and one to which both the United States and Taiwan should agree, he said.

In response to a question regarding Taiwan's entry into the World Trade Organization (WTO), Chen noted that Taiwan has completed bilateral and multilateral consultations with 26 WTO member states with only Canada and Hong Kong not yet having signed a formal agreement with Taiwan.
Further progress on Taiwan's WTO entry is expected in the near future, he said.

As to the contested Spratly island chain, Chen said the Republic of China has always claimed sovereignty over the island group in the South China Sea, but it has also insisted that disputes over the island chain's sovereignty be resolved peacefully by all the countries that have laid claim to the islands. Taiwan has also called for the joint exploration of natural resources in the region, he said.
He also reiterated Taiwan's opposition to its exclusion from most international organizations, despite its economic and political development.
Chen said Taiwan's exclusion is due mainly to Beijing's "concerted and sustained efforts" to thwart the development of official relations between Taiwan and the international community.

Commenting on the state of cross-strait relations, Chen said Taiwan is looking forward to a visit to Taiwan this fall by Wang Daohan, chairman of the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait. He said the visit would be conducive to rebuilding mutual trust between the two sides of the strait.

DOC.HEADLINE: WASTE BATTERIES TO BE RECYCLED

TEXT.P: Waste batteries should be recycled from Nov. 1, a senior official with the Cabinet-level Environmental Protection Administration (EPA) said on Friday.
Shen Chih-hsiu, an EPA specialist, made the statement at a public hearing called by opposition Legislator Fan Hsun-lu.

Shen said the EPA has decided to serve a public notice in May calling for an all-out recycling of waste batteries. "We'll give local companies a six-month grace period during which time they can carefully calculate how much money is needed to recycle waste batteries and incorporate it into their operational costs."
After the grace period expires, Shen said, recycling waste batteries will become mandatory for local companies.
Shen also outlined the EPA's goals, including that the monthly recycling rate will reach 25 percent of the total by the end of 2000.
"By then, we also hope 6,000 waste batteries collecting points can be established and construction of a recycling plant will get underway," Shen noted.
As most ordinary members of the public do not understand which kinds of batteries must be recycled, waste battery recycling does not operate smoothly at the moment.
Shen said the EPA is scheduled to call a meeting on April 29 to discuss effective measures to improve the situation.
Speaking on the same occasion, Legislator Fan said in addition to traditional batteries, Taiwan is expected to see the phase-out of more than 1 million old-fashioned mobile phone hand sets this year.
"As most batteries installed in old-styled hand sets contain such heavy metals as nickel and cadmium, the dumped old hand sets will pose a great potential threat to our environment," Fan noted.

Quoting unofficial tallies, Fan said one out of every four Taiwan people now owns a cellular phone. According to Fan's estimate, a total of 16.29 million waste batteries from cellular phones will scatter at various corners of the island by the end of June.
"How to effectively collect all these batteries for recycling has become a serious problem," the lawmaker from the main opposition Democratic Progressive Party warned.

Liu Ming-lung, secretary-general of the Environmental Quality Protection Foundation, blasted the EPA for failing to efficiently use the billions of dollars of recycling funds collected in recent years to improve garbage and waste battery recycling.
Liu suggested that the EPA use its recycling funds to encourage local companies to adopt more effective measures to collect waste batteries.

Liu also urged the EPA to adopt a BOT (build-operate-transfer) system to allow private investment in the construction of a waste battery recycling plant. Under the BOT scheme, private investors will carry out construction and operate the plant in a set period, after which the plant will be turned to government control.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, April 16, or the first day of the third month of the Year of the Rabbit according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1828: Francisco Jose de Goya, Spanish painter and etcher whose art reflected the political and social turmoil of his time, dies at the age of 82.
1850: Madame Marie Tussaud, Swiss founder of the famous museum of waxworks in London, dies at the age of 89.
1889: Sir Charles Spencer Chaplin, known as "Charlie," film actor and comedian much loved for his portrayal of a tramp in baggy pants and bowler hat, is born in Britain. His productions include "The Kid," "The Gold Rush," and "The Great Dictator."
1912: American pilot Harriet Quimby becomes the first woman to fly the English Channel.
1917: Vladimir Ilich Lenin returns to Russia after three years of exile in Zurich.
1923: Japanese Crown Prince Hirohito arrives in Keelung for an "inspection" tour of Taiwan, which is under Japanese rule.
1925: In commemoration of Dr. Sun Yat-sen, who died in Peking on March 12, 1925, at the age of 59, the Kwangtung Provincial Government changes the name of Hsiangshan County, the place of birth of Dr. Sun, to Chungshan County.
1941: German troops enter Sarajevo, Yugoslavia, and the main synagogue is destroyed.
1948: The Organization for European Economic Co-operation (OEEC) is established in Paris by Western European nations in accordance with the Marshall Plan.
1960: The Taiwan Provincial Government begins implementation of labor insurance regulations by establishing the Labor Insurance Bureau.
1972: Yasunari Kawabata, Japanese writer who won the 1968 Nobel Prize for literature, commits suicide at the age of 73. His novels, including "Thousand Cranes," often concern alienated, lonely individuals in search of beauty and purity.
1972: US Apollo 16 is launched from Cape Kennedy, Florida, to make the fifth manned moon landing.
1975: The Communist Khmer Rouge seize Phnom Penh, capital of Cambodia.
1978: A tornado strikes the eastern state of Orissa in India, killing some 180 people.
1981: The Kaohsiung C.K.S. Cultural Center is inaugurated.
1982: Queen Elizabeth proclaims Canada's new constitution, severing the colonial links with Britain.
1985: The first test tube baby in the Republic of China is born at the Veterans General Hospital in Taipei.
1990: In London, Freed African National Congress leader Nelson Mandela publicly thanks the world for its support during his 26-year imprisonment by the South African government.
1998: Khmer Rouge leader Pol Pot is reported dead of a heart attack in his Cambodian jungle stronghold at the age of 73. During his four-year reign of terror, in which some two million Cambodians died.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Men in old times educated themselves for their own sakes. Men now educate themselves to impress others."

DOC.HEADLINE: ASIA NEEDS STABLE US ECONOMY: ASEAN

TEXT.P: The worst of the economic downturn in Asia is over, but the region still needs a stable US economy to fully recover, a senior leader of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) said Thursday.

Speaking at a Pacific Economic Cooperation Council (PECC) in Canberra on Thursday, ASEAN Secretary-General Rodolfo Severino said all ASEAN countries except Indonesia would grow this year, while inflation rates would fall. But the world's largest economy -- the United States -- was crucial to economic growth in Asia, he said.
"It would affect rather severely the chances of a recovery in the region if a downturn (in the United States) was to occur," he said.
He said weakness in the Japanese economy, exchange rate misalignment among major currencies and uncertainty in regard to external financial flows also posed risks.
"We hope we're through the worst. There are signs that the recovery will begin this year, but there are ponderable challenges," he said.
He noted that cooperation among Asian governments has improved.
"ASEAN governments have begun to inform one another about their internal policies and reforms and have exchanged views on them," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: INDIDER SEES RAISING OF TIBETAN FLAG AS ZHU'S FAILURE

TEXT.P: The raising of Tibet's flag in St. John's, Newfoundland, nearly led to the cancellation of a visit there by mainland Chinese Premier Zhu Rongji.
"It was at our request that Mayor Andy Wells raised the flag of Tibet yesterday," a spokesman for the Canada Tibet Committee told the Central News Agency on Thursday.
James Pilgrim said his group's intention in raising the flag was threefold:
--To remind Canadians about Canada's impending decision as to whether it should sponsor a resolution at the United Nations in late April condemning mainland China's human rights abuses; and
--To call particular attention to the Panchen Lama, the world's youngest political prisoner.

"Please note that we did not call for the isolation of, nor economic sanctions against, China. Our intention was to demand that cooperation be carried out in such a way that human rights and economic development will develop hand-in-hand," Pilgrim said.

The flag raising was intended as "a peaceful, symbolic sign of protest," he stressed. But the visiting mainland took exception to the gesture, and seemed to consider the act even more insulting than the hundreds of protesters they have encountered on every leg of their journey in North America, he said.
The flag was lowered Wednesday at about 4 p.m., following threats by Zhu to cancel the trip to St. John's. Pressure from within the Newfoundland business community was a factor as well, he said.
"The Canada Tibet Committee strongly objects to the demands made by the Chinese delegation. We regard them as a sign of over-sensitivity and a diplomatic failure on their part," he said.

On Thursday, a demonstration was planned outside Hotel Newfoundland, where Zhu was scheduled to meet with federal and provincial politicians. Pilgrim said that although the demonstration had not been organized by the Canada Tibet Committee, it still planned to take part.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA TO CONTINUE TO SUPPORT NATO ACTIONS:

TEXT.P: Australia on Thursday flatly rejected a Yugoslav demand that Canberra stop supporting US-led NATO bombings of Yugoslavia if it wants to achieve the release of two Australian aid workers now being held by Yugoslavia.

In response to media reports on the demand from the Yugoslav Foreign Ministry, Foreign Minister Alexander Downer said Australia "will never give in to any threat and blackmail" and will insist on the release of the two aid workers -- Steve Pratt and Peter Wallace. The two are being held on charges of spying, though Downer said the charges are groundless and untrue.
Australia is a strong supporter of the bombings, said Downer, adding that Canberra will never agree with the ethnic cleansing campaign now being launched by Serbian troops in Yugoslavia.

Earlier Downer told reporters that he had sent a letter to UN Secretary-General Kofi Annan, asking him to help secure the release of the two workers, who are now under detention in an unknown place in Yugoslavia.
Political analysts said the two workers have become Yugoslavia's pawns, as the alliance intensifies its bombing campaign.

"Yugoslavia is trying its best to get the bombings suspended and it appears willing to bargain it with the possible release of the two aid workers," one analyst said, adding, "But it is impossible Belgrade would succeed because they have to stop the ethnic cleansing campaign against Albanians first and then resettle them back where they originate."

DOC.HEADLINE: PECC TO PUSH FOR ADMISSION OF TAIWAN, CHINA TO WTO

TEXT.P: The 23 member countries of the Pacific Economic Cooperation Council (PECC) on Friday announced it would push for the admission of Chinese Taipei, mainland China, Russia and Vietnam to the World Trade Organization (WTO).

At a news conference immediately after the conclusion of a three-day PECC standing committee meeting in Canberra, the tripartite organization of business, government and academic officials issued a statement saying PECC members "attach the highest importance to accession into the WTO of all PECC economies which are now in the process of acceding, namely, Russia, Chinese Taipei, Vietnam and most especially China."

"At this time, when many economies in Asia are undergoing deep and wide-ranging structural reforms, it is imperative that they (the four nations) get fully integrated into the rules-based trading system, charged with promoting and maintaining free and open trade and investments, under the auspices of the WTO," the statement said.
PECC's standing committee will present its statement to a meeting of trade ministers of Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum member states in June.

The statement said the committee supports the idea that all APEC member states should use an upcoming APEC leaders' meeting in Auckland in September to confirm their final support for the WTO entry of mainland China, Taiwan, Russia, Vietnam.

In addition, PECC successfully broadened its scope at the meeting by reaching an agreement with the Association of Southeast Asian Nations under which the two bodies have agreed to work together in the future.
"We are delighted to see the results of this meeting because PECC will play a constructive role in pushing the world trade," PECC Chairman Roberto Romulo said in an interview with CNA.

DOC.HEADLINE: INDIA IMPOSES ANTI-DUMPING DUTY ON CHINESE MAGNETS

TEXT.P: India has imposed a preliminary anti-dumping duty on hard ferrite ring magnets (HFRM) from the Chinese mainland after India's domestic industry claimed that their business suffered a sharp decline in 1996-1997.
India's commerce ministry said the magnets -- used in loudspeakers and in public address systems -- were dumped on the Indian market at below-market value.
According to the New Delhi-based English newspaper The Hindustan Times, said the preliminary anti-dumping duty would be 21 rupees per kilogram on imports of HFRMs pending a final determination.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER DPP CHAIRMAN BLASTED FOR REMARKS ABOUT PLEBISCITE

TEXT.P: Former opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairman Hsu Hsin-liang was blasted Friday by other DPP members for recent remarks on plebiscites and Taiwan independence.

During a television interview on Thursday, Hsu, who has shown a strong interest in making a presidential bid, said that while he agrees plebiscites are a fundamental right, a vote on independence could "bring disaster" upon Taiwan.

Trong Chai, a DPP legislator and the leader of a pro-plebiscite hunger strike that entered its seventh day Friday in front of the Legislative Yuan, said it is improper and unthinkable that Hsu could have made such remarks.
The Taiwan Plebiscite Action Committee rebuked Hsu in a formal statement on Friday.

Chen Yi-shen, deputy executive chief of the committee said the ruling Kuomintang's argument that a plebiscite on independence is tantamount to military action against Taiwan by Beijing is "shamefully disgraceful."
That Hsu has adopted the same position is regrettable, Chen said.
He emphasized that the current hunger strike is only one way of increasing Taiwan people's awareness of the issue and their support for plebiscites.

The last thing that the pro-plebiscite activists would like to see is a dispute between the camps of Hsu and Chen Shui-bian, the DPP's most likely presidential candidate in the elections slated for 2000, he said.

Meanwhile, Yang Chin-hai, a DPP National Assembly deputy, was hospitalized Thursday, the sixth day of the activity. Twenty-three other DPP legislators and pro-plebiscite hunger strikers continued the strike on Friday, although the health of some is deteriorating, according to doctors monitoring the group.

DPP Legislator Shen Fu-hsiung, who has taken part in the strike since the first day, said he has lost 5 kilograms so far. In addition, his blood pressure has become unstable and he is suffering from periodic blackouts, he said.
To keep up his strength, Shen said he has maintained a "turtle" rest position for most of the time over the past several days.

The strike need not continue until all participants are hospitalized for it to be successful, he said, adding that he will end his strike when he feels he cannot sustain it any longer. He said he is opposed to the idea that the hunger strikers should continue the strike until the last moment as if running a relay race.

DOC.HEADLINE: CIER FORECASTS ROC 1999 ECONOMIC GROWTH RATE AT 4.97 PERCENT

TEXT.P: The Chung-Hua Institute for Economic Research (CIER) on Friday forecast the Republic of China's 1999 economic growth rate to be 4.97 percent, up 0.05 percentage points from the figure the institute forecast in the first quarter.

The institute cautioned, however, that there are three variables that could affect growth -- the most important being the performance of the US economy. An economic slowdown in the United States would result in a global recession, which could substantially lower the ROC's economic growth this year.

CIER said that if the US stock market experiences a significant downturn, ROC exports in the second, third and fourth quarters would all likely decrease by NT$10 billion, which would result in economic growth this year of only 4.16 percent.
Another variable that affect growth is the degree to which investments by domestic manufacturers lag behind schedule.

The third variable is the pace of East Asia's economic recovery. If the region recovers faster than expected, it would likely result in increased regional trade, which could lift the ROC's exports to Asia in the second, third and fourth quarters by NT$3 billion per quarter. If that were to happen, the ROC's economic growth in 1999 could rise to as much as 5.2 percent, CIER said.
CIER also forecast that the New Taiwan dollar would trade at an average level of 33.03 to the US dollar in 1999, while it predicted the nation's consumer price index would grow 2.01 percent in 1999.

DOC.HEADLINE: POLICY ANALYST MARKS TRA ANNIVERSARY WITH CALL FOR CONTINUED SUPPORT

TEXT.P: To honor American commitments made under the Taiwan Relations Act (TRA), the US Congress and the Clinton administration should strive to enhance Taiwan's freedom and security by urging mainland China to renounce the use of force against Taiwan and by selling Taiwan missile defense systems and technology, according to an American expert.

Stephen Yates, senior policy analyst at the Asian Studies Center of the Heritage Foundation, wrote in a background piece that for 20 years the TRA has provided a security umbrella that has facilitated Taiwan's impressive economic expansion and democratization. To protect these gains and to continue to faithfully implement the TRA, the United States should do several things, he said.

First, the United States should urge mainland China to renounce the use of force against Taiwan. This is consistent with the United States' long-standing insistence that Taiwan's future be determined by peaceful means, he said.

Second, the United States should sell Taiwan missile defense systems and technology. Considering mainland China's provocative military exercises and its tests of nuclear-capable missiles near Taiwan in 1995 and 1996, and mainland China's increased deployment of missiles near Taiwan, providing assistance for Taiwan's missile defense is "both appropriate and consistent with the TRA," said the policy analyst.

Third, the United States should actively support Taiwan's membership in international organizations. With a strong economy and vibrant democracy, Taiwan is clearly prepared to make significant contributions to the international community through institutions involved in trade, economic development and humanitarian assistance, Yates said.

Finally, the United States should promote Taiwan's democracy in mainland China and abroad.
