Consistent with its interest in human rights in Taiwan, the United States must properly recognize and reward the Taiwan people for their success in establishing a democracy. One way to do this is to "treat Taiwan's leaders officially with the respect appropriate to duly elected representatives of a thriving democracy," noted Yates.

He said it is up to Congress to keep America committed to the simple goals of the Taiwan Relations Act -- to deter aggression by the mainland, to promote economic freedom and to protect the human rights of the Taiwan people.

Ronald Reagan described American commitments under the TRA as a "moral obligation" to a long-time friend and ally. The United States "must do all it can to help the democratic people of Taiwan to live free from military coercion and to guarantee Taiwan's ability to make an appropriate contribution to global institutions that promote peace and prosperity," wrote Yates.

The analyst concluded that "The Taiwan Relations Act is an example of American foreign policy at its best. There is no better way to mark the 20th anniversary of its enactment than to reaffirm the US commitment to its honorable goals and to restore clarity and consistency to America's China policy."

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT LEE RECEIVES SALVADORAN VICE PRESIDENT-ELECT

TEXT.P: President Lee Teng-hui said during a meeting with visiting Salvadorian Vice President-elect Carlos Quintanilla Schmidt that the Republic of China will give its full support to El Salvador's national construction plan.

Lee received Quintanilla at the Presidential Office Friday, and congratulated Quintanilla and President-elect Francisco Flores for their victory in elections last month. Both men will take office June 1.
In the elections on March 7, Flores of the governing Republican National Alliance won more than 52 percent of the votes in the first round.
Lee said that when he visited El Salvador two years ago, he was quite impressed by Flores, who was president of the Congress at the time.
Guintanilla told the president that he and Flores are devoted to the country, adding that both will devote themselves to the construction of the nation in the next five years.
He expressed the hope that the Republic of China will provide its full support, as it has in the past, and share its experiences in political and economic development.
Lee lauded Guintanilla and Flores as young and capable leaders, adding that the Republic of China would be willing to provide assistance.

Lee said that after he steps down from the presidency next year, he will not only serve Taiwan's aborigines but also offer his services overseas, adding that he would be willing to share his insights on government administration and agricultural economics -- his specialty -- with El Salvador.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN PINEAPPLE EXPORTS TO JAPAN RISING
DOC.DATELINE: Chunghsing Village, central Taiwan, April 16 (CNA) (By Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's pineapple exports to Japan are expected to top 150,000 kilograms, or 15,000 cartons, this year, about twice the amount exported last year, the Taiwan provincial government reported on Friday.
This year's estimate is still far short, however, of the 1 million kilograms exported in 1989.

After a nearly decade-long hiatus, Taiwan pineapple farmers finally managed to resume in 1998 exports to Japan of the unique species of pineapple that was developed by the Taiwan Agricultural Research Institute more than a decade ago, officials from the provincial Department of Agriculture and Forestry (DAF) said.
The export of Taiwan's "Tai Nung No. 4" pineapple to Japan began in late March and is expected to be completed before the end of April.

According to DAF officials, Tai Nung No. 4 pineapples taste much sweeter and are smaller than the ordinary "Smooth Kaiying" species found in most pineapple-producing countries. In addition, its meat is more yellow and its texture and fibers are much finer and more tender than those of the "Smooth Kaiying," they noted.
Another noticeable difference is the pineapple's skin. Tai Nung No. 4 pineapples can be peeled easily by hand, which makes consumption much easier and more pleasant, the officials said.

Taiwan pineapple farmers, which are centered in southern Taiwan, exported a combined volume of 57,750 kilograms, or 5,775 10-kilogram cartons, of Tai Nung No. 4 pineapples to Japan last year -- the first time Taiwan had exported pineapples to Japan since the late 1980s.

Taiwan began to export Tai Nung No. 4 pineapples to Japan around 1986, soon after the species was developed. Exports rose by leaps and bounds, and in 1989 about 1 million kilograms were exported to Japan.
But poor quality control, cut-throat competition and a lack of systematic contract production led to a nearly 10-year period in which hardly any pineapples were exported to Japan.

Taiwan also exports other fresh fruits, including mangoes, lichee and bananas, to Japan, with bananas remaining the biggest export, totaling about 5 million 12-kilogram cartons each year, according to DAF officials.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR UP

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar rose NT$0.048 against the greenback on the Taipei market Friday, closing at 32.852.
The local currency opened at 32.88 and was traded between 32.842 and 32.89.
The interbank US dollar trading reached US$533 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: APPLICATION OF TRA IN NEW CIRCUMSTANCES DISCUSSED (1)

TEXT.P: The United States has to consider in advance American obligations under the Taiwan Relations Act to changing strategic and technological circumstances so as to minimize misunderstanding or miscalculation on both sides of the Taiwan Straits, according to an expert on Asian affairs.

Gerrit Gong, director of the Asian Studies Program at the Center for Strategic and International Studies (CSIS), testified Wednesday before the House International Relations Subcommittee on Asia and the Pacific that the United States has six anchor interests in cross-strait relations, including its interpretation and application of the Taiwan Relations Act.
The first interest, he said, is to help preserve an equilibrium of confidence so that those on both sides of the Taiwan Strait can determine the pace and scope of their mutual interaction peacefully.

It is the United States' position that both sides should peacefully determine what is mutually acceptable to them, free from coercive pressure from the other side or from the United States, he said. The United States should reject any challenge to the status quo by force, and discourage Taiwan independence, while leaving it to Beijing and Taipei to create the positive conditions necessary to entice peaceful unification, explained Gong.

It is also in the interests of the United States to maintain Taipei and Beijing's responsibility for their continued dynamic balancing of cooperation and competition, and not to allow responsibility for cross-strait peace and communication to be shifted to Washington for restraint or adjudication.
Although competition will continue between Taipei and Beijing, it is in the United States' interests to build margins of safety, not simply limits of tension, said Gong.

The third anchor interest is seeing a constructive and authorized direct dialogue between Taipei and Beijing that deals directly with the differences between them. He suggested such direct communication come through multiple channels and at multiple levels.

Gong noted that there is an important role for "Track II" dialogue convened and facilitated by institutions such as CSIS. But there is also a need for consistent, confirmed, authoritative messages between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait if cross-strait trust and confidence are to be built on a solid foundation.
The United States' fourth interest is to encourage other Asia-Pacific countries publicly to state their interest in regional peace, security and stability.

Gong noted that this does not mean other countries should take sides in what they may see as a Chinese political issue. But there is a danger to all the region if non-peaceful means are employed to resolve questioned borders, territorial lines or other disputes. While formal collective security agreements have yet to be developed in the Asia-Pacific region, emerging regional institutions should perceive a collective interest in the peaceful resolution of disputes, including issues touching concerns of sovereignty.

Fifth, it is in the United States' interest to maintain a working executive and Congressional consensus on US-mainland China-Taiwan relations. Particularly in the last two years of a second presidential term, the importance of maintaining a working consensus on trilateral relations may be directly proportional to the difficulty of its achievement, according to the Asia expert.

A healthy discussion of the alternative merits of different policy approaches is a hallmark of US democracy, but it is not in the United States' interests for domestic politics in Washington to become the dispute resolution mechanism for issues better resolved directly by involved parties, said Gong.
The United States' sixth interest is the advance consideration of the application of the Taiwan Relations Act in circumstances changed by evolving strategic developments. (more)

DOC.HEADLINE: APPLICATION OF TRA IN NEW CIRCUMSTANCES DISCUSSED (2)

TEXT.P: He said that important to maintaining an equilibrium of confidence are accurate mutual assessments of intent and capability by Beijing, Taipei and Washington. These assessments would come as part of the process of ongoing adjustment to the mutual understanding of what and how the TRA applies in circumstances changed by ongoing strategic developments.

For example, Gong said, new developments in information warfare and aspects of the revolution in military affairs require ongoing efforts to fulfill US obligations under the TRA. In particular, as air, land, sea, space and the electromagnetic spectrum are brought together in new strategic combinations, situations could well arise in which vital centers of national security gravity for Taiwan could come under attack without visibly triggering the TRA.

Indeed, he added, new combinations of familiar and emerging strategies (such as a mainland air-borne blockade of Taiwan by missile-carrying planes) must be analyzed within the parameters of the three joint communiques and the TRA to forestall any misunderstandings about where and how the TRA might apply within the context of new technologies and strategies or their applications.

Gong noted that new patterns of cooperative engagement capability; issues in regard to new definitions of theater, front lines, etc.; questions regarding effective political presence; and many other emerging issues will shape the nature of competition and conflict in ways that will require constantly updated discussions of US interests in cross-strait applications of the TRA so as to minimize misunderstanding or miscalculation.

DOC.HEADLINE: 81-YEAR-OLD TWO-TIME COLLEGE GRADUATE PROVES LEARNING NEVER GETS OLD

TEXT.P: Proving that learning is a lifelong process, 81-year-old Kaohsiung resident Chen Hsin-liang is preparing to receive his second bachelor's degree from National Open University (NOU) on Saturday.

Chen earned his first degree -- a bachelor of humanity science -- at NOU six years ago after studying for that for more than a decade. After receiving his degree, Chen decided to pursue additional studies in the social sciences.
This time, Chen completed works on his second degree in only six years. He said Friday that he intends to continue studies by taking graduate courses at NOU, while his another aim is to stay fit.

Of the 490 students from around the island who will be awarded bachelor's degrees of NOU on Saturday, three are above 65 and Chen is the oldest. Five graduates will be earning double degrees and 63 will obtain their second degree.

National Open University allows students to earn degrees from their homes and according to their own schedules, with lessons coming in the form of videotapes, and radio and television programs. To be accepted into the school, applicants must pass an entrance examination similar to those given to other college students.

DOC.HEADLINE: JEFFEREY KOO SEES TAIWAN RISING SPACE FROM PECC-ASEAN COOPERATION
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 16 (CNA) (By Elizabeth Hsu) (By Peter Chen)

TEXT.P: Canberra, April 16 (CNA): The initial cooperation between the Pacific Economic Cooperation Council and the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) will give Taiwan more chances to make friends in the region, the leader of the Chinese Taipei Committee of PECC said on Friday.

In an interview with the CNA in Canberra, Jeffrey Koo said it would be very "helpful" for Taiwan after PECC and ASEAN members forge a cooperation because Taipei could better improve its relations with the countries in the region.

PECC this year invited ASEAN's secretary general Rodolfo Severino to make a speech in which he called for a cooperation between ASEAN and PECC to resolve their problems. PECC chairman Roberto Romulo responded positively by asking ASEAN to take part in all PECC meetings in the future, setting the initial cooperation between the two organizations.
"We are glad to see such development between PECC and ASEAN and hope to foster better ties between Taiwan and all ASEAN member countries in the future," Koo said.

During te three-day Standing Committee meeting of the PECC in Canberra, about 90 delegates from Taiwan, mainland China, Canada, Hong Kong, Singapore, Japan, Malaysia, the Philippines, Thailand, Russia, Vietnam, Indonesia and South Korea, discussed a wide range of issues, including trade policy, transportation, telecommunications, agriculture, energy and above all, the information technology .

Roberto Romulo told the CNA that he would like to see the role of PECC rises so that it could promote not only global trade, but also trade liberalization as set forth by the APEC leaders meeting in Bogor, Indonesia in 1993.
Under the Bogor declaration, trade liberalization is set by 2010 for developed economies of the APEC forum and 2020 for developing countries.
Romulo said the target would be reached despite the Asian financial and economic crisis, which started in Thailand, and then spread to other Asian countries, and then to other countries in the world.
He said trade protectionism should be prevented with all means and trade liberalization would only lead to a better world in the future.

During the three-day meeting, the only country that boycotted the PECC meeting was the United States, which had dispute with the organizers when it was asked to pay the due fees, worth more than US$300,000.

The US National Committee of the PECC was unable to make the payment and sought to boycott the Canberra meeting this year. But the presence of the US is very important in any future PECC meetings, Koo said.

In order to avoid similar cases in the future, the Japanese delegates suggested that the selection of the chair of a national committee be made very carefully in the future in order not to repeat the present mistake.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SEEN AS TOMORROW'S HIGH-TECH HERO
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 16 (CNA) (By Elizabeth Hsu) (By Peter Chen) (By Peter Chen)

TEXT.P: Canberra, April 16 (CNA): Bill Gates is the current guru in information industry, but increasing numbers of players in the IT are of Chinese born, and most likely Taiwanese would become tomorrow's hero, according to a report by the Australian Financial Review on Friday.

In a dispatch from Taipei, the daily's correspondent Rowan Callick reported tomorrow's high-tech hero would not be Bill Gate or other Westerners, but instead could be Chinese-born. "And most likely, he would come from Taiwan," the daily said.

The daily reported that it is Taiwan's vibrant, deep and broad high-tech sector, the third biggest in the world after the United States and Japan, that has driven its economy through and beyond the Asian turmoil.
Callick said that apart from Australia economy and mainland China, Taiwan is the only economy in the region to have kept growing.

He said the beating heart of its high-tech sector is the Hsinchu Science-based Park, where 259 companies, 48 of them foreign -- two-thirds of which are American -- and employs 71,000 people, half of them women, are taking the lead in the high-tech industry in Taiwan.

Along with Hsinchu, there are also other new parks and the Taipei government assures these companies of rapid customs clearance and even more attractively, exempts components in exports from tax in addition to a five-year tax holiday.
The government also offers special guarantee to protect intellectual property rights and it continues to develop the nearby educational institutions that feed the Hsinchu park's R & D departments.

The daily reported Taiwan produces more than 60 percent of the world's motherboards, more than half of its image scanners, mice and monitors, and 30 percent each of its interface cards and notebook PCs.

The report occupies the whole page with a five-column headline: "Taiwan's Beating Heart." The report said Taiwan was able to recruit those talents, who mostly received their education from the US and work at the Silicon Valley in California. These experts have to travel between Taiwan and California and make the island country of 22 million a leading producer and exporter of high-tech products.

DOC.HEADLINE: FMD CASES REPORTED IN MAJOR HOG FARM

TEXT.P: The Council of Agriculture (COA) sent officials to southern Taiwan Friday after a large hog farm reported cases of foot-and-mouth disease (FMD).
The officials said that inspectors first detected FMD-infected hogs in a meat market in Pingtung County.

The officials have traced the disease to a large farm in Linluo Village, Pingtung County. Of 2,546 hogs inspected, 33 were found to have developed FMD symptoms, which included blisters on the hogs' hooves.

As this is the first reported case of FMD at a major hog farm since an outbreak in 1997 decimated Taiwan's hog population and caused heavy financial losses, COA officials are paying close attention to the situation and hope it will not affect ROC hog exports, which resumed only recently.
Inspectors said they are now checking whether farm owners have inoculated the hogs as required by regulations.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC TO SET UP FIELD HOSPITAL AT STENOKVEC REFUGEE CAMP IN MACEDONIA
DOC.DATELINE: Skopje, April 15 (CNA) (By Yen Ling-ju and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The Republic of China has decided to set up a field hospital at the Stenokvec refugee camp in Macedonia to provide medical services for ethnic Albanians from neighboring Kosovo, a province of Yugoslavia.

ROC Vice Foreign Minister David Lee, who is heading a delegation of officials, social workers, volunteers and medical personnel on a humanitarian visit to Macedonia, announced the decision here on Thursday after reaching a consensus with representatives of the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees and the international relief group CARE.

Lee said medical service is the most important part of the ROC's humanitarian assistance to ethnic Albanian refugees in Macedonia, adding that the ROC medical service team will stay in Stenokvec for two to three weeks.
"After the period expires, We'll decide whether to extend the service based on the practical situation and the Macedonian government's request," Lee said.
Lee further said the ROC will seek feasible ways to help improve communications services in refugee camps in Macedonia.

The ROC delegation arrived in Macedonia on Wednesday, bringing with it US$2 million worth of relief goods, including foods, clothing, pharmaceuticals, medical equipment, blankets and many other daily necessities.
Macedonian Foreign Minister Aleksandar Dimitrov said on Thursday that the ROC delegation has offered enormous assistance for the refugees.

"This is a proof that the development of relations and cooperation between Macedonia and the ROC has proceeded smoothly," Dimitrov said, adding: "We are continuing with the cooperation and that is a permanent determination of the both countries."
Dimitrov met with Lee on Thursday for wide-ranging talks. After the meeting, Dimitrov told reporters that Macedonia will open an embassy in Taipei within a week.

Dimitrov said Vera Modanu, director of the Macedonian Foreign Ministry's Asian Affairs Department, has been named Macedonia's first resident envoy to the ROC. Modanu, who speaks fluent Chinese, will leave for Taipei soon to arrange for the opening of the Macedonian embassy.

For his part, ROC Vice Foreign Minister Lee said his mission represents a symbol of the sympathies of the 21 million Taiwan people towards Macedonia, quoting an old maxim "The real friend is recognized at the difficult times."

Noting that his delegation is composed of lawmakers from Taiwan's three major political parties, representatives from 13 philanthropic organizations and medical professionals, Lee said the delegation is mainly aimed at expressing the ROC's sincere sympathies for Macedonian people.

Lee further said he is pleased to learn that Macedonian Prime Minister Ljubco Georgievski will visit Taiwan next month, saying the visit will contribute to the establishment of a long-term friendship and cooperation. The ROC forged formal diplomatic ties with the Balkan state in January.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC WILLING TO ASSIST IN KOSOVO RECONSTRUCTION
DOC.DATELINE: Skopje, April 15 (CNA) (By Yen Ling-ju and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The Republic of China is willing to consider assisting in reconstruction of Kosovo, a war-torn Yugoslav province neighboring the ROC ally of Macedonia, ROC Vice Foreign Minister David Lee said here on Thursday.
Lee arrived in Skopje earlier this week at the head of a 90-member delegation to offer humanitarian aid to a large number of ethnic Albanian refugees from Kosovo.

Lee told a news conference here that the ROC has not received any request for providing shelter to ethnic Albanian refugees. "We think it is better for the Albanian refugees to stay in countries or areas close to their homeland."
Lee said the ROC has so far offered some US$5 million in cash donations, medical equipment, foods, clothing and other daily necessities to help relieve ethnic Albanian refugees from Kosovo.
This is the first time in the ROC's diplomatic history that Taiwan has sent a large group of medical professionals and volunteers to take part in overseas humanitarian relief work.

Lee presided over the inaugural ceremony for a field hospital established with the ROC's assistance at the Stenkovec refugee camp in Macedonia. Stenkovec is the largest refugee camp in Macedonia, sheltering about 25,000 ethnic Albanian refugees from Kosovo.
Twenty-six medical professionals and dozens of volunteers from Taiwan will work at the field hospital to offer medical services for refugees.

Lee said the medical team will stay in Stenkovec for two to three weeks. "After the period expires, we'll decide whether to extend the service based on practical situation and the Macedonian government's request," he added.
Lee further said the ROC will seek feasible ways to help improve communications services in refugee camps in Macedonia.
Meanwhile, Macedonian Foreign Minister Aleksandar Dimitrov said on Thursday that the ROC delegation has offered enormous assistance for the refugees.

"This is a proof that the development of relations and cooperation between Macedonia and the ROC has proceeded smoothly," Dimitrov said, adding: "We are continuing with the cooperation and that is a permanent determination of the both countries."
Dimitrov met with Lee on Thursday for wide-ranging talks. After the meeting, Dimitrov told reporters that Macedonia will open an embassy in Taipei within a week.

Dimitrov said Vera Modanu, director of the Macedonian Foreign Ministry's Asian Affairs Department, has been named Macedonia's first resident envoy to the ROC. Modanu, who speaks fluent Chinese, will leave for Taipei soon to arrange for the opening of the Macedonian embassy.

For his part, ROC Vice Foreign Minister Lee said his mission represents a symbol of the sympathies of the 21 million Taiwan people towards Macedonia, quoting an old maxim "The real friend is recognized at the difficult times."

Noting that his delegation is composed of lawmakers from Taiwan's three major political parties, representatives from 13 philanthropic organizations and medical professionals, Lee said the delegation is mainly aimed at expressing the ROC's sincere sympathies for Macedonian people.

Lee further said he is pleased to learn that Macedonian Prime Minister Ljubco Georgievski will visit Taiwan next month, saying the visit will contribute to the establishment of a long-term friendship and cooperation. The ROC forged formal diplomatic ties with the Balkan state in January.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO POLITICAL HIGH RISK IN TAIWAN INVESTMENTS: SCHOLAR

TEXT.P: Investing in Taiwan is not politically risky, even though next year the country will hold a presidential election while facing lingering cross-strait relation issues, said Tien Hung-mao, president of the Institute for National Policy Research, on Friday.
Tien's remark, was made during the second day of a two-day seminar dubbed "Access to Asia." The seminar is sponsored by the Pensions 2000 Corp. of the United States.

Tien pointed out that most Taiwan voters are treading a middle of the road line, meaning that even if the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) were to gain power, they would not declare independence.

Taiwan's democratization process during the past 10 years has been peaceful and stable, with of the few violent confrontations that occurred in other countries during their experience with democracy, said Tien.

He also introduced to the 100-plus US retirement fund executives and managers, the various political parties in Taiwan, as well as the political intentions of the presidential hopefuls in the forthcoming election.

On the issues regarding cross-strait relations, which most of the foreign fund trusts managers were concerned about, Tien stressed that both Taipei and Beijing have learned a lesson from the missile crisis across the Taiwan Strait in 1996, thus eliminating a repeat occurrence.
Toeing a moderate line to avoid being considered as partisan or radical has become the trend for modern Taiwan presidential hopefuls as that is the voters choice, remarked Tien.

Therefore, leaders of the opposition party, either former Taipei mayor Chen Shui-bian who is widely believed to be the DPP's presidential candidate for the 2000 election, or Hsu Hsin-liang, the DPP's former chairman and other presidential hopeful, are both adjusting their political stances, the scholar further analyzed.

If the DPP won the presidential election, it would not declare Taiwan's independence, as that would be an excuse for the Chinese mainland to assault Taiwan, Tien observed. He assured his audience not to worry about that possibility.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCKS, FUTURES DECLINE

TEXT.P: Taiwan share prices fell 0.4 percent on Friday as a result of profit-taking by investors.
The benchmark Taiwan Stock Exchange Weighted Price Index fell 31.35 points to close at 7,466.82 points.
Trade on Friday saw a total of 4.54 billion shares change hands on a turnover of NT$165.05 billion (US$5.02 billion), the highest level this year.

Among the eight major stock categories, electronic shares sustained the largest losses, dropping 2.4 percent, followed by cement stocks, which fell 1.1 percent. Textile stocks also slipped 0.3 percent.

The financial sector continued to perform well and posted the largest gain of the day, rising 2 percent. Foodstuff issues climbed 1.6 percent, construction shares 1.1 percent, and cement shares rose 1 percent. The paper and pulp sector went up 0.6 percent.
The over-the-counter market advanced 3.45 points to close at 176.45 points, on a turnover of NT$12.05 billion, the highest level this year.
The TAIEX Capitalization Weighted Price Index Futures (TAIEX Index Futures) for April dropped 20 points to close at 7,460, with 2,774 contract transactions.

TAIEX Index Futures for May fell 40 points to close at 7,479, while those for June rose 29 points to close at 7,539 points. Contract transactions for the two months totaled 2,773 and 90, respectively.
September futures went up 21 points, closing at 7,520 points, with 7 contract transactions. December futures increased 49 points to close at 7,599, with 2 contract transactions.

Reference levels provided by the Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange for TAIEX Index Futures trading on Friday were 7,480 points for April, 7,519 points for May, 7,510 points for June, 7,499 points for September, and 7,550 points for December.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S WTO BID SURPASSES M'LAND'S: BOFT HEAD

TEXT.P: Board of Foreign Trade director Chen Ruey-long said on Friday that Taiwan is making far more progress in gaining entry into the World Trade Organization (WTO) than mainland China.

Despite the concessions made by mainland Premier Zhu Rongji during his US visit resulting in great progress for a mainland WTO entry bid, Taiwan's preparations and progress is superior, Chen insisted.
Chen made the statement at a public hearing held by legislator Chin Huei-chu at the Legislative Yuan concerning Taiwan's reaction to Zhu's US visit.
Taiwan's grounds for WTO entry bid are clear and its application should not be hampered by political factors as long as it meets WTO requirements, said Chen.
"We will insist the WTO handle Taiwan's bid separately from that of the mainland's," noted Chen.

Shen Lyu-shun, Director of North America Affairs Dept. under the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, pointed out that he believed Taiwan will remain an important trade partner to the US despite the mainland's opening of markets. The result would be that trade between Taiwan and the US is likely to be partially replaced by US trade with the mainland.

Professor of international trade Chiang Cheng-tze from Soochow University indicated that the government should assist Taiwan enterprises in strengthening their competitiveness to survive the challenges to be brought by Taiwan's entry into the WTO.

Meanwhile, Premier Vincent Siew said in the Legislative Yuan that the government would seriously weigh the issue on opening direct trade, postal and transportation, the so-called "three links" with mainland China if the two economies were to be admitted into the global economic organization at the same time.
Answering questions raised by legislators, Siew said there was no specific schedule for Taiwan's WTO entry.

Regarding imported agricultural products, Chairman of the Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture Pong Tzuo-kuei said import duties will be slashed from the present 20 percent to 14 percent once Taiwan is admitted and then to 12 percent the next year.
Yet farmers' interests will be protected as the government will set quotas for sensitive products such as rice and garlic, said Pong. (by Amanda Chang)

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER CAUTIOUS ABOUT FIVE-DAY WORK WEEK

TEXT.P: Premier Vincent Siew said on Friday that a proposal to fully implement a five-day work week in the government sector needs further study and evaluation to avoid a negative impact on the nation's economy.
Siew said the proposed measure will have a far-reaching impact on other sectors. He argued that the issue must be fully assessed before the legislature moves to approve the proposal.
The premier made the remarks while fielding questions at the Legislative Yuan.

Lawmakers of the three major political parties -- the ruling Kuomintang, the opposition Democratic Progressive Party and the New Party -- reached consensus earlier in the day on amending current laws to allow the full implementation of the scheme beginning on Jan. 1, 2000.

The five-day work week scheme is not compulsory in Taiwan at present, and each sector is free to decide how many days its workers can be off during a week in order to maintain a competitive edge. Public servants have enjoyed the treatment twice a month since early last year.

The Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD), Taiwan's highest economic planning agency, said the full implementation of the five-day work week scheme should be realized step by step, and that the right time should be when Taiwan's per-capita income hits US$20,000.

According to a CEPD analysis, Taiwan's economic growth will drop by 0.09 percent for each additional day off by workers, and wage costs will increase by 0.35 percent as a result. In other words, the full implementation of the five-day work week scheme will bring Taiwan's economy down 1.2 percent annually as it produces an additional 13 holidays every year.

Meanwhile, the business community, including the Chinese National Federation of Industries and the ROC General Chamber of Commerce (GCC), have voiced strong opposition to the plan citing concern over a persistent domestic financial crisis and a serious labor shortage.
GCC Chairman Wang You-theng said the scheme cannot be applied rashly at a time when Taiwan is seeking to upgrade its international competitiveness.
GCC Deputy Secretary-General Y. H. Kuo said the 140 business groups belonging to the GCC all oppose the legislature's plan to promote the full five-day work week scheme.

Kuo stressed that the lawmakers should have discussed the issue with the private sector rather than moving directly toward an amendment because a full implementation will increase the pressure on local industries which are still battling the Asian financial crisis.

DOC.HEADLINE: RUSSIAN SCHOLAR TO VISIT TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Dr. Alexander Yakovlev, Academician of Russian Academia of Science, will arrive in Taipei on April 18, 1999, for a week-long visit, according to a press release issued by the Ministry of Foreign Affairs on Friday.
During the visit, he will call on Minister of Foreign Affairs Jason C. Hu, President of Academia Sinica Yuan T. Lee, and other government officials.
Yakovlev will also meet with local scholars and visit several cultural and economic establishments of the Republic of China.
He is scheduled to deliver a speech on " Russia Today" at downtown campus of Tamkang University on April 21, and depart from Taipei on April 23.

DOC.HEADLINE: US SAID PRESSING TAIWAN FOR OPENING HEAVY MOTORCYCLE MARKET

TEXT.P: Vice Minister of Economic Affairs (MOEA) Lin Yi-fu said on Friday that Taiwan will take appropriate measures to deal with a possible US demand that Taiwan allows imports of US-made 150 c.c. and other heavy motorcycles.

Taiwan's imports of US-made heavy motorcycles were not inlcuded in the agenda of the bilateral negotiations on the island's bid to enter the World Trade Organization (WTO) which concluded early last year.

When asked to comment on reports that the US is pressing Taiwan to open up its heavy motorcycle markets, Lin said that the US did made the demand before, but has not repeated it in recent talks with Taiwan.
Taiwan wishes to begin multilateral WTO negotiations in May, during which, Lin said, the US may raise the issue again.
Lin said MOEA is considering the feasibility of allowing the heavy motorcycle imports beginning July 1 of next year, January 1, 2001 or two years after the ROC enters the WTO.
The ROC government will put out feelers concerning trade issues that other WTO member countries might raise through the ROC's representative offices abroad.
The opening up of heavy motorcycle imports involves questions such as the Environmental Protection Administration's exhaust standards, Lee said.
Lin added that if the US were to repeat the demand, related government agencies would need to hold cross-agency meetings to discuss the issue.
If the ROC were to open up motorcycle imports to the US, other WTO member countries might also be allowed to export their motorcycles into Taiwan.
Taiwan's motorcycle industry hopes the government will come up with a specific timetable so they can bring forth counter solutions.

DOC.HEADLINE: COSTA RICAN PRESIDENT OPENS ROC INFORMATION CENTER

TEXT.P: Republic of China (ROC) Ambassador to Costa Rica Mao Kao-wen and Costa Rican President Miguel Angel Rodriguez jointly presided over the opening of the Costa Rican Journalist Association's ROC information center on Thursday.
Over a hundred guests, including members of the Costa Rican diplomatic community and local academic and media members attended the ceremony.

Ambassador Mao said in his speech that it was the ROC's honor to have Costa Rica set up the information center under the name of the Republic of China, and that it represented both countries' dedication to democracy and the protection of freedom of speech.

There has been a long history of friendship and close cooperation between the two countries, Mao continued, adding that both countries have the same determination to uphold freedom, democracy, peace and human rights.
Based on this common ideal, the ROC and Costa Rica signed a news-exchange agreement in August, 1997 to establish a communication channel for bilateral media exchange and cooperation, Mao said.

Mao hoped that the ROC information center will help Costa Rican journalists, public relations workers and mass communication students to learn and familiarize themselves with new media technologies to meet the demands of the information age.

DOC.HEADLINE: SOONG LEADS IN SURVEY

TEXT.P: A poll result showed that former Taiwan governor James Soong is the most likely to win the 2000 presidential election, beating Vice President Lien Chan, former Taipei mayor Chen Shui-bian and former Democratic Progress Party chairman Hsu Hsin-liang.
This poll was conducted by a political website run by the Holix Technology Co. at the Taipei Convention Center during a 3-day internet exhibition.
Among 1,082 voters, Soong headed the poll with 492 votes, or 45.47 percent, former Taipei mayor Chen Shui-bian came in second ,obtaining 366 votes or 33.83.
Lien and Hsu won 9.06 percent and 3.88 percent respectively.
Meanwhile, 7.76 percent of the votes went to candidates other than the selected four.
The error of margin of the poll was 5 percentage points.
Holix made four posters with each of the candidate's and then randomly invited the shows' visitors to vote for their favorite candidate. (by Amanda Chang)

DOC.HEADLINE: MOEA CORPS. ALMOST COMPLETE Y2K TESTS

TEXT.P: The eight national corporations under the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) have completed 94 percent of the work required to cope with the Y2K crisis, Vice Economics Minister Chang Chang-pang said Friday.
Chang made the remark after presiding over a task force meeting to review the progress by the eight state-run corporations.
He said only few state-owned corporations that are in the non-manufacturing sector are behind schedule.
The eight companies have spent a total of NT$1.53 billion to address the problem.
Chang indicated that the corporations are expected to complete the remaining work on time.
Of the eight companies, the Taiwan Power Company has completed one hundred percent of its testing.

DOC.HEADLINE: COA COMPLETES PET DOG REGISTRATION SYSTEM

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Council of Agriculture (COA) on Friday passed a regulation stating that owners of pet dogs must register with the authorities.
According to the system, dog owners are obliged to pay NT$4,800 (US$146) for each registration, with a discount -- NT$1,200 (US$36.53) for each ligated pet dog, COA officials said.
The registration is a one-time payment, they explained.
The COA officials noted that as soon as the system is put into effect those who refuse to follow will be fined from NT$2,000 to NT$10,000 per report.

The registration process includes implanting an identification chip, establishing a household file and issuing a pet ID. If the owner losses the pet, a report must be filed with the pet administration within five days. A heavy punishment will be imposed on owners who abandon their pets deliberately.
The COA officials noted that the registration system will initially only cover dogs, with cats to be included in the next stage.
There are now some one million pet dogs in Taiwan, COA statistics show. In the first year of the act, about 200,000 pet dogs are expected to be recorded, the COA said.

DOC.HEADLINE: MANILA CALLS FOR DIPLOMATIC RESOLUTION OF STRATLY DISPUTY

TEXT.P: Mainland China should heed calls for a quick, peaceful and diplomatic solution to the problem in the South China Sea and refrain from taking steps that increase tension in the area, Malacanang said Friday.
In a press statement, Presidential Spokesman Jerry Barican said however, there has been no official information that mainland China intends to build up its military capability in the disputed area.
"The Philippines has not been officially informed of any security estimates by foreign governments regarding the intention of mainland China vis-a-vis the South China Sea," Barican said.
He said the policy of the Philippine government is still to pursue peaceful efforts on a bilateral as well as multilateral basis in resolving the territorial dispute.

Quoting Pentagon sources, a newspaper reported Friday that mainland China intends to expand its military presence in the Spratlys within the next five years and develop Mischief Reef as its command headquarters and control facility for air and naval forces.

Mainland China has constructed permanent structures at Mischief Reef, which is within the 200-nautical mile exclusive economic zone of the Philippines. The Philippines calls the disputed reef Panganiban Reef

Barican said any attempt by any party to increase the military tension in the disputed islands would have grave repercussions in the region. "The South China Sea is a major international waterway and there are several claimant countries in the area," he said.
The Spratlys are claimed wholly or in part by mainland China, the Philippines, Vietnam, Brunei Darussalam, Malaysia and the Republic of China.

DOC.HEADLINE: PHILIPPINES SURVIVES ASIAN ECONOMIC CRISIS

TEXT.P: The Philippines fared better than its neighbors in parrying the effects of the Asian financial crisis that battered the region starting in mid-1997, according to a survey sponsored by the World Bank and published by Asiaweek in its April 16, 1999.

The survey, which was conducted by national economic agencies and business associations, covered 3,710 business firms, the bulk of which are engaged in manufacturing. Of these companies, 816 are in Indonesia, 814 in Malaysia, 659 in Thailand, 857 in South Korea, and 564 in the Philippines.
Salient points of the survey were released Friday to Malacanang reporters by Presidential spokesman Jerry Barican.
The survey showed that among the five countries, Indonesia was worst hit in production capacity decline, with production falling by 21 percent between 1996 to 1998.
The Philippines suffered the least, with a capacity contraction of 9 percent, the survey showed.
On liquidity problems, only one third of the companies reported any major problems in cover interest payments and operational costs with cash flow.

According to the survey, the Philippines reported the fewest liquidity problems, 23.3 percent. The Philippines likewise had the second lowest number of illiquid (39.1 percent) and insolvent (6.1 percent) companies.
As to the impact of lower revenues on liquidity, three quarters of the companies surveyed cited lower revenues as a significant cause of their liquidity problems.
In this respect, according to the survey, the Philippines was the second least hit at 67.5 percent, with Thailand as the worst hit at 81.0 percent.

In an accompanying article, Asiaweek quoted secretary Benjamin Diokno of the Department of Budget and Management as saying that the Philippines expects to register a growth of 3 percent in gross national product (GNP) this year. (CNA Manila)

DOC.HEADLINE: SA ASKS INDIA, PARKISTAN TO EXERCISE RESTRAINT

TEXT.P: South Africa urged India and Pakistan to demonstrate restraint and continue dialogue following their renewed missile testing on Thursday.

The Ministry of Foreign Affairs said in a statement that South Africa remains convinced that national, regional and international peace and security is not enhanced through the proliferation of military capabilities, especially as this related to weapons of mass destruction and their delivery systems.

After a lull following last year's shock nuclear tests, India resumed missile tests Sunday and Pakistan Wednesday. The South Africa government urged restraint and dialogue between the governments of India and Pakistan in the wake of renewed missile testing.

The statement said India and Pakistan should demonstrate restraint and continue dialogue between themselves to build on the accomplishment of the Lahore Declaration. The latest tests represented a continued escalation in the arms race in South Asia, it said.

DOC.HEADLINE: ACADEMIA SINICA PRESIDENT MIFFED BY QUESTIONS ABOUT POLITICAL CAREER

TEXT.P: Miffed by questions about his willingness to be a running mate in the 2000 presidential elections, Lee Yuan-tse, president of Academia Sinica said on Friday that he will devote all his energy to his present job.

Arriving at the Taoyuan County Hall for a meeting with Magistrate Annette Lu, Lee was mobbed by a group of local reporters who peppered him with questions about his willingness to be the running mate of Chen Shui-bien, the presidential hopeful of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party.
Lee told the crowd," It is not my business. All I want to do now is to carry out my job with all my energy."

Annoyed by reporters' aggressive inquiries whether he will change his mind, the Nobel laureate said angrily "no", adding "The press has bothered me too much. It borders on cruelty with the persistent questioning based on groundless speculation."
He said, "The press should not ask me 'Did you kill anyone?' simply because somebody said that I have killed a person. It is unfair for the journalists to disturb me because of baseless remarks."

Lee was visiting Lu to explore the possibility of opening an Academia Sinica campus in Taoyuan County. He threatened to walk away when pursued by reporters about the prospect that he would become Lu's vice president running mate.
In an effort to ease tensions, Lu said that the press' concerns signify Lee's credibility and popularity among the general public.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEWFOUNDLANDERS PROTEST ZHU'S VISIT

TEXT.P: About 80 people staged a protest outside the Hotel Newfoundland Thursday, where Canadian politicans and businessmen were lunching with Chinese Premier Zhu Rongji, a participant said Friday.
"There was a lot of media coverage, including live feeds and even Hong Kong press," James Pilgrim told the CNA.

The spokesman for the St. John's chapter of the Canada Tibet Committee said the public support was great: a lot of people waved their flags, and people have been calling into radio stations with support all day.

A hotel employee tried to quickly unlock the back gate for Zhu and his entourage to slip out of the hotel, but CTC member Duleepa Wijaywardhana and Pilgrim sprinted around the very long path to the back, and "luckily made it in time to wave the flag right over Zhu's limo."
"We were quite polite. Anyways, the Chinese gave us a few thumbs down, but otherwise we smiled very politely and didn't act in any threatening way," Pilgrim recounted.

Afterwards, some local Chinese came down and talked with CTC people. It went well: very calm, open exchange of ideas. "They didn't agree with what we were doing, but said that had it been Jiang Zemin rather than Zhu Rhongji, they would have joined us," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: FIELD HOSPITAL DONATED BY TAIWAN OPENS IN SKOPJE

TEXT.P: A field hospital donated by Taiwan formally opened at the Stenkovec refugee camp outside of Skopje on Friday.

Manned by 26 Taiwanese medical personnel, the eight-tent hospital consists of clinics specializing in internal medicine, obstetrics and gynecology, dentistry, pediatrics, and otolaryngology, said Liu Chi-chun, president of the Luchu Association, a Taiwan charity which provided medical aid.

The hospital is expected to treat 400-500 patients a day during its two weeks of operation. It will then be donated to Macedonia unless the medical team is asked to extend their service time, said David Lee, vice foreign minister of the Republic of China who arrived at Skopje on Wednesday as the head of the aid mission.

Lee's 91-strong delegation, including public officials, medical crews and journalists, on Wednesday brought US$2 million worth of relief goods. All of the delegation members, except the medical crew, departed Skopje on Friday afternoon on a chartered plane for Taiwan where they are expected to arrive on Saturday.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI WELCOMES VISIT BY NEW TOKYO GOVERNOR
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, April 16 (CNA) (By Mike Chang and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Chuang Ming-yao, Republic of China representative to Japan, said on Friday that the ROC government welcomes Tokyo Governor-elect Shintaro Ishihara to visit Taiwan to strengthen mutual understanding.

Speaking at a public news conference at the Taipei Economic and Cultural Representative Office in Tokyo, Chuang also expressed the hope to pay a visit to Ishihara and thanked the Tokyo municipal authorities for the past assistance they have extended to visitors from Taiwan.

When asked about media reports that Ishihara may invite ROC President Lee Teng-hui to visit Tokyo, Chuang said he welcomes such a move and that it is a goal he hopes to achieve, but he added that it is premature to talk about the issue at this time.

Touching on the US-Japan security defense agreement, the ROC de-facto ambassador hailed the accord as the cornerstone of peace and prosperity in the Asia-Pacific region and that it also serves as a shield to deter potential regional conflicts.

Chuang said the next round of bilateral fishery discussions will be conducted in Taipei since the last round was held in Tokyo last November. But he added that the two sides have yet to set a precise date.
Despite the lack of formal diplomatic relations, Taiwan maintains very close trade relations with Japan.

Taiwan exports to Japan totaled US$2.71 billion in the first quarter of 1999, up 14.5 percent from the same period a year ago, while Japanese imports to Taiwan hit US$6.82 billion during the same three months, down 3.5 percent on an annual basis, leaving Taiwan with a trade deficit of US$4.11 billion, down 12 percent from the corresponding period in 1998.

ROC trade officials stationed in the Tokyo representative office estimated that Taiwan's trade deficit with Japan will drop by about 10 percent for the whole of 1999 from last year's level of US$17.8 billion based on the figure posted in the first three month.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC-AUSTRALIA ENERGY MEETING WRAPS UP

TEXT.P: The 1999 ROC-Australia vice-ministerial energy meeting wrapped up here Friday, with Australia agreeing to study the feasibility of selling uranium and liquefied natural gas (LNG) to Taiwan.

The two countries also reached agreement on strengthening bilateral cooperation on energy during the two-day gathering, which was co-chaired by ROC Vice Economic Affairs Minister Yin Chi-ming and his Australian counterpart Tim Mackey.
Under the agreement, Taiwan Power Corporation, which has been a longtime customer of Australian iron and coal, will now become a new buyer of uranium and LNG from the country.
In addition, the Australian delegation also agreed to provide relevant information to facilitate Taiwan jointly exploring oil fields with Australia in the future.

South Africa and Canada have been Taiwan's major suppliers of uranium, while Indonesia and Malaysia are the island's leading sources of LNG. The two countries export around 6 million tons of LNG to Taiwan every year.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT LEE IS MORE THAN WILLING TO MEET WANG

TEXT.P: Republic of China (ROC) President Lee Teng-hui is more than willing to meet Wang Daohan, the Chairman of Beijing's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS), said an official of the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) on Friday.
Sheu Ke-sheng, vice chairman of the MAC, said that President Lee would act as a personal guide for Wang during his visit to the island in the fall.

Sheu made the remarks in response to a report by the local United Daily News on Friday that Wang told the Hong Kong-based Chinese-language Yazhou Zhoukan (Asia Weekly) that he would like to see President Lee during his proposed trip.
Wang's interview will be published in the latest edition of Yazhou Zhoukan, said the United Daily News.

Meanwhile Jan Jyh-horng, deputy secretary-general of ARATS' Taiwan counterpart, the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF), told the Legislative Yuan on Friday that Beijing's delay in confirming a date for Wang's visit jeopardizes the arrangement of his Taiwan schedule.

Political leaders usually have their schedule of events set months in advance, and it will be hard to arrange extra meetings on short notice with some leaders if Wang does not set his proposed trip's dates soon, said Jan.
In a unrelated development, ARATS politely denied the SEF's demand to negotiate on several issues on Friday.
In a response to the SEF's April 2 letter, ARATS stalled the SEF's demand to send Jan to Beijing in April for negotiations on cooperation in stopping crime and smuggling across the Taiwan Strait.
Su Chi, Chairman of the MAC said that Beijing has virtually rejected all of Taiwan's efforts to discuss Wang's trip and other practical issues concurrently.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies Friday are as follows:
The Central Daily News:
The Legislative Yuan will revise the current civil service law to legalize full implementation of a five-day work week system in the public sector from Jan. 1, 2000.
The China Times:
Top mainland negotiator Wang Daohan called for cross-strait negotiations on unification under a "one China" principle and based on an equal footing.
The United Daily News:
Lawmakers from both ruling and opposition parties reached a consensus on the full implementation of a five-day work week system in the public sector from next year.
The Liberty Times:
The majority of members of the ruling Kuomintang's Central Committee and Central Advisory Committee support Vice President Lien Chan's presidential bid.
The Commons Daily:
The Legislative Yuan will discuss a plebiscite bill next Tuesday.
The China Post: Foot-and-mouth disease outbreak strikes a medium-sized pig ranch in the southern Pingtung county. @The China News:
Foot-and-mouth disease reappears.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Saturday, April 17, or the second day of the third month of the Year of the Rabbit according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1421: More than 100,000 people drown when the sea breaks through the dike in Dort, Holland.
1790: American public official, writer, scientist and printer Benjamin Franklin dies at the age of 84. He played a major part in the American Revolution, negotiated French support for the colonies, signed the Treaty of Paris and helped draft the US Constitution.
1824: The United States and Russia define respective rights in the Pacific Ocean and on the northwest coast of America.
1894: Nikita S. Krushchev, Soviet politician, is born. As Soviet leader he denounced Stalin and thwarted the Hungarian Revolution of 1956. He was deposed in 1964 for his failure to improve the Soviet economy.
1895: The Treaty of Shimonoseki is signed, compelling the Ching court to pay a huge indemnity, open its seaports, recognize the independence of Korea, and cede the Liaoning Peninsula, Taiwan and the Pescadores to Japan.
1897: During a revolt in Ottoman-held Crete, war breaks out between Greece and the Ottoman Empire.
1906: A Pacific cable between China and the United States is completed.
1938: Chang Kuo-dao, governor of the Chinese communist government that controls the region comprising Shensi, Kansu and Ningsia issues a statement in Hankou distancing himself from the Chinese Communist Party.
1941: US President Franklin D. Roosevelt approves the first military aid program of US$45 million for China.
1946: Communist troops enter Changchun, Kirin Province, in northeastern China.
1950: The Chinese Women Anti-Aggression League is formally inaugurated.
1964: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs of the Republic of China issues a statement severing diplomatic relations with Congo.
1968: US President Lyndon B. Johnson meets with South Korean President Park Chung Hee in Honolulu, pledging US protection of noncommunist Asia.
1971: Egypt, Syria and Libya sign an agreement to form a confederation.
1971: The East Pakistanis declare East Pakistan an independent nation called Bangladesh with Sheik Mujibur Rahman serving as the nation's first prime minister.
1973: President Lon Nol of Cambodia announces the resignation of his Cabinet.
1980: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) accepts mainland China as a member, and the Republic of China is forced to pull out of the organization.
1989: The Mainland Affairs Council passes a proposal to allow teachers and staff of public schools to travel to the Chinese mainland for family visits.
1992: Legislative proceedings are completed for the National Employment Act, which is to serve as the basis for the employment of foreign nationals in the Republic of China.
1994: Mainland China's public security unit announces it has solved a criminal case in which 24 Taiwan tourists were killed at Qiandao Lake on March 31, 1994.
1995: Fire breaks out at a KTV on Hankou Street in Taipei, killing 12 people and seriously injuring 14 others.
1996: US President Bill Clinton signs a joint declaration on security cooperation with Japanese Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto pledging to maintain American military force levels in both Japan and elsewhere in Asia.
Confucius' lesson of the day: " A wise man is ashamed to say much; he prefers to do more."

DOC.HEADLINE: LOTS OF DEBATES NEEDED BEFORE FIVE-DAY WORK WEEK IMPLEMENTED: EXPERTS

TEXT.P: A great deal of debate is needed before a five-day work week program can be fully implemented in the government sector, and both those for and against the idea have voiced strong opinions on the matter.

Opposition lawmakers from the New Party (NP) and the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) reached a consensus Friday, pushing for the full implementation of a five-day work week in the government sector beginning Jan. 1, 2000.
Almost all related agencies of the administration voiced opposition to a quick implementation of the program.
Premier Vincent Siew said the program will have a far-reaching impact on all sectors involved, adding that it should not be carried out impetuously before national and social conditions mature.

Wei Chi-lin, director-general of the Central Personnel Administration, said an impetuous implementation of the program will further aggravate unemployment in Taiwan, which is currently poised for a rebound.
Wei said he believes the five-day work week is a correct direction and a world trend, but a hasty implementation on Jan. 1, 2000 is tantamount to "killing the hen for its eggs."
He said he is also opposed to making a timetable for its implementation, saying that the program's start should be decided by the market, rather than by the government.

Vice Economic Affairs Minister Yin Chi-ming said that with Taiwan's overall international competitiveness and domestic productivity not yet having reached the standards of a developed country, the full-scale implementation of a five-day work week would only result in domestic businesses' relocating overseas.

A spokesman for the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) said that if the five-day work week is fully implemented next year, the number of holidays will increase by 14 days to 111 days, making the Republic of China the nation with the most holidays in the world.

The CEPD official said Taiwan's economic growth would drop by 0.09 percent for each additional day workers have off, while wages would increase by 0.35 percent. In other words, the full implementation of a five-day work week program will bring Taiwan's economy down 1.26 percent annually as it produces an additional 14 holidays every year.

Meanwhile, the nationwide Chinese National Federation of Industries, which has 140 industrial associations around Taiwan as its members, voiced strong opposition to hasty implementation of the program, saying that the program, aimed at cutting the average weekly working hours from the current 44 to 40, is poised to increase the businesses' personnel costs by 10 percent to 20 percent.

Hsin Ping-lung, a senior researcher at the Chung-Hua Institute for Economic Research, a private economic think-tank, said that Japan's experience with the implementation of a five-day work week has shown that while wages do increase initially, they are eventually offset by increases in work efficiency and a higher degree of automation.

Newly released statistics from the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) indicate that Taiwan people spent a total of NT$71.8 billion (US$2.17 billion) on leisure activities in 1998 -- a year in which the government sector began following a work schedule that contained two five-day work weeks per month.

Spending on leisure activities in 1998 was 7.5 percent higher than in 1996 and 2.9 percent higher than in 1997. The amount spent on movies in Taiwan grew by a whopping 18.5 percent in 1998 compared with 1997.
In addition, the statistics also showed that visits to Taiwan's 110 major tourist attractions increased 3.6 percent in 1998 to 66.77 million.
Meanwhile, the occupancy rates of Taiwan's tourist hotels rose by 24.5 percent in 1998 to 2.44 million guests.
All the rising figures represent increased revenues and expansion in the domestic service and travel industries, DGBAS officials noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC HUMANITARIAN RELIEF MISSION RETURNS FROM MACEDONIA

TEXT.P: An ROC humanitarian relief delegation returned to Taipei on Saturday after a visit to Macedonia to express concern and offer assistance to ethnic Albanian refugees from neighboring war-torn Yugoslav province of Kosovo.
Vice Foreign Minister David Lee, who headed the delegation, said the group has satisfactorily completed its mission of assisting Kosovar refugees and the ROC ally of Macedonia.
During its three-day stay in Macedonia, Lee said, the delegation also met with many Macedonian officials to discuss feasible ways to further boost bilateral friendship and cooperation.

A 27-member medical team, composed of medical professionals and volunteers, still stay in Macedonia to operate a field hospital donated by the Republic of China. The field hospital is installed at the Strenkovec refugee camp, which shelter about 25,000 Kosovar refugees.
Lee said even though the group only made a brief stay in Macedonia, its visit still attracted much attention from Macedonian people.

Lee himself gave interviews to many news organizations, including Macedonian television stations, Japan's Kyodo news agency and Associated Press, during his stay in Macedonia to explain to the international community the ROC's humanitarian relief efforts.

Lee told the foreign press that the ROC has so far not received any request for sheltering ethnic Albanian refugees, but he added that the ROC is willing to consider assisting in reconstruction of Kosovo.

Lee said the medical team will stay in Macedonia for two to three weeks. Asked whether the ROC government will launch another round of humanitarian assistance to Kosovar refugees, Lee said it won't be decided until Macedonian Prime Minister Ljubco Georgievski makes an official visit to Taiwan in May.
Georgievski is expected to sigh three economic cooperation and investment protection agreements with Taiwan during his upcoming visit.

The ROC has so far offered about US$5 million in cash donations, medical equipment, foods, clothing and other daily necessities to help Kosovar refugees in Macedonia. The ROC forged formal diplomatic ties with the Balkan state in January this year.

Meanwhile, the six legislators who took part in the humanitarian relief journey, issued a joint statement upon their return, saying that the ROC should work even harder to boost trade, economic, educational, cultural, tourist and medical exchanges with Macedonia.

Noting that Macedonia's political and social situation remains stable despite the influx of a large amount of Kosovar refugees, the lawmakers said Macedonia welcomes ROC investments to help revitalize its economy.
The lawmakers from both ruling and opposition parties said they will push the Legislative Yuan to set up a special panel to boost relations with Macedonian parliamentarians.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLAND CHINA IS NOW PARTWAY THROUGH WTO DOOR: CHRETIEN

TEXT.P: Canada and mainland China announced Friday "major progress" in their bilateral talks over market access in regard to mainland China's World Trade Organization membership bid.

Canadian Prime Minister Jean Chretien said he and visiting mainland Chinese Premier Zhu Rongji were able to "agree in principle on trade in goods, including agriculture, and we were nearly there on services."
"China is now partway through the WTO door, and I am now confident that China will be a member of the WTO this year," Chretien added.

The remaining issues will be dealt with by officials of the two countries in Beijing before the end of April, Zhu said. Chretien wants to keep the momentum going so both governments can conclude negotiations as soon as possible.
Before Zhu's visit to Canada, officials from the two nations reached agreement on market access for agricultural and industrial goods, including a number of chemicals, minerals and farm products.

The two countries also agreed that mainland China's management of animal and plant health regulations will ensure that Canadian beef, pork and poultry producers are given fair and competitive access to the mainland Chinese market.

Asked whether mainland China will first sign a final agreement with Canada or the United States, Zhu said: "It's not important with whom we will sign first. As long as the conditions are ripe, we can sign. We're very patient, as we have already been waiting for that moment for 13 years."

DOC.HEADLINE: UN SEEN SEEKING AUSTRALIAN MILITARY PRESENCE IN E. TIMOR

TEXT.P: The United Nations is expected to request that the Australian military provide security for a planned autonomy ballot in July in the troubled territory of East Timor following reports of an alleged massacre in the territory.

In a dispatch from New York, The Sydney Morning Herald reports Jamsheed Marker, representative of UN Secretary-General Kofi Annan, said he hoped the Australian military presence was not necessary, but he said he was concerned by recent violence in East Timor, in which militia, backed by the Indonesian military, killed East Timorese in the town of Liquica, 30 kilometers west of the territory's capital, Dili.

The Australian daily on Saturday reported from Jakarta that a confidential Australian Embassy report on the killing of East Timorese civilians in Liquica concludes that allegations of a massacre are plausible and accuses the Indonesian military of colluding with militia forces in the lead-up to the incident.
Marker said the United Nations was still determining what formal presence it would need in East Timor.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSSIE DOLLAR, BOURSE SURGING

TEXT.P: The Australian stock market has hit record highs with bullish sentiments while its currency has risen to a two-month high with the help of rising commodity and resources prices in the world market, market analysts said.
The All Ordinaries Index rose 5.3 points to close at a new record high of 3,099.8 on Friday, up slightly from Thursday's close.
The Australian currency closed at 64.25 US cents on Friday.

Analysts said the 3,100-point barrier is expected to be breached next week because sentiments among investors remain bullish, and reports of rising prices of resources and commodities will continue to boost the sentiments of investors, who are expected to buy to cash in on the current conditions.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING TIGHTENING CONTROL OVER GAMBLING

TEXT.P: Mainland China is tightening its control over lotteries and closing down Internet sites offering get-rich quick games of chance for fear of a nationwide surge in gambling fever that could result in increased social unrest.

State-run banks will gradually take over the role of selling tickets for licensed lotteries, and from July 1, prizes worth less than 500 yuan must be paid in cash, according to a report in The Australian.

Illegal Internet-based gambling houses are to be closed down in a campaign that will target both gamblers and the advertisers who support gambling sites, the daily reported, quoting the Civil Affairs Bureau in the southern province of Guangdong.
Reports have abounded in recent months of people who have gambled away their life savings in the hope of winning it back many times over, the daily reported.

DOC.HEADLINE: BREAKTHROUGH IN CANCER DETECTION AND TREATMENT REPORTED (I)

TEXT.P: A US-based researcher who has made a breakthrough in cancer treatment has reported that his new treatment targets only specific cancer cells and spares normal cells.

Paul O.P. Ts'o, an academician of Academia Sinica, the highest research institute in Taiwan, reported the breakthrough at the fourth Taiwan Joint Cancer Conference held at Veterans General Hospital in Taipei on Saturday.

Ts'o, a professor at Johns Hopkins University in the United States, noted that current anti-cancer drugs kill normal cells as well as cancer cells, which results in damaging side effects for cancer patients.
But Ts'o's method uses a specific ligand, or carrier, that can identify the receptors of particular cancer cells and attack them, cutting to the minimum the drug's toxicity and side effects.

Ts'o has begun to develop anti-hepatitis and anti-hepatoma drugs, using specific ligand that carry the drugs to the liver, pass through the receptors of the liver cell membrane and enter into the liver cell itself. By doing so it suppresses the production of specific genes or enzymes that might influence the growth of diseases or drug resistance.

He said that he has conducted animal trials of these new treatment approaches in the United States and has obtained very positive results so far. The absorption of anti-cancer drugs into the livers of mice was enhanced by three to four fold with ligand as compared with the anti-cancer drugs without ligand.
He said that he is now planning to conduct trials on large animals, and will then monitor the effects of different drugs and different carriers or ligands.

He also announced the development of a procedure that allows researchers to separate and identify the origins of particular cancer cells within the blood. With the assistance of his colleagues in America, he has developed a procedure that relies on multiple tumor markers and automated microscopes to obtain valuable cancer information that cannot be obtained through other means.
He said that the method offers an alternative, non-invasive means of early detection of distant metastasis, such as prostate cancer, stomach cancer, lung cancer, pancreatic cancer and ovarian cancer.

This method has been developed in the United States and is currently under clinical observation by major cancer centers and institutes to obtain enough clinical data for commercialization, he reported.

He pointed out the deficiencies of traditional diagnostic methods, saying that tumors that can be detected by X-rays or other imaging instruments already contain millions of cancer cells, while available tests on certain tumor markers within the blood are not always accurate.

The most reliable diagnosis is to conduct a biopsy of the suspect tissue or organ, but this method usually requires surgery, except in the case of the cervical smears examined to detect cervical cancer, he said.

Faced with the difficulty of early detection, Ts'o has worked with several medical schools and cancer centers in the United States to develop an automated microscope that separates and identifies cancer cells circulating within the bloodstream. With the microscope, the presence of as few as 500 to 1,000 cancer cells in the blood can be detected.
He said that the method should be very useful for types of cancer that are difficult to diagnose in their early stages, such as pancreatic, ovarian, lung, stomach and prostate cancer.

Other types of cancer, such as breast cancer, can be detected using traditional methods of detection, so the new method will not necessarily be any better than traditional ones. But this method will offer physicians an powerful follow-up or monitoring tool to check for the recurrence of cancer in an area that has recently undergone treatment.

Ts'o said that his method could be useful in three areas: early detection of cancer; checking for the recurrence of cancer soon after a patient has undergone surgery or radiotherapy; and the assessment of anti-cancer drug efficacy. If a drug does not have a sufficient therapeutic effect, it can be changed for another type of drug, enabling physicians to ensure that the drugs are not used incorrectly, that the correct dosage of the drugs are given and that no resistance to the drugs can develop. (to be continued)

DOC.HEADLINE: BREAKTHROUGH IN CANCER DETECTION AND TREATMENT REPORTED (II)

TEXT.P: He noted that the procedure is currently available in the United States at a cost of between US$450 and US$500 per test, and results can be obtained within two days. Ts'o also said he is contemplating introducing the new detection technology to Taiwan later this year.
Ts'o said that early detection of cancer has been made possible through the development of the automated microscope, which he recently learned has won the Computerworld Smithsonian Award of 1999.
But Ts'o, who is concurrently chairman of Cell Works Inc. in the US state of Maryland, said modestly that the microscope's development is the result of a team effort.
The 70-year-old academician expressed his hope of working with many of Taiwan's outstanding researchers to benefit cancer patients here as soon as possible.

DOC.HEADLINE: SEF OFFICIAL BARRED BY BEIJING FROM ATTENDING GOLF TOURNEY ON MAINLAND

TEXT.P: Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) Deputy Secretary-General Chang Liang-jen, who was invited to take part in a golf tournament sponsored by Taiwanese business people in mainland China, was denied permission to enter the country Friday by mainland Chinese authorities.

SEF sent a letter on April 6 to its Beijing counterpart, the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS), asking that Chang be permitted to enter the mainland to take part in the golf tournament, which includes several competitions in the southern mainland Chinese cities of Fuzhou and Guilin, beginning April 15.

Both SEF and ARATS are intermediary bodies authorized by the Republic of China government and Beijing to handle exchanges across the Taiwan Strait in the absence of formal contacts between the two sides.

A brief reply was finally received Friday, after the start of the tournament. Although ARATS in its reply did not explicitly deny Chang permission to enter the mainland, it did say the Guilin competition had been canceled because "nobody registered to enter the contest" and that the golf tournament was an "interior" activity among Taiwan business people in mainland China.
But after checking with the sponsors of the tournament, SEF officials learned that the competitions in both Fuzhou and Guilin were being held as scheduled, SEF officials said.
SEF Vice Chairman and Secretary-General Shi Hwei-yow called the reply unbelievable, saying that it was regrettable that ARATS has boycotted cross-strait exchanges with political measures.
Shi also said he is increasingly worried about the welfare of Taiwan business people operating in mainland China, adding that they could face the threat of a "red terror."

SEF again called for ARATS to respect the four points of agreement reached by both sides during a meeting between SEF Chairman C.F. Koo and ARATS Chairman Wang Daohan in Shanghai last year. One of the agreements was that both agencies would help each other in arranging for visits by SEF and ARATS personnel to the other side as a way of improving relations across the Taiwan Strait.

DOC.HEADLINE: WASHINGTON URGED TO HELP TAIWAN'S ENTRY INTO WORLD FINANCIAL BODIES
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, April 16 (CNA) (By Nelson Chung and Eva Chen)

TEXT.P: Fredrick Chien, president of the Control Yuan of the Republic of China, urged Washington on Friday to assist Taiwan's entry into international organizations, especially financial ones.
Ever since the enactment of the Taiwan Relations Act (TRA) by the US Congress 20 years ago in April 1979, relations between Taipei and Washington have experienced twists and turns, said Chien.

Generally speaking, however, the US government has taken the TRA rather seriously, though Washington needs to play a more active role in helping Taiwan to participate in international financial organizations, he said.

Chien made the remarks when he attended a meeting with reporters from the Chinese-language news media in Washington. The US government's executive branch also mentioned this point when it reviewed its China policy several years ago, added Chien.
The former minister of Foreign Affairs of the Republic of China still holds that the level of Taiwan's mainland policy is ranked higher than its foreign policy.

There are priorities in foreign policy that are not likely to have a direct impact on the welfare and security of the Taiwan people -- whether they are performed well or not, explained Chien. But a wrong step or direction in Taiwan's mainland policy could result in an irrational response from Beijing that would harm Taiwan people's safety and well-being, he added.

As to reports indicating that proposals have been made that both sides of the Taiwan Strait reach a non-aggression agreement prior to final reunification, Chien noted that such an agreement could be termed as either a transitional or provisional agreement.

Taiwan's largest opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) has become more rational in recent years, and its stance on many issues has become closer to that of the ruling Kuomintang, observed Chien.
He concluded his conversion with the Chinese reporters by calling on overseas Chinese to support the Republic of China.

DOC.HEADLINE: SEMINAR ON ROC OPENS IN WASHINGTON

TEXT.P: A seminar on issues related to the Republic of China opened in Washington on Friday.

The two-day seminar co-sponsored by the Taiwan-based Chiang Ching-kuo Foundation for International Scholarly Exchange and by Chinese studies groups in the United States will discuss a broad range of issues concerning the Republic of China, including its ties with the United States and mainland China.

The seminar brings together more than a hundred scholars and experts from the United States and Taiwan, including David Dean, the former chairman of the American Institute in Taiwan and an adviser to the Chiang Ching-kuo Foundation; Hsu Cho-yun, a member of Academia Sinica; and Kau Ying-mao, a professor of political science at Brown University.
