In a luncheon held by the seminar's organizers at the Library of Congress, Stephen Chen, Taipei's representative to Washington, donated 600 Chinese-language books to the library on behalf of the ROC government.

DOC.HEADLINE: US TO KEEP CLOSE WATCH ON CROSS-STRAIT TIES: AIT CHIEF

TEXT.P: The United States will keep a close watch on the development of relations across the Taiwan Strait in the months ahead, American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) Chairman Richard Bush said on Friday.

The top American liaison officer with Taiwan in the absence of official diplomatic ties made the statement at a seminar marking the 20th anniversary of the Taiwan Relations Act (TRA), the US law governing substantive relations with Taiwan. The two-day seminar was held at the Flutcher School of Law and Diplomacy in suburban Boston.

Bush said in his speech, titled the US role in the Taiwan Strait issue, that the United States looks forward to see the two sides of the Taiwan Strait develop a practical, constructive engagement formula and framework to reduce tension.

Bush reiterated the five US basic stances on cross-strait issues: cross-strait problems should be resolved by peaceful means; the two sides should conduct constructive dialogue to mend differences; cross-strait issues should be resolved by Chinese people themselves as the United States will not act as a go-between; the United States will deal with cross-strait dialogue with an impartial attitude; and cross-strait agreements should be acceptable to both sides of the strait.

Noting that the United States believes the two sides of the Taiwan Strait can cultivate a good atmosphere and mutual trust with their wisdom to improve bilateral relations, Bush said reducing cross-strait tension is the first step to the long haul of resolving bilateral disputes.
But went on to say that the United Strait also insists that any solution to cross-strait disputes must be approved by the people of Taiwan.

Speaking on the same occasion, Shaw Yu-ming, deputy secretary-general of the Republic of China's ruling Kuomintang, said Taiwan's democratic achievements indicate that Chinese people can enjoy democracy and freedom.

"We believe Taiwan's achievements can inspire mainland China's democratic evolution," Shaw stressed, adding that he hopes the United States will use every possible opportunity to convince mainland authorities to undertake democratic reforms.
Shaw also urged the United States to continue faithfully implementing the Taiwan Relations Act in order to safeguard Taiwan's security and democratic way of life.

"We also hope the United States will discourage mainland China from engaging in an arms race with Taiwan, assist mainland China in economic development and instill democratic ideals among mainland youths," Shaw said, adding that he believes these efforts will be conducive to maintain mainland China's stability and peaceful evolution.
The seminar was moderated by Alan Wachman, a professor at the Flutcher School of Law and Diplomacy.
Former AIT Chairman Nat Bellocchi and more than 20 scholars and experts from both sides of the Taiwan Strait and the United States took part in the seminar.
The participants will discuss issues related to Taiwan's security on Saturday. (BY K. C. Huang and Sofia Wu)

DOC.HEADLINE: TWO PASSPORT FORGERY RINGS BUSTED

TEXT.P: The Criminal Investigation Bureau (CIB) on Saturday announced the successful crack of two passport forgery rings and the arrest of several key suspects involved in the two cases.

One of the forgery case, which involved cross-border human smuggling operations, was busted by the CIB's International Criminal Affairs Division, while the other was handled by the bureau's Fourth Investigation Corps.

The International Criminal Affairs Division said it was tipped off that a Taiwan-based cross-border human smuggling ring had often offered high prices to purchase the Republic of China's identity (ID) cards in Taipei City and Taipei County in recent months.

The ring allegedly would replace photos on the purchased ID cards with mainland Chinese people's photos and then commissioned several large travel services in Taipei to apply for ROC passports with the Ministry of Foreign Affairs.

With the legally acquired passports, the ring then applied for visas to Japan and the United States. Afterwards, the ring would sent all related travel documents to its accomplices in mainland China's Fujian province by DHL express delivery.
The mainland Chinese human smuggling ring then used all those papers to send prospective mainland migrants to Japan and the United States via Camboida, Vietnam and Thailand.
After weeks of monitoring and tracking, CIB agents managed to detect that the Taiwan ring was operated by Wang Chuan-chen nicknamed "little Hung."

CIB agents arrested Wang when he showed up to pick up passports at a travel agency in Taipei Friday afternoon. They also confiscated two passports with Japan and US visas as well as several tampered or falsified ID cards and other documents.

Wang, 44, confessed to police that he began last June to collude with two mainland men in mainland China's Fujian province in conducting illegal cross-border human smuggling by tampering or forging the ROC's ID cards and other documents. Each passport could fetch NT$150,000 to NT$200,000. Wang said he had made more than NT$1 million through such operations over the past year.
In the second case, Chen Jung-teh, 50, was accused of having stolen ROC passports and sent them to a Singaporean man, nickname Lao Wong, in Thailand.

According to CIB officials, Lao Wong would then tamper with those ROC passports which Chen would sell to prospective mainland migrants through the assistance mainland China-based human smuggling rings.
Chen allegedly could earn US$15,000 by sending each mainland migrant to Australia or Canada via Thailand or the Philippines.
Chen allegedly had also tempted several staff members at local travel agencies to help him secure ROC passports by illegal means.

CIB investigations show that two large passport theft cases reported at Chiang Kai-shek International Airport, Taiwan's main gateway, in July 1998 and January 1999, respectively, were related to Chen's ring.
CIB officials said they will make further investigations into the case in order to arrest other accomplices.

DOC.HEADLINE: LOCAL GOVERNMENTS CONTEND FOR BIGGER SHARE OF NATIONAL REVENUES

TEXT.P: The heads of 21 cities and counties locked horns with the mayors of Taipei and Kaohsiung Saturday in a meeting called by the Ministry of Finance (MOF) to discuss the disbursement of revenue by the central government to local governments.

Both Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou of the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) and Kaohsiung Mayor Frank Hsieh of the Democratic Progress Party (DPP) expressed their objections to proposed reductions in the size of their appropriations from the central government.

Each year the central government distributes money to city and county governments, as well as to the special municipalities of Taipei and Kaohsiung. The funds are obtained through a variety of taxes and in accordance with a complicated formula.

Of the amount distributed, 82 percent goes to the special municipalities and to city and county governments. Twelve percent is given directly to Taiwan townships, and the central government keeps for itself the remaining 6 percent.

The MOF usually gives 47 percent of the amount earmarked for distribution to the cities of Taipei and Kaohsiung. But this year the ministry proposed reducing that amount to 41 percent, though no final decision has been made.
The proposed reductions for the two municipalities would result in 41 percent of the revenue to be dispersed going to Taipei and Kaohsiung and 41 percent to the 21 city and county governments.

Ma said the proposed reductions would result in a shortage of NT$10.8 billion in the Taipei City budget. He said it would be difficult to fill in the gap because the budget plan has already been prepared and submitted to the city council for debate.
He accused the central government of pulling the rug out from under him and reneging on a promise not to cut its financial support for the city.

Without the NT$10.8 billion, Ma said, he can hardly deliver on some of his campaign promises. He accused the central government of trying to preempt him from fulfilling his promises by cutting off Taipei's financial means because of his "gentle manner" toward the authorities.

He asked during the meeting whether the same thing would have been done to his predecessor, DPP member Chen Shui-bien. While mayor, Chen was known for taking a tough line toward the central government, which is dominated by the KMT.

Meanwhile, Hsieh, whose Kaohsiung City government would face a shortage of NT$3.8 billion under the proposed reductions, suggested the central government dip into the 6 percent it keeps for itself rather than "rob Peter to pay Paul."

The government should dig into its own pocket rather than pit Taipei and Kaohsiung cities against other local governments, he said. Hsieh also called the central government to allow local governments, including Kaohsiung City, to raise their own income by issuing lotteries.

Minister of Finance Paul Chiu rejected Hsieh's suggestion that the central government should disburse some of the amount it keeps for itself, saying the central government's 6-percent share is reserved for emergency use.

The finance minister called on Ma and Hsieh to take into account the cash-starved counties and cities under the provincial government, some of which are so poor that they cannot produce a budget before an April deadline.
Chiu said the gap between the two municipalities and the city and county governments needs to be narrowed.
Chiu's opinion was supported by the city and county heads present at the meeting. Some even demanded that they receive 62 percent of the funds to be dispersed and the municipalities, 20 percent.

No conclusion was reached during the meeting, which Chiu said would be the final one with local government heads. He said his ministry would work out a formula and present it to the Cabinet for a final decision.

DOC.HEADLINE: GIO CHIEF TALKS ABOUT WTO MEMBERSHIP FOR BEIJING

TEXT.P: Taiwan would be glad to see mainland China admitted to the World Trade Organization (WTO), but the applications of Taipei and Beijing for WTO membership should not be linked together, a government spokesman said in Chicago Saturday.

Speaking at a seminar sponsored by the East Asian Studies Center of Chicago University, Chen Chien-jen, director general of the Government Information Office, said WTO membership for Beijing may help open the mainland Chinese market to the products of the United States, Taiwan, and other countries in the world.

Both Taipei and Beijing have applied for admission to the WTO. Taipei has refuted Beijing's claim that Taiwan should not join the trade organization before mainland China. Taiwan believes it is better qualified for WTO membership than mainland China.
Chen told the seminar that their applications are not related in any way, and should be processed separately.
The seminar was held on the occasion of the 20th anniversary of the enactment of the Taiwan Relations Act (TRA).
Chen also said in the seminar that the TRA is a unique US law, which has contributed greatly to the maintenance of stability and peace in the Asian Pacific area.

The enactment of the law was prompted by the US decision to switch diplomatic recognition from Taipei to Beijing on Jan. 1, 1979. The act was passed by US Congress in March, 1979 and signed into law by former US President Jimmy Carter in the next month.
The TRA provides a solid legal foundation for the development of substantive relations between Taiwan and the United States, Chen added.

DOC.HEADLINE: DIRTY JOKES WELL KNOWN AMONG TAIWAN TEENAGERS: SURVEY

TEXT.P: An academic survey on the sexual culture of Taipei's junior-high-school students has discovered that almost all of those surveyed have heard dirty jokes, though boys have more often told them than girls.
Lee Lan, a professor of public health at National Taiwan University interviewed 10 student groups in their first year at San Ming Junior High School in Taipei last year on issues related to sex.
More than 60 percent of the 1,500 students polled said they have told dirty jokes, with 67 percent of the boys and 57 percent of the girls saying they have told such jokes.

Most of the jokes they reported hearing came from their classmates, while teachers, comic books, TV programs, newspapers and the Internet were also cited as sources. Some teachers tell the jokes to enliven their classes, the survey found.
Most of the boys surveyed said they enjoyed hearing dirty jokes, though a few said they were disgusted by them. Most of the girls interviewed said they would laugh if the jokes were funny.

The survey also revealed that students who tell dirty jokes tend to be popular, and it found that junior-high-school students in Taipei are exposed to an environment filled with sexual-related information.
Thirty-eight percent of those interviewed, or 50 percent of the boys and 32 percent of the girls, said they have come into contact with "erotic products," such as pornographic videos and magazines.
But boys usually said it was entirely by accident that they did so, Lee said.
Those surveyed said the products typically came in the form of television shows, videotapes, comic books, magazines, movies, video compact discs (VCDs) and the Internet, Lee said.
The survey also revealed that 4.8 percent of the junior-high-school students polled have had sex.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR UP

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar surged on the Taipei market on Saturday, buoyed by a stronger Japanese yen and by inflows of foreign funds into the island.
The NT dollar opened at 32.84 against the greenback and traded between 32.75 and 32.84 before closing at 32.79.
The local currency rose NT$0.062 against the US dollar, compared with its close in the previous session.

Interbank US dollar trading reached US$397 million during the session. Trading was particularly hot at the island's two largest foreign currency brokerages. Their combined turnover on Saturday was nearly US$500 million -- the highest total weekend turnover of all Taiwan's brokerages combined since Oct. 4, 1997.
Dealers said the NT dollar is now in an upward trend and that the trend will likely be maintained in the near future.

DOC.HEADLINE: SHARE PRICES SKYROCKET

TEXT.P: Taiwan's share prices surged on Saturday, with the weighted price index, the market's key barometer, moving up 114.68 points to close at 7,581.5.
The bourse opened at 7,467.85 and soon then experienced an upward trend until the closing due to hot buying by foreign investors.
A total of 4.24 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$137.3 billion (US$4.19 billion).
Gainers outnumbered losers 348 to 92, with 67 stocks unchanged.
Only foodstuff shares of the eight stock categories posted a fall of 0.2 percent during the three-hour session.

The largest gain of 3.9 percent was registered at plastic and chemical issues. Textile shares enjoyed the same rise, followed by cement shares, which grew 3.5 percent; paper-making and construction stocks, 2.4 percent, respectively; electronic engineering issues, 1.2 percent; and financial stocks, 0.2 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Sunday, April 18, or the third day of the third month of the Year of the Rabbit according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important evens that have occurred on this date in the past:
1480: Lucrezia Borgia, the illegitimate Italian daughter of Pope Alexander VI, is born. She was married three times by the age of 18 to further her father's political ambitions.
1906: An earthquake devastates San Francisco, killing more than 1,000 people and making 300,000 others homeless.
1925: The first world women's exposition is opened in Chicago.
1927: The national government is established in Nanking by the Kuomintang.
1933: Fighting spreads in North China. Several strategic passes along the Great Wall fall to the Japanese.
1942: Bombers from a US aircraft carrier, led by Lt. Gen. James Doolittle, bomb Tokyo for the first time.
1943: Isoroku Yamamoto, Japanese naval officer, is killed when his plane above Solomon Islands is shot down by US warplanes. He planned Japan's naval Strategies during World War II, including the attack on Peral Harbor in 1941.
1946: The League of Nations is formally dissolved.
1948: The first National Assembly approves, by a two-thirds majority, temporary provisions granting emergency powers to the president during the ongoing anti-communist campaign.
1949: The Republic of Ireland is formally proclaimed in Dublin.
1954: Gamal Abdel Nasser becomes prime minister of Egypt.
1955: Albert Einstein, the German-born American theoretical physicist who won a Nobel Prize in 1921 for his explanation of the photoelectric effect, dies at the age of 76. His specific and general theories of relativity revolutionized modern thought on the nature of space and time, and formed a theoretical base for the exploitation of atomic energy.
1968: Army officers in western Africa's Sierra Leone take over the government, dissolve the legislature and suspend the constitution.
1977: A boat capsizes near Suao Port in eastern Taiwan, killing 32 college students and teachers on board and injuring 16 others.
1980: Former Rhodesia becomes independent Zimbabwe under President Canaan Banana.
1982: Monaco's Prince Rainier III and his wife, Princess Grace Kelly, arrive in Taipei for a visit.
1988: The ROC Red Cross Society begins forwarding mail from Taiwan residents to mainland China.
1989: The Mainland Affairs Council under the Executive Yuan decides to permit news gathering and film-making on the mainland.
1998: Official talks between South and North Korea end with the two sides failing to resolve a dispute over aid to the starving North and the reunion families.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A wise and good man may be known in three ways which I am not able to show in my own person. As a moral man he is free from anxiety; as a man of understanding he is free from doubt; and as a man of courage he is free from fear."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies Sunday are as follows:
The Central Daily News:
The Ministry of Finance will consider three proposals on the distribution of government revenue to local governments.
The China Times:
The share of government revenue sent to both local governments and the two municipalities is expected to be adjusted to 41 percent.
The United Daily News:
Shi Hwei-yow, vice chairman of the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF), said the delay in consultation between the SEF and its mainland counterpart on the visit of mainland China's top negotiator Wang Daohan with Taiwan could affect his trip to the island this autumn.
The Liberty Times:
The share of funding to be distributed to Taipei and Kaohsiung will be cut, however the actual money received will not be decreased.
The Commons Daily:
Some 30 people have reportedly died in rioting in East Timor.
The China Post:
Cities, counties battle for funding as money dries up.
The China News:
Thousands more fleeing Kosovo.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP'S CHEN STARTS US SWING

TEXT.P: Former Taipei Mayor Chen Shui-bian left for a nine-day visit to the United States on Sunday.

Speaking prior to his departure at the C.K.S. Airport, Chen, a heavy weight in the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), said that he will meet US congressmen, call on think tanks, grant interviews to The Washington Post and The New York Times, and hold seminars with Chinese community representatives.
This is Chen's third overseas visit in 20 days, following a trip to Japan in late March and a tour to South Korea and Mongolia earlier this month.

Chen, who lost his mayoral reelection bid to the incumbent Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou of the ruling Kuomintang late last year, is widely viewed as the DPP's most likely candidate in Taiwan's 2000 presidential election.

DOC.HEADLINE: GIO-PRODUCED DOCUMENTARY WINS GOLD MEDAL IN HOUSTON FILM FESTIVAL
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, April 18 (CNA) (By Nelson Chung and Victor Lai)

TEXT.P: A documentary featuring the relationship between the year of one's birth and the 12 animals in the Chinese Zodiac won a gold medal in the culture and history category of the Houston International Film Festival on Saturday.
The documentary was produced and distributed by the Republic of China's Government Information Office (GIO).
Nearly 3,000 films participated in the international film division, with more than 100 entered in the culture and history category.
Festival organizers said that the award indicated that the quality of Taiwan's documentary production is international standard.
According Lo Chuan-hsien, GIO representative in Houston, the award-winning documentary, produced by Chuang Chih-cheng, depicted the subject through vivid and humorous descriptions.

Lo said that Chuang successfully introduced the origin of the relationship between the year of one's birth and the 12 animals, its relationship with arts and folklore, and related beliefs and customs.
The 12 symbolic animals are the rat, the ox, the tiger, the hare, the dragon, the snake, the horse, the sheep, the monkey, the cock, the dog, and the boar.

DOC.HEADLINE: SEMI-CONDUCTOR IND. SHOWS RECOVERY

TEXT.P: Taiwan's semi-conductor industry has started showing signs of recovery as the global economic climate for the industry gradually resumes, sources reported on Sunday.
Influenced by the recovery, downstream industries of the semi-conductor industry such as wafer packing and IC lead frame manufacturing also received more orders amid expanded market demand.

Several IC lead frame producing companies showed negative figures in their account books for the first quarter of this year, a consequence of last year's economic recession. Yet these companies are planning to adjust prices upward by 5 percent as demand is buoyed by a recovering economy and the price move is accepted by IC lead frame buyers.
All the companies surveyed anticipate earning a profit or at least not incurring a serious deficit in 1999.
Apart from the revitalized semi-conductor market, some IC lead frame producing companies also are seeking an increase in corporate capital to expand productivity.

Due to Taiwan companies' efficiency and quality in wafer OEM (original equipment manufacture), Japanese semi-conductor related corporations such as MII and Sumitomo, are planning to set up IC lead frame manufacturing companies in Taiwan to enhance competitiveness. (by Amanda Chang)

DOC.HEADLINE: RYDER IN TAIWAN FOR SEMINARS

TEXT.P: Ryder, the United States' No. 1 company in the distribution and warehouse industry, will launch a series of seminars around Taiwan next week to help Taiwan small businesses set up strongholds in America.

Starting on Tuesday, Ryder's managers, at the invitation of the China External Trade Development Council (CETRA), will hold symposiums in northern Taipei and Hsinchu, as well as central Taichung and southern Kaohsiung, on strategies for entering into the north American market.

According to CETRA, other leading US distribution firms such as EG & G, Caterpillar, and Perfect Express, and the Free Trade Alliance of San Antonio, will send officials to take part in the seminars here.

DOC.HEADLINE: SECURITY LAWS TO BE AMENDED TO INVITE FOREIGN INVESTORS

TEXT.P: The Securities and Futures Commission under the Ministry of Finance is planning to amend its laws governing securities to attract foreign corporations to issue securities and raise funds in Taiwan, sources from the commission reported on Sunday.

According to the commission, few foreign corporates have issued bonds and depository receipts and raised funds since the guidelines concerning the issuance of securities by foreign corporates were proclaimed in 1997.

In order to effectively attract foreign corporates, the commission intends to review and revise the guidelines. The commission will take in the viewpoints of the Taiwan Stock Exchange and the Securities Trading Center before any final decisions are made.
The revision will mainly focus on how to attract foreign corporates and then convince them to reinvest all or most of the profits generated from securities back into Taiwan.
The issue of whether only Taiwan laws and courts or those of other countries' are entitled to govern foreign investments will be left to discussion, the commission added.
The commission promised to design guidelines that offer incentives to encourage foreign investment while guarding the rights of Taiwanese investors. (by Amanda Chang)

DOC.HEADLINE: QUAYLE WARNS BEIJING AGAINST USE OF FORCE

TEXT.P: Washington, April 17 (CNA): Former United States (US) Vice President Dan Quayle said Saturday that it would be a serious mistake on the part of the People's Republic of China to make a military invasion on Taiwan. But he did not say whether he would commit American forces to defend Taiwan if he were president.

When asked on the CNN program "Evans, Novak, Hunt & Shields" whether he would be willing to commit American forces if the PRC threatened Taiwan, the recently announced candidate for the Republican presidential nomination replied that "I have told the Chinese, privately -- and they know my views on that, if I become president. And they know that it would be a serious mistake on their part if....."
Co-host Al Hunt then said: "And you would commit American forces."

Quayle responded that "I am saying it would be a serious mistake on the PRC's part to have a military invasion of Taiwan. The PRC is concerned about Taiwan declaring independence. I am not encouraging Taiwan to declare independence, I don't think that they should declare independence.
"But Taiwan is a democratic entity, they have an independence party, that independence party might take over someday, and there is a hypothetical possibility that they might declare independence.

"It would not be wise on their part, but that the PRC has got to realize that the dispute between the PRC and Taiwan will be resolved peacefully. You have to say that quietly, firmly, and they have to understand that you mean business," he said.
Meanhile, the former vice president still does not think Beijing should be admitted to the World Trade Organization now.
When asked would he also deny the PRC permanent most favored nation trading status, Quayle said he thinks that the United States has to deal with this issue on an annual basis.

"China is not ready for the WTO. They may be someday, and someday we'd like to have them there because we'd like to have a mediation of trade disputes, but they clearly are not ready, and it would take a waiver, as you well know, of Jackson-Vanning (clause of banning free trade with several Communist countries) and the Congress before they could be admitted to the WTO," said Quayle.

He stressed that the United States should not give the PRC permanent MFN status, adding that "I believe that this should be reviewed on an annual basis because we have a real challenge with China, and the challenge with China is on a number of fronts, not just on human rights."

"The religious persecution issue is serious. The proliferation issue, the proliferation of technology, high technology, technology that can be used with weapons of mass destruction to Pakistan, to Iran and some other nations that raise grave concerns with us, and also we have the very sensitive issue of Taiwan. The PRC clearly has its sights on Taiwan. Taiwan is now ready for the admission to World Trade Organization," said Quayle.

The latest USA Today/CNN Gallup poll of Republicans' choice for the presidential nomination shows that Quayle ranked third with seven percent of support, lagging far behind Texas Governor George W. Bush, with 53 percent, and former Cabinet member Elizabeth Dole, 16 percent. But Quayle remains confident that he will defeat Vice President Al Gore, the favorite Democratic candidate, to win the 2000 presidential election. (by Nelson Chung)

DOC.HEADLINE: HELMS' BILL WILL AFFECT CROSS-STRAIT RELATIONS: EXPERT

TEXT.P: Washington, April 17 (CNA): The Taiwan Security Enhancement Act recently introduced by US Senate Foreign Relations Committee Chairman Jesse Helms (R-NC) is a very serious bill and will cause far-reaching changes in the cross-strait situation, said an American China expert Saturday.

Robert G. Sutter, a senior specialist in International Politics, Foreign Affairs, Defense and Trade Division of the Congressional Research Service, told a conference on Chinese studies here that the Act will effectively deal with a situation in which the security of Taiwan is threatened due to the imbalance of military power across the Taiwan Straits.
Even if this bill does not win support from the Clinton administration, Washington will have to take some appropriate measures in response to the threat against Taiwan, said Sutter.

The Taiwan Security Enhancement Act will require enhanced military exchanges between the US and Taiwan, and ensure that the ROC has the necessary equipment to maintain her defense, prohibit any politically motivated reductions in arms sales, and authorize the sale of a broad array of defense articles, including missile defense systems, satellite early warning data, diesel submarines and advanced air-to-air missiles.

The specialist noted that although the Kosovo crisis might distract the Congressional attention from the Clinton administration's China policy, just as the Congress shelved the China issue for about seven months during the Persian Gulf War, the issue will last longer and could be used by the Republicans to attack Vice President Al Gore in the 2000 presidential election.

Looking to the future, Sutter said the outlook is not for a consensus between the Congress and the administration on the US-China policy since its critics remain active due to PRC behavior. The Republican-dominated Congress may continue to press for a tougher US policy towards Beijing, but he does not believe critics will be able to rupture the relationship.

Professor Kao Ying-mao of Brown University pointed out that there seems to be a tremendous confidence crisis across the Taiwan Strait, and Taiwan will not enter into political negotiations with mainland China unless the safety and security of Taiwan are guaranteed by the United States. Thus, he said, the Taiwan Security Enhancement Act, co-sponsored by Helms and Sen. Robert Toricelli (D-NJ) in late March, is very important.

David Laux, president of the USA-ROC (Taiwan) Business Council, said the people of the United States and the world do not fully understand the strength and importance of Taiwan's economy. In fact, Taiwan is America's 7th largest trading partner and 70 percent of its huge foreign exchange reserves are held in US dollars, so Taiwan is very important to the United States.

The former Taipei Office managing director of the American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) believed that after helping Taiwan to join the World Trade Organization, the United States would try to assist Taiwan in its bid to re-enter such international financial institutions as the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund.

David Dean, adviser to Chiang Ching-Kuo Foundation for International Scholarly Exchange, said 20 years after its enactment, the Taiwan Relations Act is still a viable and important American law protecting Taiwan's security. And the United States will continue to strive for balanced relations with both sides of the Strait, leaving the two sides to resolve their differences by peaceful means.

Charles Cross and James Lilley, the other two former managing directors of the AIT Taipei Office, also spoke of their experiences in establishing strong security, trade and other substantive relations between the US and Taiwan after President Jimmy Carter derecognized Taipei in 1979.

More than 100 scholars and experts in Chinese studies from Taiwan and the US attended the two-day conference and held other panel discussions on current problems and future prospects of Taiwan-mainland China relations, economic development and social changes in Taiwan, development in mainland China from 1949-1999, as well as various related subjects. (by Nelson Chung)

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA IS TARGET OF HUMAN SMUGGLERS

TEXT.P: Canberra, April 18 (CNA): Australia, often called the "lucky country," is a growing target of human smuggling operations originating in southern mainland China.

The latest arrivals of illegal migrants in Australia from Fijian has caused alarm for the Federal and State governments because they were undetected by Coast watch patrols until they entered remote towns.

They were detained after Australian residents near Cairns in Queensland, Hoffs Harbor in New South Wales and Broome in Western Australia alerted police, who made the arrests and sent them to a detention center in Western Australia for questioning and identification.
Prime Minister John Howard has vowed to heighten surveillance along Australia's 37,000 km coastal areas.
Howard admitted that Australia is vulnerable to illegal boatloads of immigrants because "this is a very big country with a very big coastline."
"We have to be realistic about what can be achieved. But I assure the Australian people that we'll leave no stone unturned to give ourselves the best surveillance system we can afford," he said.
But Howard and his Defense Minister John Moore declined to use the military to crack down on any future illegal migrants, despite calls by the premiers of Queensland, Western Australia and Tasmania.
So far at least 100 refugees from Fijian have been detained and police are looking for more refugees, who may still be at large after landing in different places over the past two months.
Immigration Minister Philip Ruddock said many of these refugees were the victims of "snakeheads" operators, who charged each of them US$25,000-35,000 for the illegal odyssey.
All these refugees share the same dream of earning lots of money in their new country so that they could pay back their huge debt, build houses and lead a better life in mainland China in the future.
Australia is increasingly a magnet for boat people from Fujian, the center of mainland China's trade in illegal human cargo, according to a report by the Australian.
The daily reported smuggling rings have spirited away a generation of men and women from villages of coastal China because the rewards of sneaking into a foreign country are too tempting to resist.

It reported money sent back to Fujian province, the capital of mainland China's illegal emigration industry, is fueling a building boom and transforming the lives of people who, less than a decade ago, relied on the soil for their subsistence.

The daily quoted Mark Craig, a risk-management consultant and an expert in Asian organized crime from Queensland, as saying that triads who once specialized in heroin dealing are turning to illegal immigration as a lower-risk source of income.

He said the outbound traffic in human cargo has been gathering strength and voracity, run by powerful criminals, known locally as snakeheads with links to triads that dominate Chinatowns around the world.
Young Fujianese will pay upwards of up to US$35,000 for a stake in the riches offered by countries where, they are told, the streets are paved with gold.
Craig estimated the illicit human smuggling trade to the United States alone at US$3.5 billion a year. He said he has since 1994 publicly warned about the potential for a similar exodus to Australia.
Craig, who organized a five-member delegation to visit Fujian last November, said evidence of smuggling from Fujian has been well documented in the United States since 1980.

DOC.HEADLINE: 20 PERCENT DECIDED ON PRESIDENTIAL CHOICE

TEXT.P: About 22 percent of eligible Taiwan voters have decided whom to vote for in the 2000 presidential election, according to a new poll published on Sunday.

The poll, conducted by a poll center at the commission of the Television Society of the Republic of China, also found that nearly 39 percent of the surveyed are in favor of a specific candidate for president.

Among the 39 percent, more than half of them said a major event, or the exposure of a candidate's impropriety would cause them to change their minds, while over 30 percent said that they would switch their support if they are not satisfied with a political platform.

Amid speculation in local newspapers about who will run together with whom, the poll showed that nearly 65 percent will continue their support for a presidential candidate even if they disagree with his running mate.
The poll found that 46 percent believe the 2000 presidential election will be a race between the ruling Kuomintang and the opposition Democratic Progressive Party.

On whether the candidates from the third party or without party affiliation could win, only 15 percent of the polled said yes, while nearly 64 percent said no. The remaining 21 percent either said they don't know or didn't answer.
Professor Pao Chung-ho of National Taiwan University said the figures show the crucial role party affiliation still plays in Taiwan presidential elections.
But other factors, such as the domestic financial situation and cross-strait relations, which could affect the national interest, also play a role, Pao said.
The poll was conducted by random calls to eligible voters April 12-13. Effective samples received totaled 1,227 with a margin of error of 2.8 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN RANKING FOR IMD COMPETITIVENESS DROPS

TEXT.P: A report on national competitiveness compiled by the International Institute for Management Development (IMD) ranked Taiwan 18th among 46 countries, sources reported on Sunday.
Taiwan dropped from last year's 16th position to this year's 18th, illustrating the impact of the regional economic downturn.
Among all 47 countries, the United States ranked at the top of the list, followed by Asia's Singapore and North Europe's Finland.

Meanwhile, mainland China declined from last year's 24th spot to 29th, South Korea, dropped for the fifth consecutive year, to the 38th position from last year's 35th. Indonesia was down to 46th from 40th.
Russia stayed in the bottom of list while Slovenia, which was listed for the first time, also ranked 46th.

In response, Schive Chi, vice chairman of the Council for Economic Planning and Development, said that the setbacks for most Asian countries best illustrated the serious impact of the Asian economic turmoil.

Among the comparison items on the IMD list, Taiwan showed backwardness in business administration, economic power, its financial system and technological power. Schive said the results could be attributed to serious loopholes in the financial system and business administration.
IMD's report faithfully reflected Taiwan's shortcomings, said Schive.

Meanwhile, in terms of internationalization, infrastructure, government efficiency and human resources, Taiwan progressed according to the list. He said the progress was due to the government aggressively opening its telecommunication markets and promoting privatization as well as government re-engineering. (by Amanda Chang)

DOC.HEADLINE: ZHU LAUGHS OFF PROTESTS

TEXT.P: Visiting mainland Chinese Premier Zhu Rongji laughed off a human rights protest held Friday night in Toronto.
Jean Chretien, Canada's prime minister, and Zhu spoke to a business audience in Toronto as hundreds of pro- Tibet, Taiwan and Chinese democracy activists staged noisy demonstrations outside.
The demonstrators wanted mainland China to grant independence to Tibet and allow more freedom and democracy across mainland China.
The dinner went ahead without disruption. But Zhu made light of the protests during a breakfast speech Saturday morning. Zhu said the protests outside his hotel hadn't caused him any trouble.
He thanked Ontario Premier Mike Harris and "also the citizens of Toronto very much for their law-abiding capability," he said through an interpreter.

Zhu said he had "a very good sleep last night because although there were many people who were standing outside my hotel shouting for Taiwan independence and independence for Tibet, actually I was still able to have a good sleep."
He told Harris that unlike a similar demonstration during his recent visit to New York, Friday night's protest wasn't so noisy as to interrupt his sleep.
Harris did not raise any human rights issues during the meeting. Instead, he concentrated on promoting Ontario businesses and jobs, a senior aide said.
The next stop on Zhu's tour is Calgary, from where he will proceed to Victoria and Vancouver. He is scheduled to leave Canada on April 20.

DOC.HEADLINE: 82 PASSPORTS MISSING AT CKS AIRPORT

TEXT.P: Some 82 passports issued by the Republic of China were reported missing at the CKS International Airport, aviation policemen said on Sunday.
Hsiao Pu-shien, who works with local tourists bound for overseas, reported to police that he brought the passports with him to the airport Sunday morning.

Hsiao first handled check-ins at the Cathay Pacific Airways counter before moving the passports to a China Airlines group check-in counter. He said he left the passports unattended for about 20 minutes while he left with his girlfriend.
When they returned, they found the passports missing and after searching for nearly half and hour, reported their missing to aviation police.
Hsiao said that the missing passports belong to a tourist group which was originally scheduled to leave Sunday night for Thailand.
As government agencies close on Sunday, the tourists were forced to cancel their trip.

This is the second incident of missing passports at CKS airport this year. To avoid repeated incidents, police have registered the stolen passports' information in their computers to tract their whereabouts.
To prevent them from being smuggled out of the country, aviation police have also asked custom agents to step up checks on checked-in luggage.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENTIAL OFFICE OPEN TO PUBLIC FOR THE DAY

TEXT.P: The Republic of China (ROC) Presidential Office was opened to the public on Sunday, and despite rainy Taipei weather, many people were drawn to the normally closed-off office.
The eighty-year old stately building is situated in downtown Taipei, and is the symbol of the ROC's highest ruling body.

The Presidential Office has retained a sense of far-off mystery to the people since Taiwan's age of martial rule when it was closed to the public. After the martial law was lifted, the Presidential Office first offered public tours in 1995.
The bronze statues of President Lee Teng-hui and Vice President Lien Chan in the hall drew the most crowds as people were eager to take pictures with the busts.

As visitors followed the tour route, they saw the President's office, the reception room, and the Chiehshou Hall, where important festivities and meetings are held. The north and south courts outside the building also offered great views.
The visitors were impressed by the interior of the Presidential Office, and most thought it was fortunate that ROC leaders had such wonderful surroundings in which to lead the nation.
The Presidential Office has been opened to the public on several occasions in the past, resulting in Sunday's somewhat diminished numbers compared to previous occasions.
But the visitors were still excited to see the once-forbidden grounds of the President's office, and thought the experience was educational and historical.

DOC.HEADLINE: JEERS, CHEERS GREET ZHU IN CALGARY

TEXT.P: Dueling demonstrators jeered and cheered mainland Chinese Premier Zhu Rongji's arrival in Calgary Saturday, the Canadian Press said.

More than 200 people waited for the Chinese premier at a downtown hotel. A police barricade separated protesters waving Tibetan flags and shouting "Rongji go home" from supporters who held mainland Chinese flags and yelled words of welcome, according to the report.
"He's a leader who cares about the lives and the living standards of Chinese people so he's doing a lot for Chinese people," it quoted supporter Sam Chen.

But Nima Dorjee of the Tibet-Canada committee said Canada should be ashamed for rolling out the red carpet for Zhu. He was angry that Calgary Mayor Al Duerr gave Zhu a white hat when he arrived at the airport.
"To me the symbol of the white hat is no longer that of peace, it's no longer that of honor -- it is one that is given to despots and dictators now," Dorjee was quoted.

After Tibet's failed 1949 uprising against the Chinese, the Dalai Lama and 120,000 followers fled their Himalayan homes for what has become a lifelong exile. Mainland China annexed Tibet after the revolt.
Duerr said critics are making too much of the white hat presentation. "I have never intended for the white hat to be a political statement. It's a symbol of our hospitality and that's it."
Zhu attended a dinner with Justice Minister Anne McLellan Saturday evening. He toured a biotechnology facility before going to a reception hosted by Alberta Premier Ralph Klein.

DOC.HEADLINE: TACHIA GODDESS OF THE SEA STARTS FOUR-COUNTY 8-DAY PATROL
DOC.DATELINE: Taichung, central Taiwan, April 18 (CNA) (By Victor Lai)

TEXT.P: The folk deity Matsu, Goddess of the Sea, left from the Tachia Chenlankung Temple in Taichung at the start of an eight-day trip to four counties on Sunday.
More than 100,000 worshippers throughout the island will escort the goddess Matsu on the 280-kilometer tour. The goddess will visit 59 temples in Taichung, Changhua, Yunlin and Chiayi Counties.
Political figures did not miss the chance to pray to the goddess and to solicit support from the worshippers.

The four prospective contenders in next spring's presidential election, Vice President Lien Chan (Kuomintang), former Taiwan Gov. James Soong (KMT), former Democratic Progressive Party Chairman Hsu Hsin-liang, and former Taipei Mayor Chen Shui-bian (DPP), were among the hundreds of thousands of worshippers seeing the goddess off.
Other prominent political figures in attendance included Taiwan Gov. Chao Shou-po, Taichung County Magistrate Liao Yung-lai, Taichung Mayor Chang Wen-ying, and Chiayi Magistrate Lee Ya-ching.
The Tachia Goddess of the Sea usually makes a patrol trip to neighboring counties once a year to offer blessings for worshippers, resulting in a large cultural event throughout central Taiwan.

In accordance with the customary practice, three firecrackers were ignited before Matsu left the Chenlankung Temple. They were ignited respectively by former Taiwan Gov. Soong, Chenlankung Temple Chairman Yen Ching-piao, and Chen Chi, representative of the worshippers.
The four prospective presidential contenders attracted special attention from the worshippers, and they took advantage of the opportunity to spell out their political ideals.

Soong, who is critical of mainstream KMT leadership, told the media at the temple that the vigorous development of religious activities implied the people's desire for political cleanness and stability.

DOC.HEADLINE: HK MIDDLE CLASS SUFFERING: ACADEMICS
DOC.DATELINE: Taichung, central Taiwan, April 18 (CNA) (By Victor Lai)

TEXT.P: Singapore, April 18 (CNA): Hong Kong has become a contentious society rife with all sorts of highly-vocal interest groups, each with its own agenda, said two senior Singapore academics.

"Fanned by a free and sometimes wild press, some interest groups have become very vocal and assertive," said a report written jointly by East Asian Institute head Wang Gungwu and research director John Wong.
They warned that the worst-affected group would be the middle class, being the least organized and most divided.
"As political anxiety over the handover subsided after 1997, the politics of identity have given way to potential class conflict," they noted.
Before the handover, politics of identity dominated debate in the British colony, with a clear divide between the "pro-China" and the "pro-democracy" camps.
However, after the handover, class struggle has dominated politics in the Special Administrative Region (SAR), said the report, a copy of which was obtained by The Straits Times.
The regional economic crisis, it noted further sharpened class conflicts among organized labor, business interests and the middle class.
"Little organized and badly divided, the middle is set to lose out," the two academics predicted.
But they clarified that this did not mean Hong Kong is in a "state of disarray".
"People are still highly pragmatic and socially mobile, and life is still organized around the practical aspects of making money," they said.
The point to be made was that when a deeply-divided society is in crisis, it is difficult for its government to mobilize political and social consensus or introduce tough policies.
Meanwhile, the SAR faces a double challenge: It not only has to stay competitive as a global city, but it also has to fulfill its long-term strategic need of staying relevant to mainland China.
"If Hong Kong were to slowly deteriorate into just another Chinese city, its very survival would be at stake," the paper said.
Over the years, the territory has developed a viable economic symbiosis with southern mainland, which will grow more important after the current recession.
This generates the impetus inevitably for closer political and social integration with mainland.
Yet, under the principle of "one country, two systems" , Hong Kong's institutional structure is not required to evolve to accommodate mainland's.
But the SAR was also not supposed to develop its own political identity.
"Hence, this is a dilemma for Hong Kong," the report said.

Same bed, different dreams. This Chinese saying may reflect the acceptable position for mainland and Hong Kong today. But it is a serious problem which must be tackled in time or a political crisis might develop, said a Wang Gungwu and John Wong.
While Hong Kong continues to enjoy a thriving economic symbiosis with mainland, the issue of how long it can keep a political and social distance has to be resolved.
"Clearly the matter cannot wait for 50 years. The next generation of leaders of both China and Hong Kong will have to start tackling the problem of 'tougchuang yimeng," they said.
Most of Hong Kong's residents are apparently happy with their status quo, expressing little desire to see an earlier convergence of the two systems.

Eventually, they must accept the mainland and learn how to live with it, the writers said, adding, "The question of Hong Kong's future political and social integration with China remains the most intractable part of the post-colonial transition for Hong Kong. There is still a great deal of uncertainty as to how this will exactly come about, in as much as China itself is also in a dynamic process of political and social change."

DOC.HEADLINE: GANGSTERS RECRUIT MEMBERS FROM SCHOOL CAMPUSES

TEXT.P: Police said on Sunday that they have nabbed 18 people for their involvement in an organized criminal gang.

Police said that those nabbed included Yang Chin-cheng, 33, head of the Skyhawk den of the Bamboo Union in Sanchung, Taipei County, who police claim was involved in recruiting members to the gang from high school campuses or from teenaged dropouts.
Police said that Yang instructed a 17-year-old teenager, with the surname Wu, to recruit new members from middle and senior high schools in Taipei County.
Among the 18 nabbed, seven were from Sanho Junior Middle School in Sanchung, police said.
In a early morning raid of the gangster's den, police seized gang banners, knives, secret code manuals, bookings, receipts, and poles used to discipline members.
Police said that the newly recruited gangsters would make a living by receiving a commission from collecting debts for others.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies Monday are as follows:
The Central Daily News:
The National Assembly will meet in June to discuss constitutional amendments.
The China Times:
The voting day for next year's presidential election is tentatively set on March 18.
The United Daily News:
The ROC agreed to increase import quotas for Australian agricultural and husbandry goods.
The Liberty Times:
The Central Weather Bureau warned that eastern and western Taiwan may be hit by major earthquakes.
The Commons Daily:
The plebiscite promotion association intended to collect 210,000 signatures to support its cause.
The China Post:
Matsu, savior of the downtrodden, begins island trip.
The China News:
Capitalizing on Matsu; sea goddess pilgrimage starts on political foot.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP LAWMAKER SAYS HUNGER STRIKE RIPE FOR REASSESSMENT

TEXT.P: Hunger strikers may consider on Tuesday whether to end the strike now that they have succeeded in getting a plebiscite bill included in legislative debates, a Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) legislator said on Monday.
The Legislative Yuan resolved last Friday, the seventh day of the DPP-initiated hunger strike, that a proposed plebiscite bill would be discussed during its Tuesday session.

DPP Legislator Hsu Tien-tsai (Tainan), who is among the 24 DPP lawmakers and pro-plebiscite activists that have been striking in front of the Legislative Yuan since April 10, said that a reassessment of the strike would be needed after it passed its 10th day.
Hsu said the Legislative Yuan has shown a certain degree of goodwill by agreeing to including the proposed plebiscite bill in discussions on Tuesday.
He said he would give full consideration Tuesday to whether the strike should be continued.
Meanwhile, doctors monitoring the group of hunger strikers said that some have reached their limits, with low blood pressure and hypoglycemia.

A group of college and university students will join the hunger strikers late Monday afternoon for a vigil that will last until Tuesday morning when the Legislative Yuan begins debate on the proposed bill.
