DOC.HEADLINE: COA DENIES OFFERING ADDITIONAL 'DOWN PAYMENT' TO AUSTRALIA

TEXT.P: The Council of Agriculture (COA) on Monday denied that it has agreed to offer additional "down payment" to Australia in exchange for his support of the Republic of China's bid to enter the World Trade Organization (WTO).

The Cabinet-level council was responding to a United Daily News report that Taiwan's has quietly decided to offer additional import quotas for Australian farm goods as a "down payment" for its WTO accession. In addition, the report said, Taiwan will also offer similar "down payment" to Canada.
"The report is not true," COA Chairman Peng Tso-kwei said, adding that the COA has no plans to make further concessions on the "down payment" issue.

The "down payment" refers to preferential import quotas offered by a WTO membership applicant to a specific WTO member economy for a specific product before the applicant's formal entry to the Geneva-based world trade regulatory body.
COA officials said the ROC has already paid much price in its bilateral negotiations with 26 WTO contracting parties concerning terms for its WTO accession.

The officials pointed out that Taiwan has offered "down payments" to Australia, New Zealand, Canada, the United States, Argentina, Chile, Japan and South Korea, allowing a specified amount of some of their agricultural products to enter the Taiwan market before Taiwan's WTO admission.
For instance, Australia is eligible to export to Taiwan 2,400 tons of apples, 600 tons of tangerines and 1,000 tons of peaches and plums annually.

COA officials said Australia indeed asked for additional agricultural import quotas and new quotas for its livestock and poultry early this year. Australia demanded that its annual import quotas for apples, tangerines and peaches/plums be raised to 4,800 tons, 5,000 tons and 3,000 tons, respectively.

Meanwhile, the officials said, New Zealand has also requested for doubling the annual import quotas for its apples and peaches/plums. New Zealand currently can export 8,000 tons of apples and 500 tons of plums/peaches to Taiwan a year.

Canada has been pressuring Taiwan to open its doors to Canadian livestock and poultry ever since the ROC agreed early last year to allow imports of 10,000 tons of chickens, 7,500 tons of pork bellies and 12,500 pork and beef offals from the United States annually prior to its WTO entry.

"Despite strong pressure from Canada, the COA has no intention to compromise on this issue," a senior COA official said, adding that unless higher level of government authorities make a different decision based on other considerations, the COA will not budge from its stance.

In related news, local press report said Chen Ruey-long, director-general of the Board of Foreign Trade, will travel to the United States in the next few days to look into the possible impact on Taiwan of recent Washington-Beijing negotiations over terms for mainland China's WTO accession.
Bilateral Mainland China-US WTO negotiations reportedly made breakthroughs during mainland Premier Zhu Rongji' recent US trip.

DOC.HEADLINE: CEPD HEAD COMMENTS ON IMD'S RANKING OF TAIWAN

TEXT.P: A Swiss-based organization that ranked Taiwan as the world's 18th-most competitive country has faithfully reflected the advantages and weaknesses of the island's economic situation, an economics official said on Monday.

P.K. Chiang, chairman of the Council for Economic Planning and Development, made the remarks after the International Institute for Management Development (IMD) gave Taiwan the No. 18 spot, down from No. 16 last year, in its 1999 World Competitive Yearbook.

Even though Taiwan moved down two notches, Chiang said he was glad to see the government's efforts over the past year have borne fruit, and that the government has identified Taiwan's problems and is prepared to address them.

Chiang noted that of the 17 countries ranked above Taiwan, 12 -- including the United States and various European countries -- have not been affected by the fallout from the Asian financial storm. Except for Singapore, which retained its second-place ranking from last year, all Asian countries have fallen in the survey.

Of the 47 economies examined in the survey, the United States was No. 1, while Taiwan was fourth among Asian countries, behind second-place Singapore; Hong Kong, which placed seventh; and Japan, which placed 16th.

Chiang said the main reason for Taiwan's slip was that the IMD conducted the survey during the first quarter of the year, when Taiwan's economy was at its lowest point. In addition, Taiwan was being rocked at that time by a series of financial crises suffered by several enterprises. These developments affected foreign manufacturers' views about Taiwan's economic situation, he said.

The IMD's rankings seek to indicate the ability of a nation to provide an environment that sustains the competitiveness of enterprises. The study covers more than 250 criteria groups under eight competitiveness input factors: the domestic economy, internationalization, government, finance, infrastructure, management, science and technology, and people.

Assessing Taiwan's performance, Chiang said there has been marked improvement in areas that have been targeted as major shortcomings in past years. In terms of government efficiency, Taiwan moved up three notches to 11th, and in infrastructure it moved up five notches to 21st. This year Taiwan was ranked 27th in terms of internationalization and 15th in terms of its people.

Chiang acknowledged, however, that in the wake of the region's financial storm, Taiwan's economic growth spiraled down each quarter last year. As a result it dropped to 12th in terms of its domestic economy.
Taiwan's rankings in the areas of financial systems, enterprise management, and science and technology also dropped, he said.

Chiang said the government needs to step up its efforts to monitor and regulate financial institutes and enterprises, as well as continue to promote economic recovery. These goals are reflected in the CEPD's tactics to strengthen economic fundamentals and expand domestic demand, he said.

The nation also needs to continue to push its Asian-Pacific operations hub project and government restructuring to promote continued internationalization and improved government efficiency, Chiang said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Monday, April 19, or the fourth day of the third month of the Year of the Rabbit according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1832: Jose Echegaray y Eizaguirre, Spanish dramatist, mathematician, statesman and Nobel Laureate, is born.
1853: Russia claims to be the protectorate of Turkey in a prelude to the Crimean War.
1882: Charles Darwin, British naturalist, dies at the age of 73. He revolutionized the study of biology with his theory of evolution based on natural selection. His most famous works include "Origin of Species," and "The Descent of Man."
1906: Pierre Curie, French chemist and physicist, is run over and killed in Paris at the age of 47. He and his wife Marie shared the 1903 Nobel Prize for fundamental research on radioactivity.
1928: Japanese troops occupy Shantung Province in northern China.
1942: Chinese Expeditionary Forces, led by Gen. Sun Li-jen, capture Yenangyuang in northern Burma, rescuing more than 7,000 British and Burmese troops from Japanese encirclement.
1948: The first National Assembly elects Chiang Kai-shek as China's first president under the new Constitution garnering 2,430 out of 2,704 votes.
1956: Prince Rainier of Monaco marries American screen actress Grace Kelly in Monte Carlo. Over 1,200 guests attend the televised Catholic wedding ceremony.
1959: The Dalai Lama, Tibetan leader fighting the communist Chinese invasion, finds sanctuary in India.
1960: President Syngman Rhee is toppled in a nationwide pro-democracy student uprising that was protesting South Korean election fraud.
1966: Australian troops leave Sydney to join American forces in Vietnam.
1974: The Blood Donation Association, ROC, is inaugurated.
1975: India's first satellite is launched by Soviet rocket.
1977: Education Minister Tsiang Yien-si resigns for an incident in which 32 college students and teachers were killed when their boat capsized near Suao Port in eastern Taiwan. Tsiang was succeeded by Li Yuan-zu.
1992: Minister of Foreign Trade Yvonne C.M.T. van Rooy of the Netherlands visits Taipei to seek stronger bilateral relations.
1993: A total of 87 Branch Davidian cult members, including their leader David Koresh, are killed when federal agents storm their compound in Waco, Texas, after a 51-day standoff. Nine other members are freed.
1995: A huge truck bomb destroys the Alfred P. Murrah government building in Oklahoma City, killing 168 people and injuring more than 400 others.
1995: Malawi President Bakili Muluzi pays a state visit to Taipei.
1997: The SS Sheng Da, a mainland China container freighter, steams into Kaohsiung Port on its maiden voyage, becoming the first ship to sail directly to Taiwan from the mainland in 48 years, and completing an historic crossing of one of the world's great political divides.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Be not concerned that men do not know you; be concerned that you have no ability."

DOC.HEADLINE: SCHOOLS URGED TO DECLARE WAR AGAINST CAMPUS GANGSTERS

TEXT.P: Vice Education Minister Yang Kuo-tsu said on Monday that he will see to it that schools of all levels around Taiwan declare a war against the infiltration of organized crime onto school grounds.
Fielding questions at the Legislative Yuan, Yang said the Ministry of Education (MOE) will send notices to this effect to school authorities islandwide within one week.
Meanwhile, he said, the MOE is calling for all members of society to join a nationwide drive to sweep gangland influences out of Taiwan's schools.

Yang was bombarded by accounts from legislators of students being bullied in school by gangland figures or being forced to do jobs outside school that the legislators considered improper for students.

According to the legislators, some students have had sand sprinkled into their boxed lunches by fellow classmates who demand money in order to let the students eat in peace in the future. The legislators hinted that the sand-sprinkling bullies have been trained by the underworld.

Meanwhile, some junior-high-school students have been forced by gangsters to take part in weddings as flower boys and girls, and some high-school students have been forced to attend funerals, acting as a family members of the deceased, the legislators said.

Democratic Progressive Party Legislator Tsai Ming-shien said gangs have wielded influence on school campuses for about three years. He urged the MOE to come up with concrete and immediate measures to help eradicate organized crime in schools.
Kuomintang Legislator Chu Li-lun urged the MOE to help establish mid-way homes to accommodate youngsters who are either led astray by "bad people" or who suffer from behavioral problems.

Meanwhile, Wu Tsai-shun, director of the Taipei County government's Bureau of Education, said Yang Chin-cheng, a figure affiliated with the underground "Chu Lien" Clan, was arrested Sunday by police in Sanchung, Taipei County, for inducing junior- and senior-high-school students to join the clan.
Once students joined the clan, they were trained to dun debts, sell goods, or rig public projects, Wu said.
Some 66 students in Taipei County have reportedly joined the "Chu Lien" Clan.

According to authorities at San Ho Junior High School in Sanchung, a student at the school surnamed Tsai was instructed by a gang to recruit new members from within the school. He is known to have provided the names of six students he thought would be suitable, although none were found to have participated in any illegal activities.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA TO EXPRESS CONCERN OVER VIOLENCE IN E. TIMOR

TEXT.P: Prime Minister John Howard will contact Indonesian President B.J. Habibie this week to express Australia's grave concern over rising violence in East Timor, where at least 30 civilians have been killed by pro-Indonesian militias, which have the tacit backing of Indonesia's military.
Howard will either write or telephone Habibie, asking him to stamp out further violence by militias in East Timor.
In his sharpest condemnation yet of Jakarta, Howard blamed the Indonesian military and its arming of the militias for the violence.
"You have to wonder whether these pro-integration militia men are getting some kind of permissive response from the Indonesian army," Howard told Australia's Channel Nine TV Network on Sunday.

Foreign Minister Alexander Downer was even more explicit, saying both the Indonesian government and the armed forces had "clearly failed" to maintain law and order and protect the people of East Timor from militia leaders.

"It is imperative that the armed forces begin the process of disarming the militias and that those responsible for the violence and killings be brought to account," he said. The federal Cabinet on Monday will hold a meeting to discuss the issue and Australia's options in attempting to persuade the Indonesian government to crack down on the violence in East Timor.

Political analysts said the sudden upsurge of violence appears calculated to disrupt fresh talks on East Timor's future at the United Nations in New York. The violence has threatened to derail plans for a UN-sponsored July ballot aimed at paving the way for a settlement of the 23-year-old conflict over Indonesian rule of the territory.

DOC.HEADLINE: MUCH FRICTION IN HONG KONG, SAY SINGAPORE ACADEMICS

TEXT.P: Hong Kong has become a contentious society rife with all sorts of highly-vocal interest groups, each with its own agenda, said two senior Singapore academics.

"Fanned by a free and sometimes-wild press, some interest groups have also become very vocal and assertive," said a report written jointly by East Asian Institute head Wang Gungwu and research director John Wong.
They warned that Hong Kong's middle class may be most affected, being the territory's least organized and most divided group.
"As political anxiety over the handover subsided after 1997, the politics of identity have given way to potential class conflict," they noted.
Before the handover, politics of identity dominated debate in the British colony, with a clear divide between the " pro-China" and the "pro-democracy" camps.
But, after the handover, class struggle dominated politics in the Special Administrative Region, said the report, a copy of which was obtained by The Straits Times.

Although they said the region's economic crisis further sharpened conflicts between organized labor, business interests and the middle class, they said they do not see Hong Kong in a "state of disarray," as some sociologists have suggested.
"People are still highly pragmatic and socially mobile, and life is still organized around the practical aspects of making money," they said.

DOC.HEADLINE: HARVARD ECONOMIST OPTIMISTIC ABOUT ASIA'S ECONOMY

TEXT.P: Noted Harvard economist Jeffery Sachs is "on the whole, optimistic" about crisis-hit Asia's return to economic growth, especially in the second half of this year.

"The region is moving beyond the panic stage and is poised for the start of economic recovery," he said in a paper titled "The Asian Crisis: What happened and what is to be done, released over the weekend in Geneva.
"However, the pace of recovery is still open to question because of uncertainties about the cleanup of debt and long-term institutional reforms," he added.

Among the other provisos mentioned: The United States and Europe must ensure there is sufficient liquidity in the world's financial markets by cutting interest rates, as necessary, and also keep their domestic markets open to imports.
Overall, Sachs argued that the current "crisis greatly overstates the weakness of Asia and the collapse is not really justified by any fundamental weakness."
He forecasts that just as the collapse of Asian economies occurred faster than expected, the recovery will also be faster than expected.

DOC.HEADLINE: Y2K LESS THREATENING TO BEIJING THAN OTHER PROBLEMS

TEXT.P: The threat of the millennium bug -- Y2K -- is much less serious to mainland China than are problems in its economic and political sectors, including surging unemployment, a deflating economy and the 10th anniversary of the Tiananmen Square massacre.
In a dispatch from Hong Kong, Rowan Callicks of The Australian Financial Review noted that there are about 20 million computers in mainland China, a country with 1.2 billion people.

The daily reported that the Y2K problem is far less serious than mainland China's surge in unemployment in provincial centers, the 10th anniversary of the Tiananmen Square massacre and the 50th anniversary of the founding of the People's Republic of China. Other concerns that outweigh Y2K are economic deflation and environmental disintegration.
The daily reported that Y2K has not appeared on many radar screens in mainland China.
A Y2K working group within mainland China's Ministry of Information said only computer technicians seemed to be aware of and concerned about the Y2K threat.

But Y2K may be less troublesome to mainland China than to other countries, because mainland China underwent computerization fairly recently. As a result, much of its computer equipment is already Y2K compliant, according to the report.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA'S POULTRY INDUSTRY IN TURMOIL

TEXT.P: Australia's US$1.3 billion poultry industry is in turmoil after the appearance of news reports that more than 250,000 chickens were found to be carrying the deadly Newcastle disease and that Australian authorities have started destroying the birds.
Poultry industry sources are worried that the new outbreak of chicken disease in New South Wales (NSW) could damage local sales and even affect exports.
This is the second outbreak since last September when 100,000 birds were destroyed on two properties in western Sydney.
A spokesman for the Department of Agriculture of NSW said the disease is not thought to be dangerous to humans, but those who work closely with the infected birds may develop conjunctivitis.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC-SWAZILAND ECONOMIC CONFERENCE OPENS

TEXT.P: The Republic of China (ROC)-Swaziland Conference on Economical and Technological cooperation opened in Taipei on Monday.

Wang Chih-kang, ROC minister of Economic Affairs, and his Swaziland counterpart M. V. Sithole, Swaziland minister for Economic Planning and Development, will head discussions ranging from trade, investment and tourism to medical care during the conference which lasts until Thursday.
The conference, which alternates between the ROC and Swaziland each year, is an important conduit for bilateral economic and technological cooperation, economic officials said.

They said that Swaziland hopes to attract Taiwan investment, noting that it will soon complete a long-term national development plan and engage in a socio-economic reform project over the next three to five years.

The southern African nation has set up an investment promotion board and an industrial zone, expanded highway construction and electricity transmission networks in order to improve its telecommunications system.
Swaziland officials also said their country offers good investment opportunities in its paper making, pharmaceutical, jam, fertilizer, cement and electrical appliances industries.
Minister Wang led a delegation to Mbabane, Swaziland, last year, for a similar conference resulting in the signing of an investment guarantee agreement.
Bilateral trade between the ROC and Swaziland totaled US$2.64 million in 1998.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR UP TO TWO-MONTH HIGH

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar rose NT$0.004 to the greenback on the Taipei market Monday, closing at the two-month high of 32.75.
Continuing inflows of foreign funds was the main power prompting the appreciation of the local currency, dealers said.
The NT dollar opened at the day's low of 32.778 and had a high of 32.69.
The interbank US dollar trading reached US$597.5 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: 1ST AIRCRAFT MAINTENANCE PERSONNEL TRAINING INSTITUTE TO BE LAUNCHED

TEXT.P: Taiwan's first professional commercial aircraft maintenance personnel training institute will be inaugurated in Taipei on Tuesday.

China Institute of Technology and Commerce (CITC) said on Monday that the Civil Aeronautics Administration (CAA) has agreed to its application for setting up an aircraft maintenance personnel training center.
A CITC spokesman said the CAA will present a certificate to the institute in the Taipei suburb of Nankang on Tuesday for the establishment of the special training department.
"The CAA has conducted five stages of inspection of our facilities, faculty, training programs and management operations before it finally agrees to issue the certification," the spokesman said.
Noting that aircraft maintenance is instrumental to flight safety, the spokesman said the CITC will dedicate itself to the upgrading of aircraft maintenance services in Taiwan.

Up to date, basic training for aircraft maintenance personnel is offered by local airline companies. With the rapid development of aviation technology, aircraft maintenance personnel requires professional expertise in various fields, ranging from computer, electronics and communications to automated control and composite materials.

Against this background, it has become increasingly difficult for airline companies to offer comprehensive training programs for maintenance personnel. As a result, advanced Western countries have allowed the establishment of professional training institutes to train qualified maintenance manpower under the supervision of civil aviation authorities.
To catch up with this general world trend, the CAA has decided to encourage private investment in aircraft maintenance manpower cultivation.
The CITC filed its application on Dec. 31, 1997. After two years of preparations, the institute finally passed the CAA's inspection.

The institute plans to recruit graduates of colleges or senior high vocational schools in related fields for intensive professional training. Each student must receive at least 1,900 hours of professional aircraft maintenance training. After graduation, the student can take part in qualification tests sponsored by the CAA.

CAA officials said two other organizations -- the state-run Aviation Industry Development Corp., Taiwan's only aircraft manufacturer, and Hsinhsing Senior High Vocation School -- have also filed applications for setting up aircraft maintenance technicians training centers.

DOC.HEADLINE: ICBC OPENS 2ND BRANCH IN AUSTRALIA

TEXT.P: Canberra, April 19 (CNA): The Taipei-based International Commercial Bank of China (ICBC) will open its second branch in Australia on Tuesday to provide banking services to migrants from Taiwan and other overseas Chinese, ICBC president Wang Shue-sheng said.

In an interview with CNA, Wang said the new branch in Brisbane will provide services, including lending and accepting deposits to Taiwanese migrants, particularly businessmen, to facilitate doing business and building new homes.
The ICBC set up its first banking operation in Sydney, which a few years ago was allowed by the Australian government to become a branch office.
"There are quite a lot of Taiwanese businessmen and migrants in Brisbane and other cities in Queensland. Our new branch includes a Mandarin-speaking staff to eliminate language barriers," Wang said.

In addition to banking services in Brisbane and Sydney, Wang said his two Australian branches will provide business information and investment opportunities in Taiwan so that Taiwanese migrants can conduct business with their counterparts in Taiwan.
Wang said the two branches would provide loans to Taiwanese migrants, migrants from other countries and Australian businessmen for different fields of investment.
"We hope we can help our migrants and other clients to increase their business aside from their investment projects," he said.
Wang said the ICBC has set up 20 branches in the United States, Canada, Japan, the Philippines, Colombia, Thailand, Malaysia, Singapore, Vietnam, the Netherlands, France and Australia.
"We will continue to set up branches in other cities or countries so that we can spread our wings and expand operations," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S TOP BLOOD DONOR HONORED

TEXT.P: Tsai Shun-fa known as "Bean Curd Papa" was honored by Premier Vincent Siew Monday for donating blood 495 times over 20 years.

Tsai, 52, began to donate blood some 20 years ago after his sister described him as a "fatty". She told him he should "release some blood" to seek a physical balance. He said he donated the first time out of curiosity.
Once he became a blood donor, Tsai made a a regular donation every 14 days.

The Pingtung-based bean-curb merchant, said he donates routinely and the donations are not interrupted when he travels. "I donate whenever I am every 14th day," he said. Consequently, he has become an "old friend" at Taiwan's six major blood donation centers.
Tsai's admirers say that his heart is more tender than his bean curd, which is renowned in the Pingtung area for having a heavenly tasty.

Before the citation ceremony, Tsai told reporters that blood donation is rewarding, "particularly when you're informed that your blood has saved a life." He added that he would continue as long as he is able.
The citation ceremony was held Monday to mark the 25th founding of the Blood Service Foundation of the Republic of China.

Foundation President Lin Kuo-sin said the amount of donated blood collected by the foundation has grown from 3,000 bags in 1974 to 1.79 million bags in 1998, thanks to donors who gave blood to strangers.
Lin described the philanthropic deed of blood donation as the most successful social movement in Taiwan. He said that blood donation has made Taiwan great.

Lin quoted statistics to say that with 1.79 million bags donated in 1998, Taiwan's per capita blood donation ratio reached 8.21 percent, much higher than the percentages in neighboring South Korea, Hong Kong and Malaysia. There is room, however, for local residents to improve as Japan and the United States average 10 percent, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCKS, FUTURES RISE

TEXT.P: Taiwan share prices rose 0.5 percent on Monday as the international stock market remained strong, boosting local market sentiments.
The benchmark Taiwan Stock Exchange Weighted Price Index closed 41.68 points higher at 7,623 points.
Trade on Monday saw a total of 4.67 billion shares change hands on turnover of NT$151.97 billion (US$4.63 billion), compared to NT$165.05 billion in the last session.
Advancers led decliners 288 to 164, with 51 stocks unchanged.
Among the eight major stock categories, the paper and pulp sector posted the biggest gains of the day, rising 5 percent, followed by cement shares, which climbed 2.2 percent.
Textile issues went up 2 percent, foodstuff shares 1.9 percent, construction shares 1.8 percent, and electronic stocks gained 0.8 percent.
Plastic and chemical stocks and financial shares posted the only losses of the day, dropping 0.6 percent and 0.3 percent, respectively.
Meanwhile, the over-the-counter market also registered gains, rising 3.25 points to close at 181.35 points, with a turn over of NT$9.87 billion.
The TAIEX Capitalization Weighted Price Index Futures (TAIEX Index Futures) for April advanced 50 points to close at 7,620, with 1,296 contract transactions.

TAIEX Index Futures for May gained 44 points to close at 7,644, while those for June rose 41 points to close at 7,670 points. Contract transactions for the two months totaled 3,540 and 92, respectively.
September futures climbed 50 points, closing at 7,650, with 7 contract transactions. December futures increased 50 points to close at 7,680, with 3 contract transactions.

Reference levels provided by the Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange for TAIEX Index Futures trading on Monday were 7,570 points for April, 7,600 points for May, 7,629 points for June, 7,600 points for September, and 7,630 points for December.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC TO INCREASE EXCHANGES WITH KALMYKIA REPUBLIC

TEXT.P: The Republic of China is happy to step up exchanges and cooperation in trade, economics, and culture with the Republic of Kalmykia, Vice President Lien Chan told visiting Kalmykian President Kirsan Nikolayevich Ilyumzhinov on Monday.
Lien noted that the ROC has experience, talent and technology to offer the Caspian republic as it develops its industrial, mining and agricultural and livestock industries.
Lien hoped that Ilyumzhinov would meet more government and business leaders during his stay to discuss further cooperation.
Ilyumzhinov first visited the ROC in July 1996 and met with Lien, who was then premier. He said he was happy to see Lien again and expressed the hope of closer trade relations.
He urged Taiwan businessmen to invest in his country, adding that Kalmykia has enjoyed rapid economic development in recent years with ample trade opportunities still available.
Ilyumzhinov was accompanied by the Mongolian & Tibetan Affairs Commission Chairman Kao Koong-lian while visiting Lien.
Ilymuzhinov, who arrived here Sunday, will also call on the Ministries of Economic Affairs and Foreign Affairs before leaving Taiwan Thursday.
The Republic of Kalmykia became one of the 21 Russian republics in December 1993. It is located off the Caspian Sea and has a population of 340,000.

DOC.HEADLINE: HOWARD TO MEET HABIBIE OVER E. TIMOR
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 19 (CNA) (By Lilian Wu) (By Peter Chen)

TEXT.P: Canberra, April 19 (CNA): Australian Prime Minister John Howard on Monday said he will soon meet Indonesian President B.J. Habibie in Bali to discuss how to prevent further killings in East Timor.

In a news conference in Canberra on Monday afternoon, Howard said he phoned Habibie on Monday and both leaders agreed to hold an urgent meeting in Bali within the next 10 days. Canberra has accused the Indonesian army (ABRI) of failing to curb a series of massacres in the former Portuguese colony.

Howard said he told Habibie the latest killings in Dili, capital of East Timor, will damage Indonesia's international image and he asked his counterpart to help prevent further killings. Habibie agreed, Howard said.
Howard on Monday accused ABRI of "turning a blind eye" on pro-integration militias, while they were shooting at least 30 civilians, causing chaos in the territory.
East Timorese migrants in Australia held a series of demonstrations in Sydney, Perth, Melbourne and Canberra on Monday to demand Australia's help in stopping the militia killings in their homeland.
Habibie, however, appears to rule out the stationing of United Nations (UN) peacekeeping forces in East Timor. So far only Brazil has offered to send peacekeeping troops to the territory.
Australia has offered various forms of assistance, including medical teams and relief food, to East Timor. But Canberra has not offered peacekeeping forces.

DOC.HEADLINE: ECONOMICS MINISTER REPORTS ON TAIWAN'S ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) is making efforts to assist and guide domestic industries in the areas of telecommunication, micro-electronics, energy resources and environment protection, as well as bio-medicine, said the head of MOEA on Monday.

Economics Minister Wang Chih-kang, reported on Taiwan's economic development and its global deployment of high-technology industries in the next century, at the monthly meeting in the Presidential Office.
In light of technology globalization, the minister encouraged domestic banks to establish branch offices overseas to provide a global net of financial services.

Wang's strategy proposals included promoting the rise of new industries, an overall stimulation of research activities, satisfying demands of private investments and entry into international economic and trade organizations.

Wang observed that advanced technologies contributed a lot to Taiwan's economic development. For instance, he said, the total production value of the semi-conductor sector, totaled NT$281.8 billion last year, or 180 percent growth within five years, accounting for 3.45 percent of the international market, and Taiwan's IC production ranked 5th in the world. Taiwan's telecommunication industry ranked 3rd in the world, the MOEA head added.

Wang deemed that the future development pattern of Taiwan's economy must be associated with the global deployment of enterprises. In other words, factors to be taken into consideration include, where can commodities be produced with low added value, where to produce commodities of high added value, the right location to conduct research work, and the right place to establish management headquarters.
The MOEA hopes to retain the latter three items in Taiwan, Wang noted.
In view of the fact that high-tech industries are increasing in number, the long-term development of the sector is a challenge for Taiwan, remarked Wang.
In a era of high-tech and network economies, said Wang, establishing a telecommunication environment can be achieved by accelerating the building of a telecommunication network, Wang concluded.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN LEGISLATIVE DELEGATION SETS OFF FOR US VISIT

TEXT.P: A parliamentary delegation of the Republic of China (ROC) left Monday for a four-day visit to the United States with an aim of promoting ROC-US relations.

Vice President of the Legislative Yuan Yao Eng-chi, leader of the 10-member group, said before his departure that they are scheduled to call on US Congressional leaders and meet with officials from the American Institute in Taiwan during the visit.

He and the delegation will also try to judge the attitude among Congressmen toward the ROC's joining the World Trade Organization, the World Health Organization, and the planned theater missile defense (TMD) system.
The delegation is made up of seven legislators from the ruling Kuomingtang, two from the Democratic Progressive Party, one from the New Party and one independent.

DOC.HEADLINE: MACEDONIAN PRIME MINISTER TO ARRIVE ON MAY 2 FOR 6-DAY VISIT

TEXT.P: Macedonian Prime Minister Ljubco Georgievski is scheduled to arrive in Taipei on May 2 for a six-day official visit, Vice Foreign Minister David Lee said on Monday.
Lee made the statement in a report to the Legislative Yuan's Foreign and Overseas Chinese Affairs Committee.
Georgievski's visit has twice been postponed because of the influx into Macedonia of a large number of ethnic Albanian refugees from the war-torn neighboring Yugoslav province of Kosovo.

"We hope the Kosovar situation will not worsen so that Georgievski will be able to visit Taiwan as scheduled this time," said Lee, who just returned from a visit to Macedonia to offer humanitarian assistance to Kosovar refugees.

Lee said Georgievski himself also hopes to visit Taiwan as early as possible to meet with senior ROC officials and sign three bilateral agreements to facilitate future investment and economic cooperation.

Lee said the ROC humanitarian relief delegation had attracted extensive media coverage during its stay in Macedonia last week. "The group's activities have impressed Macedonian people and help boost friendship between our two countries," he noted.

A 26-member ROC group, composed of medical professionals and volunteers, is operating a field hospital at Stenkovec, the largest Kosovar refugee camp in Macedonia, to offer medical services to ethnic Albanians.
Lee said the medical team will stay in Macedonia for two to three weeks. If necessary, the team may stay even longer, depending on the practical needs and the Macedonian government's stance.
The ROC has so far offered some US$7.5 million in cash, pharmaceuticals, medical equipment and various relief goods to Kosovar refugees.

As of early April, about 140,000 ethnic Albanians had fled their Kosovar homeland and entered Macedonia. The influx of the large number of refugees has had a strong impact on the Macedonian economy. In the past, 20 percent of Macedonian exports went to Yugoslavia. The outbreak of the Kosovo crisis has seriously disrupted Macedonia's industrial production and exports.

Lee said the Ministry of Foreign Affairs has drawn up several proposals for a third round of aid to Macedonia. Nevertheless, he said if the ROC decides to offer new aid to Macedonia, the assistance will be offered in cooperation with the international community. "We'll not make a final decision until after the development in the Balkans has become more clear," added Lee.
The Republic of China forged formal diplomatic ties with Macedonia in January this year.
Lee left for the United States Monday evening to chair a meeting of ROC diplomats stationed in North America.

DOC.HEADLINE: NTU GRADUATE SCHOOLS WIN HIGHEST ACADEMIC ACCLAIM: SURVEY

TEXT.P: National Taiwan University (NTU) ranked first in nine of the 18 graduate school categories in the "Best Graduate School Survey" held by Common Wealth magazine.

To help college students and people interested in seeking higher education better understand Taiwan's graduate schools, the magazine's annual special edition "Jobs & You" chose 18 categories of graduate studies. The categories had the largest number of students enrolled and similar departments were found in at least ten universities.
Common Wealth interviewed college deans, department directors and three senior professors and experts to provide mutual academic reputation critiques.

The magazine also collated data on each department's full-time teaching faculty, classes, funding, acceptance rate, registration rate, published dissertations and honorary awards received to compile three indicators: teaching resources, research ability and student identification.

Survey results show that NTU ranked first in the Chinese literature, foreign literature, economics, accounting, law, chemistry, electrical engineering, mechanical engineering and civil engineering graduate programs.
National Tsinghua University (NTHU), which emphasizes development research, ranked first in mathematics, physics, statistics and chemical engineering.
The survey also shows an intensified competitiveness in popular subjects such as business administration and electrical engineering.
While the National Chengchi University (NCCU) ranked first in its School of Business Administration, it was closely followed by NTU and the National Sun Yat-sen University.

NTU's School of Electrical Engineering won the highest acclaim in its category, but NTHU and the National Chiao Tung University (NCTU), with their proximity to the Hsinchu Science-based Industrial Park, have the advantage of offering both academics and practical business experience.

Schools of statistics, business administration and education were the hardest to enter with acceptance rates all under ten percent. The schools of statistics, was the most difficult with a meager 5 percent acceptance rate of graduate school applicants.

DOC.HEADLINE: GIO CHIEF PRESIDES OVER WORK MEETING IN US
DOC.DATELINE: San Francisco, April 18 (CNA) (By Neil Lu and Victor Lai)

TEXT.P: A two-day work meeting for the North American units of the Republic of China's Government Information Office (GIO) was held at Monterey, California on Saturday and Sunday.

The meeting, presided over by GIO Director General Chen Chien-jen, decided to push for international understanding concerning Taiwan in three areas: Taiwan's economic prosperity and democratic development; Taiwan's pursuit of a stable and peaceful relationship with mainland China; Taiwan's determination to step up international cooperation and participation.
The GIO director general told CNA that Taiwan's presidential election next spring will be also a major theme of the GIO in promoting the country.
At the work meeting, attended by the chiefs of the 11 GIO units in North America, Chen said that promoting international understanding is a long-term, all-out and multi-level task.
He expressed the hope that they will take the initiative and seize opportunities to let the international community understand Taiwan.
Chen said that mainland Chinese Premier Zhu Rongji's recent remarks on the American Civil War provided a good chance for Taiwan to promote international understanding.
Zhu hinted at a White House press conference recently that Beijing might consider learning from President Abraham Lincoln and use military force against Taiwan.

Chen said that during his visits to major American news organizations during his current US trip, he explained to them that President Lincoln had become a great historical figure because of his pursuit of human rights, equality, and liberty, not because of the Civil War.
The GIO chief described the work meeting as a success and is considering holding the gathering annually. Chen has concluded his US trip and will leave for Taipei on Monday.

DOC.HEADLINE: HOT SALES FOR ENVIRONMENTAL FRIENDLY MOTORCYCLE

TEXT.P: The "electric powered motorcycle development plan" approved by the Executive Yuan last March has been successfully carried out as a total of 3,500 electric power motorcycles have been sold since the plan's approval, sources reported on Monday.

Officials from the Environmental Protection Administration (EPA) said that only a limited number of companies developed electric power motorcycles in the past due to a lack of battery and drive technologies.
However, due to an expanding market and government backing, more than five types of electric bikes have been launched with more coming on the market, the EPA added.
Under government regulations, a minimum of NT$12,000 subsidy will be granted for each purchase of an electric power motorcycle. The fuel tax can also be exempted.
This subsidy makes the price almost equivalent to that of a fuel-powered motorcycle while maintaning the pollution-free edge.

The EPA pushed consumers to buy the environmental friendly transportation devises by offering an additional subsidy of NT$2,000 for each of those who retire their old fuel-powered bikes produced before 1992 while buying an electric-powered one.
Regarding the concern that the power for electric power motorcycle is insufficient, the EPA recommended riding less than 20 kilometers per day. (by Amanda Chang)

DOC.HEADLINE: IMF ADDED TO ASIAN CRISIS: SACHS

TEXT.P: Singapore, April 19 (CNA): The International Monetary Fund (IMF) "actually contributed to the financial panic that helped to bring down the Asian economies", according to Harvard University economist Jeffery Sachs.
Launching yet another scathing attack on the IMF, Dr. Sachs, the director of Harvard's Institute for International Development, said its performance had "left much to be desired".
A long-time IMF critic, the Harvard don argued that the external supervision of the fund's activities had to be increased and improved.

"This requires the decision-making process within the IMF to be more transparent and more democratized to include a larger number of developing countries," he said in a paper released in Geneva over the weekend.

Advocating floating of exchange rates as the norm for the global monetary system, he warned that the IMF "cannot, and should not, be either the international lender of last resort or the international deposit insurance agency".

In January, IMF First Deputy Managing Director Stanley Fischer suggested the fund formalize and expand its role as lender of last resort to rescue governments which fall prey to abrupt shifts in capital flows.

Dismissing this idea, Dr. Sachs said the new global monetary system should instead "establish regional monetary bodies and an international bankruptcy court to speed up international debt restructuring".
International bailouts ought to be redesigned in light of the "failure of the first IMF programs" for Thailand, Indonesia and South Korea.

"There should be ways to "bail in" rather than bail out foreign creditors. For example, debt relief, "standstills" for existing debt and priority payments for new loans should all be standard features of rescue packages," Sachs said. Enditem/RM (sherman wu)

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN POTTERY ART TO BE EXHIBITED IN BEIJING

TEXT.P: A variety of Chinese traditional and modern pottery objects created by people on Taiwan will be exhibited at the "1999 Chinese Pottery Art Exhibition for Cross-Strait Exchanges" in Beijing.

Under the auspices of The Republic of China Pottery Art Association and the China Development Fund Managing Committee of the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC), the Taiwan pottery exhibition will be held in the Chinese History Museum in Beijing from April 22 to May 9.
It is hoped that the exhibition will be able to show the creative power of people in open society and help promote cultural exchanges between Taiwan and mainland China, an MAC official said Monday.

To help improve mutual understanding between the people on Taiwan and the Chinese mainland, the MAC has sponsored other kinds of cultural exchange since the establishment of the China development fund in 1994, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: LOCALLY DEVELOPED CHIPSETS COMPETE WITH INTEL

TEXT.P: The world's largest silicon chips maker, Intel, will be facing the challenge of an allied group of more than 10 electronic and semiconductor manufacturers preparing to push into the Intel-dominated memory chipset market.
The low-cost PC 133/266 chipsets will be the main weapon of the group, headed by the Taipei County-based Very Innovative Architecture (VIA) Technologies Inc.

VIA Technologies held a workshop on the PC 133/266 and the manufacturing standards of memory chipsets in Taipei on Monday. Attendees were representatives from relevant businesses including Micron, NEC-Taiwan, Fujitsu, Mitsubishi, Hitachi, Samsung, Siemens, Hyundai, Toshiba and Hewlett Packard-Taiwan.

During the meeting the manufacturers supported VIA's development of the PC133 memory chipset for personal computers (PC). VIA officials said the low-cost product will help them tap into the current market trend for low-cost PCs.
They are pinning their hopes that the PC133 can compete with Intels' RAMBus in the world PC market. The new generation of Intel memory chips all allow quick calculations.

However, VIA officials said, the manufacturing cost of RAMBus is much higher than that of the previous generation of Intel products -- a fact that will cause Intel to demand a higher price from contracted makers before transmitting its RAMBus technology.
VIA Technologies is Taiwan's largest integrated circuit designer and maker, with NT$2 billion (US$60.98 million) in capital.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT TO DECIDE PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEES AUG. 28-29

TEXT.P: The ruling Kuomintang (KMT) has decided in principle to hold a Central Committee plenary session Aug. 28-29 to decide its nominee for the 2000 presidential election, KMT sources said on Monday.

KMT regulations governing the nomination of its presidential candidate state that one week prior to the Central Committee meeting, primaries must be held in various parts of the island, at which time party delegates will vote to select the party's presidential and vice presidential nominees.
Results of the primaries will first be presented to the KMT Central Standing Committee, and then to the Central Committee plenary meeting, for approval.
The schedule was decided by a preparatory meeting of plenary session Monday afternoon.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW RULES ENABLE POLICE TO EVICT AIRCRAFT-OCCUPYING PASSENGERS

TEXT.P: The legal affairs section under the Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC) on Monday passed a set of new rules that will enable police to evict aircraft passengers.
There have been incidents in the past, where some passengers refused to leave an aircraft in protest against a flight delay or poor airline service.
Such moves affected the operations of the airline, the airport, as well as the country's image.

In order to solve the problem, in 1977 the MOTC's Civil Aeronautics Administration (CAA) held meetings with consumer groups and the airline industry to work out procedures for settling passenger disputes.
The newly-formulated rules, to be formally announced within two weeks, will provide a legal basis for airport police to evict aircraft-occupying passengers.

According to the new rules, if a domestic flight is delayed over 15 minutes, an international flight more than 30 minutes, or the flight is diverted from its scheduled destination, the passengers should be informed of the reasons.

If the interests of the passengers are affected, the airlines are required to provide necessary communication, beverages, meals, accommodations, medical aid, transfer service and other transport means free of charge.
If passengers refuse to leave the aircraft, the airlines can notify local CAA personnel and the airport police to help solve the dispute.
If the passengers insist on staying on the aircraft, the new rules empower the airlines to ask the airport police to evict them with the consent of local CAA personnel.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI DENIES LEE PLANS TRIP TO MANILA

TEXT.P: Taipei on Monday denied a wire service report that Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui will pay a visit to the Philippines later this month.
"I have never heard of such a thing," said Lin Bih-jaw, deputy secretary general to the president, while answering to press queries.
"I simply don't understand why there is such a report," Lin said. Other ranking presidential officials, who asked anonymity, also said that they knew nothing about the reported trip.
Meanwhile, Deputy Director Chen Ming-cheng of the Foreign Ministry's Information and Cultural Department also denied the report.
A Manila-datelined AP story reported that President Lee is planning to visit the Philippines this month to meet with a private group and that mainland China has warned Manila not to allow the visit.
It quoted a senior foreign affairs official in Manila on Monday as saying that Lee had been invited by Filipino alumni of Cornell University to a private event in the country.
Lee, earned his doctoral degree in Agronomy from Cornell University in the United States, paid a visit to his alma mater in 1995.

DOC.HEADLINE: EXECUTIVE YUAN CONCEDES TO TAIPEI, KAOHSIUNG

TEXT.P: The Executive Yuan (Cabinet) on Monday made concessions to the cities of Taipei and Kaohsiung over revenue allocation for fiscal 2000, agreeing to give 47 percent of revenues to the country's two major cities.
Because of financial difficulties, the Executive Yuan initially intended to decrease the allocation to 41 percent from originally-promised 47 percent.

That proposal prompted Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou and Kaohsiung Mayor Frank Hsieh to strongly criticize the Executive Yuan for several days because their budget plans had already been submitted to their respective City Councils for review.

Facing the unexpected political storm, Premier Vincent Siew met with Mayor Ma on Monday morning and told him that the Cabinet would honor its original promise of giving 47 percent of the revenue to both Taipei and Kaohsiung.
According to that promise, Taipei and Kaohsiung will get NT$83.1 billion and NT$29.3 billion respectively.

The remaining counties and cities will get NT$154 billion, including NT$38.1 billion in subsidies from the Central Government and NT$14.3 billion in special subsidies to be diverted from the fund for emergency relief use.

Also attending the Siew-Ma meeting were Vice Premier Liu Chao-shiuan, Executive Yuan Secretary-General Hsieh Shen-shan, and Director General Wei Duan of the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS).
Hsien Shen-shan called a press conference on Monday afternoon to announce the Executive Yuan's revenue allocation plan, in the presence of Finance Minister Paul Chiu and the DGBAS's Wei.
When asked by the media whether this pattern will be used for revenue allocation for fiscal 2001, Hsieh refrained from making a direct response, simply saying "Let us study again."

DOC.HEADLINE: SEF REFUTES M'LAND NEGOTIATOR'S REMARKS ON 'ONE CHINA'

TEXT.P: Taipei on Monday said that recent remarks by mainland's top negotiator with Taiwan on the "one China" issue shows that Beijing has intentionally negated the existence of Taiwan.

Shi Hwei-yow, vice chairman and secretary general of the Strait Exchange Foundation (SEF), was referring to the so-called 86-word "new interpretation of the 'one China' policy" by Wang Daohan, chairman of the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS).
"They (Wang's remarks) not only denied the existence of the Republic of China, but also has tolled the knell for the nation," Shi said.

Wang said in a recent media interview that "there is only one China in the world, Taiwan is part of it....., both sides should make efforts to negotiate, on an equal footing, the unification of China , and that Taiwan's political status should be discussed by both sides under the framework of one China."
Both the SEF and ARATS are intermediary organizations authorized by Taipei and Beijing, respectively, to handle cross-strait exchanges in the absence of formal contacts.
Shi said that compared to Wang's previous remarks on the same issue, the recent statement "contains nothing new, and even backtracks".

Wang told a visiting pro-unification group from Taiwan in Shanghai last year that " 'one China' refers neither to the Republic of China nor to the People's Republic of China. Rather, it's a unified China."

Shi said that since the "one China" issue has become the most serious barrier to cross-strait talks, he has suggested that both Taipei and Beijing follow the agreement reached between them earlier that each side be allowed to have their own interpretation of "one China".

DOC.HEADLINE: NO 'MONEY DIPLOMACY': FOREIGN MINISTRY

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) on Monday denied that it has engaged in "money diplomacy."
MOFA spokesman Roy Wu was responding to a local paper report Monday which said that the ministry has spent a lot of money in seeking closer relations with foreign countries.
Wu said that with a yearly budget of about US$700 million, the MOFA is incapable of engaging in the so-called "money diplomacy".

The report also said that legislators have no clear idea of how much is being used for foreign aid programs, and consequently they cannot efficiently supervise the ministry's operations through screening its budget.
Wu said that his ministry is drafting the "international cooperation bill", under which Taiwan's international aid programs will all become transparent. (by Amanda Chang)

DOC.HEADLINE: SWAZILAND MINISTERS VISITS ROC AGRICULTURAL DEPARTMENT

TEXT.P: Visiting Swaziland economic and agriculture ministers on Monday called on the Council of Agriculture (COA) and extended their thanks for the COA's long-term effort to help develop the southern African country's agriculture.

M.V. Sithole, minister for economic planning and development and Agriculture Minister R.D. Nicolas-Fanourakis are attendees at the 1999 ROC-Swaziland Conference on Economic and Technologic Cooperation that opened in Taipei on Monday and will last through Thursday.

While meeting with COA Chairman Peng Tso-kwei, Nicolas-Fanourakis expressed his hope that the COA will transfer technology concerning water conservancy to his country, which is mostly covered by desert lands.
Sithole said that Swaziland will continue to learn from Taiwan in the hope of developing as successful an economy as achieved by the ROC.
Peng told his African visitors that the COA is delighted to help Swaziland's agricultural development in any way.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Tuesday, April 20, or the fifth day of the third month of the Year of the Rabbit according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1526: Baber, or Zahir ud-Din Mohammed, leads 2,000 Moguls to victory over 10,000 Muhammadens and 100 elephants under Ibrahim at the battle of Panipat. The conqueror of India later captured Delhi and Agra and founded the Mogul dynasty.
1657: Jews in New Amsterdam (now New York City) are granted equal rights and privileges as citizens.
1836: The US Congress separates the western part of Michigan Territory and forms a new territory known as Wisconsin.
1859: Holland concludes a treaty granting Portugal the right to govern the eastern part of Timor, Atauro Island and Oecussi.
1889: Adolf Hitler, German housepainter and subsequently German dictator who founded the National Socialist (Nazi) Party and architect of World War II, is born in Austria.
1908: Taiwan's West Coast Railway Trunk Line from Keelung to Kaohsiung, with a total length of 405 kilometers, is opened to traffic.
1916: The Taipei Yuanshan Zoo is inaugurated.
1924: The Panchen Lama of Tibet, under suppression from Britain and the Dalai Lama, leaves Lhasa for an unidentified destination in China.
1933: President Franklin D. Roosevelt issues a statement removing the United States from the gold standard.
1944: The RAF drops a record 4,500 tons of bombs on Germany in a single raid.
1945: Soviet troops penetrate Berlin defenses.
1950: The Taiwan Garrison Command Heaquarters is established with Gen. Sun Li-jen serving at its first commander.
1957: Japan protests to the Soviet Union over nuclear tests.
1968: Liberal Party Pierre E. Trudeau becomes the 15th prime minister of Canada.
1970: President Richard M. Nixon announces the withdrawal of 150,000 US military personnel from South Vietnam.
1974: The Republic of China announces the termination of Taiwan-Japan flights by China Airlines and Japan Airlines after Japan and communist China sign an air pact in Beijing.
1978: Soviet warplanes force an off-course South Korean airliner down in the Soviet Union near the Arctic Circle, killing two passengers aboard and injuring 13 others.
1984: Britain announces that its administration of Hong Kong will cease in 1997 when the colony is returned to communist China.
1986: A reservoir bursts and floods a Sri Lankan town, killing 100 people and making some 20,000 families homeless.
1989: A 16-inch gun turret aboard the 45-year-old battleship USS Iowa explodes during Atlantic firing practice exercises, killing 47 sailors on board.
1990: Soviet troops storm Lithuania's state printing works after Mikhail Gorbachev cuts off 85 percent of gas supplies to the rebellious republic.
1996: World leaders meeting in Moscow agree to increase nuclear safety through new cooperation.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A man who does not anticipate deceit nor imagine untrustworthiness, but who can readily detect their presence, must be a very superior man."
