DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING-CLAIMED 'ONE CHINA' NON-EXISTENT AT MOMENT: PRESIDENT LEE

TEXT.P: ROC President Lee Teng-hui said on Tuesday that the Beijing-claimed "one China" is non-existent at the moment.
President Lee made the statement while meeting with a delegation of columnists and journalists from Central and South America.

Stressing that the Republic of China is a sovereign independent state, Lee said the ROC can never accept Beijing's "one China" principle which regards the People's Republic of China as the central government and downgrades the ROC as a local government.

"The reality is that two equal political entities now exist on the two sides of the Taiwan Strait," Lee noted, adding that the ROC has successfully developed a new Chinese culture through its political and economic reforms as well as its ingestion of essence of Western culture.
Lee pointed out that what the ROC pursues is a China unified under the principles of freedom, democracy and equitable distribution of wealth.
"Against this background, only when mainland China changes its system to narrow our gap can China's unification be gradually realized," Lee said.

Noting that the ROC has set up a National Unification Council to promote China's unification, Lee said "one China" will exist only when the two sides of the Taiwan Strait unify under freedom and democracy.

Touching on the Taiwan Strait issue, Lee said the strait has become a "public asset" in the international community as three to four vessels from different countries sail in the Taiwan Strait everyday. Therefore, the president said the future of the Taiwan Strait cannot be decided by any single country and that the ROC hopes to maintain peace and stability in the strait.
Commenting on Beijing's refusal to renounce the use of force against Taiwan, Lee said freedom and democracy are the most effective weapons.

"Mainland China's live-fire military exercises and missile tests in the run-up to the ROC's first-ever presidential election in 1996 have proved that hegemonic, militant actions were unwise and of no avail," Lee said.

Looking ahead, Lee said, the ROC will further substantiate its democratic reforms by promoting judicial, educational and spiritual reforms in addition to boosting the development of such high-tech industries as electronics, information and biotechnology.

Turning to relations with Latin American countries, Lee said Taiwan has been a major market for Latin American products as it has usually incurred deficits in its trade with Latin American countries. Based on its pragmatic diplomacy, Lee said, the ROC is more than willing to develop trade and economic relations with Latin American countries no matter whether they maintain formal diplomatic ties with Taiwan or not.

The Latin American delegation includes many influential columnists and journalists from Central and South American countries, including Panama, Costa Rica, the Dominican Republic, Peru, Argentina, Chile, El Salvador, Paraguay, Nicaragua, Guatemala, and Venezuela.

DOC.HEADLINE: ZHU TO FACE HUMAN RIGHTS QUESTIONS AGAIN IN B.C.

TEXT.P: Mainland Chinese Premier Zhu Rongji was on the last leg of his Canadian visit Monday, a visit where he's encountered protesters at nearly every stage.
The Chinese entourage arrived at Victoria, B.C., late Sunday evening. There were no protesters to meet Zhu when he arrived about an hour behind schedule at Victoria Airport.
B.C. Premier Glen Clark said he will broach the subject of human rights when he meets with the Chinese premier Monday.
Clark said he will appeal to Zhu's image as a great Chinese reformer and suggest that "to encourage trade with the West they have to make progress in the human rights field as well."

Pro-Tibet groups are planning a demonstration outside a luncheon set for Tuesday at Vancouver's Trade and Convention Center. The Canada Tibet Committee said it's protesting China's human rights record.

Clark's high profile on the Chinese human rights issue contrasts that of his Alberta and Ontario counterparts. Neither Ralph Klein nor Mike Harris raised the issue with Zhu, concentrating their talks instead on promoting bilateral trade.

The difference might have been caused by the party colors of the three premiers: Clark heads the New Democratic Party while Klein and Harris are Tories. It also shows an irony that leftist politicians are more concerned about human rights than right-wingers.

DOC.HEADLINE: EXPERT PRESENTS SCENARIOS OF CHINESE NUCLEAR BUILDUP
DOC.DATELINE: Ottawa, April 19 (CNA) (By S. C. Chang) (By Nelson Chung)

TEXT.P: Washington, April 19 (CNA): Deployment of missile defense systems in Japan or Taiwan, coupled with Indian nuclear and missile deployments, could spark a worst-case scenario, in which Beijing could embark on an aggressive, accelerated nuclear weapon buildup and reverse many of the international arms control commitments it made in recent years, according to a new study to be published later this month.

Ming Zhang, author of the study titled "China's Changing Nuclear Posture: Reactions to the South Asian Nuclear Tests," however, said this scenario is remote, "firstly because Chinese scientists really doubt whether India has a nuclear capability in hand and secondly because it will take many years before the United States and Taiwan actually deploy a missile defense system."

Even in the worst-case scenario, Zhang said "China has no intention of reaching nuclear parity with the United States or Russia. That's a misperception in the United States that as Washington and Moscow build down their arsenals, that Beijing will be building up to proportionate levels."

The China-born scholar with close ties to mainland Chinese political, arms control and military officials told the Washington-published "Defense News" weekly that "This will not happen, even under the most dire international developments, because the Chinese leadership will not permit themselves to spend (into bankruptcy)."

Zhang wrote in the study that "It is hard to imagine that China would do nothing if India deployed a significant number of nuclear weapons or targeted nuclear weapons at China." He also refuted oft-stated Indian claims that Beijing has already deployed nuclear weapons in Tibet, insisting that China's long-range missiles can reach India from far outside Tibet.

Zhang noted, however, that "After India's nuclear tests, it seems likely that China will deploy nuclear weapons in Tibet to strengthen its defense against India. At 4,000 meters above sea level and facing down on India, the Tibet plateau is ideal for weapon deployment."

Moreover, he said India's nuclear tests in May 1998, coupled with recent test launches of an extended-range ballistic missile capable of striking most targets in mainland China, could prompt enhancements to Beijing's nuclear launch sites in bordering provinces of Gansu, Qinghai and Yunnan.

The deployment of nuclear weapons along mainland China's eastern border is the first of three scenarios Zhang details in the study, to be published later this month by the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace here.

But Zhang said the most likely option for China in the next five years is a continuation of the status qua, in which Beijing is slowly modernizing its strategic force with DF-31 and DF-41 solid-fueled, road-mobile intercontinental ballistic missiles; second-generation nuclear submarines capable of launching 12 JL-2, multi-warhead intercontinental missiles; and modest upgrades to its strategic bomber force.
Mainland China likely will maintain its estimated 450-warhead arsenal through 2005 or possibly 2010, replacing obsolete warheads with newer, more reliable ones, according to Zhang.

However, he warned that events in India, Taiwan and the United States involving Washington's military presence in the region could prompt what he calls a worst-case scenario, in which Beijing could embark on an aggressive, accelerated nuclear weapons buildup.

His worst-case scenario also includes Beijing's refusal to ratify the Comprehensive Test Ban Treaty, circumvention of the Missile Technology Control Regime, and a reversal of support for the nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty.
"China's commitment to the international nonproliferation regime is strong, but not irreversible," Zhang wrote.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIAN MINE CAMPAIGNERS TO BE HONORED
DOC.DATELINE: Ottawa, April 19 (CNA) (By S. C. Chang) (By Nelson Chung) (By Peter Chen)

TEXT.P: Canberra, April 20 (CNA): Two Australian Aboriginal campaigners against uranium mining in the Jabiluka Natural Park will be recipients of the highly prestigious Goldman Prizes and will be honored by U.S. First Lady Hillary Clinton in Washington D.C later this week.
Yvonne Margarula and Jacqui Katona are chosen by a network of 21 leading international green groups, who work with a confidential panel of environmental experts representing 30 countries.
Each of them will receive a cash prize of A$100,000 (US$63,700) which they have pledged to use to further promote the campaign against environmental pollution and damage in Australia.
The Goldman Prizes are given to outstanding campaigners of environmental protection. Recipients are nominated without their knowledge by the green groups.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEADERS OF AUSTRALIA, MALAYSIA TRADE CRITICISM
DOC.DATELINE: Ottawa, April 19 (CNA) (By S. C. Chang) (By Nelson Chung) (By Peter Chen) (By Peter Chen)

TEXT.P: Canberra, April 20 (CNA): Bilateral relations between Australia and Malaysia are set to worsen after Prime Minister John Howard and Mahathir Mohamad traded critical remarks, political analysts predicted on Tuesday.
Howard was furious after hearing the six-year verdict given to former deputy prime minister Anwar Ibrahim, on charges of corruption.
He said there had been a "lurch towards authoritarianism" in Malaysia and Anwar had been prosecuted because of a "political dispute."
In response, Mahathir on Monday described Howard as "racist."

DOC.HEADLINE: SYDNEY'S DEPUTY MAYOR TO RESIGN
DOC.DATELINE: Ottawa, April 19 (CNA) (By S. C. Chang) (By Nelson Chung) (By Peter Chen) (By Peter Chen) (By Peter Chen)

TEXT.P: Canberra, April 20 (CNA): Henry Tsang, one of Australia's few senior government officials of Chinese origin, is quitting the job of deputy mayor of Sydney in September to play a bigger role in fostering relations between New South Wales and East Asia.
Tsang won the seat in the Upper House of NSW in the March 27 election as a candidate of the Labor Party.
Tsang, who is serving his second term, tried, but failed to win election as Sydney's mayor in the past.
NSW Premier Bob Carr has asked Tsang to devote most of his time promoting relations between NSW and East Asia in trade, economic cooperation, tourism and other fields of mutual interests.
Tsang will remain in his current job until September of this year.
He was born in mainland China, fled to Hong Kong in 1949 and then migrated to Australia in 1960s.

DOC.HEADLINE: ADB: TAIWAN'S ECONOMY TO GROW 4.9 PERCENT IN '99
DOC.DATELINE: Ottawa, April 19 (CNA) (By S. C. Chang) (By Nelson Chung) (By Peter Chen) (By Peter Chen) (By Peter Chen) (By Herman Y.C. Pan)

TEXT.P: Washington, April 19 (CNA): Taiwan's economic growth rate is expected to remain roughly the same in 1999 as in 1998, but is expected to increase to 6.3 percent in 2000, the Asian Development Bank (ADB) said on Monday.

The ADB, in an annual report on Asia's economic outlook issued from here and its Manila headquarters, said Taiwan's gross domestic product (GDP) is expected to rise 4.9 percent. It's a slightly downward revision from last November's forecast of 5.2 percent.

GDP growth rate for Taiwan in 2000 is expected to be over 6 percent, said the report. It's the best among the newly industrialized Asian economies, namely Hong Kong, Singapore, South Korea and Taiwan.
"This increase is largely predicated upon a boost to domestic demand through government spending on several large-scale infrastructure projects," the ADB said.
The projects include a US$13.4 billion high-speed railway project and extensive housing construction.
As a result, the ADB said, the fiscal deficit will remain high at 6.4 percent and 6.3 percent of GDP in 1999 and 2000 respectively.
Regarding Taiwan's monetary policy, the ADB said that "with prudent financial regulations in place", Taiwan's looser monetary stance should prevent a credit crunch in the next few years.
The ADB said Taiwan consumer price inflation was likely to be a mere 1.9 percent in 1999 with a rise to 2.6 percent in 2000.
Exports are expected to experience "robust growth" in 1999 and 2000. The current account will show a surplus of $7.8 billion in 2000, the ADB said, but gave no forecast for 1999.

DOC.HEADLINE: REPORTS ON PRESIDENT LEE'S VISIT TO MANILA NOT TRUE: FM HU

TEXT.P: Foreign Minister Jason Hu said on Tuesday that his ministry has never made any kind of arrangements for President Lee Teng-hui to visit the Philippines, and that foreign media reports saying President Lee has been denied a visa to that country are not true.

Hu's comment came after foreign wire services reported one day earlier that the Filipino Alumni of Cornell University was planning to invite Lee to a private gathering later this month in that country but the government has voiced opposition to that plan as a result of pressure from Beijing.
Philippine Foreign Minister Domingo Siazon was reported as saying that he opposes the plan "in view of the serious repercussions..."
Hu said it was inappropriate for the Philippine government to make a haste response in such a case.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCKS, FUTURES RISE SLIGHTLY

TEXT.P: Taiwan share prices closed slightly higher on Tuesday, rising 0.1 percent, as heavy buying in the construction sector offset early falls triggered by losses on Wall Street.

The benchmark Taiwan Stock Exchange Weighted Price Index rose 4.56 points to close at 7,627.74 points, with a turnover of NT$133.15 billion (US$4.07 billion), down from the previous session's NT$151.97 billion.
Among the eight major stock categories, construction issues, paper and pulp shares and textile shares registered gains, while electronics shares dropped.
Advancers led decliners 242 to 223, with 39 stocks unchanged.
The over-the-counter market fell 1.49 points to close at 179.86, with a turnover of NT$7.97 billion.
TAIEX Capitalization Weighted Price Index Futures (TAIEX Index Futures) for April edged up 20 points to close at 7,640 points, with 901 contract transactions.

TAIEX Index Futures for May gained 18 points to close at 7,662, and those for June climbed 5 points to close at 7,675 points. Contract transactions for the two months totaled 3,970 and 165, respectively.
September futures dropped 39 points to close at 7,660, with 13 contract transactions. December futures decreased 45 points, closing at 7,635 points, with 7 contract transactions.

DOC.HEADLINE: MORE THAN HALF OF TAIWAN STREET STALLS PULL IN NT$1 MILLION A YEAR

TEXT.P: More than half of the stalls on Taiwan's streets bring in more than NT$1 million (US$30,770) a year, an investigation by the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) showed on Tuesday.
There are nearly 390,500 street vendors in Taiwan, with an average of 1.5 working at each stall, and employment at such stalls accounts for 4.2 percent of total employment in Taiwan.
There is one street vendor for every 33 male workers and one for every 17 female workers, the officials said.

The total turnover of Taiwan's street vendors amounted to NT$392.62 billion (US$12.08 billion) last year, and 142,617 stalls -- or 54.17 percent of the total number -- brought in more than NT$1 million each.
The DGBAS estimated that a vendor could earn an average of NT$36,000 (US$1,108) per month, or NT$5,000 (US$154) more than an average factory worker.

As a result, street vendors are reluctant to change jobs. The DGBAS investigation revealed that only 17.28 percent of Taiwan's street vendors said they are thinking of leaving their jobs, and most said they were hoping they would be paid NT$36,000 (US$1,108) a month if they were to switch jobs.

Most manufacturing companies, however, are willing to pay workers a maximum of NT$27,000 (US$830) per month. Officials said this means the chances of Taiwan's street vendors abandoning their life on the street are slim.

DOC.HEADLINE: COA SAYS NO REDUCTION IN PROPOSED DOG REGISTRATION FEES

TEXT.P: The Council of Agriculture (COA) said on Tuesday that it is not considering a reduction in the proposed fee for dog registration.
The COA was responding to public criticism that the one-time registration fee of up to NT$4,800 (US$147) is too high.
The officials said the proposed fee is lower than those of other nations and that there is no reason for a reduction. They said they would introduce an educational campaign to cushion opposition.

The officials noted that in line with the animal protection law, they are now working on a draft regulation that requires the registration of pet dogs in an attempt to reduce the number of strays on the island. Under the proposed regulations, dog owners must register their dogs' birth and death with authorities.

Under the proposed registration process, dogs would receive identification chip implants, while owners would be given a registration certificates with their names, the name of their dog and a unique identification number that each dog would be assigned. If the pet goes missing, owners would need to report the animal's disappearance to the pet administration within five days.
For dogs that have been sterilized, the cost of registration would be between NT$800 and NT$1,000 (US$24.60 and US$30.76). For unsterilized dogs, the cost could run as high as NT$4,000.
COA officials said that compared with the United States, Japan and mainland China, Taiwan's proposed registration fee is low.

They noted that each dog registration in mainland China costs between 5,000 and 6,000 renminbi (US$604-US$725), US$30 in the United States, and 3,000 yen (US$24) in Japan, and in some cases the registration period is only one or two years, they added.
They said that local people should be educated about the concept of paying a registration fee in order to own a dog.
Taipei City will begin to implement the registration system in September at the earliest, the officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: MORE ELDERLY PEOPLE LIVE ALONE IN TAIWAN: SURVEY

TEXT.P: The number of elderly people living alone in Taiwan has increased more than one third in seven years, according to a recent survey.

The survey showed that the number of elderly people, aged 65 or older, who lived alone increased from 10 percent in 1989 to 10.8 percent in 1996, but the number of those who lived with spouse only rose from 12.5 percent to 17 percent, an increase of more than one third, or some 90,000 people, during the same period.

In 1996, one out of every ten elderly people lived alone, while two out of every ten lived only with their spouse, according to the survey made by the Taiwan Provincial Family Planning Research Institute. Only about half of the elderly people lived with their married children.

Statistics compiled by the Ministry of the Interior and the Department of Health also indicated that in 1996, 32.7 percent of Taiwan's gray-haired population lived alone or with their espouse. Most people in Asia prefer living with their children in old age.

The survey also pointed out that people with higher education tend to live alone in old age. Of the elderly people living alone or with their spouse, the percentage for primary school graduates and illiterates are 20 percent and 40 percent higher respectively than the percentage of high school graduates.

The poll also found that 68 percent of Taiwan's elderly people receive financial assistance from their children or relatives, down 12.5 percent from the 1989 level. Currently, about one third, down from 50 percent of seven years ago, of Taiwan's elderly citizens depend on their children for living. Twenty five percent of them said they have "economic difficulties."

While Taiwan's elderly people are becoming more lonely, situations of elderly women on the island are even worse, according to the survey. Despite the fact that there are still more old male citizens who live alone than their female counterparts, elderly women are generally at a disadvantage in health, leisure, and finance.
Over the past seven years, the number of elderly women who received economic aid from their children or relatives has declined more quickly than that of men.

DOC.HEADLINE: ASIA'S CONGLOMERATES FACE 'MERGE OR PERISH' CHOICE

TEXT.P: As Western giants are forging mega-mergers to become bigger in their multinational operations, Asia's family-owned conglomerates are ill-equipped and ill-prepared to face the challenge and problem in a time of rising globalization.

In an article titled "Merge or Perish," Geoff Hiscock, business editor of The Australian, said the colossal mergers of Daimler and Chrysler, of British Petroleum and Amoco and of Vodafone and Air Touch show that Asian conglomerates are lagging behind when it comes to merger mania.

He said that this raise the question of how well Asia's family-controlled conglomerates will be able to compete globally, given that many of them lack the cash and the management systems to build brands and distribution networks outside the region.

He quoted Rob Hogarth, a Melbourne-based head of KPMG's Asian business group, as saying that for an Asian conglomerate to be "globalization ready," it must meet three key conditions: It must have a proper capital base, the ability to compete without recourse to local favors, and some involvement with a multinational through a joint venture or technology transfer.

Hiscock said only a few conglomerates can do that in Asia. The best of them are Japanese and Korean companies -- namely Sony, Toyota, Honda, Canon, LG and Samsung. These are among the few companies that have the scale, quality or price advantages to go head to head with the world's best.
Other companies that are capable of competing are Acer of Taiwan and Singapore Airlines, he said.

Other well-known conglomerates in Asia -- including Indonesia's Salim Group and Thailand's CP Group -- have found themselves vulnerable as a consequence of the Asian economic downturn and the pressures of globalization, he noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: NAVY CONFIRMS NEW SHIP PURCHASE PLAN

TEXT.P: The ROC Navy General Headquarters (NGH) confirmed on Tuesday that it plans to purchase an amphibious ship from the United States in the new fiscal year, which starts on July 1, 1999.

Lei Kuang-shu, an NGH department chief, was responding to a local newspaper report that the ROC Navy will take delivery of a retiring US amphibious vessel in October to upgrade its ability to defend outlying islands against possible attack by communist China.

Lei said the Navy is working on details concerning the delivery of the ship. However, Lei would not divulge any details, saying a bilateral agreement prohibits the Navy from revealing when the ship will be delivered and returns to Taiwan.
The United Daily News reported on Monday that the Navy will purchase the USS Pensacola, a 14,000-ton amphibious ship to be retired in the near future after 28 years of service in the US Navy.

Quoting unidentified military sources, the paper said the USS Pensacola is capable of transporting up to 50 amphibious vehicles and has deck space for several helicopters and would be instrumental to reinforcing and resupplying the Republic of China-held outlying islands in case they came under attack.

The Taiwan-held outlying islands include Penghu, Kinmen, Matsu, Tungyin, Wuchiu, Pratas and Taiping Island, one of the Spratly islands. Many of those outlying islands are closer to rival mainland China than to Taiwan.

The paper said the Pensacola would replace the ROC Navy's World War II-era amphibious vessels, some of which have been in service with the navy for 50 years, twice the usual service life of naval vessels.
The Pensacola, also known as LSD-38, based at Norfolk, Virginia, has been deployed in the Adriatic Sea with a detachment of US Marines since the NATO bombing of Yugoslavia began last month.
The Pensacola has been designed for rapid action with transportation of helicopters, gunship, and 1,150 combat troops with artillery, tanks and light armored vehicles.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI HOPES MAINLAND CHINA WILL OPEN MORE HARBORS FOR TRANSSHIPMENT

TEXT.P: As the second anniversary of the opening of direct offshore cross-strait transshipment services was marked on Monday, Taipei authorities expressed their hope that more harbors in the Chinese mainland would be opened for transshipment operations.

The development of cross-strait transshipments occurred against a backdrop of uneventful relations between Taipei and Beijing, said officials of the Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC).

The MOTC drafted in May 1996 measures for the establishment of a direct offshore cross-strait transshipment service, and business operations began on April 19, 1997. The service connects Taiwan's Kaohsiung Harbor and the mainland harbors in Fuzhou and Xiamen. But all cargo sent to those ports must be shipped to another destination without clearing customs.

A total of 11 shipping companies were permitted to operate direct offshore cross-strait transshipment services in the past two years, and together they transshipped 400,000 TEUs (20-foot equivalent units), according to MOTC statistics.
The increased volume of cargo being handled at Kaohsiung Harbor is partly the result of the cross-strait transshipment business, said MOTC officials.
Starting in late 1997, the MOTC even allowed ships traveling across the strait to dock directly at the transshipment centers before they traveled to a third area or country.

The MOTC officials said they hoped mainland China would open other important harbors, such as those in as Guangzhou, Dalian, Shanghai, Qingdao and Tianjin. Meanwhile, Taiwan is ready to open its harbors in Taichung and Keelung to transshipment services, they said.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR UP

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar posted its 11th consecutive gain against the greenback on the Taipei foreign exchange market on Tuesday, rising NT$0.022 to close at 32.728.

Since April 7 the NT dollar has risen NT$0.407 against the US dollar, though its upward climb is likely to face resistance as the central bank appears intent on continued market intervention to prevent violent fluctuations in the value of the NT dollar, dealers said.
Dealers said the NT dollar would have trouble breaking the 32.5-point barrier, because of the central bank's desire for a moderately stable currency.
During Tuesday's session, the NT dollar opened at the day low of 32.742 and experienced a high of 32.695.
Interbank US dollar trading reached US$419 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP PRESIDENTIAL HOPEFUL PROJECTS MODERATE IMAGE: US CHINA HANDS
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, April 19 (CNA) (By Herman Pan and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Former Taipei Chen Shui-bian paid visits to four major American think tanks in Washington, D.C. on Monday as part of his efforts to allay US policy advisers' suspicions about his attitude toward mainland China.

Chen, who is widely believed to seek Taiwan's main opposition Democratic Progressive Party's (DPP's) nomination to run in the island's next presidential election, met with the think tanks' senior executives and Asian and China affairs experts.
The four think tanks were the American Enterprise Institute, the Center for Strategic and International Studies, the Peace Institute and the Heritage Foundation.
During the meetings, Chen had explained in detail his own views and the DPP's stances on issues related to Taiwan's future and its relations with rival mainland China.
After extensive talks with Chen, many US China hands said they feel that Chen has tried hard to expel American opinion leaders' suspicions about his and the DPP's stances on cross-strait relations.
The DPP has advocated the legislation of a plebiscite law to allow Taiwan people to decide the island's future status and Chen used to be seen as a pro-Taiwan independence activist.
Chen arrived in Washington, D.C. on Sunday for a three-day visit as part of his global "journey of learning" aimed at promoting his presidential bid.

Chen also met with former US Ambassador to mainland China James Lilley on Monday. Lilley, who also once served the top US envoy stationed in Taipei in the absence of official diplomatic ties, said after his talks with Chen that he feels that Chen has demonstrated a responsible attitude toward Taiwan's future.
"Even though some DPP members advocate a constitutional amendment to legalize plebiscite, Chen told me he does not think Taiwan will pass such a constitutional amendment this year," Lilley said.
Lilley recalled that when he met with Chen in Washington, D.C. in January 1998, Chen projected a moderate image. "My impression about Chen has not changed after Monday's talks," he noted.
Chen will also visit New York and Los Angeles before ending his current US trip.

DOC.HEADLINE: LISBON, BEIJING DIVIDED OVER HANDOVER CEREMONY INVITATION LIST

TEXT.P: Lisbon and Beijing remain divided over who should be invited to witness Macau's return to Beijing at the end of this year, Macau's press reported on Tuesday.

According to Macau's media, Lisbon intends to invite Chris Patten, the last Hong Kong governor, and leaders of Sao Tome and Principe, a Portuguese-speaking African country with formal diplomatic links with Taiwan, to witness the Dec. 20 ceremony marking the transfer of Macau's sovereignty to Beijing.
In addition, the Portuguese government has also expressed its hope that Beijing will not invite Indonesian representatives to the event if the situation in East Timor does not improve.
But media reports from Macau indicated Beijing is expected to reject Lisbon's proposals.

DOC.HEADLINE: COA TO BAN AUSTRALIAN LIVESTOCK IMPORTS

TEXT.P: The Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture (COA) announced Tuesday an immediate temporary ban on the import of horses, pigs and dogs from Australia and of dogs from Malaysia to prevent the Nipha virus from invading Taiwan.
The COA's animal and plant quarantine agency invited related government agencies to a recent animal quarantine meeting, at which they agreed to the ban.
Previously the council issued bans on cow, goat, horse and hog imports from Malaysia.
The COA has already issued official letters to airport and seaport quarantine personnel to step up inspections of imported livestock and related products.

The COA pointed out that a recent outbreak of the Hendra virus had killed horses in Australia in January, while in Malaysia ongoing epidemics of Japanese encephalitis and the Nipha virus have affected both humans and livestock.
To prevent the viruses from entering Taiwan through animal imports, the COA has decided a temporary suspension of imports is the best solution.

In addition to encouraging increased vigilance at airports and seaports, the COA also asked the National Police Administration, sea coast patrol units and the Ministry of Finance's customs bureaus to step up smuggling inspections.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC DEFENSE MINISTRY CONFIRMS PLA PLAN TO CONDUCT REGULAR WAR GAMES

TEXT.P: The Republic of China's Defense Ministry confirmed a local newspaper report on Tuesday that the People's Liberation Army (PLA) will conduct large-scale exercises between July and September.
Ministry spokesman Kung Huan-ting noted that the PLA usually carries out regiment- or division-wide joint maneuvers during the three-month period.

He said this year's live-fire combat exercises are expected to be held in the northwestern, northern and southwestern sections of mainland China, with the focus to be on the testing of new high-tech weapons and equipment.
The ROC armed forces plan to conduct "Chengkung Performance Exercises" and "Hankuang Exercises" in May and June this year.
Kung stressed that the two exercises are designed to review the results of the training of Taiwan's new-generation forces, and have nothing to do with countering PLA plans.
According to the newspaper report, the PLA will conduct live-fire war games and test-fire newly developed cruise missiles between May and August.

As this year marks the 50th year of the establishment of the People's Republic of China, Beijing will expand its military parades and display all kinds of newly developed weapons and related equipment, he said.

This is the last year of a three-year plan by the PLA to study advanced weapons technologies, so Beijing may step up its propaganda attacks by announcing its strides in weaponry development to pressure Taiwan, he said.
The ROC Defense Ministry will keep a close watch on the development of the PLA's military exercises, said the spokesman.

DOC.HEADLINE: TIGER WOODS TO TAKE PART IN JOHNNIE WALKER CLASSIC

TEXT.P: US golfer Eldrick "Tiger" Woods will take part in the ninth Johnnie Walker Classic, to be held in Taiwan between Nov. 9 and 14, organizers said Tuesday.

Woods, who was the No. 1 golfer in the world for the 65 weeks between June 1996 and March 1998, is the first world-class player to agree to participate in the match, which will take place at Taoyuan's Tahsi Country Club.
This year's event will be the first to be held in Taiwan, organizers said, though the isalnd has sought to hold it four times in the past.

In a press conference to announce his participation in the event, Woods said hello to his Taiwan fans in a televised message, saying that he is looking forward to defending his title in Taiwan 20 months after winning it in Thailand last year.

The match's US$1.35 million in prize money is the most of any golf event in Taiwan. Organizers said they hope that many world-class golfers will come to Taiwan to take part and that the event promotes the sport of golf in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: MANILA: VISIT BY LEE WOULD NOT CONTRIBUTE TO REGIONAL STABILITY

TEXT.P: The Philippine government justified on Tuesday its rejection of a planned visit by Taiwan President Lee Teng-hui, saying that such a visit would not contribute to stability in the region.

Presidential spokesman Jerry Barican said the planned personal visit by President Lee would adversely affect not only Philippine-mainland China relations but also Taiwan's relationship with mainland China.

Earlier on Monday, the Republic of China government in Taipei had denied wire service reports that Lee was planning to visit the Philippines this month to receive an honorary degree from Filipino alumni of Cornell University. "I've never heard of such a thing," said Lin Bih-jaw, deputy secretary-general to the president, when queried by the press.

In Manila, foreign affairs sources said the Philippine government decided not to grant a visa for Lee to make the personal visit. This was confirmed by Barican, who stressed that the decision was reached after careful deliberations within the Cabinet. The spokesman also acknowledged that Beijing had raised the issue with Manila at several levels.

Philippine foreign affairs officials have expressed concern that under Manila's "one-China" policy, a private visit by President Lee would still strain relations between the Philippines and mainland China. They have noted that the territorial dispute over the Mischief Reef in the Spratly Islands is already a standing irritant to the bilateral relationship.

DOC.HEADLINE: DOCTORS SAY SOME TYPES OF BRAIN DAMAGE PARTIALLY REVERSIBLE

TEXT.P: People with severe brain damage stand a much better chance of improving if they receive proper and heavy treatment within the first three months of their injuries, said neurosurgeons at Taipei's Chenhsin Medical Center.
Chiu Chia-hsin suffered severe brain damage after being involved in a car accident one year ago. But Chiu regained consciousness after being treated for hydrocephalus at the hospital.

The hospital was also able to successfully treat a 60-year-old patient with a brain tumor. After undergoing treatment, the woman was able to move her fingers and distinguish between some objects. She was also able to identify family members.
Before the woman was sent to Chenhsin, her family had been reluctant to subject her to further treatment, as she had been in a coma since last October, and her family had given up hope.
But the hospital's neurosurgery team persuaded the woman's family to let them operate.

Encouraged by its two successes, doctors at Chenhsin Medical Center said all severely brain-damaged people have the right to receive treatment, especially since their families' financial burdens are lessened by national health insurance subsidies.

They defined severely brain-damaged people as those who are awake but unable to idenfity people, places or objects. Such people can sleep, chew and form facial expressions, though they cannot communiate with other people or express thoughts or feelings.

Doctors said people with brain damage stand a much better chance of recovering if they receive treatment within the first three months of their injuries. Patients who are not treated within the first year of their injuries stand only a 2 percent chance of regaining consciousness, doctors stressed.

Whether such patients can regain consciousness depends on factors such as their age and the type of injury they have. Younger people, and those whose brain damage is the result of external brain injuries, brain tumors and hydrocephalus stand a greater chance of regaining consciousness after undergoing treatment, said doctors.
But those people whose injuries are caused by paralysis, poison, or damaged or atrophied brain nerves are unlikely to recover, doctors added.
No matter what their age or type of injury, people with brain damage are unlikely to experience a full recovery, doctors said, adding that such people will likely require lifelong rehabilitation.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN ARTISTS' WORKS TO BE ON EXHIBITION IN CENTRAL AMERICA AND SPAIN

TEXT.P: Renowned Taiwan woodcraft artist Wu Jung-szu will leave for Republic of China ally Costa Rica on May 14 to hold an exhibition there of his works, while 11 contemporary Taiwan painters are to hold a month-long exhibition in Spain starting May 25.
Wu's woodcraft exhibition will take place May 14-22 and will feature 18 of his masterpieces.

Meanwhile, the "Taiwan Files -- Taipei Contemporaries' Self and Dialogue" exhibition will be on display in Zaragoza, near Madrid, later that month. The exhibition has been planned by Chang Chang of New York City's Central Art Gallery.
The exhibition, from May 25 to June 25, and will showcase 33 paintings by 11 artists.

DOC.HEADLINE: CONFERENCE ON TAIWAN INDIGENOUS PEOPLE TO BE HELD IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: An international conference on Taiwan's indigenous peoples will be held at Academia Sinica, Taipei's highest-level research institute, from May 1 to May 3, the organizers said on Tuesday.

The International Conference on the Formosan Indigenous Peoples, co-sponsored by the Council of Aboriginal Affairs under the Executive Yuan, Academia Sinica, and the privately owned Sung Ye Museum of Formosan Aborigines has allocated 200 seats at the conference site to the public, as part of the organizers' efforts to enhance the general public's awareness about Taiwan's aborigines.

The three-day conference will be followed by a three-day tour of aboriginal communities in central Nantou County and southern Pintung County, and will be capped by a fete on May 8 at Taipei's Sung Ye Museum of Formosan Aborigines which will feature performances of aboriginal dance and music, a taste of aboriginal dishes, and an exhibition of aboriginal artifacts.

DOC.HEADLINE: EXPORT ORDERS FOR MARCH EXPECTED TO HIT US$10 BILLION

TEXT.P: The monthly value of export orders received by Taiwan companies in March is expected to return to the US$10 billion level for the first time since last November, officials with the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) announced on Tuesday.
Orders from the United States remained stable, while those from Southeast Asia increased and those from Europe decreased.
In their analysis of the figures for March, however, the officials remained somewhat conservative, describing them as just an upturn, and pointing out that a full recovery is still some way off.

Taiwan received export orders worth US$10.3 billion and US$10.1 billion in September and October of last year, respectively, but since November, the values had consistently failed to reach the US$10 billion mark.

DOC.HEADLINE: WORLD VISION TAIWAN MOVES TO HELP KOSOVO REFUGEES

TEXT.P: World Vision Taiwan launched a campaign on Tuesday to donate 60,000 life-saving packages, with help from legislators from across the political spectrum, to help displaced Kosovo refugees.
Each package will contain sufficient dry foods, clean water and hygiene items to sustain a family of five or six for one week.

Shao Ching-ming, the president of World Vision Taiwan, visited a refugee camp in Macedonia a short while ago, and decided to launch the campaign together with the president of World Vision Canada, who recently visited a refugee camp in Albania.

Macedonia and Albania both share a border with the strife-torn Yugoslavian province of Kosovo, where ethnic Albanians are being driven from the province into neighboring countries and subjected to ethnic cleansing tactics by troops belonging to Yugoslav President Slobodan Milosevic.
Six legislators threw their support behind the campaign, and signed a "declaration on helping Kosovo refugees." Some legislators also agreed to donate one day's worth of salary to the campaign.

A spokesman for World Vision Taiwan said that each life-saving package costs NT$2,000 (US$60.60), and that members of the public wishing to support the campaign can remit donations through the postal remittance service, or alternatively can call the "hungry hotline" on (02)2585-6300.
Shao quoted UNHCR statistics which show that about 36,000 Kosovo refugees have fled to Albania, 130,000 to Macedonia, and another 7,300 to Montenegro, and that the number is growing.
He added that the life-saving packages will be sent to those most in need as soon as possible.
The Republic of China Foreign Ministry has already begun providing assistance to Kosovo refugees in Macedonia, sending a plane-load of relief materials last week.
A field hospital operated by physicians from Taiwan's Luchuhui Society, a private charity group, is already established in Macedonia, providing medical services to about 300 refugees each day.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI REJECTS SEOUL CALLS FOR RESUMPTION OF RECIPROCAL FRUIT TRADE

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Council of Agriculture (COA) on Tuesday rejected a call from South Korea for a resumption of reciprocal trade in fruit between the two countries, the council announced on Tuesday.

Seoul has asked Taipei through its representative office in Taipei to restore the reciprocal trade agreement reached at a bilateral ministerial meeting in 1985, under which each country undertook to purchase equal value fruit from the other.

The deal was suspended by Taipei in 1997 on the grounds that Seoul failed to fulfill its obligations under the pact, resulting in a heavy trade deficit against Taiwan which hit US$24.42 million in 1998 alone.
The Korean Mission in Taipei said that South Korea's agriculture sector has suffered great losses because Taiwan closed its market to South Korean apples and pears.
The COA said that because of South Korea's failure to live up to it's side of the agreement, it will not consider restoring the pact.

However, COA Chairman Peng Tso-kui said that once Taiwan becomes a member of the World Trade Organization (WTO), South Korean apples and pears will once again have easy market access to Taiwan under WTO terms.

DOC.HEADLINE: HUNGER STRIKE FOR PLEBISCITE ENDS IN FAILURE

TEXT.P: The 11-day-old hunger strike dubbed the "410 fast" came to an end on Tuesday without achieving its goal of pressing for legislation of a plebiscite law.

A promised discussion of the issue slated for Tuesday's parliamentary session resulted in a vote to shelve the plebiscite bill, an official move signaling the legislature's refusal to concede to the hunger strikers' tactics.
The campaign organizers said that they had to call off the hunger strike for the sake of the 23 strikers' lives, but stressed that their determination and resolve has not softened.

In a joint statement, they reiterated the need for a plebiscite law to ensure the right of the people of Taiwan to self-determination, and said they will take further action in the future to achieve their end.

Legislator Trong Chai from the opposition Democratic Progressive Party, a front-man for the hunger strikers, who included DPP lawmakers and independence activists, said at the beginning of the fast last Saturday that they are convinced "a plebiscite can be the best solution to problem of Taiwan's sovereignty," and could also serve to decide the country's major policy decisions.

However, the ruling Kuomintang did not agree and nor did the New Party, which opposes Taiwan independence. The hunger strikers were also blasted for trying to push through their plebiscite proposal without the common agreement of the majority.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, April 21, or the sixth day of the third month of the Year of the Rabbit according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1634: Jan van Riebeeck, Dutch naval surgeon and founder of Cape Town, South Africa, is born.
1898: The United States declares war on Spain.
1910: Mark Twain, pen name of Samuel Langhorne Clemens, American author and humorist, dies at the age of 74. He drew on his childhood along the Mississippi River to create masterpieces of humor and sarcasm, including "Tom Sawyer" and "The Adventures of Huckleberry Finn."
1926: Elizabeth II, Queen of England since 1952, is born.
1930: Fire breaks out at the Ohio state penitentiary, killing 355 people.
1935: An earthquake hits central and northern Taiwan, killing some 3,000 people.
1937: Steamships formally begin plying between Shanghai and San Francisco once a week on regular basis.
1946: John Maynard Keynes, British economist, dies at the age of 63. He proposed that high unemployment, being a result of insufficient consumer spending, could be relieved by government-sponsored programs.
1948: Government troops of the Republic of China evacuate Yenan.
1949: The Chinese communists resume their all-out offensive and cross the Yangtze River.
1954: The United States flies a French battalion to Indochina to defend Dien Bien Phu, which is overrun by Vietnamese forces three weeks later.
1957: Taiwan voters go to the polls for the third time to elect county magistrates, city mayors, and provincial assemblymen.
1958: The Taiwan Provincial Assembly Building in Wufeng, Taichung Hsien, is inaugurated.
1960: Brazil moves its capital from Rio de Janeiro to Brazilia, the brain-child of President Juselino Kubitschek.
1966: The Republic of China and Dahomey resume diplomatic relations.
1971: Francois Duvalier, known as "Papa Doc," Haitian dictator, dies at the age of 64. Elected president in 1957, he declared himself president for life in 1964 and ruled in an authoritarian manner until his death. He was succeeded by his son Jean-Claude who fled the country in 1986 after widespread civil unrest.
1975: South Vietnamese President Nguyen Van Thieu resigns after denouncing the United States as untrustworthy.
1987: Terrorists explode a bomb near the main bus station in Colombo, Sri Lanka, killing and injuring more than 400 people.
1989: More than 10,000 workers and students, shouting for democracy and human rights, march from campuses to converge on Tienanmen Square in Beijing in defiance of official warnings against anti-government protests.
1997: An advance contingent of communist Chinese troops enter Hong Kong in preparation for the handover of the British crown colony to communist China on July 1.
1998: Seoul drops efforts to receive Japanese compensation for women held as sex slaves during World War II and says it will pay the surviving women.
Confucius lesson of the day: "A good horse is considered so, not because of its mere brute strength, but because of its moral qualities."
