DOC.HEADLINE: SUMMER MILITARY DRILLS ROUTINE: MAC HEAD

TEXT.P: Mainland Affairs Council Chairman Su Chi said on Wednesday that Republic of China military drills slated for this summer are all routine exercises and urged the public not to speculate on the issue.
Su said the ROC's annual military exercises and training focus on self-defense measures that are not aimed at mainland China.

Su's remarks came one day after the Ministry of National Defense (MND) confirmed in a regular news conference media reports that mainland China will conduct high-tech live-fire warfare exercises in its northern, northeastern, and southeastern regions during the July-September period, while the ROC military will hold its Chengkung and Hankuang exercises in May or June.

The MND also called on the outside world not to associate its yearly summer military drills with similar activities in the mainland. It added, however, that it will closely monitor the movements of the mainland Chinese troops.

DOC.HEADLINE: DEFENSE MINISTER DENIES REPORT ON MEDIUM-RANGE MISSILE PLAN

TEXT.P: Defense Minister Tang Fei on Wednesday denied a US media report that the Republic of China plans to develop medium-range missiles.
Tang was commenting on a Washington-based Defense News report that the conditions for Taiwan to deploy medium-range missile has gradually ripened.
Tang said he was surprised by the report, stressing that the Ministry of National Defense (MND) has no such a plan.

Tang said the US defense weekly apparently has reached its conclusion after interviewing some Taiwan politicians from both the ruling and opposition parties about the development and deployment of medium-range missiles.
"Those opinions only represented their personal views, not the defense ministry's established policy," Tang said.
The minister said he understands that the issues related to develop and deploy various defensive and strategic weapons, including medium-range missiles, have been widely discussed in local society.

"Opinions expressed in those discussions mainly reflect personal views," Tang said, adding that the MND currently has no plans to develop medium-range missiles. "The deployment of medium-range missiles has not yet formed part of our policy," he stressed.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER US AMBASSADOR SAYS US MUST WATCH BEIJING'S MISSILE MANEUVERS

TEXT.P: If the United States lets the mainland Chinese know that there would be no missile defense in the western Pacific, they will build more missiles "because it will give them leverage to force Taiwan to the negotiating table on their terms," according to James Lilley, former US ambassador to Beijing.

Lilley, however, said during a Senate Foreign Relations Subcommittee hearing on Tuesday that the United States should not get into a real contest with the mainland Chinese now over theater missile defense systems.

When the United States sent its carriers to waters near Taiwan in March 1996, it could have led to a disaster, he said, adding that he believes it is essential to establish an understanding with Taiwan about future contingencies and planning to deal with those contingencies. "This is the sort of soft war you can carry out ... without really challenging the (US-PRC) relationship," he said.

Lilley said decisions about whether the United States should build its Aegis-class destroyers into a theater missile defense system to defend Taiwan and whether the United States should sell Taiwan the destroyers to participate in the system need not be made for some time.
But if mainland China continues to increase its missile capacity, "then you look at the TMD as an integral part of an overall anti-missile system that you develop in that area," he said.

He also stressed that the United States should be concerned about reports that Beijing may be pursuing the development of multiple independently targetable reentry vehicles (MIRV), but he does not think there is anything the United States can do about it, except tighten security at Los Alamos and other national weapons laboratories.

The mainland Chinese have been after MIRV for a long time, Lilley said. Former Defense Secretary William Perry has said Beijing may have succeeded in trying to get the SS-18, a solid-fuel missile with MIRV capability, from the Soviet Union.

He said one of the most specious arguments made by the mainland Chinese apologists is that theater missile defense will force them to get MIRV. But the mainland Chinese are determined to get MIRV because it is in their national interests. And they can use theater missile defense as an excuse, and "have Americans run around parroting their line."

Meanwhile, Lilley noted that in mainland Chinese Premier Zhu Rongji's US visit the whole strategic-military arrangement was downplayed, and even President Bill Clinton neglected to use the term "constructive strategic partnership," in both his foreign policy address and his joint press conference with Zhu, "because anybody knows a strategic partnership does not exist. It is a word game."

He added that the mainland Chinese are against NATO expansion; they are against the United States' position in Kosovo; they are against the Japanese-American security treaty, which is the cornerstone of the United States' strategy in Asia; they are against the United States' position on Taiwan; and they sometimes have not been helpful toward the United States' position on North Korea.

Of mainland China, Lilley said: "It should be a country that goes by international rules of trade, rule of law across the board, expands its electoral base, opens up its system and deals with its problems on its periphery in a peaceful way. And I think this is what we should aim for."

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER US DEFENSE SECRETARY SUPPORTS TMD SYSTEM IN ASIA

TEXT.P: Mainland China is more reluctant than Russia to see the United States develop and deploy a missile defense system in the western Pacific because "it would deny to them the capability to use their missile forces against Japan, Taiwan, Korea and the like," said former US Defense Secretary James Schlesinger Tuesday.

He told a Senate Foreign Relations Subcommittee hearing on missile threats to the United States that Washington has to make clear to the mainland Chinese that it is necessary for the United States to deploy missile defenses that would protect US bases in the Pacific, "not only from our own interests but from the standpoint of the overall security and stability in Asia."
Schlesinger said the United States should also inform the mainland Chinese that the areas the United States would protect would include Japan and South Korea.

But he noted: "The delicate problem is the subject of Taiwan. I think that that is a subject on which the least said, the better; that we ought to continue to reiterate that, indeed, the United States' policy, as it has been since 1972, is a one-China policy; that we continue to believe that the PRC (People's Republic of China) and the Republic of China will work out their differences peacefully."

"The Chinese will understand that we -- particularly if we deploy the Aegis system -- have the capability of providing a missile defense for Taiwan, but I do not think we should ever say that. The Chinese would regard it not only as a threat but interference, as they say, in their domestic affairs," the former director of the Central Intelligence Agency said.

Since the Anti-Ballistic Missile Treaty prevents the use of theater missile defenses in a national missile defense mode, "we need to modify the treaty to permit a minimum number of (missile defense) sites, but sufficient to protect the continental United States as well as Alaska and Hawaii" against potential missile attacks by such "rogue nations" as Iran, Iraq and North Korea, which are hostile to the United States, said Schlesinger.
But if the Russians are unwilling to agree to such a deployment, "then I think that we have no alternative but to move towards abrogation" of the ABM Treaty," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN EXPORTS TO US ON THE RISE
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, April 21 (CNA) (By Herman Pan and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Taiwan exported US$2.47 billion worth of goods to the United States in February, up 6.2 percent over year-earlier levels, sources from the US Department of Commerce said on Tuesday.
Taiwan's imports from the United States in February, however, fell to US$1.22 billion, down 24.1 percent from the same 1998 month, according to the latest tallies released by the department.
As a result, Taiwan posted a trade surplus of US$1.25 billion with the United States in February, a stunning increase of 74.8 percent over its February 1998 surplus.
Taiwan was the source of the United States' sixth-largest trade deficit in February.
Department officials attributed Taiwan's increased exports to America in February to the fact that the island's exports have begun to gain momentum since earlier this year.
Meanwhile, Taiwan's purchases from the United States have not increased. This has resulted in a trade surplus that has grown significantly during the first two months of this year.

In all, the United States suffered a deficit of US$19.5 billion in the trade of commercial goods and services in February, up 15.6 percent from January. February's deficit was a single-month record high. Wall Street analysts had predicted a deficit of US$14.4 billion to US$17.6 billion, according to Department officials.
The United States' US$4.62 billion trade deficit with mainland China in February was one of its largest, and it was 32.2 percent higher than its trade deficit with the mainland in February 1998.
Department of Commerce statistics showed that for every US$1 in goods that the United States exported to mainland China, the Chinese mainland exported US$5.90 worth of goods to the United States.

DOC.HEADLINE: EXPLORATION BID OF PRATAS ISLANDS URGED

TEXT.P: Scholars and Kaohsiung city councilors attending a Wednesday seminar here voiced strong support for the city authorities' intent to develop the Pratas Islands in the South China Sea.

In a seminar called by Kaohsiung City Councilor Chen Yun-lung, Hu Jien-tzu, director of National Sun Yat-sen University's water rescues study institute, opined that development of the Pratas Islands should center on the protection of its marine ecology.

Under the precondition, he said, the Kaohsiung City Government's exploration activities will help crack down on illegal fishing operations on nearby waters, thus buttressing the Republic of China's sovereignty over the islands.

Hu called on Kaohsiung City councilors to back the municipal authorities' idea to set up a bureau on managing and developing marine resources, and urged marine police to cooperate with the Ministry of National Defense to jointly maintain order and sweep illegal activities near the Pratas Islands.

Lee Wen-liang, head of the Kaohsiung City's Urban Development Bureau, said Mayor Frank Hsieh has instructed relevant agencies to form a task force to study the feasibility of exploration and management of the Pratas Islands.

In February 1990, the Executive Yuan authorized the Kaohsiung City Government to trustee the Pratas Islands. In addition to a Fishermen Service Center, the Kaohsiung municipal authorities maintain no other facilities there.

Echoing Hu's view, Lee Chan-jung, a researcher with the National Museum of Marine Biology Aquarium, said that as much as 98 percent of the coral reefs near the Pratas Islands have been destroyed in recent years by mainland Chinese and Hong Kong fishermen who illegally poached there.

Citing a recent investigation by the cabinet-level Council of Agriculture and the Kaohsiung City Government, Lee pointed out that about half of the 137 categories of coral reefs there have disappeared.
He stressed that marine ecology near the Pratas Islands must be first restored before the authorities take moves to develop the island.

Since the Business Management Committee under the ruling Kuomintang revealed early this month its interest in developing the Pratas Islands into a tourism spot, the islands have become a hot discussion topic recently. Kaohsiung Mayor Hsieh also announced on Tuesday that he will lead an inspection delegation to the island in late April or early May to assess the possibility of working out a marine tourist route from Taiwan to the island.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT BRINGS CHILDREN TO OFFICE

TEXT.P: Mirth and laughter reverberated in the new building housing the ruling Kuomintang when scores of children joined their parents on Wednesday.
The children, many of them in primary schools or kindergartens, took part in the first-ever "bring children to the office" activities sponsored by the KMT's Central Committee.

John Chang, KMT secretary general, welcomed the young guests, saying that the day was planned to give them an understanding of their parents' working enviroment, enhance their relationship with their parents, as well as learn the work ethics of their parents' profession.

Chang noted that "bring your daughter to the office" was first introduced in the United States, with the hope that young girls would avoid the gender gap through working side by side their mothers, while upgrading their working skills.
Chang noted the campaign has since received an enthusiastic response in the US and that both sons and daughters now join their parents at the office.
He urged the Executive Yuan to follow suit and set April 23 as a "Children and Parents Day" in Taiwan.

KMT officials led the children on a tour of the new building, explaining the duties of the KMT party workers. They also arranged a mini-concert and other entertainment programs for the children so that they could learn how a political party operates through playing.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERIOR MINISTER VOWS TO REDUCE LARCENY BY 20%

TEXT.P: Minister of the Interior Huang Chu-wen said he believed larceny crimes can be lowered by 20 percent in a year's time as long as people cooperate with the police, sources reported on Wednesday.
Huang made the remark in a morning radio program, adding that he was confident and determined to prevent serious criminal events from happening.

Driven by public's strong fear and resentment to the increasing of theft cases, police have since January been actively working to stop larceny. Huang added that statistics compiled by the Ministry of the Interior (MOI) show that cases of reported theft during January and February fell 12.92 percent compared to the same period last year.

To cheer up and honor the police for their hard work, the minister and the Director-General of the National Police Administration Ting Yuan-chin will visit the island's major police stations. By doing so, they believe the country's police will work harder and the public's confidence in the nation's security will return.
Regarding the problem of long unsolved cases, Huang said he has instructed the administration to keep investigating every unsolved case.
Huang also urged judges to hand down harsher penalties to those found guilty of larceny, specially to repeated violators. (by Amanda Chang)

DOC.HEADLINE: YUNLIN COUNTY CLARIFIES ILLEGAL LABOR REPORTS
DOC.DATELINE: Yunlin, northern Taiwan, April 21 (CNA) (By Wendy Chung)

TEXT.P: The Yunlin County government clarified recent reports of falsifications of government names in order to collect foreign labor brokerage fees on Wednesday.

The county government said recent cases of criminals assuming government agency names to collect foreign labor broker fees have seriously sullied the image of the government, and called on businesses and employers to report illegal activities to the police or the social affairs department.
The county government advised the public to hire foreign labor through registered legal brokers, or to inquire at the social affairs department to avoid fraud.
According to the Yunlin County government's statistics, there are presently 23,000 foreign labors in the county and six legal labor brokerage companies.

Yunlin in southern Taiwan, like other parts of the island, is in bad need for foreign workers to fill the vacancies caused by labor shortage, leading to a booming foreign brokerage market and frequent cases of illegal activities.

DOC.HEADLINE: CKS INT'L AIRPORT'S 2ND TERMINAL TO BE OPENED IN JAN.

TEXT.P: The construction work at Chang Kai-shek International Airport's second passenger terminal will be completed in January 2000, the Civil Aeronautics Administration (CAA) announced on Wednesday.
Transportation and Communications Minister Lin Fong-cheng was at the airport to inspect the progress of the second terminal Wednesday afternoon.

By mid-April 83.76 percent of the construction work has been completed. The NT$22.10 billion expansion project began in 1988 under a government plan to promote the airport as the hub of an Asian-Pacific aviation center.
By January of next year, 16 administrative/employment agencies and 11 domestic and international airlines will call the new terminal home.

The total area of the second passenger terminal is 208,000 square meters, compared to 169,000 square meters of the first terminal. The first terminal had an original capacity of eight million passengers, however, last year's user population reached 16 million, resulting in overcrowding.
The second terminal will be able to handle an estimated 32 million passengers per year.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S HUMANITARIAN DELEGATION IN SKOPJE TO RETURN

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs said on Wednesday that the 26-member Taiwanese charity "Luchu Association" will withdraw from the Stenkovec refugee camp outside of Skopje after providing a week of medical aid in the war-torn Yugoslav province of Kosovo.
Seven military doctors will remain in the refugee camp while ten more doctors from Taiwan will travel to Macedonia next Monday, MOFA officials added.
Director of MOFA's European Affairs Liu Hsiang-pu said the ten doctors, specialized in internal medicine and dentistry, plan to stay in Macedonia for one month.
Regarding the Luchu Association's early return, MOFA said it has no right to compel private charity groups to extend their service time, adding that the group's efforts were appreciated.

The Luchu Association left for Macedonia last Friday with 26 medical personnel to join a Taiwan-donated field hospital located in the Stenkovec refugee camp. The group originally planned to stay and provide medical assistance for two weeks. (by Amanda Chang)

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT LEE URGES AVIATION SAFETY IMPROVEMENT

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui on Wednesday asked the Civil Aeronautics Administration (CAA) under the Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC) to improve the nation's aviation safety.

Lee made the request after listening to a report on "The policy on civil aviation development and outlook" by CAA Director General Chang Yu-heng at a Central Standing Committee meeting of the ruling Kuomintang.
The president said that the CAA should continue its efforts to satisfy passengers and to strive for a "zero accident, zero defect" goal.
He also urged CAA officials to strengthen their efforts to promote Taiwan's development into an Asia-Pacific aviation center.
CAA's Chang said in his report that after several air accidents last year, the CAA took measures to ensure aviation safety, and the results of those measures are now evident.
Meanwhile, MOTC Minister Lin Fong-cheng said that the MOTC will step up its supervision of aviation safety measures being implemented by all airlines.
He went on to say that improvements will also be made in airport aviation control and flight-guidance equipment, airport transport connections and overall airport operations.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER TO ATTEND INAUGURATION OF SALVADORAN PRESIDENT-ELECT

TEXT.P: Premier Vincent Siew is expected to attend the inauguration ceremony of Salvadoran President-elect Francisco Flores on June 1 on behalf of Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui, diplomatic sources said on Wednesday.

Visiting Salvadorian Vice President-elect Carlos Guintanilla Schmidt extended an invitation to President Lee for the inauguration when the two met last week. Lee promised to send a high ranking official to the event.
Diplomatic officials commented that Siew, has not yet decided whether to use the opportunity to also visit neighboring countries, saying that the matter needs further assessment.
In the March 7 election, Flores of the ruling Republican National Alliance won more than 52 percent of the votes in the first round.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRIZE-WINING FEMALE WRITER SU HSUEH-LIN DIES

TEXT.P: Renowned female writer Su Hsueh-lin died on Wednesday at the age of 104.
Su, who taught at National Cheng Kung University until retiring in 1973, died at 3:05 p.m. at the National Cheng Kung University Hospital after a long illness.
A statement issued by the hospital said that Su was admitted on Jan. 30 suffering from the flu and transferred into the intensive care unit on Feb. 7 after the flu became pneumonia.
Her condition deteriorated after her 104th birthday earlier this month.

Su won her reputation long before she fled the Chinese Communist regime in mainland China to Taiwan in 1949. She earned numerous prizes including the Chungshan Literature Prize and the National Literature Prize, the highest honor granted by the government.
Su was born in 1884 in Anhui, in central mainland China, and never married.
Professor Tang Yi-nan, one of Su's students who took care of her in her late years, said that according to Su's wishes, her body will be cremated and the ashes sent back to her Anhui homeland.
After learning of Su's death, Chen Chien-jen, director general of the Government Information Office, expressed his sadness, praising Su as a great woman who influenced the Chinese literature.

DOC.HEADLINE: HABIBIE CLOSES IN ON NOMINATION

TEXT.P: Singapore, April 21 (CNA): Indonesia's ruling Golkar party appears all but certain to be nominating Dr. B.J. Habibie as its presidential candidate with the armed forces (Abri) chief, General Wiranto, as his running mate.

Ministerial sources told The Straits Times that while several Golkar elders and regional representatives have decided since January to back the incumbent for a five-year term, they are not making their decision public until after the party's leadership meeting.
The party also decided to have a slate of four other candidates "as part of the 'wayang' and to democratize the whole process", said a Cabinet minister who is a Golkar executive member.

He said, "Technically, it is not correct to say Habibie is the sole candidate. He is the leading candidate among others the party has chosen. But informally, a large number of us have already made up our minds that he should continue to be president. "
He added that the choice of Gen. Wiranto as Vice-President was more Habibie's personal preference than a party decision.
"Habibie is voluble. Wiranto is calm and steady. They'll made a good combination," he said.
He said a number of factors were in favor of the German-trained engineer, despite the handicap of his past association with former president Suharto.
The most critical was that State Secretary Akbar Tand-kung, who is also a leading contender for the presidency, had thrown his weight behind Habibie.
Akbar has extensive grassroots links with organizations like the Indonesian Muslim Student's Association and ties with party branches in several provinces.

"Given the circumstances and lack of support that former president Suharto would have otherwise got from the military, Habibie has done quite a good job of maneuvering different groups and winning over the support of key individuals," he said.
Another factor was that Habibie has the support of most of the Golkar regional representatives outside Java, particularly in eastern Indonesia.
"They see him as a non-Javanese, and this is something very appealing for people who went through 32 years under a Javanese president," said the source.
"There is also a sense that Habibie, if he is allowed to stay on, would be able to continue with the reform process he has started."
Analysts said that while Habibie is strong in provinces outside Java, there are doubts over how much support he would get in Java - the political heartland of Indonesia.
The Cabinet source admitted that there were difficulties, especially in East Java, which he described as "the Achilles heel of Golkar and Habibie".
Support for Ms. Megawati Sukarnoputri, the chairman of the Indoneisa Democratic Party (PDI-Perjuangan), and the enigmatic Mr. Abdurrahman Wahid of the Nadhlatul Ulama, are strong in these areas.
Besides this, there is a real challenge in Golkar from a small group of urban-based intellectuals, like Marzuki Darusman, the head of the party faction in Parliament.
Political observers said that while Habibie "stood the best chance of being nominated," Mr. Akbar had "a 20 to 30 percent possibility", given his own strong backing within the party.

Said a source who attended a party meeting in Jakarta last wee,: "Akbar will back Habibie for personal reasons. But problems will arise if Akbar's supporters go against the wishes of their leader and reject Habibie at the upcoming leadership meeting.
"The issue here is whether Akbar will get them to toe the line to back Habibie or ride on their support and go for the throne himself. We can never discount the latter possibility." (sherman wu)

DOC.HEADLINE: MANILA WILLING TO MONITOR E.TIMOR ELECTIONS

TEXT.P: The Philippines is willing to help Indonesia monitor the forthcoming plebicite in East Timor through programs sponsored by the United Nations aimed at ensuring a peaceful and clean polling, Malacanang said Wednesday.

Presidential Spokesman Jerry Barican said the participation of the Philippines will be through the National Movement for Free Elections, which could help Jakarta institute voter education programs under the auspices of the UN Development Program.

"Having close and friendly relations with Indonesia, the Philippines is prepared to join other countries in participating in the forthcoming plebicite in East Timor, if such an invitation to participate is made by Indonesian President B. J. Habibie," Barican said in a press briefing at the Palace.
Indonesia took over East Timor, a former Portuguese, in 1975.
In the face of mounting violence in East Timor, Habibie has scheduled a plebicite in July to determine whether its residence would accept an autonomy proposal for the former colony. (Timothy Sun)

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN RANKS 3RD SAFEST PLACE FOR INVESTMENT

TEXT.P: A survey conducted by the Swiss-based Business Environment Risk Intelligence (BERI) ranks Taiwan as the third least risky area for investment in the world.
The latest survey, published at the end of March, placed Taiwan third among 58 states around the world in terms of investment risk, trailing only Switzerland and Singapore.
Rounding out the top ten were the Netherlands, Japan, Germany, Austria, Norway, the United States and Belgium.
Singapore, Taiwan and Japan were the only three Asian states listed as areas of little risk.
Mainland China ranked 19th and South Korea 22nd, were considered as mid-risky places for investment.
The BERI gauges risk by evaluating business operation risk, political risk and the ability to pay debts in hard currency.
The survey is published three times a year; March, July and November.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies Thursday are as follows:
The Central Daily News:
The United States confirmed that mainland China has stolen its nuclear technology secrets.
The China Times:
The Ministry of Education on Wednesday passed amendments to existing regulations on "long distance education," which will allow students to take up to one third of their degree credits via interactive teaching programs on the Internet.
The United Daily News:
Police cracked down on campus criminal ring members.
The Liberty Times:
Two US high school students killed at least 15 classmates and injured 20 others in a campus shooting rampage.
The Commons Daily:
Former Taipei Mayor Chen Shui-bian said he takes pride in being a Taiwanese.
The China Post:
Sixteen were dead in horrifying school 'suicide mission.'
The China News:
'Suicide mission' on Denver campus leaves 16 dead.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC ECONOMICS MINISTER CHANGES TRAVEL COURSES FOR WTO DRIVE

TEXT.P: Republic of China Economic Affairs Minister Wang Chih-kang will visit Washington, D.C. in early May to drum up support for Taiwan's entry into the World Trade Organization (WTO), sources from the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) reported Thursday.
Wang's originally scheduled visit to New Zealand next week for a ministerial-level meeting of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum thus has been cancelled, according to the sources.
Yang Shih-chien, a minister without portfolio and a veteran economics expert, will take Wang's place at the APEC meeting, which is scheduled to kick off in New Zealand Sunday, the sources said.

The clock is beginning to count down for Taiwan's WTO accession in the wake of reports that mainland China will become a WTO member this year. As Taiwan believes it should be admitted into the world trade regulatory body at the same time, if not before mainland China, Taiwan's government is accelerting the WTO drive tempo.

Wang will leave for Washington on May 3 accompanied by Vice Economic Affairs Minister Lin Yi-fu to drum up support for Taiwan's WTO bid in the US capital, in particular support for Taiwan in a WTO working meeting next month in Geneva, the sources said.

The WTO Secretariat has informed Taipei recently that it will resume a WTO working group meeting to screen Taiwan's multilateral consultation results May 10-12, marking the first such resumption in years by the WTO authorities.
The latest WTO notification prompted Wang to change his travel plans from New Zealand to Washington, D.C., where policy-makers hold the keys to WTO accession for both mainland China and Taiwan.

ROC business and trade officials attach extreme importance to the Geneva screening meeting, hoping the meeting will be the last one before Taiwan is formally admitted as a WTO member before the end of this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: MORE ROC DOCTORS TO LEAVE FOR MACEDONIA NEXT WEEK

TEXT.P: A group of ROC military doctors will leave for Macedonia next week to offer humanitarian medical services to ethnic Albanian refugees from the war-torn neighboring Yugoslav province of Kosovo, a foreign affairs official said on Thursday.

Liu Hsiang-pu, director of the European Affairs Department of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA), said he has consulted with the Ministry of National Defense on the dispatch of military medical professionals to Macedonia to replace a voluntary medical team organized by the Luchu Hui, a private local philanthropic organization.

"The Defense Ministry has agreed to send a military medical team to Macedonia to offer humanitarian relief services to Kosovar refugees," Liu said, adding that the military medical team will stay in Macedonia for one month.
Liu said the military medical team will be composed of doctors in general medicine, surgery, family medicine, obstetrics-gynecology and dentistry.
"The military doctors will leave for Macedonia in several groups starting Monday," Liu said, adding that the MOFA will also ask local public health authorities to send medical personnel to Macedonia.
Liu further said the ministry will decide whether to send additional personnel and continue medical services to Kosovar refugees two weeks before the military medical team's one-month tenure expires.

The Luchu Hui-organized voluntary medical team has operated a field hospital at the Stenkovec refugee camp on the outskirts of the Macedonian capital of Skopje for 10 days. The hospital offers medical services to an average of 300 outpatients a day.
Liu said as an Israel-operated field hospital in the area will end its services soon, the workload for the Luchu Hui hospital is expected to become even heavier.

About 12 Luchu Hui doctors will continue to stay in Stenkovec, the largest refugee camp in Macedonia, to offer medical services to Kosovar refugees, while the other 14 Luchu team members will leave Macedonia for home via Zurich on Sunday.

The Republic of China forged formal diplomatic ties with Macedonia in January this year. The ROC has so far offered about US$5 million in cash donations, pharmaceuticals, medical equipment and other relief goods to assist Macedonia in coping with the influx of a large number of Kosovar refugees.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATORS CONCERN ABOUT FOREIGN LABORERS IN HSINCHU IND. PARK

TEXT.P: Legislators on Thursday expressed concern about the large number of foreign laborers in the Hsinchu Science-based Industrial Park in northern Taiwan.
Legislators made the criticism after reviewing the park's operation budget during a legislative committee.
Su Huan-chih of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party said that nearly 5,000 foreign laborers in the park pose a threat to the local workers.

Su stressed that the government has provided various incentives to the manufacturers in the park, and the employment of large number of cheap foreign laborers affects the employment opportunities of local workers, a situation he said runs against the principle of social justice.
He urged the government to review the situation, adding that labor cost in high-tech industries is not high and there should be no need for cheap foreign laborers.

Feng Ting-kuo of the New Party asked the National Science Council (NSC) to set a limitation on employing foreign laborers in the industrial park so that local workers take precedence over foreign ones.
Feng noted that unemployment in Taiwan is serious and that park manufacturers are only trying to save money by employing foreign laborers.

NSC Chairman Huang Chen-tai said that Hsinchu park currently employs 72,000 workers. Among them more than 4,700 are foreign workers. He noted that currently there are three shifts in the park's plants, with the graveyard shift the most difficult to fill, therefore most foreign laborers work that shift.
Huang said that he agreed with Feng that local workers should take precedence over foreign workers, but it is also true that the plants have difficulty in recruiting workers for the graveyard shift.
Huang said that NSC will study the issue further.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT OF KALMYKIA REP. MEETS TAIPEI MAYOR

TEXT.P: Visiting President Kirsan Nikolayevich Ilyumzhinov of the Kalmykia Republic on Thursday met with Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou and expressed interest in creating sisterhood ties between the Russian state and Taipei.
Kalmykia, one of the 21 autonomous republics of the Russian Federation, is the only Lamaist state in Europe. The country located off the Caspian Sea has a population of 330,000.
During the meeting with Ma, Ilyumzhinov presented Ma a blue silk Hata to show his respect.
Ma welcomed Ilyumzhinov and said he will seriously consider the sisterhood ties proposal.
Ma could not hide his surprise over the youth of Ilyumzhinov, 36 years old.

Ilyumzhinov, who speaks fluent English, told Ma that he is preparing to run in the Russian Federation presidential race slated for June 2000. Ma wished Ilyumzhinov success and jokingly asked him not to forget to send Taipei an invitation to the inauguration.

Ilyumzhinov said Lamaists, or Tibetan Buddhists in his country had been harshly treated during the Russian rule and that many Lamaist temples had been dismantled. He has seen to it that 15 Lamaist temples have been rebuilt since taking office, he noted.
Ilyumzhinov, meanwhile, urged Taiwan businesses to invest in Kalmykia, where livestock and the oil industry are the main sources of income for its people.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT NOT MULLING 3RD SCIENCE-BASED INDUSTRIAL PARK

TEXT.P: The government has no plans to build a third science-based industrial park, Huang Chen-tai, chairman of the National Science Council, said on Thursday.
Huang made the remarks while fielding questions during a legislative committee.

Legislators said that the Tainan Science-based Industrial Park, the second industrial park following the Hsinchu park, still is experiencing problems and therefore the government should not consider building a similar park at this time.

Huang noted that the building of a third park will depend on a lot of conditions, which he said included foreign and domestic economic conditions and the manufacturers' assessment of the prospective development of their industries.

Huang said that if the Tainan Science-based Industrial Park turns out to have excellent results, and high-tech manufacturers experience difficulty in acquiring land for expansion, then it would be prudent to consider building a third park.
The Tainan industrial park currently has a sixty percent occupancy rate. (By Lilian Wu) EDNITEM ZCZC CEP008 04-22-99 TODAY IN HISTORY

Taipei, April 22 (CNA) Today is Thursday, April 22, or the seventh day of the third month of the Year of the Rabbit according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
