1724: Immanuel Kant, German idealist philosopher and one of history's greatest thinkers, is born. He argued that reason is the means by which the phenomena of experience are translated into understanding. His classic works include "Critique of Pure Reason" and "Critique of Practical Reason."
1870: Vladimir Ilich Lenin, Russian leader of the Bolshevik Revolution and first leader of communist Russia, is born.
1904: Robert Oppenheimer, American nuclear scientist who developed the atom bomb, is born.
1915: The Germans use poison gas for the first time on British troops on the Western Front in World War I.
1944: Allied forces land on Dutch New Guinea.
1947: Wei Tao-ming becomes governor of the newly established Taiwan Provincial Government.

1951: The first contingent of officers from the US Military Assistance Advisory Group (MAAG) in Taiwan, arrives in Taipei. US Maj. Gen. William C. Chase, the first MAAG chief, arrives in Taipei later.
1956: Beijing appoints the Dalai Lama chairman of a committe to prepare Tibet for regional autonomy within communist China.
1961: The construction of the Taipei Chunghua Bazaar is completed with Gov. Chow Chih-jou of Taiwan Provincial Government presiding over the inauguration ceremony.
1969: American surgeons conduct the first human eye transplant.
1973: President Hammer de Roburt of the Republic of Nauru and his wife arrive in Taipei for a visit.
1974: A Pan American Airlines passenger plane crashes in Bali, Indonesia, killing 107 people.
1975: The first batch of Vietnamese refugees arrive on the western coast of the United States, as South Vietnam falls to the communists.
1980: SS Don Juan, a vehicle ferry, collides with a car float and sinks near Mindoro Island in the Philippines, killing some 1,000 people.

1984: Medical researchers working in the United States and France identify a type of human cancer virus that may be the causative agent in the killer disease Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndrome (AIDS).

1991: The second extraordinary session of the First National Assembly passes, at its sixth plenary meeting, the Additional Articles of the Constitution of the Republic of China and approves the abolishment of the Temporary Provisions Effective During the Period of Communist Rebellion.
1992: Gasoline leaked from a nearby refinery explodes in the sewer system of Guadalajara, Mexico, killing more than 200 and injuring over 600 others.
1993: The Legislative Yuan ratifies a 1989 ROC-US copyright agreement and passes amendments to the ROC's copyright law that go into effect April 26.
1993: Tonga's Prime Minister Baron Vaea and Madame Vaea visit the Republic of China.

1994: Former US President Richard M. Nixon dies of a stroke at the age of 81. He visited mainland China in 1972 and established detente with the USSR. When Congress recommended three articles of impeachment for Nixon's involvement in the Watergate scandal, he resigned from office on Aug. 9, 1974.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "When the rulers encourage education and good manner, the people are easily amenable to government."

DOC.HEADLINE: MAOIST INDOCTRINATION MAKES A COMEBACK IN MAINLAND CHINA
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 22 (CNA) (By Ben Wu) (By Stanley Cheung)

TEXT.P: Hong Kong, April 22(CNA): Mainland China's propaganda tsars have recently revived the Maoist ideological indoctrination campaign to face a series of highly sensitive anniversaries this year, the Hong Kong Standard reported today.
The Cultural Revolution-style political sessions have also recently made a comeback in the offices of party organs and government agencies, the report said.

Using a central leadership decision to launch a rectification campaign earlier this year, the party's propaganda department has recently asked all party cells within government agencies and army units to resume their regular political sessions, according to the report.
The move, it added, marks the implementation of the decree by President and party chief Jiang Ze-min on the so-called "three talks" to strengthen ideology in officialdom.
Jiang has recently asked cadres to "talk more about politics, about morality and about learning".

Using Jiang's instruction, the party Central Committee's Propaganda Department has issued internal documents ordering party cells in central agencies to resume the Maoist-style ideological indoctrination campaign of "criticism and self-criticism".
Propaganda tsar Ding Guan-gan has asked cadres to conduct e "face-to-face and back-to-back" indoctrination during the political sessions, the report quoted sources as saying.
"Face-to-face" refers to the practice of criticizing each other by party members, while "back-to-back" means self-criticism.
The sources said it was the most intense ideological indoctrination campaign since 1989.

Liberal officials reportedly said the conservatives were using the leadership's concerns about a string of politically sensitive anniversaries to upgrade the leftist campaign to consolidate their power base.

The mainland has seen several sensitive anniversaries pass quietly. March marked the 10th anniversary of imposition of martial law in the Tibetan capital Lhasa and the 40th anniversary of Tibet's god-king, the Dalai Lama, fleeing his Himalayan homeland to exile in India after an abortive uprising against communist rule.

Last week also marked the 20th anniversary of the Communist Party decision to crush the Democracy Wall movement in the same month. It was also the 10th anniversary of the death of reform-minded Communist Party general secretary Hu Yaobang, whose death sparked student-led demonstrations for democracy.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA'S CHICKEN INDUSTRY STRUGGLING WITH DISEASE
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 22 (CNA) (By Ben Wu) (By Stanley Cheung) (By Peter Chen)

TEXT.P: Canberra, April 22 (CNA): Australia's chicken meat industry is waging an uphill battle to contain an outbreak of a virulent mutation of Newcastle disease as the number of slaughtered birds surged to 1.5 million.
The outbreak, which the industry described as different from that of the endemic virus in mainland China and Hong Kong years ago, is the worst-ever in Australia's chicken meat industry.
While the slaughtering of birds continues the disease has spread to 30 farms from the original three farms in the Mangrove Mountain Ridge area in New South Wales.

The 1.5 million slaughtered birds account for only a fraction of the 300 million birds processed each year with a gross value of about US$790 million. The industry employs more than 16,000 people across Australia.
The sources from the industry said the disease does not present a health risk to consumers.

Australia's chicken meat exports, mainly to Asian and European countries, have grown steadily in recent years with sales totaling about US$32 million in fiscal 1997-98, according to the industry sources.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINA OBTAINS WEAPON INFORMATION PARTLY FROM SPYING: CIA
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 22 (CNA) (By Ben Wu) (By Stanley Cheung) (By Peter Chen) (By Nelson Chung)

TEXT.P: Washington, April 21 (CNA): Mainland China obtained at least basic design information on several US nuclear weapons including the W88 miniaturized nuclear warhead and neutron bomb, and its weapons technical advances were due partly to espionage, according to a Central Intelligence Agency report submitted to the US Congress Wednesday.
CIA Director George Tenet also briefed congressional intelligence committees Wednesday on the intelligence report assessing the implications of mainland China's acquisition of US nuclear secrets.

Unclassified findings of the CIA report noted that the full extent of weapons information acquired by Beijing could not be determined and it is not sure whether any weapon design documentation or blueprints were obtained. It was not known whether China had shared with other countries classified nuclear weapons information it obtained from the United States.

But US intelligence officials believed that mainland China probably used US design information as reference for its own weapons development program, instead of duplicating American weapon designs, said the report.

It confirmed that mainland China obtained at least basic design information on several US nuclear weapons, including the Trident II W88 nuclear warhead, as well as information on a variety of American weapon design concepts and features, including those of the neutron bomb.

The CIA report said Beijing has had the capability to develop a multiple nuclear warhead system for its intercontinental ballistic missiles for many years, but it has not done so. The US secrets it acquired might help Beijing develop a multiple nuclear warhead for a future mobile missile.

Mainland China's weapons technical advances were due not only to espionage, but also to contact with scientists from other countries including the United States, conferences, publications, media disclosures, declassified US weapons information and to Beijing's own research, added the report.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING'S UNFRIENDLY GESTURES UNDERMINE CROSS-STRAIT TIES: MAC

TEXT.P: Beijing's repeated, unfriendly gestures toward Taiwan are not conducive to improving ties between Taiwan and mainland China, said Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Vice Chairman Lin Chung-ping on Thursday.

Lin said Taipei has been consistent in its position on welcoming a visit to Taiwan by Wang Daohan, chairman of the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS) and mainland China's top negotiator with Taiwan. And Taipei has proposed that officials from its Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) visit the mainland to make preparations for the visit, he added.

Lin discounted a recent report by the pro-Beijing Hong Kong daily "Wen Wei Po" which said that Taipei has been turning a deaf ear to Beijing's calls for preparatory arrangements for a SEF-ARATS dialogue. He also rejected claims SEF has not responded to ARATS' proposals to jointly organize cross-strait forums and seminars.

The "Wen Wei Po" report also quoted ARATS officials as saying that it is meaningless and inappropriate for SEF to send any of its officials to the mainland now for talks on Wang's proposed Taiwan visit since SEF has been reluctant to cooperate with ARATS on efforts to improve exchanges between the two intermediary bodies.
Lin said Beijing's high-handed attitude toward Taipei will only boomerang, adding that the more Beijing attempts to pressure Taiwan, the more alienated Taiwan's people will feel from mainland China.

If Beijing is indeed serious in its intention to communicate with Taipei, it should not attach preconditions to talks between the two sides, as it has in the past and continues to do now, Lin said. Instead, Beijing should try to win the hearts and minds of the people living in Taiwan, he said.

Lin said Beijing is a master at attempting to manipulate cross-strait talks by attaching preconditions and by raising the stakes. Beijing has taken a tougher stance toward Taiwan since the third quarter of last year, he said, adding that the change in attitude came at a time when mainland China seemed unable to hold its currency to a stable 8-1 ratio against the US dollar, when economic reforms were slowing down and when social unrest was on the rise.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATORS ASSURED OF US SUPPORT FOR TAIWAN
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 22 (CNA) (By Deborah Kuo) (By Nelson Chung)

TEXT.P: Washington, April 21 (CNA): Members of the visiting Legislative Yuan delegation from Taipei were told Wednesday by US Congressional leaders that the recent visit of mainland Chinese Premier Zhu Rongji to Washington has not caused any damage to the interests of Taiwan, and that the US remains committed to the safety and security of Taiwan.

House Republican Whip Tom Delay (R-TX) told Yao Eng-chi, leader of the delegation, that Taiwan's national interests have not been compromised due to Zhu's visit, and that things would go smoothly if both Taipei and Beijing can join the WTO at the same time, although Taiwan is more qualified than mainland China to enter the world trade body.
Delay said the United States remains committed to providing Taiwan with weapons necessary for its safety and security.

Sen. Craig Thomas (R-WY), chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Subcommittee on Asia and the Pacific, also said that US congressional support for Taiwan has not diminished, and that the US will continue to help Taiwan defend itself.

Thomas said he has a hunch that Washington will reach an agreement with Beijing on the latter's admission to the WTO within this year. He expressed the hope that Taiwan will be able to enter the WTO at the same time.
The senator also expressed the hope that the two sides of the Taiwan Strait will resolve their differences peacefully over time.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIAN LNG INDUSTRY CALLS FOR REFORMS TO LURE ASIAN BUYERS
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 22 (CNA) (By Deborah Kuo) (By Nelson Chung) (By Peter Chen)

TEXT.P: Canberra, April 22 (CNA): The petroleum industry has called on the Australian government to remove impediments to developing major new liquefied natural gas (LNG) projects in an attempt to compete with major LNG exporting countries to win buyers from Asia.
The urge was made by executive director Barry Jones of the Australian Petroleum Production and Exploration Association (APPEA) when he spoke at the association conference in Perth on Wednesday.
He said Australia could easily grab up to 30 percent of the Asian imports if the current impediments, such as those in customs treatment and project approvals, can be removed.

DOC.HEADLINE: ASIAN FUND MANAGERS BUYING AUSTRALIAN STOCKS
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 22 (CNA) (By Deborah Kuo) (By Nelson Chung) (By Peter Chen) (By Peter Chen)

TEXT.P: Canberra, April 22 (CNA): Asian fund managers are in a buying spree at the Australian stock market due to the strong economy here, market analysts said.

The buying spree has caused the All Ordinaries Index to surge to record highs in the past several days, except for Wednesday, when investors sold some of their profits, analysts said. The index closed at 3068.3 on Wednesday, down 21.7 points from Tuesday's close.

The survey, based on interviews with 35 funds management companies in the region, highlights some interesting insights into Asian views of the Australian share market, according to the Australian Financial Review on Thursday.
The survey shows that the five most popular sectors for Australian investment by Asian fund managers are telecommunications, banking and finance, transport, insurance and utilities.

DOC.HEADLINE: SINGAPOREANS UPBEAT ABOUT ECONOMY
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 22 (CNA) (By Deborah Kuo) (By Nelson Chung) (By Peter Chen) (By Peter Chen) (By Sherman wu)

TEXT.P: Singapore, April 22 (CNA): After months of gloom and doom, Singaporeans are far more upbeat about the economy now than in December of last year.
They are also more secure about keeping their jobs and boosting their financial positions in the next three months.

Reflecting this surge of optimism, the new Consumer Confidence Index (CCI), launched by The Straits Times last December, registered a staggering 137-point jump for the first three months of this year.
With a base of 100, the index value leapt to 237.

Developed with the Nanyang Technological University, the CCI is derived from quarterly polls of Singaporeans' confidence in the country's economic prospects, price movements, financial position and job security.

The survey was conducted by the Marketing Planning and Development Department of Singapore's Press Holding on March 30-31 by polling 407 Singaporeans and permanent residents aged 20 years old and above.
It found that about a third of those polled now think the economy will be in better shape over the next three months, with just 15 per cent predicting worse conditions.

DOC.HEADLINE: EARTH DAY NETWORK LAUNCHED
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 22 (CNA) (By Deborah Kuo) (By Nelson Chung) (By Peter Chen) (By Peter Chen) (By Sherman wu) (By David Wang)

TEXT.P: New York, April 21 (CNA): Earth Day Network, the international organization coordinating Earth Day 2000 events, is launching its Worldwide Campaign on Earth Day tomorrow at UN Headquarters in New York City.

Denis Hayes, chair of Earth Day Network, will join decision makers including Bill Richardson, U.S. Secretary of Energy, Klaus Toepfer, Executive Director of the UN Environment Programme, and Jocelyn Dow, Acting President of the Women's Environment and Development Organization, in announcing plans for a year of action on energy and other critical environmental issues.
Hayes organized the first US Earth Day in 1970 and headed the first international Earth Day in 1990, which involved 200 million people in 141 countries.

The Earth Day Network Worldwide Campaign for Earth Day 2000 will connect environmental advocates worldwide, creating a unique global network that will launch campaigns on energy, global warming and other critical environmental issues.

DOC.HEADLINE: JAPAN, MAINLAND CHINA TREMBLE AS SMALLER NATIONS START TO RECOVER

TEXT.P: The economies of both Japan and mainland China are starting to tremble as the smaller economies of Thailand and South Korea are beginning to recover, according to The Australian Financial Review on Thursday.

Asia business editor Peter Hartcher in an analytical article titled "When Strong Nations Start to Tremble" reported that Thailand is expected achieve zero-percent growth while South Korea's economy will grow by 2 percent.
Hartcher said the real Asian economic crisis is slow and not necessarily obvious, though much bigger in scale and more severe in its consequences.
"This crisis is less like a volcano and more like continental drift -- you don't necessarily notice it as it's unfolding, but eventually it rearranges the world," he said.

He said the economies of both Japan and mainland China dominate Asia's economic landscape. Japan now accounts for fully 70 percent of the economy of Asia, while mainland China accounts for another 15 percent.

The difference between the two big Asian economic powers from the smaller ones is that Japan and mainland China do not depend on the rest of the world to finance their economies, because both countries run large current account surpluses, giving them relative immunity from the whims of foreign investors.
But if the two economies should begin to falter as smaller economies begin to recover, it could have a serious effect on Asia's economic future, according to the paper.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S WORK WEEK SHRINKING

TEXT.P: The average number of hours worked per week in Taiwan's non-agricultural sector stood at 44 last year, down 0.8 hours from the preceding year, according to the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS).
DGBAS statistics released on Thursday indicated that compared with 10 years ago, the average number of hours worked per week has fallen by 2.7 hours.
The decrease was mainly attributed to the introduction of a bi-monthly five-day work week by the government and some other private enterprises last year.
In the manufacturing sector, Taiwan's work week averaged 45.7 hours in 1998, higher than Hong Kong's 43.8 hours, but lower than Singapore's 49.5 hours and South Korea's 47.8 hours.
The average work week for American and European workers last year was 40 hours, the DGBAS said.

DOC.HEADLINE: WATCH CENTER FILES CITIZEN'S SUITS AGAINST 5 LOCAL GOVERNMENTS

TEXT.P: The newly formed Taiwan Watch Center filed "citizen's suits" against five local-level governments on Thursday in protest of their failure to take effective measures to improve air quality.

This was the first time that such a suit has been filed with the Administrative Court since an amendment bill to the Air Pollution Control Law cleared the legislature last year. The revised anti-air pollution law legalizes the "citizen's suit" system for the first time in Taiwan.

Liu Ming-lung, secretary-general of the Environmental Quality Protection Foundation (EQPF) said the Taiwan Watch Center has filed the suits as part of the celebrations of the 29th anniversary of World Earth Day, which fell on Thursday.
The Taiwan Watch Center was formed by the EQPF earlier this month to oversee government enforcement of all environment-related laws or regulations as well as detect Taiwan's environmental woes.

The "citizen's suits" were filed against the Taipei County Government, the Hsichu County Government, the Taichung City Government, the Taichung County Government and the Yunlin County Government for different reasons, Liu said.

The Taipei County Government, the Taichung county Government and the Taichung City Government were sued mainly because garbage incinerators have emitted excessive amounts of poisonous dioxin for many years.
Liu said the three local-level governments should immediately draw up concrete measures to reduce their dioxin emissions to meet standard levels scheduled to take effect in 2001.
The "citizen's suit" against the Hsinchu County Government was filed in response to complaints from county residents that Ta-An Aluminum Co. has consistently emitted smelly exhaust fumes.

Liu said the Hsinchu County Government should ordered the company to suspend operations and should not allow the company to resume operations until its air pollution control facilities have been improved to meet government requirements for exhaust emissions.
Meanwhile, the Yunlin County Government was sued because two major gravel factories in the county have not installed any air-pollution control facilities.

Under the new anti-air pollution law, the relevant local governments should adopt effective measures to improve the air pollution situation within 60 days after the Administrative Court metes out a verdict.
Liu said if the five county and city governments fail to take actions, their chiefs and related government officials will face charges of dereliction of duty.

Liu said the introduction of the "citizen's suit" is expected to gradually change the direction of domestic environmental protection drives. "If environmental officials at various levels fail to strictly enforce environmental protection laws and regulations, they will likely have to spend most of their time in courtrooms rather than in their offices."

In related news, more than 30 legislators from both ruling and opposition parties have thrown their support behind a draft bill calling for inclusion of the "citizen's suit" provisions to all environment-related laws or statues.
At present, only the anti-air pollution law has "citizen's suit" provisions.

"We hope all other environmental laws, such as the environmental impact evaluation statue, the anti-water pollution law, the noise control law, the toxic waste disposal law and the hazardous chemicals disposal law, will include the 'citizen's suit' provisions to push government authorities to tighten law enforcement and thus improve our living environment," said Legislator Chao Yung-ching, who initiated the amendment of the anti-air pollution law to introduce the "citizen's suit" system.

DOC.HEADLINE: WRECKAGE OF MISSING HELICOPTER FOUND ON TAIPEI COUNTY HILLTOP

TEXT.P: The wreckage of a commercial helicopter and the remains of three crewmen that disappeared Wednesday morning were found Thursday afternoon in a mountainous area in Juifang, Taipei County, said members of a rescue crew.
A rescue helicopter spotted the wreckage in a swath of scorched brush on a 757-meter high hilltop in Juifang.

The rescue helicopter was unable to land at the scene, though the crew did spot the charred remains of two bodies near the wreckage after circling around. They did not find any sign of the copter's third crewman.

Daily Air flight B5550 took off from Taipei's Sungshan Airport at 10:18 a.m. Wednesday. Bound for the eastern city of Taitung, the copter was to be used on a service between Taitung and offshore Orchid Island.
Sungshan Airport's flight control center lost contact with flight B5550 about 10 minutes after its takeoff.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN ECONOMY RECOVERING: BUSINESS COMMUNITY

TEXT.P: As Taiwan's export sector and its stock market have shown signs of improvement, local business leaders said unanimously on Thursday that the local economy is recovering.

Chinese National Association of Industry and Commerce Chairman Jeffrey Koo, Chinese National Federation of Industries Chairman Kao Chin-yen and General Chamber of Commerce of the Republic of China Chairman Wang You-theng all said that the Taiwan's economy is expected to recover after having bottomed out.

Although the financial problems of some local enterprises have not been fully resolved, Kao said, Taiwan's economy has shown signs of improvement in the first quarter of 1999 as orders for both the local and foreign markets have increased in the first three months of the year.

S.T. Tai, chairman of the Taiwan Small Business Association, also opined that the local economy has been stably gaining momentum since export orders and the stock market started rising at the beginning of the year.
Tai, however, called on Taiwan firms to closely watch developments in the mainland Chinese, Japanese and South Korean markets and to upgrade their industrial levels at the same time.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP PRESIDENTIAL HOPEFUL STRESSES IMPORTANCE OF NATIONAL SECURITY
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, April 21 (CNA) (By Jay Chen and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Former Taipei Mayor Chen Shui-bian stressed the importance of safeguarding Taiwan's security in a speech delivered to a Washington-based Taiwanese association on Wednesday.

Chen, who is widely believed to seek the main opposition Democratic Progressive Party's (DPP's) nomination to run in Taiwan's next presidential election, said those in power are obligated to avoid unnecessary sacrifice of lives and financial losses.

In the face of mainland China's persistent military threat, Chen said Taiwan should tread the "middle of the road" to avoid an outright confrontation with communist China and ensure the island's sustained development and dignity.

Chen said he has advocated a new "middle of the road" concept with an aim to curb an outbreak of any ethnic conflicts on the island while pursuing "composite security" in military, economic, political, social and energy fields as well as Taiwan's security under regional and global strategy.
As the two sides of the Taiwan Strait lack mutual trust, chen said he looks forward to see the two sides establish a military dialogue mechanism to boost transparency in military information.
Under such a mechanism, Chen said, the two sides can inform each other of their military exercise plans and exchange visits by their military officials.

The DPP has been widely seen as a pro-Taiwan independence party. During his three-day visit to the US capital, Chen has tried hard to allay US policymakers and advisors' suspicion of his party's stances on relations across the Taiwan Strait and on Taiwan's future status.
Chen stressed that both the DPP and he himself will respect the common wish of Taiwan people concerning the island's future.

Over the past three days, Chen has met with seven senators and five congressmen as well as China hands with five noted Washington-based think tanks. Chen is also believed to have met with several American officials in charge of Asian-Pacific affairs.

During those meetings, Chen reportedly has repeatedly expressed his concern about Taiwan's security, urging his American hosts to continue supporting legislative bills related to Taiwan's security and well-being. Chen reportedly also has exchanged views with his American hosts on Taiwan's bid to join the World Trade Organization and the feasibility of the island's participation in the US-proposed theater missile defense (TMD) system.
Chen said his Washington visit is mainly aimed at increasing mutual understanding and getting rid of misunderstanding.
Chen arrived here on Sunday and he will travel to New York on Thursday to continue his "journey of learning" designed to boost his presidential bid.
Chen's global "journey of learning" already took him to Japan, South Korea and Mongolia to increase his contact with foreign politicians.

DOC.HEADLINE: ECONOMIC PROSPECT INDICATOR SHOWS YELLOW-BLUE LIGHT FOR MARCH

TEXT.P: In light of a better export performance and a continuing infusion of public investments, Taiwan's economic prospect indicator showed a yellow-blue light again for March, according to government figures.

The Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) is scheduled to publish next Tuesday its economic prospect indicator for March 1999. Taiwan's composite economic indicator for March is expected to score a figure between 17 and 18, which is about the same figure as in the previous month.

Generally speaking, the economic prospect indicator is ahead of actual economic performance by one month. A yellow-blue light for March together with no breakthrough in Taiwan's composite economic performance means that the economic situation in April will be much the same as it was in February.

In other words, Taiwan's economy has not bottomed out and begun recovering yet. A resurgence is expected to be evident after May, when a stable economic upturn will be seen in both Taiwan's economy and in those of its Southeast Asian neighbors, said CEPD officials.

Southeast Asian countries will increase their imports from Taiwan after their economies experience a stable resurgence. In addition, the United States' economy is expected to remain robust, at least for the near future, and this will also benefit Taiwan's exports.

Taiwan's economic performance has also been helped by the Executive Yuan's program to expand domestic demand. With an inflow of private investment, including the construction of a high-speed railway and a power plant, economic recovery in Taiwan is certain, CEPD officials said.

As for the CEPD's individual indicators, the industrial product index's annual growth rate rose to 7.9 percent, resulting in a green light; the growth rate in exports after clearing customs rose to 8.5 percent, resulting in a green light; and annual growth rate in new orders for manufacturers may rise by 6 to 10 percent, resulting in another green light.

Taiwan's product inventory rate is expected to weigh in at 68 percent to 72 percent, resulting in a yellow-blue light, non-agricultural employment is expected to increase 1 percent to 2 percent, while its indicator light will remain unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: CEPD HEAD LEAVES FOR VIETNAM

TEXT.P: Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) Chairman P. K. Chiang left on Thursday for Vietnam for a private visit.

In addition to attending the annual conference of the Taiwan Businessmen Association in Vietnam, the CEPD head said he will also take part in seminars sponsored by Taiwan business people based in that country in a bid to gain an understanding of Vietnam's investment climate. Currently, there are around 500 Taiwan businessmen with operations in that southeast Asian country.
M. F. Yeh, director of the CEPD's Economic Research Department, and Y. T. Liao, a member of the department, accompany Chiang on the tour.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCK, FUTURES RISE

TEXT.P: Taiwan share prices closed 0.3 percent higher on Thursday, as bargain-hunting following a steep fall in the previous session triggered a slight upward surge.
The benchmark Taiwan Stock Exchange Weighted Price Index rose 20.44 points to close at 7,494.60 points.
Trade on Thursday saw a total of 3.08 billion shares change hands on a turnover of NT$105.90 billion (US$3.23 billion), down from NT$149.11 billion in the previous session.

Among the eight major stock categories, the financial sector posted the largest gains of the day, rising 0.9 percent. It was followed by plastic and chemical shares, which climbed 0.6 percent, while electronics stocks gained 0.5 percent.

Cement shares dropped the most at 2 percent, and foodstuff issues posted a 1.1 percent decline. Constructions stocks went down 0.5 percent, and paper and pulp shares 0.3 percent. The textile sector remained static.
The over-the-counter market registered a slight decline of 0.6 points, closing at 173.62 points, with a turnover of NT$5.96 billion.
TAIEX Capitalization Weighted Price Index Futures (TAIEX Index Futures) for May rose 31 points to close at 7,590 points, with 4,262 contract transactions.
Thursday was the last trading day for April futures, while futures for March 2000 were added to the market.

TAIEX Index Futures for June gained 49 points to close at 7,600, while those for September climbed 60 points, closing at 7,605 points. Contract transactions for the two months totaled 149 and 3, respectively.
December futures went up 42 points to close at 7,606 points, with 6 contract transactions. No transactions were registered for March futures.

Reference levels provided by the Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange for TAIEX Index Futures trading on Thursday were 7,559 points for May; 7,551 points for June; 7,545 points for September; 7,564 points for December; and 7,628 points for next March.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR DOWN

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar dropped NT$0.020 to the greenback on the Taipei market Thursday, closing at 32.795.
The local currency opened at 32.768, and was traded between 32.768 and 32.831.
The interbank US dollar trading reached US$487 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER REJECTS IMF'S PREDICTIONS OF LESS THAN 4 PERCENT GROWTH

TEXT.P: Republic of China Premier Vincent Siew rejected on Thursday a prediction by the International Monetary Fund that the ROC's economy would grow this year by less than 4 percent.

Premier Siew made the remarks after the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) presented a report to the Executive Yuan on its plan to strengthen Taiwan's economic structure.

Siew pointed out first-quarter indicators show that Taiwan's economy is recovering, while the Statistics Department of the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) has published a report on nine main economic indicators that also contain signs of economic recovery.

Taiwan's recent economic indicators -- including those for exports, industrial production, investments and the wholesale price index -- have all demonstrated constant gains, and plans to expand domestic demand have been carried out, Siew said, adding that are all signs of economic revival.

The MOEA's Statistics Department also presented a report on nine major indicators of the ROC's economic condition, including exports that have cleared customs and the stock market. According to the indicators, Taiwan's economy is now in the midst of a gradual upswing, and this year's economic growth picture looks positive.
According to the statistics, the annual growth rate of customs-clearing exports this year was 3.5 percent, much higher than original predictions of minus 5.4 percent.

Export orders grew from minus 5.6 percent in the fourth quarter of last year to 2.7 percent in the first quarter of 1999, while the annual growth rate of industrial production has returned to last year's standard level of more than 5 percent.

In view of this year's economic growth, Taiwan's leading semiconductor companies -- Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. and United Microelectronics Corp. -- have each added a NT$10 billion investment and have a predicted annual growth of 0.2 percent.
The number of companies that went out of business in January was down more than 10 percent -- the first time in 12 months that the figure has declined.

The Statistics Department pointed out that the local bourse finished at 7,474 points on Wednesday, an increase of 2,052 points, or a 38 percent, from its Feb. 5 level of 5,422 points. Meanwhile, daily turnover has advanced from NT$55 billion to NT$149.10 billion, which is another sign of a reviving economy.

DOC.HEADLINE: UN PLANS PEACEKEEPING MISSION DESPITE TEMPORARY PEACE IN E. TIMOR

TEXT.P: The United Nations is planning an emergency peacekeeping mission despite a peace deal reached between warring factions in East Timor after the visit of Indonesian armed forces chief Gen. Wiranto.

The Security Council has discussed the weekend's bloody rampage by Indonesian-sponsored militias in the former Portuguese colony in which at least 30 Timorese civilians and some pro-independence supporters were gunned down.

The Timorese political factions -- pro-independence and pro-integration groups -- on Wednesday signed a peace accord at a meeting brokered by Wiranto and Dili's Bishop Carlos Belo. But the hasty truce did not mention any surrender of arms between the warring factions.
UN Secretary-General Kofi Annan has asked that plans for a peacekeeping mission be developed in case violence in East Timor increases.
Political analysts and officials in Australia and other Western countries are unsure how long the truce will last as the UN-supervised vote to decide the future of East Timor in July draws near.

Indonesian President B.J. Habibie still insists that security in the territory is solely his country's concern, meaning Indonesian armed forces and police will continue to be stationed in East Timor even after autonomy is ensured in the July voting.

Under the UN plan, Australia is expected to play a significant role in sending a peacekeeping force to East Timor if warring factions resume their fighting and if pro-integration militias resume their bloody rampage in Dili and other cities, analysts said.
But senior UN officials said the peacekeeping troops would not fight the militias. Instead they would be used to maintain order either with the aid of Indonesian troops or in their absence.
Annan would first need to win Habibie's approval before the UN peacekeeping troops are sent to East Timor.

"So far, that agreement is not there, but we have to prepare for the possibility that the situation descends into complete chaos and Indonesia changes its mind on UN support," one senior UN official said.

DOC.HEADLINE: MALAWI MINISTER VISITING TAIPEI

TEXT.P: Malawi Finance Minister Cassim Chilumpha arrived in Taipei on Wednesday for a three-day visit.
While here, he will call on Foreign Affairs Minister Jason Hu, Foreign Minister Paul Chiu and other government officials. He will also visit cultural and economic establishments.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC VICE PRESIDENT MEETS WITH CHICAGO UNIVERSITY OFFICIALS

TEXT.P: Vice President Lien Chan met on Thursday with Dr. Gary Eppen, deputy dean of the University of Chicago's MBA school.

During the meeting, Lien told Eppen that Taiwan's healthy economic structure and the careful steps the government has taken have prevented Taiwan from being hard-hit during the global financial crisis.

Eppen, who is visiting Taiwan for the first time to promote exchanges and cooperation with local universities, provided Lien, a University of Chicago alumni, with an update about his alma mater. Lien is also on the university's board of directors.
Lien said that last year, Taiwan's economic growth reached 4.8 percent, the second highest in Asia, and he predicted continued growth this year.

Over the past few years, Taiwan's economy has been successfully transformed into a high-tech based economy, Lien continued, adding that the country's abundant skilled manpower has helped Taiwan to develop into a "technology island."
He went on to tell Eppen that the island's future development path lies in the fields of biotechnology, aeronautics, and precision mechanics.
Eppen expressed the hope that his visit will encourage more students from Taiwan to pursue higher education at his school.
Also present at the meeting was the university's Professor William Kooser, and president of Taiwan Shiseido Co. Ltd. Lee Kuo-hsiang, who is also an alumni of the university.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PRESIDENT MEETS WITH RUSSIAN SCHOLAR

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui received visiting Russian scholar Alexander Yakovlev on Thursday, and exchanged views with him on political and economic reforms.

Lee explained Taiwan's constitutional reforms of the past decade, including the abolishment of the Period of National Mobilization for Suppression of the Communist Rebellion, and the lifting of a ban on publishing newspapers and forming political parties.
He told Yakovlev that the ROC president is now elected by popular vote, and that the country can now be described as a completely democratic country.
Lee said that the people of Taiwan have overcome their past sorrows, and are now leading happy lives.
He said the ROC government is focusing its attention on judicial, education and spiritual reforms, with the aim of developing the island into a modern and civilized country.
Yakovlev said that Russia has not yet found the proper direction for its reforms, which is why his country's reforms have failed to produce satisfactory results.
Addressing the subject of nationalism, Yakovlev said he has written articles to express his opposition to nationalism, but added that his view is not accepted by the Russian authorities.
Lee said that during peacetime, there is no need to incite nationalism, but pointed out that mainland China has been encouraging nationalism with the intention of countering the world's big powers.
He described the Beijing move as "quite dangerous" and "unwise."

DOC.HEADLINE: COMPUTER GIANTS TO LAUNCH SOFTWARE JOINT VENTURE IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Taiwan's computer giant Acer and the world's largest business software designer, Computer Associates, on hursday inaugurated a joint venture to produce business software in Taiwan.
Acer Chairman Stan Shih, and Computer Associates' Chairman Charles B. Wang signed a memorandum on the as-yet unnamed joint venture at a ceremony in a Taipei hotel.
During the ceremony, Shih said that he hopes the new venture will change the perception of the island as a hardware rather than software manufacturer.
Taiwan is the world's third-largest semiconductor maker, but ranks only 23th in terms of software manufacture, said Shih.

The primary stage of the joint venture will see software designed by Computer Associates brought into Taiwan, and the long term, will focus on the development of financial management software for local small- and medium-sized businesses.

They will also cooperate with an accounting firm to design a computerized accounting system for local small- and medium-sized firms which is intended to run on a computer specially manufactured by Acer, said Shih.

DOC.HEADLINE: FAMILIES OF DEAD CHOPPER CREW TO RECEIVE NT$10.2 M COMPENSATION

TEXT.P: The families of three crew members killed in a Daily Air helicopter crash on Wednesday will each receive compensation of NT$10.2 million, a Daily Air executive said on Thursday.

Three hours after the bodies of the three crew were found at the crash scene in a mountainous area near the town of Juifang, Taipei County, an anonymous Daily Air executive said that the families of the dead pilot, co-pilot and a third crew member will get the same compensation as three other Daily Air crewmen who died in a similar helicopter crash last year.
Daily Air tried on Thursday afternoon to help the families of the dead get to the crash scene, but gave up as night fell on the rugged mountainous area.
A company executive said that they will take the families to the scene by helicopter on Friday.

Although the remains of the three crew members, as well as the cockpit voice recorder, have already been found, the rescue crew was ordered to leave them untouched pending on-site examinations by prosecutors and coroners.

Daily Air flight B5550 took off from Taipei's Sungshan Airport at 10:18 a.m. on Wednesday. Bound for the eastern city of Taitung, the chopper was to provide an air link between Taitung and Orchid Island, which lies to the east of the southeastern city.

Air controllers at Sungshan lost contact with flight B5550 about 10 minutes after takeoff, and a search helicopter spotted the wreckage of the craft at the top of a 757-meter hilltop on Thursday afternoon.
The accident has raised concern among legislators over the airworthiness and safety record of Daily Air, which has now lost two helicopters in as many years.
Legislator Tsai Huang-lang called on the Civil Aeronautics Administration on Thursday to ground the airline pending comprehensive safety checks.

DOC.HEADLINE: RAIDS ON CAMPUS CRIMINAL GANGS KICK OFF

TEXT.P: An islandwide sweep to purge schools of criminal organizations began on Wednesday night and continued into Thursday night, law enforcement authorities said on Thursday.

Police raided about 1,000 tea shops around the island popular with the nation's youth, billiard parlors, KTV bars and other sites where teenagers tend to congregate after school, in an effort to nab teenagers who have been recruited by criminal organizations.
More than 2,000 teenagers were ordered home after being reprimanded, fined or referred to the authorities for further investigation on suspicion of criminal activity, said the authorities.
The campaign was launched in line with government action to prevent the island's criminal organizations from expanding their influence onto school campuses by recruiting teenage students.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATORS TRYING TO PROHIBIT FOREIGN WORKERS FROM NEW SCIENCE PARK

TEXT.P: The Science, Technology and Information Committee of the Legislative Yuan on Thursday passed a resolution to forbid the under-construction Tainan Science-based Park from employing foreign workers.

The committee also adopted a resolution requiring the Hsinchu Science-based Park to reduce the foreign workers' share of the park's labor force from the current 6.5 percent to 3 percent within two years.
Despite lobbying efforts by the National Science Council (NSC), the two resolutions were adopted as a result of heavy support from the opposition Democratic Progressive Party and the New Party.
A shocked NSC Chairman Hwang Jenn-tai said that he would respect the resolutions, but added that the NSC will carry out the resolutions only if they comply with related laws.
Hwang expressed worry that the restrictions on employing foreign workers may affect the investment willingness of manufacturers in the two science-based parks.
The Hsinchu Science-based Park now has 72,000 employees, 4,700 of whom are foreign workers. The legislators passed the resolutions with the aim of protecting the interests of local workers.

DOC.HEADLINE: CBC GOVERNOR CALLS FOR FINANCIAL GLOBALIZATION

TEXT.P: Central Bank of China (CBC) Governor Perng Fai-nan said on Thursday that local banks should seek mergers with foreign banks and cultivate more talent in their workforces to achieve genuine globalization.
The CBC governor made the call while delivering a keynote speech at a seminar on the Asian financial crisis and restructuring of the shattered economies of the regions in the wake of the crisis.

Perng suggested that local banks jointly set up holding companies as a way of merging with foreign banks overseas. Under such a scenario, Taiwan-based banks would be able to extend their clientele from Taiwan businessmen abroad to local enterprises and individuals, he added.
Speaking on Asia's economic recovery, Perng said he believes that the worst of the region's financial woes have already passed.
Turning to the recent influx of foreign capital into Taiwan, Perng said the infusion of foreign funds has contributed noticeably to the recent rebound of the local currency.

DOC.TEXT:
