DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, April 23, or the eighth day of the third month of the Year of the Rabbit according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1616: William Shakespeare, English playwright and poet whose body of works is considered the greatest in English literature, dies at New Place at the age of 52. His plays include historical works, such as "Richard II"; comedies, including "Much Ado about Nothing" and "As You Like It"; and tragedies, such as "Hamlet," "Othello" and "King Lear." He also composed 154 sonnets.
1616: Miguel de Cervantes, Spanish writer who is best known for his classic satirical novel "Don Quixote," dies at the age of 69.
1873: The Dutch war against the Sultan of Achin begins in northwest Sumatra, Indonesia.
1895: Russia, Germany and France protest against the cession of Chinese territory to Japan.
1897: Lester Pearson, Canadian prime minister from 1963-1968, is born. He won the 1957 Nobel Peace Prize for his part in settling the Suez crisis.
1919: Peking Teachers High School for Girls is formally established.
1928: Shirley Temple Black, American child star who went on to become US ambassador to Ghana, is born. As Shirley Temple she was an immensely popular child actress of the 1930s, starring in films such as "Wee Willie Winkie" and "Bright Eyes."
1935: Joseph Stalin officially opens the Moscow underground rail system.
1945: US and Soviet forces meet at Torgau in eastern Germany.
1946: Hsia Kai-chun, noted writer in modern Chinese literature, dies in Shanghai at the age of 63.
1949: Government forces of the Republic of China evacuate Nanking.
1962: In the biggest-ever "ban the bomb" demonstration, some 150,000 people rally in London's Hyde Park.
1965: The Soviet Union launches its first communications satellite.
1965: President Charles de Gaulle of France emphasizes his opposition to the United States' Asian policies by pulling out French units from naval maneuvers held by the Southeast Asia Treaty Organization.
1969: A Los Angeles jury decides that Sirhan B. Sirhan should be sent to the gas chamber for the murder of Sen. Robert Kennedy in June 1968.
1975: US President Gerald Ford declares the Vietnam War is over as panic grips Saigon after its Cabinet resigns.
1985: The Industrial Technology Research Institute successfully develops an amorphous-silicon solar battery of high commercial value.
1986: National Taiwan University Hospital separates a pair of 14-day-old Siamese twins, saving the life of one of the girls. The twins set a record for being the youngest to be separated.
1990: American Professor Robert Polhill is released in Beirut after 39 months in captivity by Islamic fundamentalist groups.
1990: Li Peng, premier of mainland China, arrives in Moscow for a visit, becoming the most senior Beijing leader to tour the Soviet Union in 26 years.
1991: Tens of thousands of striking Soviet workers fill the streets in Minsk on the eve of the Communist Party plenum.
1997: After 26 days of occupation by rebel captors, Peru's government launches a sudden attack on the Japanese ambassador's residence in Lima, freeing 71 hostages. Three soldiers, one hostage and all 14 guerrillas die in the attack.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A wise and good man is one who sets himself seriously to order his conversation aright."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO AX TARIFFS BEFORE ENTERING WTO

TEXT.P: Taiwan is planning to make a major, across-the-board cut in its import tariffs in preparation for its admission to the World Trade Organization (WTO), sources from the Ministry of Finance (MOF) said on Friday.

The MOF will amend relevant statutes before September to ax import tariffs on 8,100 categories of commodities and goods from abroad. The cuts will be the largest ever in Taiwan's import history, MOF officials said.

The cuts will cost Taiwan an estimated NT$22.4 billion (US$683 million) in tariff revenues in the first year after its WTO admission, and a cumulative loss of NT$48.2 billion (US$1.47 billion) in the first four years after its admission, said Liu Rong-chu, director of the MOF's Department of Customs Administration.

The tariff reductions are also poised to lower Taiwan's average weighted import tariff from its current level of 8.25 percent to 7.55 percent in the first year after its WTO admission. The largest tariff reductions will be in the area of agricultural products, where tariffs are slated to be reduced from a 1997 average of 15.12 percent to 8.71 percent.
Reductions of the average weighted tariff on agricultural products would amount to 35.58 percent if a comparison were made between 1994 and 2004 tariff levels, Liu said.
As a result of the reductions, Taiwan's chicken, beef, citrus and grapes are expected to sustain the greatest impact with increased imports, he said.
Meanwhile, the average weighted tariff on imported industrial products will fall by 0.68 percent to 3.96 percent in the first year after Taiwan's WTO admission, he added.

Liu said Taiwan has completed bilateral consultations with the 26 WTO member countries that have asked for such talks, and other related talks and agreements necessary before Taiwan is admitted into the world trade regulatory body are expected to conclude before long.

Mainland China promised to make a major concession in regard to its import tariffs during Premier Zhu Rongji's visit to the United States in early April. That promise has helped push forward mainland China and Taiwan's bid to join the WTO, Liu said, adding that he is optimistic that Taiwan will be admitted before the end of this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: DOLPHIN FOUND GROUNDED ON CENTRAL TAIWAN BEACH

TEXT.P: A dolphin that became grounded on a beach in central Taiwan has been transferred to a fish pond, police reported on Friday.
The dolphin was first noticed by a police officer, surnamed Hsu, patrolling the beach around 7 a.m. The dolphin appeared listless and injured, Hsu said.
Hsu immediately called for help, and he and others carried the dolphin to a nearby saltwater fish pond.
Police said they have no idea how the 200-kilogram dolphin injured itself or how it lost its way at sea and ended up on the beach.

DOC.HEADLINE: DOMESTIC VIOLENCE NO LONGER A 'FAMILY AFFAIR,' MINISTER SAYS

TEXT.P: Domestic violence is no longer a family affair, with the establishment of the Domestic Violence Prevention and Control Committee under the Ministry of the Interior (MOI), Interior Minister Huang Chu-wen said on Friday.

At a ceremony marking the committee's inception, Huang said the organization would serve as a government arm for intervening in cases of domestic violence and abuse. Previously there was no legal authority for such intervention, he noted.

With the implementation of the Domestic Violence Prevention and Control Law late last year and the creation of the new committee, law enforcement agencies will no longer be barred from households in which violence and abuse are occurring, he said.

The committee, with 21 contracted commissioners, will commit itself to accomplishing 10 major tasks in the following year, including the improvement of relevant statutes in regard to the prevention and control of domestic violence, the establishment of a nationwide domestic violence prevention and control system and the creation of an alarm mechanism and an information databank, he added.

Meanwhile, Huang said, the MOI will ask the governments of Taipei, Kaohsiung and other cities and counties around the island to establish similar centers to help control domestic abuse and to eradicate domestic violence.
Taiwan society has recently witnessed an increase in domestic violence, including cases of children murdering their parents and parents abusing their children.

On Friday, another such case was reported, as a man was charged with killing his 69-year-old mother with a fruit knife before attempting to commit suicide. The man, who survived his self-inflicted knife wounds, said he killed his mother because of a quarrel over an inheritance, according to police.
A recent survey showed that between 11.7 percent and 35 percent of Taiwan's women are living under the threat of domestic violence.

DOC.HEADLINE: US LAWMAKERS WRITE PRESIDENT LEE ON TRA ANNIVERSARY

TEXT.P: More than 50 US senators jointly sent a letter to President Lee Teng-hui on the 20th anniversary of the enactment of the Taiwan Relations Act (TRA) to reaffirm US commitment to the security and well being of Taiwan.

Sen. Jesse Helms (R-N.C.), chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, presented a copy of the letter Wednesday to Vice President Yao Eng-chi of the Legislative Yuan, when he and 10 other legislators visited the Senate.

Among those who signed the letter were Senate majority leader Trent Lott (R-Miss.); Orrin Hatch (R-Utah), chairman of the Judiciary Committee; Frank Murkowski (R-Alaska), chairman of the Energy Committee; and Craig Thomas (R-Wyo.), chairman of the Foreign Relations Subcommittee on Asia and the Pacific.
More than 100 members of the US House of Representatives also wrote a similar letter to President Lee.

In March, 1979 the US Congress passed the Taiwan Relations Act and President Jimmy Carter signed it into law in the following month. The law, which provides a legal basis for the continuation of US relationship with Taiwan after the switch of diplomatic recognition from Taipei to Beijing on Jan. 1, 1979 , "represents the continued commitment of the American people to preserve a vital relationship with a long-standing ally," wrote the senators.

They noted that 20 years ago, no one could have predicted how successful this relationship would be. Over the past two decades, Taiwan has established an extraordinary record as a prosperous democracy.

Economically, Taiwan has grown to become the world's 15th-largest trading country and the seventh-largest trading partner of the United States. "Taiwan now shares its well-deserved prosperity with other nations through a variety of official and unofficial assistance programs," added the letter.

Politically, the senators continued, Taiwan has become a full-fledged democracy. Today the people on Taiwan enjoy the full exercise of political freedom, including freedom of speech, freedom of the press and the freedom to organize political parties. "Taiwan serves as the model of democracy in a region of the world very much in need of a good example."

"The people of Taiwan deserve the credit for these accomplishments, but it has been the Taiwan Relations Act that has allowed the United States to stand side by side with our friends on Taiwan as they have overcome numerous challenges and met with unprecedented success. We salute you and the people of Taiwan for your perseverance and your creativity in working with the United States through the unique diplomatic mechanism which is the Taiwan Relations Act," they wrote.

"The Taiwan Relations Act provides a special role for the Senate of the United States. For that reason, we are especially pleased and honored to extend our congratulations for a successful two decades of cooperation. As we continue to cooperate in the years ahead, please be reassured of our commitment so effectively expressed in the Taiwan Relations Act to the security, and the social and economic well being of Taiwan," said the senators.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC FOREIGN MINISTER TO VISIT MARSHALL ISLANDS

TEXT.P: ROC Foreign Minister Jason Hu will leave for the Marshall Islands on April 29 for a three-day visit aimed at further boosting relations between the two countries.
This will be Hu's first visit to the Marshall Islands since the Republic of China forged formal diplomatic ties with the North Pacific island nation last November.

Hu will head a large delegation, composed of legislators from various political parties, officials in charge of tourist, fishery and investment affairs, industry and business executives, and journalists, on his good-will visit.
During his stay there, Hu will attend a ceremony marking the 20th anniversary of the establishment of the Marshall Islands' constitutional autonomous government on May 1.

Hu will also meet with Marshall Islands President Imata Kabua, Foreign Minister Phillip Muller and other senior officials to exchange views on matters of mutual concern, including feasible ways to promote bilateral cooperation in various fields.

On May 1, Hu will sign agreements with relevant Marshall Islands officials on the promotion and protection of investment in each other's countries as well as on the exemption of double taxation on investors.
In addition, Hu will attend a ground-breaking ceremony for construction of an airport apron to be donated by the ROC.

George Jin-gou Chang, director of the East Asian and Pacific Affairs Department of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, told a news conference on Friday that the donation is aimed at helping the Marshall Islands boost its tourist industry.

Chang said the ROC will also donate three garbage trucks and 40 large dustbins to help improve the Marshall Islands' sanitary facilities. "Hu will present the donation on behalf of our government during his visit," Chang added.
Meanwhile, Hu will attend an earth-breaking ceremony for constructing the ROC's embassy in the Marshall Islands.
Noting that the Marshall Islands is rich in agricultural, fishery and tourist resources, Chang said Taiwan entrepreneurs are welcome to invest in that country.

"The Marshall Islands is eager to learn from our country's development experience and welcomes our investment," Chang said, adding that Hu and his mission will tour the Marshall Islands' tourist and fishing facilities during their stay.

The delegation will leave for the Marshall Islands via a chartered Far East Air Transport plane at 6 p.m. on April 29 and will make a stopover in Guam for refueling. The delegation is scheduled to return to Taipei at 6:30 a.m. May 2.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING STALLING OVER ARATS CHIEF VISIT: MAC OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: Mainland China is delaying a visit of Taiwan officials to arrange for a visit to Taiwan of the mainland's top negotiator with Taiwan, to the great disappointment of the Republic of China government.

Lin Chong-pin, vice chairman of the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC), who recently returned from an April 8-15 visit to the United States, said on Friday that it seems that mainland China wants to delay the trip and that the US shares the opinion that mainland China is stalling Wang's visit.

Lin noted that Taiwan has suggested to the mainland that Jan Jyn-horng, deputy secretary-general of the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF), lead a delegation to visit the mainland to exchange views on matters related to Wang's visit.

But he said that the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS), the SEF's Beijing-based counterpart, replied last week only that it is preparing for Wang's visit, and would like to invite SEF officials "at an appropriate time."
Lin noted that when SEF Chairman Koo Cheng-fu visited the mainland in October, Wang promised to visit Taiwan in spring this year.

Lin said the SEF had therefore planned to expect Wang in the spring. During deputy secretary general-level talks between the SEF and ARATS on March 18, the SEF invited Wang to visit Taiwan on April 29, or the sixth anniversary of the Koo-Wang talks in Singapore which helped establish the framework of cross-strait dialogue after a hiatus of nearly five decades.
But according to Lin, ARATS denied any agreement on a spring visit had been made, and suggested instead an autumn date.

Lin said that the SEF believes Wang's visit will be more significant if related discussions and arrangements can be completed before his arrival in Taiwan, and urged the mainland to consider the proposal seriously.

Touching on mainland China's claim that the so-called "Taiwan issue" cannot be postponed indefinitely, Lin said that the attitude is not conducive to positive cross-Taiwan Strait development, and added that during his recent meetings with US officials, they agreed with his views.

Lin further said that the mainland has long realized that the Taiwan issue is a long-term, complex and difficult one, and that it will be impossible to achieve unification in the short term, or to deal with it by force.

Lin also revealed that Taiwan has proposed a military mutual trust mechanism to the mainland, which has been rejected by Beijing. He noted that Taiwan hopes that there will be positive cross-strait exchanges, including exchanges of military personnel, exchanges of information on military exercises and more transparency with regard to military buildups.

DOC.HEADLINE: ABANDONMENT OF BABY GIRLS A SERIOUS PROBLEM IN MAINLAND CHINA

TEXT.P: The abandonment of baby girls by parents in mainland China is becoming a serious problem, and a former minister has called for society to address the issue, as the government seems unable to cope with, according to a report in The Australian.

Beijing correspondent Lynne O'Donnell quoted Peng Peiyun, a former minister of family planning who is now a vice chairman of the national legislature, as making the call in the government's official mouthpiece, The People's Daily. She said mainland orphanages were overflowing and unable to cope with the increasing number of daughters being given up by parents preferring sons, who can carry on the family name.

Swelling orphanages are just the tip of the larger problem of females being treated as commodities in mainland China, Peng said. There is also a burgeoning market of young women who are kidnapped and then sold into virtual slavery in rural areas.
The daily reported that in all its various guises, the abuse of mainland Chinese females is a modern manifestation of an archaic penchant of Chinese families to produce boys.
Peng said the number of daughters being abandoned has increased rapidly in recent years, while mainland social organizations are ill-equipped to deal with the problem.

In mainland orphanages, abandoned children -- mostly girls or children with disabilities -- now outnumber orphans. "The issue of abandoned babies has already become a social problem that cannot be ignored," she said.

The issue of abandonment is extremely sensitive in mainland China, particularly as it highlights widespread disregard for population control policies outside carefully supervised cities. But local officials can often be bribed to turn a blind eye to violations of the country's official one-child policy, the daily reported.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING, CANBERRA SIGN TOURISM AGREEMENT

TEXT.P: Australia has become the first Western country to be recognized by mainland China as an officially approved destination for holiday travel, and tourism promoters here expect it will lead to a significant boost in tourism to Australia.

Canberra and Beijing on Thursday officially signed a long-heralded tourism agreement through which Australia expects to gain substantial benefits after mainland Chinese authorities open the way for quantum leaps in in-bound tourism from mainland China, the Australian Tourism Commission (ATC) said.

Australian Tourism Minister Jackie Kelly on Thursday announced that the Australian and mainland Chinese governments had agreed to arrangements that would allow mainland Chinese nationals to travel to Australia for holidays.

Other countries receiving similar approved destination status (ADS) along with Australia are Singapore, South Korea, Thailand, Malaysia and the Philippines. But Australia is the first Western country to enjoy such status, ATC chairman Don Morris said.

DOC.HEADLINE: IOC'S BRIBERY SCANDAL BLAMED IN CANBERRA

TEXT.P: Organizers of the Sydney 2000 Olympic Games blamed the International Olympic Committee's (IOC) bribery scandal for a budget shortfall caused by lower-than-expected corporate sponsorship.
The organizers made the accusation at a meeting in which they unanimously approved a resolution that would give Prime Minister John Howard the right to open the Games.

Olympics Minister of New South Wales Michael Knight on Thursday laid the blame for the US$33 million sponsorship shortfall at the feet of the bribery scandal that has dogged the IOC over the past five months.
To make up for the budget shortfall, the Sydney Organizing Committee for Olympic Games has vowed to cut costs by US$48 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: MARCH JOBLESS RATE AT SINGLE-MONTH HIGH SINCE 1983

TEXT.P: Taiwan's unemployment rate stood at 2.84 percent in March, the highest jobless level for that month since 1983, the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) reported on Friday.

Due to the economic slowdown, and the seasonal factor -- which sees employees quitting their jobs and seeking new ones after the Chinese Lunar New Year, which usually falls in February -- both the unemployment and the broadly-defined jobless rate in March shot up to a new high, while the labor participation rate dropped to a new low, DGBAS officials said.

The broadly-defined jobless rate hit a record high of 4.37 percent in March. This rate refers to the unemployment rate plus long term unemployed who are not seeking employment. In this sector, 152,000 were out of a job in March, 5,000 more than the figure posted for February, and a 16-year March record.

Meanwhile, the number of people who lost their jobs in March because of workplace closure or business downsizing totaled 97,000, 3,000 more than the February figure, and a new March record since 1983, the officials noted.

On average, the labor participation rate was 57.52 percent in March, the lowest March level since 1982. The labor participation rate is the ratio of the working population to the population aged 15 and over.
DGBAS officials said they expected the unemployment rate to fall in April and May when the seasonal factor is traditionally at a minimum.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR UP

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar surged NT$0.074 to the greenback on the Taipei market Friday, closing at the day's high of 32.721.
The local currency opened at the day's low of 32.78. The interbank US trading reached US$466 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: CANADA DENIES BOMBING TARGETS IN YUGOSLAVIA

TEXT.P: Canada was annoyed Thursday by US officials airing an airborne combat video mistakenly identified as being Canadian in origin.
The video, taken from an attacking aircraft, centers on what NATO said is a Yugoslav army barracks surrounded by civilian buildings. A "smart" bomb then hits the target, destroying it.

Ottawa immediately denied the video was made by Canadian CF-18 fighter jets, as claimed by the Pentagon. US officials later admitted they had made a mistake; the attacking planes were from another, unidentified NATO country.
Canada considers it a breach of security to reveal the names of countries responsible for specific attacks.
"NATO guidelines are in fact not to divulge who has released weaponry," Canadian Defense Minister Art Eggleton said. "That's what we follow and that's what we believe to be the proper thing to do."
Canada has "a small pilot community, and we don't want them exposed to harassment or security problems" as a result of "being identified with any specific attack," Eggleton said.
It does not seem that Canada will formally protest the tape's release. According to Eggleton, Canadian officials were in "contact" with Pentagon officials soon after the tape was shown.

DOC.HEADLINE: SOCIAL ORDER, CRIME-FIGHTING IMPROVEMENTS SHOWING EFFECT

TEXT.P: A police briefing on city crime on Friday told Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou that the rotten social order of Taiwan's largest city is improving.

Police statistics reveal that more than 7,500 crimes of theft and robbery were reported in Taipei in the first three months of this year, down 800 cases from the same period of last year. 5,200 of the crimes consisted of motorcycle theft.

In terms of violent crimes such as homicide, assault and battery, 176 cases were reported during the three-month period, 130 of which, along with several similar previously unsolved cases were dealt with, according to the statistics.

Although the general crime rate declined, police said robberies still accounted for a major part of all the criminal activities that have threatened the lives and property of the city's residents. Most of these robberies were in the form of pedestrians being robbed by motorists, the police reported.

Responding to the report, Ma said that despite the evidence showing a significant decrease in crime, he believes that the real indicator of whether social order has improved comes from public opinion.
Only when Taipei's citizens really have a sense of safety can social order be regarded as having improved, said Ma.

In order to meet the demands of the mayor, the Taipei City Police Headquarters (TCPH) has formulated a package of anti-crime strategies including establishing systems of community policing, neighborhood watches, and crime prevention, TCPH officers said.
The strategies are designed to prevent crime, a key move in the maintenance of social order, and a special task force with this objective has been organized, the officers said.

DOC.HEADLINE: ADB WARNS OF RISKS AMID SIGNS OF RECOVERY IN ASIA

TEXT.P: The Asian Development Bank (ADB) made an optimistic projection of Asia's economic outlook for 1999 but also warned of "many, many risks" in its forecast.

"Most of the severely affected economies (in Asia) show signs of recovery, but the economic sectors do continue to deteriorate," said the bank's vice president, Peter Sullivan. He forecast Asia's economy will grow an average of 4.4 percent this year, up from last year's 2.6 percent.

During a speech at the National Press Club, Sullivan cited poor performance in the banking sector last year as one of the risks that could impede reforms in Asia. Unrecoverable loans, which account for 20 percent to 35 percent of sector portfolios in Indonesia, Malaysia and Thailand, displaced strong financial reform programs, he said.

Financial flows into the region are uncertain, Sullivan continued. He cited a prediction by the World Bank of further reductions in capital flows and of a more prolonged crisis in developing countries worldwide.

At the corporate level, these uncertainties make forecasting returns on investments difficult, he said. Conservative investment strategies therefore are likely to continue to restrain flows over the medium term, he added.

Another risk factor is the high degree to which today's global market is interconnected. Sullivan said the examples of Brazil and Russia, which have affected Asia's prospects, indicates that any unexpected slowdown in North America, Europe or Japan would reduce the chances of Asian economies increasing their exports and would further stall recovery.

Finally, he said the ADB's upbeat forecast assumes that Asian countries will press on with their own domestic reform efforts. That looks likely, "but it depends on political and social stability and continued commitment to reform," he stressed.

The human cost and environmental degradation are also worth policy makers' attention, he said. Rising unemployment, growth in the ranks of the poor and nearly poor, inflation that has bitten into real income and shrinking government budgets that include cutbacks on social services have all taken their toll, he said.
In rural areas, problems have been complicated by environmental disruption through increased deforestation and over fishing, he noted.
In Indonesia, school enrollment has sharply fallen, and if not reversed, the trend could create a lost generation of poorly educated workers. "That will hold back future growth," he warned.

DOC.HEADLINE: SINGAPORE OFFERS FREE Y2K HELP TO APEC MEMBERS

TEXT.P: Singapore is putting in place a scheme to help developing countries cope with the Y2K computer bug, Singapore Trade and Industry Minister Lee Yock Suan said at the opening of a Y2K symposium on Thursday.
From the middle of this year, training will be provided free of charge to any developing country in the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum which wants it.

Lee said it might already be too late for organizations to look for technical Y2K solutions, and that participants could be thinking about sharing plans to deal with domestic and cross-boarder problems.
Such planning would also reassure the public and avoid unnecessary panic, he said.

The two-day APEC Y2K symposium was focused on the cross-border impact of the millennium bug in key sectors such as telecommunications, financial services, customs, transportation and energy, as well as examining problems unique to small- and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs). It is being attended by more than 300 representatives from the 21 APEC countries.

Singapore expects all its key government systems and service providers to be Y2K-ready within the next 60 days, and all government agencies are finalizing contingency plans in case of unexpected disruptions.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAGAZINES CLOSED DOWN BEFORE "TIANANMEN ANNIVERSARY"

TEXT.P: The Beijing regime has shut down two liberal publications and has prohibited cadres from publicly expressing dissent in new measures aimed at stifling dissent ahead of the sensitive June 4 Tiananmen Square anniversary, the Hong Kong Standard reported Friday.
Another measure requires police permission for gatherings of more than 20 people, the report revealed.

It quoted a Beijing source as saying that the authorities had ordered the closure of two liberal magazines -- the Guanchawencong, (Observers' Digest) and Sansipinglun (Commentaries of the Three Thoughts).
Both magazines are regarded as a forum for liberal scholars to discuss various social issues.
The Guanchawencong is a publication of the state-run Economic Daily.
The Jiangxi-based Sansipinglun is an outspoken publication that addresses science and social issues.
According to the report, the closures are aimed at eradicating "unlawful publications."

It noted that the authorities were usually "lenient" toward these publications, which are enthusiastic in discussing social issues but stop short of touching sensitive subjects, such as the June 4 crackdown.

The report said the ban would be enforced only in the run-up to the June 4 anniversary and would be lifted in late summer when the country celebrates its 50th anniversary in a relatively festive political atmosphere.

"Apart from the closure of the magazines, a punitive system has also been established to prevent party cadres from publicly voicing dissent during the sensitive period around June," the report quoted another source in Beijing as saying.

According to an order from the central leadership, cadres face immediate dismissal from their posts for public statements of dissent. The order applies to all party organs and government offices, universities, think-tanks and other semiofficial institutions, the sources said.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLAND CHINA PREMIER'S US VISIT WILL NOT AFFECT TAIWAN'S INTERESTS
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, April 22 (CNA) (By Jay Chen and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: A visiting parliamentary group from the Republic of China said here on Thursday that mainland Chinese Premier Zhu Rongji's recent US visit has not affected Taiwan's national interests.
The delegation, headed by Legislative Yuan Vice President Yao Eng-chi, was composed of 11 legislators of different political stripes.

Legislator Shen Chih-hui, a member of the ruling Kuomintang, told a news conference at the Taipei Representative Office in Washington, D.C. that the delegation reached its conclusion after meeting with several congressional leaders, think tank researchers and officials of the American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) and the office of the US Trade Representative.

"After a two-day stay in Washington, D.C., we have reached the conclusion that Zhu's just-concluded US visit has neither undermined US commitment to Taiwan nor affected Taiwan's bid to join the World Trade Organization (WTO)," Shen said.

She pointed out that American officials had told the ROC delegation that the United States expects to complete bilateral talks with mainland China on terms for Beijing's WTO accession within the next few weeks.

As for Taiwan's WTO membership, Shen quoted American officials as saying that the United States will join forces with the 15-member European Union and Japan to push for Taipei and Beijing's simultaneous WTO entry.
Shen said this was the first time since its inauguration early this year that the ROC's Fourth Legislative Yuan has formed a group to visit the United States.

"This is mainly because we are concerned about possible adverse impact on Taiwan's security as a result of Zhu's US visit," Shen noted, adding that after extensive talks with American officials and lawmakers, the delegation members believe that US determination to maintain peace and stability in the Taiwan Strait has remained unchanged and its support for Taiwan's WTO bid has also not been weakened simply because of Zhu's visit.

Nevertheless, Shen said she does not think that Taiwan will be able to join the WTO ahead of mainland China. "Because of political factors, the most likely scenario is that both sides of the Taiwan Strait are admitted to the Geneva-based world trade regulatory body simultaneously," she predicted.
