DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN MINISTRY KEEPS CLOSE WATCH ON INDONESIAN SITUATION

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) is keeping a close watch on the situation in Indonesia as the Southeast Asian country will hold a parliamentary election on June 7, a senior ministry official said on Friday.
George Jin-gou Chang, director of the MOFA's East Asian and Pacific Affairs Department, made the statement at the ministry's routine weekly news conference.
Chang said with the election day approaching, the Indonesian situation has shown signs of increasing tension.

Stressing that the ROC government is concerned about the security of Taiwan business people and their families there, Chang said the MOFA and the ROC representative office in Indonesia have both been closely monitoring developments there.

Chang said Lin Shui-chi, new ROC representative to Indonesia, signed a memorandum of understanding with the Bandung police chief earlier this month on intensified protection of ROC expatriates' security. Bundung, a booming city in western Java, is a major Taiwan investment destination.
Chang said the ROC representative office has issued a warning to ROC expatriates residing in the Bandung area, urging them to heighten alert in order to protect their own safety.
Anti-ethnic Chinese riots broke out in many Indonesian cities last year, forcing the ROC to evacuate its expatriates from that country at one point.
Chang said the ROC representative office in Jakarta has made an overall review of its previous emergency relief measures and will make necessary improvements.

"The representative office has kept close contact with Taiwan trade associations in various Indonesian cities or areas as well as forges cordial ties with Indonesian law enforcement authorities and other related agencies," Chang noted.
He pointed out that the Indonesian situation generally remains stable at the moment, except for some remote areas where sporadic religious and ethnic conflicts have been reported.

If the situation there gets worse, Chang said the MOFA will call an inter-ministerial meeting to work out feasible measures to cope with the situation and ensure safety of all ROC nationals residing in Indonesia.

DOC.HEADLINE: CUSTOMS RATES ON 4,500 ITEMS TO SLASHED AFTER WTO ENTRANCE

TEXT.P: Vice Economic Affairs Minister Lin Yi-fu said on Friday that only 4,491 import items will be subjected to a large cut of customs rates after Taiwan joins the World Trade Organization (WTO).
Lin made the remarks while reporting on the government's pace in negotiations with WTO members seeking to enter the Geneva-based world trade regulatory body to a Legislative Yuan committee.

Brushing aside local media reports that customs rates on about 8,100 import items will be reduced following Taiwan's admission to the WTO, Lin said, deducting those import items whose customs rates have been already cut and those whose import duties need not to be adjusted, only 4,491 items are covered in that area. Over 3,400 of the 4,491 items are industrial goods, while the rest are agricultural products, he added.

Council of Agriculture (COA) Vice Chairman Ling Shiang-nung said the Taiwan's agricultural sector will suffer an estimated loss worth NT$34 billion (US$1.02 billion) in the first year after Taiwan is admitted to the WTO, and that the figure may rise to NT$54 billion in the sixth year. Products such as beef, chicken, grapes and oranges will be hardest hit, he added.

In a bid to minimize the impact of the WTO's membership on the Taiwan agricultural sector, Ling revealed that COA has allocated NT$21 billion in fund with an aim to help local farmers tide over the difficult time.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN LABOR BAN IN SIP SHOULD BE REASSESSED: CLA

TEXT.P: A ban on the employment of foreign laborers at the Tainan Science-based Industrial Park (SIP) might be an unfair labor practice and should be reassessed before its enactment, noted officials of the Council for Labor Affairs (CLA) Friday.

The Technology and Information Committee of the Legislative Yuan passed a resolution Thursday requesting the National Science Council (NSC) to establish a quota for the employment of non-high-tech personnel, and to ban the employment of foreigners in the Tainan SIP.

The resolution was passed on the grounds that the SIP manufacturers are subsidized by the government. In a supplementary resolution, the committee demanded the Hsinchu SIP cut its foreign labor to 3 percent from the present 6.5 percent within two years.
However, NSC Chairman C.T. Huang cautioned the Legislative committee's resolution might violate current law.

CLA officials said the question of whether there should be a ban or a quota for foreign laborers in the SIP, should be assessed by the foreign labor policy evaluation sub-committee of the Legislature. The evaluation sub-committee should take all factors into consideration prior to making a final decision. Factors involved are: domestic unemployment, economic development prospects and the condition of demand and supply for laborers in various sectors.
Such a decision, remarked officials, pertains to government policy. If a quota were placed on a particular sector, the issue of fairness must be discussed.

High-tech industries are permitted to employ foreign labor if they have investment of more than NT$200 million, officials pointed out, adding that the government is now considering upgrading the threshold to NT$500 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: BOOK EXHIBITION OPENS AT NTU

TEXT.P: An exhibition including books from the 15th through 18th century opened Friday at the National Taiwan University (NTU) library in Taipei.
Books by Spanish authors took a large part in the exhibition, while there are also a handwritten copy of Aesop's Fables in ancient French and a parchment book from the 14th century.

The books on display are the sole remaining copies in the world, officials of the university library said. The exhibition features books written by Spanish missionaries in Taiwan in the years between 1600 and 1800. These works provide a rare glance into the life and work of foreign missionaries, officials said
This is the first time that the university library has displayed in public its ancient book collection. The exhibition lasts until May 7.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN SPOUSES WANT NATIONALITY LAW BE REVIEWED

TEXT.P: An associaiton of foreign spouses in Taiwan on Friday welcomed a move by lawmakers asking the Council of Grand Justices to review whether Article One of the Nationality Law is constitutional.

The 79 legislators, led by Lai Ching-lin of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), on Thurday appealed to the grand justices to review the article, under which ROC citizenship is granted to children born to ROC men and foreign wifes, but not to those born in Taiwan to ROC women and foreign husbands.

The associaiton said that if the grand justices rule the article unconstitutional, then it should be annulled immediately, and made retroactive, meaning that childeren born to either ROC men and foreign wives or ROC women and foreign busbands would be entitled to ROC citizenship. (by Amanda Chang)

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SHARE PRICES RECLAIM 7600-POINT LEVEL

TEXT.P: Encouraged by Wall Street's overnight rally, Taiwan share prices on Friday soared 1.6 percent to close at 7,612.80, marking 11 consecutive weeks of gains, dealers said.
The Taiwan Stock Exchange weighted price index rose 118.20 points to reclaim the 7,600-point level on turnover of NT$149.998 billion (US$4.57 billion), with 4.59 billion shares changing hands.
Gainers led losers 382 to 69, with 48 unchanged.
Investors' interests were focused on textiles, paper, plastics, cement and steel shares while bargain-hunting for low-priced shares which were believed to have larger return on investment potential.
All the eight major stock categories gained with textile shares posting the largest rise of 3.9 percent.

Both cement as well as paper and pulp shares surged 3.3 percent, followed by chemical and plastic stocks, which climbed 2.5 percent, construction shares rose 1.8 percent, food stuff issues increased 1.6 percent and financial shares were up 0.9 percent.
Meanwhile, trading on the over-the-counter market also closed higher to finish at 176.22 on turnover of NT$6.419 billion.
Regarding trading on Taiwan's stock index futures, it opened and closed higher in Friday's session.
The TAIEX Capitalization Weighted Stock Index futures (TAIEX Index Futures) for May climbed 63 points to finish at 7,653, with 4,592 contract transactions.

The TAIEX Index Futures for June posted a rise of 70 points to close at 7,670, with 160 contract transactions, while those for September increased by 85 points to close at 7,661, with 14 contract transactions.
The TAIEX Index Futures for December also rose 98 points to 7,693 with 3 transactions were contracted. (by Amanda Chang)

DOC.HEADLINE: SEF PUSHES ARATS FOR ENVOY'S TAIWAN VISIT

TEXT.P: The Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) sent a letter to its mainland Chinese counterpart on Friday, proposing a new round of bilateral talks in mid-May on a planned visit by mainland China's top envoy, Wang Daohan, to Taiwan.

In a letter faxed to the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS), SEF also suggested the two sides continue negotiations on technical issues such as the repatriation of mainland Chinese hijackers and illegal immigrates and fishing disputes.
SEF urged the ARATS to respond to its proposal quickly as the two sides had already reached consensus earlier to hold a meeting on the above-mentioned issue later this month.
SEF and ARATS are two intermediary bodies authorized by Taipei and Beijing, respectively, to deal with two-way exchanges in the absence of formal contacts.
SEF Chairman Koo Chen-fu paid a historical Ice-melting visit to mainland China in last October, and ARATS Chairman Wang has promised to visit Taiwan this year to reciprocate Koo's visit.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN DELEGATION TO ATTEND APEC MINISTERIAL CONFERENCE

TEXT.P: A Taiwan delegation led by Minister of State Yang Shih-chien will attend a ministerial-level conference of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum from April 26-29 in New Zealand.
The meeting of ministers in charge of small- and medium-sized businesses (SMEs) is expected to work out a five-year action program to promote the development of SMEs.

Yang and his delegation, including Taipei's representative to New Zealand Frank Lin and John Ni, director-general of the Small- and Medium-Sized Business Administration under the Ministry of Economic Affairs, is slated to return on May 1.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAISUGAR OPENS PHALAENOPSIS PLANT IN COSTA RICA

TEXT.P: State-run Taiwan Sugar Corp. inaugurated a phalaenopsis plant in Costa Rica on Friday, with scores of ranking Costa Rican government officials attending the ceremony.

First-phase construction of the five-hectare compound was already completed, and completion of the second-phase construction is slated for June. The plant is expected to begin commercial production in 2001, with an estimated business turnover of NT$55 million (US$1.67 million) every year.
The Taisugar's Costa Rica phalaenopsis plant is the second of its kind abroad following the opening of a similar one in Vancouver, which was set up to meet the demand from the north American market.
Amid its diversification strategy, Taisugar has been eager to seek phalaenopsis production sites overseas as part of its bid to grab a larger share of the international flower market.

Meanwhile, the state-run unit is also considering to set up a phalaenopsis production plant in Macedonia as a way to venture into the vast European markets, a Taisugar executive said, adding that a group of Taisugar experts is scheduled to visit the Balkan state in May to study the feasibility.

In addition to phalaenopsis, Taisugar also cultivates a wide range of tropical flowers. Currently, Taisugar's phalaenopsis exports hit around NT$150 million every year, and it is planning to increase the figure to NT$800 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP PRESIDENTIAL HOPEFUL PREFERS TO KEEP TAIWAN'S STATUS QUO

TEXT.P: The Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) will maintain the status quo of Taiwan even it prevails in the 2000 presidential election, said Chen Shui-bian, the DPP's former Taipei City mayor on Thursday.

In a seminar with faculty and students at Columbia University, the front-runner for DPP's presidential nomination played down the possibility that Taiwan would change its approach toward Beijing if the pro-independence DPP becomes the ruling party.
Chen said the DPP, even if it wins the presidency, would rather keep the status quo than upset it.

Citing as proof the election in 1991 for the entire parliament's seats as well as the first popular presidential election in 1996, Chen said that Taiwan is a sovereign state rather than a part of the People's Republic of China as Beijing claims.

In order to quiet fears that the DPP would campaign to force a plebiscite over Taiwan independence, Chen said the odds are against a plebiscite given the lack of consensus among the political parties.

However, he claimed that any disruption of Taiwan's status quo, from a declaration of independence to Beijing's annexation of the island with force, should be done only with the sanction of the general public, adding that a plebiscite is a way to seek public opinion. However, he said whether a plebiscite should be used to fathom the people's political willingness needs more study.

As to an "interim accord" between Taipei and Beijing, which was called for by a US official, Chen said the exact meaning is far from clear and the distrust between Taipei and Beijing at this time preempts any mediation efforts.
Even the US advocacy of "Beijing not attacking Taiwan as long as Taiwan doesn't declare independence" is a vague idea filled with uncertainty, said Chen.

"Is Taiwan's presidential election a step on the path to independence? Was President Lee Teng-hui's US trip in 1995 a move betraying his attempt to split the motherland as Beijing claimed?" asked Chen.

Noting that according to a US Defense Department report, Beijing is expected to deploy 600 missiles across the Taiwan Strait by the year 2005, Chen said he doubted this conforms with the "no attack against Taiwan" concept.

Agreeing that normalizing Taipei-Beijing ties is a desirable goal, Chen said a breakthrough in direct postal, transportation and trade links is possible if both Taiwan and mainland China are admitted into the World Trade Organization this year, as membership will oblige both countries to open markets to each other and will therefore place Taipei and Beijing on a course of normalization.

In response to questions from the audience, Chen painstakingly explained that Taipei-Beijing ties are neither an international nor a domestic relationship. They are something not defined by conventional political science.
Thursday's seminar included China experts Professor Andrew J. Nathan and Donald S. Zagovia, professors of political science at Columbia University.

Chen made a pitch for his "new central line", referring to a shift toward the center of the political spectrum from the DPP's previous extreme idea of pressing for Taiwan independence during a speech at the Taiwan Association.
Although he has not yet officially declared himself a candidate for DPP's nomination, Chen is expected to eventually be the party's standard bearer in the 2000 presidential election.
His dominance over the field of DPP's presidential aspirants has virtually denied former DPP chairman Hsu Hsin-liang any chance.
Hsu has hinted that he might quit the party and run as an independent candidate if not nominated by DPP.
In Thursday's speech to about 800 Taiwanese in New York, Chen urged Hsu not to pull out of the DPP. Chen said the party can ill-afford a division in trying to win the presidential election.
Praising Hsu's contribution to the party and to the island's democratization, Chen also called for party supporters to join him in asking Hsu to remain in the party.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC ARMY SUCCESSFULLY FIRES MODIFIED HAWK MISSILES

TEXT.P: The Republic of China Army successfully fired its modified version of the Hawk missiles in a drill on Friday, the Army Headquarters said.
In a press release, the headquarters said that during the drill held at Chiupeng base, Pingtung County, southern Taiwan two missiles were fired and that both successfully hit their targets.

The Army said the missiles fired were modified versions of the third-generation Hawk which has been the backbone of the Army's air-defense system against invading low and middle level aircraft since 1964.
The modification of the Hawk started in 1995 and finished in 1997. Friday's test demonstrated that refurbishing program has greatly improved the nation's air defense capability.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies Saturday are as follows:
The Central Daily News:
US lawmakers write ROC President Lee Teng-hui on the 20th anniversary of the Taiwan Relations Act (TRA).
The China Times:
The main opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) mulls new stand on independence issue.
The United Daily News:
Self-paid medical bills under the National Health Insurance Program will be adjusted.
The Liberty Times:
US lawmakers write President Lee, reaffirming security commitment to Taiwan.
The Commons Daily:
New Tokyo Governor Shintaro Ishihara assumes office, vowing to break more rules.
The China Post:
The DPP caucus demands alleged brawling lawmaker's removal.
The China News:
Sweeping tariff cuts were announced.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Saturday, April 24, or the ninth day of the third month of the Year of the Rabbit according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1731: Daniel Defoe, British journalist, novelist and economist -- and the author of "Robinson Crusoe" and "Moll Flanders" -- dies at the age of 71.
1800: The US Congress votes to set up a congressional library.
1877: Russia declares war on Turkey.
1898: Spain declares war on the United States after receiving a US ultimatum to pull out of Cuba.
1919: Chan Tien-yu, a railway pioneer in China, dies in Hankou at the age of 59.
1941: Hsieh Chin-yuan, one of the Chinese heroes in the War of Resistance Against Japan, is assassinated and dies at the age of 37. The ROC Army regimental commander led his "800 Brave Fighters" in a heroic battle against waves of invading Japanese troops at a warehouse in Shanghai. After three months of fierce fighting, Shanghai was captured by the Japanese on November 11, 1937.
1942: Barbara Streisand, American actress, director and singer -- and the Oscar-winning star of "Funny Girl" -- is born.
1948: Lin Hsien-tang is appointed head of the Historical Research Commission of Taiwan Province.
1955: The Bandung Conference ends with five Asian states condemning colonialism by both the West and the Soviet Union.
1963: "Liang Shan-po and Chu Ying-tai," a movie directed by Lee Han-hsiang, premieres in Taipei and receives a warm welcome from a large audience.
1965: The Indonesian government formally takes control of all foreign companies in the country.
1967: Soviet Cosmonaut Vladimir Komarov plunges to Earth and dies when parachute straps on his Soyuz craft get tangled.
1970: Vice Premier Chiang Ching-kuo arrives in New York for a visit and survives an assassination attempt in front of his hotel by a Taiwan independence fanatic.
1970: Mainland China launches "Tung Fang Hung," (The East Is Red) its first satellite, into orbit.
1975: Thousands of Vietnamese refugees are flown to Guam as communists move rapidly in their takeover of South Vietnam.
1981: A landslide hits a train on its way to Alishan in Chiayi County, killing 10 passengers and injuring 19 others.
1986: Wallis Simpson, Duchess of Windsor, for whom a British king gave up his throne amid great controversy, dies in Paris at the age of 89.
1986: ROC Minister of Foreign Affairs Chu Fu-sung and Paraguayan Foreign Minister Carlos Augusto Saldivar sign an extradition treaty in Taipei on behalf of their respective governments.
1996: Russian President Boris Yeltsin meets with his mainland Chinese counterpart, Jiang Zemin, at the start of a visit to Beijing.
1997: The head of states of Russia, mainland China, Kazakhstan, Tajikistan and Kyrgystan sign a pact on troop reductions along the former Sino-Soviet border.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A wise and good man sometimes also meets with distress; but a fool, when in distress, becomes reckless."

DOC.HEADLINE: LIMITATIONS ON FOREIGN INVESTMENT IN BOURSE TO BE LIFTED IN 2000
DOC.DATELINE: Hong Kong, April 24 (CNA) (By Mandy Wang & Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan will lift its limitation on foreign investment in its bourse by 2000 to bring itself into compliance with World Trade Organization (WTO) requirements, said a Taiwan economics officer on Friday.

Schive Chi, vice chairman of the Council for Economic Planning and Development, said at a "Hong Kong-Taiwan Economic and Trade Forum" that since 1996 Taiwan has been gradually easing restrictions on foreign investment in its stock market.

Although existing rules restrict a single foreign investor's stake in a publicly listed firm to no more than 50 percent of its equity, in practice, foreigner ownership rarely exceeds 30 percent, said Schive.

To bring the island in line with the WTO criterion, however, Taiwan authorities are expected to lift the 50-percent ceiling on overseas investors, a move bound to draw more foreign capital into Taiwan's booming stock market, said Schive.
The Hong Kong branch office of Taipei's Far East Trade Service Inc. called the one-day forum to provide a platform for business leaders of Taiwan and Hong Kong to exchange views.

In response to criticism from local bankers that Taiwan discriminates against Hong Kong banks by allowing only one of them to operate in Taiwan, Schive said it is because of Taipei's policy of shutting out banks with capital from mainland China.

This policy, however, has not impeded financial transactions between Taiwan and Hong Kong, as most of the 46 foreign banks operating in Taiwan also have branch offices in Hong Kong. These branches serve as a financial conduit between Taiwan and Hong Kong, said Schive.
There are currently 13 Taiwan-based banks doing business in Hong Kong.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOTHER COMPLETING SON'S WISH

TEXT.P: She has walked the streets, staged sit-ins and gone on hunger strikes, all for the sake of pushing for compulsory auto liability insurance to save others from suffering the tragedy that she has endured.

Fifty-seven-year-old Ke Tsai Yu-chiung, known affectionately as Mama Ke, was a quiet homemaker in the southern Taiwan city of Tainan before her son, a graduate school student, was killed in a car accident in 1989.

After a seven-year campaign to push for a modicum of legal protection for victims of traffic mishaps in Taiwan, Mama Ke is now able to rest easy, knowing that a compulsory automobile liability insurance (CALI) bill cleared the legislative floor in late 1996 and went into effect last year.
With the passage of the bill, Mama Ke is now devoting herself to completing the education her son had no chance to finish, even though the task could take 10 years or longer.

Having received only limited formal education, Mama Ke has enrolled in a night school in Tainan, where she is studying at the junior-high-school level. She envisions going on to earn a high-school diploma and then embarking on university- and graduate-level studies.

"Although the prospective studies will be extremely hard, particularly when I proceed to the later stage, I'm determined to do it just as I did in calling for the enactment of CALI," the energetic mother said.
"I am determined and inspired, because I know my son is with me," she added.
The CALI bill is based on concept of no-fault liability and guarantees cash compensation to accident victims and their families within 10 days of an accident.

The bill requires all automobile owners, including those of private and commercial cars, as well as cargo and passenger transport vehicles, to be covered by liability insurance, the premiums for which amount to about US$2.5 billion annually in Taiwan.

The law also stipulates that a certain amount of money be put aside from the premiums collected to establish a "special subsidy fund" to provide immediate compensation to victims and their families under special circumstances including hit-and-run accidents, accidents caused by uninsured drivers and accidents in which the party responsible cannot afford to provide compensation.
After CALI had been in effect for more than one year, Taiwan's 10 million motorcycles were added to the list of vehicles whose drivers must carry liability insurance.

In the first seven years after her son's death, Mama Ke devoted herself and her scant finances to campaigning for CALI's passage. Her son was killed after his motorcycle was hit by a semitrailer truck, and she received only NT$300,000 (US$9,150) in compensation from the truck driver.

Mama Ke recalled that she was so heartbroken over her son's death that she lost 10 kilograms in the first week after the accident. She said she became obsessed with a single thought -- revenge -- until seven days after the accident, when her son appeared to her in a dream and advised her to seek not retribution but "legislation."

Owing to her lack of formal education, she had to contact Tunghai University, where her son had been studying, to find out what, exactly, the term "legislation" meant. Immediately after being told about the legislative process, she embarked on her seven-year campaign.

During her long years of struggle, Mama Ke said she received not one dollar from society or the government. She maintained an office in Taipei, at which she worked during the week, while returning to Tainan each weekend. She and her aides met with families of traffic accident victims islandwide as part of her efforts to promote the legislation.
She sold an apartment and spent the savings she had put aside for her son's education to support her activities during the seven-year campaign.
In early 1996, she staged sit-ins in front of the Kuomintang's sprawling headquarters on Taipei's Jen-Ai Road for 33 consecutive weeks.
Her persistence finally won her a chance to meet the ruling party's chairman, Lee Teng-hui, who is also president of the Republic of China.

Lee, whose only son died more than a decade ago, told Mama Ke that he understood her feelings of loss, and assured her that he fully supported CALI legislation and would ask the KMT's legislative caucus to push for the early passage of the statute.

DOC.HEADLINE: A QUARTER OF CANADIAN FAMILIES USE INTERNET

TEXT.P: Almost one household in four in Canada is connected to the Internet, and more than a third of all households have at least one member who uses the Internet from home, work or school, government statistics released on Friday show.
Statistics Canada said there were 2,689,000 households -- or 23 percent of all Canadian households -- using the Internet in 1998, up 44 percent from 1997.
It reported that there are 4,272,000 households -- 36 percent of the total -- in which at least one member uses computer communications from some location.
In households with Internet connections, 86 percent use e-mail and 78 percent browse the World Wide Web, the federal agency said, using numbers from an October 1998 survey.

The proportion of Internet-savvy households rose in every province between 1997 and 1998, with the highest increases in Alberta -- where 45 percent of all households are connected to the Internet -- and British Columbia, where 42 percent are on-line.
With 26 percent of its households connected to the Internet, Quebec had the lowest proportion of Internet-connected families of any province.

DOC.HEADLINE: TOO MANY ABORIGINAL PEOPLE BEHIND BARS IN CANADA

TEXT.P: Canada's highest court said Friday there are too many people behind bars in the country and far too many of them are aboriginal people.
The Supreme Court of Canada made the unprecedented comments when it criticized judges for not taking into account the special circumstances of aboriginal people before sentencing them to prison.
In a ruling, the Supreme Court rejected an aboriginal woman's appeal for her three-year sentence after she was convicted of stabbing her husband to death.
But the ruling also criticized lower court judges for relying too heavily on jail terms when dealing with aboriginal offenders.

It said judges must respect a new section of the Criminal Code that requires more emphasis on alternatives, such as community healing and victim-offender reconciliation, which are a traditional part of aboriginal culture.
Across Canada, lawyers and judges have been awaiting the decision hoping it would provide some guidance on how to correctly interpret the Criminal Code amendment.
The court also said that there are too many Canadians in jail, calling Canada a "world leader in putting people in prison."

DOC.HEADLINE: PANCHEN LAMA TO MARK 10TH BIRTHDAY IN DETENTION

TEXT.P: Gendhun Choekyi Nyima, the 11th Panchen Lama of Tibet and the world's youngest political prisoner, will spend his 10th birthday on April 25.
He will not spend the day playing with friends. Instead he will spend it alone in an unknown mainland Chinese detention center.

Gendhun Choekyi Nyima was taken forcibly from his home on May 17, 1995, when he was only 6 years old. He and his family have been held by mainland Chinese authorities ever since. Their whereabouts remains unknown, and there is no evidence that the boy or his parents are still alive. The ensuing controversy has resulted in over 80 arrests inside Tibet.
Last week in Toronto, mainland Chinese Premier Zhu Rongji claimed that mainland China is a country "ruled on the basis of law."
"What kind of law imprisons a child for political reasons?" asked Thubten Samdup, president of the Canada Tibet Committee Friday.

"Even if there was a legitimate reason to detain him, then why hasn't he been charged, or given an attorney? Why haven't any international observers been given an opportunity to see him? This is not rule on the basis of law," Samdup added.

Tibetans around the world and across Canada will commemorate the birthday by holding vigils, rallies and cultural events. On the Panchen Lama's birthday, the Canada Tibet Committee will launch a new website, designed specifically for children.
The site includes background information, games, puzzles, artwork and more. The website is located at www.tibet.ca/panchenlama.
Canadians have joined an international postcard campaign directed at President Jiang Zemin and UN High Commissioner for Human Rights Mary Robinson.
The birthday campaigns are designed to pressure the government of mainland China to allow independent observers access to the Panchen Lama.

DOC.HEADLINE: CLOUD GATE CHOREOGRAPHER LIN HWAI-MIN'S GERMAN ENCOUNTER

TEXT.P: Lin Hwai-min loves the music of Johann Sebastian Bach -- especially the tranquility of his "Six Suites for Solo Cello." He also loves tai chi, with its slow motions and calmness, which stimulate the flow of inner energy in the human body.

Inspired by Bach and tai chi, the world-renowned choreographer created "Moon Water," a metaphysical exploration that will be staged at the Deutsche Oper Berlin from August 13 to 15 and which will highlight a summer cultural program in Berlin. The performance comes at the invitation of the cultural forum "Berlindballett."

Meeting the German press in Berlin, Lin spoke of his German experience through a literary and musical approach, and of the numerous performance tours he and his "Cloud Gate Dance Theater" have made through Europe.

The choreographer said that Bach's solo cello suites were the only choice for his lyrical piece "Moon Water," which depicts the relationship between appearance and essence, effort and effortlessness, and man and woman. Many may find such a combination crazy, "but I have no other choice," said Lin.
The August performances will be the European premiere of "Moon Water," but many European art critics have already praised the work, which premiered in Taipei in November 1998.

The German daily "Frankfurter Allgemeine Zeitung" wrote of the piece that "Johann Sebastian Bach virtually entered Asia though Cloud Gate," while the magazine "Ballet International" said, "There is nothing this season to compare with its sublime beauty."

"Der Tagesspiegel," a Berlin daily, once wrote, "Lin Hwai-min blends the East and the West into a third world of his own." Lin himself believes that most people in Taiwan are just like him, constantly facing a blend of East and West that has worn away the boundary between the two.

DOC.HEADLINE: HOWARD-HABIBIE SUMMIT MAY BE UNDERMINED: REPORT

TEXT.P: A planned summit in Bali between Australian Prime Minister John Howard and Indonesian President B.J. Habibie may be undermined following a serious political row between the coalition government and opposition in Australia over claims that the death toll in East Timor could exceed 100.

Howard is scheduled to fly into Bali to hold a high-level summit with Habibie next Tuesday in an effort to resolve the issue of East Timor. Howard is expected to demand, among other things, an end to the killing of East Timorese civilians, including pro-independence supporters and activists, by militias who are tacitly backed by Indonesia's armed forces.

Australian media have reported that diplomats, church leaders and human rights groups in East Timor are gathering the names of more than 100 people they believe were killed in Dili and other neighboring cities by militias during the latest shooting rampage.

DOC.HEADLINE: ASPIRIN SAID TO HELP SAVE LIVES OF ELDERLY PEOPLE

TEXT.P: Aspirin can save the lives of elderly people undergoing major operations, and it is also effective as preventive medication for heart attacks and stroke, according to new medical research.

The research involved some 13,000 people, most of them elderly, who underwent hip surgery in Australia, New Zealand and Britain. The study showed aspirin's blood-thinning properties reduce blood clots in arteries. According to the research, aspirin reduces life-threatening post-operative blood clots by a third and halved the rate of death from them.

The new trial demonstrated that aspirin is even more effective against deep vein thrombosis than against heart attacks and stroke, said trial leader Dr. Anthony Rodgers of the University of Auckland in New Zealand.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA TO ACCEPT 200 KOSOVO REFUGEES AS PERMANENT RESIDENTS

TEXT.P: Australia is expected to accept about 200 Kosovo refugees and give them permanent residency, the Department of Immigration said.

But the Australian government's offer to provide a temporary safe haven for up to 4,000 Kosovars who have successfully fled to Macedonia is still on hold until the United Nations gives further instructions to countries agreeing to accept the refugees, including the United States and some European countries. Australia accepts about 12,000 refugees on a humanitarian basis every year.

DOC.HEADLINE: WU POH-HSIUNG TO SEEK KMT NOMINATION FOR VICE PRESIDENCY

TEXT.P: Wu Poh-hsiung, a senior adviser to the President, divulged for the first time on Saturday that he is interested in seeking the vice presidency.

The charismatic politician, who has served as Taipei mayor, interior minister, secretary-general to the President and secretary-general of the ruling Kuomintang, made the revelation during a presentation of creative Hakka songs and dances in Hsinchu County, some 70 kilomters south of Taipei.

At the gathering, many Hakka people urged Wu to team up with Vice President Lien Chan to run in the ROC's next presidential election scheduled for March 2000. Lien is widely believed to seek the KMT's nomination for the coming presidential election.
In response, Wu said he appreciates his Hakka fellows' encouragement and support.

"To live up to your expectations, I'll adopt a more definite attitude toward the feasibility of joining the race as a vice presidential candidate," Wu said, adding that he has never hesitated to grasp every possible opportunity to serve the people.

Noting that his Hakka fellows' enthusiastic push for his vice presidential candidacy reflects their sense of crisis over the fading away of Hakka language and culture, Wu said he is willing to work even harder to help preserve Hakka cultural heritage and promote harmony and mutual respect among different ethnic groups in Taiwan.

Nevertheless, Wu said the presidential candidate usually has a final say in deciding his running mate. "Against this background, I don't think I should not be too pushy and tough in seeking the vice presidential candidacy at this moment. But anyway, I'll adopt a more clear-cut attitude in dealing with the related issue. If necessary, I'll take up the electoral challenge bravely," Wu explained.
Meanwhile, Wu's wife Tai Mei-yu also confirmed publicly that Wu will join next year's presidential election.
Tai said at the inaugural ceremony for KMT Legislator Mu Ming-chu's service center in Taipei's Shihlin district that she takes pride in her husband's capability and dedication to public services.

"I hope you will support him if he has the opportunity to run in the next presidential election," Tai said. However, she didn't give any details about Wu's electoral plan, including Wu will either seek the presidency or vice presidency.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI OFFICIALS TAKING PART IN APEC MEETING IN NEW ZEALAND

TEXT.P: Yang Shih-chien, a minister without portfolio and a veteran economics expert, led a Taiwan delegation Saturday to New Zealand to take part in a meeting under the framework of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum.
Yang is taking Economics Minister Wang Chih-kang's place in the APEC meeting slated for April 26-29 in New Zealand's Christchurch, said sources from the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA).

Minister Wang, who was originally scheduled to lead the Taiwan delegation, instead will proceed to Washington, D.C., next week to solicit US support for Taiwan's admission to the World Trade Organization, MOFA officials said.

The ministerial-level APEC meeting will focus on ways to strengthen the development of small- and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) in the Asia-Pacific region to help boost economic prosperity in the region, the officials said.

During the four-day gathering, Yang will exchange views with delegates from other APEC member countries on an APEC-initiated five-year SME action plan, and will meet with other APEC ministers and SME representatives for dialogue, the officials said.
Other members of Yang's delegation will include Lin Chung, Taiwan's representative to New Zealand, and John Ni, director-general of the Medium and Small Business Administration, the officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: DAILY AIR, CRASH VICTIMS' FAMILIES AGREE TO SERVICES BEFORE TALKS

TEXT.P: Daily Air and the families of three victims of a recent helicopter crash in Taipei County reached an agreement on Saturday to hold a funeral service for the dead prior to talks about compensation.

A Daily Air spokesman said the talks leading to the agreement proceeded in a rational manner. Expressing its condolences to the families of the victims, Daily Air said it will give each family compensation of at least NT$10.2 million (US$311,000).
Of that amount, the company itself will pay at least NT$8.6 million, while the rest would come from an insurance system.
Meanwhile, the company will also sponsor a joint funeral service for the victims, to be held Tuesday, the Daily Air official noted.
The three Daily Air employees died when their helicopter crashed into a mountainous area in Taipei County.

Daily Air flight B5550 took off from Taipei's Sungshan Airport at 10:18 a.m. Wednesday and was bound for the eastern city of Taitung. Radio contact with the helicopter was lost Wednesday morning, and the wreckage of the copter and the remains of the crewmen were found the next day.
The Japanese-made BK-117 chopper, with no passengers aboard, was to be used on a service between Taitung and offshore Orchid Island.
A preliminary investigation has revealed that bad weather and heavy cloud cover were likely the cause of the crash, Transportation and Communications Minister Lin Fong-cheng said on Saturday.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SUGAR PRODUCTION TO BE CUT BY HALF UPON WTO ADMISSION

TEXT.P: Taiwan is set to reduce both the acreage of its sugarcane plantations and its overall domestic sugar production by 50 percent as it prepares for admission to the World Trade Organization (WTO), sources from Taiwan Sugar Corp. (Taisugar) said on Saturday.

With Taiwan expected to join the WTO as early as this year, plans have been announced to reduce the island's 70,000 hectares of sugarcane plantations to 35,000 hectares, while crude sugar production is to be reduced to 150,000 metric tons annually, said Taisugar President Cheng Hung-tsai.
The reductions will go into effect once Taiwan is formally admitted to the WTO.

As more foreign sugar is allowed into Taiwan, the state-run Taisugar will be appointed by the government to oversee the import of sugar under a quota system, while private trading companies will be allowed to import small quantities, Cheng said.

Since sugar, like rice, is one of the strategic commodities of a country, most governments around the world have included sugar under protective umbrellas, and Taisugar is doing the same by offering subsidies to domestic sugarcane farmers so that the industry can survive increased imports, Cheng noted.

This year, Taisugar will buy some 300,000 metric tons of sugar from domestic sugarcane farmers at a price of NT$24.8 (US$0.76) per kilogram. Imported sugar costs an average of NT$16.5 (US$0.50) per kilogram, he said.
Taisugar is absorbing the total cost of the cash subsidies it provides to sugarcane farmers to help them maintain their plantations.
After Taiwan is admitted to the WTO, however, Taisugar will have sugar importers share in providing the cash subsidies to the farmers, Cheng added.
Currently, Taisugar also imports 200,000 metric tons of sugar annually to meet the island's overall need of 500,000 metric tons of sugar a year.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT WELCOME DPP'S ACCEPTANCE OF ROC AS TAIWAN'S OFFICIAL NAME

TEXT.P: The ruling Kuomintang welcomes the opposition Democratic Progressive Party's identification of Taiwan with the name "Republic of China," said KMT Secretary-General John Chang on Saturday.
The DPP's change in attitude is seen by many as an attempt to attract centrist voters to the party in the run-up to next year's presidential election.

Chang said he was not surprised by the DPP's decision, adding that if the party had not changed its position, it might have lost the support of more moderate elements within itsthe party. Moreover, the DPP's support for the name "Republic of China" vindicates the KMT's long-standing basic national policy, he said.
Although the DPP's move helps to bridge the gap between it and the ruling party, Chang said the KMT would maintain its pursuit of national reunification.

The pro-independence DPP, which has long sought to establish an independent country under the name "The Republic of China," will put on the table a motion at an upcoming party congress to accept, at least for the time being, the name "Republic of China."
The motion, which still must be approved by a party congress on May 8, reiterates the party's call for Taiwan's permanent separation from mainland China.
The change was driven by the party's presidential hopeful, Chen Shui-bian, who while visiting New York, said on Thursday that "Taiwan is a sovereign state named 'The Republic of China.'"

DOC.HEADLINE: US SHOULD SELL LONG-RANGE RADARS TO TAIWAN: MILITARY BRASS

TEXT.P: The Ministry of National Defense (MND) on Saturday declined to comment on a US newspaper report that the Clinton administration has decided to reject a Taiwan request for purchasing long-range radars.

An MND official said the ministry has never told the press that it plans to purchase US-made phased-array radars. "Therefore, we would not make any comments on the report," said the official, who spoke on condition of anonymity.
However, military sources said if the MND really has asked the United States to sell the long-range radars, the Clinton administration should not reject such a request.

It will be in the US interests to sell such radar equipment to Taiwan, the military sources said, adding that the long-range radars can double the surveillance range of the ROC military's current radar system.

In the face of mainland China's intensified development of sophisticated ballistic missiles and cruise missiles, the sources said the United States should provide Taiwan with long-range radars in line with the provision of the Taiwan Relations Act in order to maintain military balance between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait and safeguard peace and stability in the region. The Washington Times reported on Friday that the Clinton administration has continued denying Taiwan access to important defensive weapons for fear of offending mainland China.

The report, carried in the paper's Inside the Ring column, said an interministerial task force in the Clinton administration already decided this week to reject sales of a list of weapons needed by Taiwan to protect itself from mainland China's military attack, including long-range phased-array radars
The report said Taiwan badly needs long-range radars as communist China will deploy up to 650 M-11 and M-9 ballistic missiles within the next six years.

The report quoted a Clinton administration official, who was opposed to the special task force's decision, as saying that the long-range radars are Taiwan's priority need. "Such radars have nothing to do with any offensive weapons. Nevertheless, they can offer five minutes for the 21 million Taiwan people to escape missile attack," the official was quoted as explaining.
The Washington Times further said an annual Taiwan-US meeting on Taiwan's defensive weapon purchase needs will open in Washington, D.C. on April 27.

In addition to phased-array radars, the paper said, Taiwan also hopes to purchase US-made air-launched anti-ship missiles, submarines, advanced medium-range air-to-air missiles, Patriot air-defense missiles and aircraft targeting equipment.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC VICE PRESIDENT SPEAKS ON ECONOMIC, POLITICAL DEVELOPMENT

TEXT.P: Republic of China Vice President Lien Chan said on Saturday that economic development and political democratization are the two most important achievements in the island's modernization.

He noted that Taiwan is famed for its "economic miracle" and "peaceful revolution," because equality has been maintained during its economic development, and peace and stability have not been sacrificed during its democratization.
The vice president made the remarks at the opening of a symposium on the impact of democratization on economic development.

The symposium was held in memory of the late governor of the Central Bank of China, Y.D. Sheu, who died in a plane crash last year. The symposium was jointly sponsored by the Department of Political Science under National Taiwan University and two private foundations.
Despite the achievements Taiwan has already made in its economic and political development, Lien pointed out that Taiwan still has to improve the efficiency and quality of its democracy.

He went on to say that efforts should be made to improve the holding of elections, the interaction between the administrative and legislative branches of government and the normal operations of Taiwan's financial markets. Moreover, efforts are needed to reduce outside influence over law-enforcement agencies in Taiwan, he said.
Lien said that early this year he spelled out the nation's cross-century goal as striving for "a democracy with excellent quality, a mature economy and a caring and concerned society."
To attain that goal is not only the government's responsibility, but also the public's, he stressed.

As the 21th century is around the corner, Lien said, it is important for all echelons of society to pool their wisdom on how to improve the country's competitiveness and to construct Taiwan into a science and technology island.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP PRESIDENTIAL HOPEFUL EMPHASIZES NATIONAL SECURITY IN NEW YORK

TEXT.P: Avoiding war is the supreme obligation of a responsible politician and a sensitive political party, said Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) member and former Taipei Mayor Chen Shui-bian on Friday.

Chen said this is why national security is the main concern in the "new central line" he has adopted. Chen made the remarks during a press briefing in New York where he arrived on Thursday for a private visit.

He shrugged off questions about how he would reconcile the DPP's goal of establishing a "Republic of Taiwan" with his new central line, in which he accepts "Republic of China" as the name of the independent country his party is struggling to establish.
Chen said his new central line reflects mainstream opinion within the party and will prevail as its official position at an upcoming party congress on May 8.
He said a political party should adapt to a rapidly changing political environment with new ideas. Otherwise it will be abolished by time and voters.
Chen also deflected questions on whether the party would amend its charter to enable Chen to run as the party's candidate in next year's presidential election.

The party's charter currently prohibits any party member who has been nominated as a candidate for elected office from being nominated again within four years' time. Chen failed in a re-election bid in mayoral elections last December in which he represented the DPP.
He is nevertheless regarded as the party's main hopeful in next year's presidential election, though Chen has not said anything publicly on the matter.

He has traveled extensively at home and abroad to sell a modified pro-independence vision that he says is consistent with the party's long-standing pursuit of independence, while unlikely to lead to a military confrontation with mainland China.

In related news, Chen's main rival for the DPP's presidential nomination, former DPP Chairman Hsu Hsin-liang, rebutted a remark made by Chen in New York that the interim Taipei-Beijing agreement urged by Washington officials is more a vaguely defined concept than official US policy.

Hsu argued that the interim agreement, floated first by US Assistant Secretary of State for Asian and Pacific Affairs Stanley Roth on March 23, and conveyed to Taipei by Darryl Norman Johnson, director of the Taipei office of the American Institute in Taiwan, is in fact official US policy.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S COLLEGE STUDENTS URGED TO SPEND MORE TIME EXERCISING

TEXT.P: A recent survey by National Chengchi University indicates that 55 percent of Taiwan's college students believe they are less fit than they were in high school.
Only 18 percent said they are more fit, while 27 percent said they have not felt any change in their physical condition.

The survey was carried out between late March and early April among 1,000 students from 13 universities and colleges in northern Taiwan. Eighty-two percent of students responded to the questionnaires.
Among the major findings of the survey:
-- Except for physical education classes, 73 percent exercise fewer than three times per week;
-- 63 percent said they are exercising less than they did in high school, while 25 percent said they are exercising more;
-- 87 percent said they should improve their physical fitness;
-- 60 percent said they are not exercising enough; and
-- 23 percent said they are not fit.
The survey showed that 50 percent of the students exercise for less than 30 minutes each time.
Analysts were quoted as saying that more than 50 percent of college students are prone to become victims of chronic diseases.

DOC.HEADLINE: POLL SHOWS KMT PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE STANDS BETTER CHANCE TO WIN

TEXT.P: Even though major domestic political parties have yet to select their candidates for the next presidential election, the majority of local people have shown greater confidence in the ruling Kuomintang candidate's winning chance, according to the results of two opinion polls released on Saturday.
The ROC Collegiate Teaching Faculty Association twice surveyed local people's evaluation of likely presidential candidates of both the KMT and the main opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP).

One survey was conducted between March 10 and March 14, and the other was taken between April 15 and April 18. The first survey collected 1,168 valid replies and the second poll drew 1,142 valid replies.

In the March survey, 43.6 percent of the respondents said they believe the election of a KMT candidate as the country's next president will contribute to Taiwan's political stability, compared to 17.9 percent who said they think that the DPP candidate's win will be more helpful to Taiwan's political stability. In the April poll, the KMT-DPP ratio was 42.8 percent against 17.8 percent.

On the handling of national security affairs, 32 percent of respondents to the March poll and 32.7 percent in the April surveys said they believe the KMT presidential candidate is more capable of dealing with such issues, compared to 25.5 percent and 20.5 percent who said they think the DPP candidate can better handle such issues than their KMT counterpart.

On the diplomatic front, the two surveys also showed that the respondents have greater confidence in the KMT candidate's ability than the DPP hopeful, 41.8 percent vs. 20.3 percent in the March survey and 39.8 percent vs. 18.5 percent in the April poll.
The respondents to the two poll also showed greater trust in the KMT hopeful's ability to properly handle relations across the Taiwan Strait, according to poll results.
Nevertheless, the gap between the two parties' abilities to cope with economic problems is limited.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'DOME BREAD' FEVER SWIRLING IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: Taipei, a frontline city in the introduction of new fashions and trends to the Asian continent, is now being permeated by the fragrance of bread, which has replaced the steaming hot egg tarts from the Portuguese colony of Macau that formerly captivated Taiwan.

The dome-shaped bread, dubbed "dome," was born in Hokkaido, Japan where the local dairy farmers make the soft and puffy bread with a great quantity of milk. Taipei's Ambassador Hotel introduced the bread from Japan's northernmost island to Taiwan last year.
The wildly popular bread is creating a frenzy similar to the one seen last year when egg tarts reigned supreme.

Ambassador Hotel bakers place fresh rows of domes on their store shelves under the watchful eye of long, snaky lines of customers waiting for their chance to buy the bread at NT$100 (US$3.05) a piece.

Milking the trend for all it's worth, quick-witted businessmen have started to make their own "domes" or similarly scrumptious breads, such as the curry-filled "giant pillow bread" available at the Hilton Taipei hotel.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Sunday, April 25, or the 10th day of the third month of the Year of the Rabbit according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1719: Daniel Defoe's "Robinson Crusoe" is published in London. The novel was inspired by the exploits of a Scottish sailor and castaway, Alexander Selkirk.
1744: Anders Celsius, Swedish astronomer who devised the Celsius thermometer in 1742, dies at the age of 43.
1792: Jacques Pelletier, a highwayman, becomes the first person to be guillotined in Paris, France.
1859: Under the direction of Ferdinand de Lesseps, the construction of the Suez Canal begins. It was opened 10 years later on Nov. 16, 1869.
1874: Gulielmo Marconi, Italian engineer and inventor who shared the 1909 Nobel Prize in physics, is born. He transmitted long-wave radio signals across the Atlantic Ocean in 1901.
1895: Lai Ho, a noted Chinese writer of anti-Japanese literature, is born in Changhua.
1927: After the national government in Nanking announces a purification movement that will entail the expulsion of Chinese communists, the communists meet in Wuhan and decide to set up a Soviet-style regime.
1930: Construction of the Chianan irrigation canal is completed.
1942: An accident at a coal mine in Benxi, located within Japanese-occupied China, kills 1,549 workers in the world's worst mining disaster.
1945: Delegates of 45 nations, including the Republic of China, meet in San Francisco, California, to organize the United Nations.
1946: Foreign ministers of the United States, Soviet Union, Britain and France meet in Paris to discuss the signing of a peace treaty with Germany.
1956: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs of the Republic of China announces establishment of diplomatic relations with Haiti.
1962: The United States successfully launches its Saturn rocket, the largest in the world at that time.
1965: President Lyndon B. Johnson sends US troops to the Dominican Republic to maintain order after rebels who support Juan Bosch try to seize power.
1971: Some 200,000 anti-Vietnam War protesters march on Washington.
1974: Portugal's dictator Marcelo Caetano is overthrown in a bloodless military coup, in which he surrenders to Gen. Antonio de Spinola, who becomes president the following month.
1980: A US commando mission to rescue 53 US Embassy hostages in Teheran, Iran, is abandoned in the desert with the loss of eight lives when a helicopter collides with a tanker aircraft.
1989: Japanese Prime Minister Noburu Takeshita announces plans to resign over the "Recruit Affair," the country's biggest political scandal in decades.
1994: Tsutomu Hata becomes Japan's 51st prime minister.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "The ancient Emperor Shun was perhaps the one man who successfully carried out the principle of no-government. For what need is there really for what is called government? A ruler needs only to earnest in his personal conduct, and to behave in a manner worthy of his position."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies Sunday are as follows:
The Central Daily News: The Department of Health will test medical care program for the elders in six cities and counties in June. @The China Times: Kistler of the United States invites Taiwan to take part in its rocket recycle program. @The United Daily News: NATO decided to impose oil embargo on Yugoslavia. @The Liberty Times:
It is now certain that Former Democratic Progressive Party chairman Hsu Hsin-liang will leave the party to run in 2000 presidential election.
The Commons Daily: DPP Chairman Lin Yi-hsiung said the referring to the nation by its official name Republic of China is not going to work in international community. the China Post: Possible ROC switch ignites DPP conflict. @The China News: US sending more troop; New airstrikes launched.

DOC.HEADLINE: MANILA SEEKING TO SIGN LABOR ACCORD WITH TAIPEI
DOC.DATELINE: Manila, April 24 (CNA) (By Timothy Sun and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: The Philippine government is seeking to sign a labor accord with 20 countries, including the Republic of China, to further protect the rights of Filipino workers abroad.

According to the Philippine Labor and Employment Ministry, Saudi Arabia is the most popular destination among Philippine laborers working abroad. Taiwan ranks second, and is followed by Hong Kong and Japan.
In 1998, 158,000 Filipino workers left for Saudi Arabia to work in that Middle East country, while 79,000 and 64,000 went to Taiwan and Hong Kong, respectively.

Hailed by Philippine President Joseph Estrada as "modern heroes," overseas Filipino workers remit as much as US$5 billion every year back to their country. Against such background, Estrada has put the issue on increasing the rights of workers abroad high on his policy agenda.

DOC.HEADLINE: INDUSTRIAL LEADERS SAY FIVE-DAY WORKWEEK PLAN TOO RASH

TEXT.P: While the legislature is actively pushing for five-day workweek starting next year, industrial leaders and government officials cautioned on Sunday that next year may be too soon.
The officials made the remarks while attending a forum to discuss the proposed five-day workweek's affect on national productivity.

New Party legislator Lai Shih-pao said the proposed plan does not cut working hours, noting that under the plan the average working hours per day will be extended to 8.5 hours, He said that as working hours are not cut, productivity will not be affected.

Addressing the concerns that government service, such as passport service or national park management, could be cut due to a shortened work day, Lai responded that government service is now computerized or on the internet, adding that not only will government service not be affected, it instead will be a 24-hour service.

Kuo Yung-hsiung, deputy secretary-general of the Chinese National Federation of Industries, said that if the plan is implemented next year, civil servants will have up to 119 days of leave a year, averaging one day off every three working days, which he said will be the highest in the world.
Moreover, he noted that last year there was a shortage of up to 200,000 workers in the industrial sector. He said an early implementation of a five-day workweek will leave the sector unprepared.
He urged a gradual implementation of the plan, saying a rash decision will not be supported by the trade and industrial sectors.
Most businesses in Taiwan now implement a five-day workweek every other week. The Legislative Yuan's plan to push for a five-day workweek every week starting next year has stirred heated debate.

Lee Kao-chao, vice chairman of the Council for Economic Planning and Development, said that a shortened workweek with a goal to upgrade the quality of live is desirable, but worried that the plan will adversely impact society. (By Lilian Wu) EDNITEM ZCZC CEP005 04-25-99 PHILIPPINES TO REVIEW ONE-CHINA POLICY

Manila April 25 (CNA) The Philippine House of Representatives Foreign Affairs committee is set to review the country's One-China Policy, saying that "changing times and recent economic and political transformation" have prompted the country to take another look at the policy.

When the Philippines formally recognized and shifted its diplomatic relations from the ROC on Taiwan to mainland China, it signed a Joint Communique with mainland China on June 9, 1975; thereby establishing a One-China policy, committee chair Rep. Luwalhati Antonino said.
Antonino said that the circumstances by which the Philippines adopted the policy in 1975 have since changed and, therefore, necessitates the need to assess the benefits of the policy.
She said the overriding question is whether the One-China policy is still economically advantageous for the country. "We need to take another closer, harder look at the policy," she said.

For his part, Rep. Apolinario Lozada (Negros Occidental) wants RP-Taiwan relations expanded, saying that the One-China policy does not prelude the people of the Philippines from pursuing other mutually beneficial relationships with the people of Taiwan.

Lozada said, "The Filipino people still consider its relations with both countries very important, equal to relations with members of ASEAN and member countries of the United Nations such as the US, Japan and UK."

Lozada added, "We should focus on enhancing those areas considered to be most advantageous to all parties, the Philippines, mainland China and Taiwan. He said that enacting HR 4573, would be a "crucial step toward clarifying the country's One-China policy."
HR 4573 proposes to establish the parameters of the economic, social and cultural relations between Taiwan and the Philippines.
The bill, Lozada said, further seeks to maintain transparency and clarifies further the specific type of relationship that should exist between the people of the Philippines and Taiwan. (Timothy Sun)

DOC.HEADLINE: DEPOSITS REACH RECORD NT$17 TRILLION: CBC

TEXT.P: The total amount of money deposited in Taiwan's major financial institutes at the end of March reached a record high of over NT$17 trillion, an annual increase of 7.78 percent, according to the Central Bank of China on Sunday.

Deposits in the island's major financial institutes first broke the NT$10 trillion barrier in 1993 and continued to climb to NT$17 trillion in 5 years time. CBC officials said it is likely that deposits will reach NT$20 trillion within 3 years time.
Bank loans and investment in major financial institutes totaled NT$15.4 trillion, with most of the capital invested in securities. That number is also a new record. (by Amanda Chang)

DOC.HEADLINE: SURVEY SHOWS PHILIPPINES IS BEST ASIAN COUNTRY TO LIVE

TEXT.P: A recent survey among non-Asian foreigners ranked the Philippines the best Asian country in which to live.
The survey, which ranked Taiwan seventh, has been conducted annually by a consulting company specializing in political and economic affairs.
The top 10 Asian countries according to the survey were: the Philippines, Singapore, Japan, Malaysia, Hong Kong, Thailand, Taiwan, mainland China, Indonesia, and Vietnam.
In the eyes of foreigners, Taiwan ranks first in the cultural aspect, and has sound work conditions with economic stability. But they complained of Taiwan's environmental pollution.
The Philippines, despite environmental pollution and traffic congestion, topped the ranking, mainly because of leisure, quality of life and cultural integration.
Singapore slipped to second place, mainly because of a higher living cost.
Foreigners were satisfied with Hong Kong's social security and working conditions, but complained of high living costs and environmental pollution.
South Korea was listed as the most difficult Asian country for foreigners to live in, due to the difficulty of integrating with the Korean people.

DOC.HEADLINE: GRENADA HOUSE SPEAKER TO ARRIVE IN TAIPEI FOR WEEKLONG VISIT

TEXT.P: The Speaker of the House of Representatives from Granada Curtis Strachan was to arrive in Taipei Sunday night for a weeklong visit.

During his stay in Taipei, Strachan will meet with National Assembly Speaker Su Nan-cheng, Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng, Foreign Minister Jason Hu, and Government Information Office Director-General Chen Chien-jen.
Strachan will also tour several major cultural and economic centers before departing on May 1.
The visit will be the 73-year-old speaker's second trip to Taiwan. He first visited in September 1996.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT AIR TRAFFIC SAFETY MANAGEMENT INADEQUATE: SURVEY

TEXT.P: Over half of the Taiwan and foreign pilots working for Taiwan-based airlines are unsatisfied with the government's management on flight safety, a recent survey indicated.

The survey found that 60 percent of those airplane pilots with ROC nationality are not satisfied with the government's current management on air traffic safety, while about 45 percent of their foreign counterparts are of the same view, an indication that the government should step up its flight safety measures on local airlines.

The survey, conducted by the Ministry of Transportation and Communications, polled a total of 1,891 airplane pilots working for Taiwan-based aviation companies. One thousand three hundred and fifty four of them are ROC nationals, while the remaining 537 are foreigners.
Some 72 percent of the Taiwan airplane pilots surveyed said they are confident of flight safety on national routes, compared to 37 percent of foreign pilots who said they have confidence.

At the same time, around 30 percent of those Taiwan pilots said they have no confidence in the professional expertise of control personnel at domestic airports, slightly lower than the 33 percent of the foreign pilots who said so, according to the survey.

On the performance of the Civil Aeronautics Administration (CAA) and its staff workers, only 51 percent of the Taiwan pilots approved of their professional ability, far higher than the 40 percent who voiced disagreement. Some 41 percent of the foreign pilots expressed satisfaction with CAA's performance, 29 percent disapproved, and the remaining 30 percent would not comment.

More than 70 percent of both the local and foreign pilots support the government's measure to fully or partially suspend or withdraw airlines' management rights for their transport mishaps so as to ensure air traffic security, the poll found.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHEN SHUI-BIAN CONCLUDES US VISIT
DOC.DATELINE: Los Angles, April 24 (CNA) (By L. S. Chu and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Former Taipei City Mayor Chen Shui-bian said over the weekend that he is willing to serve as Hsu Hsin-liang's campaign manager during Taiwan's 2000 presidential race if Hsu is nominated by the DPP to be the party's candidate.

Chen, at a press conference in Los Angles before his departure for home, made the remarks in response to reports that Hsu, former DPP chairman, may quit the party if the DPP fails to choose him as party candidate.
Chen, at the end of his nine-day trip of the US, said that he was satisfied with the results.
During the visit, Chen met with US senators, congressmen, China experts, and several officials in charge of Asian-Pacific affairs, although he would not reveal the details of those meetings.

In his press conference, Chen reaffirmed his "new middle road" policy, trying to allay fears of the party's campaign for Taiwan independence, and stressed that national security is the common goal of all parties.
The US trip is part of Chen's "journey of learning" which is designed to boost his presidential bid. Besides the US, Chen has journeyed so far to Japan, South Korea and Mongolia.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTEL PRESIDENT ARRIVES IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Intel Corporation President Craig Barrett is slated to arrive in Taiwan on Sunday for a one-day whirlwind visit.
The major purpose of Barrett's Taiwan visit is to warm up an Intel-sponsored three-day seminar here which will begin on Monday.

Before leaving Taiwan on Monday evening, Barrett will first hold a news conference in the morning prior to the symposium, and will preside over a computer donation ceremony at National Taiwan University and give a speech to its students in the afternoon.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW WINE, TOBACCO PRODUCTS TO TARGET THE YOUNG

TEXT.P: Taiwan Tobacco & Wine Board (TTWB) announced on Sunday that it will introduce several new products which will be targeted at a younger consumers this summer.
TTWB officials said the new products are aimed at the younger generation, adding that this consumer group is more lavish in their spending than are their parents.

TTWB will unveil a low alcohol wine in May, the 250 c.c. can will be available in either blueberry or lemon flavor, marking the first time the brewery has tried to give one of its products a fresh face.
The TTWB will also introduce a "light" cigarette. The 520 "cool" cigarette's pronunciation in Mandarin is very similar to "I love you". The cigarette has a red heart filter as a symbol of love.
With summer approaching, the TTWB also plans to introduce Taiwan draft beer in small bottles, and will market them in the convenience stores and pubs.

The TTWB has also become more innovative in its marketing strategy, the officials added. Wu Pai, a popular rock singer, was hired as the spokesman for Taiwan Beer last year. The strategy successfully expanded the beer's popularity within the younger generation.
The officials said that they are again asking Wu Pai to be the Taiwan beer spokesman this year to further solidify market share with younger consumers.

DOC.HEADLINE: VP CALLS FOR TAIWAN'S SUSTAINED DEVELOPMENT

TEXT.P: Vice President Lien Chan on Sunday urged the private sector to play a more constructive role in Taiwan's sustained development by promoting charity activities.

Speaking at the 14th annual conference of the northern branches of the Liberty Intelligence of Our Nations Safety (LIONS) in Taiwan, Lien expressed the hope that elites of all walks of lives will extend greater love, care and service to society in order to make it a place where everyone can enjoy equitable opportunities.

Although Taiwan has achieved remarkable progress in political development over the past three decades, Lien, however, pointed out that the island's social transformation has been lagging far behind at the same time.

At a time when new social problems on youth education, public security and living environments, are emerging, the vice president called on the entire society, specially social services groups like LIONS in the private sector, to make greater contribution. "Social organizations such as LIONS are our strongest driving force," he claimed.
Lien also encouraged LIONS members to make great efforts to pursue LIONS' spirit of learning, inspiration, obligation and volunteer services.
At the end of the meeting, LIONS members presented a commemorative plaque to Lien, wishing him good luck in his bid to run the next year's presidential elections.
