DOC.HEADLINE: ANTI-NUKE GROUP PROTESTS ON ANNIVERSARY OF CHERNOBYL INCIDENT

TEXT.P: An anti-nuclear group protested in front of the legislature on Monday, calling for a proposed fourth nuclear plant to be scrapped.

The Taiwan Anti-Nuclear Action Alliance, on the 13th anniversary of the Chernobyl incident, urged the government to heed public sentiment and freeze the budget for the proposed nuclear plant in Taipei County.
They also asked for plans for the plant's construction to be scrapped and for the Legislative Yuan to pass a plebiscite law as soon as possible.

Kao Cheng-yen, a spokesman of the group, noted that a nuclear reactor at the Chernobyl plant in the Ukraine exploded on April 26, 1986, spreading a radioactive cloud across Europe, and causing grave pollution in the world's worst nuclear accident.
Kao said the incident caused heavy causalities with women giving birth to deformed babies, while crops in more than 20 countries in Europe also suffered heavy losses.
Kao said that the government has disregarded the opinions of the public by granting permits for the construction of the fourth nuclear plant in Kungliao, Taipei County.
He urged the government to freeze the budget for the nuclear plant, and to step up its push for the passage of a plebiscite law.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'FATHER OF CHINESE PHYSICS' IN CRITICAL CONDITION

TEXT.P: Former Academia Sinica President Wu Ta-you remained in critical condition Monday morning, though his life signs were stabilizing, doctors from National Taiwan University (NTU) Hospital said on Monday.
Wu, who has long been regarded as the "father of Chinese physics," went in and out of a coma Sunday as his respiratory tract became completely blocked, doctors said.
Wu's family, including his son Wu Pao-chih, have asked the hospital not to keep Wu on a respirator or cut his trachea open, in hopes of sparing Wu any further pain, doctors said.
Wu, 92, checked into NTU Hospital on March 13 with influenza. On March 26, he was sent to the intensive care unit because of heart failure and other complications.

Over the past month, Wu has been treated for cardiac illness, hypertension and diabetes. During the most recent two weeks doctors have had to put him on a dialysis machine because of kidney failure, and he has required regular blood transfusions because of massive stomach hemorrhaging.
On Saturday, Wu murmured in English on his sickbed with his eyes closed, according to Chen Tsung-hsien, a researcher at Academia Sinica and one of Wu's many students.
As his remarks became clearer, he was heard to say that his innate talent could only be graded as a B-plus. "I overcame my intellectual difficulties with my incessant and honest hard work," he said.

"My disposition is inherently shy and conservative, but my attitude turned aggressive and belligerent when facing situations which were undermining the academic sector's dignity and national interests," he said.

"I have treated my colleagues, students and all my duties with honesty, and because of that, I have won praises and accolades that were far more than I deserved. Because of my honesty, I have no regrets," Wu added.

Wu's son Pao-chih then approached him and said, "We are proud of you, Dad." As if awakened from a dream, Wu opened his eyes and said, still in English, "Thank you all," according to Chen, who has remained at Wu's side in the hospital's intensive care ward.
Wu, who entered Michigan University in 1931 at the age of 24, obtained his doctorate in physics in less than two years. He returned to China to teach before the outbreak of World War II.

The pioneer of Chinese physics, Wu held professorships at Beijing, Qinghua and Nankai Universities in mainland China before 1949. He came to Taiwan after the Republic of China moved its seat of government to Taiwan.
Among his students, many of whom went on to become members of China's scientific elite, were Yang Chen-ning and Lee Cheng-dao, co-winners of the 1957 Nobel Prize in physics.
He was president of Academia Sinica, the highest research institute in Taiwan, between 1983 and 1993.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC POLLS FIND MAJORITY OF TAIWAN PEOPLE WANT TO MAINTAIN STATUS QUO

TEXT.P: The majority of Taiwan people prefer to maintain the status quo in relations across the Taiwan Strait, according to the results of four large-scale opinion polls conducted by the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) over the past five years.

MAC Vice Chairman Lin Chong-pin said on Monday that the repeated MAC surveys were mainly aimed at exploring mainstream public opinion about the government's policy toward mainland China and cross-strait relations.

"The four massive opinion polls found that 80 percent of those interviewed prefer to maintain different degrees of the cross-strait political status quo," Lin said, adding that the results comply with those recorded in many other similar surveys taken over the past decade.

Meanwhile, more than 70 percent of respondents to the four MAC polls said they oppose the mainland China-proposed "one country, two systems" unification scheme, while the ratio of the proponents in the four survey consistently stood below 7 percent.
More than half of those interviewed further said they think the two sides of the Taiwan Strait should not start unification talks until their gaps in political systems and lifestyles are narrowed.
Survey results also showed that more than 70 percent of the respondents are satisfied with the government's pace in opening cross-strait exchanges.

Nevertheless, the number of people who said the government should not open the doors to mainland Chinese capital in the fourth survey surged to 41.3 percent, marking a 10.8 percent rise from that recorded in the previous survey.

The latest MAC survey was conducted between July 5, 1998 and Sept. 5, 1998, in which 1,604 valid replies were collected. Because of the large scale of the survey, the MAC didn't complete analysis of the findings until recently and made public the poll results on Monday.

Most noteworthy was that the number of respondents who think it is more important for Taiwan to develop relations with other countries than to promote cross-strait ties outpaced the percentage of those who think otherwise by 30 percent.

Even if Taiwan's diplomatic efforts caused tension in cross-strait relations, more than 60 percent of those responding to all the four MAC surveys still said Taiwan should continue expanding its diplomatic frontiers.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Monday, April 26, or the 11h day of the third month of the Year of the Rabbit according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1452: Leonardo da Vinci, Italian painter, engineer, scientist and the most versatile genius of the Renaissance, is born. As a painter, he is best known for "The Last Supper," and "Mona Lisa."
1885: Britain occupies Port Hamilton, Korea.
1925: Paul von Hinderburg, German general and politician, is elected president of the Weimar Republic. He appointed Adolf Hitler as chancellor in 1933.
1937: The civil war in Spain takes a devastating turn with the sudden and horrific bombing by Germany planes of the town of Guernica, killing more than 1,500 people.
1946: Chinese communist troops take over Harbin and Tsitsihar as Soviet forces evacuate.
1954: The United Nations meets at Geneva and insists on free elections in Korea.
1960: The construction of the East-West Cross-Island Highway in Taiwan is completed.
1966: Mt. Kelud erupts in Java, Indonesia, killing some 1,000 people.
1971: T.V. Soong (Sung Tzu-wen), former premier of the Republic of China, dies in the United States at the age of 77.
1971: A White House commission recommends that communist China be brought into the United Nations, with the Republic of China retaining its membership.
1975: The Embassy of the Republic of China in Saigon suspends operations.
1975: Shortly before the fall of Saigon, former South Vietnamese President Nguyen Van Thieu and his wife arrive in Taipei for a temporary stay before going into exile in the United States.
1976: The Republic of China establishes diplomatic Relations with the Republic of South Africa.
1983: Explosions occur in buildings occupied by the Central Daily News and the United Daily News in Taipei.
1984: US President Ronald Reagan and his wife Nancy leave for a trip to mainland China.
1985: Lei Yao-hua fails in his attempt to hijack a domestic China Airlines passenger plane to Hong Kong.
1986: A nuclear reactor at the Chernobyl plant in the Ukraine explodes, spreading a radioactive cloud across Europe, and causing grave pollution in becoming the world's worst nuclear accident.
1989: Lucille Ball, American TV's queen of comedy, dies in an Los Angeles hospital after a heart attack at the age of 77.
1989: Mainland students march to central Beijing to protest government statements condemning their campaign for democracy.
1994: A China Airlines A300-600 Airbus crashes at Nagoya airport in Japan, killing 264 aboard, with only seven survivors.
1994: The first all-race elections are held in South Africa for 90 seats in the national assembly and 400 seats in provincial parliaments.
1996: Communist China, Russia and three former Soviet republics sign a treaty aimed at reducing tensions long their common borders.
1997: Peng Zhen, one of the senior leaders of communist China, dies in Beijing at the age of 95.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Be conscientious and sincere in what you say; be earnest and serious in what you do: in that way, although you might be in barbarous countries, you will get along well with men."

DOC.HEADLINE: LAWMAKERS CONCERNED ABOUT MOVEMENTS OF FOREIGN CAPITAL

TEXT.P: Amid grave concern from lawmakers about an influx of foreign capital, Securities and Futures Commission (SFC) Chairman Lin Tzong-yeong said on Monday that his agency will closely monitor subsequent developments in the local financial market.
Continued inflows of foreign capital into the local stock market is an indication that Taiwan's economic fundamentals remain sound, he said.

Lin said the Central Bank of China will monitor the levels of foreign capital moving in and out, while his agency will also keep a close watch on foreign investments in the domestic stock market. As to short-term foreign capital movements in Taiwan, the SFC head said all will be dealt with according to government regulations.

As of the end of March, US$11.2 billion worth of foreign investments had been channeled into the domestic bourse, accounting for 3.5 percent of the market's total capitalization, which Lin said is still low compared with the 10-percent level of foreign capitalization seen in other countries.
Lin made the remarks when fielding questions at the Legislative Yuan. The legislature's finance committee was screening the SFC's budget for the next fiscal year.

Some lawmakers opined that the Finance Ministry's decision in February to lift the threshold for foreign capital investments in the Taiwan's stock market to 50 percent may cause serious side effects in the local financial sector.

Pointing to Thailand as example, Legislator Yu Cheng-tao with the Democratic Progressive Party said the Southeast Asian country's financial woes effectively resulted from the lax control of huge amounts of foreign capital in its stock market.
The Finance Ministry's move to allow greater foreign investment in Taiwan's bourse may pose a threat to the local financial market, he added.

New Party Legislator Lai Shih-pao said the government must take some measures to prevent speculation by foreign players in Taiwan's stock market. A sudden withdrawal of the market's huge amount of foreign capital, currently about NT$400 billion, will undoubtedly pose a danger to the financial sector, he contended.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA FAILS TO FREE CARE WORKERS IN YUGOSLAVIA

TEXT.P: Special Australian envoy Malcolm Fraser, formerly prime minister and now chairman of the relief agency CARE Australia, has failed to secure the release of his two aid workers accused of spying for NATO in Yugoslavia.

Fraser, who was granted a meeting with the CARE workers, Steve Pratt and Peter Wallace, in Belgrade, met with Yugoslav Foreign Minister Zivadin Jovanovic for two hours of talks in a bid to secure the freedom of the two workers.
Australian Foreign Minister Alexander Downer on Sunday played down hopes the aid workers would be released, saying the latest news was "not all that encouraging."

DOC.HEADLINE: PHILIPPINE SENATOR PUSHES FOR NEGOTIATIONS WITH REBELS

TEXT.P: Philippine Sen. Loren Legarda has urged the government and the National Democratic Front (NDF) to offer new, substantive compromises in order to revive stalled peace negotiations.
Legarda made the call upon the release of the last government soldier held captive by the New People's Army.
"Today, as the crisis over the captive officers draws to a close, we enter a new stage of negotiating for peace," Legarda declared.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN ARTS PERFORMERS TO PERFORM IN BRISBANE

TEXT.P: A group of performers from National Taiwan College of Arts, and Buddhist nuns from Fukuangshan Buddhist Temple on Monday arrived in Brisbane for a series of cultural exchanges with Australian performing artists.
The Taiwanese performers and nuns will stage one performance at the Art Center in Gold Coast on April 28 in celebration of Buddha's birthday.

In addition, they will also visit Fukuangshan Temple in Brisbane and points of interest, in addition to meeting Australian performing artists at Griffith University in Brisbane for an exchange of views on how to boost cultural activities among Gold Coast, Brisbane and Taiwan.
The group is scheduled to wind up its visit to Australia on May 3.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIAN PRIME MINISTER TO MEET WITH HABIBIE

TEXT.P: Prime Minister John Howard is leaving later Monday for Bali to hold urgent talks with President B.J. Habibie as Australia increases its pressure on Indonesia to resolve the East Timor issue by indicating it might send peacekeeping troops to the former Portuguese colony.
Howard is being accompanied by Foreign Minister Alexander Downer and Defense Minister John Moore.

The meeting comes after Indonesia again refused over the weekend to allow outside peace keepers to supervise the July vote for the future of East Timor, despite an escalation of violence in the territory that has left more than 100 people dead, according to reports.
Moore on Sunday told reporters that peace keepers might be needed.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN, CANADA DELEGATIONS TO APEC MEETING HOLD TALKS

TEXT.P: A delegation from the Republic of China to an Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum conference on small- and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) on Sunday held bilateral talks with Canada's delegation to the meeting immediately after arriving in Christchurch, New Zealand.

Among those representing the Republic of China at the bilateral talks with Canada were Yang Shih-chien, a minister without portfolio, and John Ni, director-general of the Small and Medium Sized Business Administration under the Ministry of Economic Affairs. They spoke with Canada's chief delegate to the conference, Canadian parliamentary secretary Walt Lastewka.
In an interview with CNA, Ni said both sides discussed ways of further strengthening technological cooperation and boosting two-way trade.
Ni said Lastewka invited ROC businesses to take part in the 26th International Small and Medium Size Business Congress, which is scheduled to take place in Toronto between October 12 and 15.

Last year, two-way trade between Taiwan and Canada was worth US$2.73 billion with ROC exports to Canada totaling over US$1.57 billion and its imports more than US$1.16 billion, according to official figures.
The APEC meeting on SMEs will open Monday afternoon, and ministers and representatives from 20 APEC member economies will attend. By Peter Chen)

DOC.HEADLINE: CANADIAN VET SEES PARALLELS BETWEEN KOSOVO, KOREA

TEXT.P: Aging veterans of Canada's Korean War contingent were in Ottawa recently to help Ted Barris launch his new book about their fight.

The similarity between Korea and Kosovo is inescapable, said Barris on Sunday. He said Canadian adults are "worried for the young men and women who might find themselves in Kosovo in the coming weeks."

The parallels go further, said Barris. His book "Deadlock in Korea" presents the Korean conflict -- a UN police action that was never officially designated a "war" -- through the eyes of a foot soldier.
Likewise, no one has formally declared war against Yugoslavia over its actions in the rebellious province of Kosovo, he noted.
NATO has sent an armada of aircraft, including a dozen Canadian CF-18 fighters, to bomb Serbian-led Yugoslav forces into withdrawing from Kosovo.
The alliance's actions have come without the explicit authorization of the United Nations.
When North Korean communist forces invaded South Korea in 1950, the former Soviet Union boycotted UN Security Council debates on the issue, clearing the way for a vote to intervene.

DOC.HEADLINE: GODDESS OF THE SEA RETURNS TO TACHIA SHRINE
DOC.DATELINE: Taichung, central Taiwan, April 26 (CNA) (By Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: The Chinese folk deity Matsu, the Goddess of the Sea, returned to her shrine in Taichung, late Monday after an eight-day, seven-night parade throughout central Taiwan.
More than 100,000 worshippers throughout the island escorted the Goddess Matsu on the 280-kilometer annual tour, which included visits to 59 temples in Taichung, Changhua, Yunlin and Chiayi Counties.
During the eight days of religious worship, other cultural events and folklore activities, including drummer troupes and Chinese kung fu fighting, were also staged.
At abut 1:30 p.m. Sunday, the "horse-riding informants" arrived in Tachia Township, indicating that Matsu's arrival would not be long.

To welcome the return of Matsu, residents in Tachia, particularly the stores along the miles of streets surrounding the Chenlankung (Calming the Rolling Billows) Temple served free food, fruit and drinks.

With thousands of worshippers and bystanders on the streets, it took hours for the Goddess of Matsu, carried by worshippers in an sedan-chair of imperial style, to make her way through Tachia's streets. The Goddess did not return to her shrine in the Chenlankung Temple until 8:30 p.m.
In some streets, the sound of firecrackers was deafening leaving the firecrackers' residual dust laying inches thick on the ground.

On Sunday, the day the Goddess returned, about 10,000 Tachia households hosted feasts for relatives and friends from around the island. The feasts cost the township some NT$100 million (US$3.05 million).

Meanwhile, Taichung County Council Speaker Yen Ching-piao, who supports direct shipping links between Taichung and mainland China's Fujian Province for religious pilgrimages, said a Taiwan fleet carrying some 10,000 worshippers will travel through a small Japanese island chain in October to Fujian's Putien County to pay tribute to the real Matsu.
Yen's calls for "direct religious shipping links" between Taichung and Fujian have been rejected by the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council for national security reasons.

More than 100,000 Taiwan pilgrims annually visit Meizhou Island located in Fujian Province's Putien County to pay tribute to the Goddess at a century-old temple. The peak seasons are in March and September on the lunar calendar. March 3 is the anniversary of Matsu's birthday while Sept. 9 marks her deification.

Matsu has been worshipped by Chinese people, particularly those in southern provinces, since the Sung Dynasty. Tradition says that Matsu was a girl of a fishing family from Meizhou Island. She sacrificed her life by drowning herself in exchange for the lives of her father and brother, both working at sea. Not long after her sacrifice, Matsu was deified.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN HOUSEMAIDS, CARETAKERS DEMAND LABOR STANDARDS LAW COVERAGE

TEXT.P: A group of foreign housemaids and caretakers petitioned the Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) on Monday for coverage of the Labor Standards Law to better protect their rights and well-being.
More than 10 foreign housemaid and caretaker representatives from around the island staged a play in front of the CLA office on Taipei's Minsheng E. Road to highlight their plight.

Taiwan currently has over 50,000 foreign housemaids and caretakers. Kung You-chien, a volunteer at the Catholic Foreign Laborers Service Center in Chungli, some 40 kilometers south of Taipei, said foreign housemaids and caretakers have become cheap labor and even "slaves" as they are often required to get ready for work round-the-clock.
"In addition to working overtime, many foreign housemaids and caretakers are denied holidays and have been troubled by the nightmare of sexual harassment," Kung said.
She went to say that as foreign housemaids and caretakers work in individual families, they are isolated and have limited channels to seek assistance or counseling.

Worse yet, Kung said, if foreign housemaids and caretakers file complaints about their working terms or conditions, employers usually would ask government authorities to repatriate them on grounds that they are not suitable for the job.

The CLA originally agreed to offer foreign housemaids and caretakers protection provided by the Labor Standards Law. However, the Cabinet-level council broke its promise in January this year on grounds that it was technically difficult to define housemaids and caretakers' work time and other related work terms.
Kung urged the CLA to pay more attention to foreign housemaids and caretakers' plight and revise current regulations to offer them coverage of the Labor Standards Law.
Kung also suggested that the CLA ban local employers who have abused their managerial power and ignored foreign workers' rights from hiring foreign housemaids or caretakers any more.

Responding to the petition, Tsai Shao-nan, deputy director of the CLA's Department of Labor Standards, said the CLA will make an overall review of the Labor Standards Law late this year and does not rule out the possibility of including foreign housemaids and caretakers into the law's coverage.

In fact, Tsai said foreign workers' rights can be protected through other relevant regulations and employment contracts. "We hope all labor-management disputes can be resolved reasonably within a legal framework," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR UP TO NEW HIGH

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar posted a gain of NT$0.026 against the greenback on the Taipei foreign exchange market on Monday, closing at two-month high of 32.695.
Dealers attributed the appreciation to the stronger Japanese Yen.
The local currency opened at 32.715, and kept in an upward trend on the value against the US dollar throughout the session.
The trading was fluctuated between 32.715 and 32.65.
The interbank US dollar trading reached US$493 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: TIER FORECASTS 5.28 % GROWTH FOR TAIWAN ECONOMY THIS YEAR

TEXT.P: Taiwan's economy, fueled by recovering world markets and a bullish domestic bourse, will grow 5.28 percent this year, the Taiwan Institute of Economic Research (TIER) forecasted on Monday.
The private economic think-tank adjusted its forecast upward to 5.28 percent from the previous estimate of 5.01 percent in light of better international and domestic economies.
TIER said on Monday that the island's economy will grow 4.57 percent, 4.61 percent, 5.78 percent and 6.06 percent in the four quarters of this year, respectively.
TIER President Wu Rong-I cautioned that there are still uncertainties which threaten Taiwan's growth.

These uncertainties include the volatile US stock market, whether the Japanese economy has bottomed out, Taiwan's readiness for the Y2K Millennium Bug, a high ratio of overdue bank loans, stagnating public construction projects and whether privately-run enterprises can improve their financial structures, Wu said.

Meanwhile, a recent TIER survey found that 35.9 percent of companies in the island's manufacturing sector think business will improve during the next six months, while 11.5 percent say business will decline.
In similar survey conducted by TIER in March, 44.9 percent of manufacturing companies said they expected business to pick up in the following six months, while 14.4 percent saw a decline.
In the latest survey, 52.6 percent of manufacturing companies said business will remain stable in the next six months, compared with 41.8 percent in March.

DOC.HEADLINE: COAST GUARD ADMINISTRATION TO BE OPERATIONAL IN JANUARY

TEXT.P: Republic of China Defense Minister Tang Fei said on Monday that the projected "coast guard administration" will formally begin operation next January.
He made the remarks while reporting on the progress of the new administration to the Organic Law Committee of the Legislative Yuan.
Tang said that a committee, headed by him, will have finished an organizational statute for the "coast guard administration" by May.
He added that all preparatory work will be finished by July 1, while personnel and training decisions will be completed between July and September.

According to the defense minister, the new administration will have six divisions (planning, patrol, communications, international affairs, information, and logistics), three departments, a mission command center, and a secretariat.

Tang said the "coast guard administration" in peacetime will handle crimes committed on water, patrol coastal areas, inspect vessels, control smuggling as well as handle illegal entry and departure cases.
During wartime, he said, the "coast guard administration" will be under the direct control of the Defense Ministry.

Most the new administration's staff will come from the existing Coast Guard Command under the Defense Ministry, the National Police Administration (NPA) under the Interior Ministry, and customs units under the Finance Ministry.
The NPA and the three branches of the armed forces will dispatch an aviation task force to carry out air missions when requested.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP PRESIDENTIAL HOPEFUL RETURNS AFTER US VISIT

TEXT.P: Former Taipei Mayor Chen Shui-bian said he is willing to serve as the top campaigner of former DPP Chairman Hsu Hsin-liang if Hsu manages to win the opposition Democratic Progressive Party's nomination to run in the next presidential election.
Chen, one of the most popular DPP politicians, made the statement shortly after his return from a US visit, part of his global "journey of learning" aimed at boosting his own presidential bid.
Chen said he would not like to see Hsu quit the DPP to run in the coming presidential election as an independent.

Hsu, a two-term DPP chairman, said on Sunday after a grueling eight-day-seven-night pilgrimage from Taichung County to Chiayi County along with an icon of Matsu, the Chinese Goddess of the Sea that he has come to a decision on his future career. "I'll make public my decision a week later," Hsu told the local press.
Many observers said Hsu's Sunday remarks signal his withdrawal from the DPP to run in the next presidential election as an independent.

"I earnestly hope that such speculation will prove untrue," said Chen, who has consistently led Hsu in approval ratings in various public opinion polls concerning who stands better chances to win the 2000 presidential election.
Chen began his global "journey of learning" in March, which already took him to Japan, South Korea, Mongolia and the United States.
During his just-concluded US trip, Chen said he visited Washington, New York and Los Angeles.

"I managed to meet with 12 American lawmakers, Clinton administration officials in charge of East Asian affairs and noted US think tank research fellows to exchange views on the possibilities of Taiwan's participation in the US-proposed theater missile defense (TMD) system, the World Trade Organization and many other important topics," Chen said.
In addition, Chen gave three interviews to US news media and met with Taiwanese community leaders in the United States.

DOC.HEADLINE: EX-CHAIRMAN HSU HSIN-LIANG AVOIDS DPP LEADERS

TEXT.P: Hsu Hsin-liang, former chairman of the major opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), who reportedly will announce his decision to leave the DPP and launch his own run for the presidency this week, avoided DPP leaders on Monday.
The DPP Central Committee, after holding an emergency meeting, tried to prevent Hsu from leaving the party.

Yu Shyi-kun, the DPP's secretary-general, paid a visit to Hsu Monday, at the behest of DPP Chairman Lin Yi-hsiung. Yu was accompanied by Kuo Chun-ming, the DPP's director-general of the Dept. of Organization Affairs, and Chou Yi-cheng, acting director-general of the Dept. of Cultural Affairs.
However, due to not having an appointment, the trio was greeted by Wang Chun-fang, a policy researcher for Hsu's party faction, causing some embarrassment.

Nevertheless, the party's secretary-general stressed that DPP Chairman Lin hopes to meet "Chairman Hsu" in person whenever Hsu is available. Yu was hopeful the meeting would occur in a couple of days.
Meanwhile, Kuo told the press that "Chairman Hsu" is a super member of the DPP and that all members hope to keep him in the party.
Staff workers at Hsu's office said that after participating for eight days in a religious pilgrimage, Hsu is now resting.
Ever since Hsu' departure from the DPP looked like inevitable, the DPP Central Committee has tried to stop him. DPP Chairman Lin tried unsuccessfully to contact Hsu on Sunday, said DPP officials.
The DPP Central Committee has concluded Hsu's departure would harm the party's bid for the presidency in next year's election.
The DPP is currently weighing how to minimize the impact of Hsu's leaving.
Ranking officials stressed the opposition party is not relinquishing its efforts to dissuade Hsu from quitting.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCK MARKET UP 0.2 PERCENT

TEXT.P: Taiwan stock prices closed 0.2 percent higher Monday, on heavy buying in the electronics sector due to Intel corporation president Craig Barrett's Taipei visit.
The benchmark Taiwan Stock Exchange Weighted Price Index rose 16.29 points to close at 7,629.09 points.
Monday saw a total of 4.15 billion shares change hands on a turnover of NT$134.84 billion (US$ 4.12 billion), down from the previous session's NT$150.00 billion.
Advancers led decliners 241 to 206, with 59 issues unchanged.
Among the eight major stock categories, electronics and construction shares posted the largest gains of the day, both surging 1.5 percent.
Paper and pulp stocks rose 0.9 percent, foodstuff issues climbed 0.4 percent, and textiles shares gained 0.2 percent.
The financial sector registered the largest loss of the day, dropping 1.5 percent. Cement shares and plastic and chemical stocks both fell 0.7 percent.
The over-the-counter market saw a slight gain of 0.56 point, closing at 176.78 points, with a turnover of NT$5.06 billion.
The TAIEX Capitalization Weighted Price Index Futures (TAIEX Index Futures) for May went down 23 points to close at 7,630, with 3,108 contract transactions.

TAIEX Index Futures for June decreased 14 points to close at 7,651 points, while those for September gained 4 points to close at 7,685. Contract transactions for the two months totaled 122 and 5, respectively.
December futures advanced 13 points to close at 7,693 points, with 2 contract transactions. Futures for next March increased 38 points, closing at 7,800, with 2 contract transactions.

Reference levels provided by the Taiwan Mercantile International Exchange for TAIEX Index Futures trading on Monday were 7,653 points for May, 7,665 points for June, 7,681 points for September, 7,680 points for December, and 7,762 points for next March.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHUNGHWA TELECOM'S STOCK SELL-OFF PROTESTED

TEXT.P: Transportation and Communication Minister Lin Feng-cheng on Monday defended his ministry's plan to sell of part of Chunghwa Telecom's share to public.

He said at a legislature cmmmittee meeting that the move to sell Chunghwa's share is aimed at strengthening the company's competitive edge in the face of the opening of local telecommunication market.

The committee on Monday started to review the Ministry of Transportation and Communication's (MOTC) 1999 year budget. According to MOTC's budget, an initial sell-off of NT$127.3 billion of Chunghwa Telecom stocks will step up its privatization progress.

But legislators from both the ruling Kuomintang and opposition parties strongly questioned the move, saying once the budget plan has been passed, the legislature may lose its right to supervise Chunghwa Telecom's operations.
Legislators went on to say that the estimated price for selling Chunghwa shares was too cheap and accused the MOTC of unfairly favoring consortiums by setting a lower-than-standard share price.

Lin explained that even after the sell, the shares held by the government and Chunghwa employees will still surpass 50 percent. He added that the move is aimed at strengthening Chunghwa's competitiveness against local and foreign competitors.

Earlier Monday, Chunghwa Telecom's labor union, which also strongly opposes the stock sale, gathered in front of the Legislative Yuan to protest against a government plan to compensate its budget deficit by selling Chunghwa's shares.
The estimated 5,000 protesters mobilized by the union used mobile telephones to simultaneously call the Executive Yuan in an attempt to paralyze the Yuan's telephone system. (Amanda Chang)

DOC.HEADLINE: NUCLEAR POWER PLANTS WILL PASS Y2K CRISIS: AEC

TEXT.P: The Cabinet-level Atomic Energy Council (AEC) said on Monday according to off- and on-line test results, the nation's three nuclear power plants will be able to pass the Y2K crisis.

The AEC's Department of Nuclear Regulation (DONR) said the power plants have conducted three overall tests of their computer systems since May, 1997 and have compiled a list of the equipment and systems that might be affected by the Y2K bug.
The three off-line test results showed the computer systems can pass the Y2K test under off-line conditions, the DONR pointed out.
The AEC also required each of the power plants to conduct on-line tests of their computer systems. The first computer mainframe to pass the test was the third nuclear power plant's second generator.
The DONR said they will continue testing the four power generators of the first and second nuclear power plants. All tests should be finished by July of this year .

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP LEADERS WANT PARTY CRISIS MANAGEMENT MEETING

TEXT.P: As former Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairman Hsu Hsin-liang's quitting the party seems inevitable, more than 20 DPP members issued a joint statement on Monday urging the party to call a crisis management meeting.
Among them are several party doyens, such as former Chairmen Huang Hsin-chieh, Shih Ming-teh and Yao Chia-wen, and former Kaohsiung Magistrate Yu Chen Yueh-ying.

The joint statement termed Hsu's possible quitting the party as the "worst crisis" the party has suffered since establishment, and voiced deep disappointment over the handling of the case by party leadership.

It calls for the convening of an emergency meeting, with Huang Hsin-chieh serving as chairman, to discuss how to cope with the situation. The emergency meeting will also have the participation of the party's past chairmen and representatives from various factions.

It is widely speculated that Hsu has decided to quit the DPP to run as an independent in next year's presidential election as the DPP leadership is expected to support former Taipei Mayor Chen Shui-bian as the party's presidential candidate.

At a press conference called to issue the joint statement, DPP Legislator Wang Tou criticized the DPP leadership, headed by Chairman Lin Yi-hsiung, for its failure to keep Hsu in the party. He described Hsu as an "excellent man."
Yu Chen Yueh-ying said that Hsu's plan to quit the DPP has created a crisis within the opposition camp. She hoped Hsu would remain in the party.
DPP Legislator Chen Ching-chun said that Hsu's quitting the party will be a loss not only to the DPP, but also to the Taiwanese people.
The joint statement said that Hsu has given many constructive proposals for party development, but did not receive proper treatment in return from the party leadership.
It added that the DPP leadership has paid little attention to Hsu's ideas on Taiwan's political development, and these factors prompted Hsu to quit the party.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STRAIT NOT WIDE ENOUGH FOR DEMARCATING MEDIAN LINE

TEXT.P: Republic of China Defense Minister Tang Fei said on Monday that the Taiwan Strait is not wide enough for making a median line between Taiwan and mainland China.
Tang made the remarks while replying a question raised by Democratic Progressive Party Legislator Lin Cho-shui before the Organic Law Committee of the Legislative Yuan.
He said that the narrowest cross-Taiwan Strait distance at low ebb is less than 2,000 meters, which is not wide enough for making a median line.
Tang went on to say that it's difficult for Taiwan and the mainland to follow international laws to demarcate a median line on the Taiwan Strait.
Likewise, the development of Taipei-Beijing relations has not reached yet the level for the two sides to discuss the demarcation of the median line, Tang added.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC MINISTER HOLDS TALKS WITH VN, NZ COUNTERPARTS
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 26 (CNA) (By Victor Lai) (By Peter Chen)

TEXT.P: Canberra, April 26 (CNA): Republic of China Minister without Portfolio Yang Shih-chien on Monday held separate talks with his counterparts from New Zealand and Vietnam on ways to strengthen trade and cooperation among the three countries' small and medium sized enterprises.

During the meetings, held on the sidelines of the APEC (Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation forum) small and medium enterprises ministers' conference, also Yang discussed with his counterparts on such issues as investment and technological exchange.
Yang is scheduled to hold similar talks with his counterparts from Thailand and the United States on Tuesday.
On Monday afternoon, business representatives from New Zealand, Indonesia and Taiwan held extensive discussions to introduce the investment climate in the respective countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: STOCK INSIDER TRADING EXIST: OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: Chairman Lin Tzong-yeong of the Securities and Futures Commission on Monday said that he would not deny the existence of insider trading in Taiwan's stock market.
Lin made the remarks at a joint session of Legislative Yuan's Financial and Budget committees, during which lawmakers fiercely criticized the insider trading in the market.

Legislator Yen Chin-fu of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), said that before the local share market closed for the Chinese lunar new year holidays on Feb., 10, about 40,000,000 shares of the Chang Hwa Commercial Bank, 70,000,000 shares of the First Commercial Bank and 50,000,000 shares of the Hwa Nan Commercial Bank were traded, compared to their average daily trading volumes of 10,000,000 shares, 20,000,000 shares and 9,000,000 shares, respectively.
The Finance Ministry, coincidentally, announced on Feb. 19 a cut in banks' business tax from 5 percent to 2 percent and a reduction of bank reserve ratio, Yen said.
Yen doubted that insider trading was involved in the case from which the businesses run by Taiwan's Kuomintang had profited greatly.

Citing reports by the Swiss-based International Institute for Management and Development (IMD) that Taiwan ranked 38th in the world in 1996 and 47th in 1998 in terms of its crackdown on stock insider trading, New Party (NP) Legislator Lai Shih-pao also rapped the commission for its inability to stop the irregularities in the stock market.

Over the past three years, Lai said, the Securities and Futures Commission only handed over 34 cases of suspected insider trading to the prosecutors for investigations, with four of them being indicted, and only one convicted.
The poor record of Taiwan's effort to guard against unfair stock trading actually has turned the island into "the haven of insider trading," he said.
Both Yen and Lai also accused KMT Business Management Committee Chairman Liu Tai-ying of trying to influence stock markets by often publicly urging the investors to buy or sell specific stocks.
Lin, however, said that his commission will redouble efforts to stop insider trading.

DOC.HEADLINE: POLICE, PROSECUTORS VOW TO KICK CRIMES OUT OF SCHOOL CAMPUS

TEXT.P: National Police Administration Director-General Ting Yuan-chin on Monday urged students to report to police immediately if they are menaced by gangsters.

Ting also appealed to parents to extend better care to their children, saying families, schools and the entire society all have the responsibility to prevent violence and organized crimes from penetrating into school campus.

Ting made the remarks at an inter-agency symposium on ways to prevent campus crimes. Officials from the Judicial Yuan, the Education Ministry, the Interior Ministry and National Youth Commission were present at the meeting to discuss ways to kick organized crimes and gang activities out of schools.
Meanwhile Taipei prosecutors also vowed on Sunday to purge away organized crimes from school campus, and they urged students not to be utilized by criminal rings as scapegoats.

The prosecutors made the remarks after local media reported that gang syndicates have penetrated into high schools and colleges in Taipei by providing students with loans and subsidiaries to lure them to join their organizations.
According to the reports, some gang syndicates even offered financial loans and monthly subsidiaries to students as part of their efforts to recruit new members.
College students recruited by criminal organizations in return will have to work for the mafia groups after they graduate, the papers reported.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SEEKS TO HOST APEC SEMINARS
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 26 (CNA) (By Flor Wang) (By Peter Chen)

TEXT.P: Canberra, April 26 (CNA): The Republic of China is playing an active role in trying to win the rights to host at least three workshops for all member economies of the Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation forum between this October and June 2000.

In an interview with the CNA on Monday, John Ni, director-general of the Small and Medium Sized Business Administration under the Ministry of Economic Affairs of Taiwan, said the Chinese Taipei delegation has won the rights to host the APEC Human Resources workshop to be held in Kaohsiung in October this year.
At least 100 delegates, with half of them coming from all the other APEC members, will take part in the Kaohsiung meeting, he said.

He said the ROC delegates also will host an SME Assistance Guidance and Dialogue Workshop in Taipei in August to promote exchanges of views and cooperation among small and medium sized business between Taiwan and other APEC member countries.
He added that the similar workshop held last year in Taipei was attended by 23 delegates from APEC and had impressive results.
"This year we will host the same workshop so that more business relations will be done to strengthen and boost trade and cooperation among all the APEC economies," Ni said.
In addition, he said the ROC delegation also is trying to gain support from participating delegates from other countries to host an E-commerce Impact workshop in Taipei in June 2000.

"This is an important workshop because an increasing number of business and cooperation projects can now be achieved through E-commerce. We hope we can organize such meeting to raise our profile because we have strong information industry," Ni said.
He said all participating delegates discussed on Monday how to strengthen their small and medium sized enterprises within their own countries and with other APEC members as well.

DOC.HEADLINE: EX-HIJACKERS TRIED FOR ATTEMPT TO REPEAT OLD TRICK

TEXT.P: The trial of four former mainland hijackers, charged for trying to commandeer the Taiwan airplane which lifted them to Kinmen for repatriation to mainland China, began at the Taipei District Count on Monday.
Jan Jyh-horng, deputy secretary general of the Straits Exchange Foundation, testified at Monday's trial against the four defendants Yang Minteh, Lin Wenchiang, Wang Zhihua and Shi Yuepo.

Jan was wounded by Yang with a home-made knife while escorting a group of convicted mainland hijackers to Kinmen aboard a plane on Feb. 8. Yang and all the other hijackers have served out their jail terms in Taiwan and were ready to be deported.

In Monday's hearing, Jan restated his willingness to exact Yang's criminal responsibility for wounding him-- a crime which would be pursued only on the victim's complaint-- even if the evidences were not enough to convict Yang of attempting to commandeer a plane.

Jan told the court that Yang persuaded him to transfer to a seat beside Yang during the flight under the excuse that he wanted to file a complaint and suddenly attacked him with a sharpen toilet flush handle.
Although Yang was immediately overpowered by the escort police, the attack left a deep laceration on Jan's face.

An ensuing inquiry found that Yang and the three other defendants conspired to block the repatriation by controlling the plane with force and diverting it to the US island of Guam, according to court document.
The three other accomplices, however, didn't come to Yang's aid as Yang was subdued almost immediately, said prosecutors who presided over the inquiry.
In his testimony, Jan said he was not sure of Yang's motive to attack him but felt Yang intending to kidnap him rather than hijack the plane.

All the defendants denied they conspired to hijack the plane at the hearing. Yang said he wounded Jan to vent his anger over the SEF for what Yang said SEF's climbdown on its promise of not deporting his son Yang Yang, with whom Yang and his wife took with them when they hijacked a plane to Taiwan in 1993.
The three other defendants said they confessed to police about their conspiracy with the hope of staying in Taiwan even if that meant longer jail terms.
They remained in custody after the hearing.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTEL DONATES COMPUTER EQUIPMENT TO TAIWAN UNIVERSITIES

TEXT.P: US computer giant Intel donated NT$13 million (US$3.93 million) worth of equipment to National Taiwan University and National Chiao Tung University, on Monday.

In a donation ceremony held at the Taiwan University, Intel President Craig Barrett presented the equipment to Chen Wei-Jao, president of Taiwan University and Chang Chun-yen, president of Chiao Tung University

Speaking at the ceremony, Barrett praised the two universities for trainging many talented computer engineers and designers who contributed greatly to the island's leading role in the world's information industry.

The donated equipment will be used to equip a server laboratory and a work station laboratory at each of the two universities. The new laboratories will open around the clock and has a capacity to be used by 300 students in a semester, said the two presidents.

After the ceremony, Barrett delivered to a packed audience a speech on digital economy which was relayed via network link-up to Chiao Tung University in Hsinchu County and Sun Yat-Sen University in Kaohsiung City.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTEL CEO SAYS TAIWAN IT INDUSTRY'S FUTURE LIES IN INTERNET

TEXT.P: Greater access to the Internet will be instrumental to the further development of Taiwan's information industry, said Craig Barrett, president and CEO of computer chip giant Intel Corp. on Monday in Taipei.
Internet access is very important for every economy to grow and prosper, said Barrett at a press conference at a Taipei hotel.
Barrett, who is on a tour of Asia-Pacific region, added that any country that wants to be an economic hub has to have bandwidth."
Barrett predicted a promising future for Internet by citing the case of the United States of America, saying the revenue of internet-related businesses in the United States would double in two years.
He said that the electronics business through Internet will be able to generate a total of US$1 trillion revenue in a couple of years.

With regard to Taiwan's IT industry, he said with the solid foundation the island has laid in the manufacturing of computer parts and components, Taiwan should turn to Internet-related products and gradually transfer itself to a Internet solution provider.

Barrett also gave a speech titled "Winning in the Digital Economy" in the National Taiwan University (NTU) later Monday. He also donated NT$13 million to help NTU and Chiao Tung University set up advanced laboratory of servers and workstations. (by Amanda Chang)

DOC.HEADLINE: BASEBALL COACH HSU SHENG-MING STABBED

TEXT.P: Hsu Sheng-ming, coach-in-chief for the Dragons in the Chinese Professional Baseball League (CPBL), was stabbed in the back by four unidentified men Monday morning on the street near his home.
Hsu got wounds on his buttocks and thigh and several cuts on his arms while fighting back with an umbrella.
"When a guy approaches me, I thought it's a maniac; but soon three more men showed up and attacked me," Hsu recalled. Hsu was later rushed to the Taipei Municipal Yangming Hospital for treatment.
The incident shocked the Dragons, which condemned the violence in a news release, urging the relevant authorities to take moves to prevent violences from ruining Taiwan's professional baseball sport.
Police said that baseball gambling disputes may be behind the attack. Hsu was reportedly warned not to talk too much against baseball gamblings.

Hsu has recently accused a former Dragons player of being involved in gamblings on baseball games, police said. Besides, gambling rings were also reportedly forced Hsu last May to intentionally let his team to lose in a match.

DOC.HEADLINE: HEADS OF SEF AND ARATS WILL MEET DESPITE OF BEIJING'S PROBLEMS

TEXT.P: Although dogged by problems at home and abroad, Beijing is believed to be pressing ahead with a slated high-level meeting with Taipei, said Su Chi, chairman of the Mainland Affairs Council, on Monday.

In a speech delivered at a forum held at National Taiwan Normal University, Su said that Beijing is beset with problems, such as its delayed entrance into the World Trade Organization, its poor human rights records, its repression in Tibet, and its alleged stealing of US nuclear weapon secrets.

Although those problems has diverted Beijing's attention from the proposed meeting between Koo Chen-fu, chairman of the Taiwan's Strait Exchange Foundation (SEF) and its mainland counterpart, Association for Relations ACross the Taiwan Strait Chairman Wang Daohan, Su said he believes Beijing will not renege on its promise to have the meeting take place in the fall.
He said that the SEF will mark on Wednesday the sixth anniversary of the first Koo-Wang meeting in 1993 in a bid to boost the momentum for their second encounter.

DOC.HEADLINE: VP TOUTS NATIONAL INFORMATION INFRASTRUCTURE INITIATIVE AT FORUM

TEXT.P: Sound government policies and a dynamic information technology industry explains Taiwan's success to turn itself into a regional science and technology hub, said Vice President Lien Chan on Monday.
Speaking at the Technology Forum organized by the US computer giant Intel, Lien said that Taiwan produced only 1 percent of the world semiconductors 10 years ago.
But in 1998, the island ranked as the fourth largest contender in the global semiconductor industry by churning out 9 percent of the world's total.
He said that the government and private sector are now jointly developing 44 projects with the purpose to set up a information superhighway for the island.
The Technology Forum was presided over by Intel's President Dr. Craig Barrett.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies Tuesday are as follows:
The Central Daily News:
Japan will approve defense cooperation pact with the United States; the cooperation scope will cover Taiwan Strait disputes.
The China Times:
The 21 cities and counties under the Taiwan provincial government will share a total of NT$163.8 billion of central government grants to local governments.
The United Daily News:
President Lee Teng-hui said no matter who will be next president, Taiwan will be able to remain stable.
The Liberty Times:
Agricultural corporations and associations will be allowed to buy "important farmlands."
The Commons Daily:
The main opposition Democratic Progressive Party will discuss a draft resolution on Taiwan's future.
The China Post:
Intel CEO urges Taiwan to keep pace with Internet.
The China News:
Fund giants plan larger presence in Taiwan; Fidelity, Morgan Stanley move to upgrade Taiwan operations.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Tuesday, April 27, or the 12th day of the third month of the Year of the Rabbit according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past.
1521: Ferdinand Magellan, Portuguese navigator, is killed by the inhabitants on the Island of Mactan in the Philippines.
1737: Edward Gibbon, British historian who wrote the six-volume classic text "The Decline and Fall of the Roman Empire," is born.
1791: Samuel F. B. Morse, American painter and inventor, is born. A portraitist whose subjects included Lafayette, he refined and patented the telegraph and developed the telegraphic code that bears his name.
1822: Ulysses S. Grant, the 18th president of the United States, is born. After his victorious Vicksburg campaign, he was made commander in chief of the Union Army and accepted the surrender of Confederate Gen. Robert E. Lee at Appomattox in 1965 to end the Civil War.
1887: The world's first surgical removal of the appendix, an operation known as an appendectomy, is performed by American surgeon Dr. Thomas Morton in Philadelphia.
1911: An uprising in Canton is failed when revolutionaries led by Huang Shing are defeated by the local garrison. The battle in Canton is the 10th uprising directed by Dr. Sun Yat-sen after he launched a revolutionary movement against the Ching court in the late 19th century.
1937: The new Golden Gate suspension bridge linking the city of San Francisco with Marin County reaches completion after four years.
1945: Allies reject peace offers by German SS chief Heinrich Himmler, insisting on unconditional German surrender.
1950: The Communist Party is outlawed in Australia under a bill introduced by Prime Minister Robert Menzies.
1950: The British government officially recognizes the state of Israel.
1956: Rocco Marciano, known as "Rocky," American boxer who won the world heavyweight championship in 1952 and defended it six times, retires as undefeated world heavyweight boxing champion.
1959: Liu Shao-chi is elected "state chairman" of communist China.
1960: The Republic of China establishes diplomatic relations with the Republic of Togo.
1960: Syngman Rhee resigns as president of South Korea, ending his 12-year rule.
1962: Hsieh Chin wins the "best director" award in a film festival held for the first time in mainland China.
1972: After a journey to the moon, US Apollo 16 spacecraft and three astronauts make a safe landing in the Pacific.
1972: Kwame Nkrumah, Ghanaian president who was deposed in 1966 by a military coup while in mainland China, dies in Bucharest, Hungary.
1978: President Mohammed Daoud is killed in a bloody coup and replaced by Afghanistan's first communist ruler, Nur Mohammed Taraki, who proclaims the Democratic Republic of Afghanistan.
1992: The International Monetary Fund and World Bank approve the membership of Russia and 12 other former Soviet republics.
1993: Koo Chen-fu, chairman of the Straits Exchange Foundation, and Wang Daohan, chairman of the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits, meet in Singapore and hold talks in what is the first official contact between Taipei and Peking since 1949.
1997: The world's longest road-rail suspension bridge, linking Hong Kong to its new offshore airport, is formally opened.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "When you meet the proper person to speak to and do not speak out, you lose your opportunity; but when you meet one who is not a proper person to speak to and you speak to him, you waste your words. A man of intelligence never loses his opportunity, neither does he waste his words."

DOC.HEADLINE: CPC PLANS ANOTHER OIL PRICE HIKE

TEXT.P: The state-run Chinese Petroleum Corp. (CPC) may soon raise prices for its products again as international crude oil prices have risen significantly in recent weeks, company sources said on Tuesday.

A senior CPC executive said crude oil prices have been skyrocketing since NATO began air strikes on Yugoslavia over the Kosovo issue in late March. For instance, the price for Western Texas crude oil already surged to US$18 per barrel, far higher than US$16 originally predicted by the CPC.

The executive, who preferred anonymity, said the company's average crude oil import cost has ranged between US$12 a barrel and US$14 since the beginning of this year. "We expect international crude oil prices to continue rising in the months ahead," he added.

The CPC announced a 2.69 percent hike for its oil profucts on April 6. The adjustment range was based on two terms: the crude oil price was US$11.67 a barrel and the New Taiwan dollar's exchange rate against the greenback was NT$33.14 vs. US$1.

"As international crude oil prices have continued rising since then, we do not rule out the possibility of adjusting our prices upward once again," the executive said, adding that the company may announce its final decision next Tuesday.
The executive further said that the adjustment range will not exceed 3 percent.

He pointed out that the recent crude oil price rise in the international market can be attributed to two reasons: an explosion at a US oil refinery which originally could produce 410,000 tons of oil products, and NATO bombing on Yugoslavia has raised US demand for fuel oil. The US demand for oil has increased by an average of 200,000 barrels a day since the beginning of NATO air strikes on Yugoslavia.
