DOC.HEADLINE: SWAZI QUEEN MOTHER SAID IN TAIWAN FOR MEDICAL CARE

TEXT.P: Swaziland's Queen Mother, is recovering from a spinal operation at a Taiwan hospital, it was reported Monday.

South African Press Association (SAPA) reported from Mbabane that the Queen Mother's absence was noticed for the first time by the public when she did not attend an annual Easter service at the Somholo national stadium with Swazi King Mswati III.
A palace spokesman explained that she was unwell and that doctors had told her to remain indoors.
The report said this was the second trip the Queen Mother made to Taiwan to receive medical treatment. On her previous trip two years ago, she was treated for a minor heart condition.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA WITHDRAWS WTO COMPLAINTS AGAINST JAPAN
DOC.DATELINE: Johannesburg, April 26 (CNA) (By J. S. Chang) (By Peter Chen)

TEXT.P: Canberra, April 27 (CNA): Australia has withdrawn its complaints to the World Trade Organization (WTO) against Japan's 390 percent rice tariff after threats of a trade war affected wheat and rice exports.

Deputy Prime Minister Tim Fischer, who also serves as trade minister, on Monday said the decision was taken because Australia faced the prospect of "a major blockage developing with rice and wheat," which could have affected its next tender for rice exports to Japan in May.
He said Australia risked a "stalemate" and could "lose out commercially" if it did not withdraw its case with the WTO.
Despite its withdrawal, Australia remains opposed to Japan's steep tariff on imported rice.
Japan imports rice from the United States and Thailand in addition to Australia.
On the bright side, Australia expects to share the rice market in mainland China after Beijing announced recently it would open its market after joining the WTO later this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIAN EXCHANGES MERGE TO COMPETE WITH ASIAN BOURSES
DOC.DATELINE: Johannesburg, April 26 (CNA) (By J. S. Chang) (By Peter Chen) (By Peter Chen)

TEXT.P: Canberra, April 27 (CNA): The Australian Stock Exchange (ASE) and the Sydney Futures Exchange (SFE) have reached a US$1 billion merger agreement that creates a new financial giant to rival Hong Kong and Singapore.
The agreement will bring together two monopoly players in Australia's capital markets as well as the New Zealand Futures and Options Exchange, which is owned by the Sydney Futures Exchange.
Market analysts said the merger would, if approved, mark a significant step in the development of Australia as a regional financial center to compete with Singapore and Hong Kong.
After Japan, the Australian Stock Exchange ranks about equal with Hong Kong as the region's biggest stock exchange and the SFE is the region's largest futures and options exchange.
The merged entity would be better able to compete for international listings and trading volume, analysts said.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA ISSUES WARNING OVER EAST TIMOR
DOC.DATELINE: Johannesburg, April 26 (CNA) (By J. S. Chang) (By Peter Chen) (By Peter Chen) (By Peter Chen)

TEXT.P: Canberra, April 27 (CNA): Australia's Prime Minister John Howard and Foreign Minister Alexander Downer have issued warnings to rogue army chiefs in Indonesia against challenging President B.J. Habibie's authority on the issue of East Timor.

Howard, Downer and Defense Minister John Moore on Monday arrived in Bali and will start talks on Tuesday with Habibie and General Wironto and Foreign Minister Ali Alatas on ways to resolve the East Timor problems in the wake of escalating violence.
On the eve of the talks, Downer on Monday night issued a stern warning to sections of the Indonesian military backing the violence in East Timor, saying the violence must stop.

Downer's warning came amid growing speculation in Jakarta that Habibie has told the military that unless it stopped the killings, he would order the armed forces to leave East Timor, which may trigger a civil war in the territory.

Downer said it's important that "all people in the Indonesian military, at all levels, respect the Indonesian Constitution, respect the position of the President of Indonesia, recognize that there are elections coming up ... that will allow people to express their views about the future of the country."

Howard is expected to seek a firm guarantee that Jakarta will fully implement the U.N.-supervised election in East Timor, including the use of up to 100 foreign police. Howard's other goal is to seek Habibie's commitment to an impartial and peaceful vote in July and accept the need for an orderly transition to either autonomy or independence for the territory.
Last week, Howard and Habibie both agreed that East Timor should finally be offered the option of independence. Both want this to be done in an orderly and peaceful manner, supervised by the U.N.
But elements of Indonesian military have decided they will not allow East Timor to become independent, fearing independence would fuel separatist sentiments in Aceh and Irian Jaya.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHUNGHWA TELECOM BECOMES WORLD'S FIFTH-LARGEST ISP

TEXT.P: Chunghwa Telecom announced on Tuesday that its HiNet (Internet in Taiwan) subscribers have topped 1 million, making it the fifth largest Internet Services Provider (ISP) in the world.

Chunghwa Telecom held a duel celebration party Tuesday to mark HiNet's fourth anniversary and reaching 1 million subscribers, with Vice Transportation and Communications Minister Mao Chih-kuo and other government officials in attendance.

Bill Gates, chairman and CEO of Microsoft, also extended his congratulations to Chunghwa Telecom through the Internet, saying that "within a decade, we believe most Americans and the people in Taiwan will be living the Web lifestyle. It will be natural for people to turn to the Web to get their news, to learn, to be entertained and to be in touch with one other."

Noting that reaching 1 million subscribers is a major milestone, Gates said that with the service and ADSL broadband infrastructure HiNet offers, he expects the number of subscribers to continue to grow.
Steven Chen, chairman of Chunghwa Telecom, said the invention of the Internet has dramatically changed the way man communicates, and that Internet use is a global trend.
Chen noted that as of January, world Internet users topped 150 million, with 79 million in the United States, followed by 14 million in Japan. Taiwan ranks eighth with more than 3 million users.
Chunghwa Telecom also presented Chen Ming-sung, the 1 millionth HiNet subscriber and the head of an engineering company, with a coupon worth NT$100,000 (US$3,050).
According to a survey by the Executive Yuan, there were 3.29 million internet users in Taiwan as of February.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR UP

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar registered a modest gain against the greenback in Taipei on Tuesday, rising NT$0.013 to close at 32.682.
The local currency opened at the day's low of 32.72 and had a high of 32.672.
The interbank US dollar trading reached US$382 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN FISHING BOATS ACCUSED OF INTRUDING INTO FALKLAND WATERS

TEXT.P: The British Trade and Cultural Office (BTCO) has lodged a protest to the ROC's Council of Agriculture (COA) over Taiwan deep-sea fishing vessels' alleged intrusion into waters near the Falkland Islands, a British colony.

COA officials said on Tuesday that BTCO Deputy Director-General Debbie Clarke and Peter Wickenden, BTCO economic division chief, paid a visit to the COA on April 14 to express their concern about the issue.

The two BTCO officials accused Taiwan squid fishing ships of having illegally operated in the Falkland waters. On April 22, BTCO Director-General David Coates also wrote the COA, saying Falkland authorities have secured the British government's approval to use armed patrol ships to crack down on intruding Taiwan squid fishing boats.
Coates further said in the letter that Falkland authorities do not rule out the possibility of opening fire at intruding Taiwan fishing vessels.

He pointed out that without operating licenses issued by Falkland authorities, foreign fishing boats are banned from operating in Falkland's economic waters because such operations will not only affected Britain's rights but will also spoil its fishery resources conservation programs.

"We would not tolerate continued illegal operations by any foreign fishing vessels in Falkland waters," Coates said in his letter, adding that he hopes the Republic of China government will immediately demand its deep-sea fishing boats not to illegally operate in Falkland waters any more. Otherwise, Coates said, Falkland patrol ships will open fire and arrest intruding Taiwan squid fishing vessels.
The British Trade and Cultural Office represents British interests in Taiwan in the absence of former diplomatic ties between the two countries.
In response to the British protest, COA officials said they have urged Taiwan deep-sea fishing ships not to illegally operate in waters near both the Falkland Islands and Argentina.
Meanwhile, the officials said the COA has asked British authorities to use more moderate ways to disperse intruding Taiwan fishing boats instead of opening fire at them.

Taiwan currently has more than 100 deep-sea squid fishing vessels and its annual squid catch is second only to Japan's in the world. The open seas in the Southwestern Pacific and economic waters of Falkland Islands and Argentina are the ROC's main squid fishing grounds.
Squid is a traversing migratory fish. In the past, ROC deep-sea fishing boats often accidentally or unintentionally intruded into other countries' economic waters while fishing squid in open seas.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCKS, FUTURES DECLINE

TEXT.P: Taiwan share prices closed 1 percent lower on Tuesday as the index retreated for consolidation after 11 straight weeks of steady gains.
The benchmark Taiwan Stock Exchange Weighted Price Index fell 78.96 points to close at 7,550.13 points.
Tuesday saw a total of 3.99 billion shares change hands on a turnover of NT$127.40 billion (US$3.89 billion), down from the previous session's NT$134.84 billion.
Among the eight major stock categories, foodstuff issues posted the only gains of the day, climbing 1.2 percent. The paper and pulp sector suffered the largest losses, dropping 2.1 percent.
Cement stocks were down 1.9 percent, followed by financial shares, which fell 1.5 percent. Plastic and chemical issues went down 1.2 percent.
Electronics shares declined 0.9 percent, construction stocks slipped 0.2 percent and textile issues posted a slight drop of 0.1 percent.
The over-the-counter market suffered a loss of 2.62 points, closing at 174.16 points, with a turnover of NT$5.45 billion.
TAIEX Capitalization Weighted Price Index Futures (TAIEX Index Futures) for May moved down 55 points to close at 7,575 points, with 3,256 contract transactions.

TAIEX Index Futures for June were down 73 points, closing at 7,578 points, while those for September dropped 60 points to close at 7,580 points. Contract transactions for the two months totaled 111 and 20, respectively.
December futures fell 35 points to close at 7,605 points, with 1 contract transaction. No transactions were recorded for next March.

Reference levels provided by the Taiwan Mercantile International Exchange for TAIEX Index Futures trading on Tuesday were 7,630 points for May, 7,651 points for June, 7,640 points for both September and December and 7,739 points for next March.

DOC.HEADLINE: US INVESTMENT BANK MORGAN STANLEY TO SET UP TAIWAN BRANCH

TEXT.P: US investment bank Morgan Stanley Dean Witter applied to the Securities and Futures Commission (SFC) for permission to open a branch office in Taiwan, a Morgan Stanley Taipei official said on Tuesday.

John S. Wadsworth Jr., chairman of Morgan Stanley Dean Witter in Asia, said that if the application is approved, they will offer securities and brokerage-related services to Taiwan and non-Taiwan investors.

The global investment bank is optimistic about Taiwan's economic development in the coming five to 10 years, and Morgan Stanley believes it will generate a profit by investing in Taiwan for the long term. These factors were the reason Morgan Stanley Dean Witter decided to establish a branch in Taiwan, said Wadsworth.
Morgan Stanley will initially focus on brokerage services. When they expand their operations in the future, futures-related services will be offered, Wadsworth added.
Meanwhile, the SFC said that all foreign investment companies are welcome to set up offices in Taiwan, and as long as Morgan Stanley meets the SFC's requirements, its application will be approved.

To apply for a branch brokerage license, the applicant has to have brokerage experience in the country where its headquarters is located. Apart from a sound financial condition, the applicant must be free of any securities-related violations for the past two years, said the SFC.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S ECONOMY RECOVERING, ALBEIT SLOWLY, SAYS CEPD

TEXT.P: Taiwan's economy is recovering, though slowly, the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) said on Tuesday.

The Cabinet-level CEPD said that the economy flashed a "yellow-blue" indicator in the first quarter of this year, slightly better than the preceding quarter's "blue" light, which indicates a recession.

Judging from the leading indicators and the coincident indicators for March, as well as from the profits of the manufacturing sector, the CEPD concluded that although Taiwan's economic recovery is weak, the economy will not turn for the worse in the near future.

According to CEPD statistics, March's index of leading economic indicators, which gauges economic prospects for the next three to six months, stood at 96.3, up 1.8 percent from February. March's level was the highest since November 1998.
The index of coincident indicators, which reflects present economic activity, also grew 1.5 percent to 104.8, the highest level since December 1997.

The CEPD's estimate regarding Taiwan's economic growth is cautious when compared with a forecast by the Taiwan Institute of Economic Research that indicated on Monday that the island's economy "has begun making an upturn."

When asked by the media whether Taiwan's economy has bottomed out, an official with the CEPD's Economic Research Department said that it is hard to make an accurate assessment merely through one or two indicators.
But "at least the economy will not turn worse in the foreseeable future," he said.

Meanwhile, a CEPD survey of the manufacturing sector showed that sales by manufacturers in March increased 19.4 percent from February, mainly because March had more business days than February, the month of the most recent lunar New Year.

New orders for March rose 2.7 percent, and the utilization rate of equipment rose 2.2 percentage points to 78.7 percent. Net profits originating from sales were up 0.3 percentage points to 4.5 percent.

The survey indicated that 20 percent of polled manufacturers believe the country's economic prospects will improve in three months' time, while 73 percent believe the economy will remain at the current level. Only 7 percent said business will turn worse.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT LEE REASSURES PARAGUAY OF ROC SUPPORT

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui told El Dia Daily News a couple of days ago that he hopes ties between the Republic of China and Paraguay will be strengthened further after the new government of this South American country weathered a crisis earlier this year.

El Dia special reporter Roque Gonzalez B. reported that President Lee made the remarks in Taipei while receiving a delegation of 14 reporters from Latin America. Gonzalez was a member of that delegation.
Lee spoke with the reporters about the ROC's strategy to put an end to its isolation and to increase its presence in Central and South America.

President Lee pointed out that he wishes Paraguay can be a door for the Republic of China to enter the South Common Market (Mercosur), so that the Republic of China can extend its business relationships with the economic bloc, which ties together Argentina, Brazil, Paraguay and Uruguay.

President Lee was asked how the Republic of China would seek to improve its relations with Mercosur and whether Paraguay could play a special role, as a result of its diplomatic ties with the Republic of China.
Lee smiled and said that is an idea he himself has proposed before.
"I proposed that idea. I think through Paraguay we should deepen our relationships with the countries of the Mercosur, because trade between us is bulky."

"We have to increase our relationships with the Mercosur and let's do it through Paraguay, which is our ally. This is a country which helps us, and thus we hope to be partners of the Mercosur," he said.
Lee made the remarks after being reminded that Mercosur concluded an agreement with the European Union in 1995, which aims to reach a treaty on free trade between the two blocs in the future.
Lee said it is necessary for the Republic of China to improve its relations with Mercosur, because of the ROC's trade deficit with the bloc.

The reporter said the Republic of China is one of the countries with the greatest purchasing power in the world, as its per capita income exceeds US$13,000. Moreover, it constitutes an interesting market for Paraguayan products.
Last year, the Republic of China imported 54,000 tons of soybeans from Paraguay. The reporter said Taiwan had sought to purchase 100,000 tons this year, though that now appears unlikely.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC TO BOOST PARLIAMENTARY DIPLOMACY WITH AFRICAN ALLIES

TEXT.P: The Republic of China government will continue strengthening ties with the parliaments of its African diplomatic partners to boost bilateral relations, Foreign Affairs Minister Jason Hu said on Tuesday.
As all of the Republic of China's African diplomatic partners are democratic nations, the parliaments will play a very important role in those countries' future development, Hu said.
Hu made the remarks while delivering a speech at the Legislative Yuan on the first meeting of the ROC-Africa Parliamentary Friendship Association.
In addition to Foreign Affair Ministry officials and Taiwan business leaders, ambassadors from African countries such as Burkina Faso, Gambia, Liberia and Nigeria were also present on the occasion.

The ROC-Africa Parliamentary Friendship Association was set up in June 1998, with the aim to boost mutual understanding and relations between Taipei and its African diplomatic allies through the parliamentary and private sectors, said Kuomintang Legislator Chu Feng-chih, who serves as head of the association.
Currently, 68 ROC lawmakers have joined the group, and they will seek to invite their African counterparts to join with them, Chu added.

DOC.HEADLINE: US TENTATIVELY AGREES TO SELL US$1.7 BILLION WORTH OF ARMS: REPORT
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, April 26 (CNA) (By Jay Chen and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The US government is leaning toward approval of US$1.7 billion worth of arms for Taiwan, the US-based Defense News reported in its latest issue that hit newsstands on Monday.
The weekly, however, pointed out that 11th-hour lobbying by pro-mainland China interests may gut the package by half.

The Defense News said a final decision was still pending on Defense and State department recommendations to approve up to two additional Patriot air defense batteries and a long-range early warning radar for sale to Taiwan.

If approved, the weekly said, the package would supplement and upgrade the three Patriot batteries Taiwan previously purchased from Taytheon Co. under a specially tailored program called Medium Air Defense System (MADS).

Nevertheless, the Washington Times reported on Friday that because of strong opposition from Kenneth Lieberthal, Asian affairs senior director with the White House National Security Council, and John Holum, the State Department's arms control division chief, the Clinton administration has decided not to sell the AN/BOND phased array early warning radar to Taiwan.
An annual US-Taiwan meeting on the island's demand for weapons and military equipment will open in Washington, D.C. on Tuesday.
Quoting US government and defense industry officials, the Defense News said the new Patriot batteries slated for Taiwan will be similar to those sold in February to Greece.

The Greek package, according to Raytheon's Feb. 23 news release, includes Patriot Advanced Capability (PAC-3) ground equipment and the Guidance Enhanced Missile. The Greek package is more advanced and sophisticated than the MADS previously sold to Taiwan.
Meanwhile, the Defense News said the AN/BOND phased array early warning radar slated for Taiwan is similar to the US Air Force's Pave Paws radar.

US government and industry sources said the large, stationary radar will communicate with Patriot ground-based fire control sensors and could provide Taiwan an additional five or six minutes of early warning to respond to a mainland Chinese missile attack.

Some Clinton administration officials stressed that the missile defense package was rendered necessary by recent mainland Chinese missile deployments across the Taiwan Strait. However, the US State Department and the National Security Council still oppose selling such equipment to Taiwan, saying the sale may prompt Beijing to make reaction detrimental to Taiwan Strait stability.

In its latest issue, the Defense News also carried a commentary urging the White House to improve defense cooperation with Taiwan in various fields. It also urged the Clinton administration to make positive response to Taiwan's arms purchase requests to be presented at the upcoming annual meeting.

DOC.HEADLINE: KAOHSIUNG MAYOR TO VISIT PRATAS ISLANDS THURSDAY

TEXT.P: Kaohsiung Mayor Frank Hsieh said on Tuesday that he will depart on Thursday for an inspection tour of the Pratas Islands.

Speaking at a municipal meeting, Hsieh said the major purpose of his trip to the Republic of China-controlled island group in the South China Sea is to study the possibility of Kaohsiung's demarcation of the islands, which will lay a foundation for the city authorities' bid to develop the islands for tourism.

Hsieh revealed that the Bureau of Civil Affairs under the Kaohsiung City Government is currently working on the issue. Kaohsiung's demarcation will also help buttress ROC sovereignty over the islands, he added.
The Executive Yuan authorized the Kaohsiung City Government to have trusteeship of the Pratas Islands in February 1990.
Hsieh said the Kaohsiung City Government's plan to develop the islands will focus on tourism and fishing, and stressed that every effort will be made to fully protect the marine ecology in the area.
At present, the Kaohsiung City Government only maintains a fishermen's service center on the islands.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC TO STEP UP FISHERY COOPERATION WITH DOMINICAN REPUBLIC

TEXT.P: Peng Tso-kwei, chairman of Taiwan's Council of Agriculture (COA), met with visiting Dominican Agriculture Minister Amilcar Romero Portuondo in Taipei on Tuesday to exchange views on bilateral agricultural and fishery cooperation.
The Dominican minister, accompanied by his deputy, Juan Jose Espinal, were in Taipei to learn about Taiwan's experience in agricultural and fishery development.
A COA official said that Taiwan began engaging in agricultural cooperation with the Dominican Republic as early as 1963.

Since then, Taiwan has dispatched numerous agricultural missions to that country. Among the areas of cooperation have been rice plantations, improvements to vegetables, and the raising of hogs and sea shrimps.
Following the talks between Peng and his Dominican counterpart, the COA official said that the COA has decided to strengthen cooperation with the Dominican Republic in the area of fisheries.
Under the cooperation plan, Taiwan will help the Dominican Republic to develop its coastal fishery operations, and to improve its harbor, commodity storage and machine repair facilities.
Meanwhile, according to CNA report from Panama City, Republic of China Vice Foreign Minister Francisco H.L. Ou arrived in Santo Domingo on Monday for a three-day official visit.
Ou was planning to meet with Dominican President Leonel Fernandez and hold talks with Dominican Foreign Minister Eduardo Latorre to exchange views on the strengthening of bilateral relations.

DOC.HEADLINE: MND LENDS SUPPORT TO MACEDONIAN FIELD HOSPITAL

TEXT.P: The Republic of China Ministry of Defense (MND) will coordinate with the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) to support the establishment of a field hospital in Macedonia, an MND official said on Monday.

Col. Chen Chieh-hu of the MND's medic bureau said that in line with the government's humanitarian aid policy, the MND dispatched a nine-member military medical service team, led by Lt. Col. Yu Mu-hsien, to Macedonia on Monday.
The medical service team will stay for a month at the Stenkovec refugee camp's field hospital. The field hospital was originally operated by the volunteer Luchu Hui.

Some members of the privately sponsored ROC medical team operating at the field hospital have already returned to Taiwan. Their duties will be assumed by the military medical team, while the volunteer ROC doctors who have remained there will be placed under the command of the military team, MND officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOEA DISCUSSING WTO MULTILATERAL AGENDA

TEXT.P: Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) officials met on Monday to discuss matters concerning Taiwan's accession to the World Trade Organization (WTO) and upcoming negotiations of the WTO multilateral working group.
Economics Minister Wang Chih-kang is scheduled to leave for the United States on May 1 to discuss Taipei's bid with US Trade Representative Charlene Barshefsky.

The negotiations of the multilateral working group are to be held in Geneva from May 10-12, and will be attended by Vice Economics Minister Lin Yi-fu, and Chen Ruey-long, director-general of the Board of Foreign Trade.

Beijing's efforts to gain entry into the WTO have been accelerated since mainland Chinese Premier Zhu Rongji made significant trade concessions during his recent US visit. Taipei's bid for WTO membership is intertwined with Beijing's entry, as mainland China has insisted that Taiwan must not be given a WTO seat before Beijing.
Wang's forthcoming US trip is to solicit Washington's support in the multilateral working group talks.
Taiwan has signed agreements with 24 WTO contracting parties on entering the world trade regulatory body, but accords still remain to be signed with Canada and Hong Kong.

The coming multilateral negotiations are likely to focus on nullifying the industrial subsidy policy, opening Taiwan to rice imports, opening the island to imported motorcycles over 150 c.c. capacity, and opening to imports of diesel-engined cars.

DOC.HEADLINE: MERGER POISED TO FURTHER DEVOUR M'LAND CHINA'S INSTANT NOODLE MARKET

TEXT.P: Taiwan's food giant President Enterprises Corp. is set to buy into the company which produces mainland China's favorite brand of instant noodles, Master Kang, a move which will turn rivalry between two competitors into partnership, trade sources reported on Tuesday.

President, currently the second-largest manufacturer and distributor of instant noodles in mainland China, is working to acquire a 33 percent controlling stake, worth about NT$4 billion (US$122.32 million), of Ting Yi Holding Co., the Hong Kong-registered producer of Master Kang, better known in the mainland as Kangshihfu convenient noodles.

Currently, Ting Yi, known in Taiwan and the mainland as Ting Hsin, which is owned by four brothers from Taiwan, is the top instant noodle producer in mainland China, holding a market share of about 32 percent.
The merger is also poised to further expand the Ting Hsin-President domination of mainland China's instant noodle market from the current 50 percent total market share.

In addition, according to President Chairman Kao Chin-yen, the new tie-up also promises to curtail stiff competition between Ting Hsin and President in mainland China, saving them from cut-throat competition by adopting a "win-win" approach.

Until recently, Ting Hsin has been continuously lowering its prices to keep its head above water in the face of severe competition from President, which has seen its market share in mainland China growing steadily.

However, Kao said that the two companies only signed a letter of intent last Saturday for the tie-up. Final agreement will not be forged until late May after President has reviewed a complete financial report to be provided by Ting Hsin.
Meanwhile, a spokesman for the Cabinet-level Fair Trade Commission said the President-Ting Hsin merger will not be approved until the commission learns more about the nature of the venture.

Fair Trade Commission Vice Chairman Liu Tsung-rong pointed out that President operates more than 2,000 7-Eleven convenient stores around Taiwan. After the merger materializes, Ting Hsin's mainland-produced commodities will be legitimately allowed to appear on shelves of 7-Eleven stores around Taiwan, with no distinction between the Taiwan and mainland Chinese markets, which is currently prohibited under the government's mainland Chinese policy, he added.
Ting Hsin currently operates 12 production hubs and 1,450 distribution centers around mainland China.

The company entered the mainland market in 1989 with start-up capital of just a few million new Taiwan dollars, but has seen its capital grow to more than NT$32 billion (nearly US$1 billion) over the past 10 years.

Although its annual sales have reached over NT$20 billion (US$612 million) in previous years, Ting Hsin's turnover has been declining in recent years due to growing competition and too-rapid diversification of its business operations.
President, which first cut into the mainland Chinese market in 1992, has increased its investment capital there to US$270 million, with 15 production plants around the country.

Ting Hsin began negotiations late last year with Campbell, one of the leading food companies in the United States, for a possible merger. However, the talks hit a snag recently after the two sides spelled out differences over the portion of shares Ting Hsin would yield, and the unit price of the shares.

DOC.HEADLINE: JAPAN'S NEW GUIDELINES GOOD FOR REGIONAL SECURITY: ROC OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: An official with the Republic of China's Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said on Tuesday that new guidelines for US-Japanese security cooperation will help regional peace and security.

Chen Ming-cheng, deputy director of MOFA's Information and Cultural Affairs Department, made the comment as three bills related to the new guidelines passed through the Japanese Lower House earlier in the day.

Chen said that US-Japanese security cooperation is designed to deter military threats from non-democratic countries, and will therefore not only safeguard the United States and Japan, but also ensure security and peace in the entire region.
Taiwan has a deep interest over the six definitions of the emergency situation in Japan's surrounding area which will be covered by the new guidelines for US-Japanese security cooperation.
One definition describes the emergency situation as "when internal unrest occurs in some country, or when there is a danger that a civil war in a third country may become an international problem."
It is generally believed that a cross-Taiwan Strait conflict would fall under that definition.
Chen noted that the ROC is a country with independent sovereignty that supports any mechanism that will help ensure peace and prosperity in the Asia-Pacific region.
He added that Taiwan will continue to play its role in promoting peace, stability and prosperity in the Asian region.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC AVERAGE PER CAPITA INCOME 15 TIMES HIGHER THAN IN MAINLAND CHINA
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, April 26 (CNA) (By Herman Pan and Amanda Chang)

TEXT.P: The average per capita income in mainland China in 1997 was US$860, ranking the mainland as a medium-to-low income country despite it's listing as the world's seventh-largest economy, according to statistics released on Monday by the World Bank.
Meanwhile, according to official tallies, the Republic of China's average per capita income in 1997 was 15 times greater than that of the mainland, at US$13,198.
However, dragged down by a weak New Taiwan dollar, Taiwan's ranking for 1997 world average per capita income dropped sharply to 39 from the previous year's 23.
The figures were gleaned from the bank's 1999 World Development Indicators survey.
According to the survey, mainland China's Gross National Product reached US$1.55 trillion, ranking it the seventh-largest economy in the world, and the second-largest in Asia in 1997.
The 1997 top ten largest economies were the United States, Japan, Germany, France, the United Kingdom, Italy, mainland China, Brazil, Canada and Spain.
In the same year, Taiwan was the 19th-largest world economy, and the fifth-largest in Asia.
The survey also shows that the average per capita income in east Asia and the Pacific accounted for just US$970, compared to the global standard of US$5,180.

Four countries in the region are defined by the World Bank as low income nations for their below average per capita income. They are Laos, with average per capita income of US$400, the Republic of Mongolia, with US$390, Vietnam, with US$310, and Cambodia, with US$300.

DOC.HEADLINE: ARMY DRILL TO BE SCALED DOWN OUT OF ENVIRONMENTAL CONCERNS

TEXT.P: The Ministry of National Defense (MND) said on Tuesday that it will scale down a war drill by reducing the amount of live ammunition fired, out of respect for local peoples' concern about the impact on the environment.

Maj. Gen. Kung Fan-ting, a spokesman for the MND, told a weekly press briefing that the "Cheng Kung Drill," aimed at demonstrating the proficiency of a newly reorganized tank brigade, will also be staged in two phrases to reduce the amount of shots fired by the tanks.

The first phrase of the drill is a demonstration of firepower to be performed at a beach in the offshore county of Penghu on April 30. It has been designed to show the combat skill of the tank unit and will be presided over by Gen. Chen Cheng-hsiang, the army's commander-in-chief.
The second part of the drill, to be held on May 18, will be a formal review of the unit and an exhibition of the its weaponry and combat equipment.
The review and exhibition, also to be held in Penghu, will be observed by local government officials, military reservists, servicemen's families and local residents, said Kung.
The drill has roused the ire of local residents during its preparation stages, because they say the ammunition used in the drill will destroy the beach and coral in the area.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRISON INMATE ACCEPTED BY CHUNG YUAN UNIVERSITY

TEXT.P: An inmate of Taiwan's Pingtung Prison prevailed over 260 competitors in the 1999 entrance examination for Chung Yuan Christian University on Tuesday, winning him a chance to made a fresh start.
The 32-year-old man, surnamed King, is spending his fifth year in jail after being sentenced to 15 years for selling drugs.

The punishment took King from the world of heroin and amphetamine, which had captured him at the age of 15, and sent him on the road to reform with the assistance of programs formed by prison authorities and a number of private welfare organizations.
King passed the university entrance test, qualifying to study at in the Department of Special Education. Only 15 of more than 260 applicants were approved by the department.

However, he cannot leave jail and attend classes until the end of November, because under existing criminal laws, inmates are eligible for parole only after serving at least one-third of their sentences.
But the university's Dean of Academic Affairs Wang Huang-san said King's place will be kept for him, and stressed that the university is very willing to embrace those who want to mend their ways.
Chung Yuan University did not join in the effort to turn "bad guys" into respectable citizens until last year.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER AUSTRALIAN PM WARNS OF RUSSIAN INVOLVEMENT IN BALKANS

TEXT.P: Australia's former Prime Minister Malcolm Fraser on Tuesday warned NATO countries that Russia could be drawn into the current Balkan conflict, and questioned the effectiveness of NATO's continuing bombing in the region.

Fresh from his return to Melbourne after visiting Moscow and Belgrade, where he failed to secure the release of CARE Australia aid workers, Fraser told a news conference that whether Russia will allow Yugoslavia to run out of oil and ammunition needs to be watched very carefully.
If the answer is in the negative, then "Russia could be pulled into" the conflict, which could increase the danger of widespread war, he warned.

Fraser, who was appointed an Australian envoy, met with Russian leaders in Moscow to seek help in securing the release of Steve Pratt and Peter Wallace of CARE Australia, the country's largest relief agency, of which the former prime minister is chairman.
He also met unsuccessfully with the Yugoslavian foreign minister for the same reason.

Fraser said Pratt was detained on charge of spying because he used military language and possibly a naive determination to retain CARE Australia's extensive records of its assets in Yugoslavia, which contributed to his arrest as a spy.
He said CARE Australia workers might have been naive in trying to cross a border of a country at war. Despite his failure, Fraser said he remained hopeful that the two aid workers would be released.

DOC.HEADLINE: FIRST MACEDONIAN ENVOY TO ROC ARRIVES IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Verka Modanu, the Republic of Macedonia's first resident envoy to the Republic of China, arrived in Taipei on Tuesday to assume her post.
Modanu said upon arrival at Chiang Kai-shek International Airport that the Macedonian Embassy in the Republic of China will become formally operational on Wednesday.
She said she hopes that her work here will help cement bilateral ties between Macedonia and the ROC, which established formal diplomatic relations on Jan. 27 this year.
Modanu, accompanied by her daughter, is here in a temporary capacity as minister rather than ambassador, in line with similar measures adopted by Taipei.

The ROC Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) appointed Peter Cheng, Taiwan's deputy chief representative in the United States, to Macedonia as the first ROC envoy to the Balkan state after the two countries forged formal relations. Cheng arrived in Skopje earlier this month to assume his post.

Because of the opposition by President Kiro Gligorov to Skopje's establishment of formal ties with Taipei, the current Macedonian head of state is not expected to acknowledge the credentials from an ROC ambassador to Macedonia, which is why Taipei decided to appoint Cheng as a minister rather than an ambassador.

The contingent arrangements by both governments are expected to be changed later this year, after Macedonia holds presidential elections in which Gligorov is not expected to be re-elected, MOFA officials said.
Modanu, who studied Chinese literature and history at the University of Beijing between 1973 and 1978, speaks fluent Mandarin Chinese.

She was director of the Asian Affairs Department under Macedonia's Foreign Ministry before being appointed envoy to Taipei. She has been working with the Asian Affairs Department since the independence of Macedonia in 1991. Before then, she worked for the Yugoslavian government and a state-run trading company for about ten years.

DOC.HEADLINE: FIRST PLATINUM VISA CARD IN TAIWAN ISSUED

TEXT.P: Chinatrust Commercial Bank (CCB) issued its first platinum visa card in Taiwan on Tuesday, offering a "royal identification" to those who seek the deluxe in life.

A CCB spokesman said that holders of the platinum credit card will receive more services than those given to gold card owners. For example, he said, they will receive complete information on key international meetings and various exhibitions, can join in health care schemes, and will have booking privileges for transportation.

The spokesman noted that platinum card holders are covered with better travel insurance than that provided for gold card holders. In addition, he said, the bank will help their "very important consumers" to analyze their annual spending.

The number of visa cards issued in Taiwan broke through the 10 million mark on Tuesday, making it the hottest plastic currency on the island, Hsiung An-ping, Asia-Pacific vice president of Visa International Service Association, said in Hong Kong, according to a CNA dispatch from the formal Beitish colony.

In the first quarter of this year, charges to visa cards surpassed NT$100 billion (US$3.05 billion), reflecting the fact that Taiwan's credit card market has not shrunk, despite the regional recession caused by the Asian financial storm, Hsiung said.
Turnover on visa cards reached more than NT$362.7 billion on the island last year, according to VISA statistics.
Taiwan is the fifth Asia-Pacific market to offer the platinum visa card, following Hong Kong, South Korea, Singapore and Malaysia, VISA said.

DOC.HEADLINE: BOFT HEAD MEETS USTR OFFICIALS FOR WTO TALKS
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, April 27 (CNA) (By Herman Pan and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Board of Foreign Trade Director-General Chen Ruey-long called at the Office of the US Trade Representative (USTR) on Tuesday to exchange views with US trade officials on Taiwan's accession to the World Trade Organization (WTO).
Chen met with David Burns, a senior adviser to the USTR Office, for talks primarily on Taiwan's proposed opening of its markets and the signing of a final protocol on WTO entry.

The WTO Secretariat has decided to hold a working group meeting on Taiwan's accession from May 10-12, prompting Taipei to accelerate preparatory work in Washington, Geneva and Taipei, in the hope of being able to join the world trade regulatory body this year.

The USTR has stressed on many occasions that Taipei's and Beijing's accession to the WTO should be achieved based on their respective economic and trade conditions, according to Burns, who made a similar statement when he met an ROC delegation of legislators in Washington, D.C. last week.
USTR officials, however, have also hinted that Taiwan and mainland China are expected by the international community to enter the WTO simultaneously.

The USTR is scheduled to make public its 1999 "Special 301" watch list on April 30, and Taiwan is expected to remain included. USTR officials said they are concerned about the fairness of Taiwan's judicial process, especially in several cases concerning infringement of patent and trademark rights of US-developed products, said Chen.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP MODIFIES DRAFT RESOLUTION TO WOO PARTY HARDLINERS

TEXT.P: A committee of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) modified a controversial draft resolution on Tuesday to head off the perception that the pro-independence party has betrayed its original ideals and has accepted the Republic of China as the official name of Taiwan.

The DPP Committee for Party Development decided to replace the original text, which reads: "Taiwan, whose official state name is the Republic of China," with "Taiwan, whose official name, as provided in the current Constitution, is the Republic of China."

The new statement mirrors the reality rather than the party's official opinion, and should not offend the extremists within the party who will not be satisfied with any idea less than an independent "Republic of Taiwan," said a committee member.

The original text, designed to free the party from having to fulfill its previous pledge of pressing for Taiwan's independence via plebiscite, has come under fire from party hardliners who criticize it as backing down on previous DPP promises.

The prospect of making plebiscite a constitutional right via amendment, however, is dim in the foreseeable future, given the lack of public support. In addition, many DPP leaders harbor the concern that their campaign for independence will destabilize the subtle triangular ties between Taipei, Washington and Beijing.
They are also worried that blind adherence to the independence cause will cost the party votes which are vital if the DPP is to come to power in the next national elections.
The new text of the draft resolution will be presented to the party congress for approval on May 8 after receiving the nod from the Party's Central Executive Committee.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP URGES FORMER CHAIRMAN TO STAY IN PARTY
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 27 (CNA) (By Maubo Chang) (By Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: Taipei, April 27 (CAN) A reported decision of former Democratic Progressive Party Chairman (DPP) Hsu Hsin-liang to quit the party and enter the race for president as an independent roused a chorus of calls on Tuesday for him to stay with the party.

Hsu's arch-rival within the party, Chen Shui-bian, whose dominant position in the race for party nomination for the 2000 presidential election has forced Hsu to consider withdrawal, personally called for Hsu to settle their competition within the party.

Former Taipei City Mayor Chen said he will not insist on standing for the party personally in the election, but he stopped short of backing out of the party primary, which he is almost certain to win.
The heads of DPP branch offices islandwide issued a joint statement on Tuesday urging Hsu not to leave the party he helped found.

Meanwhile a group of Hsu's DPP supporters threatened on Tuesday to recall the current party chairman, Lin Yi-hsiung, for failing to stop Chen from canvassing voters at home and abroad long before the party primary has even kicked off.
Hsu is reported to be working on a statement regarding his decision to quit the party, which is expected to be issued on the eve of the party congress on May 8.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies Wednesday are as follows:
The Central Daily News:
The annual National Assembly session will start in June and lasts for two months.
The China Times:
The United States is expected to sell phased array long-range early warning radars to Taiwan.
The United Daily News:
President Enterprise Inc., a leading food conglomerate in Taiwan, signed a letter of intent on Tuesday with Ting Hsin Holdings (Caymen Islands), to acquire up to a 33 percent stake of Ting Hsin's Tingyi Holdings, which will allow the food giant to eat up mainland Chinese instant noodle market.
The Liberty Times:
The lower house of the Japanese Diet on Tuesday passed legislation to bolster defense ties with the United States.
The Commons Daily:
The main opposition Democratic Progressive Party finalized a draft resolution on the party's stance on Taiwan's future.
The China Post:
ROC food giant eats up the mainland Chinese instant noodle market.
The China News:
Taiwan's giant food makers President and Tingyi move to cooperate.

DOC.HEADLINE: DOMINICAN PRESIDENT MEETS WITH ROC VICE FOREIGN MINISTER
DOC.DATELINE: Panama City, April 27 (CNA) (By Eduardo Chen and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: President Leonel Fernandez of the Dominican Republic met with visiting Republic of China Vice Foreign Minister Francisco H.L. Ou on Tuesday to talk about mutual relations between the two countries.
Fernandez reiterated his country's support to the ROC government and people, and extended thanks for Taipei's assistance to the country in its educational development.

He also expressed his hope that Taiwan Sugar Corp. can become involved in Santo Domingo's efforts to privatize its sugar business. Taisugar's manufacturing and management know-how are expected to help the Caribbean country enhance its sugar refinery technology, the president said.
Ou thanked Fernandez on behalf of the ROC government for the solid support the Dominican Republic has given the Republic of China in the international community.

Before the meeting, Ou called on Foreign Minister Eduardo Latorre Rodriguez to exchange views on bilateral cooperation and exchanges. Ou and his entourage were scheduled to head to Paraguay on Wednesday.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, April 28, or the 13th day of the third month of the Year of the Rabbit according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1545: Yi Sun-shin, Korean admiral and national hero, is born.
1758: James Monroe, the fifth president of the United States, is born. His administration is remembered for the acquisition of Florida in 1819, and in 1823 for proclaiming the Monroe Doctrine, which declared that no European power would be allowed to colonize any part of America.
1789: On a return trip from Tahiti in the South Pacific, mutinous crew members of the British transport ship Bounty set adrift Captain William Bligh and 18 sailors in an open boat. Bligh and his royal crew manage to reach Timor Island near Java on June 14 after sailing 3,500 miles.
1902: The US Senate passes an anti-Chinese bill.
1922: Chang Tso-lin, a warlord who headed a separate army in Manchuria, declares war on Feng Kuo-chang, who headed the Chihli faction of the powerful Peiyang Army. When war between the northern warlords erupts, Dr. Sun Yat-sen issues a manifesto urging the reunification of China by peaceful means.
1936: King Fu'ad of Egypt, who became the country's monarch when Britain granted limited independence to Egypt in 1922, dies at the age of 68. His son Farouk ascends to the throne.
1945: Italian dictator Benito Mussolini is shot and strung up head down by his countrymen.
1952: At his own request, Dwight D. Eisenhower is relieved of duty as Supreme Allied Commander Europe. He is succeeded by Gen. Matthew Ridgway.
1952: The Treaty of Peace between the Republic of China and Japan is signed in Taipei by Foreign Minister George K.C. Yeh and Japan's special envoy, Isao Kawata.
1953: Japan is again allowed self-government after it was taken away following World War II.
1962: The Taiwan Television Enterprise, Ltd. is established in Taipei.
1963: Yang Chuan-kuang, the ROC's decathlon champion who won the first Olympic silver medal for his country in Sept. 6, 1960, sets a new world record in the sport in the United States with 9,121 points.
1969: President de Gaulle of France resigns and is succeeded by Georges Pompidou.
1975: Premier Chiang Ching-kuo is elected chairman of the Central Committee of the ruling Kuomintang.
1988: A Republic of China delegation attends the annual convention of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) in Manila.
1992: Yang Chi-chang, a police officer, is killed in an explosion while trying to defuse a bomb placed by blackmailers near the McDonald's fast food branch on Minsheng East Road in Taipei.
1995: A leaking gas line explodes at a subway construction site in Taegu, South Korea, killing more than 100 people and injuring nearly 200 others.
1996: The Ministry of Economic Affairs announces that starting July 1, 1996, imports of another 1,609 categories of industrial commodities will be allowed into Taiwan from the Chinese mainland, marking the ROC government's largest-scale relaxation of restrictions on mainland imports.
Confucius's lesson of the day: "A gentleman of spirit or a man of moral character will never try to save his life at the expense of his moral character, he prefers to sacrifice his life in order to save his moral character."

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA TO PLAY KEY ROLE IN EAST TIMOR DESPITE UNCERTAINTY

TEXT.P: Australia is set to play a leading role in carrying out a UN-supervised peace plan for East Timor, but political analysts remain doubtful that there will be peace or a fair vote to decide the future of the former Portuguese colony.
Prime Minister John Howard and President B.J. Habibie on Tuesday reached an agreement under which Indonesia will allow East Timorese to decide on their future in an Aug. 8 vote.
Australia agreed to send a contingent of police and US$13 million to fund a referendum on the autonomy of East Timor.
In addition, Australia will send medical teams and provide logistics support for East Timor in conjunction with the United Nation's peace plan for the territory.
Indonesia has agreed to allow Australia to set up a consulate in Dili, the capital of East Timor.

But shadow foreign minister Laurie Brereton strongly criticized Howard's efforts, saying Howard, Foreign Minister Alexander Downer and Defense Minister John Moore have failed to secure assurances that warring factions in the territory will be disarmed.

In addition, Howard did not receive any assurance from Indonesia, especially from armed forces chief Gen. Wiranto, that the Indonesian military will allow the Aug. 8 vote to proceed fairly and peacefully.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC REPRESENTATIVE VISITS SAKHALIN, VLADIVOSTOK
DOC.DATELINE: Moscow, April 27 (CNA) (By H.K. Chang and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Republic of China Representative to Russia James Wen-chung Chang visited Russia's Siberia region from April 17-24 to study the possibility of bilateral trade opportunities.

Chang, traveling at the head of a delegation composed of ROC officials stationed in Russia, visited Vladivostok, Russia's most important Pacific seaboard port, and Sakhalin, an island off the country's east coast.

Both Vladivostok and Sakhalin are Russian points of entry to the Asia Pacific region, and their local governments and business communities are prepared to offer a warm welcome to Taiwan businesses wishing to invest there, according to Chang.

The Sakhalin authorities are currently exploring petroleum and liquefied natural gas (LNG) reserves off the islands' coast, and Chang said chances remain high that Taiwan will consider importing LNG from Sakhalin, as long as quality, transportation and price problems are resolved.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC-FRANCE INDUSTRIAL TECH COOPERATION MEETING TO OPEN IN MAY

TEXT.P: A French Cabinet-level official in charge of industry and foreign trade affairs will visit Taiwan on May 3 for a bilateral industrial technology cooperation meeting, officials of Taiwan's Industrial Development Bureau (IDB) said on Wednesday.

Jeanne Seyvet will lead a delegation comprising officials in data procession technology, trade and economics, and postal affairs, to talk with a Taiwan delegation headed by IDB Director-general Wang Ya-kang, IDB officials said.
Topics on the agenda will center on electronics, power, environmental protection, transportation, biotechnology, industrial cooperation, and intellectual property rights, they said.
The officials added that the French side is expected to raise new cooperation projects, such as telecommunication technology joint ventures, and management of nuclear waste and waste water.

The Taiwan delegation will be composed of officials from the IDB, the Ministry of Transportation and Communications, the Department of Health, the Government Information Office, the Environmental Protection Administration, Taiwan Power Company, and Chinese Petroleum Corp.

DOC.HEADLINE: CONGRESSMAN CALLS FOR RADAR SYSTEM SALES TO TAIWAN

TEXT.P: As talks between US and Republic of China government officials begin Tuesday on Taipei's annual request for US arms, US Rep. Benjamin Gilman (R-N.Y.), chairman of the House International Relations Committee, is seeking to reverse the Clinton administration's efforts to bar the sale of defensive radar systems to Taiwan.

Congressman Gilman said in a letter to Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright that he will seek legislation to circumvent the decision if the State Department denies Taiwan a long-range early warning radar system.

The Washington Times quoted on Tuesday US officials close to the arms sales talks as saying that the White House and the State Department prevailed over the Pentagon in interagency policy discussions and succeeded in blocking several important weapons systems sought by Taiwan.

Rep. Gilman noted in the April 22 letter that the State Department "is advocating a policy that is not merely wrongheaded, but also dangerous to the people of Taiwan and the personnel of our US armed forces who may one day be called on to help defend Taiwan."

The White House opposes the radar sales because of mainland Chinese opposition to Asian missile defenses that could neutralize Beijing's growing short-range missile force, reported the Washington Times. The US Defense Intelligence Agency estimates that mainland China will deploy up to 650 M-9 and M-11 missiles near Taiwan over the next six years.

"I will not accept a decision by the administration to deny early warning radar systems to Taiwan," Gilman said in the letter, adding that "I have directed my staff to prepare legislation to rescind the president's legal authority to restrict the transfer of such systems to Taiwan."

The New York Republican said that the legislation would be introduced immediately after it is clear that the radar system sale has been refused, adding that the measure "will command broad, bipartisan support in the Congress."

DOC.HEADLINE: US CONGRESSMAN SLAMS CLINTON ADMINISTRATION ON HUMAN RIGHTS

TEXT.P: Rep. Frank Wolf blasted the Clinton administration on Tuesday for its "miserable" record on promoting human rights, pointing to President Bill Clinton's decision not to mention mainland Chinese religious persecution during recent talks with mainland Chinese Premier Zhu Rongji.

Congressman Wolf said on the House floor Tuesday that he believes it is the Clinton administration's intention to miss the May 1 deadline for the Commission on International Religious Freedom to submit its first report on the condition of religious freedom around the world, by not naming its three commissioners as required by the International Religious Freedom Act, which President Clinton signed into law six months ago.

It ensures that the Clinton administration can continue to "fudge the facts" instead of taking serious action against countries such as mainland China that refuse to protect the rights of religious believers, said Wolf.

The Virginia Republican said the administration's record on promoting human rights "is positively miserable." In mainland China, Catholic priests and bishops are still in jail and some have been there for decades. So are Protestant pastors and lay people, he said. Churches continue to be destroyed, and worshippers are beaten, imprisoned and fined.

But, Rep. Wolf pointed out, there was no mention of this by President Clinton during his recent meeting with Zhu. Nor was there discussion of the fact that Beijing has stopped all dialogue with the Dalai Lama over the future status of Tibet or the mainland Chinese government-sponsored campaign to encourage Tibetan Buddhists to become atheists.

Now, he added, a recent report indicates that the Christian church in Hong Kong is getting squeezed in subtle ways. And the Clinton administration has done nothing about the situation for religious believers in Sudan, Vietnam, India, Pakistan and Indonesia.

The congressman stressed there is so much going on around the world that there is no excuse for the Commission on International Religious Freedom not to be given a chance to do its work. Too much time has been wasted already, he said. "The lives of innocent people are at stake and our lame response thus far is a disgrace," said Wolf.

DOC.HEADLINE: US READY TO SELL TAIWAN LONG-RANGE RADAR SYSTEMS: REPORT

TEXT.P: The Clinton administration has agreed in principle to sell early warning radar systems to Taiwan, according to a senior member of Congress.
Rep. Benjamin Gilman (R-N.Y.) said Tuesday that he had "initial reports of the administration's decision in principle to approve the sale."
In a press statement, the chairman of the House International Relations Committee said that "this is the right decision at the right time."
The decision "will send an important signal to the People's Republic of China about our resolve to assist Taiwan in providing for its legitimate self-defense needs," he added.
According to his staff, the statement came after their telephone conversations with White House and State Department officials, who had apparently reversed their earlier position on this issue.
According to a Washington Times report on April 23, the White House and State Department were opposing the proposed sale so as not to upset mainland China.
In another article on Tuesday, the Times said that Gilman had warned the administration against leaving Taiwan "vulnerable to the growing (missile) threat" from the mainland.
"I will not accept a decision by the administration to deny early warning radar systems to Taiwan," he said in a letter last week to Secretary of State Madeleine Albright.
He also said that he had directed his staff to prepare legislation "to rescind the president's legal authority to restrict the transfer of such systems to Taiwan."
Gilman had earlier sent a letter to President Bill Clinton, urging him to approve the sale.

In Tuesday's statement, the senior member of Congress said that he will decide whether to introduce the legislation after full briefings and assurances from the administration regarding these transfers.

The White House and the State Department had no immediate comment. State Department and Pentagon officials earlier told reporters that the United States remains committed to the Taiwan Relations Act and its provisions related to Taiwan's defense needs.

If the administration has indeed decided to provide Taiwan with early warning radar systems, it will be welcomed news to a Republic of China military delegation currently in Washington for the annual defense procurement talks.

The phase-array radar systems are said to be much more powerful than any systems currently in Taiwan's possession and will provide up to six more minutes of warning time against missiles from across the Taiwan Strait.

DOC.HEADLINE: HOST OF AUSTRALIAN CRIME SHOW ALARMED AFTER MURDER OF UK SHOW HOST

TEXT.P: The murder of a popular television host in Britain has alarmed the host of a similar program in Australia and led to a serious review of security measures to be taken for the presenter and staff of the "Australia's Most Wanted" program.
Jill Dando, host of the BBC's monthly "Crimewatch UK" program, was gunned down outside her London home in what UK police believe was the work of a professional hit man.

Roger Climpson, the host of the Seven TV Network's "Australia's Most Wanted" program, broadcast weekly on Monday night, has never had his life threatened. But the TV network is now reviewing the security of Climpson and his staff.

Executive producer Ron Sinclair said security measures are always in place at the studio, but that they are precautionary only. He indicated more security for Climpson and his colleagues would be added in a bid to prevent a similar incident from happening.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESENT POPULATION POLICY IS TO RAISE MARRIAGE RATE: MOI

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Interior (MOI) said on Wednesday the present population policy is focused on raising the marriage rate to prevent a decline in, and the aging of, Taiwan's population.

According to an MOI report on Taiwan's population structure, Taiwan's population will turn from zero to negative growth in three to four decades, resulting in population gaps, a graying population, a smaller labor pool and too many dependents.
The MOI said Taiwan's present population policy should focus on reasonable population growth, as both excessively high or low birth rates are "unreasonable."

According to MOI statistics, the number of Taiwan women who are married fell from 61.8 percent of the female population in 1983 to 58.7 percent in 1997. The decline is attributed to the fact that many women are marrying later in life.

To improve Taiwan's marriage rate, the government should encourage people to marry and have children at the "right time" to combat the current tendency to marry late or not at all. The government should also educate the public on the disadvantages of having only one child, the MOI said.

The MOI pointed out that even a moderate birth rate increase could help maintain reasonable population growth, but officials said the emphasis should be on getting people to marry at the right age and have two children, not indiscriminately encouraging childbirth.

Statistics show that Taiwan's population density of 606 people per square kilometer is the second highest in the world. But birth control policies have slowed the island's birth rate to 1.570 percent, and by 2036 the rate will be 1.170 percent.
Meanwhile, an aging population is expected to increase Taiwan's mortality rate from 0.559 percent in 1997 to an estimated 0.624 percent in 2001 and 1.070 percent in 2031.

As a result of more deaths and fewer births, Taiwan's population growth rate is expected to fall from 0.948 percent in 1997 to 0.837 percent in 2001. Between 2031 and 2036, the rate is expected to drop to almost zero, as birth and mortality rates become nearly equal.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIAN ANTI-GUN LOBBY RENEWS PLEA TO BAN SEMI-AUTOMATIC WEAPONS

TEXT.P: Alarmed by the latest killing of teachers and students in the United States, the anti-gun lobby in Australia has renewed its plea for a ban on all semi-automatic rifles across the country.

The memories are still fresh in Australia of the 28-year-old man who used semi-automatic weapons to gun down 35 people and injure scores of others at Port Arthur in Tasmania in April, 1996, stunning the world and breaking the record for killings by an individual.

As members of the bereaved families commemorate the dead in Tasmania this week, the anti-gun lobby said the latest killing of 15 teachers and students in Colorado has revived fears of more such incidents in Australia.

Immediately after the 1996 massacre, Prime Minister John Howard reacted by asking all gun owners to surrender their weapons. But gun lobby groups and owners have resisted the government on the issue, with less than half of the country's gun owners surrendering their weapons between 1996 and 1998.
The gun lobby in Australia is powerful, with around 3 million registered gun club members.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAOIST-STYLE CAMPAIGN GATHERS MOMENTUM IN MAINLAND CHINA

TEXT.P: All mainland Chinese ministerial and sub-ministerial officials have been required to undergo reappraisal by their subordinates as a Maoist-style "rectification" campaign intensifies.

According to a report appearing in the Hong Kong Standard on Wednesday, all central party organ and ministry officials will be subjected to closed-door political sessions in Beijing for the whole of this month.
The has been intensified with additional ideological indoctrination, or the so-called "three talks" campaign, the newspaper quoted mainland sources as saying.
President Jiang Zemin, who is also Communist Party General Secretary, had earlier called for an ideological campaign to "talk more about politics, about morality and about learning."
The current Maoist-style rectification campaign has brought daily business in central party organs and ministries to a virtual standstill, officials from several central departments claimed.

All officials above the departmental level have been asked to produce a self-assessment report that includes assessments on morality, ideology, behavior, responsibility, competence in business, and their achievements or failures to meet work targets.
Officials have also been asked to confess or guarantee in writing whether they or any of their family members have ever been involved in any corruption-related wrongdoing or crime.
The reports will be presented to all subordinates and staff, who will then be asked to remark on and grade their bosses' performance.

DOC.HEADLINE: PASSPORT FORGERY RING BUSTED; SUSPECTS NABBED

TEXT.P: The Aviation Police Bureau (APB) announced on Wednesday the cracking of an ROC machine-readable passport (MRP) forgery ring and the arrest of four key suspects involved in the production of forged passports.
This is the first time that an MRP forgery ring has been busted in Taiwan since the government began to issue the technically advanced passports in 1995.
Police said the ring has colluded with mainland Chinese human smuggling rings to sell doctored or forged ROC passports to prospective mainland immigrants.

APB Director Chang Shih-liang said aviation police have tightened monitoring and security checks at major Taiwan airports after several batches of ROC passports were reported missing from Chiang Kai-shek (CKS) International Airport over the past few years.

After several months of intensive investigation, aviation police tracked down Lin Hsin-kuei, 46, who was suspected of falsifying ROC passports. They launched an all-out search of Lin's home in Linkou, Taipei County, on Tuesday evening after securing a search warrant from the Taoyuan Prosecutor's Office.

Police arrested Lin and three of his accomplices at Lin's home. Also seized were a large number of photos of mainland Chinese people, 13 finished fake ROC MRP passports, 12 semi-finished fake passports, 13 US visas, four old-style ROC passports and a large amount of counterfeiting equipment.

Dozens of genuine ROC passports which had been reported missing or stolen were also discovered at Lin's home. Initial investigations show that at least one of those passports was stolen at CKS Airport on July 4, 1998.

Lin told police that he originally engaged in international trade. About three years ago, he said, he began to counterfeit or tamper with ROC passports with methods he invented himself. According to Lin, a doctored ROC passport could fetch tens of thousands of new Taiwan dollars on the black market, while a forged or doctored ROC MRP could be sold to mainland Chinese human smuggling rings for up to US$30,000.

Police said they suspect that Lin's ring might have been involved in the several large-scale passport theft cases reported at CKS Airport, Taiwan's main gateway, over the past two years. On April 18, more than 80 passports were reported missing from the airport.
The three other arrested ring members were identified as Chen Wen-jung, 45; Huang Chi-wen, 30; and Tseng Mao-lin, 51.
According to APB officials, Chen is a senior executive with a Taipei travel agency, and Huang is a medical college student, while Tseng has an extensive criminal record for document forgery.

The four suspects have been transferred to the Taoyuan Prosecutor's Office on charges of document forgery. Police said they will continue their investigations to check whether any other accomplices are involved.
