DOC.HEADLINE: CANADA LIMITS ALUMINUM IN DRINKING WATER

TEXT.P: A Canadian federal-provincial committee which watches over water safety has for the first time set limits on the permitted amount of aluminum in the country's drinking water.

Committee spokesman Barry Thomas said on Tuesday that all water treatment plants should be run to achieve "the lowest level of aluminum possible." The committee recommended that treatment plants set a target of 100 micrograms per liter.

"Neurological toxicity such as Alzheimer's is one of the concerns we have," he said. Research suggests aluminum can accumulate in the brain, killing cells and causing memory loss. Studies have found higher rates of Alzheimer's where drinking water has high aluminum levels.

The committee has also launched a major study to examine the health effects of water chlorination. Chlorine, used to disinfect water, combines with organic matter to form hundreds of byproducts which are suspected of contributing to the risk of cancer, especially bladder cancer.

Canada already has a health guideline for chlorine byproducts in drinking water, which is 100 parts per billion, but there is concern the guideline is too high. A task force will make recommendations on the issue by 2001, said Thomas.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR EDGES UP

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar moved slightly up to the greenback on the Taipei foreign exchange market Wednesday, rising NT$0.001 to close at 32.681.
The local currency opened at 32.68, and was traded between 32.658 and 32.7.
The interbank US dollar trading reached US$391 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC HOLDS SEPARATE TALKS WITH US AND THAILAND IN NEW ZEALAND

TEXT.P: Yang Shih-chien, a minister without portfolio in the Republic of China, has held separate bilateral talks with the United States and Thailand on the sidelines of an Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum conference on small- and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs), which is being held in Christchurch, New Zealand.

During his talks on Tuesday with the United States' chief delegate -- Deputy Secretary of Commerce Robert Mallett -- Yang asked the US government to support the ROC's bid to join the World Trade Organization (WTO), and Mallett agreed to relay Yang's request to high-level authorities in the United States.

Meanwhile, Mallett said he was concerned about Taiwan's calculations of import prices for US medicines and drugs and asked Taipei to continue its firm policy of protecting intellectual property rights. Yang agreed to relay his request to ROC authorities.
In another meeting, Thai Minister for Industry Suwap Liptapanlop asked Taiwan to share with Thailand its experiences in SME development so that Thailand can develop its own SMEs.
Thailand will send a group of government officials and business leaders to Taiwan soon to study Taiwan's SME development, and Yang said he welcomed the visit.
Yang said the ROC delegation has ended its bilateral talks with Canada, Vietnam, New Zealand, the United States and Thailand during its participation in the APEC conference in Christchurch.
Taiwan has no plans for similar talks with other APEC members, including mainland China, Hong Kong, Japan and South Korea.

Delegates representing 20 APEC members on Tuesday discussed various topics, including education, the liberalization of trade, and financing at a general meeting. All delegates were particularly concerned with finding ways to avoid financial crises similar to the one that struck Asia in 1997.
The three-day APEC SME conference is expected to be concluded Wednesday afternoon.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN INVESTMENT IN MAINLAND CHINA SHRINKS; FOREIGN INVESTMENT STABLE

TEXT.P: The uncertain atmosphere regarding the renminbi's valuation has caused Taiwan businesses to show signs of slowing their investments in mainland China in the first three months of this year, economics officials said on Wednesday.

During the period, only 85 applications to invest in the mainland received approval from the Investment Commission under the Ministry of Economic Affairs, a 45 percent drop against the same period of last year, the officials said.
The regional recession caused by the Asian financial meltdown has also contributed to the fall, the officials said.

Meanwhile, statistics released by the bureau show that there were 221 investments in Taiwan raised by foreign and overseas Chinese investors during the January-March period of this year, up 26 percent from the year-earlier level.
The value of these investments totaled US$403.9 million, up 6.18 percent, reflecting stable growth in terms of investment in Taiwan from overseas.
Most of the investment came from the United States, Britain's Virgin Islands and Cayman Islands, Japan, Holland, and Singapore, according to the statistics.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO MAKE NO SIGNIFICANT CONCESSIONS ON WTO ENTRY: MOEA

TEXT.P: Republic of China Economics Minister Wang Chih-kang said on Wednesday that Taipei will make no concessions on its accession to the World Trade Organization (WTO) during his forthcoming trip to the United States.
Wang explained his statement by pointing out that as Taipei has already concluded bilateral WTO negotiations with Washington, no further concessions are necessary.

The economics minister is scheduled to leave for the United States on May 3 to discuss Taipei's WTO bid with US Trade Representative Charlene Barshefsky, while negotiations of the WTO Multilateral Working Group are to be held in Geneva from May 10-12.
Wang's upcoming US visit is to solicit Washington's support in the Multilateral Working Group talks.

He made the remarks in answer to questions from lawmakers at the legislature during a joint staff conference of the Economic and Energy Resources Committee, and the Budget Committee. The legislators were concerned about Taiwan's WTO bid.

Beijing's efforts to gain entry into the WTO have been accelerated since mainland Chinese Premier Zhu Rongji made significant trade concessions during his recent US trip, and the lawmakers wondered whether Wang would also make significant concessions during his forthcoming trip.
However, Wang observed that Taiwan's bid for entry into the WTO is already firmly grounded, since the world trade regulatory body is avowedly non-political.
Barshefsky herself has made a strong point for the island's accession based on this fundamental point, Wang pointed out.
Taiwan, which has promised tariff and quota concessions acceptable to WTO member economies, deserves an unbiased evaluation of its application, stressed the economics minister.

The forthcoming WTO Multilateral Working Group negotiations will be critical for Taipei's bid, Wang said, and went a step further by saying that Taipei's multilateral negotiations have proceeded into the final stage.
A total of 134 economies' backing will be needed, and the support of the influential United States and the European Union are deemed indispensable, Wang said.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC SEES RISING ROLE IN HELPING ASIAN NATIONS DEVELOP SMES

TEXT.P: The Republic of China is set to play an increasing role in providing its experience to help Asian countries develop small- and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs), according to a spokesman for the Chinese Taipei delegation to the APEC SMEs conference in Christchurch, New Zealand on Wednesday.
The three-day conference, in which delegates from 20 APEC member economies took part, ended on Wednesday.
Chen Tze told CNA that the ROC delegation, led by Minister without Portfolio Yang Shih-chien, was asked by delegates from Indonesia and Thailand to provide assistance in developing their SMEs.
He said Yang and John Ni, director-general of the Small- and Medium-Sized Business Administration under the Ministry of Economic Affairs, agreed to try their best to help SMEs in the two countries.
"We have no reservations about offering our assistance to Thailand and Indonesia and some other Asian countries in need of our experience in the field of SMEs," Chen said.
The conference ended with a joint statement which recognized the rising role of SMEs in the development of APEC member countries.
"SMEs will be the engine of growth in the knowledge-based economies of the future. By their nature, they are innovative, flexible and opportunity-seeking," the statement said.
Four principal areas were defined by the conference as important for promotion of SME growth:
-- Enhancing management performance through education;
-- Reducing barriers to trade and compliance costs;
-- Improving capital markets and access to them; and
-- Strengthening electronic links to assist businesses within the region.

Also emphasized was the need for educational training, removing non-tariff barriers to trade, and the need for capital access so that SMEs can overcome problems caused by a credit crunch such as the one which occurred in Thailand, triggering the Asian financial crisis in 1997.
In addition, the delegates recognized the importance of the Y2K problem.
They also recognized the critical role that SMEs will play in the economic recovery of the Asian Pacific region.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCKS, FUTURES CONTINUE DECLINE

TEXT.P: Taiwan share prices closed 0.7 percent lower on Wednesday as the index continued to decline after recent steady gains.
The benchmark Taiwan Stock Exchange Weighted Price Index fell below the 7,500-point level, dropping 53.52 points to close at 7,496.
Wednesday saw a total of 3.77 billion shares change hands for a turnover of NT$114.64 billion (US$3.51 billion), down from the previous session's NT$127.40 billion.
Among the eight major stock categories, the paper and pulp sector and plastic and chemical shares registered the only gains of the day, rising 1.8 percent and 0.2 percent, respectively.
Construction stocks suffered the biggest losses, sliding 2.7 percent, followed by cement issues, which fell 1.9 percent. Electronic shares went down 0.9 percent.
The financial sector was down 0.7 percent, while textile stocks posted a 0.4 percent decline. Foodstuff shares remained static.
The over-the-counter market fell by 1.64 points, closing at 172.52 points, for a turnover of NT$4.62 billion.
TAIEX Capitalization Weighted Price Index Futures for May closed 16 points lower at 7,559, with 2,636 contract transactions.

TAIEX Index Futures for June eased 11 points to close at 7,567 points, while those for September fell 19 points, closing at 7,561. Contract transactions for the two months totaled 150 and 5, respectively.
No transactions were registered for December or next March.

Reference levels provided by the Taiwan Mercantile International Exchange for TAIEX Index Futures trading on Wednesday were 7,575 points for May, 7,578 points for June, 7,580 points for September, 7,585 points for December, and 7,684 points for next March.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S WOMEN CARE MORE ABOUT HEALTH THAN LOVE: SURVEY

TEXT.P: Women in Taiwan aged 20 to 30 consider health, rather than love, to be the most important factor in their lives, according to the results of a survey released on Wednesday by Taiwan Cerebos Co.

Taiwan Cerebos, the local branch of the Japanese foodstuff company, sponsored "wish-making activities" islandwide, in which their female consumers were asked to list the issues which most concern them. The results show that 23 percent of the survey respondents care most about their physical condition.
The second and third most common concerns were work and academic study, accounting for 19 and 13 percent, respectively.
Only a few of the respondents gave priority to love or physical appearance.

To make sure the survey results met with current trends, psychologist Sun Ming-ming also conducted a series of random street interviews with local women, the outcome of which was consistent with the survey result.

According to Sun, those who value health are convinced that it is the basis of a happy life, although a happy life must also consist of a good career and economic independence. quitquitquitquitquitquit Noted writer Tsai Shin-ping said the results show that modern women no longer place as much emphasis on love as did their forebears, nor do they see marriage as their most sought-after goal.
Personal development and self-assertion, instead, have become more attractive to today's women in Taiwan, Tsai added.

DOC.HEADLINE: `SOCCER DIPLOMACY' IDEA FOR SPRATLYS GAINING GROUND
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 28 (CNA) (By Amanda Chang) (By Timothy Sun)

TEXT.P: The plan would see soldiers from the various claimant nations garrisoned on the islands competing in a soccer tournament, and mainland China is the latest claimant country to express interest.
Mainland China's ambassador to the Philippines Fu Ying said her country would consider the idea of a tournament between the Philippines, Vietnam, and Malaysia.
Two other claimant nations -- Brunei and the Republic of China -- have yet to manifest their desire to join the tournament.

DOC.HEADLINE: US REAFFIRMS ROC ARMS POLICY DESPITE BEIJING PRESSURE
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, April 27 (CNA) (By Herman Pan and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The US Department of State reaffirmed on Tuesday that its policy on arms sales to Taiwan remains unchanged.

The State Department made the statement after He Yafei, minister-counselor at the mainland Chinese embassy in Washington, D.C., met with Stanley Roth, assistant secretary of state for East Asian and Pacific affairs.
He requested the meeting to express Beijing's strong opposition to US arms sales to Taiwan, just as an annual ROC-US meeting on Taiwan's arms purchase plans opened here on Tuesday.

He told the press before his meeting with Roth that Beijing thinks that US arms sales are gross interference in mainland China's sovereignty, and have impaired its territorial integrity. "Therefore, we strongly ask the US government to strictly abide by its three joint communiques with us, particularly the 1982 joint communique which requires the United States to gradually cut arms sales to Taiwan."

He, who once served as deputy director of the arms control department under mainland China's State Council, said Beijing demands that the United States stop selling advanced weaponry systems to Taiwan, in particular the theater missile defense (TMD) system, as well as all related equipment and technology. He said such sales will adversely affect the development of Beijing-Washington relations.

Shortly after the meeting, the State Department issued a press statement which said US policy on arms sales to Taiwan has long been widely known and that this policy remains unchanged. "We also don't expect any change to this policy in the future," the statement added.

The US Defense News reported in its latest issue that the Clinton administration is leaning toward sales of US$1.7 billion-worth of weapons to Taiwan, including additional Patriot air defense batteries and the AN/BOND phased array early warning radar system. However, the weekly also said some Clinton administration officials oppose sales of those highly advanced defensive weapons for fear of offending Beijing.

According to an article carried in Tuesday's Washington Times, Rep. Benjamin Gilman (R-N.Y.), who is also chairman of the House International Relations Committee, has warned the Clinton administration against leaving Taiwan "vulnerable to the growing (missile) threat" from mainland China.
"I will not accept a decision by the administration to deny early warning radar systems to Taiwan," Gilman said in a letter to Secretary of State Madeleine Albright.

Meanwhile, Rep. Douglas Bereuter (R-Neb.), also chairman of the House Subcommittee on Asia and the Pacific, said in an interview on Tuesday that the United States and Taiwan have always conducted bilateral arms deals quietly as it is appropriate.
"Clearly we have the responsibility through the Taiwan Relations Act, now 20 years old, to provide equipment that will provide Taiwan's defense," Bereuter said.
He went on to say that mainland China's acceleration of missile deployments along its coast opposite Taiwan will certainly cause concerns of Taiwan and the United States.

"So as I've suggested to officials from the PRC and various governments generally that governments have provocative actions are not in their interest to do that," Bereuter said, adding that Taiwan-US discussions on ballistic missile defense are quite a normal reaction to Beijing's military build-up across the Taiwan Strait.

DOC.HEADLINE: NOODLE MERGER MUST ABIDE BY GOVERNMENT RULES: MOEA

TEXT.P: Economic Affairs Minister Wang Chih-kang said on Wednesday that the ROC government will not change its policy on mainland China investment, even after Taiwan enters the World Trade Organization (WTO).

Wang was referring to a highly publicized merger of President Enterprises with the Hong Kong-listed Tingyi Holding Corp., a subsidiary of the Taiwan-based Ting Hsin Co., saying the Investment Commission under his ministry will closely monitor the case once it receives an application to proceed from President.

Local media reported that President, a leading local food-processing company, signed a letter of intent on April 24 with Ting Hsin, the maker of the leading brand of instant noodle in mainland China, to acquire a 33 percent share of its stocks.

The transfer of shares is reportedly worth NT$ 4 billion (US$121.2 million), and has aroused grave concern from ROC lawmakers about whether the deal violates the government's "no haste, be patient" policy regulating Taiwan investment in the mainland.

The regulations require Taiwan businesses to register large-scale mainland investment projects worth US$50 million or more with the government, and each such investment plan is screened by the government on a case-by-case basis.
Fielding questions at an interpellation session at the legislature, Wang assured lawmakers that the Investment Commission will process the case fairly.

Meanwhile, Fu Don-cheng, head of the Department of Economic Affairs under the Mainland Affairs Council, declined to comment on the investment plan, saying only that the government is willing to see Taiwan businesses conduct "normal" investment in the mainland in compliance with government rules.

DOC.HEADLINE: M'LAND BACKLASH ON WTO TRADE-OFFS
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 28 (CNA) (By Flor Wang) (By Stanley Cheung)

TEXT.P: Hong Kong, April 28(CNA): Mainland Chinese Premier Zhu Rongji is being asked to tone down some of the concessions he reportedly made to the United States to secure mainland's entry into the World Trade Organization (WTO), the South China Morning Post reported today.
The report said that a well-connected group is trying to persuade top government leaders, including President Jiang Zemin, to revise the terms for accession into the international trade body.
A Beijing source reportedly said representatives of the textile industry have asked the leadership not to yield to US demands that quotas on Chinese textile exports be extended until 2010.
"The textile lobby is close to Jiang and his aides because Shanghai is the power base for the president as well as the industry," the source was quoted as saying.
According to the report, the Zhu cabinet has also been urged by representatives of the banking and insurance industry not to open that area of the economy too wide, too soon.
Mainland bankers and insurers allege that US and other foreign banks and insurance companies enjoy "political and psychological advantages".
Other WTO opponents have focused on possible threats to "economic sovereignty" and even national security.

Leftists, or quasi-Maoists, have long argued that an influx of foreign capital and goods would aid efforts by "neo-imperialists" to turn the mainland into a capitalist state via "peaceful evolution", the report noted.

Additionally, Zhu faces tough opposition from within the telecommunications sector, where senior cadres including Information Industry Minister Wu Ji-chuan holds reservations about opening up the sensitive sector.
The report said WTO opponents had switched to citing political reasons for blocking multinationals.
They quoted an anti-WTO lobbyist as saying state secrets might be leaked if a foreign company gained control of a major telephone company.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING STEPS UP ATTEMPTS TO SUPPRESS TAIWAN IN WORLD COMMUNITY

TEXT.P: ROC Foreign Minister Jason Hu said on Wednesday that mainland China is very likely to step up attempts to suppress Taiwan in the international community after its premier's recent barnstorming-style trip across the United States and Canada.
Hu made the remarks in his report to the Legislative Yuan Foreign Affairs Committee on the possible adverse impact on Taiwan of mainland Premier Zhu Rongji's recent US-Canada visit.

Hu said the Beijing leadership thinks its relations with the United States and Canada have improved following Zhu's visit. "Against this background, mainland China is likely to intensify its suppression on Taiwan," he noted.
Quoting mainland officials, Hu said mainland China has adopted a new measure against Taiwan.

Under the new measure, Hu said, mainland China will deny visas to foreign nationals whose passports bear ROC visas or records showing they had visited Taiwan. Mainland China would accept their visa applications only when they apply with new passports.

According to Hu, two Europeans were denied visas by mainland officials in Hong Kong. The mainland officials told the Europeans that this is a new measure against Taiwan after Zhu's US visit. They demanded that the Europeans apply for mainland visas with brand new passports.
Hu said some foreign countries have said they will immediately issue their nationals new passports to enable them to apply for mainland visas.

"We hope the recent incident was just an isolated case," Hu said, adding that the Ministry of Foreign Affairs is closely watching the developments of the issue and will work out countermeasures to cope with the new situation.
Meanwhile, Hu said the United States has yet to make a final decision on whether to sell long-range early warning missiles to Taiwan.
Hu said the ROC government will not give up any opportunity to seek US supplies of advanced defensive weapons to help safeguard Taiwan's security.

Noting that the Republic of China needs long-range early warning radars to have an additional five or six minutes of early warning to respond to a possible mainland missile attack, Hu said such equipment is defensive in nature.
"We hope the United States will carefully consider our defense needs and will not just consider mainland China's possible reaction to its arms sales to Taiwan," the minister stressed.

In related news, Hu also said that Macedonian Prime Minister Ljubco Georgievski has decided to postpone his planned visit to Taiwan in consideration of Macedonia's current political and economic situation.
Georgievski was originally scheduled to arrive in Taipei on May 2 for his first visit to the ROC since the two countries forged formal diplomatic ties in January this year.
However, the military confrontation in the Balkans and the influx of a large number of Kosovar refugees into Macedonia have affected political and economic situation in Macedonia.
"We have informed Georgievski that we fully understand his difficulty and will respect his decision on his travel plan. We welcome his visit at his convenience," Hu added.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC TO INCREASE PURCHASES FROM MACEDONIA: FM

TEXT.P: ROC Foreign Affairs Minister Jason Hu said on Wednesday that the nation will increase its purchases from the Republic of Macedonia to help tide the Balkan nation over its present difficulties.
Hu made the remarks during a meeting with Verka Modanu, Macedonia's first resident envoy to the ROC, on Wednesday afternoon at the Ministry of Foreign Affairs.

Modanu said that the flood of refugees fleeing the neighboring Yugoslavian province of Kosovo into her country has had a heavy impact on the nation's economy. She said that Macedonia had originally agreed to take 20,000 refugees, but noted that more than 140,000 refugees have now swarmed across the border, representing about 8 percent of Macedonia's total population.

She said the multitude of refugees has greatly affected Macedonia's stability, and added that Macedonian Prime Minister Ljubco Georgievski announced on Tuesday night that the nation has declared a state of emergency and has closed its common border with Yugoslavia.

Under these circumstances, she said, exports to central and western Europe have all stopped, dealing a devastating blow to the nation's exports of tobacco, textiles, chemical and industrial products, and wine.

She also noted that plant closures have increased the number of the jobless by 30,000 in the past two weeks alone, while official figures put the monthly losses of the nation at US$220 million since Kosovo crisis, a huge loss for the already impoverished country.
Modanu expressed her appreciation for the help offered by the government and people of the ROC.
Modanu, who arrived here on Tuesday night to assume her post, first toured the Taipei suburb of Tienmou, where the Macedonian embassy is located, before calling on Hu.

Hu welcomed her arrival, saying that her mission and goal are the same as the ROC's -- to upgrade bilateral relations to a new level -- and that the ROC will always be on the side of the Macedonian government and people.
Hu said that the ROC will put together joint ventures, emergency assistance for the refugees, and arrange for a visit to Taiwan by Macedonia's Prime Minister.

Modanu, who studied Chinese literature and history at the university of Beijing between 1973 and 1978, speaks fluent mandarin Chinese, and acted as an interpreter when Hu and Vice Foreign Minister David Lee visited Macedonia.

She was director of the Asian Affairs Department under Macdeonia's Foreign Ministry since Macedonia's independence in 1991 before being appointed envoy to Taipei. Before that, she worked for the Yugoslavian government and a state-run trading company.

DOC.HEADLINE: ASUSTECK TO SET MOTHERBOARD FACTORY IN MAINLAND

TEXT.P: Taiwan Asusteck Computer Inc. said on Wednesday that after a long evaluation a motherboard factory will be set up in mainland China.
Asusteck made the statement at a shareholders conference adding that the factory will be in either Shanghai or Guangdong.

Bound by the government's "No haste, be patient" policy, a set of guidelines governing investment in the mainland, Asusteck is allowed to invest 20 percent of its total capitalization, equaling US$200 million, in mainland projects.
Under the guildlines, the investment amount for any single project is not allowed to exceed US$50 million.
Asusteck said it would phase in the capital for the motherboard factory. It is also weighing the possibility of setting up a labor-intensive laser disk factory in the mainland.

Asusteck will be the last Taiwanese motherboard manufacturer to invest in mainland China. Taiwan computer companies have rushed to set up plants on the mainland to take advantage of lower labor cost and vast market. (by Amanda Chang)

DOC.HEADLINE: CZECH PRESIDENT TO ADDRESS CANADIAN PARLIAMENT

TEXT.P: Czech President Vaclav Havel will address a joint session of the Canadian Parliament during his three-day visit to Canada, which begins Wednesday.
The last statesman given that honor was South Africa's Nelson Mandela.

The philosopher-poet turned Czech leader, whose writings and charisma spearheaded the Velvet Revolution that brought democracy to Czechoslovakia and then smoothed the division of the federation into two republics, will likely wax philosophical in his parliamentary address.

Vladimir Kotzy, the Czech ambassador to Canada, said he has seen extracts from the speech. It looks at the relationship between humanity and the state, the balancing of rights and responsibilities and challenges concepts of the individual's place in society, Kotzy noted.
Alain Dudoit, a former Canadian ambassador to the Czech Republic, said Havel's speeches are always deeply meaningful. He is one of the few leaders around who writes his own texts, Dudoit added.
"All his speeches are defining speeches," Dudoit said. The Canadian Broadcasting Corp.'s Newsworld channel will televise the speech live.
The 62-year-old president of the Czech Republic is scheduled to open his visit in Winnipeg by meeting members of the oldest Czech-Canadian association in the country.
He will fly to Ottawa on Thursday for the speech to a joint session of the Commons and Senate.
On Friday, he will sit down for talks with Canadian Prime Minister Jean Chretien.
Havel, head of one of NATO's newest members and fresh from the alliance's 50th anniversary celebrations in Washington last weekend, will discuss the Kosovo conflict with Chretien.
There are a number of other issues on the table, including the Canadian requirement that Czechs obtain a visa before visiting Canada, according to Kotzy.
Canada imposed the visa requirement a year ago to stem a surge of Romas, also known as gypsies, who flocked to Canada seeking refugee status.

The ambassador said, "It's an issue we're not very comfortable with." He said the Czechs have been working with other European countries to ease the plight of the Roma, who complain of bitter discrimination in some Eastern European countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: KOO URGES RESUMPTION OF REGULAR CROSS-STRAIT TALKS

TEXT.P: Taiwan's top negotiator with the mainland, Koo Chen-fu, on Wednesday urged mainland Chinese authorities to resume the cross-strait dialogues.

Koo, chairman of the Strait Exchange Foundation (SEF), made the call while speaking at a tea party commemorating the sixth anniversary of the first meeting between Koo and his mainland counterpart, Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS) Chairman Wang Daohan, on April 29, 1993 in Singapore.
During meeting Koo and Wang signed a joint agreement establishing a mechanism for regular cross-strait dialogues.
The accord marked the end of confrontation between the two sides that began after the 1948 civil war.

Beijing, however, unilaterally suspended scheduled cross-strait talks in the summer of 1995 in protest against ROC President Lee Teng-hui's visit to the United States earlier that same year, sending exchanges between Taiwan and the mainland to a standstill.

Tension in the Taiwan Strait began was able to begin easing after Koo paid a visit to the mainland last October. During the trip, Koo met Wang in Shanghai and reached agreements concerning the resumption of Taiwan-mainland talks, including a visit to Taiwan by Wang this year.
Koo said Wednesday that he hopes cross-strait talks can be resumed as soon as possible, calling them the best means to benefit the people on Taiwan and mainland China.
The SEF and the ARATS are semi-official intermediary bodies established in 1991 to handle cross-strait exchanges in the absence of official links.
All former SEF leaders and incumbent executive officials, as well as officials of the cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council, took part in Wednesday's party.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHEN OFFERS TO PULL OUT OF RACE

TEXT.P: Chen Shui-bian stunned members of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) on Wednesday by asking the party leadership to name former DPP chairman, Hsu Hsin-liang, as the party' candidate in the 2000 presidential election.
Chen, the popular former Taipei City mayor asked the DPP Central Standing Committee not to alter the party's rules concerning the nomination of party candidates for public office.

The rules, which limit party members to stand for election only once every four years, in elections for president, vice president, Taiwan governor or mayorship of the two major municipalities, virtually prohibit Chen from taking part in the 2000 presidential election because of his failed re-election bid in 1998 for the Taipei City mayorship.

In a statement presented to the DPP Central Standing Committee, Chen asked the leadership to urge Hsu to retain his party membership and to name Hsu as the party's standard bearer in the presidential race.
Chen said he is afraid the party will split if Hsu withdraws.
Hsu said last week he is ready to quit the party and run as an independent if DPP authorities either suspend or do away with the four-year rule.

In an interview published in Wednesday's United Evening News, Hsu stopped short of declaring his withdrawal from the DPP but pledged a run, whether as the DPP candidate or as an independent, in the 2000 race in which he will be a serious candidate rather than an also-ran.
The DPP Central Standing Committee, however, refused to accept Chen's offer, claiming that it was a personal statement not a proposal formally presented to the meeting.
Members of the committee persuaded Chen to take back the offer in a closed door debate and were silent on the issue after the meeting.
Chen announced his offer in an ensuring press conference at his personal office Wednesday afternoon and called on the party to unite behind Hsu's candidacy.
His call met a cold reaction from Hsu who voiced doubt whether Chen would really stop seeking the party's nomination.

Contending that his proposed withdrawal from the party has nothing to do with Chen's political ambition, Hsu said he would not compete with Chen for the DPP nomination although he has decided to run for president.
He regretted that Chen has erroneously boiled down the dispute to his contest with Chen for the party's blessing.

Hsu echoed Chen's call to maintain the party's four-year limit, saying that it should not accommodate any individual's ambition. He lamented, however, that Chen made the call only after many party leaders had already given their endorsement to waive the rule.
Chen's sudden turnabout will plunge the party into turmoil which will be difficult to rectify, said Hsu.
The four-year limit is expected to cause heated debate at the DPP Congress on May 8.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC CBC GOVERNOR ARRIVES AT ADB MEETING
DOC.DATELINE: Manila, April 28 (CNA) (By Timothy Sun and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Perng Fai-nan, the Republic Of China's (ROC) Central Bank of China governor, arrived in Manila Wednesday to attend the board of governors meeting of the Asian Development Bank (ADB).

Perng, as the head of the ROC delegation, noted that the Republic of China is a founding member of the ADB, and that the body has unilaterally altered the designation of the ROC to "Taipei, China" without the consent of the ROC.
He stressed that the ROC is not satisfied with the designation and will make every effort to fight for its official name.
The annual meeting will be held in Manila from April 30-May 2. The ADB will hold several seminars, including one on how to avoid a repeat of Asian financial crisis, on Thursday.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN VOTED INTO WSC

TEXT.P: Taiwan took part in the annual World Semiconductor Council (WSC) conference April 23 for the first time as a full member after receiving membership during the conference.
A ten-member delegation lead by Morris Chang, Chairman of the Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturer Company, flew to Fiuggi, Italy to attend the third annual WSC conference.
WSC members account for 95 percent of the semiconductor production worldwide. Taiwan was granted full membership into the semiconductor industry association as part of the agenda.
Besides welcoming Taiwan as a full member, some 100 industry representatives from around the world also approved a white paper on reducing worldwide fluorine emissions.

DOC.HEADLINE: MND NOT SURPRISED BY BEIJING'S BUILDING OF SIMULATED AIRPORT

TEXT.P: The Ministry of National Defense (MND) said on Wednesday that it is not surprised by reports that mainland China has built an airport with bunkers and runways identical to a major airbase in central Taiwan.

Reports said that the airbase, which simulates Taichung's Chingchuankang Airbase, was built next to the Dingxin military airport in China's northwestern Gangsu Province. It is speculated that the mainland will use the simulated airport to train its pilots and missile units to attack Taiwan.
Kung Feng-ting, a MND spokesman, noted that mainland China has never given up its threat to take Taiwan by force, and has always seen Taiwan as a prospective enemy.

Kung said the ministry has kept abreast of such information, adding that in response to possible mainland infiltration and sabotage, the military has reviewed its anti-air weapon deployment and the air base security.
The MND is also seeking to upgrade the quality of its military personnel through various training and drills.
Meanwhile, An official in charge of the mainland affairs said the simulated airport reflects the double-forked strategy of the mainland.

Lin Chong-pin, vice chairman of the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC), said on the one hand, the mainland is trying to woo Taiwan's people through private exchanges, while still pressuring Taipei to return to the negotiating table through military intimidation.
Lin said that Beijing's simulated war against Taiwan targets will not only raise international concern, but will make it easier for Taiwan to purchase defensive weapons more easily.

Shi Hwei-yow, vice chairman and secretary-general of the intermediary body Straits Exchange Foundation, said that Beijing's reported simulation will seriously hurt the feelings of the nations' people toward mainland China.

Shi said the mainland should understand why the number of Taiwan people in support of unification with the mainland has dropped dramatically since the government lifted the ban on visits to the mainland, and why up to 80 percent of the public is in favor of maintaining the status quo between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.

Shi also said that there is a possibility that the mainlanders engaged in spying, photographing, and collecting secret military information to obtain the blueprints for the Taichung airbase while visiting Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies Thursday are as follows:
The Central Daily News:
Taiwan's top negotiator with mainland China Koo Chen-fu called for early resumption of cross-strait consultations.
The China Times:
Former Taipei Mayor Chen Shui-bian said he would not run for the presidency in 2000.
The United Daily News:
Chen Shui-bian urged the opposition Democratic Progressive Party to nominate former DPP Chairman Hsu Hsin-liang as its 2000 presidential candidate.
The Liberty Times:
Chen Shui-bian called on the DPP to choose former party chairman Hsu Hsin-liang as its presidential candidate.
The Commons Daily:
Chen Shui-bian threw support behind Hsu Hsin-liang's presidential bid.
The China Post:
Chen Shui-bian urges DPP nomination of Hsu for president.
The China News:
Chen hints at bowing out of race.

DOC.HEADLINE: BARSHEFSKY CONFIRMS FORTHCOMING MEETING WITH WANG
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, April 28 (CNA) (By Herman Pan and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: US Trade Representative Charlene Barshefsky confirmed on Wednesday that she will meet with Republic of China Economic Affairs Minister Wang Chih-kang in Washington, D.C. early next month.
Barshefsky, who met with the press after attending a lecture, however, declined to answer questions about the accession of Taiwan and mainland China into the World Trade Organization (TWO).
WTO Director General Renato Ruggiero also met with the press at the same occasion. He said he is positive that Taiwan will be admitted soon.
Disclosing that "mainland China will enter the WTO first, and then ensues Taiwan," Ruggiero, nevertheless, ducked further questions about how the process will be arranged.

Economic Affairs Minister Wang is scheduled to visit Washington, D.C. May 5-7 to solicit US support at a time when the WTO is accelerating the screening process for Taiwan and mainland China's accession, according to Board of Foreign Trade Director General Chen Ruey-long, who has just concluded two days of consultation with officials from the US Trade Representative office.

During Wang's stay, he will conduct a closed-door meeting with Barshefsky. He will also meet with US congressmen, including John Rockefeller (D-WV.) and Frank Murkowski (R-Ala.) and deliver a speech to a US enterprise club, according to Chen.

During Wang's second visit to Washington in 15 months, he will drum up US support for Taiwan, and will reiterate Taiwan's stance that Taiwan and the mainland's entry into the WTO should be handled separately and be based on their fundamental economic and trade conditions, Chen said.
Meanwhile, Wang said in Taipei Wednesday that he will not make significant concessions to speed up Taiwan's WTO bid during the Washington trip.
