DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, April 29, or the 14th day of the third month of the Year of the Rabbit according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1661: Cheng Cheng-kung, also known as Koxinga, a national hero and one of the Ming loyalists and resistance fighters against foreign invasion, claims Taiwan from the Dutch and chooses Anping (present-day Tainan) as his capital, in the hope of returning to mainland China one day to restore the Ming dynasty.
1769: Arthur Wellesley, Duke of Wellington, English soldier and later the prime minister known as the Iron Duke, is born. He defeated Napoleon at Waterloo.
1885: Due to the efforts of Emily Davies, the guiding force behind a committee dedicated to securing higher education for women, Oxford University decides to allow women to sit college examinations, but not to award them degrees.
1901: Hirohito, the Japanese emperor who advocated the country's unconditional surrender that ended World War II, is born. He renounced his divine status in 1946.
1903: After Russia refuses to leave Manchuria when the troops of other foreign powers withdraw from Chinese territory, and prior to the outbreak of the Russo-Japanese War, Chinese students studying in Japan meet in Tokyo and set up a resist-the-Russia volunteer corps.
1942: Japanese troops capture the Burmese town of Lashio, cutting off the Burma Road between China and India.
1945: US forces in Germany liberate 32,000 victims of the Nazi concentration camp at Dachau, just northwest of Munich.
1946: Former Japanese leaders are indicted in Tokyo as war criminals.
1957: The first nuclear reactor goes into operation in the United States.
1969: Hsu Peh-yuen, governor of the Central Bank of China, is released from office and succeeded by Yu Kuo-hwa, who is concurrently minister of finance.
1975: The last US troops are evacuated from Saigon as thousands of foreigners and South Vietnamese are ferried out by helicopters from the American embassy there.
1980: Alfred Hitchcock, the British-born film director and the screen's master of suspense, dies in Los Angeles at the age of 80.
1985: The space shuttle Challenger is launched, and Dr. Wang Kan-chuen becomes the first Chinese American astronaut in space.
1992: Bolivian Vice President Luis Ossio Sanjines officiates at the inauguration of the Bolivian Commercial and Financial Representative Office in Taipei.
1992: A jury in California acquits four policemen charged with beating a black driver, setting off three days of riots in Los Angeles which spread to various other places in the United States.
1993: Representatives of the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) and its mainland counterpart, the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait, sign three agreements and a joint accord at a historic meeting in Singapore; the agreements and accord went into effect on May 29.
1994: A Kenyan ferry capsizes near Mombasa, killing 300 passengers.
1996: A male worker guns down 35 tourists near the ruins of an Australian colonial prison in Tasmania.
1996: On the third anniversary of the Koo-Wang talks, SEF Chairman Koo Chen-fu appeals to mainland China not to postpone the second Koo-Wang talks so that both sides can resume their pursuit of reunification.
1998: North Korea publishes an open letter by its leader Kim Jong-Il calling for unification with South Korea.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A workman who wants to perfect his work first sharpens his tools. When you are living in a coutry, you should serve those nobles and ministers in that country who are men of moral worth, and you should cultivate the friendship of the gentlemen of that country who are men of moral worth."

DOC.HEADLINE: US EXPORTS CAN HELP FREE PRC PEOPLE: COX
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 29 (CNA) (By Ben Wu) (By Nelson Chung)

TEXT.P: Washington, April 28 (CNA): American policy toward the People's Republic of China should proceed from a central premise, "It is our sincere hope for the Chinese people that they will no longer live under a Communist government," US Rep. Christopher Cox (R-CA) said in an article published Sunday.

The congressman wrote in the San Jose Mercury News last Sunday that to this end, America's -- and California's -- world leadership in high-tech enterprises promises far more than economic benefits. "The export of these products to the Chinese people can be a great democratizing and liberating force," he said.

In January, the PRC sentenced Lin Hai, a 30-year-old software executive and Web page designer, to prison for supposedly "inciting subversion of state power." His so-called "crime" consisted of exchanging e-mail addresses with an anti-Communist group in America.

Rep. Cox noted that if Lin Hai had been able to keep the contents of his computer messages away from the prying eyes of the Ministry of Public Security -- using strong encryption in commercially available software -- he would be a free man today.
"That is why America's companies, the leaders in encryption technology, must be able to export their products to China and around the world," said the congressman.

He explained that strong encryption is -- as Beijing's Communist leadership is well aware -- "a massive threat to totalitarian regimes and their government-maintained monopoly on information, because it permits individuals to communicate privately without fear of government eavesdropping or interception."

The Californian Republican disagreed with the Clinton administration that the current prohibition on American business exporting encryption software is necessary for US national security, saying the administration "seems to place a higher priority on stopping the export of encryption software to the Chinese people than on preventing the theft of our nuclear weapons technology by the People's Liberation Army."
Rep. Cox claimed that "This is exactly backward. Rather than control commercially available computers, software and technology, we should safeguard our most critical military secrets."

He has chaired for the past nine months a House select committee investigating the transfer of militarily sensitive technology to the PRC. And the committee's classified report found overwhelming evidence that such transfers -- including theft through espionage -- have caused serious harm to US national security, and continue to this day.

Although some have inferred that this would mean clamping down on commercial exports, Rep. Cox pointed out that to the contrary, the committee found that the current export-licensing process, which is riddled with errors and plagued by delays, often does very little to protect US national security, while frequently doing a great deal to damage America's competitiveness in world markets.

The committee has therefore recommended streamlining export rules. The United States should provide a new "fast track" for most items, while focusing greater resources and expertise on the limited targets "that we know from our intelligence are the subject of specific collection efforts by the PRC and others," said Rep. Cox.

He added that encouraging exports to mainland China that promote individual freedom and well-being is in the US national security interest. For this reason, in addition to allowing the export of encryption software, "US policy should focus on unleashing the Internet as an engine of freedom in China."

The recent public attention to espionage raises proper concerns about America's lack of security, "but it should not distract us from our objective of freedom for China's people -- a result that American technology exports can help bring about," noted the congressman.

Rep. Cox stressed that "It's time to focus not on whether to engage -- we should all be agreed on that -- but rather on the terms of engagement. We should have no illusions about with whom we are dealing. We should have no doubt about where our policy is taking us. Freedom -- not engagement and possibly marriage to a Communist dictatorship -- is what our policy toward China should be seeking to achieve."

DOC.HEADLINE: SPRATLY SOCCER DIPLOMACY GAINING GROUND

TEXT.P: The "soccer diplomacy" initiated by Defense Secretary Orlando S. Mercado for soldiers garrisoned on the Spratly Islands to ease tension in the area, is fast gaining ground.
The latest claimant country to express interest to join the proposed soccer tournament is mainland China.
Mainland China's ambassador to the Philippines Fu Ying said her country would consider playing soccer with the Philippines, Vietnam and Malaysia.
She made the statement during her courtesy call on Mercado at the latter's office in Camp Aguinaldo.
Two other claimant nations, Brunei and Taiwan have not yet joined the tournament.
Mercado proposed the holding of a series of soccer matches between Filipino soldiers and Vietnamese troops stationed on the islands during his visit to Hanoi earlier this month.
Vietnam has shown interest in the proposal, Mercado said. Last week, Malaysia, also a claimant country, agreed to join the tournament.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA MOVES TO MAXIMIZE U.N. PEACE PLAN FOR E. TIMOR
DOC.DATELINE: Manila April 28 (CNA) (By Timothy Sun) (By Peter Chen)

TEXT.P: Canberra, April 29 (CNA): Australia is maximizing a U.N. peace plan for the balloting on August 8 to decide the future of the former Portuguese colony of East Timor.

Prime Minister John Howard has returned to Canberra from his Bali summit meeting with President B.J. Habibie, upbeat and optimistic over the Indonesian leader's declaration that Jakarta would on May 5 sign the East Timor agreement brokered by U.N. Secretary General Kofi Annan and reached by foreign ministers of Indonesia and Portugal in New York.
Howard said he was briefed by Habibie that the agreement demands Indonesia disarm the warring factions in East Timor.

Senior Australian officials estimate at least several hundred police and civilians will be needed to ensure security on East Timor, where rampaging militia gangs have killed at least 40 people with unconfirmed figures showing more than 100 dead.

Foreign Minister Alexander Downer said he pushed hard at the summit meeting in Bali for a significant U.N. police force presence from six countries -- Australia, the U.S., Britain, Japan, Germany and the Philippines.

DOC.HEADLINE: CIB TO INVESTIGATE CREATOR OF CHERNOBYL VIRUS

TEXT.P: A Taipei college graduate who is performing compulsory military service has been targeted for investigation for creating the CIH Chernobyl virus, which has reportedly paralyzed computers in Asia and the Middle East, the Criminal Investigation Bureau (CIB) reported Thursday.
The man, identified as Chen Ying-hao, graduated from Taipei's Tatung College of Industrial Technology and is now stationed at a military base in northern Taiwan, according to CIB officials.
Chen created the CIH Chernobyl virus last year when he was still studying at the college.

The virus, which is believed to have first attacked computers in Taiwan in June 1998, can erase data stored on hard drives and make it impossible to restart the computer by damaging the computer's basic startup program, or BIOS.
The virus targets computers running Windows 95 and 98 and has spread mainly over the Internet and through the use of pirated software.

The CIH Chernobyl virus exists in at least three versions. The most destructive one was timed to hit Monday, April 26, the 13th anniversary of the Chernobyl nuclear power plant disaster. Another version is set to strike on the 13th day of June, while the third strikes on the 26th day of each month, according to officials from CIB's Computer Crime Prevention and Control Squad.
It was learned that Tatung College took away Chen's degree after discovering what he has done, though they did not know at the time that the virus could spread so much havoc.
According to Republic of China laws governing information-technology products and applications, Chen could face a jail term of up to three years, CIB officials said.
Foreign wire service reports have said that the CIH Chernobyl virus struck computers mainly in Asia and the Middle East, with South Korea being the country hardest hit.
Although some universities in the eastern United States have reported that some computers had crashed because of the virus, US experts are still assessing the damage.
CIB analysts said some computer hackers create viruses not to wreak havoc but to show off their "extraordinary" skills.

DOC.HEADLINE: ENTRY INTO WTO HAS MORE ADVANTAGES THAN DISADVANTAGES: CEPD HEAD

TEXT.P: Liberalization is a global trend, and Taiwan's entry into the World Trade Organization will provide the island with more advantages than disadvantages, P.K. Chiang, chairman of the Council for Economic Planning and Development, said on Thursday.

In an interview with a radio station, Chiang also said that Taiwan is an export-oriented economy, and its entry into the world trade body will help Taiwan's products to make inroads into the international market.

Chiang said, however, that many other nations are trying to make inroads into the Taiwan market, and this will place pressure on Taiwan's local automobile and agricultural industries. As such increased competition is an inevitable trend, the government will try to help upgrade traditional industries, he said.

He also spoke on the progress of the Asia-Pacific regional operations hub project, saying that both the construction of new facilities and the deregulation of certain industries are central to the project. The government will create a superb environment suitable for investment and marketing by overseas manufacturers, he said.

Chiang said a telecommunications center planned under the project is moving toward total privatization, which means domestic consumers will enjoy the benefits of cheap telecommunications services. As for Taiwan's becoming a financial center, the Executive Yuan has worked out a plan to lift bans on foreign investment in the Taiwan stock market by 2000.
But plans to develop Taiwan into a media center have lagged behind compared with other centers under the project, he said, adding that the problem lies with the slow pace of land rezoning.

He stressed that to achieve the goals set out in the Asia-Pacific regional operations hub center project, the nation needs to improve the efficiency of the legislature and accelerate the pace of deregulation.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PRESIDENT RECEIVES JAPANESE UPPER HOUSE MEMBERS

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui on Thursday received five Japanese Upper House members belonging to the ruling Liberal Democratic Party (LDP).

Lee said that despite the absence of diplomatic relations between the Republic of China and Japan, the two countries should strengthen communications so as to help ensure the stability of the Asia-Pacific region.
The president and the visitors exchanged views on bilateral relations in the fields of trade, economy and culture.
Lee welcomed the visit to Taiwan by the members of parliament, saying that such visits will help promote substantive relations and cooperation between the two countries.
The five LDP Upper House members are Yoshihiko Yamashita, Hiroshi Moriyama, Koichi Kishi, Hiroyuki Morishita and Shigenobu Saito.
ROC officials present at the meeting were Senior Presidential Adviser Ding Mou-shih, Deputy Presidential Secretary-General Lin Bih-jaw and Vice Foreign Minister David Lee.

DOC.HEADLINE: BAD CHECKS AT 15-MONTH HIGH

TEXT.P: The number of checks that bounced in Taiwan in March amounted to 98,159, a 15-month high, the Central Bank of China (CBC) reported on Thursday.
The value of the bounced checks totaled NT$23.88 billion (US$730 million), a three-month high, officials from CBC's Economic Research Department said.
CBC officials attributed the relatively high number and value of bad checks in March to an economic slowdown that protracted from the fourth quarter of last year.

Another reason for the unusually high number and value was that banking data recorded on Feb. 28 were not tabulated until March 1 because Feb. 28 was a national holiday, and the greatest number of check exchanges for all of February occurred on the last day of the month, CBC officials noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO LOSE BILLIONS OF TAX REVENUE IN FIRST YEAR IN WTO
DOC.DATELINE: New York, April 28 (CNA) (By J.J. Huang and Eva Chen)

TEXT.P: In an effort to step up its accession to the World Trade Organization (WTO), Taiwan has decided to cut its import tariffs on 4,500 commodities from a range of 7.55 percent to 8.25 percent to a range of 4.27 percent to 4.98 percent, according to reports of the Journal of Commerce in New York.

Among the 4,500 commodities, 3,400 items are industrial products, while the rest are agricultural. An estimate made by the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) of the Republic of China showed that Taiwan will lose NT$22.4 billion in the first year of its participation in the WTO, said the report.

The paper cited Vice Chairman Lin Shiang-nung of the Council of Agriculture (COA) under the ROC's Executive Yuan as saying that Taiwan's agricultural sector will lose NT$34 billion in the first year after Taiwan's entry into the WTO.

Losses totaling NT$54 billion will likely be incurred by farmers of beef, chicken, grapes and oranges in the sixth year after Taiwan's WTO entry, added Lin. To reduce the impact, the COA will allocate NT$21 billion for subsidies, the vice chairman explained.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRETORIA-BEIJING TIES ARE A BIG MISTAKE: SA SCHOLAR
DOC.DATELINE: Johannesburg, April 28 (CNA) (By Chang Jer-shong and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Pretoria's decision to switch official ties from Taipei to Beijing has proved a costly mistake, wrote Professor Themba Sono of the University of Pretoria's Graduate School of Management in an article that appeared recently in the South African newspaper The Star.
Asking "where's the Peking duck?" Sono said the promise of economic prosperity as a result of relations with Beijing has yet to be realized.

On the contrary, hopes for a boon to South Africa's economy have been dashed, as mainland Chinese exports to South Africa are harming the country's economy, said Sono, who is also president of the South African Institute of Race Relations.

Trade imbalances are increasingly in Beijing's favor, the scholar said, and he cited statistics indicating that in 1998 -- the year in which South Africa established relations with Beijing -- South Africa's exports to mainland China amounted to less than 1 billion rand (US$164.75 million), whereas imports from mainland China totaled more than 4 billion rand.
Including trade with Hong Kong into the calculations makes the disparity even worse, he said, warning that the gap is set to widen further this year.

Moreover, vast numbers of unemployed mainland Chinese people have emigrated to South Africa to make a new start. As a result, South Africa's Chinese community has grown from 30,000 or 40,000 two years ago to more than 120,000 today.

"Many Chinese find their way into SA (South Africa) illegally via our neighboring cities of Mbabane, Maseru and Maputo," he wrote. In addition there has also been increases in illegal smuggling and in the number of Chinese gang members in the country, he said.

On the other hand, Taiwan businesses in South Africa once numbered 620, and together they employed 45,000 local people. The figure has since dropped to 33,000, Sono said. He also pointed out that in 1997, South Africa's imports from Taiwan totaled 760 million rand, while exports to the island reached more than 1 billion rand.

DOC.HEADLINE: EARLY WARNING SURVEILLANCE CRITICAL TO TAIWAN'S DEFENSE: REPORT (I)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's geographic features have made early warning surveillance for cueing purposes essential to the defense of Taiwan against communist China, according to a US Department of Defense report.

The non-confidential Pentagon report, which was sent to Congress on Wednesday, analyzes the architecture requirements for a theater ballistic missile defense (TBMD) system in the Asia-Pacific region to protect key regional allies and friends of the United States.

The Pentagon carried out the study in accordance with Section 1533 of the National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 1999. The confidential part of the report was already sent to Congress in February.

The 13-page non-confidential report mainly addresses missile defense options for Japan, South Korea and Taiwan separately based on the unique political and military threat environment confronting each one.

Three pages of the report were devoted to Taiwan-related issues. Five architecture options were developed and examined for the defense of Taiwan based on the unique political and military threat environment facing the island.

The report pointed out that the key geographic feature dominating the architecture requirements and options for the defense of Taiwan against mainland China is the short 175 km sea barrier between Taiwan and the mainland.

"Shorter range missiles could fly over that barrier and remain inside the atmosphere for the entire trajectory," the report said, adding that with the size of mainland China, an attack could come from multiple directions.

Moreover, the report said, mainland China possesses theater ballistic missiles with longer ranges. "These features make early warning surveillance for cueing purposes essential for an effective missile defense," it noted.
The report presented five active theater missile defense force structure options for the defense of Taiwan.
According to the Pentagon assessment, lower tier land- and sea-based architectures could adequately defend most of Taiwan's critical assets.
However, the report said, neither architecture can provide any defense against longer range theater ballistic missiles (TBMs.)

To address the full range of threats, the report explored three land- and sea-based upper tier options. One land-based upper tier fire unit, with an additional Theater High Altitude Area Defense (THAAD)-like radar, would be able to cover the entire island of Taiwan.

"This system could intercept incoming missiles both inside the atmosphere (endo-atmosphere) and outside the atmosphere (exo-atmosphere)," the report said, adding that this architecture is referred to as an endo-exo option.
The report went on to say that either sea-based upper tier exo system could cover all of Taiwan, adding that only one ship position is required for either sea-based exo-upper tier system.
The fifth option examined in the Pentagon report is the fast exo upper tier system, which the report said could also provide shoot-look-shoot coverage for portions of Taiwan.

The report explained that the development of Taiwan missile defense architecture options were based on short and medium range ballistic missile threats which are expected to increase significantly over the next several years.

"Both of these missile types have apogees outside the atmosphere. The medium range missile also has a re-entry speed likely to preclude a high probability of intercept by lower tier systems," the report said. (To be continued)

DOC.HEADLINE: EARLY WARNING SURVEILLANCE (II)
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, April 28 (CNA) (By Nelson Chung, Jay Chen and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The Pentagon said the architecture options analyzed for Taiwan, Japan and South Korea in no way suggest or imply a region-wide architecture network.

"The report does not advocate or recommend deployment of any specific TMD architecture," the Pentagon said, adding that the report is neither aimed at discussing issues related to the TBMD development and production nor at discussing requirements for any TBMD technology transfer.
The report only provides a general review of TBMD architecture options probably to be available in the early years of the 21st century.

The Pentagon said it involves many complicated problems to develop TBMD defense for Taiwan, Japan and South Korea. A comprehensive, in-depth analysis is needed before a definite conclusion can be reached, the Pentagon stressed.
It also said if the two sides of the Taiwan Strait imporve their relations, mainland China's missile threats to Taiwan may be reduced.

According to the report, the architectures utilize representative TBMD systems now under development, including Patriot PAC-3, Navy Area Defense, Theater High Altitude Area Defense (THAAD) and Navy Theater Wide (NTW) similar to the Block I and Block II systems.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN AT ODDS WITH US ON MINOR WTO ENTRY ISSUE
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, April 29 (CNA) (By Herman Pan and Amanda Chang)

TEXT.P: Republic of China Foreign Trade Director-General Chen Ruey-long on Wednesday completed talks with the office of the US Trade Representative on Taiwan's upcoming negotiations with the World Trade Organization's (WTO) Multilateral Working Group, although no conclusion was reached on the issue of motorcycle imports, sources reported on Wednesday.

According to Chen, there are 185 paragraphs in Taiwan's WTO Working Group report, and he exchanged viewpoints with the United States regarding measures related to the government procurement and government subsidies.

During the talks, the US Trade Office accused Taiwan of having overly harsh regulations on exhaust standards for motorcycles with engines larger than 150 cubic centimeters, saying Taiwan's regulations are tougher than the strictest US regulations.

The US Trade office went a step further by urging Taiwan's Environmental Protection Bureau to conduct exhaust inspections on US-made Harley-Davidson motorcycles. The office said that as long as the motorcycles pass Taiwan's exhaust standards, the United States will not insist that Taiwan revise its environmental protection regulations.
But Chen said that Taiwan must have high standards since motorcycles are the main form of transportation on the island.
Taiwan will continue to talk with the United States to search for a solution, Chen said.

DOC.HEADLINE: HSU SAYS NO TO REPRESENTING DPP IN PRESIDENTIAL ELECTION

TEXT.P: Presidential hopeful Hsu Hsin-liang, a former chairman of opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), told the press Thursday that he will definitely not seek to represent the DPP in Taiwan's 2000 presidential election.

Hsu said he loves the DPP, but he loves Taiwan even more. He said he has always taken Taiwan's interests as a whole into consideration, and then weighed what position the DPP and he himself should take, instead of taking only the DPP's interests as a base to weigh what national policy and his personal position should be.

Former Taipei Mayor Chen Shui-bian told a news conference Wednesday that he would consider pulling out of the presidential race -- although he has not yet announced his candidacy -- if that was the only way to prevent Hsu from quitting the party. Chen also appealed at a meeting of DPP's Central Committee to leave the controversial "four-year clause" unchanged in the party charter.
According to the clause, the former Taipei mayor will be barred from running for president under the party banner until four years after stepping down as mayor.
Chen even recommended Hsu be given the nomination, he said in a statement at a news conference Wednesday.

In response to Chen's statement, Hsu noted that if what Chen said Wednesday was only for the sake of preventing Hsu's departure from the party, then Chen can safely seek to represent the DPP in the election, adding that he would not contest Chen within the DPP.
Hsu once said he definitely plans a run on his own, regardless of whether or not Chen runs.

DOC.HEADLINE: WORKERS TO HOLD STRIKE ON LABOR DAY TO PROTEST AGAINST UNEMPLOYMENT

TEXT.P: Labor workers will hold an islandwide march Saturday -- Labor Day -- to protest against Taiwan's serious unemployment problem.
In previous years protests were held in Taipei and Kaohsiung only.

News of the planned protest was announced by the preparatory committee of a nationwide labor union during a "New Taiwanese' Nightmare -- May 1 Anti-Unemployment March" press conference in front of the Legislative Yuan on Thursday.
The committee will coordinate rallies by 15,000 workers in 11 cities and counties around the island to protest what they perceive as government inaction over Taiwan's unemployment problem.
The committee said that during the economic depression, the government addressed only the difficulties faced by businesses and not those affecting workers, such as unemployment.
They added that the present policy of privatizing state enterprises is only adding to the workers' burden, and has caused 30,000 people to lose their jobs.

Among the demands of the committee were an unemployment insurance law, a policy of offering laborers the same aid funds that are available to business enterprises, an expansion of workers' participation in pension and insurance funds and a revision of the current policy of privatizing state enterprises.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERIOR MINISTRY TO GIVE CLASSES TO FOREIGN BRIDES

TEXT.P: Foreign brides married to Taiwan men will be asked to attend classes by the Republic of China government aimed at helping them get accustomed to their lives in Taiwan, the Interior Ministry said on Thursday.

The Interior Ministry said that starting late this year, foreign brides, with the exception of those from mainland China, will be required to take part in the classes before being granted permanent residency in Taiwan.

M.C. Liu, head of the Population Administration Department under the Interior Ministry, said the classes will be patterned after those currently being given by Meinung authorities in the southern township in Kaohsiung County to foreign brides living there.
The classes, which will be fully implemented late this year or early next year, are designed to help foreign brides overcome language and cultural differences while living in Taiwan, he added.
Quoting statistics compiled by the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, Liu said the number of applications by foreign spouses wishing to reside in Taiwan has amounted to more than 50,000.

Most of the foreign brides in Taiwan are from Southeast Asian countries, with those from Vietnam -- totaling more than 20,000 -- being the largest group, Liu said. Vietnam was followed in order by the Philippines, Indonesia, Thailand and Myanmar, he said.

An investigation by the Taiwan Provincial Family Planning Research Institute showed that foreign brides tend to have difficulty getting accustomed to their lives in Taiwan because of language and cultural barriers, and they usually have more children than local women do.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCKS, FUTURES DECLINE

TEXT.P: Taiwan share prices dropped 2.8 percent Thursday as a sell-off by foreign investors in the previous session prompted investors to bail out.

The benchmark Taiwan Stock Exchange Weighted Price Index plunged 206.99 points to close at 7,289.62 points, with a turnover of NT$111.31 billion (US$3.41 billion), down from the previous session's NT$114.64 billion.

Among the eight major stock categories, the paper and pulp sector posted the only gains of the day, rising 0.8 percent. Electronics shares, which were most favored by foreign investors, suffered the largest loss, falling 4.2 percent.
Construction issues slipped 3.1 percent. Foodstuff stocks and plastic and chemical shares both dropped 2.2 percent, and financial shares went down 2.1 percent.
Cement shares posted a 1.6-percent decline, and textile shares suffered a slight loss of 0.3 percent.
Decliners led advancers 372 to 84, with 39 stocks unchanged.
TAIEX Capitalization Weighted Price Index Futures (TAIEX Index Futures) for May plummeted 178 points to close at 7,381 points, with 5,961 contract transactions.
TAIEX Index Futures for June dropped 151 points to close at 7,416, with 255 contract transactions. September futures were down 138 points, closing at 7,430 points, with 13 contract transactions.

December futures slid 110 points to close at 7,456 points, while those for next March suffered a 113-point drop, closing at 7,555 points. Contract transactions for the two months totaled 3 and 5, respectively.

Reference levels provided by the Taiwan Mercantile International Exchange for TAIEX Index Futures trading on Thursday were 7,559 points for May, 7,567 points for June, 7,568 points for September, 7,566 points for December and 7,668 points for next March.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN MINISTER HU LEAVES FOR MARSHALL ISLANDS

TEXT.P: ROC Foreign Minister Jason Hu left for the Marshall Islands for a four-day official visit.

Hu was heading a 93-member delegation of parliamentarians, govenrment officials, business executives, agricultural and fishery experts, philanthropic groups representatives and journalists on the visit.
Hu said prior to his departure that this is the first high-level ROC delegation to visit the Marshall Islands since the two countries established formal diplomatic ties last November.
"I hope the visit will help us better understand the North Pacific island nation and contribute to bilateral exchanges and cooperation," Hu added.
During his visit, Hu and his mission will attend a ceremony marking the 20th anniversary of the establishment of the Marshall Islands constitutional autonomous government on May 1.

Hu will also meet with Marshall Islands President Imata Kabua, Foreign Minister Phillip Muller and other senior officials to exchange views on matters of mutual concern, including feasible ways to promote bilateral cooperation in various fields.

On May 1, Hu will sign agreements with relevant Marshall Islands officials on the promotion and protection of investment in each other's countries as well as on the exemption of double taxation on investors.
In addition, Hu will attend a ground-breaking ceremony for construction of an airport apron to be donated by the ROC to help the Marshall Islands boost its tourist industry.
On behalf of the ROC government, Hu will also donate three garbage trucks and 40 large dustbins to help improve the Marshall Islands' sanitary facilities.
Meanwhile, Hu will attend an earth-breaking ceremony for constructing the ROC's embassy in the Marshall Islands.
Foreign Ministry officials said the Marshall Islands is rich in agricultural, fishery and tourist resources and welcomes Taiwan investment.

The delegation left for the Marshall Islands via a chartered Far East Air Transport plane at 6 p.m. and will make a stopover in Guam for refueling. The delegation is scheduled to return to Taipei at 6:30 a.m. May 2.

DOC.HEADLINE: ADVOCATORS OF "REPUBLIC OF TAIWAN" KEEP TRUE TO THEIR IDEALS

TEXT.P: The preparatory committee for the "Republic of Taiwan" will continue to advocate their concept of an independent Taiwan and the ultimate building of a new Taiwan republic, said the committee's chairman after returning from Japan on a visit to promote Taiwan's independence, sources reported Thursday.
Members of the committee flew to Japan on April 21, and during their stay there submitted a declaration on Taiwan's sovereignty to the China division of Japan's Foreign Ministry.

The declaration, endorsed by 120 people, including Taiwan legislators, National Assemblymen and Christian religious leaders, said that in the San Francisco pact, which was signed in 1951 after Japan was defeated in World War II, there was nothing to indicate that Taiwan and the Pescadores should be subjected to any nation.
Therefore, the declaration said, in accordance with the United Nations charter, Taiwan residents should have the right to call for the establishment of an independent nation.

The committee on Thursday said they planned to write to Japan's Legislative Bureau under the office of the prime minister in hopes of persuading Japan to honor the pact by respecting the rights of Taiwan residents. They further hope to clarify what they said is a misconception regarding Taiwan's sovereignty.

The committee went on to say it also will establish a temporary national assembly for the "Republic of Taiwan," create a temporary constitution and ultimately organize a government to seek entry into the United Nations.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S CBC GOVERNOR MEETS WITH ADB GOVERNOR IN MANILA
DOC.DATELINE: Manila, April 29 (CNA) (By Sun Tin-wu and Victor Lai)

TEXT.P: Perng Fai-nan, governor of Taiwan's Central Bank of China (CBC), met with Asian Development Bank (ADB) Governor Tadao Chino in Manila on Thursday to exchange views on matters of mutual concern.
Chino praised Taiwan's economic development as a model for Asia, and expressed his hope that Taiwan will continue to support the ADB.

During their talks, Perng reiterated Taipei's position of seeking to again participate in the organization under the name "the Republic of China." Its name was changed, without Taipei's consent, to "Taipei, China" when mainland China entered the bank in 1986.
Chino said that he fully understood Taipei's position.
Perng asked the ADB to increase the employment of Taiwan staffers from the current five people to seven people commensurate with Taiwan's financial share in the bank. Chino agreed to Perng's request.
The CBC governor was in Manila at the head of a Taiwan mission to an annual ADB congress that will open on Friday.

DOC.HEADLINE: US DOLLAR GAINS IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The US dollar climbed slightly against the New Taiwan dollar on Taiwan's foreign exchange market on Thursday, closing at 32.689, or NT$0.08 higher than on the previous day.
A total of US$373.5 million changed hands.
The greenback opened at NT$32.685 and was traded between 32.677 and 32.725 in the session.

DOC.HEADLINE: VP WISHES WORKERS HAPPY LABOR DAY

TEXT.P: Vice President Lien Chan on Thursday wished a happy Labor Day to Taiwan workers, and hailed them as the driving force behind Taiwan's progress.
Attributing Taiwan's development to the hard work and efforts of the island's vast number of workers, Lien encouraged them to continue learning at work in order to pursue greater achievements.
"I see Taiwan's future in everyone here," the vice president said.
Lien made the remarks prior to celebrations marking Labor Day, May 1, during a visit to a precision machinery company at the Shenken Industrial Zone in suburban Taipei.

Lien also reiterated that the government is paying heed to workers' safety in their workplace, pointing out that the Council of Labor Affairs will designate this year as a "work safety year," which is a reflection of the government's intention to build a safer working environment for all workers islandwide.
In a separate development in the afternoon, Lien said Taiwan's flexible small business sector has played a key role in the island's industrial upgrading.

Stressing that Taiwan will stick to its economic opening policy, Lien told Michael Porter, a professor at Harvard University currently visiting Taiwan, that the ROC government is determined to develop Taiwan into a high-tech island.
For his part, Porter highly praised Taiwan's performance amid the Asian financial crisis, and encouraged Taiwan to pursue greater economic globalization.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP EX-CHAIRMAN RULES OUT SEEKING PARTY NOMINATION

TEXT.P: Former Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) chairman Hsu Hsin-liang said on Thursday that he would not seek the party's nomination in the 2000 presidential election.

In a riposte to a challenge from arch intra-party rival Chen Shui-bian on Wednesday, the former DPP party head solemnly declared at a press conference that he will not compete with Chen for the chance to stand for the DPP in the election.

He urged Chen to declare his candidacy immediately and said he would not stand in Chen's way. If Chen does not declare his intentions, the DPP should seek out another presidential hopeful to stand for the party, he said.
But Hsu stopped short of announcing his departure from the party he helped to found.

Chen, a former Taipei mayor, is widely believed to be the party's best hope of winning the next presidential election, although he is barred from seeking the DPP's nomination for president under current party rules.

Chen lost a re-election bid for Taipei mayor last December, and DPP rules prohibit someone who has run for certain elected positions -- those of president, vice president, governor of Taiwan Province, and mayor of Taipei or Kaohsiung -- from running for any of those posts again for four years.

Although Chen did not publicly declare his intention to take part in the party's primary, he has made his intentions clear by going on a whistle-stop tour around the island and abroad to seek political support.
To help Chen secure the party's nomination, many DPP leaders have called for the so-called "four-year clause" to be waived.

Their advocacy of Chen's nomination offended Hsu and led to his announcement that he intended to quit the DPP and run as an independent. He will reportedly announce his final decision before a DPP party congress on May 8.

The reports that Hsu will withdraw from the party have brought Chen under fire from Hsu's supporters. In a surprise preemptory movement aimed to turn the tables on Hsu, Chen urged the party on Wednesday to retain its "four-year clause," and he voiced support for Hsu's candidacy.
While stopping short of saying he would not seek the party's nomination, Chen said in a statement that the DPP cannot afford a split within the party in the run-up to the election.

His announcement put pressure on Hsu and plunged the party into chaos. Many party leaders who had been trying desperately to dissuade Hsu from quitting the party are now scrambling to urge Chen to withdraw his call to keep the four-year clause.

In an attempt to dispel perceptions that his announcement on Wednesday was made with tongue in cheek, Chen reiterated on Thursday his sincerity in calling for the DPP to name Hsu as its presidential candidate.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLAND CHINA'S WTO ENTRY WILL HELP TAIWAN: ECONOMICS MINISTER

TEXT.P: Mainland China's expected admission to the World Trade Organization (WTO) this year will help reduce pressure on Taiwan in its bid to join the world trade regulatory body, Economic Affairs Minister Wang Chih-kang said on Thursday.

As to the question of whether Taiwan will be able to join the WTO by the end of this year as well, Wang said it is a complex issue that also depends on when the WTO's next two working party meetings will be held.
The WTO's 10th multilateral working party meeting is slated to be held in Geneva from May 10-12, while the date of the 11th meeting remains undecided, he noted.
Wang will depart for the United States on Monday to seek US support for Taiwan's membership in the WTO.

While there, the economic affairs minister will visit US Trade Representative Charlene Barshefsky and call on local think tanks to exchange opinions on issues related to Taiwan's admission to the Geneva-based international organization.
Vice Economic Affairs Minister Lin Yi-fu will accompany Wang on the US tour, and Lin will proceed to Geneva on Thursday to attend the WTO's 10th multilateral meeting there.

DOC.HEADLINE: SINGAPORE'S DEPUTY PM NAMED 'CENTRAL BANKER OF THE YEAR'

TEXT.P: Deputy Prime Minister of Singapore Lee Hsien Loong has been named Asiamoney's "Central Banker of the Year" for 1999.
Explaining the honor given to Lee, the Monetary Authority of Singapore's chairman, Asiamoney editor Will Goodhart, told The Strait Times:

"At a time when other countries were moving in the opposite direction, the MAS (Monetary Authority of Singapore) has taken steps to open up Singapore's financial services sector and has embarked on an impressive reform program that will enhance its status as an Asian financial center. The impetus that BG Lee has provided to that program earns him the award in a year that saw strong competition from other Asian central bankers."

Thailand's Tarrin Nimmanahaeminda is this year's "Finance Minister of the Year," while Lee Hun Jai, commissioner of South Korea's Financial Supervisory Commission, was named the region's best restructuring agency chief -- in an award newly introduced by the magazine.

In an article on Lee's award, Asiamoney added: "He is not a central banker by training, nor does he concern himself with day-do-day management of monetary policy in Singapore, but his position atop the city state's monetary authority and his actions as that body's chairman more than qualify Lee Hsien Loong for the Central Banker of the Year award."

DOC.HEADLINE: SINGAPORE NETWORK TIES-UP WITH US ON HIGH-SPEED DATA NETWORK

TEXT.P: A Singapore research and development network has become the first in Asia to tie-up with the United States' University Corp. for Advanced Internet Development (UCAID), which coordinates a very high-speed telecommunications and data communications network that connects 150 US research universities, according to The Business Times.
The Singapore Advanced Research and Education Network (SingAREN) will collaborate with UCAID on next-generation Internet-based technologies and applications.
A memorandum of understanding was signed Wednesday via a video-conference between SingAREN and UCAID in Washington, D.C.
UCAID's network, called the Abilene net, operates at speeds of up to 2.4 gigabits per second, 85,000 times faster than today's standard modem.

The tie-up lets SingAREN connect to the Abilene net, collaborate on developing common standards across both networks, offer pre-commercial testing of high-band-width products and encourage technology transfers between the two bodies.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP'S POLICY-MAKING BODY TO HOLD CRISIS MEETING SATURDAY

TEXT.P: Amid serious internal disputes, the Democratic Progressive Party will convene a crisis meeting Saturday of its Central Standing Committee, said the party's chairman.

Chairman Lin Yi-hsiung asked former Chairman Hsu Hsin-liang not to drop out of the party for the sake of party solidarity. Hsu revealed his plans to withdraw from the DPP during an announcement Thursday that he would not seek to represent the party in next year's presidential election.

Hsu said last week that he is ready to quit the party and run as an independent in the election. The move triggered disputes in the largest opposition party of Taiwan, with most party members backing charismatic former Taipei Mayor Chen Shui-bian as the party's presidential candidate
Lin urged Hsu to stay within the party to combat the ruling Kuomintang.

Lin said that Hsu has led the opposition party for at least four years, or one-third of the 13 years since the DPP's founding. He said he hopes Hsu will continue to adhere to the idea that only a unified opposition party can fight against the KMT.

Incumbent leaders of local governments from the DPP, former DPP chairmen and members of the policy-making Central Standing Committee will all attend Saturday's meeting in hopes of settling the crisis that has arisen over the question of whether Hsu or Chen will be the party's presidential candidate.
Chen announced Wednesday that he does not intend to run in the 2000 presidential election, and asked the DPP to name Hsu as the party's candidate.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHUNGHWA TELECOM PRIVATIZATION PLAN APPROVED

TEXT.P: A plan to privatize state-run Chunghwa Telecom Co. Ltd. by auctioning it off on the stock market was approved by the Legislative Yuan on Thursday amid fierce protests by company employees.

The controversial plan was shepherded through the floor of the legislature by legislators of the ruling Kuomintang (KMT), which consider the privatization of the company a vital part of its efforts to deregulate the telecom market and prepare the island for World Trade Organization membership.

The KMT legislators supported the plan after tacking on a five-point resolution that requires the Ministry of Transportation and Communications to raise the target selling price of the company's share from the proposed NT$40 to NT$60, and to look after the interests of the employees.
They first vetoed a motion by opposition parties to postpone the bill, then rammed it, as well as the five-point resolution, through the floor in a vote largely on party lines.

Outside the Legislative Yuan, some 5,000 Chunghwa Telecom employees protested the privatization plan, which they said would result in the company's shares being sold at too low a price and in their interests being harmed.
They clashed with riot police, and several were held briefly, though they were later released.

Minister of Transportation and Communications Lin Fong-cheng said the protesters' claims were groundless and welcomed the passage of the plan, saying it will speed up the liberalization of Taiwan's telecom market and result in more efficient and cheaper telecom services for consumers.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies Friday are as follows:
The Central Daily News:
Early warning surveillance for signalling purposes is essential to the defense of Taiwan against mainland China.
The China Times:
The foot-and-mouth disease reappear in pig ranches in many parts of the island; disease control authorities heighten alert.
The United Daily News:
Ordinary members of the public will be given access to government files under a new law.
The Liberty Times:
Former DPP Chairman Hsu Hsin-liang said he will not seek the main opposition Democratic Progressive Party's nomination to run in the next presidential election.
The Commons Daily:
The DPP will continue protest over parliamentary violence.
The China Post:
Hsu says he won't seek DPP presidential nomination.
The China News:
Hsu says no to DPP candidacy.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, April 30, or the 15th day of the third month of the Year of the Rabbit according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1777: Karl Friedrich Gauss, the German mathematician and astronomer known for his contributions to algebra, differential geometry, probability theory and number theory, is born in Germany.
1789: George Washington is inaugurated as the first president of the United States in a ceremony at Federal Hall in New York.
1803: The United States buys Louisiana Territory and New Orleans from the French.
1900: The republic of Hawaii cedes itself to the United States.
1919: The Paris Peace Conference allows Japan to take over Germany's prewar rights in Shantung Province, whereupon China leaves the conference.
1945: Adolf Hitler, the German dictator known as "Der Fuhrer" who reduced his country and much of Europe to ashes, commits suicide with his wife Eva Braun after bidding farewell to the few aides remaining with him in his Berlin bunker hideaway.
1946: The national government of the Republic of China issues an order moving the national capital back to Nanking from Chungking.
1948: A total of 21 American nations sign the "Charter of Bogota," setting up the Organization of American States (OAS).
1957: Egypt reopens the Suez Canal to traffic.
1967: Muhammad Ali, who first won the world heavyweight boxing crown as Cassius Clay in 1964, is stripped of his title for refusing to be drafted into the US armed forces.
1968: President Chiang Kai-shek approves a set of "Guidelines for the Lives of Citizens" drafted by the National Committee of Chinese Cultural Renaissance Movement.
1973: US President Richard Nixon accepts responsibility for the bugging that took place at the Watergate apartment complex in 1972.
1975: The Vietnam War ends with South Vietnam's surrender to the communists after North Vietnamese tanks capture the Presidential Office in Saigon.
1977: Public and private buses begin joint operations in Taipei City.
1988: A South Korean college student is arrested after hurling three home-made bombs into the headquarters of President Roh Tae-Woo's governing party in Seoul.
1989: Finance Minister Shirley Kuo leads an ROC delegation to the 22nd annual Asian Development Bank meeting in Beijing.
1990: Elected Republic of China officials of all levels are permitted to make private visits to mainland China during recesses. Veterans who were stranded on the mainland after the nationalist government moved to Taiwan in 1949 are allowed to apply for resettlement in Taiwan.
1991: Cyclone hits Bangladesh, killing more than 125,000 people.
1991: ROC President Lee Teng-hui declares the termination of the Period of National Mobilization for Suppression of the Communist Rebellion, effective on May 1. He abolishes the Temporary Provisions and promulgates the Additional Articles of the Constitution, also effective on May 1.
1997: Trains collide at Rongchiawan station in Yuehyang City, Hunan Province in mainland China, killing 58 people and injuring hundreds of others.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "If a man takes no thought for the morrow, he will be sorry before today is out."

DOC.HEADLINE: US STATE DEPARTMENT MUM ON ARMS TALKS WITH TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The US State Department refused Thursday to confirm news reports that the United States has agreed to sell to Taiwan early warning radar systems.
State Department spokesman James Rubin said that an agreement between Taiwan and the United States on the matter prohibits public discussion of the results of arms sales consultations.

When asked about reports of the sale of long-range radar systems to Taiwan, Rubin told a routine press briefing that in accordance with the Taiwan Relations Act, the US president and Congress determine which defense articles and services Taiwan needs to maintain a sufficient self-defense capability.
Under the act, there are periodic consultations that include Taiwan military representatives, he said.
"We have had a frank and broad exchange of views on issues related to Taiwan's self-defense needs, but both sides have agreed not to discuss the details of this process," he said.

When asked to confirm that there have been consultations with Taiwan in the last two days, Rubin said there have been consultations but refused to discuss the results, adding that his understanding is that the Taiwan delegation is still in Washington.

The Clinton administration has reportedly changed its mind about rejecting Taiwan's request to buy early warning radar systems after Rep. Benjamin Gilman (R-N.Y.), chairman of the House International Relations Committee, intervened in the matter.

DOC.HEADLINE: FBI DIRECTOR CONFIRMS SECURITY BREACHES: US SENATOR

TEXT.P: FBI Director Louis J. Freeh has confirmed that espionage activities at US national weapons laboratories represent "a deep penetration by the Chinese," according to Sen. Richard Shelby, chairman of the Senate Committee on Intelligence.
Shelby said that although it is not known how deep or wide the penetration has been at this point, it is nevertheless significant.

The senator said the committee will push legislation he introduced in the Senate to put a moratorium on visits to weapons laboratories by foreign nationals this year. He said it is likely other forms of legislation will be drafted that deal with other aspects of the alleged espionage.

Although Energy Secretary Bill Richardson is not presently interested in suspending the visitation program, Shelby said, "I told him that we weren't trying to stop it, we wanted to slow it down and evaluate it, because I think national security at our labs has to be of paramount interest to the United States."

The alleged espionage activities represent an ongoing threat to US national security and require swift and decisive action, he said, adding that this is why he introduced legislation on Wednesday that would "suspend all visits to American nuclear research laboratories by scientists from sensitive countries," including mainland China, according to a statement.
"Sensitive countries," according to Shelby, are those considered dangerous to the United States and those determined to be interested in acquiring American nuclear weapons secrets.

He told reporters after a closed committee hearing that Freeh gave his committee a comprehensive update on the status of the ongoing investigation of espionage at US national labs, specifically Los Alamos, and said that as the investigation is unfolding, it is confirming some of their worst fears in regard to what information mainland China has had access to.

The Senate Committee on Intelligence has basically finished its investigation report on the alleged mainland Chinese espionage and they hope to release it in the next week or 10 days, added the Alabama Republican.
Freeh has been unwilling to discuss possible arrests since the investigation has not been concluded, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGNERS TO RUN KEY MAINLAND PROJECTS: REPORT

TEXT.P: Foreign overseers will be invited to participate in all of mainland China's key construction projects in an effort to curb rampant corruption, The Hong Kong Standard reported Friday.

Engineering, auditing, accounting, surveying and other financing consulting services will be imported as a means of strengthening supervision over major infrastructure projects and to check widespread corruption, the report quoted mainland sources as saying.
Foreign professionals will also be asked to take responsibility for the oversight of these key national projects, an official from the State Development Planning Commission reportedly said.

Premier Zhu Rongji, on a visit to the Three Gorges dam site in December, called for an upgraded engineering system. Official media quoted him as saying that if necessary top international engineering companies would be contracted to inspect the projects.
Zhu called for a check of all major infrastructure projects early this year following the January collapse of a bridge in the southwestern region of the country that killed 40 people.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC TO CONTINUE TO PROTEST ADB NAME CHANGE

TEXT.P: Taipei will again voice at an annual board meeting of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) its objections to the bank's decision in 1986 to change the designation of the Republic of China within the organization, sources from the Central Bank of China (CBC) said on Friday.
CBC Governor Perng Fai-nan led an ROC delegation to Manila to attend the annual meeting, which opened Friday.
The ADB changed the ROC's designation from the Republic of China to "Taipei, China" after mainland China was admitted to the body in March 1986.
Perng will lodge the ROC's protest against the name change while making a report on Taiwan's current economic and financial situation, said CBC officials.
A founding member of the organization, the Republic of China boycotted the bank's board meetings in 1986 and 1987 in protest over the name change.
In April 1988, then CBC Governor Chang Chi-cheng led an ROC delegation to the ADB meeting, held in Manila, under protest.

In May 1990, when the ADB's annual meeting was held in Beijing, then Finance Minister Shirley Kuo led the ROC's delegation to the meeting, also under protest. Kuo's attendance at the ADB meeting set a precedent in regard to ROC officials attending international meetings in Beijing.

The Republic of China's stake in the ADB currently stands at 1.25 percent, which puts it 13th among the organization's 55 members. The ADB was founded in 1966 to bolster economic and social development in developing countries in the Asia-Pacific region.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOST EXPENSIVE COST OF BANK ROBBERIES IS TRAUMA

TEXT.P: Traumatized employees -- not stolen cash -- are the most expensive impact of bank robberies in Canada, a security expert said Thursday.
Gene McLean, security director for the Canadian Bankers Association, said robbers take about C$4 million in an average of 1,300 robberies per year.
"It's not an issue of money," the retired policeman told a crime forum in Vancouver. "There is very little money taken from bank robberies as a rule."
Trauma is more expensive, McLean said, adding that is "the key cost of bank robbery -- the trauma to employees, the time off they take, the counseling required, the loss of work."
There were 1,365 bank robberies in Canada last year, up from 1,309 in 1997. Of the total, 193 were in Vancouver, while Toronto had 308 and Montreal had 319.
Banks have installed time locks on safes, advanced cameras and central cash dispensers that limit the available cash at the counter.
Most robbers are caught in Canada. A Toronto consultant said the average national rate runs as high as 90 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA TO SIGN A$1 BILLION WOOL CONTRACT WITH CHINA

TEXT.P: Australia is expected to sign a new A$1 billion (US$637 million) wool contract soon with mainland China after four years of tortuous negotiations, government trade officials said.
They said the contract is designed to curb the commercial anarchy that has regularly plagued the wool trade between Australia and mainland China.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA ANNOUNCES SLIGHT RISE IN IMMIGRATION INTAKE

TEXT.P: The Australian government has announced a slight increase in its immigration intake for fiscal 1999-2000, resulting in demands for an even bigger quota from Victoria Premier Jeff Kennett and the business sector.

Immigration Minister Philip Ruddock on Thursday night announced that the government would allow 70,000 migrants -- including those in the business and skilled, and family reunion categories -- to come to Australia in the next fiscal year. This figure excludes the steady quota of 12,000 refugees admitted yearly on a humanitarian basis.
In fiscal 1998-99, which ends on June 30 this year, Australia is expected to have attracted up to 68,000 migrants from Taiwan, mainland China, Hong Kong, Southeast Asia and other areas.

DOC.HEADLINE: HIGH-TECH IS TAIWAN'S EDGE, SAYS US GURU

TEXT.P: Taiwan's competitiveness lies in its high technology, and only through high-tech development can Taiwan create profits, said an American management guru here on Friday.
Michael E. Porter, a Harvard University professor, said that seeking profits and growth through high-tech industries is the only feasible way for Taiwan to upgrade its international competitiveness.
Porter made the remarks during a summit meeting with Taiwan's top entrepreneurs on competitiveness strategies.

Porter, who arrived in Taipei on Thursday at the invitation of German company SAP and Commonwealth magazine, said he agrees with the Taiwan government's "no haste, be patient" policy toward mainland China.

He said Taiwan will not sharpen its competitive edge by increasing investments or stepping up business activities in mainland China, whose market is "less cutting-edge and less sophisticated" than Taiwan's.
He reiterated Friday a viewpoint on Taiwan's competitiveness that he spelled out during a lecture made on Thursday.

Taiwan has to make good on its uniqueness -- by producing scientific and technological innovations -- if it intends to maintain its competitiveness, said Porter, who has written 15 books and more than 50 papers on economic development and management strategy.

Porter said Taiwan does not stand much of a chance of becoming an Asia-Pacific business operational center in the face of competition from Singapore and Hong Kong, but Taiwan has one of the highest "innovation indexes" of all developing countries, and holds promise as an "innovation center" in the Asia-Pacific region.

Taiwan has remained largely unscathed by the Asian economic crisis that has ravaged neighboring countries, indicating that most of the development policies and strategies followed in past years were correct, Porter pointed out.

But to remove impediments that threaten to diminish Taiwan's competitiveness, Taiwan should accelerate reforms that have not been completed, including the streamlining of its financial systems and cutting down on government red tape, he added.

Porter offered Taiwan four suggestions to turn its innovation strengths into real assets: maintain a high standard of investment in research and development (R & D), make the government more transparent, further improve intellectual property protection and shift R & D work from government-financed agencies to private sectors and educational institutions.
Porter, whose insights, articles and books have helped shape a new generation of corporate thinking, left Taipei Friday at around noon, after attending the summit meeting.
On Thursday, Porter met with Vice President Lian Chan, Premier Vicent Siew and other high-ranking officials in charge of business and trade affairs.

Porter, who was instrumental in helping map out Taiwan's economic policies during the years when Vice President Lien Chan was then premier, may be invited to be an adviser to the Executive Yuan, according to sources from the Cabinet.

DOC.HEADLINE: TIMOR LEADER THREATENS ATTACK ON UN PERSONNEL

TEXT.P: Eurico Guterres, a leading pro-Indonesian leader in East Timor, has warned that the safety of foreigners could not be guaranteed if they were sent to the territory under a UN-supervised peace plan.
He said his militiamen might attack UN personnel if they support the cause of pro-independence Timorese.

Under the UN-supervised peace plan, Australia will send at least 50 percent of the total number of police and civilians and medical workers to East Timor with the rest coming from the United States, Germany, Britain, Japan and the Philippines.
Prime Minister John Howard, in response to Guterres' remarks, said his government would not back away from supporting the UN peace plan.
