DOC.HEADLINE: MACEDONIAN PM'S TAIPEI VISIT POSTPONED
DOC.DATELINE: Bonn, April 30 (CNA) (By Lillian Lin and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: A planned visit to Taiwan by Macedonian Prime Minister Ljubco Georgievski will be indefinitely postponed as the prime minister is tied up by aggravating refugee problems at home, sources from the Macedonian capital of Skopje said on Friday.

Georgievski was previously scheduled to leave for Taipei on May 1 for an official visit to the Republic of China, which established formal diplomatic relations with the Republic of Macedonia on Jan. 27 this year.
However, since early this week, fresh waves of refugees from Kosovo have continued to flood into Macedonia, which borders the Yugoslavian province to its north.

So far, nearly 190,000 Kosovar refugees have fled the country to Macedonia, causing an increasing crisis upon the former Yugoslavian state, which is hard pressed to provide accommodation for the refugees.
The resultant threat of social instability has prompted the question of whether the nation should declare a state of emergency.

Skopje has also made an emergency appeal to members of the European Union for assistance to help it handle the escalating refugee problem. Most of the EU countries which have committed to accept the refugees have been reluctant to take concrete measures to implement this commitment, the sources said.
Meanwhile, Skopje also called for EU members to offer economic aid to Macedonia in order to help the Balkan state maintain stability.

Since the Yugoslavian crisis erupted in early March, Taipei has offered Macedonia some US$5 million in cash donations, medical equipment, food, clothing and other daily necessities to help alleviate the suffering of the ethnic Albanian refugees from Kosovo.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL TERRORIST SAID RECRUITING AUSTRALIAN MUSLIMS FOR JIHAD

TEXT.P: International terrorist Osama bin Laden, wanted for ordering bombings against US embassies in Kenya and Tanzania last August, is recruiting Muslims in Melbourne to join a jihad, or holy war, in Kosovo and Chechnya, Australian police reported on Friday.

They said Interpol in Australia has been asked to investigate Hamoud Abaid Al Anezi, who entered Australia last month on a Saudi Arabian passport. Al Anezi and four other men have been charged over an aggravated burglary at a home in Melbourne on April 19.
Al Anezi was carrying a Yemeni passport in another name at the time of his arrest, while the other four men were Iraqi nationals granted protective refugee status in Australia.
Two of the aggravated burglary victims -- Muslims living in Australia -- told police they were bashed with wooden clubs over their refusal to be recruited by Al Anezi as terrorists.
One of the Muslims alleged that Al Anezi had traveled to Australia for the purpose of recruiting other Muslims to join Bin Laden in a jihad in Kosovo and Chechnya.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC ENVOY BLASTS BEIJING OVER ARMS ISSUE
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, April 29 (CNA) (By Jay Chen and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: ROC Representative to the United States Stephen Chen criticized mainland China on Thursday for its unceasing vociferous opposition to Taiwan's acquisition of defensive weapons and related military equipment.

Chen said mainland China itself possesses many offensive weapons, but it has consistently opposed Taiwan's purchase of any defensive arms. "This is like somebody who has a sharp sword opposing its foe's purchase of a shield by claiming that the shield is of an offensive nature," Chen said, adding that this is most unreasonable logic.

The de facto ROC ambassador to the United States made the remarks in response to a protest by the mainland Chinese embassy in Washington, D.C. over the opening of an annual ROC-US meeting on Taiwan's arms purchase plans.
Chen said mainland China would protest even if the United States were to sell matches to Taiwan.

Asked about the April 27-28 ROC-US arms sales meeting, Chen said the two countries have held regular consultations on Taiwan's defense needs. "However, the two sides are required not to divulge any details about such discussions, including the participants, venue, agenda and any specific military item," he explained.

Touching on a recent Pentagon report to the US Congress on theater missile defense (TMD) architecture options in the Asia Pacific region, Chen said the report will help the US legislative branch, the media and the general public to better understand the importance of peace and stability in the Taiwan Strait.

Chen went on to say that the ROC government appreciates the US executive branch and Congress' sustained security commitment to Taiwan under the Taiwan Relations Act, the US law governing relations with the ROC in the absence of formal diplomatic ties.

In related news that same day, Chen said at a seminar that he believes historians will record that China has finally evolved into a liberal democratic country because of the existence of a free and democratic Taiwan.
Chen also said he is convinced that China will eventually unify under the principles of freedom, democracy and equitable distribution of wealth.

The career diplomat pointed out that per capita national income on both sides of the Taiwan Strait was only US$50 five decades ago. "But today, Taiwan's per capita GNP is far higher than mainland China's. That is mainly because Taiwan has adopted the right economic development strategy," Chen noted.
In addition to its economic prosperity, Chen said, Taiwan has also made significant progress in democratic and human rights reforms.
He recalled that he often received letters from Americans criticizing Taiwan's human rights records about 10 years ago when he was the ROC's deputy representative to the United States.

"The number of such letters has declined significantly since I assumed my current post in October 1997," Chen said. "Moreover, most of these letters no longer address human rights concerns but are aimed at appealing for better treatment of stray dogs on the island," Chen said.
Chen said the ROC does not oppose engagement between other countries and mainland China. "We just hope that they do not develop ties with the mainland at the expense of Taiwan," he added.

The seminar was sponsored by the Third World Affairs Association on Capitol Hill. In addition to Chen, envoys to the United States from the Philippines, Iceland, Grenada, and many other countries attended the seminar.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCKS, FUTURES RISE

TEXT.P: Taiwan share prices rose 1.1 percent on Friday, as late bargain hunting erased early losses, and while the local bourse ended low for the week, the market still rallied for the third consecutive month.
The benchmark Taiwan Stock Exchange Weighted Price Index regained the 7,300-point level, climbing 81.55 points to close at 7,371.17.
A total of 2.90 billion shares changed hands on a turnover of NT$102.85 billion (US$3.15 billion), down from the previous session's NT$111.31 billion.
Among the eight major stock categories, cement stocks posted the largest gains of the day, rising 2.1 percent, followed by financial shares, which went up 1.4 percent.
The construction sector posted 1.1 percent growth, and plastic and chemical shares advanced 1 percent. Textile issues and electronics stocks both gained 0.7 percent.
Paper and pulp shares closed 0.5 percent higher, while the foodstuff sector remained static.
The over-the-counter market climbed 2.23 points to close at 170.76, with a turnover of NT$4.19 billion.
TAIEX Capitalization Weighted Price Index Futures (TAIEX Index Futures) for May gained 59 points to close at 7,440, with 4,727 contract transactions.

TAIEX Index Futures for June rose 44 points to close at 7,460, while those for September increased 56 points, closing at 7,486. Contract transactions for the two months totaled 225 and 12, respectively.
December futures surged 96 points to close at 7,486, with three contract transactions. No transactions were recorded for next March.

Reference levels provided by the Taiwan Mercantile International Exchange for TAIEX Index Futures trading on Friday were 7,381 points for May, 7,416 points for June, 7,430 points for September, 7,388 points for December, and 7,490 points for next March.

DOC.HEADLINE: COA URGED TO HELP TAIWAN FISHERMEN IN MAURITIUS

TEXT.P: An increasing number of fishery-related incidents involving Taiwan fishermen in Mauritius has prompted calls for the government to station officials in the Indian Ocean island nation to help Taiwan fishermen who run into difficulties there.

The Kaohsiung-based Taiwan High-Seas Tuna Fishing Association on Thursday urged the Council of Agriculture (COA) to station officials in Mauritius in order to help Taiwan fishermen who encounter legal disputes and accidents there.
Port Luis, capital of the island country, is an important stronghold and a major supply base for Taiwan fishing vessels operating in the West Indian Ocean.

Taiwan does not have diplomatic relations with Mauritius, but the two countries maintain fishery cooperation links. Fishing boats from Taiwan make more than 360 visits to Port Luis every year, and the number continues to rise, the association said.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP CHAIRMAN CALLS FOR UNITED PARTY TO WIN PRESIDENTIAL ELECTION

TEXT.P: Chairman of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Lin Yi-hsiung on Friday again urged former DPP Chairman Hsu Hsin-liang to stay in the party so that a united DPP can fight against a "split ruling Kuomintang" and win the presidential election in 2000.

Faced with Hsu's imminent defection, Lin will convene an emergency meeting on Saturday which will be attended by members of the DPP Central Committee and faction leaders, as well as county and mayoral heads affiliated with the DPP, including former Taipei Mayor Chen Shui-bian, who is widely viewed as the party's most likely presidential candidate.

Lin said the problem facing the DPP is not the quitting of a member, nor is it someone's reluctance to make a presidential bid. Rather it is an issue of whether party members have the sincere resolve to end the disunity within the party, he stressed.
The DPP chairman also called on the public not to view the Chen-Hsu issue of recent days as political machinations or brinkmanship.

Chen made a plea on Wednesday that efforts to amend the party's nomination rules to accommodate his candidacy be halted, and pledged to urge delegates to next month's party congress to nominate Hsu as the DPP's presidential candidate.

Saturday's emergency meeting will focus on the defusing of Hsu's defection crisis. However, according to informed sources, Hsu's leaving is almost certain, which means the DPP must start to think about how to cope with the resulting impact.
However, party officials observed that since there are more than ten months left before the election, the DPP should have enough time to control the problem.
DPP lawmaker Chang Chun-hung, who is also the convener of the party's New Century faction, urged the party to postpone its May 8-9 National Party Congress to allow more time to settle the infighting.

In response to Chang's proposal, Lin said that the party congress should not be postponed. As to whether the controversial "four-year clause" will be amended, Lin said this should be left to the decision of the party congress.

According to the "four-year clause" in the party's nomination rules, members are barred from seeking presidential, legislative or mayoral candidacies twice within four years, which would effectively eliminate Chen from the running.

DOC.HEADLINE: COA CHIEF OUTLINES MAJOR DRAWBACKS IN FMD CONTROL OPERATIONS

TEXT.P: Taiwan's top agricultural administrator said on Friday that five major drawbacks exist in the island's pig epidemic control system.

Peng Tso-kwei, chairman of the Council of Agriculture (COA) made the statement after a string of foot-and-mouth disease (FMD) cases were reported at pig farms in major agricultural counties in the past half a month.
Peng said at a meeting of livestock disease control officials around the island that sporadic FMD cases have been reported since the island was hit by the deadly pig epidemic two years ago.
"This is mainly because the FMD virus has widely spread throughout the island," Peng said, adding that Taiwan is unlikely to resume a non-FMD-stricken area any time soon.
The scholar-turned-administrator said it took France 42 years to reclaim the International Livestock Disease Conference's recognition as a non-FMD-stricken area.
"Germany and the Netherlands also spent several decades and Argentina even spent 137 years eradicating the FMD virus," Peng noted.
Nevertheless, Peng said these examples should not be used as an excuse for lax FMD control operations. "We should redouble efforts to curb further spread of the pig epidemic," he stressed.

Peng said he feels regret that many FMD cases have been reported in recent months. He outlined five major faults in the local FMD control operations. The drawbacks include slow reports on the detection of the epidemic; low FMD inoculation rate; pig farmers' failure to establish an adequate self-defense system to prevent the disease; a lack of sense of responsibility on the part of pig farmers as well as their speculative mentality.
According to an estimate by scholars and experts, FMD vaccination rate must exceed 80 percent if an FMD-stricken area wants to effectively control the epidemic.
In Taiwan, the current inoculation rate falls below 70 percent.

Peng said the COA will join forces with local-level livestock disease control authorities to work out measures to encourage pig farmers to have all of their pigs vaccinated in accordance with government regulations.
Peng said the COA will tighten enforcement of disciplinary rules to punish pig farmers who fail to have their pigs inoculated according to government regulations.
"We'll make an all-out effort to raise the vaccination rate to 80 percent in three months," Peng said.
As the effect of vaccination is not 100 percent, Peng said pig farmers should establish their own anti-FMD system to protect their animals from being infected by the deadly virus.
Peng also demanded local livestock disease control offices to intensify inspection of pig ranches under their jurisdiction.

Speaking on the same occasion, Lai Hsiu-sui, a National Taiwan University professor, suggested that the COA offer free vaccines to help enhance vaccination rate. Lai said free vaccination will cost the government only NT$500 million to NT$600 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP LEGISLATORS CLASH WITH MP IN FRONT OF PRESIDENTIAL OFFICE

TEXT.P: A group of opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) legislators clashed with Military Police (MP) officers in front of the Presidential Office on Friday.
The lawmakers had gone to the Presidential Office to ask President Lee Teng-hui to resolve an alleged assault by Kuomintang lawmaker Tseng Chen-nung during a Legislative Yuan session last week.
The session was suspended for a week due to the alleged physical conflict between Tseng and DPP lawmaker Lai Ching-lin.

A group of nearly 60 DPP lawmakers marched towards the Presidential Office on Friday morning carrying banners and chanting slogans to protest against what they called the ruling KMT's "indulgence of violence."
The lawmakers were stopped by the MPs, and a short scuffle ensued.
DPP lawmaker Payen Talu tore off the nametag of an MP surnamed Chou, and later claimed to the press he was hit on the chest during the struggle.
The lawmakers' demand to meet the president was ignored, and the protest fizzled out amid some more slogan-chanting. The lawmakers said they will return next Tuesday to try to see Lee.

The group's convener Chang Chun-hsiung said that as Tseng's alleged violence stemmed from his defense of the Executive Yuan's budget bill, Lee, as the KMT chairman, should come forward to resolve the conflict.
Chang added that as Tseng is also a KMT lawmaker, Lee should shoulder even more of the responsibility. He also expressed regret over Payen Talu's altercation with the MPs.
